DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese representative in Taipei resigns
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 17:24:38 (By Garfi Lee, Sinyao Shih and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Japan's top representative to Taiwan has submitted his resignation, citing personal reasons, the Asahi Shimbun reported Tuesday.

The surprise move of Masaki Saito, chief of the Taipei office of the Japan Interchange Association (JIA) -- Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan -- was widely speculated as a result of the implications caused by controversial remarks he made in Taiwan in May, the Japanese daily said.

Saito said on May 1 at an annual meeting of the Republic of China International Relations Association held in National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi county that "Taiwan's status was still unclear."

Commenting on the Asahi Shimbun report, Naohiro Tsutsumi, Saito's deputy and director-general of the JIA Taipei Office, said the resignation will take effect only after the JIA board of directors approves it.
Tsutsumi, however, declined to comment on whether and how Saito's resignation will affect Japan-Taiwan relations.

According to a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, Saito has been sulkily quiet over the past several months and has seldom interacted with Taiwanese officials in charge of relations with Japan.

The official said Saito did not have a chance to accompany a group of visiting Japanese dietmen during their recent meetings to see President Ma Ying-jeou because the Japanese politicians asked not to have such arrangements made.

Meanwhile, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lee Hung-chun, who heads a legislative subgroup on Japan-Taiwan friendship, said in Hokkaido, Japan Tuesday that Saito has offered his apology over his remarks, but the Ma administration has adopted a strong stance on the matter.
Lee suggested that Taipei adopt a softer attitude when dealing with foreign countries and their officials.
"It's crucial that Taiwan makes more friends than turn friends into enemies," he noted.

Also commenting on Saito's resignation, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Huang-liang claimed that Saito offered to resign because of pressure from the Kuomintang administration.

Tsai speculated that Saito's resignation -- announced Friday, on the same day that Taiwan opens a liaison office in Sapporo, Hokkaido -- was intentionally designed as a means to protest against Taiwan over the Saito incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait currency settlement system to be completed soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 17:31:44 (By Erin Ho, Garfie Li and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese banker said Tuesday that preparations for a currency clearance and settlement system between Taiwan and China are now 80 to 90 percent complete.
"An agreement on the system will be concluded before the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed," said Hu Xiaolian, vice governor of the People's Bank of China.
The ECFA issue is expected to be broached during the fourth round of talks between Taiwan and China later this month in Taichung City.

Hu, who arrived in Taipei Monday for a cross-Taiwan Strait financial seminar, told reporters after the opening of the forum that preparations for the currency system have been in progress for quite some time.

Noting that currency clearance services would be provided by commercial banks of both sides of the strait, Hu said the preparations include matters such as the transport of currency, the opening of accounts in the participating banks, and the compilation of statistics.

The system would allow for the conversion of Taiwan and China currency in banks on both sides, which will lower the cost of currency conversion and reduce the circulation of counterfeit banknotes, thereby encouraging Chinese tourists to spend more in Taiwan, Hu said.

Meanwhile Chiang Pin-kung, Taiwan's top negotiator with China, said at the seminar that during the fifth round of cross-strait negotiations, Taiwan and China will conclude an agreement to allow bank ventures in each other's market.

He said that when he and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin meet in Taiching later this month, they will put the issue on the agenda for the next round of talks that is expected to be held in China in the first half of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes it easier for overseas Chinese to visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 18:11:42 (By Lin Shen-chu, Elizabeth Hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has eased restrictions on visits by overseas Chinese people, making it easier for Chinese nationals who live in foreign countries or in Hong Kong or Macau to visit the island, National Immigration Agency (NIA) officials said Tuesday.
Starting Tuesday, Chinese people can come to Taiwan for sightseeing as long as they have lived in a foreign country or in Hong Kong and Macau for at least one year, the officials said.

Previous regulations required them to have lived overseas for at least four years. Overseas Chinese must still have a job in the countries and areas where they live, or be the spouse or lineal relative of such overseas Chinese, to apply for a tourist permit to visit Taiwan.
Taiwan only began opening the doors for tourist visits by Chinese people who live overseas, in Hong Kong or Macau, in 2002.

Chinese people who meet the requirements can apply to visit Taiwan for tourism by providing their employment certificates, proofs of family relationship, identification cards, application forms, travel plans and itineraries.
The applications can be filed with the agency either by travel agents or by the applicants themselves, the official added.

In light of the increased demand for urgent entry permits by Chinese people wishing to come to Taiwan, the immigration agency has set up a mechanism to streamline the processing of travel documents of Chinese tourists on a case-by- case basis in order to increase efficiency, the official said.

Under the revisions, travel agencies who put down a NT$1 million (US$31,250) security deposit with the Travel Agent Association of ROC Taiwan for arranging tours for overseas Chinese to visit Taiwan will not be charged NT$100,000 for each inbound-Chinese tourist who goes missing because there have been no case of overstaying or absconding reported since Taiwan opened its doors to overseas Chinese tourists in 2002, according to the official.
However, a fine will still be imposed for inbound Chinese tourists from Hong Kong, Macau or China who overstay their visas or go missing, according to the official.

It has become common for Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan since the two sides first launched direct flights in 2008. The number of visitors from China has been on the rise, since direct flights and flight destinations were expanded in July this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma orders establishment of task force to help revive pro baseball
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 18:55:42 (By Pao-hsian Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou gave a directive Tuesday for the establishment a Cabinet- level task force, headed by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, to help revive professional baseball in Taiwan.
The president also gave instructions for 2010 to be designated as
the first year of baseball revival in Taiwan, according to Chao Shou-po, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL).
Ma gave the directives during first-ever national conference on baseball, which was held to discuss ways of reviving and upgrading the sport that has been plagued by game-fixing scandals.
During the conference, Chao said, the president stressed that it is impossible to solve during a two-hour meeting problems that have accumulated over the past decade.
He told the attendees that it is important "to eliminate the sickness" and at the same time "revitalize the liveliness" of the sport.

Ma said the relevant government agencies should make greater efforts to communicate and coordinate among themselves to help tackle the problems pertaining to irregularities in the professional baseball league.
An overall review should be conducted and proposals such as tax-free incentives for professional baseball clubs and their sponsors should be studied, the president said.

Premier Wu Den-yih said at the meeting that it is the government's responsibility to provide a "clean" environment for professional baseball to flourish, and he suggested that there should be at least one baseball stadium in every city and county around the country.
The conference was convened after some 800 baseball fans took to the streets of Taipei Sunday demanding that the government do something to rescue the sport in Taiwan.
"President Ma has heard the voices of the demonstrators and he exhorted the CPBL teams to 'hang in there' and not to give up despite the recent spate of problems," Chao said.

Fans of professional baseball clubs that were disbanded because of game fixing joined the rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to demand that the government act quickly to fix the problems that they said had led to frequent cases of game fixing.

Responding to the protesters' demands, the president invited scholars, officials of various government agencies, representatives of the professional baseball clubs and representatives of the demonstrators to attend the national baseball conference.
"The executives of all the CPBL clubs are encouraged by the government's move to revive the sport and to make it a matter of national importance," Chao added.

The clubs' executives suggested during the meeting that the government give more teeth to the efforts to crack down on the crime rings that orchestrated the game-fixing in the professional baseball league.

DOC.HEADLINE: January manpower demand expected to increase by 48,000: labor council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:02:09 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With the global economy recovering, Taiwan's manpower demand by the end of January next year is expected to increase by 48,000, compare to the end of October this year, according to the results of a survey published Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The results of the fourth manpower survey of the year, conducted Oct. 16VNov. 5 and with 3,025 valid samples returned, show that 21.3 percent of the companies that responded said they will hire more personnel in January 2010, representing an increase of about 65,200 workers.
Meanwhile, about 8 percent of the companies surveyed will reduce their manpower, representing a reduction of about 17,300 workers. That would result in a net increase of 48,000 workers.
It will be the highest net increase of manpower for a single season since the survey was launched in Q3 2007, CLA officials said.
Around 65 percent of the companies will keep their manpower unchanged in January, the survey results show.

The survey results also show that the manpower demand was gradually warming up and there seems to be a trend towards more job hirings, said Cheng Wen-yuan, director of the council's statistics department.

The manufacturing, retail and support service sectors will see the most noticeable increase in manpower needs. The highest number of job increase -- some 19,500 -- will come in the manufacturing sector, according to the survey results.
Chen said that the electronics components, computer and optical products sectors are expected to benefit most from the recovery in demand and the rising demand will generate more hiring needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade policy not priority for Obama administration: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:11:51 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: American scholars attending a Taipei-Washington video conference Tuesday suggested that the U.S. administration has prioritized global issues, such as nuclear proliferation and energy policy, and that trade policy is not at the top of its agenda.

The Office of Trade Negotiations in Taipei invited four American scholars to assess the impact of U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to Asia in mid-November and to hold dialogue with Vice Economics Minister Francis Kuo-sin Liang and other trade officials.

The moderator, Sherman Elliott Katz,who is a senior advisor at the Washington- based think tank Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress, raised the issues of U.S. trade policy, U.S. reaction towards probable China domination of the Asian market, leverage in the situation where the U.S. is a debtor and China is the creditor, China's currency, and the reduction of tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Commenting on President Obama's statement in Tokyo on Nov. 14 that the U.S. welcomes China's greater role in the world, Larry A. Niksch, a specialist in Asian Affairs with the Congressional Research Service, said that he does not think China's growth and expansion of influence would jeopardize Washington- Beijing relations.
The U.S. would not react to trade problems with protective measures, he added.

Referring to the question of whether China's position as the largest foreign creditor of the U.S. had influenced Obama's approach during his visit to China, the expert in U.S. security policy said that he did not see Obama pushing China on currency issues or China's subsidies to national industries.
Furthermore, the situation in which China is the largest foreigner holder of U.S. debt "would give China the ability to hurt the U.S. financially and economically in the longer term," he suggested.
Josh Kurlantzik, Council on Foreign Relations fellow for Southeast Asia, said that Obama's decision not to meet the Dalai Lama had "overstated the weakness of his hand."
However, Grant Aldonas, under secretary of international trade in George W. Bush administration's Commerce Department (2001-2005), held a different view of the leverage issue.

He suggested that while President Obama, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Director of the White House's National Economic Council Lawrence Summers might think that as the largest foreign creditor of the U.S., China has leverage, "the debtor has relatively the same leverage as the creditor."

Commenting on the statement by some Taiwanese scholars that the Obama administration has prioritized global issues and is less concerned about China's relationship with Taiwan, Niksch said that "the Obama administration, like the Bush administration, is pleased to see the opening of cross-strait policies by President Ma Ying-jeou and the reduction of tensions."

Niksch suggested that the improvement in cross-strait relations has overshadowed cross-strait defense issues, but added that he believes the U.S. will continue to make selective military sales to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act.
As to the possibility of a political agreement on unification, Niksch said that "the U.S. policy is changing to accept that -- as long as it is not a decision made under coercion from China."
He also emphasized the U.S. position that any major political move in Taiwan should be decided by the Taiwanese people, maybe through referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:21:31 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday: Apple Daily:
Prize-winning film sheds light on bureaucratic detachment

Taiwan's civil servants should be required to see Leon Dai's prize-winning film "No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti" and report on what they saw as the movie portrays how bureaucratic detachment could force ordinary citizens to the brink of death.
The indie film swept the Golden Horse Film Festival last weekend by bagging the coveted best picture and best director awards.

It was based on the true story of a ship repair worker's desperate fight for his daughter's right to education. The girl was born out of wedlock and her birth was not legally registered with any local household registration agency. As a result, she could not enter any elementary school.

The protagonist approached government agencies at various levels but none of them would extend him a helping hand. He ultimately tried to commit suicide but fortunately, the attempt was thwarted by police.

The black and white film reflects a common mind-set of Taiwan's civil servants who tend to be passive in dealing with their work and try to avoid mistakes rather than seek innovation or reform and also highlights another practice commonly seen in Taiwan's officialdom -- passing the buck, as the protagonist is sent from one agency to another.

The film further reminds us that we still have a long way to go to build Taiwan into a mature democracy as the democratic ideals of "government of people, by people and for people" has not yet taken root in our officials' minds. Economic Daily News
Will 'China myth' shatter like Dubai World?

The financial crisis faced by government-owned conglomerate Dubai World in the United Arab Emirates should serve as a reminder to China's leaders that extravagant development projects can collapse overnight.

Unlike Dubai -- a small desert emirate whose prosperity is a myth built largely on loans raised by its government -- China has what it takes to be an economic power -- a huge population and plentiful arable land.
Moreover, China has little foreign debt and has accumulated a large stash of foreign exchange reserves after three decades of robust export-driven economic development.

Nevertheless, these advantages could become disadvantages if the wrong strategies are pursued. For instance, the huge population has been used as a source of abundant cheap labor to support China's industrial development, but its population is aging under its strict "one child" policy. Over the long run, a large graying population could be a heavy burden for China.

Rampant corruption and growing arrogance among China's policy makers as seen through its extravagance in hosting the Olympics and unbridled large-scale construction projects may also lead to a bleak economic future. China Times: Opinion poll alone cannot make good governance
Premier Wu Den-yi has betrayed a strong personal style as seen in his proposals of "promoting grassroots economy" and "using an online survey to explore public grievances."
Theses strategies are of some significance from the perspective of reaching out to people, but if they become the Cabinet's future policy guidelines, they may fail to touch on the crux of problems.

For one thing, there are age and rural-urban gaps in the use of the Internet in Taiwan. Only 4,000 Internet users responded to the Cabinet's "public grievances" survey. The limited number cannot exactly reflect public reaction to public policies.
While high housing price ranks first in the online "public grievances" survey, it is more of a problem seen in northern Taiwan metropolises.

With fewer rural residents using the Internet, problems commonly seen in Taiwan's countryside were not reflected in the survey and problems faced by foreign spouses were also not mentioned even though they give birth to one out of every eight babies born in Taiwan nowadays.

As a matter of fact, the government should be well aware of the causes of public grievances before conducting any opinion polls. For instance, telephone and Internet fraud ranks second in the grievance survey. The government should have known the seriousness of this problem through criminal statistics instead of survey results.
Food safety problems ranked ninth in the survey, but it is a problem that the government should have long taken effective measures to tackle.
As a government leader, the premier should have foresight and capabilities to discern problems and ingenuity to address them. Commercial Times: Next Chapter of Dubainomics

Concerns over Dubai's debt situation have abated with the rebound of Asian stock markets. We believe the Dubai financial crisis is unlikely to develop into a global market disaster because the emirate's rich neighbors can well afford to bail it out.

However, the emirate's obituary was written in the aftermath of the financial crisis as yet another example of hubris. An emirate that cannot repay its sovereign debts on time simply has no credibility to become a financial center.

The Dubai development model depended in part on a well of capital secured by oil and buoyed by the confidence of the emerging market. That confidence led to the creation of man-made islands and ski slopes in the desert, and some of the world's tallest buildings. It also led to aggressive foreign investments in a portfolio that included luxury stores and frivolities.
The bubble of the portfolio, however, burst in the global financial crisis that began last year.

If Dubai wants to rise again, it must work out a new strategy different from its vision of Arab entrepreneurisalism, easy credit and anything-is-possible attitude that epitomized the "if you build it they will come" philosophy.
Taiwan once tried to learn from Dubai's development strategy, but we think it is more important to learn from the "next chapter of the Dubainomics." United Daily News Bursting of the Dubai Bubble

A year or two ago, Dubainomics was a hot topic among fashionable celebrities. Dubai's Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum was reputed to be a model leader in the Arab world, while the seven-star Burj-al-Arab Hotel and man-made Palm Island became new meccas for travelers from around the world.
However, the Dubai myth, built largely on loans raised by its government, has exploded with the debt default of its investment arm, Dubai World.

Dubai's boom-to-bust story reminds us of two lessons. First, national development should not rely overly on unrealistic dreams. The tiny gulf emirate in the desert was pursuing goals beyond its reach.

Second, the global money game is unpredictable. In the past few years, few so- called investment gurus and analysts bothered to issue any warnings or precautions on potential risks, even as they passionately recommended Dubai strategies.

Turning to Taiwan, the crisis presented a different lesson. Taiwan has the right conditions to realistically become a regional business hub, as it has pragmatic and smart entrepreneurs, hard-working people, cultural heritage and a strategic location. However, it has not achieved that dream because its two major political camps have been bogged down in a war of attrition as they are being misled by politicians. Liberty Times Taiwan's democracy at risk

Taiwanese voters will go to the polls Dec. 5 to elect city mayors and county magistrates. Although only 17 top local government posts are at stake, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has been campaigning hard in an effort to get its people in.

President Ma Ying-jeou has been on several barnstorming tours around the island to stump for KMT candidates in his capacity as KMT chairman. As the zeal he has shown in campaigning has gone out of proportion to the positions being sought, he has ulterior motives.
Ma hopes his party can score a resounding success in the elections so that he can use it as a public endorsement of his China-leaning policies.

A new round of high-level talks across the Taiwan Strait will come hard on the heels of the elections and the two sides are also scheduled to begin talks on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) next January. We are worried that more market-opening deals could be struck in those two meetings.
Therefore, we urge voters in the coming elections to cast their ballots wisely to protect Taiwan's young democracy from disappearing overnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen-Xiamen bridge inappropriate for now: Taiwan's premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:34:52 (By Y. C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Building a bridge connecting Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island and the Xiamen port in China's Fujian Province is not appropriate for now as it is a politically- sensitive matter, Premier Wu Den-yih was quoted as saying Tuesday.

Wu Hsing-chien, chief editor of the Journalist weekly, quoted Wu Den-yih as making the statement after attending a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum on Kinmen's development as a "free trade city." The seminar was held in the Legislative Yuan.
Wu Hsing-chien accompanied Wu Den-yih to Kinmen Island on Nov. 26 and conducted an interview on the same issue with the premier that day.
According to Wu Hsing-chien, the premier said during last Thursday's interview that the planned Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge will not be built at present so as to avoid political implications.
As the bridge would connect Taiwan's territory with China's soil for the first time, such a political association should be fended off at present, the premier was quoted as explaining.

However, the premier stated in the interview that a projected 4-km bridge linking the Big Kinmen Island with the Little Kinmen Island will be constructed by the end of 2010, given that it is a major plank of President Ma Ying-jeou's presidential campaign platform.
Chang Ya-chung, a political science professor of National Taiwan University, said the government's attempts to skip the proposed Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge highlighted its "lack of vision."

Judging from Kinmen's geographic proximity with Xiamen and a close economic integration between the two sides, Chang said the building of the bridge would be a boon for people on both Kinmen and Xiamen. He predicted it will be an unavoidable development.

Tung Chih-sen, a veteran journalist from Kinmen who has worked a long time for several major newspapers and a local cable station, urged the central government to shrug off unnecessary misgivings, because political motivations and funds should not be factors blocking the construction of the Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge, he said.

Amid improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties and due to its proximity to Xiamen, Kinmen has long hoped to play a leading role in boosting Taiwan-China exchanges on the tourism, financial and educational fronts.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng has said repeatedly that the county is willing to act as a guinea pig for the central government's China policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling allowing its flat panel industry to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 30 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:41:21 (By Hwang Jaw-ping and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy economics minister said Monday here that the government will properly handle issues related to the opening of Taiwan's flat panel industry to invest in China.
Huang Jung-chiou made the remarks on the sidelines of the opening of the 2009 Taiwan-US Green Energy & Technology Joint Conference in response to a call for the opening.

But Huang did not comment on whether the Ministry of Economic Affairs will reach an agreement for the opening in 2010 at an inter-ministerial meeting slated for late-December on review of the timing and scope for opening Taiwan's panel industry to invest in China.

Taiwan's contract manufacturers have very strong production capacity for small- and-medium size flat panel products and the products have gained a competitive edge in the global market, according to Huang.

Meanwhile, manufacturers of large size panels have set their sight on the flat panel television market, with the United States and Japan the two largest markets in the world. Demand for the products in China has been growing rapidly recently, Huang said.

Huang said that according to his observation, China is not willing to see the country overly rely on other countries for panel production, particularly Taiwan and South Korea. It therefore hopes Taiwan's panel manufacturers will invest in China.
"We'll keep a close eye on South Korea's move in China and properly address issues related to collaboration between Taiwan and China in panel production," he indicated.

Lou Qinjian, vice-minister of China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, urged Taiwan to open its panel industry to invest in China during a meeting in Taipei a few days ago and said that both sides have reached a consensus on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises referendum in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 21:41:36 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou lauded Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as a model of democracy in the Caribbean region as it held a constitutional referendum Nov. 25, the first of its kind to be held by a member of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS).

During a meeting in Taipei with Hendrick Alexander, speaker of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' House of Assembly, Ma noted that the Republic of China and the Caribbean country have enjoyed diplomatic ties for 28 years and that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has helped the ROC' participation in OECS activities, as well as having promoted Taiwan's international visibility and deepened Taiwan's friendship with other Caribbean countries.
Although the ROC Constitution was enacted in 1946 and implemented the next year, democracy has only developed in the country for the last 20 years or so, Ma said.
Taiwan has held four direct presidential elections and has undergone two changes in ruling parties since 1996 after martial law was ended in 1987, Ma noted.
The democracy established in Taiwan has won world recognition, he went on, pointing out that former U.S. President George W. Bush has praised Taiwan as a beacon of democracy for Asia and the world.

So far, 24 students from Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have studied in Taiwan, and in the future, the government will expand its scholarship program to provide more opportunities for students from its diplomatic allies to study here, according to Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of voters for mayor, magistrate elections totals 7.05 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Sept. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 21:54:51 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The number of voters eligible to cast their ballots Dec. 5 to elect city mayors and county magistrates totals 7.05 million, the Central Election Commission (CSC) said Tuesday.
The eligible voters in 17 of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties are set to elect mayors and magistrates, city and county councilors, and city and township heads.

Seven other cities and counties -- Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County -- will be upgraded or merged into municipalities and hold elections for local leaders along with Taipei City next year.

CSC officials also noted that the number of eligible voters for township chief elections, which will also be held Dec. 5, is around 6.23 million. While the other election, for city and county councilors, has 7.03 million eligible voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative meeting over U.S. beef opening stymied by opposition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 22:41:45 (By L.C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) paralyzed a legislative meeting Tuesday over the controversy concerning the Executive Yuan's decision to relax restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

The session, aimed at reviewing amendments to the Food Sanity and Management Law, was blocked by DPP lawmakers who occupied the podium to prevent the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus from calling a vote to pass relevant law revisions and raised large posters declaring their demands.
The meeting was called off by Legislative Vice Speaker Tseng Yung-chuan after around 10 minutes.

KMT legislators and their DPP counterparts have been divided over the amendments to the Food Sanity and Management Law, after Taiwan and the United States inked a protocol in late October in Washington, D.C. to allow the entry of U.S. bone- in beef, ground beef, intestines, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials (SRMs)" related to bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.

SRMs are defined in the protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.

In line with the terms of the protocol, KMT legislators hope to impose strict administrative inspections to examine the controversial items of imported U.S. beef products from the point of origin in the United States through to the downstream retail markets in Taiwan, as well as to ensure that Taiwanese customers can obtain detailed and swift information about the U.S. beef products imported into Taiwan.

On the other side, the DPP lawmakers insist on re-opening negotiations with the United States and banning the controversial parts from entering Taiwan through legislation, on the grounds that checks through administrative measures are not enough to fully protect the health of the public.

Negotiations on the matter between the two parties' legislative caucuses have been stalled for some time due to the differing stances amid grave concern among Taiwan's consumers over the safety of U.S beef products.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the ban was reimposed two months later when a second case was discovered.

In 2006, the Department of Health agreed to allow beef imports once again, but limited them to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any SRMs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yankees to sign another Taiwanese baseball player
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 22:53:33 (Liu Mei-yu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The New York Yankees will sign another Taiwanese player -- 18 year-old infielder Kuo Fu-lin -- nine years after singing Taiwan's biggest sports star, Wang Chien- ming, Kuo's agent confirmed Tuesday.

Kuo, a freshman at National Taiwan College of Physical Education, is scheduled to attend Yankees spring training between February and March in 2010 in the United States, according to Octagon Inc., a sports agent and marketing company.
The Yankees are expected pay Kuo a signing-on bonus of between US$300,000 and US$500,000, but Octagon refused to confirm the figures, saying only that a signing ceremony will be held next week.

Kuo played for Nan Ying High School as third baseman, and was a member of the Chinese Taipei team in the 2004 Asian AA Baseball Championship and again in the 2008 World Youth Baseball Championship hosted by the International Baseball Association (IBA).
His team came second in this year's Asian AAA Baseball Championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait currency settlement system to be completed soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 17:31:44 (By Erin Ho, Garfie Li and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese banker said Tuesday that preparations for a currency clearance and settlement system between Taiwan and China are now 80 to 90 percent complete.
"An agreement on the system will be concluded before the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed," said Hu Xiaolian, vice governor of the People's Bank of China.
The ECFA issue is expected to be broached during the fourth round of talks between Taiwan and China later this month in Taichung City.

Hu, who arrived in Taipei Monday for a cross-Taiwan Strait financial seminar, told reporters after the opening of the forum that preparations for the currency system have been in progress for quite some time.

Noting that currency clearance services would be provided by commercial banks of both sides of the strait, Hu said the preparations include matters such as the transport of currency, the opening of accounts in the participating banks, and the compilation of statistics.

The system would allow for the conversion of Taiwan and China currency in banks on both sides, which will lower the cost of currency conversion and reduce the circulation of counterfeit banknotes, thereby encouraging Chinese tourists to spend more in Taiwan, Hu said.

Meanwhile Chiang Pin-kung, Taiwan's top negotiator with China, said at the seminar that during the fifth round of cross-strait negotiations, Taiwan and China will conclude an agreement to allow bank ventures in each other's market.

He said that when he and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin meet in Taiching later this month, they will put the issue on the agenda for the next round of talks that is expected to be held in China in the first half of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan makes it easier for overseas Chinese to visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 18:11:42 (By Lin Shen-chu, Elizabeth Hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has eased restrictions on visits by overseas Chinese people, making it easier for Chinese nationals who live in foreign countries or in Hong Kong or Macau to visit the island, National Immigration Agency (NIA) officials said Tuesday.
Starting Tuesday, Chinese people can come to Taiwan for sightseeing as long as they have lived in a foreign country or in Hong Kong and Macau for at least one year, the officials said.

Previous regulations required them to have lived overseas for at least four years. Overseas Chinese must still have a job in the countries and areas where they live, or be the spouse or lineal relative of such overseas Chinese, to apply for a tourist permit to visit Taiwan.
Taiwan only began opening the doors for tourist visits by Chinese people who live overseas, in Hong Kong or Macau, in 2002.

Chinese people who meet the requirements can apply to visit Taiwan for tourism by providing their employment certificates, proofs of family relationship, identification cards, application forms, travel plans and itineraries.
The applications can be filed with the agency either by travel agents or by the applicants themselves, the official added.

In light of the increased demand for urgent entry permits by Chinese people wishing to come to Taiwan, the immigration agency has set up a mechanism to streamline the processing of travel documents of Chinese tourists on a case-by- case basis in order to increase efficiency, the official said.

Under the revisions, travel agencies who put down a NT$1 million (US$31,250) security deposit with the Travel Agent Association of ROC Taiwan for arranging tours for overseas Chinese to visit Taiwan will not be charged NT$100,000 for each inbound-Chinese tourist who goes missing because there have been no case of overstaying or absconding reported since Taiwan opened its doors to overseas Chinese tourists in 2002, according to the official.
However, a fine will still be imposed for inbound Chinese tourists from Hong Kong, Macau or China who overstay their visas or go missing, according to the official.

It has become common for Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan since the two sides first launched direct flights in 2008. The number of visitors from China has been on the rise, since direct flights and flight destinations were expanded in July this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma orders establishment of task force to help revive pro baseball
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 18:55:42 (By Pao-hsian Hsiao and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou gave a directive Tuesday for the establishment a Cabinet- level task force, headed by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, to help revive professional baseball in Taiwan.
The president also gave instructions for 2010 to be designated as
the first year of baseball revival in Taiwan, according to Chao Shou-po, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL).
Ma gave the directives during first-ever national conference on baseball, which was held to discuss ways of reviving and upgrading the sport that has been plagued by game-fixing scandals.
During the conference, Chao said, the president stressed that it is impossible to solve during a two-hour meeting problems that have accumulated over the past decade.
He told the attendees that it is important "to eliminate the sickness" and at the same time "revitalize the liveliness" of the sport.

Ma said the relevant government agencies should make greater efforts to communicate and coordinate among themselves to help tackle the problems pertaining to irregularities in the professional baseball league.
An overall review should be conducted and proposals such as tax-free incentives for professional baseball clubs and their sponsors should be studied, the president said.

Premier Wu Den-yih said at the meeting that it is the government's responsibility to provide a "clean" environment for professional baseball to flourish, and he suggested that there should be at least one baseball stadium in every city and county around the country.
The conference was convened after some 800 baseball fans took to the streets of Taipei Sunday demanding that the government do something to rescue the sport in Taiwan.
"President Ma has heard the voices of the demonstrators and he exhorted the CPBL teams to 'hang in there' and not to give up despite the recent spate of problems," Chao said.

Fans of professional baseball clubs that were disbanded because of game fixing joined the rally on Ketagalan Boulevard in front of the Presidential Office to demand that the government act quickly to fix the problems that they said had led to frequent cases of game fixing.

Responding to the protesters' demands, the president invited scholars, officials of various government agencies, representatives of the professional baseball clubs and representatives of the demonstrators to attend the national baseball conference.
"The executives of all the CPBL clubs are encouraged by the government's move to revive the sport and to make it a matter of national importance," Chao added.

The clubs' executives suggested during the meeting that the government give more teeth to the efforts to crack down on the crime rings that orchestrated the game-fixing in the professional baseball league.

DOC.HEADLINE: January manpower demand expected to increase by 48,000: labor council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:02:09 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With the global economy recovering, Taiwan's manpower demand by the end of January next year is expected to increase by 48,000, compare to the end of October this year, according to the results of a survey published Tuesday by the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA).

The results of the fourth manpower survey of the year, conducted Oct. 16VNov. 5 and with 3,025 valid samples returned, show that 21.3 percent of the companies that responded said they will hire more personnel in January 2010, representing an increase of about 65,200 workers.
Meanwhile, about 8 percent of the companies surveyed will reduce their manpower, representing a reduction of about 17,300 workers. That would result in a net increase of 48,000 workers.
It will be the highest net increase of manpower for a single season since the survey was launched in Q3 2007, CLA officials said.
Around 65 percent of the companies will keep their manpower unchanged in January, the survey results show.

The survey results also show that the manpower demand was gradually warming up and there seems to be a trend towards more job hirings, said Cheng Wen-yuan, director of the council's statistics department.

The manufacturing, retail and support service sectors will see the most noticeable increase in manpower needs. The highest number of job increase -- some 19,500 -- will come in the manufacturing sector, according to the survey results.
Chen said that the electronics components, computer and optical products sectors are expected to benefit most from the recovery in demand and the rising demand will generate more hiring needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade policy not priority for Obama administration: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:11:51 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: American scholars attending a Taipei-Washington video conference Tuesday suggested that the U.S. administration has prioritized global issues, such as nuclear proliferation and energy policy, and that trade policy is not at the top of its agenda.

The Office of Trade Negotiations in Taipei invited four American scholars to assess the impact of U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to Asia in mid-November and to hold dialogue with Vice Economics Minister Francis Kuo-sin Liang and other trade officials.

The moderator, Sherman Elliott Katz,who is a senior advisor at the Washington- based think tank Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress, raised the issues of U.S. trade policy, U.S. reaction towards probable China domination of the Asian market, leverage in the situation where the U.S. is a debtor and China is the creditor, China's currency, and the reduction of tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Commenting on President Obama's statement in Tokyo on Nov. 14 that the U.S. welcomes China's greater role in the world, Larry A. Niksch, a specialist in Asian Affairs with the Congressional Research Service, said that he does not think China's growth and expansion of influence would jeopardize Washington- Beijing relations.
The U.S. would not react to trade problems with protective measures, he added.

Referring to the question of whether China's position as the largest foreign creditor of the U.S. had influenced Obama's approach during his visit to China, the expert in U.S. security policy said that he did not see Obama pushing China on currency issues or China's subsidies to national industries.
Furthermore, the situation in which China is the largest foreigner holder of U.S. debt "would give China the ability to hurt the U.S. financially and economically in the longer term," he suggested.
Josh Kurlantzik, Council on Foreign Relations fellow for Southeast Asia, said that Obama's decision not to meet the Dalai Lama had "overstated the weakness of his hand."
However, Grant Aldonas, under secretary of international trade in George W. Bush administration's Commerce Department (2001-2005), held a different view of the leverage issue.

He suggested that while President Obama, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Director of the White House's National Economic Council Lawrence Summers might think that as the largest foreign creditor of the U.S., China has leverage, "the debtor has relatively the same leverage as the creditor."

Commenting on the statement by some Taiwanese scholars that the Obama administration has prioritized global issues and is less concerned about China's relationship with Taiwan, Niksch said that "the Obama administration, like the Bush administration, is pleased to see the opening of cross-strait policies by President Ma Ying-jeou and the reduction of tensions."

Niksch suggested that the improvement in cross-strait relations has overshadowed cross-strait defense issues, but added that he believes the U.S. will continue to make selective military sales to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act.
As to the possibility of a political agreement on unification, Niksch said that "the U.S. policy is changing to accept that -- as long as it is not a decision made under coercion from China."
He also emphasized the U.S. position that any major political move in Taiwan should be decided by the Taiwanese people, maybe through referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:21:31 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday: Apple Daily:
Prize-winning film sheds light on bureaucratic detachment

Taiwan's civil servants should be required to see Leon Dai's prize-winning film "No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti" and report on what they saw as the movie portrays how bureaucratic detachment could force ordinary citizens to the brink of death.
The indie film swept the Golden Horse Film Festival last weekend by bagging the coveted best picture and best director awards.

It was based on the true story of a ship repair worker's desperate fight for his daughter's right to education. The girl was born out of wedlock and her birth was not legally registered with any local household registration agency. As a result, she could not enter any elementary school.

The protagonist approached government agencies at various levels but none of them would extend him a helping hand. He ultimately tried to commit suicide but fortunately, the attempt was thwarted by police.

The black and white film reflects a common mind-set of Taiwan's civil servants who tend to be passive in dealing with their work and try to avoid mistakes rather than seek innovation or reform and also highlights another practice commonly seen in Taiwan's officialdom -- passing the buck, as the protagonist is sent from one agency to another.

The film further reminds us that we still have a long way to go to build Taiwan into a mature democracy as the democratic ideals of "government of people, by people and for people" has not yet taken root in our officials' minds. Economic Daily News
Will 'China myth' shatter like Dubai World?

The financial crisis faced by government-owned conglomerate Dubai World in the United Arab Emirates should serve as a reminder to China's leaders that extravagant development projects can collapse overnight.

Unlike Dubai -- a small desert emirate whose prosperity is a myth built largely on loans raised by its government -- China has what it takes to be an economic power -- a huge population and plentiful arable land.
Moreover, China has little foreign debt and has accumulated a large stash of foreign exchange reserves after three decades of robust export-driven economic development.

Nevertheless, these advantages could become disadvantages if the wrong strategies are pursued. For instance, the huge population has been used as a source of abundant cheap labor to support China's industrial development, but its population is aging under its strict "one child" policy. Over the long run, a large graying population could be a heavy burden for China.

Rampant corruption and growing arrogance among China's policy makers as seen through its extravagance in hosting the Olympics and unbridled large-scale construction projects may also lead to a bleak economic future. China Times: Opinion poll alone cannot make good governance
Premier Wu Den-yi has betrayed a strong personal style as seen in his proposals of "promoting grassroots economy" and "using an online survey to explore public grievances."
Theses strategies are of some significance from the perspective of reaching out to people, but if they become the Cabinet's future policy guidelines, they may fail to touch on the crux of problems.

For one thing, there are age and rural-urban gaps in the use of the Internet in Taiwan. Only 4,000 Internet users responded to the Cabinet's "public grievances" survey. The limited number cannot exactly reflect public reaction to public policies.
While high housing price ranks first in the online "public grievances" survey, it is more of a problem seen in northern Taiwan metropolises.

With fewer rural residents using the Internet, problems commonly seen in Taiwan's countryside were not reflected in the survey and problems faced by foreign spouses were also not mentioned even though they give birth to one out of every eight babies born in Taiwan nowadays.

As a matter of fact, the government should be well aware of the causes of public grievances before conducting any opinion polls. For instance, telephone and Internet fraud ranks second in the grievance survey. The government should have known the seriousness of this problem through criminal statistics instead of survey results.
Food safety problems ranked ninth in the survey, but it is a problem that the government should have long taken effective measures to tackle.
As a government leader, the premier should have foresight and capabilities to discern problems and ingenuity to address them. Commercial Times: Next Chapter of Dubainomics

Concerns over Dubai's debt situation have abated with the rebound of Asian stock markets. We believe the Dubai financial crisis is unlikely to develop into a global market disaster because the emirate's rich neighbors can well afford to bail it out.

However, the emirate's obituary was written in the aftermath of the financial crisis as yet another example of hubris. An emirate that cannot repay its sovereign debts on time simply has no credibility to become a financial center.

The Dubai development model depended in part on a well of capital secured by oil and buoyed by the confidence of the emerging market. That confidence led to the creation of man-made islands and ski slopes in the desert, and some of the world's tallest buildings. It also led to aggressive foreign investments in a portfolio that included luxury stores and frivolities.
The bubble of the portfolio, however, burst in the global financial crisis that began last year.

If Dubai wants to rise again, it must work out a new strategy different from its vision of Arab entrepreneurisalism, easy credit and anything-is-possible attitude that epitomized the "if you build it they will come" philosophy.
Taiwan once tried to learn from Dubai's development strategy, but we think it is more important to learn from the "next chapter of the Dubainomics." United Daily News Bursting of the Dubai Bubble

A year or two ago, Dubainomics was a hot topic among fashionable celebrities. Dubai's Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum was reputed to be a model leader in the Arab world, while the seven-star Burj-al-Arab Hotel and man-made Palm Island became new meccas for travelers from around the world.
However, the Dubai myth, built largely on loans raised by its government, has exploded with the debt default of its investment arm, Dubai World.

Dubai's boom-to-bust story reminds us of two lessons. First, national development should not rely overly on unrealistic dreams. The tiny gulf emirate in the desert was pursuing goals beyond its reach.

Second, the global money game is unpredictable. In the past few years, few so- called investment gurus and analysts bothered to issue any warnings or precautions on potential risks, even as they passionately recommended Dubai strategies.

Turning to Taiwan, the crisis presented a different lesson. Taiwan has the right conditions to realistically become a regional business hub, as it has pragmatic and smart entrepreneurs, hard-working people, cultural heritage and a strategic location. However, it has not achieved that dream because its two major political camps have been bogged down in a war of attrition as they are being misled by politicians. Liberty Times Taiwan's democracy at risk

Taiwanese voters will go to the polls Dec. 5 to elect city mayors and county magistrates. Although only 17 top local government posts are at stake, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has been campaigning hard in an effort to get its people in.

President Ma Ying-jeou has been on several barnstorming tours around the island to stump for KMT candidates in his capacity as KMT chairman. As the zeal he has shown in campaigning has gone out of proportion to the positions being sought, he has ulterior motives.
Ma hopes his party can score a resounding success in the elections so that he can use it as a public endorsement of his China-leaning policies.

A new round of high-level talks across the Taiwan Strait will come hard on the heels of the elections and the two sides are also scheduled to begin talks on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) next January. We are worried that more market-opening deals could be struck in those two meetings.
Therefore, we urge voters in the coming elections to cast their ballots wisely to protect Taiwan's young democracy from disappearing overnight.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen-Xiamen bridge inappropriate for now: Taiwan's premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:34:52 (By Y. C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Building a bridge connecting Taiwan's outlying Kinmen Island and the Xiamen port in China's Fujian Province is not appropriate for now as it is a politically- sensitive matter, Premier Wu Den-yih was quoted as saying Tuesday.

Wu Hsing-chien, chief editor of the Journalist weekly, quoted Wu Den-yih as making the statement after attending a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Competitiveness Forum on Kinmen's development as a "free trade city." The seminar was held in the Legislative Yuan.
Wu Hsing-chien accompanied Wu Den-yih to Kinmen Island on Nov. 26 and conducted an interview on the same issue with the premier that day.
According to Wu Hsing-chien, the premier said during last Thursday's interview that the planned Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge will not be built at present so as to avoid political implications.
As the bridge would connect Taiwan's territory with China's soil for the first time, such a political association should be fended off at present, the premier was quoted as explaining.

However, the premier stated in the interview that a projected 4-km bridge linking the Big Kinmen Island with the Little Kinmen Island will be constructed by the end of 2010, given that it is a major plank of President Ma Ying-jeou's presidential campaign platform.
Chang Ya-chung, a political science professor of National Taiwan University, said the government's attempts to skip the proposed Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge highlighted its "lack of vision."

Judging from Kinmen's geographic proximity with Xiamen and a close economic integration between the two sides, Chang said the building of the bridge would be a boon for people on both Kinmen and Xiamen. He predicted it will be an unavoidable development.

Tung Chih-sen, a veteran journalist from Kinmen who has worked a long time for several major newspapers and a local cable station, urged the central government to shrug off unnecessary misgivings, because political motivations and funds should not be factors blocking the construction of the Kinmen-Xiamen Bridge, he said.

Amid improved cross-Taiwan Strait ties and due to its proximity to Xiamen, Kinmen has long hoped to play a leading role in boosting Taiwan-China exchanges on the tourism, financial and educational fronts.
Kinmen County Magistrate Lee Chu-feng has said repeatedly that the county is willing to act as a guinea pig for the central government's China policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling allowing its flat panel industry to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Nov. 30 (CNA) 12/01/09 19:41:21 (By Hwang Jaw-ping and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's deputy economics minister said Monday here that the government will properly handle issues related to the opening of Taiwan's flat panel industry to invest in China.
Huang Jung-chiou made the remarks on the sidelines of the opening of the 2009 Taiwan-US Green Energy & Technology Joint Conference in response to a call for the opening.

But Huang did not comment on whether the Ministry of Economic Affairs will reach an agreement for the opening in 2010 at an inter-ministerial meeting slated for late-December on review of the timing and scope for opening Taiwan's panel industry to invest in China.

Taiwan's contract manufacturers have very strong production capacity for small- and-medium size flat panel products and the products have gained a competitive edge in the global market, according to Huang.

Meanwhile, manufacturers of large size panels have set their sight on the flat panel television market, with the United States and Japan the two largest markets in the world. Demand for the products in China has been growing rapidly recently, Huang said.

Huang said that according to his observation, China is not willing to see the country overly rely on other countries for panel production, particularly Taiwan and South Korea. It therefore hopes Taiwan's panel manufacturers will invest in China.
"We'll keep a close eye on South Korea's move in China and properly address issues related to collaboration between Taiwan and China in panel production," he indicated.

Lou Qinjian, vice-minister of China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, urged Taiwan to open its panel industry to invest in China during a meeting in Taipei a few days ago and said that both sides have reached a consensus on the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: President praises referendum in Saint Vincent and the Grenadines
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 21:41:36 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou lauded Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as a model of democracy in the Caribbean region as it held a constitutional referendum Nov. 25, the first of its kind to be held by a member of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States (OECS).

During a meeting in Taipei with Hendrick Alexander, speaker of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines' House of Assembly, Ma noted that the Republic of China and the Caribbean country have enjoyed diplomatic ties for 28 years and that Saint Vincent and the Grenadines has helped the ROC' participation in OECS activities, as well as having promoted Taiwan's international visibility and deepened Taiwan's friendship with other Caribbean countries.
Although the ROC Constitution was enacted in 1946 and implemented the next year, democracy has only developed in the country for the last 20 years or so, Ma said.
Taiwan has held four direct presidential elections and has undergone two changes in ruling parties since 1996 after martial law was ended in 1987, Ma noted.
The democracy established in Taiwan has won world recognition, he went on, pointing out that former U.S. President George W. Bush has praised Taiwan as a beacon of democracy for Asia and the world.

So far, 24 students from Saint Vincent and the Grenadines have studied in Taiwan, and in the future, the government will expand its scholarship program to provide more opportunities for students from its diplomatic allies to study here, according to Ma.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of voters for mayor, magistrate elections totals 7.05 million
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Sept. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 21:54:51 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The number of voters eligible to cast their ballots Dec. 5 to elect city mayors and county magistrates totals 7.05 million, the Central Election Commission (CSC) said Tuesday.
The eligible voters in 17 of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties are set to elect mayors and magistrates, city and county councilors, and city and township heads.

Seven other cities and counties -- Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County -- will be upgraded or merged into municipalities and hold elections for local leaders along with Taipei City next year.

CSC officials also noted that the number of eligible voters for township chief elections, which will also be held Dec. 5, is around 6.23 million. While the other election, for city and county councilors, has 7.03 million eligible voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislative meeting over U.S. beef opening stymied by opposition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 22:41:45 (By L.C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) paralyzed a legislative meeting Tuesday over the controversy concerning the Executive Yuan's decision to relax restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

The session, aimed at reviewing amendments to the Food Sanity and Management Law, was blocked by DPP lawmakers who occupied the podium to prevent the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) legislative caucus from calling a vote to pass relevant law revisions and raised large posters declaring their demands.
The meeting was called off by Legislative Vice Speaker Tseng Yung-chuan after around 10 minutes.

KMT legislators and their DPP counterparts have been divided over the amendments to the Food Sanity and Management Law, after Taiwan and the United States inked a protocol in late October in Washington, D.C. to allow the entry of U.S. bone- in beef, ground beef, intestines, spinal cords and processed beef from cattle younger than 30 months that have not been contaminated with "specific risk materials (SRMs)" related to bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.

SRMs are defined in the protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.

In line with the terms of the protocol, KMT legislators hope to impose strict administrative inspections to examine the controversial items of imported U.S. beef products from the point of origin in the United States through to the downstream retail markets in Taiwan, as well as to ensure that Taiwanese customers can obtain detailed and swift information about the U.S. beef products imported into Taiwan.

On the other side, the DPP lawmakers insist on re-opening negotiations with the United States and banning the controversial parts from entering Taiwan through legislation, on the grounds that checks through administrative measures are not enough to fully protect the health of the public.

Negotiations on the matter between the two parties' legislative caucuses have been stalled for some time due to the differing stances amid grave concern among Taiwan's consumers over the safety of U.S beef products.

Taiwan first banned U.S. beef in 2003 when a case of mad cow disease surfaced in Seattle. The ban was lifted in April 2005 to allow imports of U.S. de-boned beef from cattle aged under 30 months, but the ban was reimposed two months later when a second case was discovered.

In 2006, the Department of Health agreed to allow beef imports once again, but limited them to boneless beef from cattle younger than 30 months produced by certified slaughterhouses and without any SRMs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yankees to sign another Taiwanese baseball player
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/01/09 22:53:33 (Liu Mei-yu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The New York Yankees will sign another Taiwanese player -- 18 year-old infielder Kuo Fu-lin -- nine years after singing Taiwan's biggest sports star, Wang Chien- ming, Kuo's agent confirmed Tuesday.

Kuo, a freshman at National Taiwan College of Physical Education, is scheduled to attend Yankees spring training between February and March in 2010 in the United States, according to Octagon Inc., a sports agent and marketing company.
The Yankees are expected pay Kuo a signing-on bonus of between US$300,000 and US$500,000, but Octagon refused to confirm the figures, saying only that a signing ceremony will be held next week.

Kuo played for Nan Ying High School as third baseman, and was a member of the Chinese Taipei team in the 2004 Asian AA Baseball Championship and again in the 2008 World Youth Baseball Championship hosted by the International Baseball Association (IBA).
His team came second in this year's Asian AAA Baseball Championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 2, or the 16th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1804: Monarchy returns to France when Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself Emperor Napoleon I at Notre Dame, 11 years after King Louis XVI was guillotined.
1815: The Rajah of Nepal signs peace treaty with Britain.
1823: U.S. President James Monroe, introducing his "Monroe Doctrine," warns Europe to keep its hands off both American continents.
1901: King Camp Gillette markets a safety razor with a double-edged disposable blade in the United States.
1908: Henry Pu Yi, the last emperor of the Ching dynasty, is crowned emperor of China at the age of three.
1911: Chinese revolutionaries capture Nanjing.
1923: The Young China Party sets up in Paris, France.
1942: A nuclear chain reaction is demonstrated for the first time by American scientists working on a secret project in Chicago.
1954: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh signs the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty with U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.
1965: The World Health Organization formally recognizes Taiwan as free of malaria.
1968: The Taiwan Power Company signs an agreement with the World Bank for a loan of US$50 million for construction of the Dachien Dam.
1971: Soviet Union spaceship "Mars III" lands on Mars.
1974: The Fifth Asian Congress of Pharmaceutical Sciences opens a four-day meeting in Taipei.
1974: The Young China Party celebrates its 51st anniversary.
1976: The Fourth Asian Composers' League Conference holds its closing ceremony, with more than 100 delegates and observers from 20 countries attending.
1976: The ROC's "Hai Kung" research vessel leaves Keelung for an expedition to Antarctica.
1988: A cyclone packing winds in excess of 177 kph hits Bangladesh, killing thousands and leaving more than 5 million homeless.
1986: The Chunghwa (ROC) Blues and the Chunghwa Whites win 1st and 2nd places, respectively in the Third International Baseball Tournament.
1989: V.P. Singh, leader of the Janata Dal Party, replaces Rajiv Gandhi as prime minister of India.
1989: Elections are held for the Legislative Yuan, Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Taipei and Kaohsiung municipal councils, county magistrates, and provincial- level city mayors.
1990: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's center-right coalition wins re-election in the first elections since 1932 involving all of Germany.
1994: A ferry carrying more than 600 people collides with a freighter and sinks in Manila Bay, the Philippines. Sixty bodies are recovered, and 85 people remain missing.
1995: The ROC elects 164 lawmakers to the Third Legislative Yuan.
1995: A Singapore court sentences former Barings Bank trader Nick Leeson to six- and-a-half years in prison for his part in the crash of Britain's oldest merchant bank.
1996: ROC Foreign Minister John Chang departs for South Africa.
1997: After a bitter power struggle with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, President Farooq Leghari of Pakistan resigns.
1999: The Republic of China signs a formal aviation agreement with Palau as part of its efforts to facilitate exchanges between the two countries.
Motse's lesson of the day: "Heaven is all-inclusive and impartial in its activities, abundant and unceasing in its blessings, and lasting and untiring in its guidance. And so, when the sage-kings had accepted heaven as their standard, they measured every action and enterprise by heaven. What heaven desired they would carry out, what heaven abominated they refrained from."
