DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's authorities trying to rid election of phantom voters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 12:34:29 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: With three days to go before Saturday's county magistrate and mayoral elections, prosecutors have stepped up their efforts to drive out phantom voters, especially in the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

In the two outlying counties, where the number of voters is small, an election can be decided by a slim margin. Prosecutors said that was all the more reason for them to weed out phantom voters - people who take up residence in local areas four months before the election date for the sole purpose of being eligible to vote for specific candidates.
Some of these voters are paid by people who support particular candidates to become a "voting machine" to sway the election outcome.
The prosecutors started their crackdown several months ago.

In last month alone, the authorities mobilized over 200 policemen, searched 20 residences and summoned 117 people for questioning in two waves of crackdown to check alleged phantom voters, according to the newspaper China Times.

The reports also cited the prosecutors in saying that the number of the alleged "phantom population" was 3,215 in Kinmen, nearly double that of the number of 1,613 in the previous local elections four years ago.
Law enforcement authorities have also found that several hundred of the phantom voters belonged to the gangster organization "Tian Tao Meng (The Celestial Way)" from Taiwan proper.

In the past, law enforcement officers would simply leave if the houses they visited were locked. But this time, the officers did not give up so easily, but visited the same house for up to four times in half a day, the reports added.

Seven candidates, the most among all 17 cities and counties where elections will be held, are vying for the seat of Kinmen magistrate this year. The battle is therefore fought more fiercely there than in any other place.

Lee Wo-shih, a candidate nominated by the ruling Kuomintang, even went the distance to campaign in Taipei city and county, where around 60 percent of more than 20,000 eligible Kinmen voters now reside.
The total number of eligible voters in Kinmen is 72,509. Comparatively, the number of eligible voters in Matsu is only 7,697.
Efforts to root out phantom voters in Matsu was also intense.

Lin Ching-tsung, chief prosecutor of Lienchiang Prosecutors Office in Matsu, said that the office began to check the suspected phantom voters beginning in January and has listed 261 such cases, the China Times reported.

Reports also said that the prosecutors are also examining the passenger lists of airliners, ferries as well as the guest lists of hotels and hostels. If suspected persons travel to Matsu, the prosecutors would question them immediately.
With the rampant rumors of phantom voters in Matsu, Lin said his office "is pulling out all the stops to contain their encroachment to ensure a fair and just election."
Meanwhile, the air carriers announced that they have added more flights to Kinmen and Matsu starting Friday to meet the needs of those who reside in Taiwan proper but want to return home to vote.
A total of 16 flights to the two outlying islands have been added, and they have been quickly booked with many more people on the waiting lists.
"We were fully booked on the first day we announced the additional flights," an official of the Mandarin Airlines said. endditem/cs

DOC.HEADLINE: Prominent scholar quits post as medical studies evaluator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 13:00:48 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A prominent scholar's incisive criticism of the attitude of students studying medicine has triggered heated debate, which has led the professor in cognitive neuroscience to resign from the post as a visiting education evaluator of the Taiwan Medical Accreditation Council (TMAC).

Daisy Hung, director of the Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience of National Central University's College of Science, has tendered her resignation after TMAC decided not to adopt her evaluation opinions, Ministry of Education (MOE) officials said Tuesday.
The ministry respects TMAC's decision, the officials added.

According to TMAC Director Andrew Huang's secretary, the decision was a consensus among council members, after Hung published an article criticizing students at National Taiwan University (NTU), the top-notch university in Taiwan, for "eating instant noodles" and "chewing drumsticks" in class.

Commenting on the TMAC's decision, central Taiwan's China Medical University Hospital Vice President Lin Shinn-zong said ignoring Hung's accreditation was "disrespect for Hung" after the latter spent time and energy to seek improvement in the quality of higher education.

As Hung was blamed for disclosing contents of her evaluation which should have been kept confidential, her article published in the CommonWealth monthly drew defensive remarks from students at the NTU College of Medicine who organized a workshop on Nov. 30 to discuss what brought up the criticisms.

In her article titled "giving way to people who want education, " Hung wrote that as other universities around the world fight for talented students, Taiwan's smartest students will not only be late for class, but also eat instant noodles and chew drumsticks in class, watch TV soap opera series on their computer, or lie prone on the desk for a long nap.
The renowned educator and writer in Taiwan denounced the students for wasting the country's valuable and limited educational resources and their parents' money.

At the workshop, however, Fang Yuan, an NTU assistant professor in sociology, gave a different opinion on students' behavior. She argued that Taiwan's traditional "authoritarian" approach to education has proved its failure.

"Students" are the subject of education, she said, explaining that it is important for there to be interactions between teachers and students. She stated that every teacher has their different "silent agreement" with students.
If the teacher feels eating food in class has interfered with other students' learning, she wonders why the teacher will not act to stop it, Fang said.
She added that she believes "students' behavior in class is not equivalent to their learning attitude, nor learning effect."

DOC.HEADLINE: Diplomatic corps keep eye on local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 15:41:26 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Diplomatic missions to Taiwan are keeping an eye on Saturday's local elections in order to gain a better understanding of local politics and observe the country's democratic development.

As the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) stepped up their campaign efforts in the final countdown to the elections, many of the foreign representative offices, mostly located in the capital of Taipei, paid visits to campaign offices and election rallies across the island and experienced first-hand the heat of the race.
The so called "three-in-one" polls are for the election of mayors and magistrates, city and county councilors, and township heads.

Thomas Hodges, spokesman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) -- the de facto U.S. embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations -- told the Central News Agency that in the lead-up to Saturday's elections, much like the lead-up to other major elections in Taiwan, AIT officers visited a number of different locations throughout Taiwan, including Yunlin, Chiayi and Penghu.
They met with candidates, officials and campaigners from both major parties, as well as local journalists and other avid followers of politics, according to Hodges.
"Such visits help AIT better understand Taiwan's politics and give AIT officers a chance to meet with a cross-section of people from Taiwan," said Hodges.

"AIT takes no sides in the outcome of Taiwan's elections, but understanding the ins and outs of all aspects of Taiwan's remarkable democratic development helps AIT keep Washington better informed about political trends, public opinion, and policy developments in Taiwan," he added.

Jason Reeve, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei's General Relations, said that he just arrived in Taipei this summer, so this is his first time to personally experience the excitement of an election in Taiwan.

The local elections also attracted the attention from democracies in the Middle East, as the top Israeli envoy to Taiwan said that although as a diplomat, he will not express any view on internal political affairs, he is following with great interest the upcoming local elections to observe the democratic development in Taiwan.
"I always underline the great esteem of myself and my country to the democratic and open society of Taiwan, " said Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israel Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei.

Hsiao Bi-khim, director of the DPP's Department of International Affairs, told the CNA that over the years, the DPP would organize electoral observation missions for the diplomatic corps to have an in-depth understanding of local politics and public opinions.

"These visits are good opportunities for them to have a close observation of Taiwan's democracy and to gain a different point of view from people in local constituencies rather than through the media only," said Hsiao.

According to Hsiao, these electoral observation missions, which include visits to campaign offices, interactions with the public and candidates, and the showcasing of political achievements, are well-received by members of the diplomatic corps.

As eight cities and counties -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County and Kaohsiung County and Kaohsiung County -- will not elect new chiefs until late 2010, this year's elections will be held in only 17 of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties.
The number of voters eligible to cast their ballots on Saturday totals 7.05 million, according to the Central Election Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 15:53:49 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 28.39 points, or 0.37 percent, to close at 7,677.62.
The local bourse opened at 7,715.64 and fluctuated between 7,741.85 and 7,671.99 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.56 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$139.08 billion (US$4.33 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.73 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1.97 percent, foodstuff issues rose 1.46 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were up 0.78 percent, textile stocks increased 0.67 percent, machinery and electronics shares were 0.28 percent higher, and cement stocks advanced 0.03 percent.
The other major stock category -- banking and financial shares -- ended the day 0.2 percent down.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,572 to 1,155, with 262 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$2.43 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan developing into high tech capital-raising center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 16:00:04 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government has begun work to build Taiwan into a high technology capital- raising center as part of its efforts to promote the development of the country's capital market.

Vice President Vincent Siew said Wednesday at a forum on company management that the Financial Supervisory Commission and other relevant government agencies are mapping out measures to develop a financial center with what he described as "Taiwanese characteristics."

There has been a good industrial and value connection in the up-, mid- and downstream of Taiwan's high tech industry that can be used by the industry -- one of Taiwan's most internationally competitive -- as a base for the planned center, said Siew.
Economic and financial consultants to the government have advised that Taiwan should take advantage of its edge in the high tech sector to attract foreign companies to list on Taiwan's stock market.

Siew stated that as countries around the world attach importance to company management, strengthening management will not just help the sustainable development of a company, but will also attract international investors to Taiwan.

As a small export-oriented country, Taiwan faces powerful competitors in the international market. In that regard, the government will continue efforts to help local companies reinforce their management, Siew said.

Siew is the incumbent chairman of the Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation and he chaired the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research before being nominated as a vice presidential candidate in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.K. tourist numbers see increase with visa-free privileges: BTCO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 16:54:51 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The United Kingdom has become "the hottest" travel destination for Taiwanese, with the number of tourists having increased by over 30 percent since the U.K. lifted visa requirements March 3, a Taipei-based British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) official said Tuesday.
From March to October, the number of Taiwanese visitors to the U.K. was up by 36.4 percent compared with the same period of last year, according to statistics published by the Taiwan Tourism Bureau.
David Campbell, director of the BTCO, said at a tourism promotion luncheon that he was very pleased to see so many Taiwanese traveling to the U.K. for sightseeing, study or business.

The already close connections between the U.K. and Taiwan and exchanges between their peoples will continue to grow, as a new air service agreement signed between the U.K. and Taiwan last month will allow more flights between Taipei and London in the future, according to Campbell.
"In the run up to the 2012 London Olympics, I think it will be exciting to visit the U.K.," said Campbell.

Jane Dong, a Hong Kong manager for VisitBritain -- the official Web site for travel in the U.K. -- said her agency welcomes the latest developments and that she sees great potential in the Taiwan market.

More and more Taiwanese tourists are planning holidays to the U.K., including the Lunar New Year in February, according to Lin Wei-ching, general manager of Phoenix Travel, one of Taiwan's leading travel agencies.
"Our U.K. business has doubled since the visa lifting announcement in March. Taiwanese tourists can plan their trips to the U.K. more conveniently without the hassle of applying for visas," Lin said.

The U.K. visa decision has also been welcomed by Taiwanese businesses, according to the Taiwan Britain Business Council, which noted that one Taiwanese investor recently moved its European headquarters to the U.K. after the visa-lifting announcement because it can call board meetings in the U.K. at any time without needing to apply for visas, which is crucial when dealing with urgent requests from customers, attending meetings, exhibitions, or exploring new business opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 16:57:04 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, falling NT$0.029 to close at NT$32.170.
A total of US$644 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.200 and reached a low of NT$32.119.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vaccine donation shows Taiwan as `peace creator:' president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 17:01:01 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that Taiwan's offer to donate influenza A(H1N1) vaccine to the World Health Organization (WHO) has helped feature the country as a "peace creator" and "disseminator of love."

The government announced last month that it is planning to present 500,000 doses of the vaccine to the WHO for distribution to countries in need, after an ongoing free vaccination program for local citizens is complete.

Mentioning the offer during a trip to the Taoyuan General Hospital to visit children hospitalized with the new flu strain, Ma described the vaccine manufactured by Taiwan's Adimmune Corp. as being of very high quality.
Many of Taiwan's diplomatic allies in South America were amazed by the country's biotechnology achievements when they learned in July that it was going to produce the vaccine in October, he said.
The president further cited the results of an opinion survey that show that 70 percent of the respondents were prepared to be vaccinated against influenza A(H1N1).
Of these respondents, 75 percent said they were not considering limiting themselves to imported vaccine manufactured by the Novartis multinational company, Ma said.
Those who said they would accept only imported vaccine and those who said they would accept only locally produced vaccine accounted for 12 percent and 11 percent, respectively, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Japan relations firm despite envoy's resignation: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 17:45:08 (By Singyao Shih and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's relations with Japan will not be affected by the resignation of the Japanese representative to Taiwan, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Shen Lyushun said the MOFA respects the decision Monday by Masaki Saito, head of the Japan Interchange Association (JIA) in Taipei, to resign for personal reasons.
Relations between Taiwan and Japan are equitable and Taiwan could not have possibly forced the Japanese representative to resign, Shen said.
"The ministry respects the decision by Saito, the JIA and the Japanese government," he said.

There have been a number of recent positive developments in the relations between Taiwan and Japan, Shen said, among them the opening of a Taiwan office in Sapporo Tuesday, which was the sixth of its kind and "a major milestone in bilateral relations."
Saito's decision will not affect Japan-Taiwan relations, Shen stressed.
Saito's resignation is widely believed to have been resulted from the controversy caused by his comment in May that "Taiwan's status remains unclear."
The remark, made in Chaiyi County at a meeting of the Republic of China International Relations Association, angered Taiwan and resulted in Saito being given the cold shoulder.
He has been quiet over the past several months and has had very little interaction with Taiwanese officials in charge of relations with Japan.
Also, during a recent visit to Taiwan by a group of Japanese dietmen, they asked that Saito be excluded from their meetings with President Ma Ying-jeou.

Shen reiterated Wednesday that the Republic of China's sovereignty is "undisputable." When the Republic of China declared war against Japan in 1937, it abrogated all treaties signed between the two countries after the first Sino- Japanese war (1894-1895) that resulted in the Qing dynasty ceding Taiwan to Japan, he added.

In other responses Wednesday to Saito's resignation, the Presidential Office said that it respects his decision and that of the JIA, while Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Japan "should have already chosen" a replacement envoy.
Even though Saito's replacement may not have specific ties with Taiwan, he or she should be "a diplomat with strong credibility," he added.

He also praised Saito's performance over the past year, noting that during that time the two countries signed a working holiday pact and agreed to open an air route between Taipei Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport soon.

The local China Times newspaper suggested Wednesday that Yoshinori Katori, a former spokesman for the Japanese Foreign Ministry who was previously stationed in Israel and South Korea, would be the most suitable person to take up the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese, Chinese banks could set up footholds after MOUs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 18:06:42 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Details on the setting up of footholds by banks in Taiwan and China on the opposite sides of the Taiwan Strait could be discussed after memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial supervisory cooperation between the two sides come into effect, Taiwan's chief financial regulator said Wednesday.

Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen told lawmakers at the Legislative Yuan that the number of footholds and equality issues concerning setting up operations by Taiwanese and Chinese banks could be negotiated after the MOUs become effective Jan. 15 next year, but are not suitable for inclusion on the agenda for talks on a proposed bilateral economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
Taiwan and China will develop their own respective standards for their banks to follow when establishing footholds across the strait, according to Chen.

Local banks that want to set up operations in China will need to be listed as "good" after factoring in their capital adequacy ratio, non-performing loan (NPL) ratio and NPL coverage ratio, Chen noted.

Taiwan's top negotiator with China -- Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung -- said a day earlier that issues concerning market access for financial institutions on either side are expected to be brought up in the fifth round of talks between himself and China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin.

However, Chen had a differing view, saying that it is still too early to speculate on the matter and adding that whether the issues will be put on the agenda will only be known after their fourth round of talks conclude later in December.

Asked about when banks in Taiwan will be allowed to provide Chinese yuan deposit services, Chen said only that the time will be ripe after the number of Chinese visitors to Taiwan "reaches a certain level."

As for a currency settlement system pact between Taiwan and China slated to be signed before the proposed ECFA is sealed, Chen said that in the initial stage, banks on both sides will first provide services for the conversion of Taiwanese and Chinese currency in cash, and then later provide bank account services.

Chen also said the Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. will review an imbalance in supply and demand in response to lawmakers' speculation that the prices of Taiwan Depository Receipts (TDR) listed by overseas Taiwanese enterprises on the local market have been jacked up.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism revenues from Chinese visitors far less than expected: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 18:21:26 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Tourism revenues from Chinese visitors over the past months have been far below the expectations of the Tourism Bureau, with the number of visitors and their level of spending in Taiwan falling short of the estimates, according to a survey conducted by the Institute for Business Development (IBD).

IBD Vice President Tu Tze-chen said at a press briefing Wednesday that based on the monthly average of between 70,000 and 80,000 arrivals from China, it is estimated that the number in 2009 will reach 900,000, way below the Tourism Bureau's forecast of 1.6 million visitors.

Through IBD interviews with 28 experienced tour guides and the observations of some IBD researchers who posed as tour guides to collect information on tourists' consumption behavior, the IBD drafted an analytical report on the benefits to the tourism sector from Taiwan's opening to Chinese visitors.

The report indicates that, to the disappointment of the travel sector, Chinese tourists each spend an average NT$35,244 for an eight-day seven-night stay in Taiwan, which means that revenues from Chinese tourists this year may not reach the projected NT$30 billion that is based on an estimated average spending of NT$62,601 per person.
IBD researcher Lee Chu-yuan pointed out that the average spending of Chinese tourists was far less than expected, partly because of cut-throat competition among travel agencies.

With the itineraries of low-budget tourist groups mostly confined to night markets and cursory tours of scenic spots such as the Alishan mountain resort and Sun Moon Lake, Chinese tourists have hardly had the opportunity to appreciate Taiwan's attractions and culture and therefore might not come again, Lee added.

The IBD analysis shows that 70 percent of the Chinese tourists to Taiwan over the past few months were people from rural areas, over 40 years of age, looking forward to fulfilling the dream of "going to Taiwan," and expecting intensive tours to see as many places as possible.

IBD Vice President Tu suggested that Taiwan's travel sector help Chinese tourists to develop an appreciation for delicacies like Dintaifung dumplings and for music stores, coffee shops, wineries and the tea houses of the Eslite bookstore chain.
He said that both the government and the travel sector should target white- collar workers and young people on the Chinese mainland and design theme tours of special interest to them.

As many Taiwanese corporations are now preparing to hold year-end parties for their employees, Tu said, corporations with business establishments in China should consider inviting their Chinese employees to attend the celebrations in Taiwan. Such a gesture of company unity can also serve as a type of tourism promotion, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday: United Daily News When will Taiwan end social laceration?
China characterizes its Cultural Revolution, from 1966 to 1976, as a holocaust. Time Magazine calls the first decade of the 21st Century the "decade from hell" for the United States.

In Taiwan, perhaps we can call the roughly 10 years from the latter part of former President Lee Teng-hui's rule to the eight years of the Chen Shui-bian administration as the "decade of social laceration."

The three tragedies differ in terms of scale and extent and they happened under different political systems. The "decade from hell" occurred in a mature democracy, while the Cultural Revolution took place in an extremely repressive autocracy and Taiwan's social laceration emerged in the burgeoning stage of its democratization following decades of martial law.

The three cases indicate that historical blunders can happen in any political system and all three were led by Messiah-like political figures who misled their countries into the abyss because of their own power crises.
Mao Zedong tried to rescue his own political career by launching the Cultural Revolution.

In the wake of the 911 terrorist attacks, George W. Bush won passionate support with pledges to exact revenge for the terrorist attacks, but his unilateralism undermined his country's justice and the Wall Street-originated 2008 global financial crisis further highlighted Bush's disastrous governance.
In Taiwan, Lee Teng-hui's "two states" theory and Chen Shui-bian's pursuit of de jure Taiwan independence led to increased tension across the Taiwan Strait and split local society.

Both Lee and Chen used to be political stars, but their independence overtures pushed Taiwan into a war of attrition over the past decade and probably left irreparable wounds on Taiwan's political and economic development.
Today, China has emerged from the ashes of the Cultural Revolution and has become an economic powerhouse, while the United States is also striving to get back on track through policy adjustments.

In contrast, Taiwan is still mired in social confrontation and laceration over relations with China. Whether Taiwan should sign a free trade pact known as the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is still a topic of hot debate. None of Taiwan's political bigwigs in either the ruling or opposition camps are capable of leading Taiwan out of such a divide. Without a leader with broad vision and broad mind, Taiwan's future is bleak.
China Times: Dubai crisis offers lessons for national governance
Iceland, Ireland and Dubai were once praised as successful models for economic development, but they have been mired in financial chaos since the outbreak of a global financial crisis last summer.
The rise and fall of the three states provide good lessons for national governance and risk management.
All of the three countries used to be economic backwaters, but their governments managed to carve out niche markets with efficient governance, updated legislation and taxation system.

Their governments acted quickly and resolutely to attract investments to help materialize their ambitious goals. In just a decade, Ireland turned itself from the "beggar of Europe" into the "Celtic tiger, " Iceland developed itself into a financial hub from a poor fishing country, and Dubai built an economic miracle on its desert territory.
However, their prosperity evaporated almost overnight amid the onslaught of a global financial tsunami. The root cause lies in their lack of a sense of crisis.

In the pursuit of rapid growth, they would rather deal with devils while failing to adopt any risk control measures. They became too dependent on hot money and foreign investments for their economic development. To make matters worse, their governments gave up their responsibilities for market supervision too early. In the end, their property bubble exploded.

For Taiwan, it has something to learn from the three countries' stories. While its financial service industry has been less affected by the global crisis because of its relatively limited liberalization, Taiwan has been plagued by a host of problems, including inefficient governance, relatively high corruption and policy discontinuity. As a result, it has been unable to carve out new frontiers for its economy and industries over the past decade.

Good governance is critical to a country's economic development. Indonesia provides a good example. The country was in chaos after the 1998 Asian financial crisis because of its political disarray and official corruption. Since Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono assumed the presidency, Indonesia has gradually emerged as the "next golden brick" or the next economic powerhorse thanks to Yudhoyono's political and economic reforms and his personal integrity. Liberty Times China in process of buying out Taiwan
Over the past half-century, China has failed to take over Taiwan with brute force. It is now employing a different strategy, using money as its key weapon.
With its large stash of foreign exchange reserves and the current Kuomintang (KMT) administration's pro-China policy, China is gradually realizing its goal.
Even though Taiwan has not yet fully opened its doors to Chinese capital, Chinese companies have nonetheless been entering Taiwan in the guise of Taiwanese and Hong Kong enterprises.

Business groups with Chinese capital have bought real estate and money-losing media outlets. Why would Chinese business groups make such purchases at unreasonably high prices? They intend to use the media outlets as Chinese propaganda mouthpieces.

Moreover, it's no longer a secret in the financial community that China has used private equity funds to buy into Taiwan's banks and other financial institutions in collaboration with foreign companies.

Many ordinary Taiwan people did not pay a great deal of attention to such developments until China Strategic Holdings and Primus Financial Holdings recently won a bid to acquire Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., the second-largest life insurer in Taiwan.

Of far greater concern, however, is that once China's banks are allowed to open branches in Taiwan, they will be able to further nurture support in Taiwan's business community by buying into local blue-chip companies or by offering low- interest loans to heavily indebted companies.

Following its invasion of Taiwan's industrial and financial sectors, China's ultimate goal is to control the country's politics. After forging close ties with the ruling Kuomintang, China may now attempt to influence Taiwan's 113-member Legislative Yuan. China spends billions of dollars in military buildup annually, but would need to pay only a small portion of such money if it were able to offer financial subsidies to half of Taiwan's legislators.

Taiwan's people should not remain unconcerned about the fact that China is engaging in an asymmetrical economic war against Taiwan, fighting with "money bullets." Apple Daily Imagination more important than knowledge
A noted cognitive neuroscience scholar's sharp criticism of bad classroom etiquette among students at National Taiwan University's College of Medicine has drawn heated debate.
While some people echo Daisy Hung's views, others disagree with her criticism.
To be fair, her concern about students' eating and napping in class and their ignorance of the Chinese classics is not necessary, because imagination is more important than knowledge.

We are no strangers to strict restrictions on students' dress, bearing and length of hair. In the past authoritarian era, schools used to impose rigorous classroom decorum as part of efforts to nurture obedient citizens. Gone are such days.

In the modern-day world, individuals and countries alike compete with their imagination and ingenuity rather than their acquired knowledge from reciting the Chinese classics. Without imagination, no-one can be creative. Without creativity, no-one will have a future.

Liberal-minded students tend to be averse to following rules and like to challenge limits. Authoritarians do not like them because they often break hide- bound social norms or etiquette. However, such a characteristic provides a hot- house in which the imagination can grow. As a result, many young students are more lively, imaginative and creative than their older predecessors.
This is an encouraging trend and therefore, we need not care too much about their classroom etiquette.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan agency promoting int'l economic development holds meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 18:34:22 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) is holding an annual meeting with allies and other developing countries in the Asia-Pacific and West Asia regions in Jakarta, Indonesia this week.
ICDF, is state-funded organization dedicated to assisting the developing countries that are friendly to Taiwan in economic development.

Members of the ICDF "friends' associations" in seven nations in the region, including Indonesia, Vietnam, Solomon Islands and Thailand, and officials from the regional countries that had visited Taiwan for ICDF-organized training programs are attending the two-day meeting which opened on Wednesday, the ICDF said in a statement.
The participants have expressed hope of strengthening friendship and cooperation with Taiwan in the gathering, the ICDF said.
According to the statement, representatives of the ICDF friends' associations will present reports on their recent and planned activities at the meeting.
There will also be a Leaders Forum for the leaders of the associations and ICDF executives to brainstorm creative ways to promote bilateral cooperation and exchanges, the ICDF said.

There are 37 associations of ICDF friends around the world. In 1995, the ICDF opened the first annual meeting of members of the association to promote their interactions, ICDF Deputy Secretary General P.P. Lee said.

Supported by Taiwan's successful experience in economic development, the ICDF organizes many training camps each year to assist diplomatic allies and other countries in cultivating talents in the fields of economy, trade, agricultural activities, and information and telecommunications.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan restricts Chinese tourists from political activities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 19:02:03 (By S. H. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Immigration Agency (NIA) promulgated Wednesday a set of rules defining the scope of activities Chinese tourists can be involved in, listing four forbidden activities for them in Taiwan, including participating in political rallies.

According to the NIA, Chinese visitors in Taiwan are prohibited from taking part in activities harmful to national security, such as participating in political activities, or attending political talk shows and election campaigns. They are also forbidden from working in return for pay.

The rules were announced as Taiwan is seeing an increasing number of Chinese tourists -- an average of 2,518 a day in the first nine months of this year -- after two sides signed an agreement to boost tourism in 2008 and after direct flights between Taiwan and mainland China were expanded in July 2009.

In essence, Chinese tourists in Taiwan must abide by the agreement inked by Taiwan and China about Chinese people sightseeing in Taiwan Chiu Hsin-ying, a NIA section chief in charge of inbound and outbound affairs, said.

Although the government has not allowed Chinese people to come to Taiwan on their own without joining tour groups, Chinese tourists currently visiting Taiwan on group tours have free time aside from their tour package itinerary.

In conjunction with Taiwan's authorities, China-based travel agencies are required to introduce the rules to their clients before they come to Taiwan, Chiu said, adding that any Chinese visitor who fails to follow the regulations will be asked to leave Taiwan. Serious violations will be dealt with by law, Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica scientists honored with TAF Awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 19:14:40 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Two renowned scientists of Taiwan's leading academic institute Academia Sinica were recently awarded the 16th Taiwanese-American Foundation (TAF) Awards in recognition of their outstanding accomplishments in the fields of nanotechnology and epidemiology research, the institute said Wednesday.
According to an Academia Sinica press statement, Wu Maw-kuen and Chen Chien-jen together received the TAF Award in science and engineering at an award ceremony held Nov. 28 in Taipei.

Wu, who is a distinguished research fellow and director of the Institute of Physics at Academia Sinica, specializes in superconductivity and magnetism and is the director of the Taiwan National Science and Technology Program for Nanoscience and Nanotechnology, according to the press statement.

Chen, a distinguished research fellow of Academia Sinica's Genomics Research Center, specializes in epidemiology, human genetics, public health and preventive medicine. He served as minister of the Department of Health from 2003 to 2005 and National Science Council from 2006 to 2008, it added.
The TAF is a non-profit organization founded in 1982 in Long Beach, California by successful entrepreneur Kenjohn Wang and his wife Jacqueline, who are originally from Taiwan.

Every other year, the foundation gives awards that recognize those who love Taiwan and identify Taiwan as their homeland and who have achieved outstanding accomplishment in three categories: science and engineering achievement, humanities achievements, and social services achievement.

The 2009 TAF awards also honored distinguished musician Kuo Chih-yuan, and Chai Trong-rong, legislator of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Kuo was bestowed the Humanities Achievement Award, while Chai received the Social Services Award. Each laureate was also given a grant of US$20,000.

Over the past 27 years, 63 people have been bestowed the TAF Award, dubbed as the Taiwanese Nobel Prize, including former President Lee Teng-hui, former Vice President Annette Lu and former Academia Sinica President and Nobel Prize laureate Lee Yuan-tseh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese women win first table tennis game at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 19:24:05 (By Oscar Wu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's women's table tennis team won its first game in the team competition at the 2009 East Asian Games (EAG) in Hong Kong Wednesday, after the men's table tennis team and the women's basketball team lost their games that same day.
Taiwan's women beat South Korea 3-2 in the Group B competition and was set to face Hong Kong the following day.

The victory over South Korea was not expected to be easy. Hsu Jung-chan, the team's head coach, said earlier that South Korea had a strong team and that he was not optimistic about the first game because three of the Taiwanese players had begun to suffer cold symptoms.
Earlier in the day, the men's table tennis team lost to South Korea 1-3 in the Group B competition.
Six teams are competing in the women's and men's table tennis competition, with Taiwan, South Korea and Hong Kong in the same group.
The men's loss means that Taiwan will have a tough job becoming one of the top four teams to make the finals.

In women's basketball, Taiwan lost to China 61-69 in the preliminary round, a loss that was attributed in part to the lower average height of the Taiwanese players -- 10 centimeters shorter than the Chinese team. Taiwan scored only 23 rebounds, less than half of China's 47 rebounds, which sealed their defeat.
The Fifth East Asian Games, which began that same day, will run through Dec. 13. Its official opening ceremony will be held Dec. 5.

Around 2,300 athletes from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, China, Hong Kong, Macau, Mongolia and Guam will compete in 262 events encompassing 22 sports, making it the largest international multi-sport event ever held in Hong Kong.
Taiwanese athletes will compete in a record 20 sports, according to Thomas Tsai, president of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee.
In the 2005 Macau EAG, Taiwan competed in 17 sports and came home with 12 gold medals, 34 silvers and 26 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan delays decision on Next Media's requests for TV channels
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 20:20:02 (By Amy Huang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Communications Commission (NCC) on Wednesday delayed a decision on controversial media company - Next Media's application to operate television channels on the island.
Next Media in mid August submitted an application to run five TV channelsVnews, general information, movie, entertainment and sports.

But the company's application has raised concerns after it became the target of vehement protests last week from parents, educators and others for providing easy-to-access animated video clips of news events, including sexual harassment and violent crimes.

Next Media's Web site started an animated news service in mid- November, enabling readers of its affiliated Apple Daily newspaper to access the obscene motion graphic news by simply scanning the bar code on the paper with a cell phone.
Next Media has since canceled the animated news section after being fined by the Taipei City Government, which ordered schools and public libraries to cancel subscriptions of the paper.
But the media group's TV projects, TV channels for news and general information in particular, are expected to come under more scrutiny.
The NCC on Wednesday announced it is requiring the media corporation to present more details of its operational plans.

As a matter of fact, NCC spokesman Chen Cheng-chang revealed last week that Next Media may not get approval for running TV news and general information channels, although it is highly likely that the projects for movie, entertainment and sports channels might be approved by the commission.

NCC members decided, however, that they have no objections against the movie channel plan, but they requested more details on how the media group plans to operate the entertainment and sports channels. The commission will review details of the three channels as a package.

Chen said that the NCC has not ruled out the possibility of granting permission to Next Media to run the three proposed channels, adding that the commission is only requiring more details to clarify that the TV channels will not apply similar methods in processing entertainment and sports news as Apple Daily did.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of Internet fraud cases up 17% in first 11 months of 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 20:27:54 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The number of Internet fraud cases is rising rapidly in Taiwan, while telephone fraud is on the decline, which indicates a shift in the mode of telecommunications used by swindlers, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

From Jan. 1 through Nov. 22 this year, there were 17.32 percent more cases of Internet fraud than in the same period last year, Jiang noted during an inter- ministerial meeting held to discuss the possibility of cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation to fight telecommunications crimes.
However, during the same period, there was a 16.73 percent drop in the number of telephone fraud cases, he said.
"There is a need for the authorities to work out measures to tackle the new form of fraud," the minister said.

According to Jiang, the decrease in the number of telephone fraud cases is partly attributable to the launch of the "165" anti-fraud hotline by the government to educate the public about the ploys used by criminals.
Also helpful was the signing of a judicial assistance agreement between Taiwan and China, he said.
Since the agreement became effective in June this year, the two sides have worked together to crack seven major criminal cases and arrest 210 suspects, Jiang said.

While a task force under the Cabinet has put forth various plans to address rampant telephone fraud, it is important that these plans be implemented so as to stop the harassment of the public by criminals, he said.

According to the results of an online poll conducted Nov. 25-29 by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, the issue of rampant telephone and Internet scams was number two on a list of top ten public grievances, after high housing prices in urban areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Protest zone planned for upcoming cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 20:41:21 (By C. C. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A large demonstration zone will be set up for protesters to express their opinions during the upcoming round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks to be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City, an official said Wednesday.

Ma Shao-chang, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the purpose of the zone is to allow people with different views to express their opinions in public.

Those who want to protest against relevant issues can freely enter or leave the zone, which will be set up near the venue of the fourth round of negotiations between the SEF and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), Ma said.
China's top envoy on Taiwan affairs -- ARATS President Chen Yunlin -- will be able to "easily" hear the voices of the protesters when attending the talks in Taichung City, Ma added.
According to Ma, the protest zone will have a size of about 99,100 square meters.
The visit will be Chen's second to Taiwan. During Chen's first visit in November 2008, protesters in Taipei stranded him in a hotel for hours after he had dinner with ruling party officials.
A preparatory meeting ahead of the upcoming round of SEF-ARATS negotiations will be held on Dec. 9 in a city in southern China, according to media reports.
The SEF and ARATS are expected to announce the date of their preparatory meeting Thursday.
SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Kao Koong-lian and ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong will take part in the meeting on behalf of their respective bodies, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fubon Financial to bid for stake in Chinese bank: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 21:01:10 (Tien Yu-pin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based Fubon Financial Holding Co Ltd. on Wednesday declined to confirm a foreign newswire report that it is among the bidders for Morgan Stanley's stake in the Chinese investment bank -- China International Capital Corporation Ltd. (CICC) -- in a deal that could be worth more than US$1 billion.
The company's General Manager Gong Tian-xin said he had "no comment, " in response to local media reporters' queries about the matter, but hinted that the deal is in progress.

Morgan Stanley will sell its entire holdings of 34.3 percent in CICC, the country's first and most profitable investment bank, seeking between US$1.2 billion and US$1.5 billion, according to the report.
Other private equity firms that have joined the bidding include Bain Capital, Carlyle Group, General Atlantic, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co and TPG, according to the report.
Gong said that because the Chinese market is so large, Taiwanese banks trying to break into the market should focus on core businesses.

He added that the company's move to increase its stake in China's Xiamen City Commercial Bank in July is aimed at building on its strength in offering loans and lines of credit to small and medium-sized enterprises and providing personal investment advice. The goal is to gradually expand its business in China to include banking, life and property insurance services, and securities and mutual funds brokerage, he said.

Taiwanese banks seeking to venture into the Chinese market should choose the second most prosperous cities because there are already a number of big foreign banks in the most booming cities, Gong advised.

The total assets of Chinese banks are eight times that of Taiwan's, the total value of China's stock market is about five times that of Taiwan's, and China's insurance market is about twice the size of Taiwan's, Gong said, citing a report on the financial markets on the two sides.
He also said that Fubon Financial Holding Co. would welcome any move by Chinese banks to buy a stake in the island's second-largest financial services company by market value.

CICC, China's first joint venture investment bank, was established in August 1995 as a strategic partnership among prestigious Chinese and international financial institutions and corporations. CICC has a registered capital of US$125 million, according to its Web site.

Meanwhile, another report revealed that the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (ICBC), the world's most profitable bank, is in talks to acquire a 20 percent stake in Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding Co. in a potential deal of US$3 billion.
If the deal goes through, it will be the first direct investment by a Chinese bank in a Taiwan financial group.
Cathay Financial President Chen Tsu-pei declined to comment on the report.

However, Premier Wu Den-yih, Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der and Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean Chen have all said that the government has no plans to relax the restrictions on Chinese investment in Taiwan's state- related banks.

Chen said that it is currently illegal to allow Chinese investment in domestic banks, but that Taiwan and China intend to allow their banks to gain footholds on the other side in the initial stage of a cross-strait financial agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism chief affirms significance of Chinese tourist arrivals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 21:39:54 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau chief Janice Lai said Wednesday that the estimate of NT$30 billion in tourism revenues this year from Chinese tourists was not a hyper forecast, but rather a careful calculation based on tourist consumption behavior.

Lai stressed the significance of having more Chinese tourist arrivals and refuted an analytical report by the Institute for Business Development (IBD) that stated the Tourism Bureau had overestimated the benefits.

The IBD report released earlier on Wednesday indicates that tourism revenues from Chinese visitors over the past months have been far below the expectations of the Tourism Bureau, with the number of visitors and their level of spending in Taiwan falling short of the estimates.

Lai challenged the accuracy of the analytical report on grounds that it was based on IBD interviews with tour guides and the observations of some IBD researchers who posed as tour guides to collect information.

She pointed out that it would be difficult for tour guides to obtain a broad enough picture of the industry to make assessments. Besides, since Chinese visitors in Taiwan do not always remain with their tour groups as one third of the time is allowed for free movement, the tour guides might not be fully informed on the tourists' activities and consumption behavior, she argued.

The tourism chief said that the bureau's NT$30 billion estimate was based on a survey conducted last year among 6,000 tourists, 440 of whom were from the Chinese mainland. The Tourism Bureau has commissioned academic institutes to conduct the sample survey at the airport every year, she added.

Lai said there is no need for the Tourism Bureau to exaggerate to the travel sector the benefits of having more Chinese tourist arrivals, and that tourism exchanges between Taiwan and China have cultural as well as economic relevance.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese mission assists Guatemalans living in remote areas
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 1 (CNA) 12/02/09 21:50:22 (By Huang Kwang-tsun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China mission in Guatemala has won the appreciation of the Central American nation by offering training programs to people living in remote areas of the country, sources at the ROC Embassy in Guatemala said Tuesday.

ROC Ambassador to Guatemala Adolfo Sun said the idea of offering training classes on bamboo growing and high mountain vegetable cultivation to help improve incomes in remote areas came from his visit in July to Huehuetenango Province in the west of Guatemala.
During the visit, he exchanged views with Congressman Mirza Judith Arreaga and local officials on the proposed programs.
Arreaga then led the mayors of nine cities in the province on a visit to Taiwan in August to get to know about its political, economic, agricultural and urban development.

ROC embassy officials, the Taiwanese mission and a trade service delegation continued to visit cities in the province to learn about the area's agriculture, production and distribution, as well as training facilities for women.
Sun donated a container-load of organic fertilizer to impoverished farmers in Huehuetenango on behalf of Taiwan's Beverly and Victor Co. Oct. 30.

The mission then offered high mountain vegetable cultivation classes in the province's Chimatenango vegetable cultivation training center and a bamboo cultivation and forestation program at its Cuyuta bamboo artifact training center.
Arreaga and the city mayors expressed appreciation for Taiwan's assistance, saying that the training programs are a good way to help people out of poverty and expressing hope that they can continue.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. will send officials to Taiwan to check passport security
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.2 (CNA) 12/02/09 22:01:47 (By Shih Hsing-yao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is organizing a working group to visit Taiwan soon to inspect Taiwan's passport security measures, as the U.S. is considering whether to offer visa-free treatment to Taiwanese citizens, an official said Wednesday.

"The U.S. working group will consult with our government agencies in charge of passport affairs on possible measures to further enhance passport security," Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Shen Lyushun said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

According to Shen, the U.S. working group hopes to learn more about Taiwan's processing of its passport applications and will request that Taiwan makes it mandatory for its citizens to apply in person for passports to reduce the possibility of irregularities.

"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is giving priority to the goal of securing visa-free treatment within one year for Taiwan passport holders traveling to the U.S. and European Union member countries, Shen told lawmakers.

While the U.S. Department of State and Congress are basically open to the proposal, he said, the U.S. Homeland Security Department is still reluctant to give the green light as the specter of the 911 terrorist attacks still remains.
"We need to make greater efforts to convince them that we have taken effective steps to plug the loopholes in the passport processing procedures," Shen said.
He briefed lawmakers on the U.S. government's policy and stance toward Taiwan, in the wake of President Barack Obama's recent visit to China.

Taiwan-U.S. relations will continue to move in a positive direction, following a recent briefing in Taipei by American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt on Obama's visit to China in November, Shen said.
For one thing, U.S. arms sales to Taiwan will continue, Shen forecast.

"While the U.S. may defer its decisions on some items, they will remain on the evaluation list, " Shen said, adding that the long-stalled talks under the Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement will resume early next year.
Moreover, he added, the United States will continue to support Taiwan's efforts to participate meaningfully in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese baseball player in Japan gets steep pay raise
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 22:31:28 (By Hsiao pao-hsian and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Chen Wei-yin, a Taiwanese Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) pitcher, re-signed Wednesday with the Chunichi Dragons in Japan's Central League for an annual salary of 110 million Japanese yen (US$1.15 million), a sharp rise from the 35 million yen he was offered in 2009, a Japanese newspaper reported Wednesday.

It took the Taiwanese left-handed pitcher only two years to secure a salary of over 100 million yen. When he returned in 2008 to play for the Dragons after a two-year break because of an elbow injury, he was earning six million yen, according to the Nikkansports newspaper.
The pay rise came in the wake of Chen's 1.54 earned run average (ERA) in the NPB's 2009 season, which was recorded as the best in nearly 40 years for the Dragons, the newspaper reported.
Chen said he was not disappointed with the pay he was offered in the new contract.
Chen played for the Chinese Taipei national baseball team in the 2004 and 2008 Olympic Games.
Meanwhile, right-hander Kazuki Yoshimi was offered 90 million yen for 2010, a pay rise of 52 million yen from 2009.

Other Taiwanese NPB baseball players who have received annual salaries of more than 100 million yen include Yasuaki Taiho (Chen Tai-feng in Chinese) who was earning 180 million yen, Kaku Taigen (Kuo Tai-yuan) and Kaku Genji (Kuo Yuen- chih).

DOC.HEADLINE: Spectacular New Year fireworks to be staged at Taipei 101: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 22:51:08 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The upcoming 2010 New Year fireworks show at Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest skyscrapers -- will be the most spectacular and colorful ever presented by the organizers, an official said Wednesday.
This will be the sixth year that the tower will ring in the New Year with a dazzling fireworks show.

According to Liu Chia-hao, a spokesman for the Taipei Financial Center Corp. that owns the building, the company will spend a record NT$30 million on the 188-second show, which is NT$10 million more than last year, in response to complaints by revelers that the 2009 event was not exciting enough.
Some 22,000 fireworks will be launched, the most ever and 6,600 more than last year, Liu said.

In addition, he said, the angles covered by the 2010 show will be the widest in history, with fireworks to be launched at angles of 180 degrees, 90 degrees, 45 degrees and 30 degrees from the Taipei 101 tower.

The show will also feature moving displays such as fire wheels, drifting stars and bouquet showers that will come in a full range of colors, including gold, silver, red, green, blue, purple and the seldom-used yellow, Liu said.

As part of the celebrations, a New Year's Eve party will be held at the Taipei 101 observatory on the 89th floor of the building, and partygoers will be treated to presentations of magic shows, a live band performance and a closup view of the fireworks show.
The party will be limited to 1,000 people and the tickets will cost NT$2,010 each.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Yunlin orange shipments head for Beijing, Xiamen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/02/09 23:24:01 (By C. K. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two containers of oranges from Yunlin County headed for Beijing and Xiamen Wednesday -- marking the first batch of a total of 980 metric tons of the fruit that China ordered from the central Taiwan County.

The Yunlin county government officials expressed the hope that Chinese customers could purchase more of the fruit as its harvest season has just begun and will run through January. They added that greater efforts will be made to diversify market outlets in China.

Taiwan produced about 254,000 metric tons of oranges every year in a total of 4,125 hectares of land, with half of the fruit being grown in Yunlin -- making the county the island's largest producer of oranges.
Apart from Yunlin, Tainan, Nantou and Kaohsiung also produce oranges.
Taiwan farmers' overproduction of oranges creates a headache for the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA).
Meanwhile, the COA is set to began purchasing oranges from local farmers next week to help deal with a foreseen oversupply and stabilize the fruit's price in retail markets.

COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said last week that the current market price for oranges is between NT$7.5 and NT$11 per kilo, and by purchasing them at NT$13.5 per kilo, the government will help in the earnings of farmers.
Oranges of inferior quality that the COA buys will be used to make organic fertilizer, and a subsidy program has also been launched to urge farmers to leave their land fallow, COA officials said.
Farmers agreeing to take part in the program are entitled to a subsidy of NT$200,000 (US$6,150) for each hectare of land they leave fallow. Last year, 347 hectares of land were made fallow.
According to Chen, the COA plans to purchase 1,870 metric tons of oranges for shipments to China this season, up from 1,200 metric tons last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 3, or the 17th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Madrid surrenders to French forces led by Napoleon Bonaparte.
1810: Britain captures the island of Mauritius from France.
1818: Illinois becomes the 21st state of the United States.
1828: John Quincy Adams loses the U.S. presidential election to his arch-rival Andrew Jackson.
1894: Robert Louis Stevenson, Scottish writer of essays, poetry and novels, dies at the age of 44. He authored "Treasure Island," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "Kidnapped."
1901: American film producer and film animator Walt Disney is born. He created such immortals as Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck.
1943: The Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference is issued simultaneously in Chungking, Washington and London.
1944: U.S. forces advance across the Saar River in Germany during World War II.
1948: Republic of China government troops evacuate Hsuchow in eastern China.
1958: Dutch businesses are nationalized in Indonesia.
1960: Chou Tao-chi graduates from National Chengchi University and becomes the first student to earn a national doctorate in the Republic of China.
1966: The Kaohsiung Export Processing Zone is inaugurated.
1966: Macau imposes a curfew after massive riots allegedly incited by the Communist Chinese.
1967: South African surgeon Dr. Christiaan Barnard successfully performs a human heart transplant, the first of its kind in the world.
1971: Pakistani planes attack northwest India in a dispute over Kashmir. India responds by declaring a state of emergency.
1975: Communists take control of Laos, declare an end to the 600-year-old monarchy and set up the People's Democratic Republic of Laos.
1976: Rear Adm. James H. Morris, commander of the amphibious forces of the U.S. 7th Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1983: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) wins a landslide victory in supplementary parliamentary elections. The KMT captures 62 of 71 seats up for grabs in the Legislative Yuan. The opposition wins six seats and independents take three.
1989: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev end a summit meeting on Malta in the Mediterranean Sea, signaling the end of the Cold War and entry into a new era of peace and cooperation.
1992: Millions of gallons of crude oil spill into the sea off the coast of La Coruna, Spain, threatening ecological disaster.
1993: Ukraine and the United States fail to resolve a dispute over Ukraine's stockpile of some 1,000 long-range nuclear warheads.
1994: The first popular elections for the governor of Taiwan Province and the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung municipalities are held. James C.Y. Soong is elected governor of Taiwan. Chen Shui-bian and Wu Den-yih win the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively.
1995: Chun Doo Hwan, former president of South Korea, is arrested on charges of military rebellion stemming from a 1979 coup and a later massacre of civilians by the army.
1997: South Korea signs a letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for a loan of US$57 billion, the largest of its kind ever provided by the IMF, to help South Korea get through its financial crisis.
1999: Visiting Malawian President Bakili Muluzi and his ROC counterpart Lee Teng-hui sign a communique reconfirming the friendship between their two countries.
2000: Francis Ng wins the "Best Leading Actor Award," Maggie Cheung wins the "Best Leading Actress Award," and To Kei-Fung wins the "Best Director Award" at the 2000 Golden Horse Awards.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says his party's dramatic win in legislative elections will not change his commitment to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that he is willing to share political power and resources with other political parties on the basis of mutual respect, to promote political stability, national identity and democratic reform.
Motse's lesson of the day: "We are certain that heaven desires to have men love and benefit one another and abominates to have them hate and harm one another."

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. will send officials to Taiwan to check passport security
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.2 (CNA) 12/03/09 08:24:40 (By Shih Hsing-yao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States is organizing a working group to visit Taiwan soon to inspect Taiwan's passport security measures, as the U.S. is considering whether to offer visa-free treatment to Taiwanese citizens, an official said Wednesday.

"The U.S. working group will consult with our government agencies in charge of passport affairs on possible measures to further enhance passport security," Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Shen Lyushun said at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and National Defense Committee.

According to Shen, the U.S. working group hopes to learn more about Taiwan's processing of its passport applications and will request that Taiwan makes it mandatory for its citizens to apply in person for passports to reduce the possibility of irregularities.

"The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is giving priority to the goal of securing visa-free treatment within one year for Taiwan passport holders traveling to the U.S. and European Union member countries, Shen told lawmakers.

While the U.S. Department of State and Congress are basically open to the proposal, he said, the U.S. Homeland Security Department is still reluctant to give the green light as the specter of the 911 terrorist attacks still remains.
"We need to make greater efforts to convince them that we have taken effective steps to plug the loopholes in the passport processing procedures," Shen said.
He briefed lawmakers on the U.S. government's policy and stance toward Taiwan, in the wake of President Barack Obama's recent visit to China.

Taiwan-U.S. relations will continue to move in a positive direction, following a recent briefing in Taipei by American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt on Obama's visit to China in November, Shen said.
For one thing, U.S. arms sales to Taiwan will continue, Shen forecast.

"While the U.S. may defer its decisions on some items, they will remain on the evaluation list, " Shen said, adding that the long-stalled talks under the Taiwan-U.S. Trade and Investment Framework Agreement will resume early next year.
Moreover, he added, the United States will continue to support Taiwan's efforts to participate meaningfully in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese baseball player in Japan gets steep pay raise
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/09 08:24:57 (By Hsiao pao-hsian and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Chen Wei-yin, a Taiwanese Nippon Professional Baseball (NPB) pitcher, re-signed Wednesday with the Chunichi Dragons in Japan's Central League for an annual salary of 110 million Japanese yen (US$1.15 million), a sharp rise from the 35 million yen he was offered in 2009, a Japanese newspaper reported Wednesday.

It took the Taiwanese left-handed pitcher only two years to secure a salary of over 100 million yen. When he returned in 2008 to play for the Dragons after a two-year break because of an elbow injury, he was earning six million yen, according to the Nikkansports newspaper.
The pay rise came in the wake of Chen's 1.54 earned run average (ERA) in the NPB's 2009 season, which was recorded as the best in nearly 40 years for the Dragons, the newspaper reported.
Chen said he was not disappointed with the pay he was offered in the new contract.
Chen played for the Chinese Taipei national baseball team in the 2004 and 2008 Olympic Games.
Meanwhile, right-hander Kazuki Yoshimi was offered 90 million yen for 2010, a pay rise of 52 million yen from 2009.

Other Taiwanese NPB baseball players who have received annual salaries of more than 100 million yen include Yasuaki Taiho (Chen Tai-feng in Chinese) who was earning 180 million yen, Kaku Taigen (Kuo Tai-yuan) and Kaku Genji (Kuo Yuen- chih).

DOC.HEADLINE: Spectacular New Year fireworks to be staged at Taipei 101: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/09 08:25:08 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The upcoming 2010 New Year fireworks show at Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest skyscrapers -- will be the most spectacular and colorful ever presented by the organizers, an official said Wednesday.
This will be the sixth year that the tower will ring in the New Year with a dazzling fireworks show.

According to Liu Chia-hao, a spokesman for the Taipei Financial Center Corp. that owns the building, the company will spend a record NT$30 million on the 188-second show, which is NT$10 million more than last year, in response to complaints by revelers that the 2009 event was not exciting enough.
Some 22,000 fireworks will be launched, the most ever and 6,600 more than last year, Liu said.

In addition, he said, the angles covered by the 2010 show will be the widest in history, with fireworks to be launched at angles of 180 degrees, 90 degrees, 45 degrees and 30 degrees from the Taipei 101 tower.

The show will also feature moving displays such as fire wheels, drifting stars and bouquet showers that will come in a full range of colors, including gold, silver, red, green, blue, purple and the seldom-used yellow, Liu said.

As part of the celebrations, a New Year's Eve party will be held at the Taipei 101 observatory on the 89th floor of the building, and partygoers will be treated to presentations of magic shows, a live band performance and a closup view of the fireworks show.
The party will be limited to 1,000 people and the tickets will cost NT$2,010 each.

DOC.HEADLINE: First Yunlin orange shipments head for Beijing, Xiamen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/09 08:25:20 (By C. K. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Two containers of oranges from Yunlin County headed for Beijing and Xiamen Wednesday -- marking the first batch of a total of 980 metric tons of the fruit that China ordered from the central Taiwan County.

The Yunlin county government officials expressed the hope that Chinese customers could purchase more of the fruit as its harvest season has just begun and will run through January. They added that greater efforts will be made to diversify market outlets in China.

Taiwan produced about 254,000 metric tons of oranges every year in a total of 4,125 hectares of land, with half of the fruit being grown in Yunlin -- making the county the island's largest producer of oranges.
Apart from Yunlin, Tainan, Nantou and Kaohsiung also produce oranges.
Taiwan farmers' overproduction of oranges creates a headache for the Cabinet- level Council of Agriculture (COA).
Meanwhile, the COA is set to began purchasing oranges from local farmers next week to help deal with a foreseen oversupply and stabilize the fruit's price in retail markets.

COA Minister Chen Wu-hsiung said last week that the current market price for oranges is between NT$7.5 and NT$11 per kilo, and by purchasing them at NT$13.5 per kilo, the government will help in the earnings of farmers.
Oranges of inferior quality that the COA buys will be used to make organic fertilizer, and a subsidy program has also been launched to urge farmers to leave their land fallow, COA officials said.
Farmers agreeing to take part in the program are entitled to a subsidy of NT$200,000 (US$6,150) for each hectare of land they leave fallow. Last year, 347 hectares of land were made fallow.
According to Chen, the COA plans to purchase 1,870 metric tons of oranges for shipments to China this season, up from 1,200 metric tons last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 10:02:48 (By Lilian Wu)
