DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier pushes for water conservation campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 11:54:55 (By Jiachen Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: It is time to introduce a water conservation campaign, as drastic climate changes and environmental degradation are prolonging the drought season in the Taiwan area, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Wednesday.

At an inter-agency meeting, Chu instructed the relevant offices to double their efforts to raise public awareness of the value of clean water and to highlight the need for conservation of the resource as shortages could occur at any time.

Chu gave a directive for the relevant offices to report before mid-December on the water supply situation in southern Taiwan so that the government can decide whether there is enough water for the first rice crop at the beginning of 2010, or if it should advise the plantation of other crops that require less water.
Similar reports on the water supply situation in northern and central Taiwan should be presented by mid-January, he said.

The vice premier also asked that Taiwan Water Corp. report soon on the water- pumping systems scattered throughout southern Taiwan that can serve as a back-up in the event of drought or water shortages early next year.

Chu convened the meeting after Water Resources Agency Director Yang Wei-pu said Monday that water reserves in reservoirs in southern Taiwan have fallen to alarming levels as a result of low rainfall and buildups of silt.
Water consumption in Taiwan is 274 liters per head per day, equivalent to emptying Sun Moon Lake in 20 days, Yang said, adding that water shortages may occur from early next year.

Meanwhile, Liu Chung-ming, director of the Global Change Research Center at National Taiwan University, said that although typhoons this year brought torrential rain to the island, this cannot avert the dry spell mainly because of excessive water usage and failure to collect the rain water.

"People from the south had better not to return to their homes for the upcoming Chinese New Year holiday (which falls in February 2010) , " Liu said in an interview with the United Daily News, suggesting that water shortages are just around the corner.

Quoting a research report compiled recently by his center, Liu said the number of dry days in the southern city of Tainan have averaged 204 per year in the past, but this year the number so far is 300.
"The drought situation is becoming more serious," he said.
He predicted that eastern Taiwan will have more wet days in years to come, while central and southern Taiwan will become drier and drier.
"People in western and southern Taiwan should prepare for droughts as the dry days could increase by 50 per year in the future," Liu warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers move to revise law to ban animated crime reporting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 13:28:49 (By Amy Huang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers, with the support of a civil group, is moving to revise a series of laws to ban sensational animated news on television, Websites and in other media.

The mass-circulated China Times said Thursday that the Social Welfare Committee and the Environment and Health Committee of the Legislative Yuan began debating a proposal Wednesday to ban "any detailed description of tools and methods used to commit crimes and suicides."

In a response to the recent controversy over animated graphic news published by the Apple Daily, the proposal will also prohibit "graphic animated news that includes bloody or obscene images of violence, sex, or horror."
In order to institute the ban, three acts that govern broadcast and television, satellite broadcast and television, and children and teenagers welfare, will have to be revised.

Kuomintang Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu, who sponsored the proposal along with KMT lawmakers Alex Hrong-tai Fai and Shyu Jong-shyoung, said the use of graphic images to reconstruct crime stories serves only to reopen the wounds of the victims and their family members.
"It tramples on the privacy of the victims, debauches the society and goes against the morals and ethics of journalism, " Hung was quoted in the China Times as saying.
She dismissed the idea of setting up a news rating system, saying it would not solve the problem. "Action News, " as it is called by Apple Daily, is not at all news, she added.
"In order to prevent other media from following the lead of the Apple Daily, an absolute ban should be imposed," Hung said.
A similar proposal was submitted by the Children Welfare League, through Kuomintang lawmakers Shyu Jong-shyoung, Huang Ho Tsai-feng and Lin Hung-chih, and was also debated at the meeting.
The Apple Daily's Action News is usually published on its Website and is also accessible by mobile phone.
After it copped two fines of NT$500,000 (US$15,547) each in two days, the newspaper on Nov. 28 issued an apology and restricted access to its Action News.

The fines were imposed by the Taipei City government on grounds that there were no restrictions for minors, after the National Communications Commission (NCC) said it could do nothing about the issue.
Amid the controversy, the Apple Daily group's plans to set up a a TV company suffered a setback, as the NCC on Wednesday returned its applications for three television licenses.

NCC Spokesman Chen Cheng-Chang was quoted by the China Times as saying that the Apple Group's "operation proposal," which is part of the application to explain how the TV programs will be presented, was too vague.
"We haven't turned down the applications, but the Apple Daily should allay public concerns by stating in the application how it plans to broadcast its programs," Chen was quoted as saying.

Meanwhile a private watchdog, the Media Monitoring Alliance, said Wednesday in its October Report that the Apple Daily is not the only paper that publishes sensational news accompanied by graphics or pictures that disregard journalistic principles.
The alliance said the Apple Daily topped the list with 46 stories, followed by the United Daily News with four, China Times with three, and Liberty Times with three.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan designer wins prize in major competition in New York
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/09 13:34:39 (By Jaw-Pyng Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese fashion designer Johan Ku won the top prize Wednesday in the Avant- Garde design category of a major fashion design competition in the U.S. for emerging talent.

Ku, owner of the Johan Ku Design Studio, won award in the 2009 Gen Art's Styles International Design Competition with one of his 2004 designs -- a knitted one- piece wool dress that highlights the delicacy of the yarn and displays creative patterns.
Ku, who is currently studying in London, returned to New York to attend the award ceremony in midtown Manhattan Wednesday evening.
"I'm thrilled to bits, " Ku told the Central News Agency after receiving the prize.
The prize would serve as a stepping stone for him to access the global fashion market, he said, adding that he looks forward to one day having his own brand and finding the right investment partners.

The 30-year-old, who graduated from Taiwan's Shu Te University with a first degree in fashion design and is now in a graduate program at London's Central Saint Martins School of Art and Design, expressed thanks to many people, particularly his mother, whom he said "never tried to stop me from pursuing my interests."
Wenlan Chia, a renowned Taiwanese fashion designer in New York who was one of the judges of the competition, offered her congratulations to Ku.
"With his talent and perseverance, Ku is set to make his name in the global fashion arena," Chia said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosan black bears with 'green style' enter stage

TEXT.P: Each of these three represents a unique quality in Taiwan -- an eye-catching creativity and cultural learning institute, a fashion design house with a global reputation, and the only local toy company authorized to make stuffed toys for the Disney Corporation.

All excel in their respective fields. However, they had not established any links with each other until this fall, when they decided to do something no-one has ever done before for the Formosan black bear, an endangered species indigenous to Taiwan.

In a unprecedented effort to promote a green lifestyle and wildlife protection, Lilin Hsu, the founder and chairman of the Xue Xue Institute, decided to feature the country's largest land animal as a soft toy and commissioned a young Taiwanese team to come up with the design, using green materials.

"In order to express a perspective about loving the Earth and supporting a green lifestyle, it is necessary to consider mass-producing something in a way that a commercial market can accept, " said Hsu, who is also well-known for her successful management of a Taiwanese department store in the 1980s.
Hsu noticed the work of the young design team Biaugust Creation Office at an exhibition, when it introduced its "Nonlife Zoo" series of artworks featuring species that are facing extinction.

Searching out suitable materials for her idea, Hsu went to her old friend Shiatzy Chen, a local fashion designer whose luxury brand was the first Taiwanese fashion brand to enter the European market and which was also described by the Asia Wall Street Journal as "the most popular Taiwanese fashion brand."
Chen donated four kinds of high quality fabrics to Hsu for the Formosan black bear soft toys, which are stuffed with ecological polyester staple cotton.
The limited edition of 800 of the toys, about 30 centimeters tall, are expected to go on sale in December for NT$600 each.

"They really look better and more creative than I would have thought, " said Chen, admitting that her decades-long friendship with Hsu was one of the reasons she was willing to support this cross-industry cooperation.
Letting more people know about their green approach and creating a platform for local young designers to showcase their work made Hsu's decision even more meaningful, Chen added.
Chen said she will not rule out the possibility cooperating with Hsu again if the toys attract enough attention from the public.
Hsu's first contact with her other partner in the venture -- leading toy maker Hwa Harng Toys Co. -- was not as smooth.

Hwa Harng, a toy company with a history of more than 30 years, is the only local toy manufacturer authorized to make toys for the Disney Corporation, the Japanese company that owns the rights to the anime character Doraemon, and a Taiwanese convenience stores mascot.
For Hwa Harng, Hsu's order was just too small, and it took Hsu a lot of effort to persuade the company to accept her custom.

"From a business point of view, it is not a good deal at all, " said Jim Chang, sales manager at Hwa Harng, adding that they nevertheless made an exception for Hsu, manufacturing her toys for no profit.
Each of the toys will come packaged in a Tyvek paper bag, which is made of strong polyethylene fiber that can be reused as a backpack or drawstring bag.
"It is another way of promoting environmental protection, as it is a multiple- use bag, " said Amy Wu, a Xue Xue manager.

In addition to the Formosan black bears, Xue Xue will also launch another six larger stuffed toys -- a Formosan macaque, a giraffe, a chicken, a cow, an elephant and a deer -- which will be sold along with a cup for NT$1,280 each, with a production run of 360 for each toy.
The toys made a shining debut when they first went on show at the Xue Xue headquarters in October.

According to Hsu, high-ranking officials from Hong Kong Disney decided to take all of them when they visited Xue Xue and have been in negotiation with Xue Xue over distribution rights in Hong Kong and China.
"Strength sometimes comes from a group, " said Hsu, expressing optimism about cooperating with more partners in the future to promote a green lifestyle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't targeting NT$100 b. output from digital publishing by 2013
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 15:01:50 (By Lee Ming-chung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The government plans to invest US$2.13 billion (US$65 million) over the next five years in Taiwan's digital publishing industry and will integrate the resources of related government agencies to achieve a production value target of NT$100 billion (US$3.1 billion) by 2013, Cabinet spokesman Su Chun-pin said Thursday.

Following a report to the Cabinet Wednesday by officials of the Industrial Development Bureau, Premier Wu Den-yih gave a directive for the Ministry of Economic Affairs to assist the industry to integrate the production of e-book devices, distribution of resources, and patent rights application, Su said.

The government plans to implement the plan through the development of the digital content industry, digital publishing and digital libraries, and the establishment of a business platform, according to Su.
He said that the premier emphasized the great market potential of the e-book business and the advantage Taiwan has in the field because of its advanced information industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to hold first national K-1 kickboxing competition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 15:12:26 (By Sarah Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The 2009 Chinese boxing (San Da) tournament and the first national K-1 kickboxing competition will be held in Taipei Friday, with winners from the past few years competing for the title of the first K-1 king of Taiwan.

The Chinese Boxing (San Da) Combat Association, which is organizing the event, has held four national San Da tournaments since it was established in 2003, but has not staged a national K-1 tournament before.
Taiwanese fighter Yang Tong-hsiung, winner of the 2008 K-1 World Grand Prix in Taipei, is seen as one of the front runners in the national competition.
Yang, the winner of the first San-Da tournament in 2005 and holder of the title "King of San-Da in Taiwan, " described K-1 as a sport that requires great endurance.
Yang is very fast and courageous, which makes him a good K-1 fighter, according to his Japanese coach.
TheKin K-1 stands for karate, kickboxing, kung fu and other standup martial arts, and also for "King," said Japan's Fighting and Entertainment Group (FEG), the organizer of the 2008 K-1 World GP.
San Da, also known as Chinese kickboxing, is basically kickboxing with throws, and it combines techniques from kung fu, kickboxing and freestyle wrestling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei among top 10 most expensive cities in Asia: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 15:18:25 (By Liu Chien-pang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei is among the 10 most expensive locations in Asia for international assignees, after Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagaya, Kobe, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Beijing and Singapore, according to a survey conducted by the consultant ECA International.

ECA International released a survey report Wednesday on cost of living in major cities in the world. Many international corporations use the biannual report as reference in calculating assignment salaries.

According to the report, Luanda in Angola remained the most expensive city in the world for two consecutive years 2008-2009, while four cities in Japan -- Tokyo, Yokohama, Nagoya and Kobe -- along with Oslo and Stavanger in Norway, Copenhagen in Demark, and Geneva and Zurich in Switzerland were listed among the top 10.

In Asia, with the strong yen outweighing the impact of deflation in the Japanese capital, Tokyo maintained its position as the most expensive location. The Korean capital Seoul moved up to seventh place in 2009, while Taipei and Kaohsiung fell in the rankings this year to 10th and 15th, respectively, as a result of declining prices.
Taipei's ranking in the world was 99th, as compared with 78th in 2008, and Kaohsiung's ranking in 2009 was 138th, dropping from 99th the previous year.

Although prices have generally remained stable, exchange rate fluctuations have contributed the most to changes in the cost of living for international assignees over the past year, according to ECA International.
The ECA survey compares a basket of consumer goods and services commonly purchased by assignees in over 390 locations worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: St. Vincent and Grenadines officials call for Taiwan investments
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 15:47:32 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Officials from St. Vincent and Grenadines (SVG), one of Taiwan's Caribbean allies, called on companies in Taiwan Thursday to invest in their country and explore its wide range of business opportunities in areas ranging from information communications technology (ICT), to renewable energy and tourism.

The delegation from Invest SVG, a government investment promotion agency, made the appeal at a seminar in Taipei, saying that SVG could serve as springboard for Taiwanese companies to tap into the markets of the Caribbean, Latin American and North America.

"Don't think of St. Vincent and the Grenadines as your only market, think of the world as your market and St. Vincent and Grenadines as your access point," said Cleo Huggins, executive director of Invest SVG.

Huggins said the delegation's visit is aimed at extending the longstanding relationship between her country and Taiwan, attracting foreign direct investment from Taiwan and helping Taiwanese companies explore business opportunities in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, which she described as having a "strong, vibrant and growing" investment climate.

It is an excellent time for Taiwan to capitalize on the investment opportunities in a wide range of business sectors such as agro-processing, light manufacturing, international financial services, ICT industries and tourism development in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, according to Huggins.

The country has a sound regulatory framework, political and economic stability, high educational standards and a skilled labor force of 63,000 people, and offers various attractive incentives from tax exemption to freedom to repatriate funds and the right to own property, she added.

Shirla Francis, director of Invest SVG and Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Telecommunications of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, said that Taiwan, with its world reputation for a strong ICT industry, should explore business opportunities in SVG in areas such as development of computer applications for both the public and private sectors, mobile phones repairs, computer programming, management of information systems and IT security and management.

"ICT is the platform on which sustainable economic development is attainable, as it acts as an enabler in all sectors of the economy, and SVG recognizes that partnerships with our friends can help us achieve an sustainable economy," Francis said.
"I hope the businesses in Taiwan will see the opportunities that SVG, as a small Caribbean island, has to offer. I do warmly invite you to explore some of those opportunities," she added.
Taiwan and SVG have had unbroken diplomatic ties for 29 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Vision Taiwan to honor foster families
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 16:01:01 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan chapter of the Christian charity World Vision said Thursday that it will hold a ceremony on Dec. 5 to honor families within its foster care service for their contribution to sheltering children who are victims of domestic violence and other forms of abuse.
"The foster family recognition ceremony will be a time for sharing many stories of love," the charity said in a press statement.

Since 1991, World Vision Taiwan has been operating foster care services, on commission by the Taipei City Department of Social Welfare, to provide safe temporary homes for thousands of abandoned or abused children.
World Vision reports show that in 2008, abuse, neglect, and domestic violence were the main reasons for putting children into foster care.
Therefore, foster families play an indispensable role in helping to protect children, World Vision Taiwan said.

It related the story of Xiao An, a victim of domestic violence who was also raped in her own home. Xiao An was later moved to a foster home, where she still felt dirty and often hurt herself, the charity reported. However, her foster mother has given her unconditional love and has consoled and cared for her in her darkest hours, it added.
"My foster family is the sanctuary in my life," Xiao An was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Executive Yuan sets up command center to deal with dengue fever
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 16:15:38 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the Executive Yuan Thursday to establish a central command to stem the spread of dengue fever.
Wu gave a directive for Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang to head the task force, which will be called the Central Epidemics Command Center against Dengue Fever.

The premier gave the directives in the wake of the country's first fatal case of dengue hemorrhagic fever this year, which occurred in November and amid worries that the dengue situation has escalated in Taiwan, particularly in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

"It's quite rare for dengue fever to intensify despite the fact that it is almost winter and low temperatures are not conducive to spread of the disease, " Wu said during a regular Executive Yuan meeting.
He instructed the DOH to find out why the situation has escalated and to implement a monitoring system that would enable local governments to deal with the problem in a timely manner.

The recent fatality was a 52-year-old woman surnamed Lee from Pingtung City, who was a polio patient with a history of heart disease and blood clots. She developed a fever, headache, nausea and vomiting around late November and died on Nov. 27 of internal bleeding caused by dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne infection that causes a severe flu- like illness, and sometimes a potentially lethal complication called dengue hemorrhagic fever.
Taiwan has reported seven cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever and more than 600 cases of regular dengue fever cases so far this year, according to the Centers for Disease Control.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 17:03:53 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 7.05 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 7,684.67.
The local bourse opened at 7,733.51 and fluctuated between 7,738.03 and 7,658.51 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.62 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$113.91 billion (US$3.54 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial shares moving up the most at 0.95 percent. Textile stocks increased 0.23 percent, machinery and electronics shares advanced 0.07 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares gained 0.05 percent.

The four other major stock category lost ground, with construction issues moving down the most at 1.11 percent. Paper and pulp issues decreased 0.86 percent, foodstuff issues dropped 0.78 percent, and cement stocks shed 0.42 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,617 to 959, with 270 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$6.48 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor questions appropriateness of protest zone
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 18:07:02 (By Hao Hsueh-chin, Chou Yung-chieh and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The mayor of the city that will host the fourth round of negotiations between Taiwan and China on Dec. 21 questioned Thursday the appropriateness of setting up a protest zone to accommodate demonstrators during that time.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Thursday it's not a well-conceived plan, and that its constitutionality is questionable.

"City Hall has no plans to set up such a zone, " Hu said, in direct opposition to an announcement made Wednesday by Ma Shao-chang, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, the semi-official body that handles negotiations with China in the absence of official ties.
"I do not know whose idea is it or who is working on such a plan," Hu added.
According to law, the site of a demonstration should be chosen by the protestors and is subject to approval by City Hall, Hu said.

"It is unusual to set up a demonstration zone before anyone has applied for permission to hold a protest," he added. "Are the authorities willing to violate the Constitution in order to limit the people's freedom to stage demonstrations?"

Ma Shao-chang said Wednesday that the planned protest zone will be able to accommodate 60,000 people, and is big enough for different groups that might like to express their opinions during the negotiations.

Ma did not disclose the exact location of the protest zone, but the United Daily News said Thursday it would be in a lot across the street from the Windsor Hotel where the Chinese delegation will be staying.
The paper said the lot, as well as the hotel, belong to the Pou Chen Group.
The lot is about 60 meters away from the hotel, well within seeing and hearing distance, but is beyond striking distance for stone-throwing, according to the report.
It will allow for protestors' voices to be heard by the Chinese delegation but not for any disruptions of the negotiations, the paper cited a source as saying.

Meanwhile, the city's police chief Hu Mu-yuan said Thursday that people who intend to hold a protest should first seek permission from the police, a statement that refuted a media report that protestors may demonstrate freely in the protest zone.
"Applications should be filed six days before the demonstration," he said, citing the Assembly and Parade Act.
However, he expressed doubts over the suitability of the lot mentioned by the United Daily News, saying it is too big and that its surface is uneven and covered with rocks.
Premier Wu Den-hih said that he will ask the SEF to discuss with the Taichung city government on issues related to proposed protest zone.

In order to finalize the details of the negotiations, a Taiwan team led by SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian will depart for Fuzhou, Fujian Province on Dec. 9 for talks with their Chinese counterparts from the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

The Chinese delegation for the fourth round of cross-strait negotiations will be led by ARATS President Chen Yunlin whose visit to Taiwan in November 2008 for the second round of talks in Taipei was marred by protests.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 18:08:58 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.02 to close at NT$32.15.
A total of US 947 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.20 and fluctuated between NT$32.093 and NT$32.208.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 18:12:11 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday: CHINA TIMES: Accurate reporting produces journalistic freedom
The Liberty Times recently published a front-page photo that it claimed was of a recent presidential motorcade that had inconvenienced the public.
The Presidential Office responded by saying that the road pictured has no shoulder and that the motorcade was one of former President Chen Shui-bian's, not President Ma Ying-jeou's.

Nonetheless, the newspaper said defiantly that it had identified the photo as a composite image and it refused to apologize. We believe this practice is a gross violation of journalistic ethics. Even though the media cannot guarantee that all its news stories would be factual, or that the facts would be fully verified, it has to give the assurance that it is reporting the truth. It should not publish photos that it knows are not accurate and simply caption them as composite images.
We support the response of the subject of the story. The Presidential Office chose to make a public clarification, but has not threatened any lawsuits. Instead, it has asked only for an apology.

The media should uphold journalistic ethics and should not try to create an environment that will induce government intervention. Media organizations that report the news accurately are the ones that will enjoy the greatest journalistic freedom. LIBERTY TIMES:
Japanese envoy's resignation highlights President Ma's China-leaning nature

Japan's representative to Taiwan Masaki Saito tendered his resignation recently, ostensibly for personal reasons, but it is obvious that he resigned because he could not perform his duties in Taiwan as he was being shunned by the Ma administration. Saito has been given the cold shoulder by the administration since he commented in May during a speech that "Taiwan's status remains uncertain."
His resignation will remove the thorn in the side of the Ma administration and will delight China, but the big losers will be the Taiwan people.

Japan relinquished its sovereignty over Taiwan and Penghu under the San Francisco Peace Treaty, but did not transfer the islands to anyone. Under international law, Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to its people.

The Chiang Kai-shek army only came to Taiwan to accept the surrender of the Japanese army after World War II. It moved its seat of government to Taiwan in 1949 after its defeat by the Chinese Communists in a civil war.
Thus, Taiwan's official name is the Republic of China, although the sovereignty of Taiwan is totally unrelated to that of the ROC. Saito's statement simply reflected that fact.
President Ma advocates the fallacy of "ultimate unification," and it is only natural that he would resent Saito's views on the issue. APPLE DAILY: Encouraging crime
Sixteen years ago, a man killed his girlfriend and dumped her body. He was sentenced to two years, nine months and 11 days in prison.
Now, he has killed again. This time, he shot his girlfriend at close range, in gangland style execution, thinking that he will be given another lenient sentence.
If he had been imprisoned long enough for the first murder, he might not have acted so rashly again.
He thinks people's lives are cheap, so he killed again.

We believe there were at least three accomplices in this crime -- the other two being the judge and the parole officer who showed this man mercy 16 years ago. UNITED DAILY NEWS: No more using ECFA to tear apart Taiwan

The most serious problem in Taiwan is division. It is divided on various issues, ranging from national identity, cross-strait policy to ethnicities. No wonder, even the disgraced former President Chen Shui-bian during his term quoted the late U.S. President Abraham Lincoln by saying "A house divided against itself can not stand."

A pluralistic society will naturally have different voices, but if there is constant confrontations and divisions, then it will "not stand." For over two decades, local politicians have tried to create a wedge among the public.
It has created a polarized society. Taiwanese versus mainlanders, Love Taiwan versus not love Taiwan, blue camp versus green camp, southern Taiwan versus northern Taiwan.
Mow a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China has proven to be a new way to tear apart the nation.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has used the issue to divide the nation into agricultural cities and counties and those that are not, and into those who are for the agreement and those who are not.

The DPP has made the ECFA bashing its major platform. DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen said during a campaign rally that the Ma administration has done nothing that has helped or benefited the people during the past 18 months.
She said that the signing of the ECFA will allow Chinese products to enter Taiwan tariff free, and that the agriculture sector will bear the brunt of it.
The DPP has endeavored to turn a complex issue into a simplified concept of the Ma administration's "tilting toward China and selling out Taiwan."

We think that the DPP only knows how to oppose without coming up with its own answers to the problems faced by Taiwan. When the ASEAN plus one (China) is put into effect next month, Taiwan's major industries will immediately face unequal tariff treatment in China. Does the party know that if these major industries lose their competitive edge, not only will Taiwan's agricultural sector be impacted, the entire nation could face a major crisis.
COMMERCIAL TIMES: Is Taiwan ready to seize the opportunities unleashed by China in its economic transformation?

With the closer trade exchanges that are taking place between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, more and more Chinese trade delegations are visiting Taiwan. Among them was one led by Lou Qinjian, deputy chief of China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology.

Lou said before his departure from Taiwan earlier this week that the two sides could work on trade opportunities in five sectors -- LCD, semiconductor, telecommunications, green energy and cloud computing.

For Taiwan, which enjoys an edge in manufacturing technology in the telecommunications sector, it will be an opportunity and a challenge. Government agencies should also ease the relevant regulations so that Taiwan will not be marginalized in the fierce market competition.
But a more important question is whether Taiwan is ready to seize the rare trade opportunities? ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS: Only one out of 10 public grievances hard to root out
Premier Wu Den-yih asked the Executive Yuan's Research, Development and Evaluation Commission to list 15 public grievances and find the top 10 through a survey.
The result showed that high housing prices in urban areas top the list.

The other complaints are rampant telephone or online fraud, difficulty in landing jobs and the unemployment problem, high consumer prices, drug abuse, too many traffic tickets and the strict vehicle towing policy, unsafe nurseries, unclean public toilets, lax food safety inspections, and illegal use of arcades, roads, or parking lots.
We believe that it is an incomprehensive approach to choose 10 out of the 15, and that it is easy for the government to solve the problems if it has the determination.
But we believe the real thorny question is drug abuse, which we believe has to do with the collusion between Taiwan's gangsters and politicians and businessmen.
The government has so far adopted an appeasement attitude, and has never come up with affective measures.
If the Wu Cabinet can solve the other nine problems, and then pull out all stops to crack down on the gangsters, then it will be a boon to the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma planning to visit South Pacific allies in early 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 18:30:31 (By Sinyao Shih and Deborah Ku)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is planning to visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region in early 2010 and attend a Taiwan-South Pacific leaders' summit, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

President Ma was originally scheduled to visit the South Pacific and attend the leaders' summit in the Solomon Islands in October. The plan, however, was canceled due to Typhoon Morakot, which walloped southern and eastern Taiwan in August. The worst typhoon to hit Taiwan in 50 years killed more than 600 people.

"Climate change will be one of the topics expected to be discussed by President Ma and his South Pacific counterparts during the summit," said Bau-shuan Ger, deputy director-general of the MOFA Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs.

Climate change is an important issue for the South Pacific and all Taiwan's six allies in that region will be represented at the next conference of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change slated to be held in Copenhagen, Denmark from Dec. 7-18 this year, Ger said.
Other issues of mutual concern, including agriculture, medical services and vocational training, are also expected to be on the summit's agenda, Ger said.

Heads-of-state of all Taiwan's six diplomatic allies in the South Pacific region, namely the Solomon Islands, the Marshall Islands, Palau, Kiribati, Nauru and Tuvalu, are expected to attend the summit, whose exact date has yet to be decided, according to Ger.
The leadership summit will be the third of its kind since Sept. 4, 2006, when it was first held in Palau, and Taiwan was represented by then President Chen Shui- bian.
The upcoming trip will be President Ma's first visit to the South Pacific since he took office in May 2008. He previously visited the Solomon Islands in 1997 in his capacity as a professor.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai to buy Dell factory in Poland
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 18:57:21 (By Carol Yeh and Fanny Liu )

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Hon Hai Group has signed a deal to buy U.S. computer giant Dell's factory in Poland, further expanding its operation territory in Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA).

Following the transfer, Dell will become a customer of Foxconn, a division of Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., sourcing its desktops, notebooks, servers and storage systems for EMEA customers from the Lodz factory in central Poland, according to company announcements.

In a statement published late Wednesday, Hon Hai said PCE Paragon Solutions Kft., one of its units, has signed a contract to buy the facility with Dell Global B.V. and Dell International Holdings VIII B.V..

Financial details of the transfer were not disclosed and the agreement is subject to all the usual European Union regulatory approval and closing procedures. All employees at the Polish facility will keep their jobs and their positions.

After the deal is completed, industry analysts expect Hon Hai will be able to receive more orders from Dell, including the orders for making Dell's notebooks in 2011, threatening other Taiwanese outsourcing factories for Dell, such as Lite-On Technology, Pegatron Corp., Wistron Corp., and Quanta Computer.
Yuanta Securities analyst Chen Feng-feng noted that as the factory in Poland has been under gross profit margin pressure, the transfer will have limited impact on Hon Hai's profit in 2010.

UBS Securities is more optimistic about Hon Hai's performance next year. It issued a abuyrating on Hon Hai Wednesday, and raised its target price for the stock in 2010 to NT$184, from the previous target price of NT$144.

The deal with Dell is the latest acquisition launched by Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract electronics maker, after it announced in November that its affiliate Innolux will merge with Chi Mei Optoelectronics to bid for the liquid crystal display (LCD) industry's top position, and September's decision of buying a Sony's LCD TV assembly plant in Mexico.
Hon Hai shares were at NT$138.5 when the market closed Thursday, up NT$0.5 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to create 99,000 jobs next year: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 19:05:29 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih has directed the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to formulate employment promotion measures with the goal of creating 99,000 jobs next year, government spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.
Wu said at a regular Cabinet meeting that as unemployment is a lagging indicator of the economy, the government should treat boosting employment one of its top priorities, according to Su.

Wu said he has therefore asked the country's top economic planning agency in collaboration with related agencies to map out the 2009 employment promotion measures with the goal of creating 99,000 jobs, since the 2008-2009 Short-term Employment Promotion Measures will conclude at the end of this year and about 45,000 temporary jobs offered under the program will end by that time, Su said after the meeting.

Considering that about 80 percent of the short-term employees need some employment services, the premier also asked the Council of Labor Affairs and related government agencies to strengthen employment consultation and vocational training services in a bid to reduce unemployment and meet the needs of employers and employees.

Wu also said that related agencies should adjust their employment-boosting measures in keeping with the central government's policies to stimulate economic growth and increase employment over the next year.

For example, they should chart plans for strengthening vocational training to improve employment in six key emerging industries that are slated for priority development -- tourism, health care, biotechnology, green energy, cultural and creative industries, and high-end agriculture, Wu said.

Meanwhile, Wu said that Vice Premier Eric Lilun Chu will convene an inter- ministerial meeting to boost employment during the period around the Lunar New Year as the local job market would likely still be struggling because the economy has not shown any signs of a strong rebound.
Wu made the remarks at the meeting after being briefed by the CEPD on the current employment situations and the responding strategies.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to earmark budget to help reduce ECFA impact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 19:20:34 (By P. C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: To help minimize the impact of a planned Taiwan-China trade pact on some local businesses, the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will earmark NT$300 million (US$9.23 million) next year to serve that end, the bureau announced Thursday.

The bureau said it has managed to come up with NT$100 million in funds to finance a set of auxiliar measures worked out by the MOEA with an aim to help some sectors overcome possible negative effects arising from an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries.
Twelve traditional sectors such as bedding, towel, ceramics and footwear, are widely believed to be most affected once the ECFA and FTAs take effect.

The bureau said that it will allocate an additional NT$300 million from April next year to subsidize the auxiliar measures over the long term, which include setting up a certification system for locally produced fine-quality goods and creating an emblem for high-end quality products.
A task force will also be formed and hold meetings periodically to assess the best means to help affected sectors in industrial transformation or competitiveness upgrading, it added.

Meanwhile, it was reported that ECFA-related issues will be discussed in the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations when top negotiators from Taiwan and China meet later this month in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

According to Ministry of Economic Affairs officials, the government hopes that formal ECFA negotiations can start by January 2010, when representatives of the two sides will exchange lists of products they hope will be covered by an early harvest program under the trade deal.

Taiwan's government hopes the agreement to be signed as soon as possible in the face of increased economic integration in Asia, evidenced by an "ASEAN plus one" arrangement which will take effect early next year and by an "ASEAN plus three" pact by 2013.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local company to invest in Slovakian LCD plant
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 19:41:22 (By Pan Chi-i and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan-based AU Optronics (AUO) has announced that it will invest more than 191 million euros (US$280 million) from 2010 to set up a liquid crystal display (LCD) plant in the Slovak Republic.
The plant, which will be responsible for manufacturing, assembling and selling back-end LCD modules, is AUO's second manufacturing base in Europe, a company spokesman said Thursday.

AUO Chairman K.Y. Lee, who signed a letter of intent on the issue with Slovakian Economic Minister Lubomir Jahnatek a day earlier, said Europe is one of the major markets for LCD TVs. AUO, the world's third-largest LCD panel maker, also sees Europe as a market with high growth potential for the company's green business.

The signing ceremony was witnessed by Slovakian Deputy Prime Minister Dusan Caplovic and Chen Chiun-ming, representative of the Taipei Representative Office in the Slovakian capital of Bratislava, according to the company.

Slovakia is located in Central Europe and has been a member of the euro zone since 2009. The country not only offers high quality and competitive human resources but also enjoys stable economic development, Lee added.

Jahnatek said at the signing ceremony that Slovakia warmly welcomes AUO's decision to establish a manufacturing plant in the country as the move is in line with the country's policy of attracting investment from industries promoting innovation, research and high technology.
AUO also has LCD factories in Taiwan's Lungtan and Taichung, as well as plants in China's Suzhou, Songjiang and Xiamen and in the Czech Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's visually-impaired go on cycling tour to promote confidence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 19:53:13 (By Lee Hsi-chang, Lee Chia-fei and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Thirty visually-impaired people peddled on a two-day cycling tour Thursday to challenge themselves in a celebration of the International Day of Persons with Disabilities.

Organized by the Taichung City Society for the Welfare of the Visually Impaired, the event is aimed at encouraging the visually-impaired to walk out into the world and embrace society through cycling.

Accompanied by one volunteer each, the participants left for a 70 km two-day bicycling trip Thursday from Taichung City's Guang Fu Elementary School. Their destination is a leisure farm in Taichung County's Tachia township.

"Blind people should always keep a healthy mindset and be brave to walk out so as to gain assistance and care from others," said Liu Ching, chairman of the Taichung City Society for the Welfare of the Visually Impaired.

Hsiao Chia-chi, deputy mayor of Taichung City, presented a grant to the visually-impaired participants and praised their courage in challenging themselves, as it would help raise public awareness about the welfare of people with visual disabilities.
He also vowed to build Taichung City into a barrier-free environment "full of love."

Chen Mei-huei, one of the participants in the cycling event, expressed gratitude to those who have helped her and said that she joined the event not only for health reasons, but also to expand her circle of friends.

International Day of Persons with Disabilities, observed on Dec. 3 each year, was designated by the United Nations in 1992. This year's theme is "Making the Millennium Development Goals Inclusive: empowerment persons with disabilities and their communities around the world."

Noting that of Taiwan's 23 million population, there are over one million people live with disabilities, Premier Wu Den-yih said at a Cabinet-level meeting Thursday that the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) should speed up building Taiwan into a barrier-free island and establish a long-term health care system to look after the needs of people with disabilities.

According to the MOI, under the government whitepaper on promotion of the rights and welfare of persons with disabilities, the agency has mapped out 348 mid-term and long term action plans to cover the needs of physically-challenged people, including long term health care insurance, vocational training and employment services.

Turning to the Ministry of Justice's (MOJ's) review of the two United Nations human rights treaties that cleared Taiwan's legislative floor this March -- the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights -- Wu said all government agencies should regularly hold seminars on human rights to internalize the ideas of these two covenants as part of the governments administrative culture and to help civil servants learn to respect the rights of the people.
"Human rights can never just be a beautiful word, but rather something that can be felt by the people," the premier said.
President Ma Ying-jeou requested the MOJ in July to review and revise laws and regulations that were not in accordance with the two U.N. human rights covenants.

According to the MOJ, a total of 16 government agencies and 219 laws and regulations have yet to meet the requirements of these two covenants and the ministry will report to Ma before Dec. 10 Human Rights Day and announce the revised regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health authorities urged to re-examine HIV/AIDS therapy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 20:21:27 (By Chen Li-ting, Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A civic group fighting for the rights of HIV/AIDS patients urged the health authorities Thursday to re-examine the HIV anti-viral therapy in light of the treatment's declining efficacy.

"More than 10 years after highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) was introduced into Taiwan, we have discovered that the panacea might be losing its magic, " said Yang Hui-chung, a director of the Persons with HIV/AIDS Rights Advocacy Association of Taiwan.

The results of a survey conducted by the association among a group of 1,058 HIV- positive individuals between July 25 and Nov. 20 reveal that 321 of the respondents have been provided with antiretroviral medication.

Among 163 respondents who have taken the drugs for at least one year, 35, or 21.5 percent, saw their CD4 count register under 350 cells per cubic millimeter of blood, and in 22 of the patients, or 13.5 percent, HIV remained detectable in their blood.
This indicates a failure of the therapy to produce satisfactory results, despite long-time treatment, Yang said.
CD4 cells, which help to identify, attack and destroy specific bacteria, fungi and viruses that affect the body, are a major target for HIV. The CD4 count decreases with HIV disease progression.
The CD4 count is used in combination with HIV viral load to determine the progression and outlook of the disease and to monitor the effectiveness of treatment.

The survey also found that one in every four patients who has received HAART has experienced severe or very severe side effects, while one in six has had his or her work and living patterns seriously or very seriously affected.

One HIV-infected man who contracted the virus more than 10 years ago said that all three categories of antiretroviral drugs currently available in Taiwan are showing poor results because HIV has become resistant.
He said that over the years, the drug combinations for his treatment have been changed more than 10 times and he has had to endure various side effects, including severe diarrhea.
He urged the Department of Health (DOH) and the Bureau of National Health Insurance to speed up the pace of introducing new antiretroviral drugs into Taiwan.
"I want to live. All I ask for is basic life-saving drugs that will allow me to continue to survive," he said.
Meanwhile, Yang suggested that the DOH advance the timing for the beginning of therapy for HIV-positive people in order to increase the treatment's efficacy.
According to guidelines set by the DOH, therapy should be initiated only when an HIV-infected person registers a CD4 count of under 200 cells per cubic millimeter of blood.
But Yang said Taiwan should follow the World Health Organization's recommendation and provide patients with the therapy earlier, at 350 cells per cubic millimeter of blood.

Also Thursday, the Taiwan Lourdes Association -- a Catholic organization serving people living with HIV/AIDS -- called the authorities' attention to the long- term care for HIV/AIDS patients, as the antiretroviral therapy has helped prolong the life of these patients.

Due to their weakened immune systems, many HIV-positive individuals also suffer from other chronic diseases such as hepatitis, hypertension, diabetes, metabolic arthritis, depression and human papillomavirus infection, the association noted.
Official statistics show that as of October, 18,815 HIV/AIDS cases had been recorded in Taiwan, 15,533 of whom are still surviving.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reiterates pledge to probe vote-buying allegations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 20:36:58 (By Shu-hua Lee, Garfie Li, Vicky Hsu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that he will not intervene, but will fully support prosecutors in probing vote-buying allegations in relation to the Saturday's elections for county magistrates and city mayors.
Ma said as long as there is suspicions of bribery, the prosecution authorities must investigate, no matter which party or candidate is involved.
Cracking down on election bribery did not just start now, said Ma, adding that he also took it seriously when he was the Minister of Justice over 10 years ago.
However, as bribery cases still exist, Ma said a more aggressive approach on probing vote-buying allegations should be taken. He hopes that all voters can cooperate to eliminate unfair elections.

Among suspected bribery and violence cases reported to prosecutors' offices throughout the country, 60 suspects having been indicted and 98 taken into custody as of Dec. 2, according to figures provided by the Ministry of Justice.
Premier Wu Den-yih said on the same day that he was pleased about the Justice Ministry's performance on cracking down against suspected bribery cases without distinction of party.
Meanwhile, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's legislative whip, Wang Sing-nan, said at a press conference that the upcoming election is the most severe one in terms of vote-buying.
Wang quoted the media's reports in saying that candidates have been offering bribes ranging from NT$500 to NT$30,000 per person for voters to support them.
In Pingtung County, the bribes were reported to be NT$500 per person, and in the outlying county of Kinmen and Lienchiang, the bribes were reportedly as high as NT$30,000 per person, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipower employees protest for better retirement welfare
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 20:54:34 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 10,000 employees of the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) protested Thursday in front of the Presidential Office, demanding better retirement welfare and company restructuring.

The protesters, organized by the company labor union, demanded that the government compensate retirees for losses incurred due to the enforcement of the Labor Pension Act in 2005 and allow company retirees to enjoy better pension terms under the Labor Standards Law.

The employees also raised the issue that for many years the government-owned company's organization has failed to be in line with reality, recruiting many people as laborers but putting them to work as office clerks. Pension welfare packages for clerks are much better than those for laborers, according to the union.

As a government enterprise, Taipower has a peculiar company organization with about 70 percent of the employees -- around 19,000 -- enjoying dual capacities as government functionaries as well as employees of business or industrial establishments.

Under the Labor Standards Law, with the enforcement of the National Pension Act in January 2008, the lump-sum benefits formerly paid out to a retired laborer upon death, disability or old age has been converted to a monthly annuity at an income replacement ratio of 1. 55 percent, with old-age benefits available in principle from age 60 to anyone who has been enrolled in the plan for 15 years.

Since government functionaries upon retirement are entitled only to a monthly annuity at an income replacement ratio of 0.65 percent, many Taipower employees have expected that they will be able to enjoy better terms as retired laborers. Employees of other state enterprises have also made similar petitions.

The Commission of National Corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has convened meetings with other government agencies, including the Ministry of Finance and the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, to figure out the financial cost of allowing all 42,000 employees of state enterprises with dual capacities to be covered as laborers.

No decision has been made due to objections from the Council of Labor Affairs, which is concerned about the possibility that the already heavily burdened Labor Pension Fund would go bankrupt if such provisions were made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum initiative on U.S. beef to be submitted to CEC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 21:01:58 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A civic initiative that calls for a referendum on U.S. beef imports will be submitted to the Central Election Commission (CEC) next week following the completion of a first-stage signature drive, an organizer said Thursday.

A total of 206,880 signatures have already been collected for the initiative, which demands a re-opening of talks with Washington on U.S. beef imports, according to Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the Consumers' Foundation, which is leading the movement.
Hsieh urged consumers who have not signed the petition to take part in the second phase of the signature drive, in which the foundation hopes to collect 1.2 million signatures.

Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and beef offal, sparking a huge public outcry.

Civic groups led by the Consumers' Foundation and politicians contend that allowing the entry of products that are considered at high risk of spreading bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, could endanger the health of local consumers.
With their appeals for re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef talks having been rejected by the government, the groups decided to push for a referendum to allow the people a say on the issue.

Under Taiwan's referendum law, a referendum proposal must pass two thresholds to be accepted. In the initial stage, signatures from 0.5 percent, or 86,000, of the 17.32 million eligible voters in the last presidential election must be collected, a threshold that has already been met by the civic groups.

If a referendum screening committee finds that the proposed referendum conforms to legal guidelines, the referendum's sponsors then need to collect signatures of endorsement from 5 percent of the voters, or 860,000 signatures, for the question to be put to a referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung expects to have world-class opera house by 2013
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 21:42:12 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih and Emile Shen, Minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, joined Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Thursday at the groundbreaking of the Taichung Metropolitan Opera House on the west side of the city.

Wu said the opera house, which will accommodate a main auditorium with 2,011 seats, a theater with 800 seats and a smaller theater with 200 seats, will be one of the most unique architectural structures in Asia when it is completed at the end of 2013.

Japanese architect Toyo Ito, who won the contract after a contest for the project in 2005, said at the groundbreaking ceremony that he would bring together the best resources to build one of the best metropolitan opera houses in the world.

The Taichung city council approved a revised construction budget plan last year. The construction cost is estimated at NT$3.57 billion (around US$110 million), of which NT$1.78 billion will come from the central government and NT$1.79 billion will be raised by the local government.

Although the city government was planning to adopt an "OT" (operation and transfer) model, inviting private businesses to run the opera house and transfer the operations to the government after a certain number of years, the seven open bids held over the past four years failed to attract private investors. Some of the bids were aborted and some had no contenders at all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan announces new rules to stem H1N1 infections at schools
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:02:21 (By H. K. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) announced Thursday a new rule to partially replace the previous "325" guideline for schools nationwide to follow as part of the government's efforts to stem cluster infections of influenza A(HIN1) among students.

According to the ministry, the new "814" rule requires that individual students who have flu-like symptoms take days off if 80 percent of the students at the school have been vaccinated and have developed immunity against swine flu.

Taiwan began a national swine flu immunization program Nov. l, with people entitled to one free shot in order of priority, starting with typhoon-affected victims, medical personnel in charge of disease control and prevention, and pregnant women.

They were followed by toddlers and preschool children, seriously ill patients, elementary, junior and senior high school students, individuals in the 19 to 24 age bracket and those over 25 years of age at high risk of cardiopulmonary disease.
Next to be vaccinated were healthy people in the 25-49 age bracket and those between 50 and 64 years of age.

Based on the "325" guidelines published Aug. 18 by the Central Epidemics Command Center under the Cabinet-level Department of Health, classes at kindergartens, primary schools and junior and senior high schools, as well as cram schools and day-care centers, must be closed for five days to prevent cluster infections if any two students in the same class are diagnosed with H1N1 within a period of three days.
The MOE made the change on the grounds that the antibody against the virus will develop 14 days after vaccination against the HIN1 virus, ministry officials said.
Schools covered by the "814" rule will no longer be subject to the "325" guidelines.

Following an inspection of an elementary school in Taipei County later Thursday, Education Minister Wu Ching-chi said the spread of influenza A(HIN1) has slowed at schools around the country after the government's immunization program kicked in Nov. 1, with elementary, junior and senior high school students getting shots from Nov. 16-30.
Wu said the number of class closures had dropped in the last week, a sign indicating that swine flu infections have been brought under control after the peak infection season in November.
As of that day, the number of classes closed had fallen to 1,046, down from 1,925 Nov. 27, which accounted for 2 percent of the country's total classes.
Taipei County in northern Taiwan has been the administrative area most affected, having closed up to 25 percent of the county's total classes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cardiovascular deaths in Taipei on increase: health department
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:10:05 (By Jian Chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei city health officials said Thursday that deaths from cardiovascular disease (CVD) in Taiwan's capital increased last year compared to the 1999 figure.
The officials said that every two hours and 27 minutes, a person died from CVD in 2008, compared to the 1999 figure of three hours and two minutes.
The officials said CVD claimed 3,587 lives in the city last year, which made it the number two cause of death, while cancer still topped the list.
The fatality rate for heart disease was the highest among all the forms of CVD for both men and women, the officials added.

More men than women died from heart disease in 2008, as heart disease death rates per 100,000 people were 100.3 for males and 54. 4 for females, which were up 46.9 percent and 35.9 percent, respectively, from 1999.

The CVD death rate for people under the age of 24 increased 90.8 percent from 1999, while the heart disease death rate for this age group was more than double -- rising 218 percent compared to 10 years ago.
In contrast, the CVD death rate for the 45-64 age group and for the age group above 65 were both lower than a decade ago. However, the age group above 65 still recorded the highest number of deaths.
The officials noted that CVD is closely related to age and obesity, with smokers and patients with the "three-highs" -- high blood pressure, high blood sugar and high blood lipoid -- most at risk.
They suggested that people over 40 should get the health department's free blood screening tests and enroll on its quit smoking programs.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) , CVD is the number one cause of death globally. More people die annually from it than from any other cause and an estimated 17.1 million people died from CVD in 2004, representing 29 percent of all global deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think tank calls for panel industry investment in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:24:38 (By Tien Yu-pin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should allow the flat panel display industry to invest in China to avoid it losing its importance in the Chinese market in the wake of South Korea's LG Display Co. Ltd. establishing a joint venture Nov. 16 to build its 8.5th- generation liquid crystal display (LCD) panel production line in China, a local private think tank said Thursday.

Following the lifting of a South Korean ban on flat panel investment in China, China is expected to introduce a spate of protectionist measures to protect the joint venture, including new barriers to investment, high tariffs, and a minimum initial investment, said Yang Sheng-fan, deputy director of the Topology Research Institute (TRI).
Jointly constructed by Guangzhou Development District and LG Display, the new LCD panel plant will start construction in 2010 and is expected to go into production in 2012.
Once the new LCD panel project is completed, Taiwan's panel makers could lose its advantage in terms of cost competitiveness in the Chinese market, Yang said.

The government should come up with complementary measures as it makes plans for local panel makers to break into the market, in order to help them sustain their competitive edge in the industry, Yang said.

For example, the industry should keep its research and development centers in the country and establish 10th-generation and 11th- generation panel production lines in Taiwan to ensure that the country's industry is in line with the global trend and has the capability and technology to develop next-generation products such as organic light-emitting diodes and flexible display devices.
TRI analyst Corwin Lee predicted that before 2020 the global panel industry will continue to face an oversupply, causing a slump in prices.

Under the scenario, products made by Japan and South Korea are expected to hold a certain portion of the market share due to brand loyalty, so Taiwan's panel makers, in the face of weak domestic consumption and failure to develop their brand names should therefore seek cooperation with Chinese manufacturers to explore the vast Chinese market, according to Lee.

Should Taiwan's panel industry not be able to invest in China, exports of panel products could take a beating that could create a domino effect across the broader industry, including low production capacity utilization, lack of cost competitiveness in the Chinese market and a failure to build next-generation panel production factories, Lee predicted.

TRI projected that following South Korea's panel industry policy liberalization policy and the establishment of the proposed 8.5th-generation panel production plant in China, panel manufacturers in the two countries are expected to be running at over 90 percent capacity utilization by 2015.
If Taiwan's panel makers are not allowed to invest in China, they will only be running at 70 percent capacity utilization by that time, the institute forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: No entry for Chinese using tourism under false pretenses: MOI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:27:40 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior announced revisions Wednesday to the Regulations Governing the Approval of People of the Mainland Area Visiting Taiwan for purposes of Tourism, hoping to close a loophole and prevent Chinese from using tourism as a disguise to enter Taiwan for other purposes.
A ministry spokesman said that those suspected of planning to overstay or conduct other activities in Taiwan will be denied entry.

Although the government has relaxed restrictions on Chinese visitors to Taiwan since last July, pre-trip examination of identity is required and Chinese tourists must apply in groups, each group comprising no fewer than five persons.
Several overstay cases have been reported and some Chinese visitors have been found to have conducted activities other than sight-seeing while in Taiwan, according to the spokesman.

Meanwhile, the ministry has allowed more convenience for Chinese tourists and travel agents by cancelling the regulation that any changes of tour itineraries must be reported to the authorities immediately.

Many travel agents had raised the issue that weather and traffic conditions can cause inevitable changes in tour itineraries and that the immediate reporting requirement had burdened not only the tour guides but also related administrative offices.
The revised regulations will be submitted to the Cabinet for approval, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan scores two basketball wins at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:37:20 (By Oscar Wu, Stanley Cheung, Chris Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan scored two wins in the basketball events but was knocked out of the men's table tennis team competition at the 2009 East Asian Games in Hong Kong Thursday.
Taiwan beat Hong Kong 112-47 in women's basketball after losing to China 61-69 a day earlier. The team was to face Japan Friday.
In men's basketball, Taiwan beat Macau 118-59 in the preliminary round of the Group A competition.

Taiwan's men's basketball teams have performed excellently in the previous three East Asian Games, bagging two gold medals and one silver. The most recent gold was seized in the 2005 event held in Macau.
In men's table tennis, Taiwan lost to Hong Kong 1-3 in the team competition and failed to make the finals.
Taiwan's women's table tennis team also lost to Hong Kong 0-3 in the Group B competition, after beating South Korea 3-2 a day earlier.

Also that day, the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association said that Hsu Wen-hsin is expected to replace Chan Yung-jan to compete in the women's tennis events after Chan decided to withdraw from the competition because of injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trade group visits Washington, D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/03/09 22:44:27 (By Zep Hu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A mission led by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou arrived in Washington, D.C. Wednesday to explore business opportunities in the U.S. private and government sectors.

"The aim of the visit is to forge business opportunities for the photovoltaic and electric motor industries of the two countries, " Hwang said, adding that they will visit the U.S. Department of Energy and the Department of Commerce while in the U.S. capital.
This is the first time in many years that a high-ranking MOEA official has visited the United States.

The delegation includes Industrial Technology Research Institute President Johnsee Lee, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials and representatives from Taiwan's leading lithium-ion battery manufacturers E-One Moli Energy Corp., Amita Technologies Inc. Ltd. and Simplo Technology Co., Ltd., as well as electric motor engine manufacturer Fukuta Electric and Machinery Co.
According to Hwang, Taiwan is strong in these two fields and some American companies, such as Tesla Roadster and GM, are keen to expand two-way collaboration with their Taiwanese counterparts.
Many of Tesla Roadster's motors, batteries and control modules are provided by Taiwanese companies, he noted.
The delegates also attended the annual meeting of the Republic of China-United States of America Business Council Nov. 30 and visited Detroit, the center of the U.S. automobile industry.

Wang Chung-yu, vice chairman of the Republic of China-United States of America Council, called on the U.S. to resume bilateral talks with Taiwan on a trade and investment framework agreement to further expand business opportunities between the two countries, especially at a time when Taiwan and China are preparing to ink an economic cooperation framework agreement -- a pact similar to a free trade agreement.

Cooperation between Taiwan and the United States should be a win-win situation for both countries and would help Taiwanese firms expand into the U.S. market, while U.S. companies would be able to seize more business and investment opportunities through partnerships with Taiwan-based enterprises, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Referendum initiative on U.S. beef to be submitted to CEC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 21:01:58 (By Yang Su-min and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A civic initiative that calls for a referendum on U.S. beef imports will be submitted to the Central Election Commission (CEC) next week following the completion of a first-stage signature drive, an organizer said Thursday.

A total of 206,880 signatures have already been collected for the initiative, which demands a re-opening of talks with Washington on U.S. beef imports, according to Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the Consumers' Foundation, which is leading the movement.
Hsieh urged consumers who have not signed the petition to take part in the second phase of the signature drive, in which the foundation hopes to collect 1.2 million signatures.

Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and beef offal, sparking a huge public outcry.

Civic groups led by the Consumers' Foundation and politicians contend that allowing the entry of products that are considered at high risk of spreading bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, could endanger the health of local consumers.
With their appeals for re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef talks having been rejected by the government, the groups decided to push for a referendum to allow the people a say on the issue.

Under Taiwan's referendum law, a referendum proposal must pass two thresholds to be accepted. In the initial stage, signatures from 0.5 percent, or 86,000, of the 17.32 million eligible voters in the last presidential election must be collected, a threshold that has already been met by the civic groups.

If a referendum screening committee finds that the proposed referendum conforms to legal guidelines, the referendum's sponsors then need to collect signatures of endorsement from 5 percent of the voters, or 860,000 signatures, for the question to be put to a referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung expects to have world-class opera house by 2013
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/03/09 21:42:12 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih and Emile Shen, Minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs, joined Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Thursday at the groundbreaking of the Taichung Metropolitan Opera House on the west side of the city.

Wu said the opera house, which will accommodate a main auditorium with 2,011 seats, a theater with 800 seats and a smaller theater with 200 seats, will be one of the most unique architectural structures in Asia when it is completed at the end of 2013.

Japanese architect Toyo Ito, who won the contract after a contest for the project in 2005, said at the groundbreaking ceremony that he would bring together the best resources to build one of the best metropolitan opera houses in the world.

The Taichung city council approved a revised construction budget plan last year. The construction cost is estimated at NT$3.57 billion (around US$110 million), of which NT$1.78 billion will come from the central government and NT$1.79 billion will be raised by the local government.

Although the city government was planning to adopt an "OT" (operation and transfer) model, inviting private businesses to run the opera house and transfer the operations to the government after a certain number of years, the seven open bids held over the past four years failed to attract private investors. Some of the bids were aborted and some had no contenders at all.
