DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 4, or the 18th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1154: Nicholas Breakspeare becomes the first Englishman to become the pope.
1795: Thomas Carlyle, Scottish historian and essayist, is born. His works include "Sartor Resartus" and "The French Revolution."
1892: Gen. Francisco Franco, Spanish dictator from 1939 until his death in 1975, is born.
1893: Britain and France reach an agreement on Siam (Thailand).
1912: Turkey reaches an armistice with all the Balkan allies except Greece.
1947: Tennessee Williams' play "A Streetcar Named Desire" premiers on Broadway, with Marlon Brando and Jessica Tandy in the leading roles.
1936: Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek of the Republic of China leaves Loyang for Xian to meet with Chang Hsueh-liang.
1939: Wu Pei-fu, a noted Chihli faction general of the Peiyang army, China's first modern fighting force, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 66.
1963: Pope Paul VI approves the decision of the Roman Catholic Vatican Council to authorize the use of vernacular languages instead of Latin in performing the sacraments.
1963: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee approves the resignation of ROC Premier Chen Cheng, who is concurrently serving as the vice president, and names Yen Chia-kan as the new premier.
1965: The United States successfully launches "Gemini 7," which would orbit the earth for a record 14 days.
1966: Beijing's Red Guard arrests communist leaders such as Peng Chen, Tien Han and Wan Li.
1973: Jordanian Minister of Tourism and Antiquities Ghaleb Z. Barakat arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1975: The Third Conference of East Asia Economists opens in Taipei with 30 Japanese and 50 Chinese delegates attending.
1975: Defense Minister Kao Kuei-yuan announces that the fighting capability of the ROC armed forces has nearly quintupled over the last quarter of a century.
1975: Willem Pretorius, the new South African consul-general to the ROC, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1976: The Central African Republic becomes the Central African Kingdom, and President Jean Bedel Bokassa is crowned king.
1976: A seminar on agricultural engineering and development is held at National Taiwan University to mark the 60th anniversary of the establishment of the Chinese Agriculture Society.
1977: A hijacked Malaysian airliner carrying 100 people crashes in Singapore, killing everyone onboard.
1989: Members of East Germany's Politburo and Central Committee resign, and Head of State Egon Krenz is forced to step down only six weeks after replacing a beleaguered Erich Hoenecker.
1994: U.S. Secretary of Transportation Federico Pena visits the ROC, becoming the first U.S. secretary to carry out the new U.S. policy governing high-ranking official visits to Taipei.
1998: A trial is held in Shanghai for a Chinese entrepreneur accused of providing e-mail addresses to an online democracy magazine.
1999: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian leaves for a five-day European visit.
2000: The fourth Global Semiconductor Industry Seminar opens in the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, with more than 200 of the leading lights of the global semiconductor sector participating.
2000: David Yen, one of Taiwan's most prominent anti-smoking activists, is granted a Thai royal decoration in Taipei for his contributions toward successfully controlling tobacco consumption in Thailand.
2001: Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yen Ta-jen goes to Xiamen City opposite to the Taiwan-held frontline island aboard a passenger vessel for a four-day visit, the first of its kind for a Republic of China official in more than 50 years.
2001: The remains of 14 crew members of a surveillance aircraft affiliated with the former Republic of China Air Force's 34th Squadron, nicknamed the Black Bats Squadron, that was shot down by mainland Chinese fighters in Jiangxi province nearly four decades ago are airlifted back to Taiwan.
Motse's lesson of the day: "The interest of the wise ruler lies in carrying out what makes for order among the people and avoiding what makes for confusion. When the administration of the ruler answers the desires of the people, there will be order, otherwise there will be confusion."

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/09 08:44:38 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior announced revisions Wednesday to the Regulations Governing the Approval of People of the Mainland Area Visiting Taiwan for purposes of Tourism, hoping to close a loophole and prevent Chinese from using tourism as a disguise to enter Taiwan for other purposes.
A ministry spokesman said that those suspected of planning to overstay or conduct other activities in Taiwan will be denied entry.

Although the government has relaxed restrictions on Chinese visitors to Taiwan since last July, pre-trip examination of identity is required and Chinese tourists must apply in groups, each group comprising no fewer than five persons.
Several overstay cases have been reported and some Chinese visitors have been found to have conducted activities other than sight-seeing while in Taiwan, according to the spokesman.

Meanwhile, the ministry has allowed more convenience for Chinese tourists and travel agents by cancelling the regulation that any changes of tour itineraries must be reported to the authorities immediately.

Many travel agents had raised the issue that weather and traffic conditions can cause inevitable changes in tour itineraries and that the immediate reporting requirement had burdened not only the tour guides but also related administrative offices.
The revised regulations will be submitted to the Cabinet for approval, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Think tank calls for panel industry investment in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/09 08:45:30 (By Tien Yu-pin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should allow the flat panel display industry to invest in China to avoid it losing its importance in the Chinese market in the wake of South Korea's LG Display Co. Ltd. establishing a joint venture Nov. 16 to build its 8.5th- generation liquid crystal display (LCD) panel production line in China, a local private think tank said Thursday.

Following the lifting of a South Korean ban on flat panel investment in China, China is expected to introduce a spate of protectionist measures to protect the joint venture, including new barriers to investment, high tariffs, and a minimum initial investment, said Yang Sheng-fan, deputy director of the Topology Research Institute (TRI).
Jointly constructed by Guangzhou Development District and LG Display, the new LCD panel plant will start construction in 2010 and is expected to go into production in 2012.
Once the new LCD panel project is completed, Taiwan's panel makers could lose its advantage in terms of cost competitiveness in the Chinese market, Yang said.

The government should come up with complementary measures as it makes plans for local panel makers to break into the market, in order to help them sustain their competitive edge in the industry, Yang said.

For example, the industry should keep its research and development centers in the country and establish 10th-generation and 11th- generation panel production lines in Taiwan to ensure that the country's industry is in line with the global trend and has the capability and technology to develop next-generation products such as organic light-emitting diodes and flexible display devices.
TRI analyst Corwin Lee predicted that before 2020 the global panel industry will continue to face an oversupply, causing a slump in prices.

Under the scenario, products made by Japan and South Korea are expected to hold a certain portion of the market share due to brand loyalty, so Taiwan's panel makers, in the face of weak domestic consumption and failure to develop their brand names should therefore seek cooperation with Chinese manufacturers to explore the vast Chinese market, according to Lee.

Should Taiwan's panel industry not be able to invest in China, exports of panel products could take a beating that could create a domino effect across the broader industry, including low production capacity utilization, lack of cost competitiveness in the Chinese market and a failure to build next-generation panel production factories, Lee predicted.

TRI projected that following South Korea's panel industry policy liberalization policy and the establishment of the proposed 8.5th-generation panel production plant in China, panel manufacturers in the two countries are expected to be running at over 90 percent capacity utilization by 2015.
If Taiwan's panel makers are not allowed to invest in China, they will only be running at 70 percent capacity utilization by that time, the institute forecast.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cardiovascular deaths in Taipei on increase: health department
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/09 08:53:00 (By Jian Chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei city health officials said Thursday that deaths from cardiovascular disease (CVD) in Taiwan's capital increased last year compared to the 1999 figure.
The officials said that every two hours and 27 minutes, a person died from CVD in 2008, compared to the 1999 figure of three hours and two minutes.
The officials said CVD claimed 3,587 lives in the city last year, which made it the number two cause of death, while cancer still topped the list.
The fatality rate for heart disease was the highest among all the forms of CVD for both men and women, the officials added.

More men than women died from heart disease in 2008, as heart disease death rates per 100,000 people were 100.3 for males and 54. 4 for females, which were up 46.9 percent and 35.9 percent, respectively, from 1999.

The CVD death rate for people under the age of 24 increased 90.8 percent from 1999, while the heart disease death rate for this age group was more than double -- rising 218 percent compared to 10 years ago.
In contrast, the CVD death rate for the 45-64 age group and for the age group above 65 were both lower than a decade ago. However, the age group above 65 still recorded the highest number of deaths.
The officials noted that CVD is closely related to age and obesity, with smokers and patients with the "three-highs" -- high blood pressure, high blood sugar and high blood lipoid -- most at risk.
They suggested that people over 40 should get the health department's free blood screening tests and enroll on its quit smoking programs.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO) , CVD is the number one cause of death globally. More people die annually from it than from any other cause and an estimated 17.1 million people died from CVD in 2004, representing 29 percent of all global deaths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan trade group visits Washington, D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 2 (CNA) 12/04/09 09:10:37 (By Zep Hu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A mission led by Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou arrived in Washington, D.C. Wednesday to explore business opportunities in the U.S. private and government sectors.

"The aim of the visit is to forge business opportunities for the photovoltaic and electric motor industries of the two countries, " Hwang said, adding that they will visit the U.S. Department of Energy and the Department of Commerce while in the U.S. capital.
This is the first time in many years that a high-ranking MOEA official has visited the United States.

The delegation includes Industrial Technology Research Institute President Johnsee Lee, Ministry of Economic Affairs officials and representatives from Taiwan's leading lithium-ion battery manufacturers E-One Moli Energy Corp., Amita Technologies Inc. Ltd. and Simplo Technology Co., Ltd., as well as electric motor engine manufacturer Fukuta Electric and Machinery Co.
According to Hwang, Taiwan is strong in these two fields and some American companies, such as Tesla Roadster and GM, are keen to expand two-way collaboration with their Taiwanese counterparts.
Many of Tesla Roadster's motors, batteries and control modules are provided by Taiwanese companies, he noted.
The delegates also attended the annual meeting of the Republic of China-United States of America Business Council Nov. 30 and visited Detroit, the center of the U.S. automobile industry.

Wang Chung-yu, vice chairman of the Republic of China-United States of America Council, called on the U.S. to resume bilateral talks with Taiwan on a trade and investment framework agreement to further expand business opportunities between the two countries, especially at a time when Taiwan and China are preparing to ink an economic cooperation framework agreement -- a pact similar to a free trade agreement.

Cooperation between Taiwan and the United States should be a win-win situation for both countries and would help Taiwanese firms expand into the U.S. market, while U.S. companies would be able to seize more business and investment opportunities through partnerships with Taiwan-based enterprises, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 09:20:07 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened slightly higher Friday, moving up 0.47 points at 7,685.14 on a turnover of NT$3.45 billion (US$107.19 million).
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 7.05 points, or 0.09 percent, to close at 7,684.67 Thursday.

U.S. dollar up in early Taipei trading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 10:17:10 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was traded at 32.179 at 9:45 a.m. Friday on the Taipei Foreign Exchange, up 0.029 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian envoy calls for two-way investment between Taiwan, Canada
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 10:38:16 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The top Canadian envoy to Taiwan called Thursday for more economic and investment activities between Taiwan and Canada, saying that both Taipei and Ottawa can serve as each other's access points to a bigger market in North America and Asia, respectively.

"We think that Canada needs to be part of your strategy as you face the challenges of an exceedingly and increasingly complex international commerce environment, " said Scott Fraser, executive director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT).

He made the remarks at a countdown event in the lead-up to the 2010 Winter Olympic Games scheduled to kick off in Vancouver Feb. 12, saying that the games provide Canada with a great opportunity to reach out to global business leaders and remind them why Canada is one of the best places in the world to invest, to innovate, to work and to compete.

According to Fraser, by investing in Canada, Taiwanese companies can strengthen their operations, penetrate new markets, acquire new technologies, resources and skills and can pursue business opportunities in Canada to serve all of the North American market and beyond.
"I should also say that we are working to convince Canadian companies that Taiwan is a great platform from which to pursue opportunities within Asia, including the Chinese mainland, " said Fraser.
Canada and Taiwan face similar challenges and have developed similar strategies, according to Fraser, as both depend on international commerce for economic prosperity.
Therefore, Taiwan and Canada can work together through investment and through collaboration on innovation to meet the challenges of a globalized marketplace, he added.

In keeping with the theme of the Winter Olympics, Wang Jen-tang, chairman and CEO of Acer, said at the event that as the worldwide Olympic sponsor from 2009-2012, Acer has launched a series of events and efforts in preparation for the games.
"The pursuit of excellence has brought Acer and the Olympic Games together," Wang said.
As the second-largest computer manufacturer in the world, Wang said, Acer will also provide 5,700 desktops, laptops, servers and staff to ensure the games run flawlessly.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pregnant woman loses baby after getting H1N1 shot
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 11:11:51 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A 41-year-old woman in her 38th week of pregnancy underwent emergency surgery to have her dead unborn baby removed Thursday, seven days after she was vaccinated against influenza A(H1N1).
It was Taiwan's first case of miscarriage suspected to have resulted from the immunization.

Some experts, however, said after an emergency meeting convened by the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) to discuss the incident that there was insufficient information to determine that the vaccine against the novel flu strain was the culprit and that an investigation had been launched.
Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director Chou Jih-haw said the woman received the vaccine Nov. 27 and that doctors found that her baby had no heartbeat Dec. 2 during a regular checkup.

The woman, a resident of Taipei City, had suffered two previous miscarriages, Chou pointed out, telling reporters that they were at the moment not aware whether she had been ill before the latest miscarriage or whether the baby had some kind of genetic deficiency.
No cases of vaccination-caused miscarriage have been reported from overseas so far, Chou added.
He noted that 11,847 pregnant women in Taiwan have received the vaccine since the government launched a national immunization program Nov. 1.

The most serious side effect of which the CDC has been informed was a rash, Chou added. He also noted that seven pregnant local women have been hospitalized with A(H1N1) infection since the outbreak began, two of whom have died.

Admitting that the latest incident might deter some other pregnant women from receiving the inoculation, Chou said that after assessing the infection risk, the authorities have decided to keep continuing the national immunization program.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan director wins major award in India
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/04/09 11:18:31 (By Paul Kuo and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan director Leon Dai won the prestigious Golden Peacock award for best film at the 40th International Film Festival of India in Goa Thursday for the film "I Can't Live Without You."

Dai, who arrived at the seaside resort in southern India that day upon short notice from the organizers of the festival, said after being presented with the honor that he hopes the award will draw the world's attention to Taiwan's film industry.
"It proves that even with limited financial resources and support, it can turn out works recognized by its international counterparts," he said.
Dai's film, made at a cost of just NT$6 million (US$186,460), is a minnow compared with the other films in the contest.
He said he has a personal affection for India, despite having never set foot in the country before.
"My father lived in Kolkata in exile for 11 years after he left war-ravaged China as an 18-year-old student in 1949," he said.
"He moved from India to Taiwan and raised a family there, and often told me about the country when I was a child. So the country is not strange to me," Dai went on.
As with other creative industry workers, Dai said, his works reflect his life, therefore India is sure to appear in his future films in some form.
The Nov. 23- Dec. 3 festival is the only one in India sponsored by the government. It has drawn about 200 films to compete for the Golden Peacock awards.
Dai's film also won four awards at Taiwan's Golden Horse Film Festival Nov. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese drumming album nominated for Grammy award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 11:59:49 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An album featuring music made by a drum ensemble from Tainan City in southern Taiwan has been nominated for a Grammy award in the traditional world music category, corporate sources said Friday.

The album, titled "Island of Drums" was recorded by the Tainan-based Ten Drum Art Percussion Group and produced by the Taipei-based Wind Music International Corp. It was nominated in Los Angeles Thursday with four other contenders from India, Scotland, Africa and Latin America for a Grammy, the world's biggest music award ceremony, which will take place in January.

Ten Drum Art's nomination marks the first time in 16 years that an album produced by a Taiwanese company has been nominated. The last one -- Taiwan's first Grammy nomination -- was an album produced by another Taipei-based music company featuring Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical The Phantom of the Opera in 1993.

The nominees for the 52nd Grammy Awards were selected in a vote by 3,600 members of the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences of the United States for outstanding achievements in the music industry.
Wind Music International Corp. is one of the three Taiwanese members of the academy, according to Yu Su-ying, head of Wind Music's business planning department.
Ten Drum Art founder Hsieh Shih, who began drumming at the age of 3 and who composed all five pieces on the album, expressed elation over the nomination.

Of the five, "The Gate of Taiwan, " a 20-minute piece featuring traditional Chinese drums of all sizes along with suona -- a traditional Chinese reed instrument -- and dulcimers, tells the epic story of how Koxinga made landfall on the coast of Tainan's Luermen in the 17th Century, according to Hsieh.
Hsieh said that growing up at a Taoist temple run by his father meant that he was familiar with the sound of drumbeats since birth.
"I was ordered to beat the drum for a ritual one day when I was 3 as the drum player was absent that day," he recalled.
As a 16-year-old high school student, he went on, he saw a performance by renowned Chinese percussionist Yan Xuemin and was enthralled.
"I was suddenly enlightened that playing drums was not merely folklore but could be a form of performance art that could earn high respect, " he said.

Hsieh founded his own ensemble, the Ten Drum Art Percussion Group, in 2000, naming the company Ten Drum Art because his given name translates as Ten, while the character for the numeral 10 can also mean "energy from all directions."

The group's performances involve not only complex drumming but also the postures of the players, he continued, adding that to perfect their performances, the players jog for 5 km every day, besides drumming at least 4,000 beats and laboring on farmland.
Hsieh described the Grammy nomination as a turning point in his career. "My goal is to build Tainan into the homeland of drumming and Taiwan into the island of drums," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier briefed by baseball leaders on league's problems
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 13:27:46 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu visited the Chinese Professional Baseball League Friday to receive a briefing on the league's corruption problems.
Chu, who was asked by President Ma Ying-jeou to head an ad hoc government team to chart plans to restore the image of professional baseball, was briefed by the league's chairman, Chao shou-po.
He also consulted with the managers of the four baseball clubs that make up the league over ways to solve the problems facing the sport.

Chu was charged with the task at a national baseball conference called by Ma Dec. 1 at the request of about 800 fans who took to the streets of Taipei Nov. 29 to demand that the government take action to boost the professional baseball league.
The league suffered a blow after several of its players were probed Oct. 26 for throwing games and many of them confessed to fixing-games in return for payments from underground bookmakers.
It was the fourth time the league had become embroiled in game-throwing scandals, angering and disappointing many fans.
Noting that baseball is Taiwan's most popular spectator sport, the government promised to help revive its tarnished image. However, it failed to act upon its words, prompting the Nov. 29 protest.

The protesters' calls were not shared by all baseball lovers, however. One sports commentator said in a letter to the editor of the China Times Wednesday that baseball clubs are not worth the government's efforts to save them.
Branding the clubs as being concerned only with their vested interests, the writer said they care only about how to protect their own interests.
But baseball clubs are not to be equated to the sport itself, and it is the latter that the government should help rather than the former, according to the commentator.

He dismissed the national baseball conference as useless because it produced nothing but empty words and said that if the league and its four clubs do not quit playing for a while and carry out thorough reforms, they will not win back their fans and give themselves a new lease on life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asian election authorities to observe local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 14:05:52 (By Jiachen Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Delegates of the member countries of the Association of Asian Election Authorities (AAEA) have arrived in Taiwan for an annual congress and to observe the three-in-one local elections, the head of the Central Election Commission (CEC) said Friday.

The AAEA delegates from 17 member countries met in Taipei that day for the 2009 congress of executive directors of the Manila-based organization. Taiwan, one of the 17 founding countries, has been the chair country since 2005, according to CEC Commissioner Henry Hau-min Rai.

The delegates will later travel around the country to see for themselves the campaign drives for the elections of mayors and magistrates, city and county councilors, and city and township chiefs, as well as observing the polling slated for following the day, Rai said.

The AAEA was founded in Manila in 1998 to provide a non-partisan forum for the exchange of information among election authorities to discuss and act on ways to promote open and transparent elections with the objective of supporting good governance and democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Canadian aboriginal delegation visits Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 14:06:01 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A delegation of Canadian aborigines is visiting Taiwan to promote exchanges and understanding of the indigenous cultures of Taiwan and Canada, the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei (CTOT) said Friday.

A conference on research into Canada's Metis tribe that was co-hosted by the CTOT, National Donghua University (NDHU) and the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples (CIP) , opened that same day in the eastern city of Hualien.

The conference discussed cultural preservation and other issues involving the identity and the rights of the Metis, with participation by two special guests from Canada -- Clement Chartier, president of Canada's Metis National Council and Frank Tough, a professor of Native Studies of the University of Alberta, according to the CTOT.

The Metis people are descended from intermarriages between Cree, Ojibway, Algonquin, Saulteaux, Menominee, Mi'kmaq, Maliseet and Europeans, mainly French. It is estimated that there are 350,000 to 400,000 Metis people in Canada, comprising about 1 percent of the country's population.

"This conference will offer a new opportunity for academics and policy makers to explore Canada-Taiwan aboriginal relations, as well as provide conference participants with a deeper understanding of one of Canada's three officially recognized aboriginal peoples, " said Scott Fraser, executive director of CTOT.

Fraser also presented awards to the 2009 Canadian Studies winners -- Chou Jou- juo of National Chung Cheng University and professors Wu Tsung-chiung, Hsu Hui- yen, Jolan Hsieh and Sun Chia-sui, all of Donghua University.
Since 1991, the Canadian Studies Program, which provides funding to conduct Canada-related research, has had more than 100 award recipients from around Taiwan.

Shih Cheng-feng, dean of NDHU's College of Indigenous Studies, said Taiwan's Pingpu -- indigenous people living on Taiwan's plains -- share similarities with the Metis people and he expressed hope that the conference will open a new window of exchanges in aboriginal studies between Taiwan and Canada.

Chartier and Tough were scheduled to visit Pingpu communities in both Kaohsiung and Tainan counties in an effort to better understand the contemporary Pingpu experience as it relates to cultural preservation, according to the CTOT.
According to the CIP, there are more than 490,000 indigenous people in Taiwan, about 2 percent of the country's population.

Currently, 14 tribes have been recognized by the government -- the Amis, Atayal, Paiwan, Bunun, Puyuma, Rukai, Tsou, Saisiyat, Yami, Thao, Kavalan, Truku, Sakizaya and Sediq, each with their own distinct language, cultural features, traditional customs and social structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Voters to go to polls in 17 counties, cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 14:48:40 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Seventeen of 25 counties and cities around Taiwan will hold elections Saturday for county and city chiefs and councilors, as well as township heads, with voting to take place between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m.

A total of 54 candidates are running in the county magistrate and city mayor elections, 18 of whom have been nominated by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , 14 by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and one by the minor Hakka Party, Central Election Commission (CEC) officials said Friday. The rest of the candidates are running as independents.
The biggest of Saturday's battles is expected to be over the Kinmen magistrate position, as seven people are running for the post.
According to the CEC, 935 candidates are vying for 592 seats up for grabs in city and county councils around the country, while 470 people are fighting for 211 township chief posts.

CEC statistics show the number of eligible voters in the county magistrate and city mayoral elections at over 7 million, with 7.04 million eligible voters in the elections for city and county councilors and 6.23 million for the township chief elections.
A total of 6,384 polling stations will be manned in the 17 cities and counties holding the elections, the CEC said, adding that 81,926 people will be mobilized to staff the stations.

The elections will not take place in Taipei City or Kaohsiung City, both of which enjoy special municipality status, or in Kaohsiung County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County, or in Taipei County all of which will be upgraded or merged into municipalities and will have their local elections next year once their new status has been implemented.
Meanwhile, KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chun-po forecast a turnout rate of around 68 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electrification project on eastern railway system launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 15:48:13 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou presided over a ceremony in the eastern township of Yuli Friday to mark the start of a railway electrification project on a line that connects the two eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung.
"Residents of eastern Taiwan have long hoped for this electrified railway system," Ma said at the ceremony.
He said he had traveled twice on the eastern Hualien-Taitung railway, which still uses diesel-powered locomotives.

"I felt sorry for the eastern residents and ashamed on behalf of the government that the Hualien-Taitung railway network remained outdated while freeways and high-speed railways have been in operation in western Taiwan for years," he said.

The electrification of the Hualien-Taitung railway over a distance of 155 kilometers is scheduled to be completed by 2012. The electrified system will mean that trains on the line will be able to travel at speeds of up to 130 kilometers per hour compared to the current 110 kph. Travel time between Hualien Railway Station and Taitung Railway Station will be reduced by 35 minutes.
The areas close to the 29 stations along the way will also be developed as tourism attractions, according to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).
Meanwhile, the president said that the railway between Taitung County and the southernmost county of Pingtung should also be upgraded.
"The MOTC should start planning for the electrification of the line that connects Taitung Railway Station and Chaojhou in Pingtung County on the South Link," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. trade group welcomes government actions on economic issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 15:59:48 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) is gratified to see that economic relations between Taiwan and China have improved significantly over the past year and that Taiwan's government has acted on a number of the group's suggestions on cross-strait trade and other economic issues.

In the latest issue of its monthly publication, Topics, AmCham offered an assessment of the status of issues raised by the group in its Taiwan White Paper released in June, covering areas such as banking, chemical manufacturing, infrastructure, insurance, intellectual property, pharmaceuticals, retail, transportation and taxation.

"AmCham is gratified that the government has continued to take the White Paper recommendations extremely seriously and has made progress in a number of areas, " Chamber President Andrea Wu was quoted as saying.
"We look forward to further close interaction with government agencies in hopes that even more issues can be resolved before the next edition of the White Paper is ready for publication," she added.

Wu cited three areas in particular requiring further government attention to enhance Taiwan's investment competitiveness, including reconsideration of the "unrealistically aggressive" schedule set for reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and the elimination of the requirement that foreign employees of non- tech companies have two years of work experience.

Also, Taiwan should expedite environmental impact approval for important pending projects, including proposed new power plants to guarantee an adequate supply of electricity in the coming decade and the Kuokuang petrochemical complex to assure sufficient future supplies of downstream feedstocks, Wu added.
According to the article, the most significant progress seen this year is the improvement in the cross-Taiwan Strait economic relationship.

Taiwan and China have already concluded memorandum of understandings that will pave the way for the mutual opening of markets in the three financial sectors of banking, insurance, and securities, and the two are preparing to begin negotiations on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

These steps, which follow previous initiatives to expand cross-strait direct flights and promote tourism from China, are in line with the position taken for many years in the White Paper that Taiwan needs to take advantage of its geographical proximity and cultural and linguistic connections with China to tap into the opportunities offered by the world's fastest-growing economy, the AmCham said.

A sampling of other White Paper issues that received positive action in the past half year include an easing of the regulatory reporting process in banking, an amendment to the Insurance Law, and plans to institute more stringent laws on protecting intellectual property rights.

Since it was first published in 1996, the AmCham White Paper has served to set the basic annual agenda for the chamber's meetings with government agencies on a wide spectrum of economic and business issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 17:28:22 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices edged lower Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 33.76 points, or 0.43 percent, to close near the day's low at 7,650.91.
The local bourse opened at 7,685.14 and fluctuated between 7,707.11 and 7,650.77 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.65 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$113.9 billion (US$3.54 billion).
Paper and pulp shares was the only one of eight major stock categories to post gains Friday, advancing by 2.2 percent.

Banking and financial shares suffered the biggest fall of the day, losing 1.1 percent. Foodstuff issues fell 0.9 percent, textile stocks fell 0.8 percent, and cement stocks and construction issues both slid 0.7 percent.
Plastics and chemicals shares dropped 0.4 percent, and machinery and electronics shares fell 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,661 to 840, with 257 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$1.29 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to issue anti-corruption stamps
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 17:35:51 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: State postal company Chunghwa Post will issue a set of stamps Dec. 9 to mark International Anti-Corruption Day, the company said Friday.
The set will be comprised of two stamps, one with a denomination of NT$5 and the other NT$25, according to a statement released by the company.

Differing only in their colors and denominations, the two stamps will have the same design: a globe with latitude and longitude lines that form the Chinese character "lian, " which means "clean and honest."
"The image conveys the idea that Taiwan is taking the lead in promoting clean and competent government and its determination in implementing anti-corruption efforts," the statement reads.
In line with the new issues, first day covers and stamp collection cards related to the same theme will be sold from Dec. 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing travel agents to explore tourism potential of aboriginal areas
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 18:24:42 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of travel agency operators from Beijing have arrived in Taiwan to tour aboriginal villages and assess their potential as attractions for Beijing sightseers.

The 36-member group, led by Beijing Tourism Bureau Director An Jinming, paid a call on aboriginal Legislator Kao Chin Su-mei Friday to discuss the possibility of arranging tours to aboriginal villages and other rural spots around Taiwan.
Kao Chin welcomed the Beijing travel agents, saying that their visit will pave the way for the first group of Chinese visitors to tour rural Taiwan early next year.
"Such tours will definitely help boost the sagging economies of the indigenous communities," she said.

She said the delegation's current tour of Taiwan is the result of a visit by her and a 100-member Taiwanese aboriginal group to Beijing in August, during which she and Beijing Mayor Guo Jinlong discussed the possibility of launching sightseeing tours to indigenous communities in Taiwan.
For his part, An said his delegation hopes to get a broader picture of rural life in Taiwan.
"I hope we can gain a better understanding of Taiwan's minorities and their communities so that we can advise travel agencies on the possibility of tours to aboriginal villages," An said.

The Beijing tourism official said that since Taiwan lifted its restrictions last year to allow visits by larger numbers of Chinese sightseers, "tourism between the two sides has gone beyond pure leisure to a cultural experience."
Over the past year, about 100,000 Beijing residents have visited Taiwan in 544 tour groups, while some 130,000 Taiwanese people have visited Beijing for tourism purposes, he noted.

An said his group is also looking to explore the concept of homestay tourism in Taiwan, and noted that this has become an increasingly popular trend in the greater Beijing area in recent years. There are about 20,000 households in 344 villages in the greater Beijing area that offer homestays, he said.

While in Taiwan, the Beijing group will visit Fusing Village in the northern county of Taoyuan, which is the home to the Atayal people; Atayal Taiaan township in the northern county of Miaoli; and Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan, which is the home to the aboriginal tribe of Sao.

They also plan to visit Sandimen township in the southern county of Pingtung, home to the Rukai people; Jhihben township in the eastern county of Taitung, and the Taroko National Park area in the eastern county of Hualien, which is home to the Amis and other aboriginal groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Hakka TV garners 2 prizes at Asia Television Awards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 18:32:40 (By Charles Kang and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Hakka Television Station stood out at the 14th Asia Television Awards (ATA) ceremony in Singapore Thursday by winning the Best Drama Series and Best Single Drama categories.

Entering the competition for the first time to compete with programs of many world-renowned television networks such as Discovery and National Geographic Channel Asia, Hakka TV earned nominations in four categories and won awards for Best Drama Series and Best Single Drama, respectively.

The Best Drama Series award was given to Hakka TV's "1895 in Formosa, " which depicts an epic love story about the Hakka people's fight against Japanese occupation that year and recounts the Hakka militia's resistance against Japanese troops.
Hakka TV Vice Director Tang Sheng-jung and Wen Sheng-hao, the lead actor in 1895 in Formosa, accepted the award on behalf of the television station and the series' other actors.
The Best Single Drama award went to Hakka TV's "Love in the Season of Osmanthus, " a black comedy in which three unsuccessful middle-age men try to rob a bank security van.

Hakka TV Director Hsu Chin-yun said the station spends considerable effort on the cast, plot and production of good-quality dramas, which serve as the best tool to promote Hakka culture because drama is the closest thing to people's lives.
"I'm very gratified that our hard work has been well received by everybody. We will continue to produce more high quality programs, " said Hsu.
Also nominated for the ATA's most prestigious "Cable and Satellite Channel of the Year" award, Hakka TV lost in the category to Discovery Channel.

Public Television Service Foundation, another Taiwanese TV channel, went home empty-handed after garnering nominations in five categories: Best Documentary Programme, Best Natural History or Wildlife Programme or Documentary-Drama, Best Single Drama or Telemovie Programme, Best Reality Programme, and Best Achievement in HD.

Other winners at the awards ceremony included Anjali Rao, host of CNN International's "Talk Asia." Rao was named the Best Current Affairs Presenter for her interview with Taiwan President Ma Ying-jeou.

The ATA is the Asian television industry's most significant and celebrated event, recognizing excellence in programming, production and performance. This year, it attracted more than 1,000 entries from 13 countries and regions in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sits on record-high forex reserves in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 18:41:48 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan recorded a foreign exchange reserve of US$347.19 billion as of the end of November, up US$5.968 billion from the previous month, the Taipei-based Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Friday.

The bank attributed the increase of forex reserves growth last month to the strong appreciation of major currencies, such as the euro and Japanese yen, against the U.S. dollar, apart from returns from foreign exchange reserve management.
The amount of reserves Taiwan held ranked the country as the world's fourth- largest forex holder in November, after China, Japan and Russia, the bank said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday: Liberty Times Taiwanese voters should cast ballots with eyes wide open

President Ma Ying-jeou has been on barnstorming trips around the country in recent weeks to stump for Kuomintang (KMT) candidates running in the Dec. 5 mayoral and magistrate elections in his capacity as party chairman.
He has urged voters to give the KMT a mandate to control local governments, claiming that this will allow his administration's policies to be implemented efficiently.
"When central and local governments are in the hands of the same party, Taiwan's progress will take off, " Ma has said repeatedly on the campaign trail.

Last year, Ma used a similar campaign slogan to help his party score a landslide victory in the legislative elections. However, he has not delivered on his promise of good governance now that the KMT controls both the executive and legislative arms of the government.

Over the past one-plus year, the people of Taiwan have lived in hardship, with many people out of work or seeing their salaries fall to levels of 30 years ago. All this has resulted from the Ma administration's incompetence and its adoption of a China-tilting policy.
We must remind voters of the wrongness of Ma's equation that a vote for the KMT in the upcoming local elections is a vote for Taiwan's future.

In a mature democracy, progress does not rely on central and local government being controlled by the same party. According to the division of power clauses set forth in the Constitution, central and local governments should act in concert even if their chiefs belong to different political parties.
Judging from Ma's recent campaign speeches, we can see that he remains unrepentant about the damage his China-leaning policy has done to Taiwan's economy and sovereign status.

We hope voters will use their ballots to teach Ma a lesson. Otherwise, his administration's plans to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China, recognize academic accreditation from Chinese tertiary education institutes and open Taiwan's universities to Chinese students could soon become realities, by which time Taiwan's future will be doomed.
For the sake of Taiwan and for our own sakes and those of generations to come, voters should cast their ballots with their eyes wide open. Apple Daily Only creative minds can stand out
Taiwanese fashion designer Johan Ku has won the top prize in the avant-garde category of the 2009 Gen Art's Styles International Design Competition in New York.

It's an extraordinary achievement for an up-and-coming talent to snatch the coveted crown in one of the world's most prestigious fashion design contests. It is no less glamourous than a pianist winning the annual Chopin piano contest.

Ku's prize-winning work does not epitomize any single Chinese, Asian or Western fashion style. It is a very complex, sophisticated creation that is full of imagination and mirrors Ku's strong personal flair.

As the professional fashion world takes attire as a media for dialogue with others and oneself, it is no easy feat for a young designer to emerge in the extremely competitive New York fashion arena where talent is in abundant supply.

Ku's victory in the New York contest proves his ingenuity. It also affirms the trend that creative prodigies will stand out. Taiwan's education system has traditionally focused more on requiring students to recite classics or knowledge rather than to encourage them to develop imagination. That's why Taiwan has lagged in scientific and technological development and represents a crisis in our education system. United Daily News Tribal smoke sign metaphor

Prosecutors in Hsinchu County set a commendable precedent recently with a ruling that confirmed the right of Atayal tribal people living in mountainous Jianshih Township to collect traffic fees from those who travel through their Smangus village.
Prosecutors cited two U.N.-sponsored international conventions signed into law by President Ma Ying-jeou earlier this year to support their ruling in favor of the Smangus tribal people.

Their ruling only highlights the central government's insufficient attention to the spirit of the two international conventions, reflected in a recent protest outside the Executive Yuan over what they called the slow progress in rebuilding their Typhoon Morakot-devastated villages.

Some demonstrators protested the government's failure to respond to their wish to live in family style temporary shelters instead of living in military barracks, where they have been housed for more than three months.

Others voiced their discontent with the government's plan to build permanent housing units on a piece of state-owned land away from their original villages. They demanded more say in how to rebuild their homes and tribal villages.
The central government should take a cue from the Hsinchu prosecutors' ruling and show more respect for indigenous people's views in planning post-disaster reconstruction projects.

Patience and time are needed in helping displaced aborigines relocate to an environment similar to their original homes to sustain their tribal history and culture. China Times Director's tears highlight local film industry's plight

Movie director Leon Dai shed tears at the Golden Horse Film Festival award presentation ceremony after his indie family drama won four awards, including the coveted best picture and best director awards.
His tears shed light on the destitution faced by Taiwan's filmmakers and movie professionals.

With a limited budget of NT$6 million, which is less than the cost of shooting single scenes in some blockbuster commercial films, Dai had to personally write the script for his film "I Can't Live Without You" in addition to directing and editing it.

The government has tried to improve the local filmmaking environment but has failed to work out effective strategies. Given its own financial straits, it can only offer prize money or subsidies to filmmakers who have won accolades in international or domestic competitions.

But government support alone cannot ensure the success of a film. Local filmmakers, including directors, may also have to adjust their attitudes, treating filmmaking as more than just an expression of their personal artistic ideals.

They need to produce films that can move the hearts and minds of moviegoers and should promote their films through commercial market channels. The government and filmmaking professionals should work hand-in-hand to create a positive or benign industrial cycle to make filmmaking a profitable enterprise. Commercial Times Improving civil service culture an urgent task

Premier Wu Den-yih's controversial directive for civil servants to come up with an action plan to improve ordinary people's lives only reveals how urgently the country needs to improve the culture of the country's civil service.

Administrative agencies have proposed more than 200 plans in a short period of time. While those plans covered nearly all aspects of people's everyday lives, Wu concluded, none of them were productive or hit the crux of problems facing the country.
The phenomenon epitomizes Taiwan's civil service culture. Civil servants tend to be perfunctory and pandering in dealing with work and have been lax in monitoring, supervision and evaluation.

If such an attitude is not improved, the government's policy planning and quality of implementation will never get better, at the expense of our country's overall development. Economic Daily News All-out efforts needed to correct distorted economic structure
In the wake of the global financial crisis, major countries around the global will definitely adjust their development strategies. Taiwan will be no exception.

To keep abreast of future global development tendencies, we should study possible changes in the global economy in the years ahead. Moreover, we should better understand major distortions in Taiwan's economic development over the past decade to serve as a basis for improvement.
First of all, we should discontinue heavy dependence on export-oriented and trade surplus-fueled economic expansion. Such reliance has only resulted in unbalanced economic development.
The overemphasis on a few industries that heavily rely on exports should be adjusted, and the trend of export industries' heavy reliance on imports of parts and components also needs to be addressed.
Last but not least, more energy should be devoted to the development of the service sector, whose development has lagged behind.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parties pull all the stops on final day of election campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 19:41:14 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) both revved up their campaign efforts Friday, the last day before the three-in-one local elections.

KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chuen-po expressed optimism over the party's chances of taking 11 of the 17 city and county seats up for grabs in the elections. However, the other six seats are more "difficult," he said, listing Hsinchu, Yilan and Chiayi counties as the "most unpredictable."
The 17 areas are Hsinchu, Chiayi and Keelung cities and Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Hualien, Yilan, Taitung, Kinmen, Lienchiang (Matsu), Penghu, Pingtung and Taoyuan counties.
At present, the KMT holds 14 of the 17 seats, while the DPP controls the other three in Chiayi, Yunlin and Pingtung counties.
Chan said the KMT's "difficulties" spring from three main factors, the first being that three of the county magistrate seats are currently in the hands of the DPP.
The second is that the KMT's nomination process for the three counties it holds was rocky and there has been little coalescence since, Chan said, citing the situation in Hsinchu and Hualien counties.
The third factor is that Yilan County is traditionally a DPP stronghold, he added.
In line with President Ma Ying-jeou's "get-out-the-vote" campaign, Chan urged voters to go to the polls Saturday, and predicted that the turnout rate will be between 67 percent and 68 percent.

Meanwhile, President Ma, who is also chairman of the KMT, stayed on the campaign trail Friday, attending a ceremony in Hualien County in the morning to mark the start of an electrification project for the eastern railway system.
He later went on to Taitung, then to Yilan County and finally to Hsinchu County where he was expected to speak at big rally later in the evening.

His slipping popularity is one of the factors that the opposition DPP has been playing on and it has also been attacking what it calls his "China-leaning" policies, especially his plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
The DPP is expected to retain control of the three counties it now holds and make a big push to take back Yilan County from the KMT.
On Friday, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen stumped for Chang Hwa-kuan and Peng Shao- chin, the party's magisterial candidates in Chiayi and Hsinchu counties, respectively.
Later in the day she traveled to Yilan County to attend a night rally for the DPP candidate there, Lin Tsong-shyan.
This will be the first major election since President Ma took office in May 2008 and it is seen by many as a mid-term test of his administration.
In addition to electing city mayors and county magistrates Saturday, voters will also cast ballots for city and county councilors and township chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei MRT's Wenhu line experiences yet another shutdown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:06:57 (By Jian Chen, Chen Hung-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Wenshan-Neihu line of the Taipei MRT system was shut down for 57 minutes Friday afternoon due to network abnormalities, the latest in a series of breakdowns experienced by the line since its launch eight months ago.
Services on the line were resumed at 4: 37 p.m. after the problem was fixed.
Tan Kuo-kuang, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei City government, explained that the incident was caused by an unstable network converter at the Zhongxiao Fuxing station.
A total of 1,520 passengers on 23 trains were affected, all of whom were evacuated within 15 minutes after the shutdown and provided with free bus services instead, Tan said.

The shutdown came just three days after the city government announced that the reliability of the Wenshan-Neihu line reached 99 percent during the September- November period, following completion of system upgrades at the end of August.
The latest incident followed a collision Nov. 26 between two trains that were approaching the Neihu depot for routine maintenance.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp., which operates the MRT system, has claimed that the collision was the result of inadequate platform length.
When questioned by an investigation panel set up by the Taipei City Council Friday, however, an official from the city's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS) rejected such a claim.

According to Chen Yao-wei, director of the DORTS's East District Project Office, the length of the platform should not be a problem because the train carriages are supposed to be detached in the depot, not on the platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: First 4 millionth tourist to Taiwan expected on Saturday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:14:22 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The four millionth tourist to Taiwan this year is expected to arrive on Saturday, the first time that tourist arrivals to this country will surpass the four million mark, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.

The lucky visitor will receive a debit card with a cash value of NT$400,000 (US$12,353) for exclusive use in Taiwan during his or her visit, bureau officials said. He or she will also receive many other gifts.
To attract more tourists to Taiwan, the Tourism Bureau launched the incentive offer this year as part of an ambitious program to increase the number of visitors.

Focusing on the high-tech and manufacturing sectors in the past, Taiwan has long neglected promoting the tourism sector. But in recent years, it has recognized that its abundance of scenic natural beauty -- including majestic mountains and beautiful coastlines -- as well as cultural assets, are resources it can use to develop the tourism industry and boost economic growth.
The one millionth, two millionth and three millionth visitors received debit cards earlier this year, but with a lower value.
Last year, more than 3.84 million visitors traveled to Taiwan, according to official figures.

To further promote tourism, the bureau, in conjunction with the Northeast Coast and Guanyinshan National Scenic Area Administration and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, is staging two photo exhibitions at the airport's terminal from Dec. 4 until Feb. 28, 2010.

One exhibition features women dressed in bridal gowns posing at beautiful spots along Taiwan's northeast coast, which has long been a popular destination among Taiwan's newly weds to take wedding photos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan officials fly to Myanmar to help detained seamen
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:40:56 (By Lin Ching-ping and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan officials posted in Thailand flew to Myanmar Friday to visit four Taiwanese nationals working on fishing vessels seized by Myamar authorities more than two weeks ago.

The officials will try to determine what legal violations were committed by the men and provide them with the necessary assistance, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand.
The crew members were working on four fishing boats that were seized by Myanmar authorities Nov. 18, probably because they intruded into that country's exclusive economic zone.

As soon as it was informed of the situation, Taiwan decided to send officials to Myanmar to help deal with the incident. The trip only became possible, however, after Myanmar authorities finally issued visas to the officials Thursday.
Before that, the TECO in Thailand had asked Taiwanese businessmen in Myanmar to help deliver daily necessities to the detained crew members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Int'l students to participate in speech contest, food fair in Pingtung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:49:07 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 200 international students attending Taiwan universities on academic scholarships granted by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will participate in aChinese-language speech contest and food fair at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan on Saturday and Sunday.

Since 1998 when Taiwan universities started offering bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. programs taught in English, the ICDF has provided scholarships to 532 students from 40 countries. The ICDF, along with 16 universities that offer 24 such programs, has been organizing parties for its scholarship recipients at the end of every year.

As co-sponsor of this year's party, the Pingtung University of Science and Technology will hold a speech contest for the international students to test their Chinese language ability. Contestants are expected to relate their experiences in learning Mandarin and their most unforgettable moments in Taiwan.
The food fair on Saturday evening will feature authentic dishes prepared by students from the Asian and Pacific region, Africa, and Central and South America.

The ICDF was set up in 1997 to consolidate international cooperation programs that were previously sponsored by the International Economic Cooperation Development Fund and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Committee of International Technical Cooperation (CITC).

It primarily cooperates with Taiwan's allies in Central and SouthAmerica , the East Caribbean, Africa and the Asia Pacific region, and its activities include technical assistance, investment and lending operations, education and training, and humanitarian assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-medical records to be fully in place within five years: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:53:30 (By Erin Ho and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner said Friday that it hopes that all health care institutions will use electronic medical records within five years.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported that 95 percent of public and private hospitals and 56 percent of clinics use e-medical records at present.

A council official said that the government will work with the private sector to realize the goal of "instituting e-medical records, digitalization of images and examination reports, and the capacity to exchange medical images between hospitals within five years. "

The CEPD said that to upgrade health care quality, many nations have actively engaged in medical reforms, including the United States, which will spend US$19.2 billion between 2009 and 2012 on medical reforms, and China, which will invest 850 billion yuan.
Medical care is one of the six emerging industries that Taiwan is promoting, and the e-medical records will be one of the priorities in the sector, the CEPD said.

Once the e-medical records system is adopted by all health care institutions, patients will be able to get their medical records anywhere in the country simply by providing their National Health Insurance IC cards.

The medical records to be digitalized include medical examination reports, scans such as computer tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, blood test results and prescription records.
The plan aims to shorten waiting times of patients at clinics, help patients avoid unneeded duplication of medical tests and prescriptions, and prevent the unnecessary waste of medical resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan keen on inking FTA with EU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:09:48 (By P. C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Though there appears to be little chance the European Union (EU) will soon begin talks with Taiwan on a free trade agreement (FTA), the government will continue to let the EU know its willingness to negotiate such a deal, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday.

Shih said he expressed Taiwan's interest in discussing an FTA to Ewa Bjorling, minister of trade of Sweden, which currently holds the EU's rotating presidency, when he met with her at a recent trade ministers' meeting of the World Trade Organization (WT0) in Geneva, Switzerland, from Nov. 30-Dec. 2.

According to Shih, however, Bjorling told him that it is not very possible that the EU would start such talks with Taiwan at present as it is busy negotiating several cooperation ventures with some regional organizations, including the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the Gulf Cooperation Council.
Shih insisted, however, that "we will continue to express our eagerness in this regard."

European Chamber of Commerce Taipei Chairman Philippe Pellegrin said in late October that reaching an agreement between Taiwan and the EU on trade is a pressing issue and much needed to advance two-way economic cooperation as well as create job and investment opportunities for both parties.
According to Pellegrin, the EU's GDP would increase by 2 billion euros, while Taiwan's economy would expand by 3.8 billion euros if the EU and Taiwan were to sign an FTA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global warming could spell trouble for Taiwan's water supply
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:46:16 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Global warming is increasing the likelihood of climate extremes and could lead to severe droughts in Taiwan in winter and spring as the frequency of small rainfalls diminishes, according to data released Friday by a local scientist.

The world has been experiencing more downpours and fewer drizzles in recent years because of climate change, and the amount of precipitation brought by typhoons is double that of 45 years ago, said Liu Shaw-chen, director of the Research Center for Environmental Changes at the Academia Sinica.

Speaking at a meeting held to discuss the prospects of the upcoming United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009 slated for Dec. 7-18 in Copenhagen, Liu said that with every one degree Celsius increase in the global temperature, the chances of heavy rains in Taiwan rise by 140 percent, while the chances of drizzles drop by 70 percent.
The frequency of drizzles has already fallen, with small rainfalls occurring only 35 days a year in Taiwan today, compared with 70 days 45 years ago, he said.
That's a worrying trend, Liu said, because drizzles are the main source of fresh water in spring and winter, and their decrease could lead to severe drought during these two seasons.
During the summer, however, the frequency of floods caused by heavy rains is expected to record a rapid increase in the 21st century, Liu warned.

The scientist also presented data showing that Taiwan's average surface air temperature in the 20th century rose 1.1 degrees Celsius -- nearly double the increase in the global average -- due mainly to global warming and the heat island effect.

The average global temperature rose 0.6 degrees Celsius during the century, and Liu estimated that the temperature increase in the 21st century will be three to six times higher, ranging between 1.8 degrees and 4 degrees Celsius.

To help stop global warming, countries around the world should conserve energy and work to develop alternative energy sources, such as solar power, wind power, biomass energy and even nuclear power, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening of Kaohsiung world trade center slated for 2014
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:55:56 (By Ema Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A projected world trade exhibition and convention center in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City is slated to begin operations in 2014 at the latest on the back of an increased budget, a government official said Friday.

Lin Sheng-chung, vice minister of economic affairs, divulged the timetable when he was asked, after giving a speech at the southern branch of the Executive Yuan, why Kaohsiung, the largest city in southern Taiwan, still lacks a world- class venue to hold exhibitions and conferences.

Stressing that the government is determined to promote the tourism, medical care, logistics services, cultural innovation and exhibition sectors to upgrade and transform Taiwan's economy, Lin noted that the service industry is increasingly playing a prominent role in Taiwan's economy, contributing 73 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product in 2008.

Wang Chang-hua, head of the Kaohsiung office of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the budget for building the planned Kaohsiung world trade center has been increased to NT$3.68 billion (US$113.2 million) to cope with rising prices of construction materials, up from the previous NT$3 billion.
Construction of the facility on a 4.5-hectare piece of land belonging to CPC Corporation, Taiwan, near the Kaohsiung Software Park is scheduled to be completed in 2011, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan beats Japan in East Asian Games women's basketball
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 23:40:52 (By Oscar Wu, Stanley Cheung, and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan solidified its chance to compete for gold in the East Asian Games women's basketball tournament after beating Japan 76-63 in a preliminary round game in Hong Kong Friday.

Taiwan led the Japanese 36-32 at halftime but broke the game open with a 25-9 third quarter. The winners were led by Liu Chun-yi with 22 points and Cheng Hui- yun with 19. Yoshie Sakurada led Japan with 21.

With the win, Taiwan joined Japan at the top of the five-team preliminary round pool with a 2-1 record. South Korea and China are both 1-1 and face off Sunday, while Taiwan concludes its preliminary round play on Monday against the Koreans.
All four teams are likely to reach the semifinals at the expense of Macau, but Taiwan would like to top the group to be better positioned in the semifinal round.
In the cue sports, Taiwan's Wu Yu-lun beat South Korea's Kim Do Hoon in the 15-red snooker single men's bronze medal match 4-0 to garner bronze.
But Taiwan's Lin Yuan-chun was defeated by Kim Ga Young of South Korea 7-3 in the women's 9-ball women's semifinals.
In table tennis, Taiwan's Wu Chih-chi and Huang Yi-hua beat their South Korean rivals 4-1 (11-5, 11-6, 7-11, 14-12) in the mixed doubles quarterfinals.
A second Taiwanese mixed doubles duo, Chiang Hung-chieh and Cheng Yi-ching, also lost in the quarterfinals 4-2 to Jiang Huajun and Tang Peng of Hong Kong.
Taiwanese teams lost to South Korea and Japan respectively in the women's doubles quarterfinals Friday.
Before Saturday's formal East Asian Games opening ceremony, a flag-raising ceremony was held Friday, with Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang presiding.
Taiwan was the seventh of the nine countries and regions to raise its flag based on its initial "T."
Lin Hung-dao, leader of the Taiwan team, led other members in the ceremony.
A total of nine countries and regions are participating in the 2009 East Asian Games, which end Dec. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sits on record-high forex reserves in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 18:41:48 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan recorded a foreign exchange reserve of US$347.19 billion as of the end of November, up US$5.968 billion from the previous month, the Taipei-based Central Bank of the Republic of China reported Friday.

The bank attributed the increase of forex reserves growth last month to the strong appreciation of major currencies, such as the euro and Japanese yen, against the U.S. dollar, apart from returns from foreign exchange reserve management.
The amount of reserves Taiwan held ranked the country as the world's fourth- largest forex holder in November, after China, Japan and Russia, the bank said.
