Taiwan's education system has traditionally focused more on requiring students to recite classics or knowledge rather than to encourage them to develop imagination. That's why Taiwan has lagged in scientific and technological development and represents a crisis in our education system. United Daily News Tribal smoke sign metaphor

Prosecutors in Hsinchu County set a commendable precedent recently with a ruling that confirmed the right of Atayal tribal people living in mountainous Jianshih Township to collect traffic fees from those who travel through their Smangus village.
Prosecutors cited two U.N.-sponsored international conventions signed into law by President Ma Ying-jeou earlier this year to support their ruling in favor of the Smangus tribal people.

Their ruling only highlights the central government's insufficient attention to the spirit of the two international conventions, reflected in a recent protest outside the Executive Yuan over what they called the slow progress in rebuilding their Typhoon Morakot-devastated villages.

Some demonstrators protested the government's failure to respond to their wish to live in family style temporary shelters instead of living in military barracks, where they have been housed for more than three months.

Others voiced their discontent with the government's plan to build permanent housing units on a piece of state-owned land away from their original villages. They demanded more say in how to rebuild their homes and tribal villages.
The central government should take a cue from the Hsinchu prosecutors' ruling and show more respect for indigenous people's views in planning post-disaster reconstruction projects.

Patience and time are needed in helping displaced aborigines relocate to an environment similar to their original homes to sustain their tribal history and culture. China Times Director's tears highlight local film industry's plight

Movie director Leon Dai shed tears at the Golden Horse Film Festival award presentation ceremony after his indie family drama won four awards, including the coveted best picture and best director awards.
His tears shed light on the destitution faced by Taiwan's filmmakers and movie professionals.

With a limited budget of NT$6 million, which is less than the cost of shooting single scenes in some blockbuster commercial films, Dai had to personally write the script for his film "I Can't Live Without You" in addition to directing and editing it.

The government has tried to improve the local filmmaking environment but has failed to work out effective strategies. Given its own financial straits, it can only offer prize money or subsidies to filmmakers who have won accolades in international or domestic competitions.

But government support alone cannot ensure the success of a film. Local filmmakers, including directors, may also have to adjust their attitudes, treating filmmaking as more than just an expression of their personal artistic ideals.

They need to produce films that can move the hearts and minds of moviegoers and should promote their films through commercial market channels. The government and filmmaking professionals should work hand-in-hand to create a positive or benign industrial cycle to make filmmaking a profitable enterprise. Commercial Times Improving civil service culture an urgent task

Premier Wu Den-yih's controversial directive for civil servants to come up with an action plan to improve ordinary people's lives only reveals how urgently the country needs to improve the culture of the country's civil service.

Administrative agencies have proposed more than 200 plans in a short period of time. While those plans covered nearly all aspects of people's everyday lives, Wu concluded, none of them were productive or hit the crux of problems facing the country.
The phenomenon epitomizes Taiwan's civil service culture. Civil servants tend to be perfunctory and pandering in dealing with work and have been lax in monitoring, supervision and evaluation.

If such an attitude is not improved, the government's policy planning and quality of implementation will never get better, at the expense of our country's overall development. Economic Daily News All-out efforts needed to correct distorted economic structure
In the wake of the global financial crisis, major countries around the global will definitely adjust their development strategies. Taiwan will be no exception.

To keep abreast of future global development tendencies, we should study possible changes in the global economy in the years ahead. Moreover, we should better understand major distortions in Taiwan's economic development over the past decade to serve as a basis for improvement.
First of all, we should discontinue heavy dependence on export-oriented and trade surplus-fueled economic expansion. Such reliance has only resulted in unbalanced economic development.
The overemphasis on a few industries that heavily rely on exports should be adjusted, and the trend of export industries' heavy reliance on imports of parts and components also needs to be addressed.
Last but not least, more energy should be devoted to the development of the service sector, whose development has lagged behind.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parties pull all the stops on final day of election campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 19:41:14 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) both revved up their campaign efforts Friday, the last day before the three-in-one local elections.

KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chuen-po expressed optimism over the party's chances of taking 11 of the 17 city and county seats up for grabs in the elections. However, the other six seats are more "difficult," he said, listing Hsinchu, Yilan and Chiayi counties as the "most unpredictable."
The 17 areas are Hsinchu, Chiayi and Keelung cities and Hsinchu, Miaoli, Changhua, Nantou, Yunlin, Chiayi, Hualien, Yilan, Taitung, Kinmen, Lienchiang (Matsu), Penghu, Pingtung and Taoyuan counties.
At present, the KMT holds 14 of the 17 seats, while the DPP controls the other three in Chiayi, Yunlin and Pingtung counties.
Chan said the KMT's "difficulties" spring from three main factors, the first being that three of the county magistrate seats are currently in the hands of the DPP.
The second is that the KMT's nomination process for the three counties it holds was rocky and there has been little coalescence since, Chan said, citing the situation in Hsinchu and Hualien counties.
The third factor is that Yilan County is traditionally a DPP stronghold, he added.
In line with President Ma Ying-jeou's "get-out-the-vote" campaign, Chan urged voters to go to the polls Saturday, and predicted that the turnout rate will be between 67 percent and 68 percent.

Meanwhile, President Ma, who is also chairman of the KMT, stayed on the campaign trail Friday, attending a ceremony in Hualien County in the morning to mark the start of an electrification project for the eastern railway system.
He later went on to Taitung, then to Yilan County and finally to Hsinchu County where he was expected to speak at big rally later in the evening.

His slipping popularity is one of the factors that the opposition DPP has been playing on and it has also been attacking what it calls his "China-leaning" policies, especially his plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
The DPP is expected to retain control of the three counties it now holds and make a big push to take back Yilan County from the KMT.
On Friday, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen stumped for Chang Hwa-kuan and Peng Shao- chin, the party's magisterial candidates in Chiayi and Hsinchu counties, respectively.
Later in the day she traveled to Yilan County to attend a night rally for the DPP candidate there, Lin Tsong-shyan.
This will be the first major election since President Ma took office in May 2008 and it is seen by many as a mid-term test of his administration.
In addition to electing city mayors and county magistrates Saturday, voters will also cast ballots for city and county councilors and township chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei MRT's Wenhu line experiences yet another shutdown
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:06:57 (By Jian Chen, Chen Hung-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Wenshan-Neihu line of the Taipei MRT system was shut down for 57 minutes Friday afternoon due to network abnormalities, the latest in a series of breakdowns experienced by the line since its launch eight months ago.
Services on the line were resumed at 4: 37 p.m. after the problem was fixed.
Tan Kuo-kuang, deputy secretary-general of the Taipei City government, explained that the incident was caused by an unstable network converter at the Zhongxiao Fuxing station.
A total of 1,520 passengers on 23 trains were affected, all of whom were evacuated within 15 minutes after the shutdown and provided with free bus services instead, Tan said.

The shutdown came just three days after the city government announced that the reliability of the Wenshan-Neihu line reached 99 percent during the September- November period, following completion of system upgrades at the end of August.
The latest incident followed a collision Nov. 26 between two trains that were approaching the Neihu depot for routine maintenance.
The Taipei Rapid Transit Corp., which operates the MRT system, has claimed that the collision was the result of inadequate platform length.
When questioned by an investigation panel set up by the Taipei City Council Friday, however, an official from the city's Department of Rapid Transit Systems (DORTS) rejected such a claim.

According to Chen Yao-wei, director of the DORTS's East District Project Office, the length of the platform should not be a problem because the train carriages are supposed to be detached in the depot, not on the platform.

DOC.HEADLINE: First 4 millionth tourist to Taiwan expected on Saturday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:14:22 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The four millionth tourist to Taiwan this year is expected to arrive on Saturday, the first time that tourist arrivals to this country will surpass the four million mark, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said Friday.

The lucky visitor will receive a debit card with a cash value of NT$400,000 (US$12,353) for exclusive use in Taiwan during his or her visit, bureau officials said. He or she will also receive many other gifts.
To attract more tourists to Taiwan, the Tourism Bureau launched the incentive offer this year as part of an ambitious program to increase the number of visitors.

Focusing on the high-tech and manufacturing sectors in the past, Taiwan has long neglected promoting the tourism sector. But in recent years, it has recognized that its abundance of scenic natural beauty -- including majestic mountains and beautiful coastlines -- as well as cultural assets, are resources it can use to develop the tourism industry and boost economic growth.
The one millionth, two millionth and three millionth visitors received debit cards earlier this year, but with a lower value.
Last year, more than 3.84 million visitors traveled to Taiwan, according to official figures.

To further promote tourism, the bureau, in conjunction with the Northeast Coast and Guanyinshan National Scenic Area Administration and Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, is staging two photo exhibitions at the airport's terminal from Dec. 4 until Feb. 28, 2010.

One exhibition features women dressed in bridal gowns posing at beautiful spots along Taiwan's northeast coast, which has long been a popular destination among Taiwan's newly weds to take wedding photos.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan officials fly to Myanmar to help detained seamen
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:40:56 (By Lin Ching-ping and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two Taiwan officials posted in Thailand flew to Myanmar Friday to visit four Taiwanese nationals working on fishing vessels seized by Myamar authorities more than two weeks ago.

The officials will try to determine what legal violations were committed by the men and provide them with the necessary assistance, according to the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Thailand.
The crew members were working on four fishing boats that were seized by Myanmar authorities Nov. 18, probably because they intruded into that country's exclusive economic zone.

As soon as it was informed of the situation, Taiwan decided to send officials to Myanmar to help deal with the incident. The trip only became possible, however, after Myanmar authorities finally issued visas to the officials Thursday.
Before that, the TECO in Thailand had asked Taiwanese businessmen in Myanmar to help deliver daily necessities to the detained crew members.

DOC.HEADLINE: Int'l students to participate in speech contest, food fair in Pingtung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:49:07 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 200 international students attending Taiwan universities on academic scholarships granted by Taiwan's International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) will participate in aChinese-language speech contest and food fair at National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan on Saturday and Sunday.

Since 1998 when Taiwan universities started offering bachelor's, master's and Ph.D. programs taught in English, the ICDF has provided scholarships to 532 students from 40 countries. The ICDF, along with 16 universities that offer 24 such programs, has been organizing parties for its scholarship recipients at the end of every year.

As co-sponsor of this year's party, the Pingtung University of Science and Technology will hold a speech contest for the international students to test their Chinese language ability. Contestants are expected to relate their experiences in learning Mandarin and their most unforgettable moments in Taiwan.
The food fair on Saturday evening will feature authentic dishes prepared by students from the Asian and Pacific region, Africa, and Central and South America.

The ICDF was set up in 1997 to consolidate international cooperation programs that were previously sponsored by the International Economic Cooperation Development Fund and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Committee of International Technical Cooperation (CITC).

It primarily cooperates with Taiwan's allies in Central and SouthAmerica , the East Caribbean, Africa and the Asia Pacific region, and its activities include technical assistance, investment and lending operations, education and training, and humanitarian assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-medical records to be fully in place within five years: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Nov. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 20:53:30 (By Erin Ho and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's top economic planner said Friday that it hopes that all health care institutions will use electronic medical records within five years.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) reported that 95 percent of public and private hospitals and 56 percent of clinics use e-medical records at present.

A council official said that the government will work with the private sector to realize the goal of "instituting e-medical records, digitalization of images and examination reports, and the capacity to exchange medical images between hospitals within five years. "

The CEPD said that to upgrade health care quality, many nations have actively engaged in medical reforms, including the United States, which will spend US$19.2 billion between 2009 and 2012 on medical reforms, and China, which will invest 850 billion yuan.
Medical care is one of the six emerging industries that Taiwan is promoting, and the e-medical records will be one of the priorities in the sector, the CEPD said.

Once the e-medical records system is adopted by all health care institutions, patients will be able to get their medical records anywhere in the country simply by providing their National Health Insurance IC cards.

The medical records to be digitalized include medical examination reports, scans such as computer tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, blood test results and prescription records.
The plan aims to shorten waiting times of patients at clinics, help patients avoid unneeded duplication of medical tests and prescriptions, and prevent the unnecessary waste of medical resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan keen on inking FTA with EU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:09:48 (By P. C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Though there appears to be little chance the European Union (EU) will soon begin talks with Taiwan on a free trade agreement (FTA), the government will continue to let the EU know its willingness to negotiate such a deal, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Friday.

Shih said he expressed Taiwan's interest in discussing an FTA to Ewa Bjorling, minister of trade of Sweden, which currently holds the EU's rotating presidency, when he met with her at a recent trade ministers' meeting of the World Trade Organization (WT0) in Geneva, Switzerland, from Nov. 30-Dec. 2.

According to Shih, however, Bjorling told him that it is not very possible that the EU would start such talks with Taiwan at present as it is busy negotiating several cooperation ventures with some regional organizations, including the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and the Gulf Cooperation Council.
Shih insisted, however, that "we will continue to express our eagerness in this regard."

European Chamber of Commerce Taipei Chairman Philippe Pellegrin said in late October that reaching an agreement between Taiwan and the EU on trade is a pressing issue and much needed to advance two-way economic cooperation as well as create job and investment opportunities for both parties.
According to Pellegrin, the EU's GDP would increase by 2 billion euros, while Taiwan's economy would expand by 3.8 billion euros if the EU and Taiwan were to sign an FTA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Global warming could spell trouble for Taiwan's water supply
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:46:16 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Global warming is increasing the likelihood of climate extremes and could lead to severe droughts in Taiwan in winter and spring as the frequency of small rainfalls diminishes, according to data released Friday by a local scientist.

The world has been experiencing more downpours and fewer drizzles in recent years because of climate change, and the amount of precipitation brought by typhoons is double that of 45 years ago, said Liu Shaw-chen, director of the Research Center for Environmental Changes at the Academia Sinica.

Speaking at a meeting held to discuss the prospects of the upcoming United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009 slated for Dec. 7-18 in Copenhagen, Liu said that with every one degree Celsius increase in the global temperature, the chances of heavy rains in Taiwan rise by 140 percent, while the chances of drizzles drop by 70 percent.
The frequency of drizzles has already fallen, with small rainfalls occurring only 35 days a year in Taiwan today, compared with 70 days 45 years ago, he said.
That's a worrying trend, Liu said, because drizzles are the main source of fresh water in spring and winter, and their decrease could lead to severe drought during these two seasons.
During the summer, however, the frequency of floods caused by heavy rains is expected to record a rapid increase in the 21st century, Liu warned.

The scientist also presented data showing that Taiwan's average surface air temperature in the 20th century rose 1.1 degrees Celsius -- nearly double the increase in the global average -- due mainly to global warming and the heat island effect.

The average global temperature rose 0.6 degrees Celsius during the century, and Liu estimated that the temperature increase in the 21st century will be three to six times higher, ranging between 1.8 degrees and 4 degrees Celsius.

To help stop global warming, countries around the world should conserve energy and work to develop alternative energy sources, such as solar power, wind power, biomass energy and even nuclear power, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Opening of Kaohsiung world trade center slated for 2014
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 22:55:56 (By Ema Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A projected world trade exhibition and convention center in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City is slated to begin operations in 2014 at the latest on the back of an increased budget, a government official said Friday.

Lin Sheng-chung, vice minister of economic affairs, divulged the timetable when he was asked, after giving a speech at the southern branch of the Executive Yuan, why Kaohsiung, the largest city in southern Taiwan, still lacks a world- class venue to hold exhibitions and conferences.

Stressing that the government is determined to promote the tourism, medical care, logistics services, cultural innovation and exhibition sectors to upgrade and transform Taiwan's economy, Lin noted that the service industry is increasingly playing a prominent role in Taiwan's economy, contributing 73 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product in 2008.

Wang Chang-hua, head of the Kaohsiung office of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said the budget for building the planned Kaohsiung world trade center has been increased to NT$3.68 billion (US$113.2 million) to cope with rising prices of construction materials, up from the previous NT$3 billion.
Construction of the facility on a 4.5-hectare piece of land belonging to CPC Corporation, Taiwan, near the Kaohsiung Software Park is scheduled to be completed in 2011, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan beats Japan in East Asian Games women's basketball
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/04/09 23:40:52 (By Oscar Wu, Stanley Cheung, and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan solidified its chance to compete for gold in the East Asian Games women's basketball tournament after beating Japan 76-63 in a preliminary round game in Hong Kong Friday.

Taiwan led the Japanese 36-32 at halftime but broke the game open with a 25-9 third quarter. The winners were led by Liu Chun-yi with 22 points and Cheng Hui- yun with 19. Yoshie Sakurada led Japan with 21.

With the win, Taiwan joined Japan at the top of the five-team preliminary round pool with a 2-1 record. South Korea and China are both 1-1 and face off Sunday, while Taiwan concludes its preliminary round play on Monday against the Koreans.
All four teams are likely to reach the semifinals at the expense of Macau, but Taiwan would like to top the group to be better positioned in the semifinal round.
In the cue sports, Taiwan's Wu Yu-lun beat South Korea's Kim Do Hoon in the 15-red snooker single men's bronze medal match 4-0 to garner bronze.
But Taiwan's Lin Yuan-chun was defeated by Kim Ga Young of South Korea 7-3 in the women's 9-ball women's semifinals.
In table tennis, Taiwan's Wu Chih-chi and Huang Yi-hua beat their South Korean rivals 4-1 (11-5, 11-6, 7-11, 14-12) in the mixed doubles quarterfinals.
A second Taiwanese mixed doubles duo, Chiang Hung-chieh and Cheng Yi-ching, also lost in the quarterfinals 4-2 to Jiang Huajun and Tang Peng of Hong Kong.
Taiwanese teams lost to South Korea and Japan respectively in the women's doubles quarterfinals Friday.
Before Saturday's formal East Asian Games opening ceremony, a flag-raising ceremony was held Friday, with Hong Kong Chief Executive Donald Tsang presiding.
Taiwan was the seventh of the nine countries and regions to raise its flag based on its initial "T."
Lin Hung-dao, leader of the Taiwan team, led other members in the ceremony.
A total of nine countries and regions are participating in the 2009 East Asian Games, which end Dec. 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70 percent of Taiwan's employees appreciate co-workers: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 15:06:07 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 70 percent of Taiwan's white-collar employees are grateful for co-workers who have given them a helping hand over the past year at a time when 2009 is drawing to a close, a recent online survey indicated.
The survey conducted by the 104 Job Bank found that 56 percent of Taiwan's office workers are also thankful for their superiors, while 16 percent indicated they appreciate their customers.

According to the poll, 41 percent of the office workers surveyed said they appreciate their co-workers or department chiefs for "valuable advice they have given them to help them resolve problems" over the past year.
Meanwhile, 32 precent are thankful for "the assistance that co-workers have offered," according to the poll.

Fang Kuang-wei, 104 Job Bank's public relations manager, said one year after the global financial crisis, Taiwan's white-collar employees now sense a higher degree of gratitude toward "those co-workers who have helped them in the office."

The survey also found that 47 percent of Taiwan's office workers prefer to express their appreciation verbally, ahead of 31 percent who opt for "concrete action to show their appreciation" and 23 percent who choose to "fully perform their duties" as the best way to display their thankfulness.
The poll was carried out over the Internet from Nov. 30-Dec. 1, collecting 1,529 valid responses. It has a margin of error of 2.51 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's voters go to polls in 17 counties, cities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 15:13:36 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Chiu Chun-chin, Ni Kuo-yen and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Seventeen of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities will have a new magistrate or mayor as well as township chiefs or councilors on Saturday, with voters casting their ballots between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. in the once-every-four years local elections.

According to the Central Election Commission (CEC), a total of 54 candidates are running in the county magistrate and city mayor elections, 18 of whom have been nominated by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), 14 by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and one by the Hakka Party. The rest of the candidates are running as independents.
A total of 935 candidates are vying for 592 seats up for grabs in city and county councils around the country, while 470 people are fighting for 211 township chief posts, the CEC said.

The number of eligible voters in county magistrate and city mayoral elections totals 7.05 million, while some 7.04 million people are eligible to vote in the elections for city and county councilors and 6.23 million for the township chief elections, it added.
There are 6,384 polling stations and a total of 81,926 people to manage the stations.

Estimating that 60-65 percent of the eligible voters will go to polls and the vote-counting is expected to be completed after 10 p.m., the CEC reminded eligible voters to bring their identification cards, personal seals and voting notifications to the ballot stations and advised those who develop cold systems to wear face masks when going to vote.

Premier Wu Den-yih and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, who cast their votes early in the morning in their hometowns of Nantou County and Taoyuan County, respectively, called on eligible voters to go to polls.
"I hope that the election process will be very fair, equitable and transparent and the counting will be completed in time," said Wu.
The biggest of Saturday's battles is expected to be fought over the Kinmen magistrate position, as seven people are running for the post.

According to the Kinmen Airport authorities, eligible voters seemed to be flocking back for the elections, as a total of 43 flights from Taiwan to Kinmen on Friday were nearly all full, with an estimated 4,000 people arriving in the county that same day.

As eight cities and counties -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County -- will not elect new chiefs until late 2010, this year's elections will be held in only 17 of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's exports expected to show growth in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 15:21:29 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports are expected to have grown for the first time in more than a year in November, after declining for 13 consecutive months, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Saturday.
The November figures for export volume are scheduled to be released on Dec. 7.
In October, export volume was valued at US$19.82 billion, the highest level recorded over the past year since the outbreak of the global financial crisis.
While the amount of exports in October still marked a contraction of 4.7 percent compared with the same month last year, it nevertheless was the first single- digit decline recorded so far this year.

Lin Li-chen, chief of the MOF's Department of Statistics, said that as the decline in exports has continued to narrow, November is a crucial month to watch to see if Taiwan's exports have successfully emerged from the downturn.

Driven by seasonal demand and a recovery, albeit small in Taiwan's major export markets including the United States, Europe and Japan, the country's exports are expected to further increase to US$20 billion in November, Lin said.
She added that the exports could even post a positive year-on-year growth -- probably by double digits -- in November.
The growth is likely to significantly expand in December, she predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Township's candidates detained on vote-buying charges
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 15:29:03 (By Andrew Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: All three candidates running for township chief in Guangfu township, eastern Taiwan's Hualien County, have been detained on charges of buying votes, as Taiwan's local elections in 17 of its 25 counties and cities kicked off Saturday.

The Hualien District Court ordered earlier in the day the detention of Huang Jung-cheng, the incumbent township chief, after prosecutors presented evidence that alleged Huang was involved in vote-buying.

Huang became the third candidate in the the township chief election who was detained on a charge of vote-buying, after his two competitors Chen Wen-kuang and Lin Yuan-juei were arrested each on a similar charge a few days ago.
Officials in charge of elections in the county known for its scenic landscape said that although all of the candidates have been detained, the election will still continue.
No matter who is elected, the winner can still be sworn in as the new township chief and serve as township chief until he is found guilty, the officials said.
All of the three defendants have insisted on their innocence.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who has been called a "Teflon-man" for his reputation for fighting corruption in politics, has vowed to crack down on bribery in this election.

Amid Ma's vows, the Ministry of Justice made public its statistics that showed as of Friday, district prosecutors around the country had indicted 76 people for vote-buying, 23 of whom were KMT members.

A total of 150 people have been detained during the MOJ's move to keep Saturday's elections clean, including 30 KMT members, 14 members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and 23 people who have no party membership, the statistics showed.
Some of the defendants and detained are candidates while others are the family members or assistants of candidates, MOJ officials stated.

Saturday's elections will produce new county magistrates and mayors, city and county councilors, as well as township chiefs in 17 counties and cities, excluding the Taipei city and county, Taichung city and county, Tainan city and county, and Kaohsiung city and county, which will hold elections next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 5, or the 19th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1782: Martin Van Buren, the eighth president of the United States, is born.
1791: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, Austrian composer considered among the greatest and most prolific composers in history, dies in Vienna of kidney failure at the age of 35. He had written more than 600 works.
1792: George Washington is reelected president of the United States.
1904: The Russo-Japanese War breaks out, with Japanese troops occupying Height 203, the ideal position for capturing Lushun, west of the port city of Talien.
1906: Russian Adm. Niebogatov goes on trial on charges of surrendering ships to the Japanese.
1915: Chen Chi-mei, a follower of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, leads a revolt against Yuan Shih-kai by trying to seize the warship Chaoho. His attempt fails the following day.
1928: The Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China is formally established.
1933: The United States celebrates the end of 14 long years of prohibition when the government nullifies the 18th Amendment, which outlawed the production, transportation or sale of alcohol.
1945: Six U.S. Navy aircraft carrying 27 airmen go missing without a trace in the Atlantic Ocean near Bermuda.
1946: A strong earthquake hits southern Taiwan, killing 69 people and injuring 170.
1949: Li Tsung-jen, acting president of the Republic of China, leaves Hong Kong for the United States.
1950: North Korean and Communist Chinese troops recapture Pyongyang as United Nations forces are forced to withdraw southward.
1957: The Dachien to Lishan section of the Central Cross-Island Highway opens to traffic.
1957: The Indonesian government orders the expulsion of all Dutch nationals.
1968: The Taiwan Provincial Government launches a one-person-one-dollar movement to raise money for national sports development.
1972: The Chase Manhattan Bank of New York opens a branch office in Taipei.
1975: Campaign activities for the Dec. 20 legislative elections open with 61 candidates contesting 37 Taiwan area seats.
1976: Professional golfers Kuo Chi-hsiung and Hsu Sheng-san leave for Palm Springs, Calif., to take part in the 24th World Cup professional golf tournament.
1978: The Soviet Union signs a 20-year treaty of friendship with Afghanistan.
1984: Ninety-three miners are killed in an accident at the Haishanyikeng mining pit in Shanhsia township, Taipei County.
1984: The Central Standing Committee of the Kuomintang unanimously supports a bill to amend the Firearms Control Act, imposing heavy punishments on the unauthorized manufacture of deadly weapons, with a maximum sentence of death.
1985: The United States decides to pull out of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
1985: Four businessmen are sentenced to prison terms ranging from two-and-a-half years to 12 years by a military court under the Taiwan Garrison General Headquarters for conducting direct trade with the Communist Chinese.
1995: Javier Solana, the Spanish foreign minister, is appointed the secretary- general of NATO.
1999: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Chang Chang-pang leaves for Miami to attend the annual Miami Conference on the Caribbean and Latin America.
2000: A total of 105 young Indonesians begin to receive two years of professional training in Taiwan as part of the ROC's efforts to help its major Southeast Asian trading partner develop small- and medium-sized enterprises.
2001: Beijing authorities sternly rejects Taiwan's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commence dialogue on the "three direct links" issue under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The "three direct links" refers to direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler answers to the desire of the subjects, it manifests an understanding of approvals and disapprovals of the people. When there is such an understanding, the good will be discovered and rewarded and the bad will be discovered and punished, and the country will surely attain order."

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing prices in Taiwan's 'Silicon Valley' to set record: agents
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 16:03:46 (By Yi-fong Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: As the economic recovery has brought a lot of orders to Taiwan's high-tech companies, the real estate market in northern Taiwan's Hsinchu areaVthe island's high-tech manufacturing base -- is expected to benefit most, with both housing prices and trading volumes to set a record by the end of the year, according to real estate brokerages.

The local real estate agency U-trust said since high-tech businesses began booming in the first quarter, home purchases and sales in Hsinchu have reached 7,600 in Q3, up from 7,500 in Q2, which was a 24 percent rise from the previous quarter.

Liu Pin-yao, a spokesman of the real estate agency, said he expected the housing trade volume in the technology-based area for the year to not only exceed last year's volume, but also reach an all-time high.

Liu said the housing prices in Jhubei City, a transportation center of Hsinchu County, reached NT$135,000 (US$4,192) per ping (3.305 square meters) in Q2, nearly the same as last year's high of NT$136,000.
The rising year-end bonuses offered by the high-tech companies will help increase homebuying in Hsinchu by the end of the year, he said.

Meanwhile, the real estate market in Hsinchu's neighbor Taoyuan City, also enjoyed growth. The city's newly-developed area around Taoyuan County Arts Park, which will be completed by the end of this year, and the Nankan area, both saw a growth rate of 40 percent for the prices of commercial property in the past two years, he added.

Property prices are also expected to rise in major cities in Taiwan, including Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung. Many of the buyers are believed to be speculators who are eying Taiwan markets as good places to invest in property.

They expect the markets to grow after Taiwan signs the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. Some of the buyers or potential buyers are big domestic and overseas investors of properties which have started to look for luxury mansions as investment targets in recent months.
Greg Yeh, chief consultant at Evertrust Rehouse, said they have received many queries about luxury mansions recently and just closed a deal worth over NT$100 million.

Yeh said that based on the experience of Hong Kong's real estate prices, which rose sharply after Hong Kong signed the closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) with China in 2003, Taiwan's market prospects are also good.

However, unlike Hong Kong, Taiwan is a democracy and the ruling party Kuomintang, with an eye on keeping the presidency in the 2012 presidential election, is eager to appease public dissatisfaction over the high prices of property, which make it difficult for young couples, single people, or even couples in their 40s or older to afford to buy their own property. Many are living with their parents or parents-in-law.

A recent survey conducted by the government found the unaffordable property prices to be a major complaint of Taiwanese people, prompting Premier Wu Den- yih to announce the central government will make plans to build affordable housing near subway lines.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 counties, cities in Taiwan perform poorly in trash recycling
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 16:17:02 (By Vicky Hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Ten out of 25 counties and cities around Taiwan have failed to reach the country's recycling target, indicating there is plenty room for improvement in this respect, according to a report released Saturday by the Legislative Yuan.
The Environmental Protection Administration has set a target of recycling 31 percent of all waste for 2008. The target will be raised to above 31 percent for 2009 and 2010.
However, in 2008, the recycling rates of 10 counties and cities fell below the benchmark, the report revealed.
Showing the poorest performance was Yunlin County, with a recycling rate of just 17.55 percent.
Coming in second was Chiayi County, at 18.94 percent.

The other eight localities whose performance was also not up to standard were Pingtung County, Liangchiang County, Changhua County, Chiayi City, Taichung County, Taitung County, Tainan County and Kinmen County, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No major violations on election day: Central Election Commission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 17:11:57 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) said Saturday that no major violation has been reported so far on election day, as over 7 million eligible voters are scheduled to cast their ballots to elect new city mayors, county magistrates, local councilors, as well as township heads.
Teng Tien-yu, secretary-general of the CEC, said that the overall election process went smoothly, with only a few minor violations.

According to National Police Agency, as of 12:35 p.m., a total of 11 violations involving 14 people had been reported, including five ballots that were torn up, two taken out of the polling station, one person illegally displaying his ballot, and another case involving the arrest of a wanted criminal when he went to vote.
Also, four people were arrested for alleged vote buying in Miaoli County, the NPA said.

Meanwhile, the election committee in Hualien County reported another mild violation in which a voter's cell phone went off while he was casting his ballots. The voter was subject to a fine of at least NT$30,000 (US$ 931), as the Public Officials Election and Recall Law stipulates that voters shall not take mobile phones and cameras to polling stations and any violator shall be punished with a fine from NT$30,000 to NT$300,000.

As to a report to the authorities in Hsinchu County Friday night that some councilor ballots were found by individuals before the election day, the Hsinchu County election committee issued a press release Saturday saying that no ballots were missing after a careful inventory was conducted, but the district prosecutors are still investigating the report.
Many of the party heavyweights had also performed their election duties, including Premier Wu Den-yih, who went to vote in his hometown Nantou County Saturday morning.
"The people are above all else. We have to respect the decision made by their sacred ballots, " said the premier, who expressed hope of seeing a fair, equitable and transparent election.

On the other hand, Wu Poh-hsiung, honorary chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), appeared to be trying to maintain a low-profile by not going to the polling station with his son Wu Chih-yang, who is running for the magistrate position in Taoyuan County.

The KMT honorary chairman spoke only through his party members that he was not in any position to speak publicly on the elections given that he no longer holds any public office in the government or the party.

Seventeen of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities around Taiwan will have their maigistrate or mayor, as well as township chiefs or councilors on Saturday, with voters casting their ballots between 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. in the once-every-four years local elections.

As eight cities and counties -- Taipei City, Taipei County, Taichung City, Taichung County, Tainan City, Tainan County, Kaohsiung Cit and Kaohsiung County -- will not elect new chiefs until late 2010, this year's elections will be held in only 17 of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties.

According to the Central Election Commission (CEC), the number of eligible voters in county magistrate and city mayoral elections totals 7.05 million, with some 7.04 million people eligible to vote in the elections for city and county councilors and 6.23 million in the township chief elections.
Estimating that 60-65 percent of the eligible voters will go to polls, the CEC said the vote-counting is expected to be completed after 10 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opposition hopes to gain seats in local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 17:52:33 (By K. H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: If the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) could garner more votes in this year's local elections compared to the election in 2005, it would mean that Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen's reformatory approach to running the opposition party has won voters' support, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said Saturday.

"Should the DPP win more than the 38.2 percent of the votes which it grabbed four years ago, such an outcome would mean that voters are supportive of the reformatory approach adopted by Chairwoman Tsai Ying-wen," the DPP spokesman said.
But Tsai Ying-wen will definitely assume the responsibility if the DPP grabs fewer seats than four years ago, the spokesman said.

The DPP currently controls Yunlin, Chiayi and Pingtung counties, and hopes to take back the magistrate of Ilan, where it stands a good chance of defeating the KMT incumbents. The opposition party has estimated that it will win in Ilan County by a narrow margin.

The elections of city mayors and county magistrates, as well as local councilors and township chief kicked off Saturday at 8: 00 a.m. The polls closed at 5: 00 p.m., with results expected after 10 p.m.
It was estimated that 60-65 percent of some seven million eligible voters went to the polls scattered across 17 cities and counties.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2008 Nobel laureate in chemistry to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 18:06:16 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Roger Yonchien Tsien, a 2008 Nobel laureate in chemistry, will arrive in Taiwan next week for a four-day visit during which he will discuss his discoveries, the organizer said Saturday.

The Chinese-American chemist is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech titled "Painting cell signals with a palette of fluorescent proteins" at Academia Sinica on Friday, and another titled "building molecules to image and help treat cancer and inflammatory disease" at the National Taiwan University Dec. 14, according to a statement released by the Academia Sinica.

Currently a professor of the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department at the University of California, San Diego, Tsien won the Nobel Prize with two other scientists, Martin Chalfie and Osamu Shimomura, for their discovery and development of the green fluorescent protein (GFP).

Among the co-winners, Tsien made unprecedented contributions to the general understanding of how GFP fluoresces, and extended the color palette beyond green, allowing researchers to give various proteins and cells different colors.

The discovery of GFP has led to its widespread use as a tagging tool in bioscience research. By using DNA technology, researchers can now use GFP as a fluorescent marker to help better observe the movements, positions and interactions of tagged proteins.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hopes to strengthen Peru ties through ICDF alumni
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 18:51:49 (By Huang Kwang-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Peru has encouraged Peruvians who have received Taiwan's assistance through the Taipei-based International Cooperation and Development Fund (ICDF) to help promote relations between the two countries.

Addressing a Christmas dinner held by the Peru chapter of the Taiwan ICDF Alumni Society in the Peruvian capital of Lima Thursday, Alejandro R.K. Huang thanked members for coordinating a series of events over the past yer that helped raise Taiwan's profile in Peru.
Huang said he hopes members will share with their friends their learning experience in Taiwan so as to advance Taiwan-Peru ties.
The Taiwan ICDF Alumni Society consists of people who have participated in training and education programs provided in Taiwan or overseas by the ICDF.
The Peru chapter was established in 1996 and has 40 members.

Also at the dinner, society members said they were very grateful for the opportunities provided by the ICDF, which allowed them to gain a lot of knowledge and experience and helped them move forward in their careers.
They also said they were deeply impressed by the Taiwanese people's friendliness and the country's social progress.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded dwarf sperm whale rescued in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 19:12:09 (By Chang Che-fon and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An injured dwarf sperm whale stranded on a beach close to a military harbor in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, was rescued and taken to a dolphin and whale rescue center Saturday.

The whale, which is over 2.5 meters long and weighs over 400 kilograms, ran aground on the beach after suffering what appeared to be shark-bite wounds, said Wang Chien-ping, a professor at the Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University's Marine Biology and Cetacean Research Center who helped in the rescue.
Wang said after checking on the whale, he spotted three wounds on its back, which imply it might have been attacked by sharks.
Judging from its size, it is a "grandfather" whale, Wang said, adding that he believes the whale was left behind by its companions after becoming injured.
The Marine Corps Command received a report of the stranded whale on the Zuoying Taosiyuan beach earlier in the day. It then contacted Wang for his assistance, according to Marine officers.
If the whale is taken back to sea in its current condition, it may not be able to survive, Wang said.
Dwarf sperm whales are the smallest of all whales. Normally, it grows up to 2.7 meters in length and 250 kilograms in weight -- making it smaller than the bigger dolphins.
The species makes slow, deliberate movements with little splashes or blows and will usually lie motionless when at the sea's surface. Consequently it can be observed only in very calm seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Independent claims victory in Hualien County magistrate race
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 19:15:27 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Fu Kun-chi, an independent candidate in Saturday's elections for local government chiefs and councilors, announced at his campaign headquarters that he has won the magistracy for eastern Taiwan's Hualien County.
Tu Li-hua, the candidate of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the main rival of Fu, conceded defeat and congratulated Fu on his election victory.

Fu, who was expelled by the KMT for insisting in vying for the magistracy in Hualien County, splitting the KMT vote, enjoyed an astounding lead over Tu and another independent candidate Chang Chih-ming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's ruling party KMT loses fiercely fought Ilan County
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 19:36:47 (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Ilan County Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua of the Kuomintang party on Saturday conceded defeat to his opponent from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and vowed to shoulder the responsibilities of losing the ruling party's control of a key county.
Two hours after polling stations closed, the vote counts showed that Lu was approximately 12,000 votes behind his opponent Lin Tsong-shyan from the DPP.
Lu conceded defeat around 7 p.m. and said that he respected the choices of the voters.
Lu was elected magistrate of Ilan County in 2005 after 24 years, or six terms of non-partisan and DPP rule of the northeastern county.

DOC.HEADLINE: Van Gogh exhibition to open Dec. 11 in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 19:40:57 (By Chen Yun-yu and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The last piece of work the 19th century Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh painted while he was in an asylum was unveiled in Taipei Saturday in the final countdown to the special three-month exhibition scheduled to open here on Dec. 11.

The painting "Country Road in Provence by Night, " also known as "Road with Cypress and Star, " was unboxed Saturday in Taipei. It is the last piece van Gogh created during his stay at the asylum in Saint Remy, Provence. The Dutch master had said that the painting would be the last time he painted stars.

"The painting represents van Gogh's view on the universe. People can feel the energy in the painter's life when they appreciate the painting," Evert van Straaten, director of the Netherlands-based Kroller-Muller Museum, said about the piece, which is the museum's crown jewel.

The museum, which has the second-largest van Gogh collection in the world, loaned most of 98 van Gogh paintings that will be on display, to the National Museum of History for the exhibition in Taipei.
Van Straaten is in Taiwan to attend an opening ceremony on Dec. 10, demonstrating the importance he attaches to the exhibition.

Van Straaten said the exhibition, which has one quarter of the Kroller-Muller Museum collection on van Gogh's oil paintings and some of his sketches in the early stage, will provide art enthusiasts a more comprehensive picture of the Dutch artist's creations.
According to van Straaten, it was very difficult for his museum to collect van Gogh's work, as the Dutch painter had requested his family not to let his paintings get in the hands of other people.
Museum founder Helene Kroller-Muller had traveled across Europe and used all kinds of means to collect van Gogh's paintings through exchanges or trading with other painters' works, Straaten said.

The exhibition, titled "Van Gogh: The Flaming Soul, " is scheduled to run from Dec. 11 to March 28 at the National Museum of History, featuring 98 of van Gogh's works -- 77 drawings and 21 oil paintings.
One painting in the exhibit -- Vase with Flower and Thistles -- is on loan from Japan's Pola Museum of Art.
According to Huang Yung-chuan, director of the National Museum of History, the van Gogh exhibit has a record insurance amount of NT$25 billion (US$776 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Ruling KMT wins island counties in local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 20:03:42 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Candidates from Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) running for magistrate posts in the outlying island counties of Kinmen and Lienchiang (Matsu) declared victory in local elections held Saturday.

Yang Sui-sheng, the KMT candidate running for the magistrate seat of Lienchiang County, which administers the outlying Matsu Islands, beat two other candidates in the race for the top seat in the county.
Lee Wo-shih, the KMT hopeful for the magistrate seat on the offshore Kinmen County, also claimed victory in Saturday's elections.

Lee defeated six other opponents in a heavily fought race on Kinmen Island, which has some 90,000 residents and has long been a stronghold of the pan-blue camp composed of the KMT and its ally, the New Party.

The two counties lie closer to mainland China than Taiwan proper. Residents there have long sought transportation links and closer economic ties with China -- a focus of President Ma Ying-jeou, from the ruling party, since he was elected in 2008.
The elections Saturday were held in 17 of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities to elect county magistrates, city mayors, city and county councillors and township chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's new LCD giant may face over capacity problems: analyst
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/05/09 20:16:02 (By Chi-i Pan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The new liquid crystal display (LCD) giant Chimei Innolux Corp., which will be created by the merger of Innolux Display Corp and Chi Mei Optoelectronics (CMO), may face over capacity problems once the merger goes into effect, Topology Research Institute (TRI) said Saturday.

Corwin Lee, an analyst at the Taipei-based TRI, said while the computer-monitor maker Innolux still needs to produce large quantities of monitors, some of its clients who are competitors of its merger partner, may cancel their orders after the merger.
Therefore Chimei Innolux would find it difficult to digest all its capacity at its production lines of monitors and notebook panels, according to the analyst.
Lee said that Chi Mei Innolux may need to seek more external orders to solve its over capacity problems.

In terms of the fifth and sixth generation production lines, Chi Mei owns two fifth, one 5.5th and one sixth generation lines; Innolux has one fifth generation line, while its sixth generation production line will not enter mass production stage until next year, according to industry sources.
The merger, which was announced last month, is expected to be completed by March.

After the merger, Chi Mei Innolux will overtake AU Optronics Corp. as Taiwan's biggest maker of LCD panels by capacity, and will rank among the world's three biggest LCD producers. Korea's Samsung Electronics and LG Display currently lead the industry.

With Chi Mei now occupying the largest market share of China' s LCD TV panels, this will also help absorb the new Chimei Innolux's capacity at its fifth and sixth generation production lines, Lee said.

Innolux, which leads the world in shipments of flat- panel computer monitors, is an affiliate of Hon Hai Group, the world's largest contract electronics maker. Its merger with Chi Mei was seen as another acquisition move by Hon Hai to further expand the scope of its operations.

With Chi Mei holding the number one market share of China's LCD TVs, industry experts predicted that Hon Hai, by merging with Chi Mei, wants to grab a big market share of China's LCD TV sets assembly business.
In addition, TRI's Lee noted that the merger may also lead to some local talents hopping to China's LCD companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japanese woman becomes 4 millionth visitor to Taiwan this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 20:23:42 (By Bian Chin-feng and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The number of tourists to Taiwan hit a record high Saturday, as the country welcomed its 4 millionth visitor, a woman from Japan, according to the Tourism Bureau.
The 62-year-old Suzuyo Goto arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport Saturday along with two friends for a six-day sightseeing trip.

After learning that she was the 4 millionth visitor, Goto could hardly contain her surprise and excitement, saying that after recovering from a serious illness in February, she decided to take a trip with her friends.
As part of an incentive program to encourage more tourists to visit Taiwan, the Tourism Bureau awarded Goto a debit card valued at NT$400,000 (US$12, 419) to be spent exclusively in Taiwan.
The 1 millionth, 2 millionth and 3 millionth visitors also received similar debit cards, but with lower values, when they arrived earlier this year.
Goto also received a commemorative certificate and souvenirs presented by David W. J. Hsieh, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau.
Despite the economic downturn, the number of tourists to Taiwan has grown this year, according to the Tourism Bureau.

"The number of tourists to Taiwan has significantly outnumbered last year's (3.85 million) . The original target was 4.1 million visitors (this year) and now we estimate that it could be more than 4.2 million," Hsieh said.
The Tourism Bureau has set a target of attracting 4.5 million tourists for 2010, he added.

Taiwan, which has previously placed little focus on developing its tourism industry, has recognized in recent years that its abundance in natural scenic beauty and cultural assets can be used to encourage more tourists to come here and develop the tourism industry as a boost to the economy.
After the launch of the "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" program that kicked off Feb. 15, 2008, the government invested NT$1 billion to boost foreign tourist arrivals.

Much of the growth in overseas tourists is due to mainland Chinese tourists, who were allowed to come to Taiwan in large numbers for the first time last year. Expanded direct flights between Taiwan and mainland China this year also led to more Chinese tourists coming here.
Goto and her friends are scheduled to visit the National Palace Museum in Taipei and sightsee in other cities, such as Hualien, Taichung and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei magistrate to visit Copenhagen for climate summit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 20:33:32 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taipei County magistrate Chou Hsi-wei will leave for Denmark Dec. 12 to attend the Copenhagen Climate Summit for Mayors, an official said Saturday.

The event, scheduled for Dec. 14-17, is being organized by the Canada-based International Council for Local Environmental Initiatives (ICLEI) -- Local Governments for Sustainability to coincide with United Nations Climate Change Conference 2009 to take place Dec. 7-18 in the Denmark capital.

According to Teng Chia-chi, chief of Taipei County's Environmental Protection Bureau, the magistrate will seize the opportunity of the meeting to promote his initiative to establish an international alliance of low-carbon cities.
The magistrate will also take part in the U.N. conference in his capacity as an ICLEI observer, Teng said.
During the trip, Chou is expected to hold talks with the mayors of Sydney, Kyoto, Wellington, Helsinki and London, Teng said.

Chou, who is scheduled to return to Taiwan Dec. 20, will visit Shanghai and Nanjing later in the month to invite the mayors of those two Chinese cities to attend a forum for mayors of low-carbon cities to be hosted by Taipei County in August 2010, according to Teng.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opposition wins magistrate seats in Chiayi, Pingtung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 20:57:50 (By Kuo Chi-shuan, Yang Hsi-rui and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has won magistrate seats in the southern counties of Chiayi and Pingtung in Saturday's local elections.
DPP candidates Chang hwa-kuan and Tsao Chi-hung announced their victories in Chiayi and Pingtung, respectively, just three hours after the polls closed at 5 p.m.
The two counties have been traditionally pro-DPP, and the DPP candidates' victories in these two counties did not come as a surprise.
The two candidates won by a big margin, with Chang garnering around 50,000 more votes than her ruling party Kuomintang (KMT) rival Wong Chung-chun.
Tsao meanwhile enjoyed a clear lead, with about 90,000 more votes than KMT candidate Chou Dian-lun.

More than 7 million eligible voters in Taiwan went to the polls to elect county magistrates, city mayors, county and city councillors and township chiefs in 17 of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities Saturday. The local-level elections are held once every four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Award-winning Taiwanese fashion designer speaks of future plans
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 4 (CNA) 12/05/09 21:04:19 (By Jaw-pyng Hwang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Award-winning Taiwanese fashion designer, Johan Ku, said that he may create his own brand under his name in the future, while revealing a plan to fly home to Taiwan for a short visit in mid-December to hold a presentation of his works.

Ku, owner of the Johan Ku Design Studio, recently won the top prize in the Avant-Garde design category of the 2009 Gen Art's Styles International Design Competition, with one of his 2004 designs -- a knitted one-piece wool dress that highlights the delicacy of the yarn and displays creative patterns.

The 30-year-old attended the award ceremony in midtown Manhattan on Wednesday. He will fly back to London, where he is studying art, on Saturday to continue studying at the Central Saint Martins School of Art and Design.

Speaking to the Central News Agency before leaving for the U.K., Ku said he wants to show Taiwanese people 10 pieces of works he created in recent years, to tell them how he creates "sculpture-like" knitwear, Ku said.
As the media has attributed Ku's victory in the New York contest to his ingenuity, Ku encouraged other Taiwanese fashion talents to be creative and confident in their works.
"So long as the works are creative, and so creative that they can conquer the international community, they will definitely be given applause generously by the community," he said.
While encouraging local designers to eye the global markets, the award winner suggested the Taiwanese government offer more support to those in the cultural and creative industries.
There should be a set of incentive measures to assist talented people in promoting the marketing, engaging in industrial production and making inroads into the international market, he suggested.

Regarding his planned presentation in Taipei City, Ku expressed hope that entrepreneurs will want to buy his works as a collection, whereby he will be able to raise funds to continue creating more fashion or to establish his own brand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Old camphor tree near university saved by students from removal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 21:31:37 (By Lin Szu-yu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: An old camphor tree over 70 years old in Taipei City was saved by a group of students of the National Taiwan University and nearby residents Saturday when a land developer was about to clear it from a piece of land in order to start the construction of an apartment building.
The old camphor tree is among a line of old trees along Hsuchow Road that sits on a piece of land which a land developer has acquired for the construction of a big apartment building.
The land developer held a briefing in May, explaining it wanted to remove the tree and transplant it elsewhere.

However, residents in the neighborhood and faculty and students of the university insisted that removal of the old camphor tree would spoil the "green tunnel" formed by old trees along the road where the tree is located.
Several protests have been held over the past few months whenever the developer sends in workers to remove the tree, whose ownership is ambiguous.

Pan Han-shen, secretary-general of the Green Party Taiwan, said Saturday that trees should be considered public properties. The land developer, however, has argued that as owner of the land, the company is entitled to decide whether to remove the tree.

The land developer complained that the construction project has been delayed for months and caused serious losses to the company. It is hoping that the city authorities will make a decision over the tree transplantation proposal as soon as possible.

For now, the old camphor tree is saved because under the city bylaw, before the Bureau of Public Works issues an approval to the land developer, it cannot be touched, and the land developer has not received a written permission from the bureau stating it can remove the tree, according to Pan.

Despite the fact that the Taipei City Government has put into enforcement the Taipei City Tree Protection Bylaw since April 2003, many old trees in the metropolitan area have been uprooted, with some transplanted, in recent years by land developers.
Under the tree protection bylaw, old trees aged over 50 years and big trees with the girth exceeding 15 meters or the height reaching 15 meters are under protection.

To root up a protected tree for whatever purposes needs the approval of the city government's Bureau of Public Works. Usually the authorities would approve the cases when proper arrangements for transplantation are made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lin Tsong-shyan wins Ilan County magistracy for DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Ilan, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 22:12:03 (By Shen Ju-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomingtang (KMT) party lost the Ilan County magistrate race to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in local elections Saturday, with the KMT candidate, incumbent Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua, vowing to shoulder the responsibilities of losing the ruling party's control of a key county.

Final vote counts showed that the DPP's candidate Lin Tsong-shyan defeated Lu by more than 20,925 votes. Lin grossed 54.26 percent of the more than 245,000 votes cast in the race, while the KMT's Lu won 45.74 percent of the votes.

Lin's victory Saturday ends the relatively brief rule by the KMT over the largely agricultural county. Before Lu was elected magistrate of Ilan in 2005, the county went through 24 years, or six terms, of non-partisan and DPP rule.
Ilan was the most fiercely fought battleground in Saturday's elections of magistrates, mayors, city and county councillors, and township chiefs in 17 of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities.
President Ma Ying-jeou rallied for his party's candidate in Ilan on the eve of the election. Also attending the campaign rally was Premier Wu Den-yi and Speaker of the Legislative Yuan Wang Jin-pyng.

The DPP had also fully mobilized its forces, with party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, former Premier (2002-2005) and Ilan county magistrate (1989-1997) Yu Shyi-kun, and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu supporting party nominee Lin at his campaign rally on the eve of the election.
While the KMT was hoping to safeguard the region, DPP politicians had emphasized the importance of regaining control of a key county in northeastern Taiwan.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai stressed the significance of winning back Ilan County for the opposition party.
"Ilan signifies as the first domino piece to incur a political transition, and the battle in Ilan is the first struggle for DPP's revival," Tsai said Friday evening at Lin's campaign rally.

The DPP had controlled Taiwan's presidency for eight years from 2000 to 2008. Not only did the opposition party lose the presidency, but it also suffered significant losses in the legislative elections in 2007.

Lin, 47, a native of Ilan County, has served as chief of Lotung Township in Ilan since 2001. With his administrative experience at the Ilan City mayor's office and impressive performance as township chief , he won the DPP nomination for the magistrate race.
Lin spoke of the legacy of former magistrate Chen Ting-nan (1981-1989) and promised to preserve the natural resources and to make Ilan County the most beautiful community on the island.
The administration of the two-term magistrate Chen was frequentl referred to as a model at Lin's campaign rallies. Chen died on Nov. 5, 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Newly-elected Hualien magistrate vows to build expressway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 22:33:47 (By C. T. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Fu Kun-chi, the victorious independent candidate for the magistrate seat in eastern Taiwan's Hualien County vowed Saturday to build an expressway for Hualien residents, who have long endured transportation inconvenience due to backward infrastructure in the remote county.

Fu made the pledge at his campaign headquarters after declaring victory in the race, which was part of the elections for city mayors, county magistrates as well as city and county councilors and township chiefs held in 17 out of Taiwan's 25 cities and counties.

Fu's election as Hualien county magistrate marked the first-ever defeat of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the magistrate posts in the eastern Taiwan county -- a traditional KMT stronghold which has long enjoyed firm backing from more than 70 percent of the local people.
The opposition Democratic Progressive Party has made little progress in Hualien County in previous elections and did not nominate any candidate to run in the race.
Fu, who was expelled by the KMT for insisting on standing for the top post in the Hualien county government without the party's nomination, garnered 56.37 percent of the votes, or 85,532 votes.

Despite competition from Chang Chih-ming, another independent candidate backed by incumbent Hualien County Magistrate Hsieh Shen-shan, Fu still took a remarkable lead over KMT hopeful Tu Li-hua, who seized 38,603 votes in the contest.

Observers attributed Fu's election success to his long-term management at the grass-roots level and his close links with local opinion leaders and township chiefs, who have formed a strong network of support for Fu in past legislative elections and Saturday's local race.
Fu has been a legislator three times and is still serving his third tenure.

He stressed after winning the race that he will definitely construct a safe expressway for Hualien people so they can travel easily between major cities in Taiwan, where many of them work, and their hometowns in Hualien.

Fu said the issue will be his top priority after he assumes office, because Hualien residents are not inferior citizens, meaning they deserve to have convenient transportation like other residents in Taiwan.

Fu is appealing a six-and-a-half-year sentence for violating securities trading regulations, and this is the reason why the KMT, under the slogan of President Ma Ying-jeou's call for clean governance, opted for Tu despite Fu's widespread popularity in Hualien County.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defeated DPP candidate in Penghu race demands vote recount
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 22:51:01 (By M.H. Kao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Cai Chien-hsing, the defeated candidate of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the election for county magistrate held in Taiwan's outlying archipelago Penghu, demanded a recount after losing the race Saturday.

According to the final election results made public by the Central Election Commission, Wang Chien-fa, the incumbent Penghu county magistrate and hopeful of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), grabbed 22,664 votes in the election, edging out Cai with a slim margin of 595 votes.
Speaking at a news conference, Cai refused to concede defeat and said he lost the race to Wang by only 420 votes.
He pointed out that there are more than 1,000 invalid ballots, saying that raises suspicions about the voting process.
Against this backdrop, Wang said he has asked the Penghu District Court to seal all the ballot boxes for a vote recount on the grounds that justice must be served.
The court has not indicated whether it will agree to Wang's demand.

Penghu Island is located southwest of Kaohsiung County and some 100,000 people have their households registered there despite the fact that the number of permanent residents is only around 60,000. Many Penghu people work in other parts of Taiwan, but continue to maintain their household registration in Penghu.

The election in Penghu was part of elections held in 17 counties and cities in Taiwan for magistrates, mayors, city and county councillors as well as township chiefs. The local level elections are held once every four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incumbent Yunlin County chief Su Chih-fen from the DPP wins big
DOC.DATELINE: Taipai, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 23:17:05 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Su Chih-fen, incumbent magistrate of central Taiwan's Yunlin County and a member of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , grossed 65.37 percent of the ballots cast by Yunlin voters in Saturday's elections of administrators in 17 counties and cities around Taiwan.
Su became the biggest winner in terms of ratio of votes, according to the Central Election Commission.

Election results released by the commission indicate that the DPP has secured the administration of Yunlin County, Chiayi County and Pingtung County - traditional DPP strongholds - and clinched one more county - Ilan.

Incumbent Yunlin County Magistrate Su and Pingtung Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung successfully won re-election. In Chiayi County, Chang Hwa-kuan's victory over the Kuomintang opponent Wong Chung-chun assured the continuity of DPP rule in Chiayi.

With a plus of winning Ilan County after DPP nominee Lin Tsong-shyan beat the incumbent KMT magistrate Lu Kuo-hua, the DPP had the highest ratio of votes in has ever enjoyed in local level elections -- 45 percent of all the votes cast for magistrates and mayors in the 17 counties and cities.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said that the election results reflected that "the DPP has rebounded from the bottom."
The 45 percent ratio of votes achieved signified that "the people are willing to give the DPP another chance," she added.
In each of the four counties -- Yunlin, Chiayi, Pingtung and Ilan Vthe DPP candidates have grossed more than half of the votes, Tsai noted.
She said that the DPP would launch a new start on a solid basis.

Su in Yunlin won 229,958 votes, 108,126 votes ahead of her opponent; Chang in Chiayi got 177,333 votes, 48,360 votes ahead; Tsao in Pingtung had 270,107 votes, 85,018 votes ahead; Lin in Ilan won 133,394 votes, 20,925 votes ahead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plant scientists conclude India visit
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 23:22:25 (By Paul Kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A delegation of biologists and plant scientists from Taiwan wrapped up on Saturday a visit to India that had focused on bamboo planting.

The five-member mission was led by Lin Nan-sheng, director of the Institute of Plant and Microbial Biology under the Academia Sinica. The visit had been arranged at the invitation of the Department of Biotechnology under India's Ministry of Science and Technology.

During the trip, the delegates held discussions with bamboo researchers in India and visited Jawahalal Nehru University, the Indian Institutes of Technology and the National Institute of Plant Genome Research.
Lin told the CNA that while the bamboo research in India has so far remained at the fundamental level and concentrated on applications, Taiwan's hi-tech research can complement India's deficiency.
Through the exchanges, Taiwan can also learn from India's experience in developing its bamboo industry, Lin said.

She, however, predicted that India might soon surpass Taiwan in terms of their achievements in bamboo research and development if the Indian government and private sectors continue their ongoing efforts.

For example, she said, an Indian business, through tissue culture technology, has successfully grown bamboo plants that are almost solid inside, which greatly increases their practical values as fuel and a material for paper making and construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins ticket to East Asian men's basketball semi-finals
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/05/09 23:26:35 (By Oscar Wu, Stanley Cheung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan moved one step further toward its goal of defending its championship at the 2009 East Asian Games men's basketball tournament after defeating Mongolia 132-94 at the games in Hong Kong Saturday, qualifying for the semifinals.

It was like a "warm-up" game in the match with Mongolia, said the Chinese Taipei coach Chen Kung-hsi, noting that the "real challenge" falls in semifinals, in which there will be strong rivals, including South Korea, Japan and China.
All 12 Chinese Taipei players scored in the game, with Tien Lei recording the highest individual score of 19 points.

Taiwan is scheduled to play against China on Dec. 7 for the first place in the Group A preliminary rounds. Japan is expected to lead in the Group B after beating South Korea 74-66 on the first day of the preliminary games.

On Saturday, Taiwan's table tennis player Chiang Hung-chieh won his ticket to the semifinals in the men's single rounds at the Hong Kong East Asian Games, as his team mates Wu Chih-chi and Huang Yi-hua (female) entering the semifinals in the mixed double.

Meanwhile, before the formal opening ceremony for the international sports event, held every four years, took place on the scenic Victoria Harbor Saturday afternoon, Taiwan was able to grab one silver medal and one bronze in the cue sports.

In the 15-red snooker group rounds, the team of Wu Yu-lun, Lin Shu-hung and Huang Chih-hua lost to Hong Kong 1-3. It grabbed silver after Wu Yu-lun beat South Korea's Kim Do Hoon in the 15-red snooker single men's bronze medal match 4-0 to win bronze.
In the Ruby sevens sport, Taiwan lost to Japan 5-9, China 5-42, and Hong Kong 17-27 in the men's preliminary matches held Saturday at the Hong Kong Stadium.
Taiwan has 239 athletes attending the fifth East Asian Games that is scheduled to run through Dec. 13. A total of nine countries and areas are participating in the nine-day multisports event.
