DOC.HEADLINE: Resounding win for KMT in local councilor, township elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/06/09 01:38:02 ( By Chou Yung-chieh, Li Shu-hua & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruing Kuomintang (KMT) won an overwhelming victory in elections of county and city councilors as well as township chiefs Saturday.
The ruling party secured 289 of the 592 seats up for grabs in the elections of councilors in 17 of the 25 counties and cities in the country.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), gained control of 128 townships, followed by the minor Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) which won three seats, and the People First Party (PFP) and the Labor Party, which won one seat each. The remaining 170 seats went to independents.

Meanwhile, the KMT kept its dominance in township administrator offices by wining 121 seats out of the 211 seats contested, while the DPP took control of 34 townships. The remaining 56 township offices were captured by independents.
The ratios of votes won by the KMT in the township elections stood at 48.81 percent; for the DPP, 20.04 percent; and independents, 30.87 percent.

The ruling party managed to win 12 seats in the county and city magistrate and mayors elections, but lost the magistrate offices in Ilan in northeastern Taiwan to the DPP and Hualien in eastern Taiwan to an independent.

Elections for eight other Taiwan counties and cities -- the city and county of Taipei, the city and county of Taichung, the city and county of Tainan, and the city and county of Kaohsiung -- will be held in late 2010.
Also on Saturday, KMT candidate Ma Wen-chun won the legislative by-election in Nantou County in central Taiwan. The post was vacated when Premier Wu Den-yih was promoted to be premier in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 6, or the 20th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Time for KMT to improve administrative efficiency: business sector

TEXT.P: A local business leader said Sunday in the wake of hotly contested local elections in which the ruling Kuomintang gave a less-than-stellar performance that it is time for the administration to conduct soul-searching and come up with plans to improve its administrative efficiency.

Chang Ping-chao, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce, said the KMT should probe the reasons why it has lost popularity in some cities and counties, and give serious thought as to how to further improve efficiency.

Although the KMT won the mayoral or magistrate seats in 12 out of 17 cities and counties in Saturday's elections, it lost two of its former magistrate seats and the party's nominees only grossed 47.88 percent of the 4,466,403 ballots cast.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party, meanwhile, won 1,982,914 of the votes cast, or 45.32 percent, a much higher ratio in comparison with the 41.95 percent it won in the last local elections four years ago.

According to Chang, the local elections had nothing to do with the KMT administration's overall economic policy and cross-Taiwan Strait policy, with the latter enjoying an approval rating of over 60 percent.

He attributed the KMT's loss of support in some cities and counties mainly to the impact and implications of the global economic meltdown and the high unemployment rate since late 2008, as well as the massive destruction caused by Typhoon Morakot in southern and eastern Taiwan earlier this year.
Tsai Lien-sheng, secretary-general of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, said Taiwan has begun to bottom out from the economic meltdown and is now set to rebound.
"If the KMT administration steers firmly, its approval ratings will rebound soon," Tsai predicted.

Meanwhile, a Dah Chang Securities spokesman said the KMT's defeat in Yilan and Hualien counties will temporarily impact the performance of the Taiwan bourse, forecasting that the TAIEX index will lose ground for two days or even only one day when the market re-opens Monday.

The spokesman explained that the election results unfolded as generally expected, while the market is now rich in funds and the global financial shock caused by Dubai's debt worries last week seems to have passed.

Wu Wen-tung, a manager with Capital Investment Trust, said investors stayed on the sidelines in the week before the elections and also predicted that if the election results adversely impact the TAIEX, the fluctuation will only be temporary.
"The market will return to its fundamentals in one week, " Wu said.
Meanwhile, John Brebeck, a fund expert with Yuanta Securities, said he does not see the local election results having any negative impact on the KMT administration's ability to steer the nation.

"Whenever the TAIEX index falls is a good time to buy, " Brebeck said, adding that the local stock market will turn bullish from now until the first quarter of 2010. (By Lin Ye-fong, Lawrence Chiu, Yu-Pin Tien, Carol Yeh and Deborah Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's government faces challenges after local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 16:11:29 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet will remain under pressure to tackle unemployment and many other issues after the ruling party took only 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats up for grabs in Saturday's local elections, political analysts said a day after polling.

Although the Kuomintang (KMT) secured a majority in the elections, it lost the magistrate seat of Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and that of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan to independent Fu Kun-chi, who was expelled by the KMT for insisting in vying for the seat against party wishes.
The KMT won 47.88 percent of the votes cast, lower than the 50.96 percent it won in the last mayor and magistrate elections of 23 counties and cities in 2005.
The DPP won four seats, one more than it won in the elections four years ago. It also gained 45.32 percent of the vote, up from the 38 percent it won in the last election.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also KMT chairman, admitted at a post-election press conference Saturday that the outcome of the elections was not "ideal" for his administration and that the party's decline in local government seats and vote share was a "warning" that the KMT will have to address.

Political analysts said Sunday that the administration is expected to face increasing challenges in boosting employment and reviving the economy, as well as in carrying out post-Typhoon Morakot reconstruction work and dealing with a looming water shortage in southern Taiwan.

Ma promised Nov. 15 at a ground-breaking ceremony for a permanent housing park in Kaohsiung County to accommodate typhoon victims that the first batch of 600 houses is scheduled for completion at the end of January next year.
The Cabinet is therefore racing against time to complete the construction project in line with Ma's promise, according to the analysts.

With the water stored in reservoirs in southern Taiwan and the Gaoping River being lower than past annual averages, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu convened an inter-ministerial meeting Dec. 2 to review water supplies in all areas of the country and develop response measures.

A consensus was reached during the meeting that before the flood season between next May and November, the government should ensure that water for public consumption and industrial use in Taiwan is not seriously affected.

The Water Resources Agency said at the meeting that measures to stop irrigation and planting in parts of the south might be unavoidable, with the affected areas slated to be announced in late December.
Another major challenge for the government is addressing the unemployment rate.
Premier Wu Den-yih said earlier in the month that as unemployment is an indicator of a lagging economy, the government is treating boosting employment as one of its top priorities.

The Cabinet is therefore working to map out employment promotion measures with the goal of creating 99,000 jobs, since 2008-2009 short-term employment promotion measures will conclude at the end of this year and about 45,000 people working temporary jobs offered under the program will find themselves out of work at that time.

The other important task for the government will be continuing its preventive measures for influenza A(H1N1) . The Department of Health will have provided 120 million doses of free H1N1 vaccine for local use before the lunar new year, the analysts said.

Other tests for the government will be the security measures it puts in place for China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, who will visit Taiwan for the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks later this month in Taichung City, as well as issues related to signing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the analysts added.

Meanwhile, Wu will also be under pressure to implement a plan to improve citizens' lives that is part of a concept of "grassroots economy" he floated since becoming premier two months ago, according to the analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Rising star fashion designer to return to Taiwan for solo show
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 5 (CNA) 12/06/09 16:28:49 (By Jaw-Pyng Hwang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese fashion designer Johan Ku, whose winning of a top prize in the 2009 Gen Art's Styles International Design Competition has gone viral, is planning to return to Taiwan this month for a solo show of his designs.
Ku told CNA Saturday that he plans to show the Taiwanese people 10 works he has created in recent years to show them how he creates his "sculpture-like" knitwear.

"Nothing is final yet, but I hope the presentation can take place at Eslite Books' Dunnan Store in eastern Taipei City," Ku said during a dinner hosted in his honor by Taiwan's representative in New York, Kao Chen-chun.

Ku, owner of the Johan Ku Design Studio, recently won the top prize in the avant-garde design category of the 2009 Gen Art's Styles International Design Competition, a major fashion design competition in the United States for emerging talent.
He won the prestigious prize with one of his 2004 designs -- a knitted series that highlights the versatility of yarn and displays creative patterns.

The 30-year-old attended an award ceremony in New York's Manhattan Dec. 2 before flying Saturday back to London where he is pursuing postgraduate art studies at Central Saint Martins College of Art and Design.

During the dinner, Ku recounted how he managed to complete his undergraduate and postgraduate studies in fashion design at two universities in Taiwan after graduating from vocational high school, and how he stuck to his guns to pursue what he really wanted.

Ku also noted how impressed he was by the help given in Europe and the United States to young designers and said Taiwan should also provide assistance to young people seeking to make their mark in the creative industry.
"Taiwan has no lack of creative talent willing to work hard, " Ku noted.

Regarding his planned presentation in Taipei, set to take place in mid-December, Ku expressed hope that entrepreneurs will want to buy his works, which will allow him to raise funds to continue creating more fashion or to establish his own brand.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP gets election boost but more challenges ahead
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 17:14:30 (By Sophia Yeh, Wen Kui-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) received a major boost when it retained three of its magistrate seats and retook the significant Yilan County in Saturday's local elections.

Even though the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) won 12 out of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats up for grabs, its support base was weakened in several localities. The ratio of votes won by the KMT this time was lower than the 50.96 percent it won in the last elections of 23 magistrates and mayors in 2005.

In comparison, the DPP's Yilan victory, along with the retention of its other three seats and the major gains it made in the KMT's traditional strongholds of Penghu and Taitung, were seen by the party as affirmation of the leadership of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who took over the party helm in May 2008 at a time when the party was in disarray in the wake of the snowballing corruption scandal surrounding former President Chen Shui-bian.

Given the fact that the DPP also saw its share of the vote increased from the 41.95 percent it won four years ago to 45.32 percent, compared with the KMT's 47.88 percent, this could mean that the party is now out of the shadow of the disgraced ex-president, according to DPP sources.

Tsai has successfully stemmed the party's slipping popularity, but her real challenge will be a DPP chair election next May, municipality elections in late 2010 and even the party's strategy for the 2012 presidential election, a party official said.
With Saturday's "minor victory, " the party official said, more people will be interested in joining the race in the municipality elections set for next year.

Even before Saturday's elections, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu and Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing had reportedly been bickering, as both are known to be interested in running in the 2010 election, when the city and county will be merged into a single municipality.
Tsai mediated between the two prior to Saturday's election, requesting them to "put party unity on the pedestal," but their fight for the candidacy is expected to start again.

The usually low-key Tsai was obviously happy late Saturday about the party's performance, saying that she was "gratified about the growth, but the outcome has not changed the basic structure of the electorate."
She described the elections as "the people casting a no-confidence vote against the performance over the past 18 months of the President Ma Ying-jeou administration."
She attributed the KMT setback to its "wrong policy," saying that the Ma administration's rapid China-tilt policy has led to uneasiness among the people.
Another reason, she went on, is the Ma administration's poor efficiency and ability.
Tsai also said that the retaking of Yilan shows that the DPP has "regained the trust of the voters."
In other localities, even thought DPP candidates did not win, the ballots they garnered were often not far behind those of their KMT rivals, which was a "tremendous boost" to the party, she added.
She said the challenge for the party now is not to beat the KMT but to become the "best and the most trustworthy" party in Taiwan.
Tsai also said the party has already begun work to formulate a "10-year policy guideline" to chart the party's blueprint for the nation's development over the next decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT's election setback makes political talks more difficult
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 18:40:19 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The less-than-ideal showing of Taiwan's ruling party in the weekend mayor and magistrate elections has made it even more difficult for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to begin talks on sensitive political issues, a Chinese scholar said Sunday.

Zhang Duncai, deputy director of Xiamen University's Taiwan Research Institute in southeastern China's Fujian Province, said the just-concluded local elections in Taiwan could be characterized as a setback for the Kuomintang (KMT) and a gain for the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

"Against this backdrop, the KMT administration, while unlikely to retrench its cross-strait engagement policy, is also not likely to promote bilateral relations at a pace as fast as in the past one-and-a-half years," Zhang forecast in an interview with CNA.

Zhang said he expects cross-strait economic and cultural exchanges to continue in the wake of the elections, with institutionalized engagements between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- proceeding without interruption and the communication platform between the KMT and the Communist Party of China remaining on track.

However, he also predicted that Taiwan's government will become more reluctant to promote any cross-strait programs that might eclipse or undermine President Ma Ying-jeou's administrative achievements or the KMT's power base.
"Political issues, in particular, will be least likely to be brought to the negotiating table in the foreseeable future, " Zhang said.
In Saturday's elections, the KMT captured 12 out of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats up for grabs, while the DPP took four seats and the remaining seat went to an independent.

Zhang analyzed that in terms of numbers, the KMT only suffered a small loss of two seats -- one to a DPP challenger and the other to a KMT maverick who ran as an independent without the party's endorsement -- while the DPP only scored a minor gain by winning one more seat than it garnered in the previous elections held four years ago.

However, in terms of the vote share, the KMT's loss could be branded as a major defeat, as it grossed only 47.88 percent of the total, far less than the 51.8 percent share it won in the 2005 election, Zhang said.
In contrast, he went on, the DPP scored a significant gain, securing a record 45.32 percent share.
Zhang also said that the results indicate that Ma's political star is fading.
"One of the indicators was Fu Kun-chi's defeat of the KMT candidate in the Hualien magistrate election by an enormous margin, " Zhang analyzed.
Fu was expelled from the KMT after insisting on running for the eastern county's magistrate post in defiance of the party's nomination policy.

Another proof of Ma's declining star power was seen in incumbent Yilan Magistrate Lu Kuo-hua's loss of his reelection bid to his DPP challenger Lin Tsong-shyan. Ma traveled extensively in the northeastern county in the run-up to the election to stump for Lu in his capacity as KMT chairman, but to no avail.
Nonetheless, it is still far too early to write a political obituary for Ma, as shown in KMT nominee Chiu Ching-chun's success in winning the Hsinchu magistrate post, Zhang noted.

Chiu fought a tight race against two strong challengers -- one from the DPP and the other from Hsinchu County Council Speaker Chang Pi-chin who ran as an independent. Without Ma's strong backing, many analysts said, Chiu might not have emerged as the final victor.

"Generally speaking, the results show that supporters of the KMT-led blue camp have used their ballots to teach Ma a lesson on the one hand, but they also affirm his determination to promote clean politics. Under Ma's leadership, the KMT has rejected nominating politicians involved in corruption allegations to run for public posts," said Zhang.
In Saturday's elections, the KMT also saw its leads in two of its traditional strongholds -- Taitung County and the offshore county of Penghu -- greatly reduced.
"The KMT should take a cue from this, as more challenging elections for municipality chiefs will take place next year, " Zhang said.
The latest elections only covered about 40 percent of Taiwan's population, while the municipality chief elections slated for 2010 will involve 60 percent of Taiwan's urban residents.
"My observation is that the setback in Saturday's elections might not be bad for the KMT, as it could remind the party of the challenges that lie ahead," Zhang said.

He also predicted that Ma's leadership will not encounter any serious challenges from within the KMT ranks following the latest setback and that he will continue to lead his party on a path of reform.
Turning to Taiwan's opposition camp, Zhang said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's leadership mandate has been greatly shored up with the party's better-than- expected showing.

The solid performance will help boost the party's morale, which has been at a low ebb following its 2008 presidential election drubbing and the exposure of a spate of corruption scandals involving former President Chen Shui-bian, Zhang noted, adding that this might allow Tsai to win another term in the coming year's party chair election.
He also predicted that the DPP is unlikely to adjust or review its pro- independence policy or its snubbing of engagement with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Buddhist nun raises over 70 poor children single-handed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 19:07:25 (By Worthy Shen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Buddhist nun has taken in more than 70 orphans and displaced children, raised them and allowed them to go to school over the past 11 years, because she cannot bear to see poor children suffer.

Zhenrong has managed to establish an orphanage in Wujie township of the eastern county of Yilan despite only meagre savings, laboring to make ends meet by producing and selling dried Chinese radish, and spinning "like a Tibetan prayer wheel" as she ferries the kids to and from school.

It all began from one day in 1998 when she saw two boys dressed in rags in Yilan County's Suao, wandering near a river. She approached them and found out that the boys, aged 6 and 7, had to scavenge for food as their father was a jobless alcoholic and their mother had left for good.
She took the boys in and allowed them to live at her mini-monastery named after Samantabhadra, who symbolizes truth and reality and is one of the four major buddhas in Chinese Buddhism.
"There is a sad story behind every child I have taken in, " she said.
The youngsters were originally displaced or abandoned because their parents had either died, had separated or had been incarcerated for drug or alcohol abuse.
"Some babies were sent here after being born out of wedlock to teenage girls," she continued.
"It grieves me that none of the abandoned babies' parents have ever visited since," she added.

With savings to the tune of NT$4 million, she took out a loan of over NT$8 million from a bank the next year to buy an abandoned resort in Wujie, where she set up her orphanage enabling her to take in more disadvantaged children.

Burdened by her financial constraints -- it was costing her at least NT$70,000 per month to run the home and a further NT$80,000 per month to pay off her mortgage, Zhenrong began curing Chinese radish, making it a staple of the home's dining table.

Surprisingly, her dried radish turned out to be a major source of income for the home after a restaurant franchise operator from Taipei visited the orphanage and offered to buy her home-cured produce.
Zhenrong also raised funds by running a recycling plant and by soliciting donations from Buddhism devotees.

She told CNA that she finds her life of hardship and toil quite rewarding when she sees "her" children receiving education, becoming socially conditioned and coming out of their shells after an early childhood of poverty, dressed in filthy rags and uncomfortable even making eye contact with other people.
"Their wardrobe now is basic but clean, " Zhenrong noted.
She said she runs the home based on Buddhist teaching that "people should help other people get rid of all their pain even if doing so sacrifices their own comfort and happiness."
Zhenrong feels good about what she has been striving to do, firmly convinced one more child saved and educated means Taiwan society will have one less juvenile delinquent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Seven legislative by-elections to be held around Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 19:32:36 (By Huang Ming-his and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: By-elections for seven legislative seats made vacant following the invalidation of two legislators' election wins and the election of five others in Saturday's mayor and magistrate elections will be held in seven counties around the country.

Three of the lawmakers will leave the legislature to take up their local government positions: John Wu of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), who was elected Taoyuan magistrate; the KMT's Chiu Ching-chun, who became Hsinchu magistrate; and Fu Kung-chi, an independent who was elected Hualien magistrate.

In addition, the KMT's Huang Chien-ting and Chang Hwa-kuan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who were elected Taitung magistrate and Chiayi magistrate, respectively, had already resigned their legislative seats prior to running in the local elections.

Two other by-elections will be held Jan. 9 in Taoyuan and Taichung counties to fill the seats left vacant by former KMT legislators Chiang Lien-fu and Liao Cheng-ching, both of whom had their election status annulled over vote-buying.

The KMT has nominated Taoyuan County Environmental Protection chief Chen Li-ling and Taiping Mayor Yu Wen-chin to run in the legislative by-elections in Taoyuan and Taichung counties, while nominating Taitung Magistrate Kuang Li-chen to run in that county's legislative by-election, set for the same day.
The remaining by-elections will be held at a later, yet-to-be-announced date.
DPP Policy Committee Chief Executive Ker Chien-ming said Sunday that the party had yet to begin a formal nomination process for the by-elections.
However, DPP Legislator Huang Wei-cher expressed optimism over the party's chances of taking the seats at stake in Taoyuan and Chiayi counties.
The DPP at present have 27 seats in the legislature following the party's victory in the Yunlin legislative by-election earlier in the year and the loss of one seat after Chang's resignation.

If the party can take the two additional seats as it anticipates, it will have 29 seats, more than the crucial threshold of one-fourth of the 113-seat legislature, which Huang said would allow the DPP to initiate presidential recall motions, request constitutional interpretations and carry out its function of checks and balances against the majority KMT.

Liao Da-chi, director of the Institute of Political Science at National Sun Yat- sen University, said the seats left vacant after the local elections expose serious problems with the talent acquisition systems employed by both the KMT and the DPP, as both parties were so lacking in viable candidates they were reduced to mobilizing legislators to run for local chief posts.

Saying that legislative by-elections are held too frequently, Liao said that in addition to the seven vacant seats, three legislative by-elections were held in Miaoli, Yunlin and Taoyuan counties after the departure of KMT lawmakers Lee E-tin and Chang Sho-wen, as well as Lin Cheng-er, an aboriginal legislator from the People First Party, whose elections were also annulled because of election- related bribery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins 1st gold at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 20:01:55 (By Oscar Wu, Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei taekwondo fighter Hsu Chia-lin beat his challenger from South Korea Sunday to win a gold medal, marking the first gold Taiwan has won at the 2009 East Asian Games that kicked off formally in Hong Kong the previous day.

Hsu spent the entire match getting the measure of Cho Seongin in the 54 kg category of the men's event before scoring his medal-winning point with a crucial mid-section attack in a sudden death round of the match.

Other Chinese Taipei taekwondo athletes, including Chan Yi-chieh, male, 58 kg category; Lee Hsing-hua, female, 47 kg category; and Chen Ying-chiu, female, 51 kg category, had all qualified for the semi-finals and were expected to win more gold medals for Taiwan later Sunday.
Meanwhile, Chinese Taipei tennis player Chiang Peng-lung and Wu Chih-chi beat their Japanese rivals 11-7 Sunday to qualify for the men's doubles final.
They will meet a Chinese pair Monday for the championship after the Chinese team defeated their challengers from Hong Kong.
A total of nine countries and areas are participating in the 2009 East Asian Games, which end Dec. 13.

Before the formal opening ceremony for the international sports event -- held every four years -- took place on Victoria Harbor Saturday afternoon, Taiwan had already taken one silver medal and one bronze in the cue sports.
Taiwan has 239 athletes competing in the multisport games, the fifth of their kind.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health agency targets next high-risk group for flu vaccine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 20:18:05 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: People aged 25 or older who are considered at high risk for complications from influenza A (H1N1) will be offered H1N1 vaccine free of charge from Monday, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced Sunday.

People in the age groups with underlying health conditions that include diabetes, asthma, chronic cardiopulmonary disease, kidney disease, liver disease, cardiopulmonary disease and severe obesity should get vaccinated as soon as possible, CDC Deputy-Director Chou Jih-haw said.
Severe obesity is defined as a body mass index (BMI) of greater than 35 kg/m2, according to Chou.

He noted that individuals with hypertension have not been listed in the high risk group so they will be given the vaccine only until Dec. 12, when the vaccine will become available to the general public.
More than 2.51 million people have been inoculated against H1N1 since the CDC began offering the vaccine nearly one month ago, of whom, 1.17 million are students at junior and senior high schools.
However, only 5,000 university students have received a shot, Chou said.
The CDC plans to get 7.5 million people vaccinated by the end of this year -- about 25 percent of the population -- in order to generate a herd immunity effect, according to Chou.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chair solidifies leadership after local elections: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 20:38:13 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The results of Saturday's local elections have solidified the leadership of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, the participants in a seminar said Sunday.

DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling said in the seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Thinktank that the ballots garnered by the DPP were on par with its historic high and that Tsai, who took over the helm of the battered party in May 2008 after scandal surrounding former President Chen Shui-bian, has established her authority.
"Her personal popularity is now higher than the party's and her leadership will be cemented," Kuan said.
Kuan also said that Saturday's results show that President Ma Ying-jeou has "flunked his mid-term test."

"The people wanted to use their ballots to express hope that the Kuomintang (KMT) will change," Kuan said, adding that she thinks the KMT will now be plunged into a dilemma of whether to change or not.

She cited as examples the fact that the public wants the government to restart its negotiations over the easing of U.S. beef imports, the postponement of a visit to Taiwan by China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin -- president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- and a referendum on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China.

Lo Chih-cheng, an associate professor of Soochow University, said the voters have helped the floundering DPP back to its feet and as long as it keeps the momentum, it will be the basis of a good restart.
But Saturday's local elections should not be "overinterpreted" as an indicator of the results of the 2012 legislative and presidential elections, he said.
Lo said Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, will face challenges from within his party and his government and his basis to engage in talks with other countries will also be impacted.

Hsu Yung-ming, a convener of the Taiwan ThinkTank, said that the people have helped the DPP back to its feet, but he added that if it reverts back to its old path, it will not be able to maintain the momentum needed for victory in the municipality elections in 2010 and the 2012 presidential election.

The KMT won 12 out of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats up for grabs, but its support base was weakened in several localities. The ratio of votes won by the KMT this time was lower than the 50.96 percent it won in the last elections of 23 magistrates and mayors in 2005.
In comparison, the DPP recovered Yilan, retained its other three seats in Yunlin, Chiayi and Pingtung counties and made substantial gains in the KMT's traditional strongholds of Penghu and Taitung.
The DPP also saw its share of the vote increased from the 41. 95 percent it won four years ago to 45.32 percent, compared with the KMT's 47.88 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet will listen to public opinion when drafting China policy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 20:43:21 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government has always had ears for public opinion in formulating policy on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Sunday.
"Public opinion has been a major guideline in the formulation and implementation of our cross-strait policies and action programs, " said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun.

The MAC, which charts and coordinates Taiwan's policy toward China, has invariably respected public opinion in dealing with cross-strait affairs and has been subjected to legislative supervision in policy implementation, he said.
"Whenever we carry out cross-strait policy, national interests have consistently been our top concern," Liu noted.

He made the statement after President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, said the previous day after his party suffered a setback in mayoral and magistrate elections that his administration is willing to listen to public opinion about the government's concrete cross-strait policies and to make necessary adjustments or improvements.
"While the MAC cannot explain in detail some policy issues at the moment, it has always referred to public opinion when drafting its policy proposals and work agenda," Liu said.

The KMT's less-than-ideal showing in Saturday's elections has prompted some politicians from the pro-independence opposition camp to demand that the Ma administration adjust its allegedly China-leaning cross-strait policies, such as signing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Citing the results of a public opinion survey the MAC commissioned National Chengchi University to conduct in late September, Liu said 60 percent of the respondents to the poll threw their support behind the fourth round of high- level cross-strait talks scheduled to be held in central Taiwan's Taichung City later this month.
"The figure indicates that local people generally support the policy of engagement with China," Liu explained.
The poll also found that 55 percent of the respondents said they favor the signing of the ECFA, a cross-strait version of the free trade agreements signed among major countries around the world.

Meanwhile, 44.7 percent said they thought the present pace of opening to cross- strait exchanges in various fields is optimal, compared to 33 percent who said the pace is too fast and 12 percent who said it is too slow.

As most of the 17 cities and counties in which the three-in-one local elections were held are either known as Taiwan's main food-producing areas or as home to traditional labor-intensive industries, the opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) stronger-than-expected showing might have an adverse impact on cross-strait exchanges and the signing of the ECFA, according to some analysts.
Kao Hui, a professor at the Kinmen Institute of Science and Technology, said that at the very least, the DPP will have more weight or more say in the direction of future cross-strait relations.
"I think DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, a former MAC head, will become more critical of the KMT's cross-strait policy as a result of her party's electoral gains," Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five municipality elections seen as next major battle
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 6 (CNA) 12/06/09 20:57:43 (By Garfie Lee and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The curtain for Saturday's local elections has just fallen, but the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is already eying the next major battle -- the five municipality elections set to take place in late 2010.

The five municipalities will be Taipei City, New Taipei City (an upgrade of what is presently Taipei County) , Taichung (a merger of Taichung city and county) , Tainan (a merger of Tainan city and county) and Kaohsiung (a merger of Kaohsiung city and county).
Although a high-ranking KMT official said Sunday that it is not yet time to talk about naming specific candidates, he said the urgent task will be to review the nominating mechanism.
"If we nominate the right people, we will have already won half the battle," he said.
The KMT has set the tone for the five municipality elections as "the latter half of a beachhead battle for the presidential election in 2012," according to the official.

He admitted that the party's performance in Saturday's elections was less than ideal and said the problem lies in the nomination process, especially because bitter competition at the primary stage often results in discord and splits within the party.

He said the party "has yet to seriously think about the question of nominating specific persons," but added that the party will choose candidates who will be in line with President Ma Ying-jeou's ideals of reform and who will avoid internal fighting and will maintain party harmony.

He said New Taipei City will be an "uncertain" area, noting that before Chou Hsi-wei was elected Taipei magistrate in 2005, it was dominated for a long time by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Even if Chou enjoys the advantage of being an incumbent it might not be easy for him to fight his DPP rival, the official went on, citing the example of Yilan County, which the KMT had taken great pains to retain only to see KMT incumbent Lu Kuo-hua lose to his DPP rival in the traditional stronghold of the DPP, where it had dominated for 24 years before Lu took over in 2005.

The KMT has to name a "strong and popular" candidate in New Taipei City, he said, noting that it has the largest population of any of the country's administrative areas, -- 3,869,879 as of November 2009 -- and adding that "if the KMT loses it in the election, the consequences will be grave."

Chou, who has made known his intention to seek re-election despite faring poorly in past public opinion polls, said the KMT should hold the primary early in a "democratic" spirit, and "not to resort to internal coordination to decide who should run."
Meanwhile, the DPP's morale was boosted in Saturday's elections, and two of its heavyweights were asked Sunday if they will run in the municipality elections.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who has been tapped as a strong contender in Taipei City, said that "whether it is the municipality elections in 2010, or the 2012 legislative and presidential elections, the party will have to adopt a well- considered overview."
"The party will have to discuss its plans and strategies before making a final decision," she said.
Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin of the KMT,, who has already said he will be seeking re-election, welcomed Sunday "any strong contenders in the race."

Former Premier and ex-Taipei Magistrate Su Tseng-chang, believed to be a strong contender in New Taipei City, said Sunday that "the "DPP's nomination mechanism and the public opinion of every municipality should be respected."
Also that day, the United Evening News said that Taichung Mayor Jason Hu is still a favorite nomination choice for the KMT in Taichung.

Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu could be a good pawn for the party -- he could either run in New Taipei City or be sent to the stronghold of the DPP, Tainan, given that Chu's father-in-law Kao Yu-jen is a politician from Tainan and his uncle-in-law, Kao Su-po, is a legislator from there, according to the reports.

In Kaohsiung, Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP, who is keen to throw her hat into the ring in the 2010 election, said that respecting the party's nomination mechanism and public opinion will be the best approach.
Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing has also expressed interest in running in the southern municipality, which is likely to put him at loggerheads with Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 7, or the 21st day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: The opening ceremony of the 2001 Austronesian Cultural Festival is held at Peinan Park in Taitung City, with famed singer Chang Hui-mei giving a performance.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: President requests election review report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 12:31:27 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has asked for an election review report as soon as possible in the wake of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) lackluster performance in Saturday's local elections, party officials reported Monday.

The officials said that many within the party are worried that the KMT's solid support base in many areas is showing signs of erosion, which they think does not bode well for the municipality elections next year.

President Ma, in his capacity as the KMT chairman, attaches great importance to such views and has asked the KMT Central Standing Committee to submit an election review report on Wednesday, the officials said.
"The KMT's support base has been seriously eroded, " a party official said.

The KMT managed to retain 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats that were up for grabs in Saturday's poll, but its level of support in several localities fell sharply, sending its overall average down to 47.88 percent compared to 50.96 percent in the last local election in 2005.
In comparison, the DPP recovered Yilan, retained its three seats in Yunlin, Chiayi and Pingtung counties and made substantial gains in the KMT's traditional strongholds of Penghu and Taitung.
The DPP also increased its share of the vote from 41.95 percent four years ago to 45.32 percent.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Sunday that the setback has sent a timely warning to the KMT, forcing it to make a thorough review.

He also said that the KMT should heed the gravitation of independent voters toward the traditionally pro-independence DPP, and advised that the strength of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and her party should not be underestimated.

Elections for heads of five municipalities -- Taipei City, New Taipei City (an upgrade of what is presently Taipei County), Taichung (a merger of Taichung City and County) , Tainan (a merger of Tainan City and County) and Kaohsiung (a merger of Kaohsiung City and County) -- will be held in late 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China planning green cooperation: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 13:14:52 (By Liu Kuang-ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China may soon open a new front in their efforts to cement bilateral ties, as talks on cooperation on the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) could be in the works, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Monday.

Noting that environmental protection officials from Taiwan and China have started planning joint measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions, Shen said the officials from both sides may meet after the Copenhagen Climate Conference for a forum on environment protection or to discuss CDM collaboration.
"The Copenhagen Climate Conference is one of the most important meetings this century," Shen said.
It is not only reviewing progress achieved under the Kyoto Protocol, its discussions would have important impact on future trends for global industrial development, he noted.

The CDM is an arrangement under the Kyoto Protocol that allows industrialized countries with a greenhouse gas reduction commitment to invest in ventures that reduce emissions in developing countries as an alternative to more expensive emissions cuts in their own countries.

According to news reports from China, as of the end of October, the Chinese government had approved 2,232 CMD projects, 663 of which have been successfully registered with the CDM Executive Board of the United Nations -- the highest number of CDM registered projects for a single country worldwide.

It is envisioned that the 663 projects will help cut greenhouse gas emissions in China by 190 million tons per year, constituting 58 percent of the total emissions reduction projected for registered CDM projects globally, according to a Chinese official.
"Taiwan can borrow from China's experience in CDM development and in turn use the CDM cooperation to create a win-win situation for both sides," Shen said.
However, local environment conservation activists have expressed diverse views on CO2 reduction options.

Pan Han-sheng, a spokesman for the Green Party Taiwan, posited that Taiwan should consider cutting greenhouse gas emissions at the source, rather than from cap-and-trade efforts, which he said address only end-product problems.
"The best and fastest solution is to impose an energy tax and a carbon tax," Pan suggested.

Kao Cheng-yen, an environmentalist and a professor at National Taiwan University, criticized the government's approach of pushing for measures to curb greenhouse gas emissions in Taiwan, on one hand, while turning a blind eye to the expansion of heavy-polluting industries, on the other.

Citing the example of a proposal to build an eighth naphtha cracking plant in Taiwan, Kao said even if all the factories in Taiwan strive to reduce their CO2 emissions, their efforts will be in vain once the proposed Guokuang Petrochemical Co. becomes operational.
Since the Legislative Yuan has already passed an act governing the development of renewable energies, the administration should capitalize on that policy, he suggested.
"The government should learn from Germany and Japan and purchase alternative energy produced by the private sector," Kao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Minor' Cabinet reshuffle around Dec. 20: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 13:36:05 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: There will be a "minor" Cabinet reshuffle sometime around Dec. 20, and two-term mayors and magistrates who have performed well will be invited to join the Cabinet when their tenures expire after that date, Premier Wu Den-yih said Monday.
However, they will not necessarily be asked to serve as ministers, or ministers without portfolio, but rather may be assigned to head state-owned enterprises, he said.

Wu said that Hsinchu's two-term mayor, Lin Junq-tzer, is one of those being considered for a seat in the Cabinet. Lin has consistently been at the top of the rankings in surveys on the performance of mayors and magistrates in Taiwan.
The possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle has been at the forefront of discussions since the ruling Kuomintang's less-than-ideal performance in the just- concluded local elections.

The KMT managed to hold on to 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats that were up for grabs in Saturday's poll, but lost a significant seat in Yilan County and saw its solid support base eroded in several localities.
