DOC.HEADLINE: EPA calls for passage of greenhouse gas control act
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 16:33:53 (By Liu Kuang-ying and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmental chief called Monday for the Legislative Yuan to pass a greenhouse gas control act as soon as possible to serve as a legal basis for facilitating efforts to curb carbon dioxide emissions.

Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said the legislation of a greenhouse gas emissions control act will enable the government to push for a supply chain carbon inventory, directly accelerating the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions from the country's industrial sector.

According to Shen, supply chain carbon inventory has been used on an experimental trial basis in Taiwan by several private companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) , China Airlines, Kuo-Kuang Motor Transport and the Taipei 101 building.
He also said that since the Legislative Yuan has already passed an act governing the development of renewable energy, the administration should capitalize on that policy.

He suggested that the Bureau of Energy under the Ministry of Economic Affairs borrow from Germany's experience in purchasing alternative energy produced by the private sector as a means to bolster the development of renewable energy.

Shen made the remarks during a hearing at the Legislative Yuan in which the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions was the centerpiece and which coincided with a meeting under the U.N. Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) that opened in the Danish capital of Copenhagen that same day.
He said EPA officials will seize the opportunity of the UNFCCC meeting to lobby for support for Taiwan's meaningful participation in the world group, including observer status.
"Taiwan will also set a timetable and goals to gradually cut carbon dioxide emissions," he said.

With the assistance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau, TSMC became in June the first company in Taiwan to lead its suppliers in successfully completing and registering a carbon inventory.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier denies need for China policy changes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 16:36:02 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih denied Monday that there is a need to change government policy toward China, despite the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) poorer-than- expected performance in Saturday's local elections.
The ruling party, which controlled 14 out of the 17 counties and cities involved in the elections prior to Saturday's polling, managed to hang on to 12 of them.
Wu said the government's policy is the result of comprehensive thinking, long discussion and broad consultation, and has not been formulated in haste.

With regard to the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the government will go ahead with it as planned, as it will serve Taiwan's interests and benefit the public, he added.
However, the premier said, the government's policy toward China should still meet three requirements -- the country's needs, public support and legislative supervision.
The government will not push any policy that fails to meet any of those requirements, Wu went on.

Noting that the proposed ECFA enjoys a support rate of 50 percent to 56 percent among the public according to the latest poll results, Wu said he hopes to boost this figure to 60 percent, while bringing opposition down to below 20 percent.

"We are working hard on this," the premier said, adding that good policy should be carried out at the right time and should be fully understood by the people, which he admitted is something the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has not managed effectively.
For example, he said, some people in central and southern Taiwan believe mistakenly that the Ma administration has opened Taiwan to many Chinese agricultural products.

In fact, among the 1,415 items of Chinese agricultural products allowed to be imported into Taiwan, 479 items were approved by the previous KMT administration, with the other 936 approved by the Democratic Progressive Party when it was in power.
"However, President Ma's administration has not approved any items thus far," the premier pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't plans to revive baseball sport from grassroots
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 17:01:23 (By Chiachen Hsien, Lin Wan-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan government will work to revive the sport of baseball in Taiwan from the grassroots level, the country's sports chief said Monday.

"Efforts will be made first to promote the baseball sport and consolidate its existence and development from the grassroots level," said Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu after attending the first working meeting of a Cabinet-level task force formed last week under instructions by President Ma Ying-jeou.
Noting that currently there are 795 little league, youth and junior baseball teams nationwide, Chu said the government will work to increase the number of such teams.
"I hope the number will double in four years," he said.

Meanwhile, Sports Affairs Council Minister Tai Hsia-ling also said after the meeting that the Ministry of Education will be responsible for promoting the sport, while the Sports Affairs Council will be responsible for training talent or star players.
Besides government efforts, she said, corporate sponsorship will also be solicited to further accelerate the development of baseball in Taiwan, from the grassroots level.

Meanwhile, she said, the number of baseball coaches at elementary, junior and senior high schools will also be increased, while qualification and appraisal of such coaches will be an issue that will be of equal importance.

The baseball-revival task force was established last week after President Ma called a first-ever national conference on baseball on Dec. 1 -- a meeting held to discuss ways of reviving and upgrading the sport that has been plagued by game-fixing scandals.
The conference was convened after some 800 baseball fans took to the streets of Taipei on Nov. 29 demanding that the government do something to rescue the sport in Taiwan.

The first working meeting of the task force held Monday also brought together officials from the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of the Interior, the Taipei-based Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) and the Chinese Taipei Amateur Baseball Association.
The second and third working meetings will be convened shortly for discussions on the development of amateur baseball and professional baseball, the Executive Yuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TV debate on ECFA can be held: economics minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 17:12:35 (By Shu-yuan Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang reiterated Monday that the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic pact will not allow imports of Chinese labor or agricultural products, and agreed with a legislator's suggestion that a television debate can be held to better inform the public about related issues.

KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, at a legislative committee meeting Monday, said that the ECFA lacks public support mainly because the economics ministry has not put enough effort into promoting the advantages of the pact and he suggested that a TV debate might be a step in the right direction.

His comments were made against the backdrop of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) worse-than-expected showing in Saturday's local elections, which has been attributed in part to the government's cross-strait policies, including its pursuit of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

According to Shih, many people in the agricultural counties still are not convinced that the ECFA will not lead to an opening of Taiwan's market to Chinese workers and agricultural products, even though his ministry has given that assurance many times.
Some underground radio shows are also misleading people about the ECFA, he said, adding that a TV debate "can be planned" to discuss the issue, as Lai suggested.

In Saturday's three-in-one local elections, the KMT took 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats that were at stake, gaining 47.88 percent of the votes cast. This was a weaker performance than in 2005, when it won 50.96 percent of the vote in the mayor and magistrate elections in 23 counties and cities.

Some analysts noted that most of the 17 cities and counties in which the elections were held this year are either known as Taiwan's main food-producing areas or as home to traditional labor-intensive industries.

The opposition pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) therefore put up a strong performance in those areas, a development that might have an adverse impact on cross-strait exchanges and the signing of an ECFA, the analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: World Health Organization workshop to open in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 17:56:36 (By Hsiao Wei-san, Wu Shu-jou and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The World Health Organization (WHO) is to hold a workshop in Taipei for the first time since Taiwan was admitted in May as an observer to the world health body's decision-making arm, the World Health Assembly.

Chiou Shu-ti, director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Department of Health (DOH), told a news conference Monday that the WHO Winter School in Taiwan -- Quality Management-Implementation of Health Promotion in Hospital and Health Services -- will be held Dec. 9-10

She said the workshop, sponsored by the WHO Collaborating Center for Evidence- Based Health Promotion in Hospitals and Health Services, based in the Danish capital of Copenhagen, will discuss the development strategy for health- promoting hospitals, the management of health-promoting services quality and cases of health care.
Citing DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang, she said health promotion deserves more attention as it will help the country's loss-making national health insurance program.
"By promoting health, we can prevent many serious illnesses, cut down expenses for surgery and save money for the program, " said Chiou.

Dr. Hanne Tonnesen, CEO of the International Health-Promoting Hospital Secretariat, said at the news conference that the more efforts a hospital puts into health promotion, the fewer beds it will need.
Meanwhile, the DOH pointed out in a press release that the idea of health promotion by hospitals is to incorporate health promotion concepts into daily life to cut the cost of medical care.

The department also noted that Taiwan boasts the world's fourth-largest health-promoting hospital network, with 55 health-promoting hospitals accredited by the WHO Collaborating Center for Evidence-Based Health Promotion in Hospitals and Health, and has won a bid to host a WHO international health- promoting hospital seminar in 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's share prices surge on heavy trading volume
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 18:09:11 (By Y.L Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose sharply on expanding turnover Monday as investors' uncertainty surrounding the weekend local elections dissipated.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, advanced 124.73 points, or 1.63 percent, to close at 7,775.64.
The local bourse opened at the day's low of 7,704.69 before hitting a high of 7,783.20 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.28 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$134.91 billion (US$4.18 billion).

All eight of the major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 2.04 percent. Machinery and electronics shares rose 1.89 percent, paper and pulp issues advanced 1.84 percent, banking and financial shares were up 1.53 percent, textile stocks were 1.31 percent higher, plastics and chemicals ended the day 1.3 percent higher, foodstuff stocks increased 1.0 percent, and cement stocks advanced 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,966 to 778, with 185 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$5.76 billion-worth of shares.

Analysts with the Industrial Bank of Taiwan said that as the market got a strong lift on the first transaction day after the elections, it would hover between 7,500 and 8,000 before edging upward to challenge the 8,000-point mark.
The analysts also expressed optimism over the market prospects because the economy has shown signs of a rebound, which is expected to further boost the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 18:10:51 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.11 to close at NT$32.280.
A total of US$775 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.320 and reached a low of NT$32.130.

DOC.HEADLINE: Proposed trade pact not included in cross-strait talks: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 18:22:32 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Monday that a proposed trade pact with China will not be discussed in the upcoming cross-strait meeting, although both sides will discuss the progress of the trade pact after the meeting.
He said the trade pact, officially known as the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , will be signed in an "open and transparent" environment.

His words came against the backdrop of the KMT's setback in the just-concluded weekend local elections, which some had interpreted as the result of public discontent with the performance of the Ma administration and conspicuously among them, concerns over his proposed trade pact with China.
Ma said that before the signing of the pact, the government will report to the Legislative Yuan to fully inform the legislature about its contents.
After the signing, the pact will also be sent to the legislature for review, he added.

He noted that there are a lot of discussions and misgivings about the impacts on Taiwan after signing the ECFA. There are concerns the trade pact would flood Taiwan with cheaper Chinese products, cause job losses and make Taiwan too dependent on China.

As such, the government will "let the public learn more about the pact in a relatively transparent environment. If it is not transparent enough, then the public will have misunderstandings and hamper its passage," Ma said.

In fact, Ma noted that the government has since March sponsored hundreds of presentations to explain the trade pact, which is intended to promote a normal cross-strait trade relations, avoid the island being marginalized in regional trade, and enhance the globalisation of Taiwan.
He stressed that all government policies will promote Taiwan's interests, safeguard its sovereignty and benefit the people.
"The government will uphold such principles and attach great importance to reciprocity and dignity in cross-strait consultations," Ma said.

He noted that the fourth and the latest round of meeting between Chiang Pin- kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, will mainly focus on four issues.
The four issues are fishery cooperation, avoidance of double taxation, examination and certification of standards and the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products.
Ma said the four issues will be very technical, and he has asked relevant government agencies to publish them if possible.

He cited as an example the recent signing of a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in financial supervision between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, saying that it was posted on the website after the signing.
He said that the MOU was signed in a manner of "dignity and reciprocity, " and there is no question of "dwarfing or sovereignty being compromised."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks cross-strait common production standards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 19:44:06 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government has listed a variety of products in the light emitting diode (LED) , photonics, flat-screen monitor and vehicle telematics industries as priority items in efforts to establish a common standardization system to be used on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Chen Jay-san, director-general of the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , said in an interview with CNA Sunday that getting such a system adopted by the two sides of the strait is expected to help Taiwanese producers secure a position in China's vast market.
The four selected industries are all sectors with strong international competitiveness, he added.

Chen is Taiwan's top negotiator in talks with China on cross-strait standard tests and certification cooperation. The two sides are expected to sign an agreement on the issue in the upcoming meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, slated for Dec. 21 in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

Because of the different standards for 3C products adopted on either side of the strait, Taiwan was unable to sell its big-screen digital television sets to China, causing local companies to miss out on the surge in demand there during the 2008 Beijing Olympic Games, Chen said.

Once an agreement on standard test and certification cooperation is forged, the bureau and its Chinese counterpart can begin follow-up contact and coordination on regular and technical matters, including Chinese authorization for Taiwan to conduct standard checks on local factories producing digital TVs for sale in China, Chen said.

Chen said the accord will cover the five categories of standards, metrology, test cooperation, verification and certification cooperation, aimed mainly at boosting industrial competitiveness, as well as consumer product safety, a category that is designed to protect consumer health and which will allow Taiwan to screen food safety directly at source.

Meanwhile, as Taiwan and China are both active in the promotion of cooperation in the LED and wireless broadband communication industries, Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute and the Beijing-based National Lighting Test Center are expected to reach an agreement that allows mutual recognition of LED tests by the end of the month, according to the MOEA.

The trade opportunities are "amazingly big," as China is carrying out a national project to replace incandescent streetlamps in major cities with LED bulbs, said Wu Ming-chi, an MOEA official responsible for industrial technology affairs.
The project means there will be demand for at least 2 million LED streetlamps every year in China, Wu noted.
Given the vast Chinese market, having the two sides share common industrial standards will put Taiwanese businesses in the best position to take a market share in China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese divided on who lost, who won elections: newspaper surveys

TEXT.P: Opinion surveys have found that Taiwanese people are divided on how to characterize the just-concluded weekend local elections in Taiwan, which saw the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party winning most of the seats and a higher percentage of votes, but the opposition claiming success because it gained the largest percentage of votes it has ever gotten in local elections.

The elections for mayors and county chiefs, city and county councilors, and township heads was widely interpreted by the media and analysts as a setback for the ruling party and President Ma Ying-jeou and a boost for the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Respondents to opinion surveys conducted by two major local newspapers, however, offered mixed interpretations of the results.

While 44 percent of the respondents to the local daily newspaper United Daily News' (UDN) survey said the opposition party won the election, only 39 percent of those interviewed by another newspaper, the China Times, gave a similar conclusion.
Meanwhile, some 19 percent of the respondents in the UDN survey said they thought the KMT and the DPP finished neck-to-neck, while 9 percent said that the DPP had lost.

The UDN survey also showed that the "fading" public appeal of President Ma Ying- jeou, from the ruling party, is one of the three reasons behind his party the KMT's less-than-ideal performance in the elections.

The poll showed Ma's approval rating has slipped one point to 33 percent since former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan stepped down on Sept. 7 to shoulder responsibility for the government's delayed response to Typhoon Morakot, which struck Taiwan in August, killing more than 600 people.
When Ma was inaugurated on May 20, 2008, his approval rating was at 66 percent. It had dropped to a low of 34 percent by the end of his first year in office.

Asked what they thought was responsible for the KMT's losses, 46 percent of the respondents in the UDN survey said the administration's poor performance, and 44 percent said its policies, such as its pursuit of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China and its lifting of a ban on certain U.S. beef products.
In addition, the UDN survey found that the rate of dissatisfaction with the president's performance has risen from 45 percent two months ago to 49 percent in the wake of Saturday's elections.

On the other hand, the approval rating of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen has shot up to 43 percent from 27 percent on May 18 when she led a protest march against Ma's administration, according to UDN survey.

The UDN survey had collected 1,066 valid samples from adults and the margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. The respondents were randomly selected throughout Taiwan through the telephone directory.

The China Times survey had surveyed 711 adults and the margin of error was plus or minus 3.7 percentage points. It was also conducted through telephone interviews and the respondents were randomly selected.

Saturday's election showed the KMT winning 12 of the 17 counties and cities in which elections were held, but only 47.88 percent of the votes cast, lower than the 50.96 percent it won in the last local elections four years ago.
On the other hand, the DPP won 45.32 percent of the votes cast, higher than the 41.95 percent it won in 2005. It also gained one more county, up from the three it already controlled.
By Elisabeth Hsu

DOC.HEADLINE: Election results are a warning for Taiwan's President Ma: analysts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 20:21:22 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: - Taiwan's just-ended weekend local elections are in fact a warning for Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou and the ruling Kuomintang ahead of even more crucial elections late next year and the presidential race in 2012, analysts said.

"Voters were in fact issuing a strict warning" to Ma, whose approval rating has dropped to an alert level since the Typhoon Morakot disaster, Hu Chu-ching, an associate professor of politics at Tunghai University, wrote in an opinion piece in the United Daily News' Monday edition.
"The Ma Ying-jeou phenomenon that prevailed for four years came to an end with the local elections, " Hu said.

The UDN's Hu noted that some "deep-blue" voters who had been firm supporters of Ma and his clean image had turned their backs on the KMT in the elections. The party should therefore seek to strengthen its alliances with its other lighter- blue parties, Hu suggested.

He reminded the KMT-led blue camp that the 2010 elections for heads of Taiwan's eight largest cities and counties will involve 60 percent of Taiwan's population, most of whom are urban residents, and will be the true test of the KMT administration. The just-concluded local elections held in 17 of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities covered only about 40 percent of the population, he noted.

For the opposition DPP, the election results show that the party has finally emerged from the shadow of the scandal-ridden former President Chen Shui-bian, according to another scholar writing in the paper.

The results of Saturday elections are not only a lesson for Ma and the KMT, but also show that independent voters have veered toward the DPP and its policies, said Chen Chao-chien, an assistant professor in the department of public affairs at Ming Chuan University.
The DPP must present a clear picture of its policies and win back the people's trust if it wants to beach the "blue whale" (KMT) in next year's elections, Chen suggested.

The scholar expressed the view that although the DPP's chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, nicknamed "Shiao Ying" (petite Ying) , " has consolidated her leadership of the DPP with its substantial gains in Saturday's local elections, she will face challenges from an emerging "anti-Ying" alliance.

The 53-year-old Tsai took up leadership of the party at a time when it was struggling to deal with the fallout from a slew of corruption scandals that had engulfed its former leader, former President Chen Shui-bian.

In Saturday's elections, the KMT won the majority of mayoral and magistrate seats, but gained only 47.88 percent of the votes cast. In the last local elections in 2005, the KMT took a higher percentage - 50.96 percent - of the votes. The party also lost two major seats in Yilan and Hualien counties that it had held for the past four years.
In this election, the DPP won 45.32 percent of the total number of votes cast -- which was a significant gain from the 41.95 percent it won four years ago.
The 2005 elections, however, were for magistrates and mayors in 23 counties and cities, instead of this year's 17.
The turnout rate in this year's election was 63.34 percent, compared to 66.22 percent in the 2005 poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: Despite lower fuel prices, Taipower to lose money in 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 20:35:09 (By Shu-yuan Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) , Taiwan's only power distributor, will come close to breaking even in 2009 after a difficult 2008 but expects to post a stiff loss next year based on an anticipated rise in crude oil prices.

The company is set to post a small loss of NT$1 billion (US$3.09 million) this year, Taipower Chairman Edward Chen said at a legislative hearing Monday, far below the record high NT$101.35 billion pre-tax loss and NT$75.6 billion net loss it reported in 2008.
Chen warned, however, that the recovering global economy could push demand for crude oil up and drive oil prices -- and the utility's costs -- higher next year, hurting profitability.

Taipower is forecasting a net loss of NT$26.7 billion in 2010, based on projected total revenues of NT$507.3 billion and expenses of NT$534 billion, Chen said, but he cautioned that if oil prices rise more than expected, the loss will be higher.

According to Chen, Taipower's estimates are based on an average price of US$73 per barrel in 2010 for West Texas intermediate crude, more than US$5 lower than the price forecast by the U.S. Department of Energy.

Taipower relies on imported oil, coal and natural gas for nearly 75 percent of its power generation, and with the cost of electricity in Taiwan kept at relatively low levels, the company is vulnerable to spikes in energy prices.
It posted an NT$23.1 billion net loss in 2007 as raw material costs began moving higher before registering a record loss last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma may be fined for citing pre-election survey
DOC.DATELINE: Yilan, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 20:38:45 (By Shen Ju-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou may be fined NT$500,000 after the examination committee of the Yilan County Election Commission resolved Monday that Ma had violated the Public Officials Election and Recall Act while addressing a campaign rally in Yilan on Nov. 25.
The election commission will meet Tuesday to decide whether or not to abide by the examination committee's finding and fine the president for citing a media pre-election survey at the rally.

Acting in his capacity as Kuomintang (KMT) chairman, Ma was campaigning for incumbent county magistrate Lu Kuo-hwa ahead of the Dec. 5 county chief election when he told the crowd that Lu had taken the lead in a local poll.

According to Article 53 of the election law, parties or individuals are prohibited from publishing, reporting, disseminating, citing or commenting on any polling materials with regard to relevant candidates or the election itself during a period of 10 days before election day.
The Yilan Election Commission sent a letter to KMT headquarters, demanding an explanation of the remarks after initiating an investigation on Nov. 26.
While Ma promptly apologized through KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po at a press conference, the KMT on Dec. 4 submitted a statement to the commission, elaborating on the incident.
Only one of the 25 members of the examination committee was absent from Monday's deliberations, and 21 of those attending the meeting judged that Ma had violated the regulations.
While such a violation could lead to a fine of between NT$500,000 and NT$5 million, the committee suggested a fine of NT$500,000 because Ma was only a campaign assistant.

At the Nov. 26 press conference, KMT Secretary-General Chan stressed that the party chairman and the party would respect the ruling of the Yilan County Election Commission, though Ma is entitled to appeal its decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Monday: Apple Daily Next Year's Battle
The prelude to the battles for five municipality mayoral posts that will be up for grabs next year will start soon.

The just-concluded local elections have helped opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen consolidate her leadership within the party, but she will soon face tough challenges as infighting over next year's poll will be far more serious.

The ruling Kuomintang is expected to be more unified for the five municipality mayoral races, as its politicians should have learned lessons from Saturday's poll in which the party suffered a setback because of splits in some districts.

In contrast, the DPP performed better than expected because it was more unified than the KMT. However, infighting over next year's battles has already emerged within the DPP ranks. If the party leadership fails to properly address this problem, the DPP might lose one of the two seats it now holds.

As next year's elections will involve important urban areas and 60 percent of Taiwan's population, it would deal a real blow to President Ma Ying-jeou's leadership if the DPP manages to win three of the five seats up for grabs. Whether or this scenario will play out depends on the KMT's administrative record and the DPP's ability to avoid becoming giddy-headed over its small gains in Saturday's elections. Commercial Times Forward-looking critical to Taiwan's future
The hotly contested three-in-one local elections have drawn to an end. Although they were routine grassroots elections, the public made a statement in the polls that should not be overlooked.
The electoral results show that Taiwan's voters have become more mature as they used their ballots to teach the ruling Kuomintang a lesson for its lackluster administrative performance.
The elections, however, were mainly the prelude to next year's battles for five municipality mayoral posts whose results will have a far more direct impact on the 2012 presidential election.
We earnestly hope both the KMT and the opposition Demoncratic Progressive Party (DPP) will come up with forward-looking policy initiatives in the run-up to the municipality elections.

Taiwan's future lies in whether the two parties can move from a zero-sum confrontation to benign competition. As the country's top leader, President Ma Ying-jeou is obligated to present strategies that will enable Taiwan to take on challenges arising from globalization, China's rise as a new economic powerhouse, and the integration of ASEAN member states and China, Japan and South Korea.

As Taiwan's main opposition force, the DPP, while advocating the importance of preserving Taiwan's sovereignty, should also tell voters how Taiwan can avoid being marginalized in the current wave of regional integration and globalization and sustain its growth.

If both parties drag their feet on zero-sum games, Taiwan's window of opportunity may eventually close. At that point, gaining power in Taiwan will be meaningless. China Times Diploma recognition marks start of transforming demagogy
Public response to the Ministry of Education's recent decision to recognize academic credentials issued by 41 top-notch universities in China has been generally positive.

The longstanding ban on recognizing Chinese university diplomas is only part of Taiwan's demagogic political culture and we hope the education ministry's latest move will mark the beginning of transforming closed-minded ways of thinking as reflected in populist rhetoric.

As demagogy is a strategy for gaining political power by appealing to the prejudices, emotions, fears and expectations of the public with impassioned rhetoric and propaganda, a demagogic society could become inward-looking, xenophobic, isolationist and retrogressive in the long run.

Over the years, demagogic overtures have often weighed in on the government's policy making. As a result, state-owned enterprises and academic research institutions dare not offer high pay to recruit outstanding foreign talents to infuse ingenuity into their ranks because they are afraid of demagogic criticism.
If Taiwan wants to continue playing a significant role in the world arena, it must change closed-minded demagogic mentality and embrace talented people with open arms.

Taiwan's refusal to recognize China's academic accreditation has denied itself a source of emerging talent. We hope the government will address this issue because the loss of talented people is one of the toughest challenges facing Taiwan today. Economic Daily News KMT's election setback comes at right time
Saturday's election setback could not have come at a better time for the ruling Kuomintang as it has brought an opportunity for Taiwan to be better off in the future.
It sent a clear message to the KMT: voters are dissatisfied with the Ma Ying- jeou administration's performance over the past 18 months.

Ma has failed to deliver on its promise to reform the economy. The global economic map has undergone a reshuffle in the wake of the global financial crisis but the Ma administration has not come up with any macroeconomic development strategies, instead indulging itself in trival issues about the "grassroots economy."

We hope the latest election setback will serve as a wake-up call for the Ma administration and look forward to a broad road map that will lead to Taiwan's overall economic restructuring and sustainable growth.

We also hope that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's election gains will not be overblown as a public backlash against the KMT administration's policy toward increased engagement with China or its plan to sign a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement.
Ma's presidential campaign platform to repair ties with China has the support of nearly 60 percent of voters, and the approach should not be changed simply because of a modest election setback.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural creativity given value in draft law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 22:04:58 (By Teresa Ueng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Artistic and cultural creativity will be fairly valued in government projects if a draft act to develop cultural creative industries that is being considered by a legislative committee becomes law in the future.

On Monday, the legislature's Education and Culture Committee reached a consensus on some clauses in the various proposed versions of the draft act, including on one that would enable the government to pay more for cultural creativity.
The committee's lawmakers agreed that the government should promote the concept that "all cultural creativity has a price" and free cultural creativity from the constraints of rigid budget law.

Legislator Chiang Nai-shin of the ruling Kuomintang proposed that government expenditures on creative services or assets with an economic utility of more than two years should be listed as a capital expense rather than as a current expense under budget law.
At present, expenditures reported as current expenses leave little room for services such as "design" that are not tangible or cannot be easily assessed.
Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party expressed her appreciation for Chiang's ideas.
"Cultural activities should carry a price" said Kuan, who served as Kaohsiung City's cultural chief before becoming a lawmaker.

She cited one project where she coordinated the budget of a wall made with artistic tiles in Taipei County in which the government would only calculate the cost of the project based on the price of tiles, but the builder insisted on a higher price because he had paid high design fees to an artist.

Meanwhile, the committee also decided to divide cultural creative industries into 15 sectors -- visual arts, music and performing arts, cultural asset applications and exhibition and performing facilities, artifacts, movie, broadcast and television, publication, advertising, product design, visual communication design, brand design, architectural design, digital content, creative life, popular music and cultural content.
The version proposed by the Council for Cultural Affairs originally divided the industry into four categories: arts, media, design and digital content.
The committee also considered a proposed artistic coupon for elementary and junior high school students and agreed to include the proposal in a tax incentive program for overall consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: 198 suspects detained for vote-buying during local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 22:13:16 (By Lin Chang-shun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice reported Monday that 198 suspects were detained on charges of buying votes at the conclusion of the Dec. 5 elections for mayors and county chiefs, county councilors and township chiefs.

Statistics released by the Ministry of Justice indicated that in recent weeks, judicial authorities around the island received 4,380 reports of suspected vote- buying. While 2,413 cases were accepted and investigated, only 56 suspects have been indicted to date.

Judging that cash has been the most effective incentive in luring voters, judicial authorities concentrated their efforts during these elections on trying to seize the large sums distributed to brokers to buy votes.

As of the eve of election day, prosecutors offices around the country had seized over NT$12 million, of which nearly 40 percent was attributed to candidates for the county council in Miaoli County in central Taiwan.
In May 2009, the Ministry of Justice announced revised guidelines for vote- buying investigations and the performance evaluation of prosecutors' offices.

The guidelines required vote-buying investigations to be resolved within nine months after an election and district prosecutors to initiate legal proceedings against those found buying their way into public office.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bank of Taiwan plans financial building in Shanghai
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 22:46:55 (By Min-kun Chang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The chairwoman of the state-owned Bank of Taiwan (BOT) said Monday that the bank will not rule out the possibility of financing a Taiwanese financial building in Shanghai that will not only be used as its Shanghai branch office but could also be leased to other Taiwanese banks.

According to Susan Chang, who was speaking to reporters on the sidelines of a financial seminar in the Chinese city, a BOT application for setting up a representative office in China has already been approved by Shanghai's banking regulatory body and is awaiting Beijing's approval.
Chang said that during her visit, she will look for possible locations for setting up a BOT branch there.

BOT, established in 1946, used to have a Shanghai branch office on the Bund in the late 1940's, and Chang said the bank has contacted the office's present owner -- China Merchants Bank -- to see if BOT can buy it back.
"We just want to check it out. We may not be able to afford it if the price is too high," said Chang.

She said the bank is waiting for the next round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, which are expected to offer a clue about whether it will be able to set up a branch office rather than just a representative office.

She pointed out that at present, Taiwanese banks need to have a representative office in China that has been established for at least two years before it can be upgraded to a branch. However, if there is a breakthrough during the talks on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, it is likely that they will be permitted to directly set up branches.
In addition, she also said the ECFA could allow Taiwanese banks to conduct business in Chinese yuan, which is what Taiwanese businessmen there need most.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural creativity given value in draft law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 22:04:58 (By Teresa Ueng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Artistic and cultural creativity will be fairly valued in government projects if a draft act to develop cultural creative industries that is being considered by a legislative committee becomes law in the future.

On Monday, the legislature's Education and Culture Committee reached a consensus on some clauses in the various proposed versions of the draft act, including on one that would enable the government to pay more for cultural creativity.
The committee's lawmakers agreed that the government should promote the concept that "all cultural creativity has a price" and free cultural creativity from the constraints of rigid budget law.

Legislator Chiang Nai-shin of the ruling Kuomintang proposed that government expenditures on creative services or assets with an economic utility of more than two years should be listed as a capital expense rather than as a current expense under budget law.
At present, expenditures reported as current expenses leave little room for services such as "design" that are not tangible or cannot be easily assessed.
Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party expressed her appreciation for Chiang's ideas.
"Cultural activities should carry a price" said Kuan, who served as Kaohsiung City's cultural chief before becoming a lawmaker.

She cited one project where she coordinated the budget of a wall made with artistic tiles in Taipei County in which the government would only calculate the cost of the project based on the price of tiles, but the builder insisted on a higher price because he had paid high design fees to an artist.

Meanwhile, the committee also decided to divide cultural creative industries into 15 sectors -- visual arts, music and performing arts, cultural asset applications and exhibition and performing facilities, artifacts, movie, broadcast and television, publication, advertising, product design, visual communication design, brand design, architectural design, digital content, creative life, popular music and cultural content.
The version proposed by the Council for Cultural Affairs originally divided the industry into four categories: arts, media, design and digital content.
The committee also considered a proposed artistic coupon for elementary and junior high school students and agreed to include the proposal in a tax incentive program for overall consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: 198 suspects detained for vote-buying during local elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/07/09 22:13:16 (By Lin Chang-shun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice reported Monday that 198 suspects were detained on charges of buying votes at the conclusion of the Dec. 5 elections for mayors and county chiefs, county councilors and township chiefs.

Statistics released by the Ministry of Justice indicated that in recent weeks, judicial authorities around the island received 4,380 reports of suspected vote- buying. While 2,413 cases were accepted and investigated, only 56 suspects have been indicted to date.

Judging that cash has been the most effective incentive in luring voters, judicial authorities concentrated their efforts during these elections on trying to seize the large sums distributed to brokers to buy votes.

As of the eve of election day, prosecutors offices around the country had seized over NT$12 million, of which nearly 40 percent was attributed to candidates for the county council in Miaoli County in central Taiwan.
In May 2009, the Ministry of Justice announced revised guidelines for vote- buying investigations and the performance evaluation of prosecutors' offices.

The guidelines required vote-buying investigations to be resolved within nine months after an election and district prosecutors to initiate legal proceedings against those found buying their way into public office.

In addition, she also said the ECFA could allow Taiwanese banks to conduct business in Chinese yuan, which is what Taiwanese businessmen there need most.
The representative offices of Taiwanese banks in China are not allowed to offer banking services and are limited to marketing and research.

Several of them, however, are planning to open branches in China following the signing last month of a long-anticipated financial memorandum of understanding (MOU) with China under which Taiwan and China have agreed to allow greater access to each other's financial markets. The MOU lays the groundwork for moves that will allow the establishment of bank branches in each other's territories, with future agreements expected to allow investment in each other's banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 8, or the 22nd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Austria becomes the first nation to establish a state education system.
1889: Jefferson Davis, the first and only president of the Confederate States of America, dies at the age of 81. He was captured by Union soldiers in 1865 and imprisoned for two years. Although indicted for treason, he was never prosecuted.
1907: One of the worst coal mine disasters in U.S. history occurs at Mononagh, West Virginia, killing 361 people.
1911: Mongolia is declared a Russian protectorate.
1917: The Republic of Finland is proclaimed.
1917: The steamship Mont Blanc collides with the steamship Imo in Halifax, Canada, killing more than 1,500 people, injuring 8,000 others, and destroying a large part of the city.
1921: Britain signs a peace treaty with Ireland under which the Irish Free States is established and Ireland accepts Dominion status.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appeals to Japan's Emperor Hirohito for peace.
1943: The United States, Britain and the Soviet Union issue the Joint Declaration of the Tehran Conference.
1957: The United States fails in the launching of its first satellite.
1960: Taiwan Province implements the use of media broadcasts for the first time in the history of Republic of China military service in order to muster the required number of reservists.
1971: India recognizes the Democratic Republic of Bangladesh.
1973: The United Nations decides to establish the United Nations University in Tokyo.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford arrives in the Philippines for talks on new terms for U.S. air and naval basses in the country.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan receives Mrs. Paul Norman Brown, national president of the American Legion Ladies' Auxiliary, at the Presidential Office.
1979: The Communist Chinese ban the sticking of "big character posters" on Beijing's wall of democracy.
1980: The 1980 Supplementary Parliamentarian election sends 70 members to the Legislative Yuan and 76 to the National Assembly.
1986: Eighty-four members are newly elected to the Legislative Yuan and seventy- three members are newly elected to the National Assembly in the 1986 legislative by-elections. Voter turnout is 65.4 percent of the 11.8 million eligible registered voters.
1988: The ROC Legislative Yuan is paralyzed by fist-fighting, as the chairman for the first time asks police to maintain order.
1989: The worst mass killing in Canadian history takes place when a gunman shoots 13 female students to death at the University of Montreal before killing himself.
1990: President Saddam Hussein announces that all 3,400 foreign hostages held in Iraq since the invasion of Kuwait are now free to leave.
1990: Gen. Hussain Mohammed Ershad steps down at the height of a pro-democracy movement in Bangladesh.
1996: The Legislative Yuan revises the Labor Standards Law so that employees in nearly all industries will be covered by the end of 1998.
1999: The ROC-Japan Economic Conference opens in Tokyo.
2000: The Republic of China's Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs removes restrictions on workers from the Philippines, with the change effective retroactively to Dec. 1.
2000: Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez arrives in Taipei for an official visit.
2001: Taiwan's two largest opposition parties, the Kuomintang and the People First Pary, decide not to participate in the "national stabilization alliance" that has been proposed by President Chen Shui-bian.
2001: The computer virus "Goner, " first found in the United States, is rampant in Hong Kong with at least 16 companies' computer systems being hit.
Motse's lesson of the day: "When the administration of the ruler does not answer to the desires of the subjects, it shows a lack of understanding of the approvals and disapprovals of the subjects. When there is no such understanding, then the good will not be discovered and rewarded and the bad will not be punished."

Legislator Chiang Nai-shin of the ruling Kuomintang proposed that government expenditures on creative services or assets with an economic utility of more than two years should be listed as a capital expense rather than as a current expense under budget law.
At present, expenditures reported as current expenses leave little room for services such as "design" that are not tangible or cannot be easily assessed.
Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party expressed her appreciation for Chiang's ideas.
"Cultural activities should carry a price" said Kuan, who served as Kaohsiung City's cultural chief before becoming a lawmaker.

She cited one project where she coordinated the budget of a wall made with artistic tiles in Taipei County in which the government would only calculate the cost of the project based on the price of tiles, but the builder insisted on a higher price because he had paid high design fees to an artist.

Meanwhile, the committee also decided to divide cultural creative industries into 15 sectors -- visual arts, music and performing arts, cultural asset applications and exhibition and performing facilities, artifacts, movie, broadcast and television, publication, advertising, product design, visual communication design, brand design, architectural design, digital content, creative life, popular music and cultural content.
The version proposed by the Council for Cultural Affairs originally divided the industry into four categories: arts, media, design and digital content.
The committee also considered a proposed artistic coupon for elementary and junior high school students and agreed to include the proposal in a tax incentive program for overall consideration.

U.S. dollar down in early Taipei trading
