DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media
DOC.DATELINE: 12/08/09 11:26:28 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: With the conclusion of Saturday's local elections, the attention has now turned to the next major battleground -- the election of heads of five special municipalities -- which account for 60 percent of the nation's population.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on who will represent the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to run in Taipei:

Liberty Times: DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's remarks that "I will be ready, when the party needs me to be ready" was considered an indication that she is willing to enter the race for Taipei mayor. However, she urged party members not to designate candidates recklessly on Monday, because she has never said that she will run. She said that the DPP should set up an overall goal before choosing candidates. It is too early to discuss this issue now.

DPP Lawmakers Yeh Yi-jin and Lai Ching-te called for moving up party primaries to March next year to choose party candidates. They said that the longer the time the primaries take, the shorter the time the candidates will be left with before the races, while it takes more time to prepare for municipalities elections, and belated primaries will cause fierce splits within the party. (Dec. 8, 2009)

China Times: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said on Monday that the election of the mayor of Taipei City, which is the capital of the country, is politically significant. He is preparing to seek a second term on the ruling KMT ticket next year.

Learning that he could face DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen in that race, Hau said Tsai is a scholar with experience in serving in the Cabinet and has succeeded in transforming the DPP; she would be a respected rival. (Dec. 8, 2009)

United Daily News: The DPP garnered a record high of 45 percent of the votes in the just-concluded local elections which enabled it not only to achieve an excellent performance in the races for chiefs in cities and counties, but also to increase the number of townships it controls. The party grabbed 11 townships in Pingtung County, 6 townships in Yunlin County, and eight townships in Chiayi County.
In Taoyuan County, which is the Kuomintang's stronghold, the DPP won the townships of Guishan and Guanyin. Yuchih Township in Nantou County also saw its first DPP chief. (Dec. 8, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: 12/08/09 12:00:15 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Whether the Ma administration will continue or adjust its policy on major issues such as a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, which has been a target of opposition attacks during the just-concluded local elections, is being closely watched.
The following is a digest of some local media reports about this issue:
China Times:

Despite the ruling "pan-blue" camp's lackluster performance in the just- concluded local mayoral and county chief elections, President Ma Ying-jeou told the National Manager Excellence Award 2009 winners Monday that it would be unfavorable to Taiwan if it does not continue to promote the ECFA.

Ma said he has instructed relevant authorities to make transparent the process and content of talks between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on the planned agreement in an effort to allow society to gain complete knowledge of the matter.
Premier Wu Den-yih also stressed that there is no need to fine-tune the existing cross-strait policy, and that the promotion of the proposed ECFA will go on as originally scheduled. (Dec. 8, 2009)
United Daily News:

Amid misgivings that a setback of the ruling Kuomintang in the local elections Dec. 5 could affect the government's cross-strait policies, President Ma stressed Monday that no negotiations on the proposed ECFA will be held during the upcoming meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), later this month.
The ECFA-related discussions and signing of the agreement will be conducted in a "relatively transparent" environment to allow the people to gain knowledge of its contents, Ma pledged. (Dec. 8, 2009)
United Daily News:
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang promised Monday at the Legislative Yuan that he is willing to have an open debate on television with those who are against the proposed ECFA with China.
It would be the first time that the government holds a public debate on TV to promote its major policies if the Ministry of Economic Affairs hosts the TV debate. (Dec. 8, 2009)
Liberty Times:

President Ma has promised that the legislature will be completely informed of the proposed ECFA's content before it is signed and that the agreement will be delivered to the Legislative Yuan for approval after it is signed.

Doubting President Ma can really sense many people's anxiety and worry over the ECFA's formation, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen said on the ECFA dispute, a national referendum is the society's most-needed form of public monitoring on the issue. (Dec. 8, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records 33rd death from H1N1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 12:48:11 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Health authorities reported Tuesday that a 53-year-old woman with underlying health conditions has died from influenza A(H1N1), the 33rd person in Taiwan to die from the virus.
The patient, a resident of Taipei County, had suffered from heart disease, diabetes and high blood pressure, according to the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC).
"Eighty-five percent of those people who died of H1N1 flu had been patients of chronic diseases, " said Chou Jih-haw, deputy director-general of the Centers for Disease Control.
The total number of H1NI flu infection cases since the outbreak began had reached 766 as of Monday, of which 33 had resulted in death, according to the CECC.
Most of these cases had recovered and been discharged, the CECC said.

Meanwhile, as of Monday, 479 classes in 325 schools around the country remained closed because of H1N1 infections among the students. The number of affected classes accounts for 0.32 percent of the total, according to the CECC.
The center attributed the decline in the number of class closures mainly to an across-the-board vaccination program launched on Nov. 16 to all students in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Key Taiwan hi-tech companies get carbon footprint certificates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 13:29:46 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Five major companies representing the supply chain spectrum of Taiwan's high- technology industry have all obtained carbon footprint certificates from authoritative organizations from home and abroad for their latest products.

Their efforts, recognized recently by the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers Association (TEEMA) , were aimed at keeping up with the global trend of protecting the environment and securing greater market potential for their products, said TEEMA Chairman Arthur Yu-cheng Chiao.

The five technological giants were Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) , United Microelectronics Corporation (UMC) , Chi Mei Optoelectronics (CMO) , Advanced Semiconductor Engineering (ASE) and ASUSTeK Computer (ASUS).

They were awarded with TEEMA's low-carbon labels in November after they obtained carbon footprint certificates for their low-carbon products from professional verification organizations, including DNV in Norway, the Swiss group SGS, and Taiwan's Environment and Development Foundation.
"Supply chain carbon footprint management is a key issue concerning the development of Taiwan's high-technology industry in the future," Chiao said.

Taiwan's electrical and electronic sector churned out US$216.6 billion worth of products in 2008, representing 48.84 percent of the country's entire industrial output, Chiao quoted TEEMA tallies as indicating.
Of that total, US$118.7 billion worth of products went to exports, comprising 46.7 percent of Taiwan's total export trade that year.

"It's crucial that Taiwanese manufacturers start managing their products' carbon footprint, " Chiao said, pointing out that reducing carbon dioxide emissions has become an increasingly pressing issue of global importance.

In a few years, he added, Taiwan's consumer electronics products bound for North America and Europe will not only have to be competitive in terms of pricing, they also must be competitive in terms of carbon footprint reduction.

Hsu Fang-ming, a TSMC official in charge of industrial safety, environmental protection and public health, noted that from 2014, Walmart, the largest retail chain store in the United States, will demand that all products on shelves carry green labels.

Officials from the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said that from 2012, EU member countries will monitor and control carbon dioxide emissions from all aircrafts departing from and landing in airports in the European Union, adding that Taiwanese airline carriers should keep that in mind and make preparations in a timely manner.

Meanwhile, TSMC and several other Taiwanese companies in other industrial and business sectors, including China Airlines, Kuo-Kuang Motor Transport and the Taipei 101 building, have engaged in supply chain carbon inventory on an experimental basis as part of the efforts to accelerate the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions, according to the EPA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of low-income households hits record high in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 14:05:39 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The number of low-income households in Taiwan hit a record high of 102,759 households or 249,834 people in September, which represents an increase of 13.5 percent and 14.9 percent, respectively.

The Ministry of the Interior, which released the statistics, attributed the increases to the global financial crisis. It said the economic downturn has driven up the unemployment rate, which then prompted the government to lower Taiwan's threshold for poverty.

By administrative districts, Taipei City led the pack with 16,047 households and 39,501 people considered low income, followed by Taipei County with 12,758 households and 31,368 people, and Kaohsiung City with 9,219 households and 21,968 people.
The cities ranked in the same order during the same period last year, according to the ministry.

In terms of the percentage of people in the cities or counties considered low income, Taitung County tops the list at 4.48 percent, followed by Penghu County at 3.58 percent and Hualien County at 2.37 percent.
On the other end of the scale, Taichung County had the lowest percentage of low income people at 0.58 percent, followed by Tainan and Chiayi counties at 0.59 percent.
Taiwan's Social Assistance Act defines low-income households as those whose total income divided by the number of individual members in the household is lower than the minimum cost of living.

The minimum cost of living is defined in Taiwan by the central and municipal authorities as 60 percent of the most recent average monthly consumption expenditure per capita, calculated by the central Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

By this criteria, Taipei had the highest minimum cost of living in 2009 at NT$14,558 (US$451) per month. That figure indicates the 35,501 people who are considered low income in Taipei survive on around US$15 a day.
Other cities fared worst than Taipei. Kaohsiung City's poor survived on only NT$11, 309 a month, Taipei County's on NT$10,792, and the other counties in Taiwan on NT$9,829.
Kinmen and Matsu counties have the lowest minimum cost of living at NT$7,400 a month.

Huang Pi-hsia, director-general of the ministry's Department of Social Affairs, cited the relatively higher cost of living in Taipei City as the reason for the city having the largest population of low income people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA must be negotiated with China: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 15:15:53 (By Lin Yi-fang, Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan must negotiate the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China in order to avoid marginalization of local industries in the Asia-Pacific region, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.
Without the agreement, many exports from Taiwan to mainland China will be subject to an import tariff of 9 percent on average, Wu said.
Meanwhile, after China joins the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) in 2010, most of its imports from the other member countries will be tariff- free, he added.
Under such circumstances, "will Taiwanese industries remain in Taiwan or will manufacturers open more factories in Taiwan? " Wu asked.
Taiwan's industries may not even have time to deliberate, he warned.

The ECFA will open a new path for most of the industries in Taiwan and will exempt them from high tariffs, he said at a breakfast meeting hosted by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.
"The government is now racing against time" because Taiwan will lose out if it hesitates over the agreement, the premier said.

Responding to media questions on whether he thought the government's China- leaning policies were the major factors that contributed to the ruling party's losses in the Dec. 5 local elections, Wu said that the facts of the government's cross-Taiwan Strait policies were distorted in many cities and counties during the election campaign.

For example, it was rumored that once the ECFA is signed, many Taiwanese workers will lose their jobs due to imports of cheap Chinese labor, and the market for local agricultural products will suffer when Taiwan lifts it restrictions on such goods from the mainland.
However, Wu noted, it was not President Ma Ying-jeou's administration that gave permission for the importation of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products that are currently allowed.
He reiterated that President Ma will not move to lift the restrictions on the more than 800 Chinese products that are banned from entering Taiwan.
The government will make greater efforts to explain the proposed ECFA to the public, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close marginally lower on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 15:35:58 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed marginally lower Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 6.93 points, or 0.08 percent, to close at 7,768.71.
The local bourse opened at the day's high of 7,802.27 and reached a low of 7,731.01 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.23 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$126.9 billion (US$3.94 billion).

Three of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 1.29 percent. Machinery and electronics shares increased 0.09 percent and construction issues advanced 0.03 percent.

The five other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares the biggest decliners, falling 0.75 percent. Paper and pulp issues fell 0.58 percent, textile stocks dropped 0.57 percent, plastics and chemicals shares shed 0.55 percent, and cement stocks fell 0.36 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,483 to 1,095, with 300 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$4.09 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan may raise wages for Chinese fishing laborers soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 15:50:20 (By Yang Su-min and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may raise the wages of the Chinese crewmen employed on Taiwanese fishing boats before the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks to secure China's help in streamlining the system used to hire such workers, a fishing official said Tuesday.

The anonymous official from the Fisheries Agency said the decision may be taken Dec. 9 when Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation meets Chinese officials in Fuzhou, southern China, to finalize the details of the fourth round of talks between Taiwan and China.
The negotiations will be conducted by Taiwan's top negotiator Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin in Taichung City Dec. 21-24.
Fisheries Agency chief James Sha, who will take part in the preparatory meeting along with Kao, is expected to broach the issue with Chinese officials, the official said.

Taiwan could propose to raise the monthly wage of Chinese crewmen from the current NT$12,000 (US$372) to NT$14,000 per month but would not raise it as high as Taiwan's minimum wage of NT$17,280, which could blunt the competitiveness of the Chinese workers.
The possible monthly salary of NT$14,000 would be higher than the NT$12,000 typically paid to Indonesian crewmen and NT$13,000 to Filipino seamen, the official said.

There are 4,669 Chinese working on Taiwan's offshore fishing boats compared to 4,485 from other foreign countries, and 12,000 to 13,000 Chinese on Taiwan's deep sea fishing vessels, accounting for 40 percent to 45 percent of foreign workers on those ships.

Taiwan has asked for Chinese cooperation in streamlining the system used to employ Chinese nationals on Taiwanese fishing boats, but in exchange for setting up the system, China asked that Taiwan sweeten the wages paid to its nationals.

Under the revamped system, Taiwan fishing boat owners would be able to recruit seamen through Chinese fishermen dispatch associations set up by state-run companies rather than through brokers, as is the case today.

The associations in turn would be required to keep and provide information on potential laborers, including their ID card numbers, photos, and proof of seaworthiness and training, according to the official.

Kao and his delegation will also work out an agreement with Chinese officials on institutionalizing the inspection and quarantine mechanism for agricultural products, according to a source close to the negotiations.

The source said Taiwan wants to set up an official channel of communication with China on the issue through which each side may access the official interpretations of related regulations of the other side and get official answers to related questions.
Taiwan may also ask Chinese authorities to expand their standards on pesticide residues during the meeting.

China has standards on 161 agricultural chemicals, only a quarter of the 657 chemicals for which Taiwan has set norms. Substances not covered by the standards are banned altogether, which severely limits the exports of Taiwanese products to China despite their high quality, the source said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Next year's municipality elections a political watershed: DPP chair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 16:07:40 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: While the local elections last Saturday may have boosted the morale of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , the real watershed for both the DPP and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will be the 2010 municipality elections, said DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Tuesday.
"We can only say that this year, the DPP has managed to find a foothold, improve its strength and morale, and rekindle the passion of its supporters," Tsai said at a foreign press briefing.
"The real political watershed for the DPP and the KMT will come next year," she added.

Tsai was referring to the elections in 2010 for the heads of five municipalities -- Taipei City, New Taipei City (an upgrade of what is presently Taipei County) , Taichung (a merger of Taichung City and County), Tainan (a merger of Tainan City and County) and Kaohsiung (a merger of Kaohsiung City and County).
The results of the Dec. 5 local elections in 17 of Taiwan's 25 counties and cities were generally seen by the public and analysts as a victory for the DPP and a setback for the KMT.

Even though the KMT won 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats that were up for grabs, its support base was weakened in several localities. This time, the KMT won 47.88 percent of the vote, less than the 50.96 percent it gained in the previous local elections for 23 magistrates and mayors in 2005.

In comparison, the DPP's victory in Yilan, its retention of three other seats, and its inroads into the KMT's traditional strongholds of Penghu and Taitung, were seen as an affirmation of Tsai's leadership.
Tsai took over the party helm in May 2008 at a time when the DPP was in disarray because of a series of snowballing corruption scandals surrounding former President Chen-shui bian.
Tsai said that the DPP may be rising from the ashes, but it is still no match for the KMT at the moment.
However, that the results of last Saturday's elections have opened the possibility of the DPP regaining power, a senario that had previously seemed impossible, she added.

"I believe people would now start thinking that the DPP is capable of getting its act together and regaining the support of the Taiwan people," Tsai said. "The DPP could return to power in 2016, if not in 2012."
Tsai attributed her party's strong showing to what she called the government's poor performance and the DPP's election strategy that she said was focused on specific public issues.
The public can tell the difference between important matters and the personal charm of political stars, she added.
Asked whether she will run for presidency in 2012, Tsai said it is too early to talk about that, as her party will first focus on next year's municipality elections.

"Since the DPP no longer has political stars like former President Chen Shui- bian, candidates must be chosen based on party consensus, " Tsai said. "In light of Taiwan's fast-changing political environment, no one can give a definite answer to questions like that now."

DOC.HEADLINE: Official challenges critics to debate on proposed pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 16:36:42 (By Erin Ho and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top trade official has challenged critics of a proposed trade pact with China to debate the issue in a public forum.

"I am willing to face anyone who is interested in or skeptical about the planned economic cooperation framework agreement in a public debate, " Huang Chih-peng, director general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, said Tuesday.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, the leading trade negotiator with China said Taiwan is suffering a "rain of fists" in the international arena, which gives it no option but to seek such an agreement with China.

"I am worried sick about Taiwan's future, " said Huang, who insists Taiwan will be hurt economically when the free trade zone set up by Association of Southeast Asian Nation (ASEAN) countries and China takes effect on Jan. 1 next year.
Its situation will further deteriorate when Japan and South Korea are incorporated into the bloc sometime before 2018, the official said.

Huang said he was willing to square off with critics in a public debate a day after Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said his ministry was mulling the possibility of staging televised debates on the issue.

As it stands, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will organize 25 public forums to brief business and industrial groups as well as the general public around the island on the issue before February of next year, Huang said.

The trade official acknowledged that while the agreement will benefit the country in general, the government is concerned about the potential negative impact the deal could have on some sectors of the economy, and he said those consequences should be clearly explained publicly.

Meanwhile, Tsai Hsung-hsiung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, told a business group Tuesday that formal negotiations with China on the proposed agreement will begin early next year.
The administration's plan to conclude a framework agreement with China has been extremely controversial, with critics contending that such a deal with China would undermine the country's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma will pay fine out of own pocket
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 16:44:50 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will use his own money to pay a NT$500,000 fine that was imposed by the Yilan County Election Commission Tuesday for remarks he made at a campaign rally that violated election law, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) sources said.

Ma was fined after the commission accepted the findings of its examination committee, which resolved Monday that Ma had violated the Public Officials Election and Recall Act by citing a media pre-election survey while addressing a campaign rally in Yilan on Nov. 25.

Acting in his capacity as KMT chairman, Ma was campaigning for incumbent county magistrate Lu Kuo-hwa ahead of the Dec. 5 county chief election when he told the crowd that Lu had taken the lead in a local poll.

According to Article 53 of the election law, parties or individuals are prohibited from publishing, reporting, disseminating, citing or commenting on any polling materials with regard to relevant candidates or the election itself during a period of 10 days before election day.

"Chairman Ma will respect the ruling to be handed down by the Yilan County Election Commission and will pay for the fine with his own money, " said Lee Chien-jung, director of the KMT Cultural and Communication Affairs Committee.
According to Lee, Ma said that he cited the poll unwittingly during the rally and that he felt sorry about his absent-mindedness.
"I made the mistake. The buck stops here," Ma said.
Meanwhile, KMT Secretary-General Chan Chuen-po said that the party should foot the bill for the fine since Ma was speaking during a "rolling meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee."
Chan guessed, however, that Ma would opt to pay the fine out of his own pocket based on his past actions.

While such a violation could have led to a fine of between NT$500,000 and NT$5 million, the Yilan County Election Commission's examination committee suggested a fine of NT$500,000 Monday based on the argument that Ma was only a campaign assistant.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 17:02:44 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, rising NT$0.070 to close at NT$32.350.
A total of US$727 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.320 and fluctuated between NT$32.199 and NT$32.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-built orchid greenhouse inaugurated in Saint Lucia
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/09 17:13:05 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A greenhouse for orchid seedlings established with the assistance of a Taiwanese technical mission was inaugurated in St. Lucia Monday.
The new facility, located on a 2,500-square meter site, is the largest orchid greenhouse in the Caribbean, said Republic of China (Taiwan) Ambassador to St. Lucia Tom T.C. Chou.

Chou presided over the inauguration ceremony along with St. Lucian officials including Governor-General Dame Peralette Louisy, Minister of Agriculture Ezechiel Joseph, Minister of Tourism Allen Chastanet and Minister of Industry and Commerce Tessa Mangel.
In his address, Chou said Taiwan, known as a kingdom of orchids, helped its diplomatic ally build the greenhouse and provide technical guidance at the request of St. Lucia's government.

The greenhouse, he noted, is expected to raise hundreds of thousands of orchid seedlings every year and help St. Lucia supply not only its domestic market but the entire Caribbean with fresh orchids year round.
Joseph highlighted the ROC embassy's constant efforts to promote cooperation between the two countries, and said St. Lucia looks forward to becoming the Caribbean kingdom of orchids.
He also praised it for introducing the concept of tourism-oriented farms to St. Lucia, which will both help local farmers increase their incomes and boost tourism.
Taiwan resumed its diplomatic ties in 2007 with the island-nation in the eastern Caribbean after relations were severed 10 years earlier when St. Lucia switched its diplomatic recognition to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business as usual during Chiang-Chen talks: Taichung authorities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 17:22:03 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government denied on Tuesday reports that it has advised businesses to suspend operations during the talks between Taiwan and China that will take place later this month in the city.

According to Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, although police are planning to set up a restricted zone covering a 50-meter radius from the venue to facilitate security, all businesses and schools located in the area will operate as usual.

The fourth round of talks between the chief cross-strait negotiators -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- is likely to be held at the Windsor Hotel Taichung.

With pro-independence groups led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party having announced their plans to hold protests during the event, the Chinese- language Liberty Times reported Tuesday that in anticipation of possible disorder and riots, the city's police have advised businesses located near the venue to suspend operations to ensure their security.

Yu Hui-mao, deputy director-general of the Taichung City Police Bureau, clarified that police have informed local businesses of possible situations that could occur but has not asked them to suspend operations.

Pointing out that Zhonggang Road, where the Windsor Hotel is located, is one of the city's busiest roads, Yu said the police are responsible for adopting proper measures to protect the rights of road users and local residents.
It is also the police department's responsibility to provide the public with the necessary information to help them better prepare for possible scenarios, he said.
Hsiao, meanwhile, said the city government welcomes any protests that are legal, peaceful and non-violent.
However, if there are any disruptions of public order, the city government will take the necessary steps against lawbreakers, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups submit signatures for referendum on U.S. beef imports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 17:40:11 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Civic groups submitted a total of 130,459 signatures to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Tuesday in an effort to initiate a referendum on the importation of U.S. beef products.

To date, more than 200,000 signatures have been collected in the campaign, which is aimed at achieving a reopening of talks between Taipei and Washington on U.S. beef imports, according to Hsieh Tien-jen, chairman of the Consumers' Foundation that is leading the drive.
The 130,459 signatures that have been submitted to the CEC by far exceed the requirement of the first threshold for a referendum initiative, Hsieh said.
The first step in the process requires at least 86,000 signatures -- 0.5 percent of the country's 17.32 million registered voters in the last presidential election.
"The remaining 70,000 signatures will be kept for the second stage," Hsieh said.

Under Taiwan's referendum law, once a screening committee finds that the proposed referendum conforms to the legal guidelines, the next step for the referendum's sponsors would be to obtain the endorsement of at least 5 percent of the electorate -- in this case 860,000 signatures.
Meanwhile, Hsieh denied that his foundation and other civic groups are being used by the opposition parties to pressure the government on the beef issue.
"There was no political maneuvering behind the referendum initiative, " he stressed, pointing out that many of the signatures are from cities and counties held by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT).
For example, he said, Chiayi's KMT Mayor Huang Hui-min mailed over 1,000 signatures to the foundation, he said.
CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you said the commission will determine by Dec. 11 whether the referendum initiative meets the terms of the regulations.
The commission will then submit the proposal to the Executive Yuan Referendum Screening Committee for confirmation, Teng added.
Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and beef offal.

However, civic groups led by the Consumers' Foundation and politicians, have contended that the importation of high-risk beef products could put consumers at risk of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
With their appeals for re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef talks having been rejected by the administration, the groups have decided to push for a referendum.

In related news, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng lashed out at the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Tuesday over their continued boycott of legislative sessions to screen amendments to the laws governing Taiwan's beef imports.
"It's highly inappropriate to stall the legislative process with boycotts that started before the Dec. 5 local elections," Wang said.
Wang called on the opposition lawmakers "not to overdo it" and instead to help restore order in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP hopes for talks with Chinese civic groups: chair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 17:59:52 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen expressed reservations Tuesday on the possibility of meeting China's top negotiator during his visit to Taiwan later this month but said the DPP has long hoped to open communications with Chinese civic groups.

"Whether or not to meet with Chen Yunlin should depend on whether there is meaning in such a meeting, " Tsai said at a press briefing with members of foreign media in Taiwan, referring to the president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

"The cross-Taiwan Strait meetings have become a formality rather than focusing on substantive issues. It would take further discussion whether the DPP wants to have such contact with China," she added.

The fourth round of talks between Chen and Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), are scheduled to take place in central Taiwan's Taichung City in late December.

Chiang and Chen are expected to ink four agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
They will also exchange initial views on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
The SEF and ARATS are Taiwan and China's respective intermediary bodies responsible for two-way exchanges in the absence of official ties between the two countries.
Despite her reservations over meeting with Chen, Tsai said the DPP is more than willing to open dialogue with the people and civic groups in China.

"The DPP has no objection to or hostility toward China. We would like to treat them as we treat others. The exchanges are more difficult given the fact that China has ambitions on Taiwan, " Tsai said.

Asked whether the DPP will stage a large scale protest against Chen's visit like last year, Tsai said there will be one big gathering to voice disagreement with President Ma Ying-jeou's cross-strait policies, which she described as "no transparency, no communication and no proper adjustment plan."

She said, however, that after gaining confidence and a morale boost from last Saturday's local elections, the DPP and its supporters would have "more room for rationality, so we will have a different attitude toward the Chen-Chiang meeting this year than last year."
She said a more detailed plan on the protest would be announced at Wednesday's party committee meeting.

During Chen's first visit to Taipei last November, he was stranded in a hotel for several hours after attending a dinner hosted in his honor by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang, because pro-independence and anti-China protesters blocked the hotel's exits.
A total of 149 police officers were injured by protesters while trying to ensure the safety of Chen and his entourage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC chairman says challenges loom despite economy's recovery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 18:06:53 (By Ye-fong Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) chairman and CEO Morris Chang said Tuesday that while the global economy is recovering, Taiwanese companies still face the challenges of a stronger Taiwan dollar, higher raw material prices and stricter control of carbon emissions.

According to Chang, the founder of the world's largest contract chipmaker, the outlook for the semiconductor industry in 2010 is relatively good, but new challenges also loom as Taiwan's and the global economy slowly rebound.

With the U.S. dollar seemingly set to weaken over the long term, Taiwan's currency is likely to appreciate, a situation Chang described as "worrying" while speaking to reporters on the sidelines of a breakfast meeting held by the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce (CNAIC).
Chang said the second challenge will come from raw material prices, and especially oil prices, which are expected to move up slowly again.

The third challenge will be dealing with stricter rules to control carbon emissions after the 2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen, a situation Chang said would inevitably increase corporate costs.

Chang said the first two challenges -- an appreciating currency and higher commodity prices -- would be medium-term problems while dealing with carbon emissions and developing alternative energy sources would be a medium- to long- term problem.
"People who give no thought to far-flung problems soon find suffering nearby, " said Chang quoting Confucius to explain that his company has also been thinking seriously about these problems.
The Taiwan dollar has appreciated against the U.S. dollar this year, rising NT$2.9 from its 22-year low of NT$35.174 against the greenback on March 2 to NT$32.280 on Monday.
Taiwan is one of the world's most export-dependent economies, and the rising Taiwan dollar has hurt the country's exports and squeezed the profitability of export-oriented companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP secretary-general tenders resignation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 19:14:16 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Wu Nai-jen, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) tendered his resignation Tuesday, just days after the DPP exceeded expectations in last Saturday's local elections.

Wu, who returned to the post eight months ago when Tsai asked him to help with the campaign for the Dec. 5 local elections, said that he was both physically and mentally exhausted after the election battle.
"I agreed to come back from retirement and work for the DPP for the last time because I couldn't bear to see the situation the DPP was in at that time," Wu said.

According to Wu, the DPP needs to give the younger generation a chance to perform, and he has confidence in them judging from how well young candidates did in last Saturday's local elections in which the DPP retained three county magistrate seats and took Yilan County back from the ruling Kuomintang.

At a breakfast meeting held by DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Tuesday morning to thank DPP staff involved in the election campaign, Tsai expressed her gratitude to Wu, whom she described as the campaign's hardest worker.
Tsai told the Central News Agency that Wu's resignation has sent her into deep contemplation but she will do all she can to retain him in his position.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical students march to highlight AIDS-related rights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 19:21:39 (By L. T. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 200 students from Taipei Medical University (TMU) held a march Tuesday in downtown Taipei, calling for the public's attention to AIDS-related human rights issues.
The students, including some from the United States, Haiti, Finland, Japan and Kenya, chanted slogans as they marched from their university, past the Taipei 101 Tower and back to their campus.
The march was held in recognition of Dec. 10 International Human Rights Day and Dec. 1 World AIDS Day.

Lin I-lun, head of TMU's foreign student association, said the major purpose of the activity was to heighten public awareness of AIDS prevention and help promote the concept of a global village and a non-discriminatory co-existence of all peoples.
Chang Wu-shou, director of the TMU's foreign affairs department, said the university is keen to see students develop an interest in international affairs and acquire a global perspective.

The TMU, as part of its efforts to help deal with the spread of AIDS in Africa, has sent two volunteer medical service groups to provide service to HIV carriers in Swaziland and Sao Tome and Principe, Chang said.

Noting that the some 40 percent of Swaziland's population in the 25-45 age group is affected by HIV, he said the TMU is keen to accept students from African countries who wish to pursue advanced medical studies and AIDS management programs.

Monicah Nthumbi, a Kenyan exchange student at TMU, said AIDS-related management is an important issue in her country and she expressed the hope that she will be able to learn modern management skills to help contain the spread of the fatal disease in Kenya.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Tuesday: UNITED DAILY NEWS:
President Ma should ask himself why he lost one million votes

The Ma administration fared poorly in Saturday's local elections. In comparison to the 2008 presidential election, the KMT obtained one million fewer votes in the 17 cities and counties where the polls were held on December 5.

After that setback, Ma said he would review his policies, a statement that has been interpreted by some as signaling an "adjustment" of his cross-strait policy. But if he does that, he would be making a big mistake.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party has painted the election outcome as a "vote of no-confidence" against the Ma administration. But the polls were local elections that were held mainly in agricultural areas and offshore counties. Although the 17 cities and counties are spread over 70 percent of the country, their total population accounts for only 40 percent of the national figure.

We think Ma's slipping popularity is due mainly to a lasse faire attitude within the administration, which has allowed public doubts to fester over his ability to govern. This situation arose from a spate of incidents, which included controversies in the military and security agencies, and a proliferation of rumors.

The improvement in cross-strait relations should be to Ma's credit, but his officials lack the communications skills, the will and the guts to defend his policies, therefore, the administration's image is one of poor performance, especially after the DPP's repeated criticisms and smears. CHINA TIMES: KMT can only regain people's hearts by addressing setback squarely
The just-concluded elections sent a warning to the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and helped the floundering Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) back to its feet.

President Ma said that both he and the KMT need to conduct a review, but the question is to review what. If they are willing to admit that they did poorly, they should also find out "what went wrong."
In fact, since the free fall of Ma's immense popularity in the wake of Typhoon Morakot in August, his decision-making style has been called into serious question.

The government has seemed to have its hands tied on some policies that it should have promoted actively because of fears of public opposition. On other controversial issues, such as the easing of U.S. beef imports, it made the decision behind closed doors.
It is not unexpected that Ma would plunge himself in such a miserable plight. The criticism of Ma as being "arrogant" has been demonstrated by this decision- making style.

The voters have sent a warning signal to the Ma administration, but they have left some leeway to make adjustments and revisions. President should seize the opportunity to learn his lesson. ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS: The KMT loses all because of Ma Ying-jeou

Although the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) managed to keep 12 out of 17 seats up for grabs in Saturday's mayoral and magistrate election, the number of votes it received fell dramatically compared to the 2008 presidential election.
In a lot of cities and counties, the KMT candidates even faced serious challenges from their lesser-known and hastily nominated rivals from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The DPP candidates therefore targeted their attacks at President Ma and his major policy initiatives. President Ma also embarked on a hectic campaign for KMT candidates.
After the election results were in, all fingers, irrespective of their party affiliation, have pointed at Ma.

Ma cited the global financial crisis and high unemployment as factors not favorable to the KMT, but his biggest shortcoming identified by critics has been his failure to concede defeat and to shoulder its responsibility.
We believe that Ma should not shirk his responsibility: the flawed nomination mechanism and the poorly organized campaigning all contributed to the lackluster showing.
We think an economic downturn provides an able leader an opportunity to govern the country. But for more than one year, Ma has failed to come up with substantive measures to stimulate the economy.
Lastly, although Ma is known for his integrity, he has not been known for good governance and use of able men.

The most gratifying news after the elections is that he has finally decided to curtail his hectic itinerary for the time being to reflect quietly on his next step. LIBERTY TIMES: Does Ma want people to suffer as a result of his misguided policies?
Taiwan voters taught President Ma Ying-jeou a lesson in the Dec. 5 local elections.
Most people in Taiwan and international media agreed that Ma has encountered the most serious setback in his political career.
We believe his policy direction and governing ability have been disapproved by the Taiwan people.

But Ma has deliberately tried to ignore that message and has tried to blame his party's less-than-ideal showing in the elections on the global economic downturn. We are worried that he would continue on his present course and lead Taiwan to destruction in the remaining two years of his term.
Everyone knows that the failure of the Ma administration is due to two major reasons: the record high unemployment rate that resulted from the economic downturn and his China-leaning policies.

Based on his remarks after the elections, it is obvious that Ma is not going to change his China-leaning course. However, we think that he should abandon that direction in order to avoid being dealt a more serious blow in future elections. APPLE DAILY: Stumping vs. anti-stumping

Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung and Legislator Chiu Yi of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) blasted central government officials Monday for failing to stump for KMT candidates in the just-concluded local elections.
They asked rhetorically whether the officials would have had the chance to serve in the central government if they had not campaigned hard in the 2008 legislative and presidential elections.

But Premier Wu Den-yih and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah responded by saying that officials should maintain administrative neutrality and stick to carrying out their own duties, which they said are the best way to stump for KMT candidates.

Both Wu and Jiang have a point. The duty of the Interior Ministry and the Justice Ministry is to crack down on vote-buying and maintain order during elections. If the ministers go on stage to canvass support from voters, they will give the impression of being both players and umpires.

Moreover, the officials have no election experience and in the fever-pitch of campaign rallies, are apt to make gaffes that could invite invective instead of support. They are therefore better off not appearing on any campaign tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's semiconductor output expected to rise in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 20:27:49 (By Chou Pin-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's semiconductor sector is expected to post a 17.8 percent growth in 2010 as the sector continues to recover from the global recession, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast Tuesday.

With the sector having begun to see a recovery in the second quarter of 2009, the contraction in output has been narrowing and is projected to stand at 8.1 percent for the whole year, according to Tan Yu-hua, a research manager at the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK).

The figure is lower than the projected decline of 11.5 percent in the global market, Tan said in a seminar on the prospects for the high tech sector in 2010 that was held by the ITRI and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The sector's global value is expected to increase 12.2 percent next year, bringing it back to the level of 2008, he added.

Lee Kuan-hua, an industry analyst at IEK, predicted that the production value of Taiwan's IC design industry, which is projected to increase 3.1 percent in 2009, will further expand by 16.4 percent in 2010.

According to Lee, the global status of the country's IC design industry has been rising in recent years, with Taiwanese firms accounting for 18.4 percent of the world's 20 largest IC designers in 2008, up from 14.1 percent in 2001.

The rise of the low-price market, the demand for green energy and new applications within the medical care sector will pose both challenges and opportunities for Taiwan's IC design industry, he went on.

To expand the market for its IC products, Taiwan should seek to cooperate with China in adopting a set of shared standards for mobile telecommunications, digital radio, wireless networking, automobile electronics and medical electronics, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry to hold seminars to explain policies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/09 20:46:23 (By K.Y. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will hold 17 seminars around Taiwan Dec. 10-23 to explain the government's plan to recognize Chinese universities and open local tertiary education institutes to Chinese college students amid concern in some quarters that doing so could jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty and job market.

Liao Kao-shien, director of the MOE's Higher Education Department, said the ministry decided to explain the two issues to the public face to face in the seminars, with the first one to kick off in Kaohsiung City and the last one to be held in Taipei City.

According to Liao, the ministry is planning to gradually recognize diplomas issued by over 100 elite Chinese universities in three stages -- 41 top Chinese universities in the first stage, 55 in the second stage and an as-yet undecided number in the third stage. Police and military higher education institutes will be excluded.

In addition, he said, the MOE is projecting to make the policy retroactive to 1997, but will continue to heed public opinions in this regard, as there are strong local fears that the measure might affect the local job market.
The MOE has initially decided that Chinese graduates must leave Taiwan within a month of completing their studies and will not be permitted to find work in Taiwan.

In terms of the maximum number of Chinese students allowed to pursue higher and advanced studies in Taiwan, the MOE said that the number will be around 1 percent of the total number of every year's freshman intake -- about 2,000 per year. Each university will be authorized to have a maximum 2 percent of Chinese students enrolled at any one time.
The MOE plans to allow Chinese graduate students to pursue master's courses at public universities, while private universities will be permitted to enroll undergraduates.

Because of the ferry services established between the Taiwanese islands of Kinmen and Matsu and two ports in China's Fujian Province, the quota of Chinese students opting to study at colleges or universities on the two outlying islands might be larger, depending on the applications from each school, Liao said.
In principle, Chinese college or graduate students will be permitted to stay in Taiwan proper for up to two years, with exceptions to be studied on a case-by- case basis, he added.
While in Taiwan, Chinese students will not be entitled to work, while their visas will be issued in accordance with the rules governing foreign or overseas Chinese students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will open market further to Chinese capital: former minister
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 21:01:34 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its market further to Chinese capital, following three principles, namely going "from restricted to loosened, step by step, and expanding after certain results have been achieved", Chen Jui-lung, chairman of the Taipei-based Sinocon Industrial Standards Foundation and a former economics minister, said in Beijing Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks at the opening of a forum on cross-strait cooperation that was jointly sponsored by the foundation and the Beijing- based Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits.

Chen told the attendees that Taiwan manufacturers played an important role in the supply of key components to China's electrical appliance industry during China's implementation of a nationwide household appliance renovation project earlier this year. The measure was introduced during the world financial crisis with the aim of boosting China's economy through the expansion of domestic consumption.

In addition, Chen said, the financial sectors on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to enter a new stage of cooperation with the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between their monetary supervisory agencies.

With the inking of the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Taiwan's monetary sector would be able to access the mainland Chinese market, and industries on both sides would benefit from cross-strait monetary cooperation, he added.

As to the entry of Chinese capital into the Taiwan market, Chen said that Taiwan plans to open its market to Chinese capital under the guidelines of going "from restricted to loosened, step by step, and expanding after certain results have been achieved".

As of the end of October, Taiwan had opened 64 categories of manufacturing industries, 117 categories of service industries, and 11 categories of public construction projects to Chinese investment. Meanwhile, 15 Chinese investment applications had been approved by Taiwan authorities up to that time.

Chen said that investors in Taiwan can enjoy the advantages of expertise in innovation and global marketing. In the future, businesses on both sides of the Taiwan Strait would be able to advance their cooperation in areas such as research and development, building brand names, reciprocal investments and shared marketing channels, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businesses, workers split on ECFA impact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 21:31:27 (Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Local businesses and workers are split on the possible impact of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) on Taiwan's economy, with workers tending to be more pessimistic than businesses, according to the results of two surveys released Tuesday by an online employment broker.

The surveys by 104 Job Bank found that 38.2 percent of the business owners that responded think the agreement will bring "more opportunities than threats, " while 34.5 percent believe there will be "more threats than opportunities."
Among the workers surveyed, however, 44.4 percent said the pact will bring "more threats than opportunities, " compared with 29.9 percent who think the opposite.

Approximately 30 percent of the business owners believe the signing of the ECFA will stimulate young people in Taiwan and China into enhancing their competitiveness, boost Taiwan's economic development, attract foreign investment and strengthen cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Slightly more than 85 percent of them said they are confident in their ability to face the challenges.

Although 56.6 percent of the workers surveyed said the ECFA can help promote Taiwan's economic development, 62.7 percent expressed concern that the agreement will lead to the dumping of cheap Chinese products in Taiwan.

Another 58.7 percent said there could be a decrease in jobs and approximately 40 percent expressed fear of transfer of local capital and technologies to China and of a larger exodus of Taiwanese businesses.
The survey of 1,988 workers was conducted Nov. 10-15, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percentage points.
The survey of 629 businesses was carried out Nov. 10-16 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.91 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung postpones amphibious vehicle tours to next March
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:10:23 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The date of the official launch of amphibious vehicle tours in the southern city of Kaohsiung has been put back to March 2, 2010, a city official said Tuesday.
The postponement has been made to allow more time for test runs of the vehicle to ensure passenger safety, according to Wang Kwo-tsai, director-general of the city's Transportation Bureau.
The city government had originally planned to begin test runs in early December and to officially launch the service in January.

Under a new plan worked out by the city government, the first phase of the test runs will begin Dec. 20 and continue through Jan. 21, during which water tours will be provided to social welfare and tour groups interested in trying the service, Wang said.
In the second phase, which will run from Jan. 22 to Feb. 28, free tickets will be offered to tourists staying in Kaohsiung hotels, he went on.
The tours will start and finish at the Hanshin Arena shopping mall so that passengers can also go shopping, he added.

The 60-minute tours will allow passengers to sightsee on land and water, including a cruise on scenic Lotus Lake and a ride around the surrounding area. There will be six tours per day for a maximum of 30 passengers per tour.
Ticket prices will be NT$300 for adults and NT$150 for children.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Police Agency Web site welcomes public opinion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:12:15 (By Lin Sheng-hsu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) has set up a special "civic forum" corner on its official Web site www.npa.gov.tw, on which members of the public are encouraged to leave comments about the police and their work, a spokesman for the agency said Tuesday.

A recent survey conducted by the Ministry of the Interior indicates that among the 10 biggest complaints of the general public, several are related to public safety and police work, rampant telephone and Internet scams, the high number of traffic tickets issued and illegal occupation of public pathways.
The NPA is also hopeful that the public will also post stories about good deeds done by policemen in addition to using the site as a space to voice their complaints, according to the spokesman.

The spokesman also reminded the public that the forum is different from the 110 police service phone number and that reports of suspected criminal activities should be made by calling 110 rather than by posting on the Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins three silver medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:43:33 (By Oscar Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan took three silver medals in taekwondo at the 2009 East Asian Games in Hong Kong Tuesday, the final day of the taekwondo events.

Chuan Chia-chia, in the women's 72 kg category, won silver after being edged out by her South Korean rival for the gold in a close fight that ended 4-5, while Sun Ai-chi, in the women's over 72 kg category, also took silver in a 4-5 defeat to her South Korean challenger.
Wu Ming-chieh won silver the men's over 84 kg category after being defeated 5-6 by a South Korean opponent.

The three silvers added to the medal tally of the Chinese Taipei team brought the total to two gold medals, nine silvers and five bronzes in taekwondo as of that afternoon -- a performance on par with an earlier forecast by Taiwan's sports authorities.

Chinese Taipei coach Liu Ching-wen said he was satisfied with his team's performance in the taekwondo events but commented that it would have performed better if the athletes had more experience. South Korea dominated the taekwondo events at the fifth East Asian Games, having taken six gold medals on Tuesday alone for a total of 13 taekwondo golds, ahead of Taiwan's two golds and China's single gold medal.
Taiwan won its first gold of the Sunday when taekwondo athlete Hsu Chia-lin, fighting in the 54 kg category, defeated his South Korean opponent. It was also Hsu's first gold.
Nine countries and areas are participating in the 2009 East Asian Games that formally opened Dec. 5 and will run through Dec. 13. Taiwan has sent 239 athletes to the games.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to review election responsibilities: KMT officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:57:56 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will make an election review report at the regular weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee Wednesday, party officials revealed after an initial review meeting Tuesday.
President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as party chairman, will also review his responsibility for the party's "unsatisfactory results, " the officials added.

Ma himself chaired Tuesday's meeting, during which party members reviewed the factors affecting the election, including the administration's performance, campaign effectiveness, the party nomination system and the economic environment in general, according to KMT spokesman Lee chien-jung.

He said Ma clarified his statement after the elections regarding the economic environment, saying that he was not blaming the unfavorable economic environment but was rather stressing the responsibility of the KMT to take the initiative in improving the economic environment.

Lee also quoted Ma as saying that the party is determined to discipline candidates found guilty of vote-buying and that he might apologize to the public for vote-buying by some KMT candidates and a shooting incident involving a failed KMT candidate in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical students march to highlight AIDS-related rights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 19:21:39 (By L. T. Chen and Flor Wang)

In fact, since the free fall of Ma's immense popularity in the wake of Typhoon Morakot in August, his decision-making style has been called into serious question.

The government has seemed to have its hands tied on some policies that it should have promoted actively because of fears of public opposition. On other controversial issues, such as the easing of U.S. beef imports, it made the decision behind closed doors.
It is not unexpected that Ma would plunge himself in such a miserable plight. The criticism of Ma as being "arrogant" has been demonstrated by this decision- making style.

The voters have sent a warning signal to the Ma administration, but they have left some leeway to make adjustments and revisions. President should seize the opportunity to learn his lesson. ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS: The KMT loses all because of Ma Ying-jeou

Although the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) managed to keep 12 out of 17 seats up for grabs in Saturday's mayoral and magistrate election, the number of votes it received fell dramatically compared to the 2008 presidential election.
In a lot of cities and counties, the KMT candidates even faced serious challenges from their lesser-known and hastily nominated rivals from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The DPP candidates therefore targeted their attacks at President Ma and his major policy initiatives. President Ma also embarked on a hectic campaign for KMT candidates.
After the election results were in, all fingers, irrespective of their party affiliation, have pointed at Ma.

Ma cited the global financial crisis and high unemployment as factors not favorable to the KMT, but his biggest shortcoming identified by critics has been his failure to concede defeat and to shoulder its responsibility.
We believe that Ma should not shirk his responsibility: the flawed nomination mechanism and the poorly organized campaigning all contributed to the lackluster showing.
We think an economic downturn provides an able leader an opportunity to govern the country. But for more than one year, Ma has failed to come up with substantive measures to stimulate the economy.
Lastly, although Ma is known for his integrity, he has not been known for good governance and use of able men.

The most gratifying news after the elections is that he has finally decided to curtail his hectic itinerary for the time being to reflect quietly on his next step. LIBERTY TIMES: Does Ma want people to suffer as a result of his misguided policies?
Taiwan voters taught President Ma Ying-jeou a lesson in the Dec. 5 local elections.
Most people in Taiwan and international media agreed that Ma has encountered the most serious setback in his political career.
We believe his policy direction and governing ability have been disapproved by the Taiwan people.

But Ma has deliberately tried to ignore that message and has tried to blame his party's less-than-ideal showing in the elections on the global economic downturn. We are worried that he would continue on his present course and lead Taiwan to destruction in the remaining two years of his term.
Everyone knows that the failure of the Ma administration is due to two major reasons: the record high unemployment rate that resulted from the economic downturn and his China-leaning policies.

Based on his remarks after the elections, it is obvious that Ma is not going to change his China-leaning course. However, we think that he should abandon that direction in order to avoid being dealt a more serious blow in future elections. APPLE DAILY: Stumping vs. anti-stumping

Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung and Legislator Chiu Yi of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) blasted central government officials Monday for failing to stump for KMT candidates in the just-concluded local elections.
They asked rhetorically whether the officials would have had the chance to serve in the central government if they had not campaigned hard in the 2008 legislative and presidential elections.

But Premier Wu Den-yih and Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah responded by saying that officials should maintain administrative neutrality and stick to carrying out their own duties, which they said are the best way to stump for KMT candidates.

Both Wu and Jiang have a point. The duty of the Interior Ministry and the Justice Ministry is to crack down on vote-buying and maintain order during elections. If the ministers go on stage to canvass support from voters, they will give the impression of being both players and umpires.

Moreover, the officials have no election experience and in the fever-pitch of campaign rallies, are apt to make gaffes that could invite invective instead of support. They are therefore better off not appearing on any campaign tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's semiconductor output expected to rise in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 20:27:49 (By Chou Pin-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's semiconductor sector is expected to post a 17.8 percent growth in 2010 as the sector continues to recover from the global recession, the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) forecast Tuesday.

With the sector having begun to see a recovery in the second quarter of 2009, the contraction in output has been narrowing and is projected to stand at 8.1 percent for the whole year, according to Tan Yu-hua, a research manager at the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center (IEK).

The figure is lower than the projected decline of 11.5 percent in the global market, Tan said in a seminar on the prospects for the high tech sector in 2010 that was held by the ITRI and the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The sector's global value is expected to increase 12.2 percent next year, bringing it back to the level of 2008, he added.

Lee Kuan-hua, an industry analyst at IEK, predicted that the production value of Taiwan's IC design industry, which is projected to increase 3.1 percent in 2009, will further expand by 16.4 percent in 2010.

According to Lee, the global status of the country's IC design industry has been rising in recent years, with Taiwanese firms accounting for 18.4 percent of the world's 20 largest IC designers in 2008, up from 14.1 percent in 2001.

The rise of the low-price market, the demand for green energy and new applications within the medical care sector will pose both challenges and opportunities for Taiwan's IC design industry, he went on.

To expand the market for its IC products, Taiwan should seek to cooperate with China in adopting a set of shared standards for mobile telecommunications, digital radio, wireless networking, automobile electronics and medical electronics, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Education Ministry to hold seminars to explain policies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/09 20:46:23 (By K.Y. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) will hold 17 seminars around Taiwan Dec. 10-23 to explain the government's plan to recognize Chinese universities and open local tertiary education institutes to Chinese college students amid concern in some quarters that doing so could jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty and job market.

Liao Kao-shien, director of the MOE's Higher Education Department, said the ministry decided to explain the two issues to the public face to face in the seminars, with the first one to kick off in Kaohsiung City and the last one to be held in Taipei City.

According to Liao, the ministry is planning to gradually recognize diplomas issued by over 100 elite Chinese universities in three stages -- 41 top Chinese universities in the first stage, 55 in the second stage and an as-yet undecided number in the third stage. Police and military higher education institutes will be excluded.

In addition, he said, the MOE is projecting to make the policy retroactive to 1997, but will continue to heed public opinions in this regard, as there are strong local fears that the measure might affect the local job market.
The MOE has initially decided that Chinese graduates must leave Taiwan within a month of completing their studies and will not be permitted to find work in Taiwan.

In terms of the maximum number of Chinese students allowed to pursue higher and advanced studies in Taiwan, the MOE said that the number will be around 1 percent of the total number of every year's freshman intake -- about 2,000 per year. Each university will be authorized to have a maximum 2 percent of Chinese students enrolled at any one time.
The MOE plans to allow Chinese graduate students to pursue master's courses at public universities, while private universities will be permitted to enroll undergraduates.

Because of the ferry services established between the Taiwanese islands of Kinmen and Matsu and two ports in China's Fujian Province, the quota of Chinese students opting to study at colleges or universities on the two outlying islands might be larger, depending on the applications from each school, Liao said.
In principle, Chinese college or graduate students will be permitted to stay in Taiwan proper for up to two years, with exceptions to be studied on a case-by- case basis, he added.
While in Taiwan, Chinese students will not be entitled to work, while their visas will be issued in accordance with the rules governing foreign or overseas Chinese students.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will open market further to Chinese capital: former minister
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 21:01:34 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will open its market further to Chinese capital, following three principles, namely going "from restricted to loosened, step by step, and expanding after certain results have been achieved", Chen Jui-lung, chairman of the Taipei-based Sinocon Industrial Standards Foundation and a former economics minister, said in Beijing Tuesday.

Chen made the remarks at the opening of a forum on cross-strait cooperation that was jointly sponsored by the foundation and the Beijing- based Association of Economy and Trade Across the Taiwan Straits.

Chen told the attendees that Taiwan manufacturers played an important role in the supply of key components to China's electrical appliance industry during China's implementation of a nationwide household appliance renovation project earlier this year. The measure was introduced during the world financial crisis with the aim of boosting China's economy through the expansion of domestic consumption.

In addition, Chen said, the financial sectors on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are expected to enter a new stage of cooperation with the signing of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between their monetary supervisory agencies.

With the inking of the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Taiwan's monetary sector would be able to access the mainland Chinese market, and industries on both sides would benefit from cross-strait monetary cooperation, he added.

As to the entry of Chinese capital into the Taiwan market, Chen said that Taiwan plans to open its market to Chinese capital under the guidelines of going "from restricted to loosened, step by step, and expanding after certain results have been achieved".

As of the end of October, Taiwan had opened 64 categories of manufacturing industries, 117 categories of service industries, and 11 categories of public construction projects to Chinese investment. Meanwhile, 15 Chinese investment applications had been approved by Taiwan authorities up to that time.

Chen said that investors in Taiwan can enjoy the advantages of expertise in innovation and global marketing. In the future, businesses on both sides of the Taiwan Strait would be able to advance their cooperation in areas such as research and development, building brand names, reciprocal investments and shared marketing channels, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businesses, workers split on ECFA impact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 21:31:27 (Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Local businesses and workers are split on the possible impact of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) on Taiwan's economy, with workers tending to be more pessimistic than businesses, according to the results of two surveys released Tuesday by an online employment broker.

The surveys by 104 Job Bank found that 38.2 percent of the business owners that responded think the agreement will bring "more opportunities than threats, " while 34.5 percent believe there will be "more threats than opportunities."
Among the workers surveyed, however, 44.4 percent said the pact will bring "more threats than opportunities, " compared with 29.9 percent who think the opposite.

Approximately 30 percent of the business owners believe the signing of the ECFA will stimulate young people in Taiwan and China into enhancing their competitiveness, boost Taiwan's economic development, attract foreign investment and strengthen cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Slightly more than 85 percent of them said they are confident in their ability to face the challenges.

Although 56.6 percent of the workers surveyed said the ECFA can help promote Taiwan's economic development, 62.7 percent expressed concern that the agreement will lead to the dumping of cheap Chinese products in Taiwan.

Another 58.7 percent said there could be a decrease in jobs and approximately 40 percent expressed fear of transfer of local capital and technologies to China and of a larger exodus of Taiwanese businesses.
The survey of 1,988 workers was conducted Nov. 10-15, with a margin of error of plus or minus 2.2 percentage points.
The survey of 629 businesses was carried out Nov. 10-16 and had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.91 percentage points.
