DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung postpones amphibious vehicle tours to next March
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:10:23 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The date of the official launch of amphibious vehicle tours in the southern city of Kaohsiung has been put back to March 2, 2010, a city official said Tuesday.
The postponement has been made to allow more time for test runs of the vehicle to ensure passenger safety, according to Wang Kwo-tsai, director-general of the city's Transportation Bureau.
The city government had originally planned to begin test runs in early December and to officially launch the service in January.

Under a new plan worked out by the city government, the first phase of the test runs will begin Dec. 20 and continue through Jan. 21, during which water tours will be provided to social welfare and tour groups interested in trying the service, Wang said.
In the second phase, which will run from Jan. 22 to Feb. 28, free tickets will be offered to tourists staying in Kaohsiung hotels, he went on.
The tours will start and finish at the Hanshin Arena shopping mall so that passengers can also go shopping, he added.

The 60-minute tours will allow passengers to sightsee on land and water, including a cruise on scenic Lotus Lake and a ride around the surrounding area. There will be six tours per day for a maximum of 30 passengers per tour.
Ticket prices will be NT$300 for adults and NT$150 for children.

DOC.HEADLINE: National Police Agency Web site welcomes public opinion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:12:15 (By Lin Sheng-hsu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The National Police Agency (NPA) has set up a special "civic forum" corner on its official Web site www.npa.gov.tw, on which members of the public are encouraged to leave comments about the police and their work, a spokesman for the agency said Tuesday.

A recent survey conducted by the Ministry of the Interior indicates that among the 10 biggest complaints of the general public, several are related to public safety and police work, rampant telephone and Internet scams, the high number of traffic tickets issued and illegal occupation of public pathways.
The NPA is also hopeful that the public will also post stories about good deeds done by policemen in addition to using the site as a space to voice their complaints, according to the spokesman.

The spokesman also reminded the public that the forum is different from the 110 police service phone number and that reports of suspected criminal activities should be made by calling 110 rather than by posting on the Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins three silver medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 7 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:43:33 (By Oscar Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan took three silver medals in taekwondo at the 2009 East Asian Games in Hong Kong Tuesday, the final day of the taekwondo events.

Chuan Chia-chia, in the women's 72 kg category, won silver after being edged out by her South Korean rival for the gold in a close fight that ended 4-5, while Sun Ai-chi, in the women's over 72 kg category, also took silver in a 4-5 defeat to her South Korean challenger.
Wu Ming-chieh won silver the men's over 84 kg category after being defeated 5-6 by a South Korean opponent.

The three silvers added to the medal tally of the Chinese Taipei team brought the total to two gold medals, nine silvers and five bronzes in taekwondo as of that afternoon -- a performance on par with an earlier forecast by Taiwan's sports authorities.

Chinese Taipei coach Liu Ching-wen said he was satisfied with his team's performance in the taekwondo events but commented that it would have performed better if the athletes had more experience. South Korea dominated the taekwondo events at the fifth East Asian Games, having taken six gold medals on Tuesday alone for a total of 13 taekwondo golds, ahead of Taiwan's two golds and China's single gold medal.
Taiwan won its first gold of the Sunday when taekwondo athlete Hsu Chia-lin, fighting in the 54 kg category, defeated his South Korean opponent. It was also Hsu's first gold.
Nine countries and areas are participating in the 2009 East Asian Games that formally opened Dec. 5 and will run through Dec. 13. Taiwan has sent 239 athletes to the games.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to review election responsibilities: KMT officials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 8 (CNA) 12/08/09 22:57:56 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will make an election review report at the regular weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee Wednesday, party officials revealed after an initial review meeting Tuesday.
President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as party chairman, will also review his responsibility for the party's "unsatisfactory results, " the officials added.

Ma himself chaired Tuesday's meeting, during which party members reviewed the factors affecting the election, including the administration's performance, campaign effectiveness, the party nomination system and the economic environment in general, according to KMT spokesman Lee chien-jung.

He said Ma clarified his statement after the elections regarding the economic environment, saying that he was not blaming the unfavorable economic environment but was rather stressing the responsibility of the KMT to take the initiative in improving the economic environment.

Lee also quoted Ma as saying that the party is determined to discipline candidates found guilty of vote-buying and that he might apologize to the public for vote-buying by some KMT candidates and a shooting incident involving a failed KMT candidate in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 9, or the 23rd day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1608: British poet John Milton, writer of "Paradise Lost," is born in London.
1824: Simon Bolivar's forces defeat the Spanish army at Ayacucho, Peru.
1905: France decrees the separation of church and state.
1908: Germany's Bundestag passes the Child-Labor Act, prohibiting the employment of children under the age of 13 years.
1930: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of the Nationalist government, convenes a military meeting in Nanchang, in China's Kiangsi Province, to begin an anti- communist campaign.
1935: Students demonstrate in Beijing to protest against the Japanese invasion of northern China and urge unity to save the nation.
1940: The British 8th Army, better known as the Desert Rats, begin an offensive against Germany's Afrikakorps in North Africa.
1941: China formally declares war on Japan, Germany and Italy.
1949: The Executive Yuan of the Republic of China holds its first meeting after moving its office to Taipei.
1961: Tanganyika declares independence.
1965: The United States provides F-5A Fighters to the ROC.
1972: The Soviet Union and North Vietnam reach an accord on military and economic aid to Hanoi.
1974: Col. Manuel Alfonso Rodriguez, chief of the general staff of the Republic of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1974: Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki forms a new Cabinet.
1974: Sheikh Ibrahim Al-Sultan, deputy minister of Foreign Affairs of Saudi Arabia, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: Hammer De Roburt, president of the Republic of Nauru, arrives in Taipei to preside over a ceremony marking the opening of flight services between Taiwan and Nauru.
1975: U.S. Assistant Secretary of State Phillip Habib arrives in Taipei to brief the ROC government on President Gerald Ford's visit to the Chinese mainland. Habib reiterates America's policy of maintaining friendly relations with the ROC.
1976: The U.N. General Assembly calls for a Middle East peace conference in Geneva with the Palestine Liberation Organization participating.
1976: W.W. Kethan, president of the International Softball Federation, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1986: The Legislative Yuan of the ROC passes a new income tax regulation raising the income tax deduction for each dependent to NT$30,000.
1986: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Nobutaka Shikanai, president of Japan's Sankei Shimbun.
1987: Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meets with U.S. President Ronald Reagan in Washington after the signing of the U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms treaty.
1990: Lech Walesa, head of Solidarity, an organization advocating free trade unions, is elected president of the Republic of Poland.
1991: Gorbachev calls the newly formed Commonwealth of Independent States illegal and dangerous.
1992: Britain's Prince Charles and Princess Diana announce they are separating but have no plans to divorce.
1996: The military government closes universities as police chase protesting students through the streets of Rangoon, Burma.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives Rotary International President Larlo Ravizza and former Rotary presidents Mat Caparas and Glen W. Kinross at the Presidential Office.
2000: Professor Reuben Jih-ru Hwu of National Tsinghua University is selected a fellow of the Third World Academy of Sciences (TWAS) for his outstanding achievements in chemistry studies.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When directing the affairs of a great nation, a man must be serious in attending to business and faithful and punctual in his engagements. He must study economy in the public expenditure, and love the welfare of the people. He must employ the people at the proper time of the year."

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- News digest of local media: greenhouse gases
DOC.DATELINE: 12/09/09 11:15:20 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's reaction to the new U.S. policy on regulating greenhouse gas emissions is generally positive. While Taiwan is likely to follow suit in controlling sources of air pollution, it may also exercise caution in order to mitigate impact to the industry.
The following is a digest of some local media reports about this issue:
United Daily News:

With the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency classifying six greenhouse gases -- carbon dioxide along with methane, nitrous oxide, hydrofluorocarbons, perfluorocarbons and sulfur hexaflouride -- as public health threats under the U.S. Clean Air Act., a Taiwan official said the government is very likely to follow suit, taking measures to restrict emissions of the six air pollution sources.

Hsieh Yen-ju, director-general of the Environmental Protection Administration's (EPA) Department of Air Quality Protection and Noise Control, said Tuesday that the government's first move would likely include the six greenhouse gases in the regulations on air pollution control concerning pollutant gas emissions by motor vehicles. (Dec. 9, 2009)
China Times:

Director General Tu Tzi-chun of the Industrial Development Bureau said Tuesday that there is no need for Taiwan to be the world's "role model" in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, or the world's guinea pig.
Although the agencies in charge of industrial development affairs support the reduction, Taiwan will only take action in synchronization with other countries, he said. (Dec. 9, 2009)
Commercial Times:

Although it has been a global trend to develop and use "green energy, " Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday that Taiwan "will not impose" an energy tax before it works out complete measures in conjunction with the taxation.

Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der explained that the purpose is not to raise taxes, but make an adjustment to the country's energy policy to meet the goal of saving energy and cutting carbon emissions. (Dec. 9, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: beef controversy

TEXT.P: The controversy surrounding Taiwan's relaxation on U.S. beef imports has again come to the fore following the end of last Saturday's local elections, with civic groups submitting signatures to the Central Election Commission calling for a national referendum on whether to re-negotiate U.S. beef trade terms.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest development of the controversy:
China Times:

The usually good-natured Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng became angry Tuesday after the legislature was paralyzed again due to a boycott by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over U.S. beef disputes.
Wang said in a tough tone that the DPP's besieging of the speaker's podium "is very, very inappropriate" and that it "should stop where it should."
"The DPP seems to want to do what it likes to do, which is utterly senseless," he said. (Dec. 9, 2009)
United Daily:
Civic groups submitted signatures to the Central Election Commission Tuesday in its effort to initiate a national referendum on restarting beef talks with the United States.

Commenting on the move of the civic groups, the Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang said he will respect the people exercising their civic rights and if the referendum passes, the department will act according to the law. (Dec. 9, 2009)
Liberty Times:

If the outcome of Saturday's local elections is the first no-confidence vote on the Ma administration, then the signatures sent to the Central Election Commission to initiate a national referendum on opposing U.S. beef imports is obviously the second no-confidence vote on the Ma administration.

The Dec. 5 elections were a rivalry between the ruling and the opposition parties. But the call for a restart of talks with the U.S. will be a big policy debate that transcends party rivalry and is a more significant event. (Dec. 9, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese volunteer finds fulfillment in helping Karen refugees
DOC.DATELINE: 12/09/09 12:19:15 (with reporting by S. C. Wu)

TEXT.P: The quietly flowing Moei River, which forms part of the border between Thailand and Myanmar, can be seen as a metaphor for the silent anguish of the Karen refugees in Thailand who fled human rights abuses, violence and desperate economic conditions in Myanmar.

For more than 60 years, Myanmar's largest ethnic group, the Karen, has been seeking greater autonomy in their homeland, which is also known as Burma -- a quest that has fueled one of the longest running internal conflicts in the world.
Karen refugees began crossing into Thailand in 1984 and the Thai military started setting up refugee camps along the border about 20 years ago.
In most of their accounts to the United Nations, the refugees speak of direct attacks by the Myanmar army, forced labor, enslavement, and destruction of their homes and crops.
There are now around 140,000 Myanmar refugees in Thailand, living in nine fenced camps along the border between the two countries.
The largest camp is Mae La, which sits on a hill about 60 kilometers north of the border town of Mae Sot.
Sam Lai, 36, often sits on this hill pondering the future of the camp's 43,000 refugees, especially the children.

Lai is a volunteer with the non-governmental Taipei Overseas Peace Service (TOPS) , and the only one from the organization who is stationed in Mae Sot, where he has worked for seven years in collaboration with local and international organizations.

"It is deplorable that the Karen refugees are now stateless, have lost their freedom and have no legal identity or protection within Thailand," Lai said. "It is hard for people outside to imagine what life is like within the highly restricted refugee camps."
Since 1996, TOPS has been administering humanitarian and educational programs at Karen refugee camps and in Myanmar migrant communities in remote Thai villages.
"What we do is to help the refugees improve their lives, and in particular, we seek to help the children avoid the harrowing experiences of their parents," Lai said.
The children's education is an issue of great concern, according to Lai. At Mae La alone, TOPS runs more than 20 day-care centers as 38 percent of the Karen children there are of kindergarten age.
"Most children who are growing up in refugee camps do not have the slightest idea of what constitutes a normal life," Lai said.

Every week, Lai visits each of the camps in Mae Sot, driving seven to eight hours along the rugged mountain roads. He often spends the night at one of the camps to better assess the needs of the refugees.

"Sometimes I do get tired and frustrated, but I have discovered that my discomforts are nothing compared to the suffering of the displaced Karen refugees whose dreams of going home might never be realized," he said.

A major part of TOPS mission in Thailand is to help run schools for migrant Karen children in remote Thai villages. The schools built on the hillsides are open-sided thatched huts made of bamboo, but according to Lai, they are five- star havens to the Karen children who long to learn.

These crude structures collapse easily during the rainy season from May to November. This year, some of them have not been rebuilt because of tighter financing since the global economic crisis broke, Lai said.
Despite the challenges, Lai and others like him do their best to bring 21st century education to the refugee children.

Taiwanese Chang Lee-an has been engaged in this effort since 2005 when he and Lai first met in Thailand. Chang, then a student in the Department of Information and Computer Engineering at Chung Yuan Christian University in Taiwan, began to collect computer equipment after he returned to Taiwan that year from his summer break.

He went back to Thailand in the summer of 2006 with the equipment to teach Karen children at Mae Sot camps how to use computers. Taking his efforts one step further, Chang established the Youth E-Service, Taiwan in January 2007 to foster youth voluntarism.

"It is good that Taiwan's college students are willing to do volunteer work during the summer and winter breaks, " Lai said. This allows them to gain useful hands-on experience and gives them an opportunity to better understand the rest of the world."
The program is also aimed at fostering interaction among youth through the development of digital learning, he said.
According to Lai, it takes many years of devoted work to make any significant difference.

"Humanitarian assistance is a long-term commitment and it requires professional knowledge, patience and a deep understanding of the problems. But Taiwanese tend to be more keen on short-term work," he said.
One of exceptions is Lin Liang-shu who has been volunteering at Karen refugee camps along the Thai-Myanmar border for many years. Lin first became involved in the work 20 years ago, when she was 25.
She has now made Mae Sot her home and, along with friends in the area, has set up the "Tak Border Child Association Foundation" to help refugee children.
For volunteers like Lin and Lai, it is not only about helping others, but also about self-discovery and development.

Lai said that through his interaction with the Karen refugees, he has learned to shed prejudices, to share his thoughts and emotions openly, and to find strength even in the most desperate situations.

"This work has also helped me to know myself better and to find ways of serving my own homeland, " he said. "I've discovered my own weak points, most of which derived from the easy life I had when I was growing up."
Nonetheless, after seven years of service in the camps, Lai has decided to quit his work with TOPS by the end of this year.
He thinks that the search for life's meaning is a matter of giving one's self a chance to explore, and that happiness means choosing the thing that one wants most to do.
"I would like to slow down and reexamine my life, but humanitarian concerns -- particularly the future of Karen refugee children -- will remain a lifelong passion of mine," he said. Enditem/ pc

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 3 (CNA) 12/09/09 15:38:11 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 28.71 points, or 0.36 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,797.42.
The local bourse opened at 7,747.6 and traded within a fairly narrow range, hitting a low of 7,742.92 during the session.
A total of 4.52 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$136.87 billion (US$4.24 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 3.17 percent. Construction issues increased 0.76 percent, textile stocks advanced 0.63 percent, machinery and electronics shares rose 0.56 percent, cement stocks were up 0.37 percent, and foodstuff issues increased 0.2 percent.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with banking and financial shares decreasing 0.08 percent and plastics and chemicals shares dropping 0.04 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,327 to 1,233, with 288 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$1.16 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-ASEAN free trade deal always a possibility, says scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Bogor, Indonesia, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 15:38:20 (By Ho Hung-ju and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The stable development of Taiwan's economic ties with China is good news for the region and could make it easier for Taiwan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to sign a free trade agreement (FTA), an Indonesian scholar said Wednesday.

Dewi Fortuna Anwar, the program and research director at Indonesian think tank The Habibie Center, said she hoped improved China-ASEAN and China-Taiwan relations would ease Beijing's sensitivity toward stronger economic relations between Taiwan and ASEAN.

Anwar would not comment directly on the potential impact of a proposed cross- Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) on free trade deals between Taiwan and other countries because she was not familiar with the ECFA. But she said "the possibility always exists" for a free trade pact between Taiwan and ASEAN.
"Taiwan is a member of the WTO and APEC. An FTA is an economic issue, not a political one, that depends on the two parties' interests," she said. "I don't see any serious obstacles."

Anwar was speaking in an interview with CNA in Bogor, where the center held a forum on "Taiwan-Indonesian Dialogue" Dec. 7-8 along with the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta, Taiwan's de facto embassy. It was the second event jointly organized by the two organizations since 2007.
Participants were divided into four groups to discuss political, economic, social and cultural, and non-traditional security issues.

Huang Kuei-po, head of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) Research and Planning Committee, said at the forum's closing session that it was meaningful for the two sides to be able to work out joint strategies to resolve regional challenges facing both countries.
As civil exchanges can be helpful in achieving the goal, he hopes the two nations will begin bilateral cooperation and exchanges based on the conclusions of the dialogue, Huang added.
According to the Habibie Center, a complete report of the conclusions will be published in January, which will be presented to the Indonesian government and congress as a policy reference.

Although Taiwan and Indonesia do not have diplomatic ties, economic ties are growing. According to Taiwan's customs statistics, bilateral trade grew at an annual rate of 25.51 percent in 2008 to reach US$10.92 billion.
Indonesia is the ninth largest source of Taiwan's imports and Taiwan's 14th largest export market.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH hopes to hike health insurance premium rates within six months
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 16:28:15 (By Chen Li-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's top health official expressed the hope Wednesday that health insurance premium rates would be hiked within six months to help solve the financial shortfalls of Taiwan's National Health Insurance system.

In an interview on a local radio station Wednesday, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang reiterated the need for higher premium rates but said other measures to cut costs and increase revenues were being considered.
Prior to the Dec. 5 local elections, Yaung argued that a premium rate hike was necessary but denied that there was a timetable for the move.

He said then that the rate, currently set at 4.55 percent of monthly salaries with a ceiling of NT$131,700, is far lower than what he described as the "reasonable rate" of 6.97 percent and warned that if the low premium remained unchanged, the universal health insurance system will go bankrupt in 10 years.
Those comments led some legislators of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to blame him for the party's poor showing in the Dec. 5 local elections.
Yaung on Wednesday said he respected their opinion and acknowledged that it was "bad timing" to talk about hiking premium rates before the elections.

Since the situation occurred, he said he would take "general responsibility" for it, but Yaung did not back down on his advocacy of hiking premium rates, especially as Taiwan's population continues to age.

The DOH minister said the system's financial woes could be partly attributed to the graying of the population. There are 30 percent more senior citizens in Taiwan than a decade ago, he noted, and their medical expenses per person average 3.3 times more than younger citizens.
Rising health care expenses that now average about US$1,000 per person per year have also taken their toll on the health system's finances.

Concerned about the sustainability of the system, Yaung said the economically disadvantaged would suffer the most if the program was forced to shut down because the wealthy could afford private insurance alternatives.

On the timing of adjusting the health insurance premium, Yaung said he hopes to accomplish it "within six months" and will do all he can to make it happen, though other measures were under consideration to ease the burden of rate hikes on the poor.
"The ultimate goal is for economically disadvantaged groups to pay less but enjoy the same health care protection as those who can afford insurance and help to pay more," he said.
Yaung also said he will actively call on legislators to convince them that a rate hike is necessary.
According to Yaung, the health insurance program's accumulated deficit will reach NT$50 billion by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improved cross-strait ties enhance Taiwan-U.S.-China ties: ex-rep.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 17:07:35 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The improvement in relations across the Taiwan Strait over the past year has contributed to the unprecedented healthy development in U.S.-Taiwan-China ties, a former foreign affairs minister and Taiwan representative to the United States said Wednesday.

Today, any two sides of the triangular relationship are hoping to enhance and strengthen their relations with each other, which is a situation that has never been seen before, observed Chen Chien-jen in a discussion co-sponsored by the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei.

According to Chen, the most crucial factor in this development has been the effort made by President Ma Ying-jeou since his inauguration in May 2008 to adjust Taiwan's cross-strait and foreign policies, which helped mend relations with China and rebuild trust with the United States.

He reminded the Ma administration, however, of the importance of internal communication in dealing with cross-strait and foreign relations issues. Without such communication, the endeavor would be like a three-legged stool with one leg missing, which could hardly stand, he argued.

The discussion held at the American Chamber of Commerce was part of the third annual China Town Hall, a U.S. nationwide webcast program presented by the New York-based National Committee on United States-China Relations.
This year's program featured Kurt Campbell, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, and speakers from 39 venues in the United States, China, Hong Kong and Taiwan.

Commenting on U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to China in November, Chen said the trip was a successful one because it showed the importance attached by Washington to China's rise and recognized China's important position in the world order.

Also, demonstrating a style and philosophy that are totally different from his predecessor George W. Bush, Obama has ruled out zero-sum games and unilateralism in dealing with China and has focused on how to expand bilateral cooperation, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NCC rejects Next Media's applications for two TV channels
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 17:13:49 (By Amy Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The National Communications Commission (NCC) rejected Next Media's applications to establish general information and news TV channels during a review Wednesday.

The decision was made because the company's presentation of news using lurid and sensationalist graphic animation does not conform with the principle that news should reflect the real facts, said NCC spokesman Chen Cheng-tsang.

The provisions of Article 5 of the Basic Communications Act stipulate that media content providers should produce and broadcast programs that safeguard human dignity, respect the rights of the socially disadvantaged and promote diversified and balanced cultural development.
Judging from news samples provided by the company, it is apparently in violation of the regulations, particularly as regards safeguarding human dignity, Chen added.
The commission said that all news reporting should be classified under the general category rather than being classified into restricted and parental guidance categories.
Chen Yu-hsin, editor-in-chief of Next Media's TV news department, said the company would respond until it had received official notification of the application rejections.
In addition to the two TV channels, Next Media Group has also filed applications to establish sports, entertainment and movie channel.
The NCC suspended screening of the applications for three channels and demanded that the company provide more details about its overall plans.

NCC members said Next Media had yet to clarify whether the entertainment and sports news to be broadcast on its TV channels will be presented using graphic animation techniques, according to the spokesman.
Next Media sparked a public outcry after its Apple Daily launched graphic animation online news services featuring explicit reconstructions of criminal acts, including sexual assaults and murders.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma apologizes for KMT candidates' involvement in vote-buying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 17:56:42 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou apologized to the public Wednesday in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) for some of the party candidates' alleged involvement in vote-buying and violence in last Saturday's local elections.
Ma also apologized to KMT supporters for the party's less-than-ideal showing in the elections for mayors, magistrates, councilors and township chiefs in 17 of Taiwan's cities and counties.

In a post-election review statement delivered at a weekly meeting of the party's decision-making Central Standing Committee, Ma said he is the one who should assume full responsibility for the party's latest election setback.
The KMT lost two magistrate seats -- Yilan and Hualien counties -- that it had held previous to the elections. The party also saw its vote share declined in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei 101 announces first New Year's Eve party
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:01:44 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New Year's Eve partiers who want to enjoy the spectacular fireworks show at Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest skyscrapers -- at close range will now have a chance to do so, a Taipei 101 official said Wednesday.
Liu Chia-hao, assistant vice president of the Taipei Financial Center Corp., which owns the building, announced the New Year's Eve party at the landmark building, the first of its kind.
Liu said guests will have the unforgettable experience of witnessing 22,000 rounds of fireworks shooting into the night sky, while enjoying live music and gourmet food and wine.
He said the fireworks display -- now in its sixth year -- has become an international event that has boosted sales in shops in the vicinity every year.

He noted that Taipei 101 last year allowed people to watch the fireworks from the observation deck on the 89th floor, with the 1,200 available tickets sold out quickly. "This is why we have decided to cooperate with Lions Travel to hold a party this year, " Liu said, adding that New Year's Eve parties are now "in vogue" and that people often have difficulty finding good party venues.
Taipei 101 will not rule out the possibility of renting spare space to private companies for New Year's Eve parties in the future, he went on.

Liu said earlier that NT$30 million will be spent on this year's 188-second fireworks show -- NT$10 million more than last year -- in response to complaints by revelers that the 2009 event was not exciting enough.
Some 22,000 fireworks will be launched, the most ever and 6,600 more than last year, Liu said.
In addition, he added, the angles covered by the 2010 show will be the widest in history, with fireworks to be launched at 180 degrees, 90 degrees, 45 degrees and 30 degrees.
Liu Wen-yi, president of Lions Travel, said that of the 1,000 tickets available for individuals this year, half have already been sold.

DOC.HEADLINE: Newspaper denounced for inaccurate report on cross-strait norms
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:17:56 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) strongly denounced a local newspaper Wednesday for inaccurately reporting officials' remarks concerning a planned cross-Taiwan Strait agreement on standards, inspection and certification.

The Liberty Times reported in a front page story Wednesday that a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official had "confirmed" that an agreement between Taiwan and China on setting up common industrial standards was reached with a "one-China market" in mind.
But Lu Chang-shuei, the MAC official responsible for public affairs and parliamentary liaison, said Wednesday that the newspaper got it wrong.

He said that when a Liberty Times reporter asked at a press conference Tuesday whether establishing common industrial standards was a "one-China market" concept, both MOEA Vice Minister Lin Sheng-chung and Chen Jay-san, director- general of the MOEA's Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, clearly replied that it was not related to a one-China market and did not have any political meaning.

The newspaper's lead headline and story said, however, that the officials' slip of the tongue on the planned standards agreement revealed the Kuomintang government's ulterior motive of forming a "one-China" market and described it as a "special standard" between the two sides of the strait.
Lu denounced the report as smearing the government's policy and efforts to promote the globalization of Taiwan's standards system.

He said that Lin had explained at the press conference that thanks to their strong technological research and development capability, some of Taiwan's industries had already gained a competitive edge internationally based and developed their own standards.
"If the mainland adopts Taiwan's standards, they will not only be used on the two sides but will gradually become international standards, " Lin said.

According to Lu, Chen insisted Tuesday that the agreement on common industrial standards, inspection and certification, to be signed in the next round of Taiwan-China talks later this month in Taichung, did not represent a "one-China" market.

Chen said the planned agreement is aimed at allowing domestic manufacturers to produce products based on common cross-strait standards so that the products can be sold in mainland China, Lu explained.
Lu reiterated that the planned agreement is aimed at encouraging domestic factories to make inroads into the mainland market and bring Taiwan's standards to the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's brain truster to serve as KMT secretary-general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:32:32 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Deputy Mayor Chin Pu-tsung, who is widely known as President Ma Ying-jeou's right-hand man during Ma's tenure as Taipei mayor, will be the ruling Kuomintang's new secretary-general, aparty spokesman said Wednesday.
Chin, who is now a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution, a U.S. think tank, will return to Taipei to take up his new post in the next few days, said KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung.
Chin will take over from Chan Chun-po, who is also a KMT vice chairman, as manager of the party's day-to-day affairs.
Chan will retain his position as vice chairman, Lee said.

Lee announced the party's personnel reshuffle decision after the first meeting of the KMT's decision-making Central Standing Committee since last Saturday's local elections in which the KMT suffered a setback.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:46:52 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Wednesday:
CHINA TIMES: Taiwan needs to do more in fight against global warming

The United Nations summit on climate change is ongoing in Copenhagen. While the 12-day conference is not expected to come up with a concrete agreement to replace the Kyoto Protocol, major world powers, such as the United States, China and European Union member states, have promised to cut greenhouse gas emissions.
In the face of this critical issue, Taiwan should not take a hands-off attitude and should instead act quickly to help protect the natural environment as it is crucial to human survival.

Taiwan has so far done little to address the global warming challenge. Relevant government agencies have seldom taken active steps to get to the bottom of the issue. To date, no convincing figures are available for Taiwan's annual carbon dioxide emissions and the annual growth or reduction rates over the past decade.

The government has also not yet come up with any concrete mechanisms to regulate various industries' greenhouse gas emissions nor has it evaluated how many local people could still live on land if sea levels in waters surrounding Taiwan were to rise one meter.

The environmental issues may not be as urgent as many day-to-day public affairs and election campaigns, but they are essential to our country's survival and sustainable growth. The government should be more far-sighted in policy formulation. If the government continues to sit idly, we may lose the battle against global warming. UNITED DAILY NEWS It is more urgent for DPP than KMT to adjust policy toward China

Some pundits have predicted that the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will adjust its policy on cross-Taiwan Strait relations following its recent election setback, which they say reflects to some extent public dissatisfaction with the party's rapprochement with China.
That may be true. But the impact is not as great as that reported by some foreign media outlets.

While we share the view that the KMT should further fine-tune its cross-strait engagement policies and strategies, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has come under even greater pressure to adjust its China policy following its stronger-than-expected showing in last Saturday's elections.

If the electoral gain is a prelude to a DPP return to power, the party will see pressure upon it to change its cross-strait policy increase in direct proportion to the possibility of realization of such a scenario.
Should the DPP return to power, it will not be possible for the party to use its previous radical pro-independence approach to interact with China.

Against this backdrop, the DPP should consider adjusting its stances on major cross-strait issues right now. Perhaps the party could start with revising its attitude toward the KMT administration's plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The DPP should drop its "downright opposition" stance toward the proposal and instead focus on how to amend or reinforce the KMT-drafted version or how to better protect Taiwan's interests once the ECFA deal is struck.

If the DPP could adjust its radical pro-independence policy, it would stand a better chance of staging a comeback. If it fails to do so, a return to power of the party would spell disaster for the country. LIBERTY TIMES Voice opposition to selling out Taiwan

Taiwan's people should stand up and protest the KMT administration's plan to strike a trade deal with China because only a few Taiwanese companies will benefit from such an accord while most other local enterprises stand to lose under market-opening terms in the agreement.

Although Taiwanese voters used their ballots to express their opposition to the Ma administration's China-tilting policy in last Saturday's local elections, the administration has decided to go ahead with its ECFA plan and talks will begin soon.
Covering a broad range of issues, the proposed ECFA agreement will be tantamout to setting norms and rules for future cross-strait commercial exchanges.

Taiwan's people should not keep silent on the issue. Judging from the Ma administration's bowing to U.S. pressure in beef trade talks in October, we should keep a watchful eye on the upcoming cross-strait high-level talks in Taichung later this month.
Tens of thousands of Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises may go bankrupt because of competition from China's state-owned corporations once the ECFA is inked.

With such a threat looming, local people should not be deterred by the Taichung police authorities' plan to confine protest activities to a designated area when Taiwanese and Chinese negotiators meet in the city.
The police's plan will not succeed so long as our people in the street are determined to oppose the KMT administration's move to pander to China at the expense of Taiwan's national interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to protest inclusion in `China Pavilion' at Shanghai expo
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:50:36 (By Chang Ming-kun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will lodge a protest with the organizer of the World Expo 2010 Shanghai for including Taiwan in the "China Pavilion, " as this implies that Taiwan is part of China's territory, an official said Wednesday.

Tsai Wen-kai, director of the Taiwan Trade Center in Shanghai, said the arrangement is in violation of a contract signed between the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) and the Bureau of Shanghai World Expo Coordination, which states that the Taiwan Pavilion will be located in an area of Zone A designated for the national pavilions of Asian countries.
According to the exhibition's master plan posted on its official Web site, Zone A will host the China Pavilion, as well as national pavilions for Asian countries other than those in Southeast Asia.

"The China Pavilion consists of the 47,000-square-meter Chinese national pavilion, a 38,000-square-meter regional joint pavilion and a 3,300-square-meter pavilion for Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan, " the plan stipulates.

In Taipei that same day, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te- shun said that such an arrangement is "definitely not appropriate" and that the MAC supports the TWTC's decision to lodge a protest with the organizer.

Taiwan is participating in the exhibition -- slated to be held May 1-Oct. 31, 2010 -- under the name of the TWTC. Construction work for the four-story Taiwan Pavilion, which will be constructed in the shape of a mountain, began Aug. 17, 2009 and is expected to be completed next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP-leaning groups to stage protests during Chiang-Chen talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Central Taiwan, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 18:56:40 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 10 civic groups in central Taiwan that lean toward the ideologies of the Democratic Progressive Party will organize rallies and marches to demonstrate their position on the upcoming cross-strait negotiations, according to a member of the Central Taiwan Society.

Strait Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chairman Chen Yunlin of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will hold their fourth round cross-strait negotiations in Taichung on Dec. 21-24.

Chiang and Chen are expected to ink four agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Chen Wan-teh, director of the Taichung-based society, said Wednesday that the civic groups have formed the One Taiwan One China 1221 Action Alliance, which will make appeals in the interest of the Taiwan people on matters related to the cross-strait negotiations.

The alliance will appeal for the talks between Taiwan and China be conducted on a nation-to-nation basis, for the contents of the agreements to be reviewed by the legislature, and for decisions involving the rights and welfare of the people to be put to referendum, according to Chen.

Chen said that a mass march and rally will be held on the eve of the Chiang-Chen talks, and a series of demonstrations will be staged in front of 13 railroad stations along the west Taiwan North-South Railway.

DOC.HEADLINE: Peace prevails between Taiwan's offshore bastion and former adversary
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 19:46:54 (By Joe Hung)

TEXT.P: Lt. Col. Alfred Medendorp of the U.S. Army was killed in action on a tiny isle only a few miles from Amoy on September 3, 1954. Chinese shore batteries on what is now better known as Xiamen bombarded Little Quemoy (Little Kinmen) , half the size of its larger neighbor of the same name without that lesser sobriquet.

Colonel Medendorp, originally from the national guard of the state of Michigan, was the first American officer of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group to lay down his life for the defense of Taiwan.

The September 3 artillery duel was a prelude to the Kinmen crisis of 1958, also referred to as the battle of the Taiwan Strait. A monument to the colonel, erected in 1992 while Gen. Hau Pei-tsun was premier, stands testimony to the U.S. determination to keep peace between Taiwan and China.

Hau was commanding general of the Ninth Division deployed on Little Kinmen, called officially Lieyu or Fiery Island, which was bombarded twice as ruthlessly during the battle of the Taiwan Strait, which broke out four years later on August 23.

The September 3 duel caused serious U.S. concern. Capitol Hill gave President Dwight D. Eisenhower authority to use force if necessary to defend Kinmen, a complex comprising fourteen tiny islands, one of them only about two miles off Xiamen, a larger island connected with the mainland of China by railway.

Kinmen is 152 miles from Kaohsiung and 207 miles from Keelung, both on Taiwan. During the battle of the Taiwan Strait, 590 officers and men of the defense force were killed, with 2,200 others wounded and 24 missing in action. At least 80 civilians on the two islands died and 221 others were injured, most of them seriously. One more American colonel was killed on the first day of the crisis.

The casualties were heavy because close to half a million artillery shells rained down on the 131.7 square-kilometer islands in the 44-day bombardment, which failed to pave the way for an invasion from the Chinese mainland. Half of them, 240,460 shells, fell on Little Kinmen. The People's Liberation Army did not make any attempt to land its troops on either of the Kinmens.

On September 26, while the battle of the Taiwan Strait continued to rage, an LVT (landing vehicle tracked) carrying a press contingent capsized off Liolo Bay on Kinmen. Six war correspondents, including one from Japan and another from the Republic of Korea, drowned.

All these servicemen and civilians did not die in vain. Peace has reigned between Kinmen and Xiamen, at first precariously and now expected to last as Taiwan is improving relations with China after eight years of hostile confrontation while President Chen Shui-bian was in office.
"Peace is so lovable," said Lin Ma-teng, a veteran turned amateur historian who is now curator of a cultural museum on Little Kinmen.

Pointing to a northeastern shore of Xiamen Island, about 3.5 miles away from Little Kinmen, Lin said skyscrapers have mushroomed over the past couple of years."The Chinese are enjoying the peace as well," he quipped, "or they wouldn't even try to build anything."

That part of Xiamen is exposed to a Little Kinmen shore battery whose 240mm howitzer can take out any structure and annihilate its occupants if a war breaks out. The tiny isle is dotted with emplacements of similar artillery batteries that can also fire surface-to-surface missiles.

They and the well-trained garrison are combat-ready, not for war but to make sure no hostilities occur by accident. No accident is likely after all tensions across the strait have been removed since May 2008, however.

"That has affected our business, " a souvenir shop owner happily lamented. Hung Chih-ching, who worked as a reporter for the Kinmen Daily newspaper before opening his store, isn't much worried about a fall in his business resulting from a cut in troop strength on the island. He enjoyed a brisk business while there were "many, many more soldiers."
"My business has suffered a bit, " he added, "but I am happy for we do enjoy the peace."

Another storeowner likes the peace better. Hung Song-po sells peanut cake, the best of its kind in China.uMore tourists come, not just from Taiwan and China but from around the world, and they are all good customers,vhe beamed.

The tourist boom, though not as large as was expected, has helped Kinmen sell its world-famous Kaoliang liquor. To an ever-growing number of connoisseurs throughout the world, Kaoliang means a fragrant, tasty and strong spirit like vodka that is made from sorghum, which Kinmen is best suited to grow.

Kinmen Distillery, owned by the county government of Kinmen, chalked up more than NT$18 billion (US$600 million) in sales last year. Kinmen, which means Golden Gate in Chinese, has a population of less than 40,000.

Relatives of Hiroyuki Yasuda, the Tokyo-based Yomiuri Shimbun correspondent killed in the LVT accident, came to Kinmen to witness his being enshrined at the Martyrs' Temple. His fellow Korean reporter, Choi Ping Woo, and four Taiwan war correspondents were honored as well in Kinmen's version of the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

President Ma Ying-jeou took part in a memorial service for them on August 23, 2008 to mark the fiftieth anniversary of the Kinmen crisis. "Let Kinmen turn from a killing field to a peace plaza, "Ma declared.
Kinmen is transforming as such. The monument on Little Kinmen and the enshrining of the six journalists attest a future in which there will be no more war between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: Capital demand huge in China: finance official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 19:54:43 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Demand for capital by Taiwanese businessmen operating in China is assessed at between US$200 billion and US$400 billion, Taiwan's Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean C. Chen said Wednesday, adding that the amount is equivalent to the combined loan energy of "several banks."

Chen made the remarks at a conference on cross-Taiwan Strait financial affairs while speaking about a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on banking supervision cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that was signed Nov. 16.

He said the MOU, which will go into effect Jan. 16, paves the way for allowing Taiwanese banks to open branch offices in China, which can solve the problem of capital demand from Taiwanese businessmen in China.

Chen further said the MOU is seen as important not just by the Taiwanese banking sector but also by those of many other countries, proven by the fact that representatives of at least four leading industrial countries having visited the FSC in the past year to study the progress of the cross-strait MOU.

Meanwhile, Banking Bureau Director-General Chang Ming-daw at the FSC assessed that the eight Taiwanese banks that have already opened representative offices in China could release loans of around NT$16 billion (US$495.94 million) in the early stage of their opening of branch offices, accounting for 0.11 percent of their total assets.

The MOU on cross-strait banking supervision cooperation was formed to facilitate regulatory cooperation across the strait in the fields of information sharing, market entry regulation, crisis management and resolution, as well as personnel exchanges. It is designed for the effective supervision and regulation of the banking financial institutions established across the strait, safeguarding the soundness and safety of the respective banking sectors of the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chain store, franchise industry boosts economy: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 20:02:34 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The chain store and franchise industry has played an important role in Taiwan's economic development, with the sector's revenue reaching NT$1.7 trillion in 2008, or 48 percent of the total revenue of the retail and restaurant industries, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

The sector made a great contribution to the service industry's total production value in 2008, which accounted for 70 percent of the US$391.3 billion in gross domestic product (GDP) that year, Yeh Yun-lung, chief of the MOEA's Department of Commerce, said at a ceremony to present accreditation certificates to 12 chain store and franchise headquarters that have performed outstandingly in service quality.
The accreditation scheme was launched by the department as part of a program to promote service quality and business performance, according to Yeh.
The program includes an assessment of chain store and franchise headquarters, a Good Service Practice (GSP) accreditation system and a business talent certification system, Yeh added.

The assessment and accreditation program was mapped out to create more jobs amid the recession by helping people seeking to launch their own franchise or chain store business to identify certified operators before making the choice of which franchise to buy into.

Twelve store operators passed the assessment this year, of which HB Housing was cited as having an excellent franchise headquarters, while Medfirst Healthcare Services Corp. and Jyi-Shien Enterprise Co., known for its Wu Tau Lunchbox products, were listed as qualified headquarters.
Meanwhile, over 900 stores were awarded GSP certificates this year, bringing to more than 6,000 the number that have been awarded the certification since 2004.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to bid for 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 20:04:14 (By Hsiao Pao-hsiang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei Baseball Association (CPBA) will submit a bid to host the 2010 Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament when the executive of the International Baseball Federation (IBAF) meets February in Rome, Italy, CPBA secretary-general Lin Tsung-cheng said Wednesday.

Lin said that the CPBA has approached members of the committee and received positive responses in this regard. The CPBA was the host of the 2006 tournament which drew national teams from all over the world to compete in Taichung, central Taiwan.
A total of 12 national teams will participate in the 2010 tournament, which is scheduled for Oct. 23-31, according to Lin.

The first Intercontinental Cup baseball tournament was held in Italy in 1973, and up to 1999 was held biennally around the world, hosted by Canada, Nicaragua, Cuba, Puerto Rico, Spain, Australia, and Taiwan. However, since 1999, there have been only two tournaments, in 2002 and 2006.
Lin said that upon being elected the new president of the IBAF, Riccardo Fraccari of Italy stressed that the tradition of the tournaments should continue and he pledged his full support.

DOC.HEADLINE: Recognition of China schools will not spur Taiwan student exodus: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 20:13:11 (By Liu Kuang-ying and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's proposed recognition of Chinese universities will not lead to an exodus of the country's top students, the Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday.
According to Vice Minister of Education Lin Tsung-ming, the move will instead prompt universities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in healthy competition.
Lin said that Taiwan universities have the competitive edge, and there is no need to worry about the "magnetic effect" of Chinese schools.

He also said that the ministry is planning a phased recognition of diplomas from more than 100 top Chinese universities, with 41 schools to be accredited in the first stage, 55 in the second stage and a yet undecided number in the third stage.

This means that Taiwan students wishing to study in China will have limited choices, he said. Besides, Taiwan is an open society and its students can go wherever they wish to pursue higher education, he added.

"Local universities, rather than worrying about losing students, should work harder to upgrade their quality so that their students can compete with those from top universities in other countries," Lin said.
Lin was responding to Legislator Kuan Bi-ling of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party who expressed misgivings over the possible effects of the government's plan.
Kuan said that Chinese universities could indeed attract top Taiwan students, and she cited the example of Premier Wu Den-yih's son who obtained a doctorate in law from China's Tsinghua University.

A Cabinet spokesman later in the day responded that Wu's son had studied for his master's degree in the United States and later worked for a Taiwan businessman. He did his doctorate in China under a company personnel development program, the spokesman said.
Lin also said that local universities would be allowed to admit Chinese students through a joint entrance examination, and in the initial stage would only accept newly graduates.
However, if necessary, specific universities could also hold individual entrance exams, he added.
If the proposal is approved by the legislature, Chinese senior high school students and college graduates could enter Taiwan universities by September 2010, according to Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC forges partnership with Motech
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 20:29:58 (By Wei Shu, Maranda Hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) signed a share subscription agreement with Motech Industries Inc. Wednesday under which the world's largest contract chipmaker will acquire a 20 percent stake in the latter.

The subscription of 75.32 million new Motech shares carries a price tag of approximately NT$6.2 billion (US$193 million) , or NT$82.7 per share, and will make TSMC the largest shareholder in the solar cell manufacturer, according to a statement released by TSMC.
The price represents a 16.9 percent discount on Motech's three-month average closing price, TSMC said, adding that the deal is subject to approval by Motech's shareholders and regulatory authorities.
Rick Tsai, president of TSMC New Businesses, said the partnership will facilitate the company's pursuit of new opportunities in the high-growth solar sector.

"With the investment, TSMC intends to leverage Motech's established platform to accelerate our time to market, better evaluate opportunities along the solar value chain, and further develop our overall solar strategy," Tsai said.

Motech is Taiwan's largest and one of the world's top 10 manufacturers of solar cells, with manufacturing facilities both in Taiwan and China. It is also Taiwan's leading supplier of photovoltaic systems and photovoltaic inverters.
The company has in-house ingot and wafer capabilities and a majority investment in polysilicon production via advanced fluidized bed reactor technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma reaffirms commitment to reform despite election setback
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 20:50:29 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) will not back off its commitment to wipe out corruption and establish clean politics despite its recent election setback.

Speaking in his capacity as KMT chairman at the party's first weekly meeting following last Saturday's local elections, Ma said the party will accelerate internal reform and work to the best of its ability for the interests of Taiwan and its people.
In the process, Ma said, both the KMT and the administration will strengthen communications with all relevant sectors to win public support for various reform initiatives.

Noting that nearly all the programs he intends to carry out -- such as mergers of cities and counties, government restructuring and taxation reform -- will touch on changes of status quo, Ma said it is only natural that there will be some backlash and discontent.
"Reform is like pulling a tooth... it tends to cause pain... If there was no price, it could hardly be called reform," Ma said.
For instance, he noted, the KMT lost the Hualien magistrate seat to Fu Kun-chi, a KMT maverick who was expelled from the party after he insisted on joining the race without the party's endorsement.
Ma said the party did not nominate Fu in the first place because he has a conviction record for his involvement in insider trading.
"We do not regret our decision, " Ma said, adding that the KMT, under his leadership, will not retreat from the path of reform.

Touching on the Democratic Progressive Party's stronger-than-expected showing in the latest election, Ma said he looks forward to normal engagement between the KMT and the DPP now that the main opposition party has risen from the ashes after a spate of corruption scandals surrounding its previous leader -- former President Chen Shui-bin.

"The KMT hopes to resume normal engagement with the DPP, " Ma said, adding that the two parties should hold regular dialogue and work together for the public's wellbeing through fair competition under the constitutional framework.
Ma apologized to the public for some of the KMT candidates' alleged involvement in vote-buying and violence in the just-concluded elections.
He also apologized to KMT supporters for the party's less-than-ideal showing in the elections for mayors, magistrates, councilors and township chiefs in 17 of Taiwan's cities and counties.
"I am the one who should assume full responsibility for the party's latest election setback," Ma said.

The KMT lost two magistrate seats -- Yilan and Hualien counties -- that it had held previous to the elections and also saw its vote share decline as compared to its performance in the previous local elections four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Controversy over U.S. beef imports flares up again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 23:18:35 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The controversy over the government's relaxation of restrictions on U.S. beef imports is heating up again, as Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang vowed Wednesday to sue a student who publicized the cellphone numbers of KMT lawmakers so that people could call them to complain about the issue.
The student, Chu Cheng-chi of National Taiwan University, was seeking sponsorship Wednesday for a billboard that would display the phone numbers of several KMT lawmakers, including Lu's.
Chu had earlier in the week displayed a poster with the phone numbers of some KMT lawmakers, and urged the public to call them to protest the wider opening of the Taiwan market to U.S. beef imports.
His action came in response to a proposed amendment to the Food Sanitation Act to clear the way for less stringent checks on U.S. beef imports.
However, KMT Legislator Kung Wen-chi, who had sponsored the proposed amendment, withdrew his version on Wednesday.
Nonetheless, Chu went ahead with his plans to erect the billboard, but said he was pleased to hear that Kung had dropped the proposal.
The student expressed the hope that KMT lawmakers would introduce a bill that would strictly prohibit imports of "risky" beef products.

In response, Lu said that Chu is an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) worker and an editor of a pro-DPP magazine, and that his actions were a means of gaining publicity with the intention of running for political office in the future.
Lu vowed to take legal action against Chu for infringement of portrait rights and disclosure of personal information.
Meanwhile, at a press conference Wednesday, the KMT legislative caucus accused the PDP of having stalled legislative meetings for one month over the controversy for political expediency.
Lu said that the KMT caucus has decided to adopt a version of the Food Sanitation Act amendment proposed by KMT Legislator Huang Yi-chiao, with some revisions.

The Huang version of the amendment states that the government would ban the importation of skulls, brains, eyes, spinal cords, bovine organs as well as ground beef from cattle raised in areas and countries where bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, outbreaks have occurred.

Those who illegally bring in beef from cattle that have been contaminated with " specific risk materials (SRMs) " related to BSE will be fined between NT$3 million and NT$15 million, the proposed bill states.

SRMs are defined in the U.S.-Taiwan beef protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.

However, DPP lawmakers have been pushing for a reopening of negotiations with the United States and a ban on the controversial beef parts, through legislation. It said administrative checks and measures are not enough to fully protect the health of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shin Kong Life Building site most expensive in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 23:18:49 (By Wei Shu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The site of the 51-story Shin Kong Life Building has the highest declared land value in metropolitan Taipei, with each ping (3.3 square meters) valued at NT$3.39 million, according to statistics released by the Land Department of the Taipei City Government.

The statistics indicate that the land, located across the street from Taipei Railway Station, has been the most expensive in the city for 12 consecutive years. The declared value in the current fiscal year is 0.41 percent higher than a year ago.
In the past year, land value in Taipei City grew by an average 2.12 percent, which was the lowest growth rate in the last six years, according to an analyst with Sinyi Real Estate.

The Neihu and Nankang districts, with many newly developed public facilities and brisk housing deals, registered the highest growth in land value over the past six years, recording increases of 36.8 percent and 36.4 percent, respectively.

Land value in Datung, Beitou and Wenshan districts on the outskirts of the metropolis showed comparatively lower growth in the past six years, though the average rate stood at 23 percent, according to the Land Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Controversy over U.S. beef imports flares up again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 23:18:35 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The controversy over the government's relaxation of restrictions on U.S. beef imports is heating up again, as Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang vowed Wednesday to sue a student who publicized the cellphone numbers of KMT lawmakers so that people could call them to complain about the issue.
The student, Chu Cheng-chi of National Taiwan University, was seeking sponsorship Wednesday for a billboard that would display the phone numbers of several KMT lawmakers, including Lu's.
Chu had earlier in the week displayed a poster with the phone numbers of some KMT lawmakers, and urged the public to call them to protest the wider opening of the Taiwan market to U.S. beef imports.
His action came in response to a proposed amendment to the Food Sanitation Act to clear the way for less stringent checks on U.S. beef imports.
However, KMT Legislator Kung Wen-chi, who had sponsored the proposed amendment, withdrew his version on Wednesday.
Nonetheless, Chu went ahead with his plans to erect the billboard, but said he was pleased to hear that Kung had dropped the proposal.
The student expressed the hope that KMT lawmakers would introduce a bill that would strictly prohibit imports of "risky" beef products.

In response, Lu said that Chu is an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) worker and an editor of a pro-DPP magazine, and that his actions were a means of gaining publicity with the intention of running for political office in the future.
Lu vowed to take legal action against Chu for infringement of portrait rights and disclosure of personal information.
Meanwhile, at a press conference Wednesday, the KMT legislative caucus accused the PDP of having stalled legislative meetings for one month over the controversy for political expediency.
Lu said that the KMT caucus has decided to adopt a version of the Food Sanitation Act amendment proposed by KMT Legislator Huang Yi-chiao, with some revisions.

The Huang version of the amendment states that the government would ban the importation of skulls, brains, eyes, spinal cords, bovine organs as well as ground beef from cattle raised in areas and countries where bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, outbreaks have occurred.

Those who illegally bring in beef from cattle that have been contaminated with " specific risk materials (SRMs) " related to BSE will be fined between NT$3 million and NT$15 million, the proposed bill states.

SRMs are defined in the U.S.-Taiwan beef protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.

However, DPP lawmakers have been pushing for a reopening of negotiations with the United States and a ban on the controversial beef parts, through legislation. It said administrative checks and measures are not enough to fully protect the health of the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shin Kong Life Building site most expensive in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/09/09 23:18:49 (By Wei Shu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The site of the 51-story Shin Kong Life Building has the highest declared land value in metropolitan Taipei, with each ping (3.3 square meters) valued at NT$3.39 million, according to statistics released by the Land Department of the Taipei City Government.

The statistics indicate that the land, located across the street from Taipei Railway Station, has been the most expensive in the city for 12 consecutive years. The declared value in the current fiscal year is 0.41 percent higher than a year ago.
In the past year, land value in Taipei City grew by an average 2.12 percent, which was the lowest growth rate in the last six years, according to an analyst with Sinyi Real Estate.

The Neihu and Nankang districts, with many newly developed public facilities and brisk housing deals, registered the highest growth in land value over the past six years, recording increases of 36.8 percent and 36.4 percent, respectively.

Land value in Datung, Beitou and Wenshan districts on the outskirts of the metropolis showed comparatively lower growth in the past six years, though the average rate stood at 23 percent, according to the Land Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 10, or the 24th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1898: Spain signs treaty with the United States, ending the Spanish-American War and ceding Cuba, Puerto Rico, Guam and the Philippines to the United States in exchange for US$20 million dollars.
1901: The first Nobel Prize presentation ceremonies are held separately in Stockholm, Sweden, and Oslo, Norway.
1902: Construction of the Aswan Dam is completed in the upper section of the Nile River in southwest Egypt.
1911: French scientist Marie Curie wins a second Nobel Prize, becoming the first person to do so.
1929: Chen Tu-siu, one of the Chinese Communist Party's co-founders, issues a statement to party comrades calling Joseph Stalin an opportunist who caused a massive split within the Communist Party.
1936: Britain's King Edward VIII abdicates, becoming the Duke of Windsor. He is succeeded by his brother, George VI.
1941: Japanese warplanes sink the British battleships "Repulse" and "Prince of Wales," killing nearly 800 in the South China Sea.
1948: The Third United Nations General Assembly adopts the Convention on Genocide and Human Rights.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek flies from Chengtu, Szechwan Province, to Taipei.
1952: The ROC government drafts its first four-year economic development plan.
1955: Cambodian Prime Minister Norodom Sihanouk arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1959: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Ku Cheng-kang as the acting secretary-general of the National Assembly.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with Gabon.
1973: A five-day Seminar on Agricultural Development with special reference to Taiwan is opened at the JCRR (Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction) Building in Taipei.
1974: Toshio Urabe, newly appointed chief of the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association, arrives in Taipei to assume his post.
1975: China Petroleum Corporation President Jerome Hu confirms the discovery of undersea oil deposits some 15 kilometers west of central Taiwan.
1975: A 12.5-kilometer section of the North-South Freeway between Chungli and Yangmei is completed. A 42-kilometer section of the roadway is now open to traffic.
1979: Mother Teresa is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for her ceaseless work in helping the destitute.
1979: The Formosa Incident, during which Formosa magazine demonstrators clash with police, occurs in Kaohsiung.
1986: Lee Yuan-tseh is awarded as the co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry at the Stockholm Concert Hall in Sweden.
1988: Mainland Chinese troops shoot into crowds of Tibetans demonstrating for human rights in Lhasa.
1988: The Indigenous Defense Fighters (IDF), manufactured by ROC aviation experts, are formally named "Ching-kuo" class fighters by President Lee Teng- hui.
1993: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela says he and South African President F.W. de Klerk are bound by the Nobel Peace Prize they accepted to spend the rest of their lives building a democratic South Africa free of racial discrimination.
1996: The Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs is established. The Taiwan Independence Party, which is a Democratic Progressive Party splinter group, is also established.
1999: The first human rights monument in Asia is officially inaugurated, on Green Island off the southeastern coast of Taiwan.
1999: Chen Shui-bian, the presidential candidate of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), formally names Annette Lu as his running mate for the 2000 presidential election.
2000: Under an amnesty decree issued by President Chen Shui-bian, 21 prisoners are released on International Human Rights Day.
2001: Fabrice de Murat, general manager of L'Oreal Taiwan, is re-elected chairman of the European Council for Commerce and Trade (ECCT).
2001: A delegation of high-ranking Taiwan police officers arrive in Beijing for a 12-day visit to the mainland. The delegation is the first of its kind to visit the mainland since the two sides separated following the end of China's civil war in 1949.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A young man, when at home, should be a good son; when out in the world, a good citizen. He should be circumspect and truthful. He should be in sympathy with all men, but intimate with men of moral character. If he has time and opportunity to spare, after the performance of those duties, he should then employ them in literary pursuits."
