DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: KMT shakeup

TEXT.P: President and ruling Kuomintang Chairman Ma Ying-jeou's appointment of his most trusted ally King Pu-tsung as the party's new secretary-general has drawn mixed reactions in the KMT ranks and wider society. While some party insiders believe King's close relationship with Ma will facilitate party reform, others have expressed doubts about his ability to fill that role.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
United Daily:
Ma's appointment Wednesday of former Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung to serve as the KMT's new secretary-general has taken the KMT hierarchy and the rest of the Taiwan political arena by surprise.

King, who is now a visiting scholar at the U.S. think tank Brookings Institution, will take over from Chan Chuen-po, one of the KMT's vice chairmen, as manager of the party's day-to-day affairs. Chan will retain his position as vice chairman.
"This arrangement will shape a new iron triangle in our endeavor to accelerate party reforms," Ma said at a weekly party meeting.
China Times:

King, nicknamed by local political observers as "King stylet" and Ma's right- hand man during his tenure as Taipei mayor, demonstrated his expertise as a campaigner and publicity guru in a number of important elections that involved Ma.
Ma is now seen drawing on King's agility to bolster and accelerate efforts to revive the KMT monolith. (Dec.10, 2009)
Liberty Times:
The surprise appointment is bound to trigger opposition within the KMT ranks as well as at the level of grassroots party workers.
As a top party manager, the KMT secretary-general must be acutely tuned to the party's grassroots and must have finely honed skills to navigate the country's political environment.
"The top manager will lead the party to a dead end if he makes judgments simply on the basis of charts and figures that he reads at the office," some senior KMT party officials said. (Dec. 10, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: Industry tie-up

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.'s acquisition of a 20 percent stake in Motech Industries, Inc. is widely seen as a landmark entry of major Taiwanese business groups into the photovoltaic industry. Market analysts say the involvement of industrial heavyweights will contribute to the development of Taiwan's export-oriented solar energy industry.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest development: Economic Daily News:

Taiwan's leading wafer manufacturer Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced Wednesday that it will acquire a 20 percent stake in Motech Industries at a cost of NT$6.2 billion (US$129.09 million).
The deal will make TSMC the largest single investor in Motech, which is Taiwan's oldest solar cell manufacturer and its stock prices are the highest among its local competitors. Liberty Times:

After resuming the post of TSMC chief executive officer, Morris Chang assigned Rick Tsai to head the New Business Department. Tsai visited various firms in the solar energy industry and chose Motech as partner because Motech's Chairman Yuan-huai Simon Tsuo is one of his acquaintances and many executives of Motech are former employees of TSMC. Commercial Times:

Industrial analysts have said that TSMC is investing in Motech on a trial basis, as Motech, with a gross profit of 15 percent of its assets, lags far behind TSMC which boasts a gross profit of 50 percent of its assets. The analysts have predicted that TSMC will not take over Motech in the long term unless Motech can raise its profits sharply.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT sponsors USA Pavilion at Taipei International Building Show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 12:24:11 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) is sponsoring a U.S. Pavilion at the 2009 Taipei International Building, Construction and Decoration Exhibition that opened Thursday, in a bid to explore the possibility of cooperation between Taiwan and the United States in the field of green construction.

"The American associations and companies represented at the U.S. pavilion are willing and ready to cooperate with the Taiwan construction industry to take advantage of American technologies and green building materials in creating a cleaner, safer building environment for the future," the AIT said in a press release.
The U.S. pavilion consists of 20 booths occupied by 14 American associations and companies that are displaying both industrial and wood building products.

At an opening ceremony for the U.S. pavilion Thursday, the APA-Engineered Wood Association signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Taiwan Architecture and Building Center for closer cooperation.

The MOU will help to foster a closer relationship between the two organizations which are leaders in the use of green building materials and will lead to further exchanges of research information related to green building standards and engineered wood products, according to the AIT.

The American companies and associations at the exhibition include the home- automation company Control4, Andersen Doors and Windows, GE Lighting, Buildtech International, Patrick Lumber Company and Fortress Wood Products.
Their displays feature energy-saving, environmentally friendly and sustainable green building products.
The 2009 Taipei international building show is being held from Dec. 10-13 at Taipei's World Trade Center.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's confidant to return soon to help streamline KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 9 (CNA) 12/10/09 13:31:32 (By Zep Hu, Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Deputy Mayor King Pu-tsung, widely known as President Ma Ying- jeou's right-hand man during Ma's tenure as Taipei mayor, will rush back to Taipei to take up his surprise appointment as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang.

Commenting on the mixed reactions within the KMT to his appointment, King told the Central News Agency that he too was taken by surprise by the appointment, but that he would make every effort to prove the skeptics wrong.
"I will speak less and do more in the future and give the job my best shot," said King, who is currently a visiting scholar at the U.S. think tank, the Brookings Institution.
He appealed to the KMT hierarchy and the wider Taiwan society to give him time to do his best to streamline the ruling party.
It is widely believed that Ma's appointment of King to the management post was a response to the KMT's setback in the just-concluded local elections.

King declined to comment on the KMT's performance in the elections, saying that it will take some time for him to gain a better understanding of the current situation and be able to comment on the party's prospects and campaign strategies in future elections.
Meanwhile, King said he will return to Taipei as soon as possible but will need to wrap up some routine matters before he leaves.
On his research experience in D.C., King said he has learned a lot at the Brookings Institution over the past several months.

He said he is now better versed in international affairs and hopes that he could help push for closer contact between Taiwan and the rest of the world and greater representation of the country in global organizations.
"One of the priorities of my new job might be to promote party-to-party diplomacy," he added.
King, who started his research at Brookings in September this year, was scheduled to finish in January 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC's investment in Motech may hold new opportunities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 14:20:55 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The country's leading wafer manufacturer Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) announced Wednesday that it will invest NT$6.2 billion (US$192.55 millin) to acquire a 20 percent stake in Motech Industries.

The deal will give TSMC a foothold in the solar energy industry, while Motech, Taiwan's oldest solar cell maker, will have a wealthy stock owner to fall back on, but it will be best if the partnership could bring new prospects for the whole industry and give it a shot in the arm.
The investment deal will take effect in January next year, TSMC said Wednesday, adding that it will hold on to its stake in Motech for a minimum of three years.
A TSMC spokesman said that Motech will call a meeting of its board of directors next January to approve the deal and TSMC is expected to gain two seats on the new board.
TSMC began to evaluate the potential of the solar energy industry long before the industry rebounded from the global financial crisis.
TSMC's chief executive officer Rick Tsai, who was assigned in June as head of its New Business Depart, was eyeing the acquisition of a solar energy firm as a means of venturing into the industry.
At one point, TSMC had reportedly set its sights on New Solar Power Corp., with which it is closely associated.
Before the global financial crisis broke, entry to the solar energy industry was relatively easy because it didn't cost much, and speculations ran rife about take-overs and acquisitions.
Now that the crisis is over and price of raw materials is dropping, the cost of solar energy could fall to the level of of grid electricity.
TSMC is eager to break into new industries, while Motech is keen to find investors with abundant cash, therefore the deal is advantageous to both sides.
But neither side knows what the next step should be, although they both agree that the prospects are bright for this burgeoning industry.

As a novice in the alternative energy field, the semiconductor giant TSMC is paying Motech a "tuition fee" of NT$6.2 billion. While this might be just a drop in the bucket for TSMC, it is equivalent of the value of Motech's entire production facility.
With TSMC as its largest single investor, Motech now has a solid foundation for future development and a chance to determine its next step.
Within this context, the linking of TSMC and Motech is a reasonable and prudent decision.
The public hopes that the cooperation between the two companies will bring new development opportunities for the emerging alternative energy industry, according to analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two U.N. human rights covenants take effect a big step: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 15:35:27 (By Shih Hsin-yao and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's adoption of two United Nations human rights covenants into domestic law, which took effect Thursday, is an important step for the country, President Ma Ying-jeou said the same day.

The two U.N. human rights treaties -- the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights -- were signed into law May 14 by Ma and came into effect on Human Rights Day, Dec. 10.

"From today on, any individual in the Republic of China can cite these two laws on human rights protection, which is an important step for Taiwan," Ma said at a human rights award ceremony held by the government-funded Taiwan Foundation for Democracy (TFD).
In support of a promise made by the president at a similar ceremony last year, the legislature passed the bill in March this year.
"I have delivered on my promise, made one year ago at a similar event, to make these two treaties domestic law," Ma said.

Taiwan was one of the original signatories to the two treaties in 1967 when the Republic of China was still a U.N. member. Although Taiwan lost its U.N. seat in 1971, it took steps many years later to adopt the treaties.

However, Wang Sing-nan, caucus whip of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, accused the government Thursday of violating the terms of the treaties that recognize "the right of everyone to the enjoyment of the highest attainable standard of physical and mental health."
According to Wang, the government's decisions to allow imports of bone-in beef from the U.S. and certain protein products from China have seriously endangered public health and lives.

The ceremony Thursday was held to honor Kim Seong-min, founder and CEO of Free North Korea Radio, who was named winner of the fourth Asia Democracy and Human Rights Awards (ADHRA), in recognition of his courage in defying the North Korean regime.

Ma said the ADHRA represents a significant transition in Taiwan, which was under martial law 22 years ago. Restrictions on democracy and violations of human rights have been eliminated through constitutional amendments and the institution of new laws since martial law was lifted in 1987, he added.

He recalled that in 2008, then U.S. President George W. Bush praised Taiwan as a "beacon of democracy" in Asia and the world. According to Ma, the statement, which was part of a congratulatory message to him on his election as president, was very moving, but at the same time put a weight of responsibility on him for Taiwan to be deserving of such praise.

ADHRA was created in 2006 by the TFD, a Taiwan-based national democracy assistance foundation, to honor individuals or groups dedicated to democratic development, the advancement of human rights and the building of democracy.

Reporters Without Borders Secretary-General Robert Menard won the first ADHRA, while Cynthia Maung, founder of the Mae Sot clinic that provides service to refugees and migrant workers in Myanmar, won the award in 2007, and Afghan human rights activist Sima Samar in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices plunge on local bourse

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan on good terms with Japan: legislative speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 15:54:51 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Sinyao Shih and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Thursday that Taiwan is on good terms with Japan, dismissing a Japanese daily's allegation that bilateral relations have "abruptly frozen" since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008.
Describing the Asahi Shimbun report as "off-base, " Wang said the daily made its mistake because the writer did not understand what Taiwan has done in its efforts to cement ties with Japan.

The Asahi Shimbun claimed in a Dec. 8 commentary that bilateral relations have plummeted to a new low, evidenced by the departure of Masaki Saito, chief of the Taipei office of the Japan Interchange Association -- Japan's de facto embassy in Taiwan. The commentary said Saito's resignation was the result of deep distrust between the leaderships of the two sides.
Also disagreeing with the Asahi Shimbun commentary, Taiwan's representative to Japan, John Feng, noted that the allegation only represents the stance of a single Japanese media outlet.
"Taiwan-Japan relations could not be better at present, " Feng said during a visit to Wang at the Legislative Yuan that same day.

Feng, who is in Taiwan on a business trip, offered his appreciation for Wang's Dec. 1 visit to Sapporo, capital of Hokkaido Prefecture, to witness the opening of a Taiwan representative office there, the country's first new office in Japan in 30 years.
"Wang's visit and the opening of the Sapporo office were a shot in the arm in terms of cementing bilateral ties," Feng noted.

Wang told Feng that he will visit Japan again in February at the head of a group of legislators to pay courtesy calls on party heavyweights across Japan's political spectrum in a bid to further consolidate two-way exchanges.

A day earlier, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs also rebutted the newspaper's allegation, pointing out that a string of successes have been achieved in bilateral ties this year, which it labeled "the year of special partnership between Taiwan and Japan."

So far this year, at least eight concrete achievements have been made, including the resumption of Taiwan-Japan fishery talks after a hiatus of more than three years, said Chen Tiao-ho, secretary-general of the Association of East Asian Relations -- a quasi-official organization established to handle exchanges with Japan after the two countries severed formal diplomatic relations in 1972.

Other headway includes the signing of a working holiday program for young people from the two sides, the establishment of a Taiwan cultural center in Tokyo, the Japan Interchange Association's financial assistance in the establishment of a contemporary Japan research center at National Cheng Chi University in Taipei, and the upgrading of the level of officials representing the two countries at the annual Taiwan-Japan economic and trade conference to the level of bureau chief, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade pact with China will not be negotiated in coming talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 16:23:13 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Su Lung-chi, Kuo Mei-lan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A proposed trade pact with China will not be negotiated, far less inked, in the fourth round of negotiations between the two sides scheduled for later this month, the country's top Chinese affairs official said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Minister Lai Shin-yuan told the Legislative Yuan, however, that Taiwan's top negotiator -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- is expected to agree with his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, on possible talks on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement in their fifth round of talks.
Out of respect for the legislature's power to supervise the executive branch, Lai said, the MAC will brief the legislature thoroughly on the negotiations upon the request of the lawmakers.

Meanwhile, Huang Yu-tsai, deputy chief of the Council of Agriculture, assured the legislature that Taiwan will not relax its animal and plant health inspection and quarantine regulations to accommodate Chinese products following a proposed agricultural agreement with China.

Huang said the agreement, which is expected to be concluded during the upcoming Chiang-Chen meeting, is meant to bring the regulations of both sides into balance and to oblige China to inform Taiwan of any disease outbreaks there.

Lai and Huang made the remarks separately but almost at the same time when the SEF announced in Taipei the details of Chen's Dec. 21-25 visit for the negotiations that will take place in Taichung City, central Taiwan.
The negotiations will take place Dec. 22-23, after which Chen's delegation will tour central Taiwan.
The SEF said in a press release that the details were finalized by SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian and Chinese officials in Fuzhou, southern China, earlier that day.
A Chinese delegation, led by ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong, will arrive in Taiwan Dec. 18 to make the final arrangements for Chen's visit.
In response to the announcement, several pro-independence groups promised to stage the largest demonstration ever seen in Taichung to greet the Chinese delegation.
The protest is designed to show disapproval of President Ma Ying-jeou's policy of reconciling with China, said former Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, who is one of the organizers.
Lin Yi-cheng, another of the organizers, said he and his followers will rally and protest wherever the Chinese delegation goes during its stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 16:59:53 (By Nick Huang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.041 to close at NT$32.308.
A total of US$606 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.350 and reached a low of NT$32.269.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier urges better execution of public construction program
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 17:05:48 (By Hsieh Chia-jen and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should ride on the momentum of economic recovery to boost its economic growth by increasing the execution rate of a NT$500 billion (US$15.5 billion) economic stimulus package, Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday.

Wu called for all out efforts to implement the four-year public construction program launched by the government amid the global economic downturn, saying that the top priorities include promoting the six emerging industries and developing the service industry to speed up the transition and upgrading of the country's industrial base.
He made the remarks after listening to a report by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on the present macroeconomic situation and economic agenda.
According to the premier, despite a relatively stable labor market, the government should continue to carry out employment promotion measures to further reduce unemployment.

It should also try to eliminate investment barriers, improve the industrial environment and pay close attention to the possible medium- and long-term impact on commodity prices caused by hikes in international oil and raw material prices, Wu said.
In light of the significant decrease in tax revenue under the sluggish economy, all government agencies should work together to retrench their expenses before the end of the year, he added.

The CEPD said predictions by international institutions indicate that the global economy is bottoming out and is expected to see a positive growth in the fourth quarter of this year, while the recovery will continue throughout next year with a 2 percent annual growth.

"Taiwan should continue to promote its economic stimulus programs as planned, given that economic recovery in this country and around the world is gradual, while the stability of the global financial system has been affected by the Dubai debt crisis," the CEPD said.
According to the CEPD, careful attention should be paid to how the hikes in oil and raw material prices will impact the global economic recovery and the price of commodities, especially food.
The government should make proper use of its grain stockpile to stabilize food prices should that become necessary, it added.

Noting that Taiwan's economy is in gradual recovery, with all economic indexes moving up slightly, the CEPD said that private consumption expenditure registered positive growth for the first time in the third quarter after declining for four consecutive quarters.
Positive growth was also seen in October in industrial productivity, export orders, the wholesale and retail industries and the food service industry, it added.

The economic climate flashed a green light signifying steady growth for the first time in October, with an increase in November's consumer confidence index, the CEPD said, adding that the country's overall exports saw positive growth in November, even though exports to the U.S. and Japan remained in decline.
The unemployment rate was still high, despite drops for two consecutive months, while negative growth was seen in the annual increase rate of average monthly earnings, according to the CEPD.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan secures one gold, two silver medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 17:08:44 (By Oscar Wu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan bagged one gold medal and two silvers at the East Asian Games Thursday after a drought of three days.
Taiwan's tennis players Chuan Chia-jung and Hsieh Su-wei won gold in Women's Doubles, defeating Kim So Jung and Lee Jin A of South Korea in straight two sets.
Earlier in the day, Taiwan players Yi Chu-huan and Lee Hsin-han had to settle for silver in the Men's Doubles after they were defeated by a Chinese pair, Zeng Shaoxuan and Zhang Ze, 4-6, 6-7, (4-7).
This has shattered Taiwan's hopes of winning at least four golds as it did in the last East Asian Games in Macau in 2005.
Also on Thursday, Taiwan cyclist Huang Ho-hsun finished second in the Individual Road Race for Women, winning Taiwan's second silver medal in the games.
In a photo finish, Huang and three others crossed the line together, clocking 2 hours, 43 minutes and 41 seconds, but the gold went to Chinese cyclist Liu Xiaohui, based on the photo images.
With a silver medal under her belt, Huang said she was more confident of winning a medal at the 2010 Asian Games in Guangzhou, southern China.
So far, Taiwan ranks fifth among the nine states and regions in the games, with four golds, two silvers and four bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet to strengthen implementation of economic stimulus package
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 17:19:56 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the concerned authorities Thursday to step up implementation of the government's four-year NT$500 billion economic stimulus package to give greater momentum to the recovery.
Wu issued the directive at a weekly Cabinet meeting, at which the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) gave a briefing on the country's economic situation.
Citing forecasts by international research institutes, the CEPD said the world economy is expected to show growth in the fourth quarter of 2009 as the global recession bottoms out.
The recovery will continue in 2010, with growth likely to register over 2 percent, the council said.
A similar trend has emerged in Taiwan, with the monitoring indicator for the country's economic activities in October finally flashing a green light, a sign of steady economic growth, the CEPD noted.
Also, the consumer confidence index showed an upswing in November, and exports posted year-on-year growth in November for the first time since September 2008, according to the CEPD.
Although Taiwan's unemployment rate has dropped for two consecutive months, it still remains high, while the average earnings of local workers have continued to decline, the council said.
Addressing the situation, Wu asked the relevant authorities to continue providing employment assistance to the jobless to help lower the unemployment rate.

He also directed them to pursue investment deregulation so as to improve Taiwan's business environment, and to pay close attention to the possible impact of recent international oil and commodity price hikes on the country's consumer prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica to welcome lectures by Nobel laureate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 17:27:46 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A 2008 Nobel laureate in chemistry will deliver two keynote speeches in Taipei to inaugurate a prestigious lecture series organized by Taiwan's leading academic institute, Academia Sinica, according to a press statement released Thursday by the institute.

According to the press release, Roger Yonchien Tsien will make a four-day visit to Taiwan Dec. 11-14. He will deliver the lectures, titled "Painting Cell Signals with a Palette of Fluorescent Proteins" and "Building Molecules to Image and Help Treat Cancer and Inflammatory Disease," Dec. 11 and Dec. 14, respectively.

Tsien, a professor at the Chemistry and Biochemistry Department of the University of California, San Diego, was awarded the Nobel Prize with two other chemists -- Martin Chalfie of Columbia University and Osamu Shimomura of Boston University -- in recognition of their discovery and development of green fluorescent protein (GFP).

Commonly used in biology as a reporter of gene expression, Tsien and his co- winners made unprecedented contributions to the general understanding of how GFP fluoresces, extended the color palette beyond green, which allowed researchers to give various proteins and cells different colors, the press release said.

"The discovery of GFP has led to its widespread use as a tagging tool in bioscience research. By using DNA technology, researchers can now use GFP as a fluorescent marker to help better observe the movements, positions and interactions of tagged proteins," it added.

Born in New York in 1952, Tsien graduated from Harvard University with a bachelor of science in chemistry and physics in 1972 and received his PhD in physiology from the University of Cambridge in 1977.

He comes from a line of top academics. His uncle Tsien Hsue-shen was a renowned rocket scientist regarded as the founding father of the Chinese ballistic missile, while his father Tsien Hsue-chu was a mechanical engineer who graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The Academia Sinica lecture series, which will officially open Dec. 11, is being organized by Wong Chi-huey, president of the institute, in an effort to build on the spirit of research and free exchange of scholarly knowledge fostered at its "Academy President's Forum" held last year to mark the 80th anniversary of the establishment of Academia Sinica. The institute will extend lecture invitations to top scholars from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Medical students, parents argue for fairness
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 17:57:17 (By Emma Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwanese students who have studied medicine and obtained academic credentials in China, along with their parents, argued for fairness Thursday at a hearing on the government's plans to recognize academic credentials earned in China.
They voiced perplexity over the government's plans not to recognize medical credentials earned in China but to recognize other credentials issued by Chinese universities in other fields.

Wu Pei-hsuan, a graduate of Peking University's medical school, said she had hoped to return to Taiwan to work at a local hospital, but her plan was stymied when she heard that her qualification would not be recognized here.
"I was forced to head instead to Australia to find a job, " Wu said at the hearing.

Thursday's hearing, held in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, was the first of 17 that the Ministry of Education (MOE) has scheduled until Dec. 23 to probe public opinion on the ministry's recent decision to recognize academic credentials issued by 41 top-notch universities in China and Taiwan's opening to Chinese students seeking to study in Taiwan.
Lin Yun-ying, whose son is studying medicine in China, said her son would prefer to return to Taiwan to work upon graduation, but the MOE's plan has blunted his desire to return home.
"Why such unfairness?" Lin asked.

Other parents who attended the hearing also expressed confusion, arguing why Taiwanese students who study medicine in Poland and the Philippines can take national medical examinations after returning to Taiwan, but those who have earned diplomas in Chinese medical schools are not given such an opportunity.

However, Ho Jow-fei, director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, did not answer their questions, saying instead that the recognition of academic credentials issued by Chinese medical schools is a matter that falls under the jurisdiction of the Cabinet-level Department of Health.
"I will refer your opinions to the inter-agency meetings at the Executive Yuan for further debate," Ho told the appellants.

Meanwhile, Chao Tien-lin, a Kaohsiung city councilor representing the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said at the hearing that it would be "unclear and toothless" if the MOE stipulates only that Chinese will be barred from taking part in Taiwan's professional and civil service examinations because "they are neither Republic of China citizens nor foreign nationals."

Chao suggested that the government make it clear in black and white that no Chinese students or citizens will be allowed to sit tests in Taiwan for professional licenses and civil service credentials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial regulator dismisses concerns over overheated TDR market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 18:40:23 (By Tien Yu-pin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top financial regulator and Taiwan Stock Exchange Corp. (TWSE) have dismissed speculations that the prices of Taiwan Depository Receipts (TDRs) issued recently by overseas companies have been artificially jacked up.

Discrepancies were seen not only in the prices of TDRs and their original shares listed on markets outside Taiwan, but also in the prices of American Depositary Receipts (ADRs) issued by Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) and United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) and their original shares listed on local bourse, according to Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen Wednesday.

However, this is a normal phenomenon, he noted, saying that it had resulted from discrepancies between supply and demand in each share market and different valuations of the TDR's future price-to-earning ratio.

The commission will collaborate with TWSE and the Taiwan Securities Association to develop means of easing the potential price hike of TDRs by maintaining a balance between supply and demand, FSC Vice Chairman Wu Tang-chieh said.
Meanwhile, a TWSE spokesman said that it common to raise funds by issuing depository receipts and that the issuance of TDRs is still in its early stages.

According to TWSE's statistics, as of the end of last month, five firms operated by overseas Taiwanese businessmen -- Want Want China Holdings Ltd., Ju Teng International Holdings Ltd., New Focus Auto Tech Holdings Ltd., Yorkey Optical International (Cayman) Ltd., and Vietnam Manufacturing and Export Processing Holdings Ltd. -- had raised a total of NT$7.1 billion (US$220 million) through TDR issuances.

The scale of TDR issuances is still small compared with that of the ADRs listed by 26 companies on the New York Stock Exchange and the NASDAQ Stock Market, which raised more than US$7.5 billion (approximately NT$250 billion) this year, the statistics show.

The ADRs issued by TSMC, UMC, Chunghwa Telecom, Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc., Siliconware Precision Industries Co., and AU Optronics Corp. have posted price increases ranging from 1 percent to 76 percent, according to the statistics.
Since 2000, the six companies have raised US$17.4 billion (approximately NT$565.7 billion) through ADR issuances, the statistics show.

The issuance of DRs will help stimulate the bourses in which their original shares are listed and could also create a price comparison effect between the two stock markets, according to the TWSE spokesman.
Taiwanese companies have issued DRs on markets in the United States, Luxembourg and London, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA planning anti-drought measures
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:15:04 (By M.C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Responding to the growing possibility of water shortages, particularly in southern regions, Premier Wu Den-yih has asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to work out a comprehensive plan to deal with the worsening situation, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Thursday.

Speaking at a news conference following the Executive Yuan's regular weekly meeting, Su said drought is a pressing issue facing both the local and central governments -- a conclusion that President Ma Ying-jeou reached during a meeting with the premier a day earlier.
He said Wu has demanded that the MOEA hammer out a comprehensive program involving government agencies, private companies and individuals, to deal with the problem as soon as possible.
Southern Taiwan could be soon suffering a water shortage and the amount of rainfall forecast for the first quarter of next year is lower than previous averages for the period, he said.

Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu has also instructed relevant government authorities that water supplies for households and industrial use prior to the next year's rainy season must be secured and that they should call one or two meetings every month to monitor the water supply situation, Su added.

Meanwhile, the Chianan irrigation association announced that same day that some 18,000 hectares of rice paddy in the Chianan area of Chiayi and Tainan counties will be left fallow for the first harvest next year due to the emerging dry spell.

The decision was made a day earlier by the South Water Resources Bureau under the MOEA's Water Resources Agency to ensure the provision of water for households and industrial use at least until the end of May next year, association officials explained.
The move will be the sixth of its kind since the Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County started operating in 1975, and its impact will not be inconsequential, they noted.

According to the officials, the Tsengwen and nearby Wusanto reservoirs have a total capacity of about 200 million cubic meters, but the two facilities have been seriously silted by mud washed down by Typhoon Morakot, which lashed southern Taiwan in August.
Since that time, no rain has fallen in the Tainan area and the two reservoirs have not taken in any more water, making the water supply in the region even more difficult, they pointed out.
Water Resources Agency Director-General Yang Wei-fu said early this month that water rationing might be imposed by the end of February if no rain falls in the months between now and next spring.

Taiwan has been affected by a looming drought since the beginning of this year, except for August, when Morakot hit the country, according to a climate change monitoring center at National Taiwan University.
During the first 10 months, it rained on only 52 days, some 90 days fewer than the average level, the center said.
The precipitation brought by Morakot to southern Taiwan, the highest level in history, underscored a sharp change in rainfall patterns as a result of climate extremes, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait taxation agreement benefits taxpayers: finance minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:26:21 (By Ye-fong Lin, Chao-fen Kao and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A proposed taxation agreement with China expected to be signed during the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks later this month will protect Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, lower the burden on taxpayers and increase the government's tax revenues in the long run, Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Thursday.

Lee also gave an assurance that information on neither individuals nor companies will be revealed during tax information exchanges between the two sides, in line with international tax treaty protocols. Such information will only be supplied when there is a specific need for tax inspection in cases of major tax evasion, he added.

He made the remarks at a session at the Legislative Yuan in which legislators voiced concern that the taxation agreement might enable China to obtain more financial information about Taiwanese businessmen operating there, which could affect their future operations.

Lee said the agreement closely follows guidelines set forth by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the United Nations in their model tax convention documents. Taiwan has signed similar tax treaties with 16 countries.

Among those 16 countries, Lee said, there have been only eight cases of tax information exchange -- all of them in relation to major tax evasion or avoidance -- in the past five years, with four cases initiated by Taiwan.
He also said it would be impossible for either side to send officials across the strait to conduct tax inspections.

The taxation agreement will cover issues such as the taxation rights of each government, the avoidance of double taxation and mutual assistance on taxation matters. In recent talks, both sides have reached consensus on most of the contents of the agreement, including tax allocation and exchange of tax information.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said that all cross-strait agreements, including the taxation one, must be open and transparent to the public, and must be reviewed and approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Lee said that without the taxation agreement, the two sides can hide their incomes from each other, causing a lot of unfairness, and that the agreement will help improve information transparency and better protect Taiwanese businessmen working in China.
In the long term, the agreement could also help attract more Chinese corporate investment into Taiwan, further increasing the government's tax revenues, Lee said.

The agreement will also ensure that Taiwanese workers who stay for less than 183 days per year in China will only have to pay taxes on their salaries received in China to the Chinese government rather than suffering double taxation.
There are about 1 million Taiwanese people working in China, who mostly allocate a larger portion of their income to be received in Taiwan so they can enjoy the country's lower income tax rate.

In addition, as the amount of Taiwanese investment in China is far bigger than the amount of Chinese investment in Taiwan, the Chinese government will need to give up its taxation right or apply lower tax rates for some of its income after the agreement takes effect.

Taiwan's net tax revenue for the first 11 months of this year totaled NT$1.43 trillion, representing a 14.6 percent drop from the same period of last year, according to the latest statistics released by the ministry Thursday.

The fourth and latest round of cross-strait talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is scheduled to take place in Taichung City Dec. 22-23.

The negotiations will mainly focus on four issues -- fishery cooperation, avoidance of double taxation, examination and certification of standards and the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should boost domestic consumption, investment: economist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:32:35 (By Cheng Yun-shuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As economies around the world are undergoing structural reshuffles, Taiwan should seek to restructure its economy by boosting domestic consumption and investment, Liu Yi-ju, chief economics consultant to the Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. said Thursday.

Liu said at a forum on economic prospects for 2010 that Taiwan has been marginalized for some time in the process of regional economic integration. With the improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, however, the country now has the chance to reverse the situation, according to Liu.
She added, however, that should Taiwan fail to grasp the opportunity for change, it will remain in the back seat in terms of economic growth next year.

Stressing Taiwan's advantages of talent and solid infrastructure for industrial development, Liu said it is possible for Taiwan to return to the international stage in terms of economics and trade, even though many international enterprises which have been focusing on China had abandoned Taiwan over the past few years.
She suggested that Taiwan should try to lure international capital in addition to its efforts to attract Chinese investors.

The economist, a former advisor to the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that instead of relying on exports to boost the economy, Taiwan should shift its focus from foreign trade to domestic consumption and investment.

While Taiwan's economic growth in the past relied heavily on exports and foreign reserves from trade surplus, the trade surplus accounted for only 4 percent to 8 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP).
On the other hand, domestic consumption accounted for 60 percent of the GDP, while domestic investment and government expenditure together accounted for more than 30 percent, according to Liu.
"It is as if a family is relying heavily on the youngest kid working at a fast food stand to earn the household's bread, while the elder brothers are idle," Liu said.
"Since the fast food stand has folded, it is time for all the brothers to do their shares of the work," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:40:01 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday: COMMERCIAL TIMES What if 'unequitable taxation" was an option in poll on public grievances?

Acting on Premier Wu Den-yi's directive, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) recently conducted an online survey to identify the "top 10 public grievances," and found that exorbitant housing prices in urban areas was at the top of the list.
However, the respondents were given 15 pre-selected options from which to chose, which means that the survey results might not be fully reflective of the whole picture.
We wonder whether the main grievances would have been different if "unequitable taxation" was included on the RDEC-proposed list.
Unequitable taxation has been relatively less frequently discussed because tax issues can be very technical and the public tends be insufficiently informed about the details.

Only through academic research papers have we learned that eight of the 40 richest people in Taiwan, who each had annual incomes of over NT$100 million in 2002, did not have to pay any income tax that year, and that average wage earners contribute more than 70 percent to the government's annual tax revenues.

It was not until early this year when the government lowered the inheritance and gift tax rates to 10 percent that we realized only 5 percent of local taxpayers -- particularly the 200 most wealthy people who were originally subject to a 50 percent tax rate -- had benefited from the new measure.

During a recent inspection tour of the Ministry of Finance, some Control Yuan members took ministry officials to task over the lowering of the inheritance and gift tax rate and what they said was the country's unusually low rate of capital gain tax. In our view, finance officials have failed to give any convincing explanations about the two issues.

We are not opposed to the government's efforts to determine the main sources of public grievances through opinion polls. But we suggest that "unequitable taxation" be included on the list next time such a survey is conducted. ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS: Policy initiatives most needed to rev up economy
President Ma Ying-jeou has vowed to improve the macro environment after the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 local elections.
Ma also recognizes that "revving up the economy" is an effective short-cut to improving the macro economy.

If he wants such endeavors to help boost the KMT's showing in next year's elections of the mayors of the country's five municipalities, then his administration should present the meat of its policy incentives as soon as possible and take action with full vigor and urgency.
However, there is irony in the government's budget plan for the coming year.

At a time when most world powers are adopting expansion strategies to sustain economic growth in the wake of the year-long global recession, Taiwan seems to be joining the ranks of the first group of countries that have ended their stimulus measures.
According to the 2010 budget plan, the government's regular budget and special budget will both fall short of this year's amounts, while public investment will also contract.

If Taiwan does not want to see itself knocked out at a time when the global economy is on the track of slow recovery, the Ma administration should correct such flawed budget planning, come up with well-devised policy initiatives and act resolutely to accelerate economic growth. CHINA TIMES Legislative speaker's temper should have flared earlier

The even-tempered Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng finally lost his cool Monday when opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers again paralyzed the legislature by besieging the speaker's podium to protest the government's decision to relax restrictions on U.S. beef imports.
The DPP, which holds 27 of the legislature's 113 seats, has managed to disrupt legislative floor meetings for more than one month over the U.S. beef import issue.
Wang angrily criticized the DPP legislators' boycott strategy, describing it as "very, very inappropriate" and "senseless."
Wang has reason to blast the DPP, but we must remind him that the ruling Kuomintang should also be blamed for the Legislature's poor efficiency.
People on the street are entitled to ask why the KMT, with more than 90 legislative seats, has been unable to pass legislation that is critical to the implementation of the government's policies.

Some KMT lawmakers like to ridicule President and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou over what they call his incompetence, but they should be aware that one of the reasons behind Ma's fading popularity is his administration's inefficiency, as many of his policy initiatives and reform programs are shelved in the Legislature.

If KMT lawmakers sit idly and let the DPP hold up the legislative proceedings over the beef trade issue, it will be a no-win situation for both parties. APPLE DAILY New appointment epitomizes Ma's reform commitment

Ma's surprise appointment of his most trusted confidant, King Pu-tsung, as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, sends a clear message that he will continue streamlining the KMT monolith in line with the principles of "integrity and capability."

King and Ma share some common features in their characters. Both are characterized by a strong moral ethos, self-motivation and drive, and political cleanliness. King is a bit more smart and shrewd and takes comfort in playing the role of a behind-the-scenes strategist and adviser.

Therefore, the duo have developed a close partnership. During Ma's tenure as Taipei mayor, King served as his door-guard in his capacity as deputy mayor, helping to steer away many filthy politicians and shady political deals and thereby allowing Ma to maintain his clean image.

We are pleased to see that Ma remains committed to reforming the KMT after the party suffered its election setback. Should that continue to be the case, we hope Ma will delegate full power to King so that he can wipe out the party's old guard with their shady criminal backgrounds. UNITED DAILY NEWS Can King Pu-tsung change KMT culture?
Some KMT lawmakers' strong reaction to Ma's appointment of King Pu-tsung as new KMT secretary-general signals how challenging and tough his new role will be.

As the KMT once ruled Taiwan uninterruptedly for more than five decades until 2000, its ranks are rife with the "sitting on a palanquin culture" -- with its politicians used to passively waiting for other people to pave the way for them to harvest their rewards and few willing to blaze a trail to explore new frontiers.
Only if King, with his resourcefulness and activism, can infuse new spirit into the KMT apparatus, will Ma's pledge to overhaul the century-old party be realized. LIBERTY TIMES No-one is an idiot
Premier Wu Den-yi is wrong to describe independence advocates as "idiots."
The majority of Taiwanese people do not want to be unified with China and a series of public opinion surveys have repeatedly confirmed this.

This is why the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has to wrap up its ultimate goal of unifying Taiwan with China in the guise of signing a cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement, which will eventually integrate both sides into a "one China" market.

With such a scenario looming, advocating independence is a wise and responsible strategy. According to the San Francisco Peace Treaty, Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to the people of Taiwan. Local people should stand up to safeguard this independent status quo and work even harder to make it a normal country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth round of cross-strait talks to open Dec. 22 in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:41:52 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The fourth round of talks between the chief cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators on each side -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will be held Dec. 22 in Taichung, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Thursday.

The main purpose of the meeting will be to sign four cross-strait agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
Chen is scheduled to arrive in the central city Dec. 21, according to an itinerary released by the MAC.

A seminar on Chinese investment in Taiwan will be held Dec. 23 on the sidelines of the talks, after which Chen and his delegation will tour Taichung's peripheral areas, including the popular tourist attraction of Sun Moon Lake, before returning to Beijing Dec. 25.
According to MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun, there are no arrangements for Chen to attend banquets hosted by political parties or businessmen during his visit.
However, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan will meet Chen Dec. 22 in Taichung, Liu said, adding that there will also be a meeting between Chen and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu on an as-yet undetermined date.
Also Thursday, Chao Chien-min, another MAC vice chairman, said there are no plans by the Taichung city government to set up a protest zone during the talks.

The pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party had earlier announced a plan to hold a demonstration in Taichung Dec. 20 to voice their objections to the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
In addition, more than 10 DPP-leaning groups in central Taiwan will also hold protests during Chen's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to aid industries affected by trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:30:13 (By Liu Cheng-chin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The government will help set up stores dedicated to selling Taiwanese products in order to solve the product distribution difficulties that local manufacturers could face following the signing of a proposed free trade pact with China, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Minister Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday.

Lai made the promise in response to a call by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lu Chia-chen for the government to come up with measures to help market local products via expanded distribution channels as the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China could have a negative impact on some traditional industries.

Once the ECFA is signed, products made by traditional industries in China will enjoy tariff-free entry into Taiwan's market, which will lead to an influx of cheap substandard goods from China and severely hurt local industries, Lu said at a legislative session.

According to Lu, Taiwanese products are of high quality, so the government should work to expand the distribution channels for local products in anticipation of cutthroat competition after the ECFA is signed.

Lai admitted that product distribution has long been a big problem for small- and medium-sized enterprises and that traditional industries have expressed concern over the issue several times over the past six years.
In addition to the MAC, the Ministry of Economic Affairs also agreed with the proposal to set up stores specifically for Taiwanese goods, Lu added.

To ease the potential impact of the ECFA, the MOEA plans to earmark NT$95 billion (US$2.94 billion) over the next 10 years to assist Taiwanese industries affected by the ECFA to enhance or transform their operations, according to Lai.

Meanwhile that day, a number of representatives from Taiwan's top 10 traditional industries, including towel, bedding, footwear, underwear, garment, sock, leather and ceramic manufacturers, rallied in front of the Legislative Yuan to protest against the ECFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung commemorates 30th anniversary of `Formosa Incident'
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:50:16 (By Cheng chi-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Thirty years after a demonstration in Kaohsiung turned into a brutal confrontation between the pro-democracy opposition and the authorities Dec. 10, 1979, the Kaohsiung city government is sponsoring a series of commemorative activities to mark the struggle for democracy and human rights.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, one of the opposition activists who attended the rally in front of the Kaohsiung headquarters of Formosa Magazine and who was arrested and jailed for several years for her part in the Formosa Incident, or Kaohsiung Incident as it is known internationally, visited an exhibition of photos and archives at the former headquarters of the magazine Thursday.

Looking back over the past 30 years, Chen said she had mixed feelings about the incident and the years that followed, since it was the first time she had stepped into the building that housed the magazine.

Formosa Magazine was created in the summer of 1979 by a group of people calling for an end to the martial law and demanding democratic elections and the lifting of a ban on unauthorized newspapers and political parties.
The incident was sparked when magazine staff and opposition politicians held a rally to mark World Human Rights Day in Kaohsiung under tight police surveillance.

Lamenting the fleeting 30 years, Chen said she was grateful toward the land that nourished the aspirations for democracy and freedom, toward the people who came to their protection and defense when they were under trial, and toward the families of those jailed, for their understanding and support.

Some of the Formosa comrades, like the late Legislator Huang Hsin- chieh, have died and some have taken different paths, Chen went on, adding that she honors the decisions of those who declined to take part in the commemorative activities.

Former Chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party Shih Ming-teh, for instance, refused to attend, while former President Chen Shui-bian, who as a young lawyer represented some of those put on trial by the KMT following the incident, is in detention, conducting an appeal against his life sentence for graft and corruption.

The Kaohsiung city government and various civic groups started the commemorative program in mid-November, including seminars, a photo and archive exhibition, a concert, a symposium and a mass rally slated for Dec. 12 in downtown Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes three tennis gold medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:53:07 (By Oscar Wu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei took three gold and two silver medals in the tennis event and one silver in the cycling event at the East Asian Games in Hong Kong Thursday.

Taiwan swept the board in the mixed doubles final, which saw Chuang Chia-jung and Yi Chu-huan edge out compatriots Hsieh Su-wei and Lee Hsin-han 6-3, 6-7, 7-5 to win gold, leaving silver for Hsieh and Lee.
Earlier that day, Chuang and Hsieh won gold in the women's doubles after defeating South Korea's Kim Song Jung and Lee Jin A in straight sets 6-0, 6-3.
Taiwan's Chang Kai Chen pulled off the women's singles title after coming from behind to beat China's Zhang Shuai 4-6, 7-6, 6-2.
In the men's doubles final, Taiwan's Li Chu-huan and Lee Hsin-han lost to China's Zeng Shao-xuan and Zhang Ze 4-6, 6-7, 4-7 to win silver.
However, the result was not a satisfactory one for Taiwan's tennis players, as they failed to beat their own record of four gold medals won at the last East Asian Games in Macau in 2005.
Chen Nan, chief coach of Taiwan's national tennis team for international competitions, said the games were merely seen as a warm up for the 2010 Asian Games in Guangzhou, China.
Also Thursday, Taiwanese cyclist Huang Ho-hsun finished second in the Individual Road Race for Women, winning Taiwan's second silver medal in the cycling events. China's Liu Xiahui won gold.
At the close of Thursday's competition, Taiwan ranked fifth among the nine states and regions taking part in the games, with six golds, 22 silvers and 20 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman recovering after heart transplant
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:55:20 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Tzu Chi General Hospital announced Thursday that it had carried out its first successful heart transplant surgery on a woman in her 60s who had suffered from left ventricular aneurysm.
The patient, identified only by her surname Liao, was discharged from the hospital that day after making a full recovery.
"This is the first time in 30 years that I have felt my heart is beating powerfully," Liao said.
According to the hospital, the woman's cardiac function had been declining since she gave birth to her second child more than 30 years ago.
She was diagnosed with left ventricular aneurysm -- a bulge in the lower chamber of the heart -- after developing severe symptoms such as chest pain and breathing difficulty in recent years.

When a left ventricular reconstructive surgery and a cardioverter defibrillator implant failed to improve her condition, she was put on a heart transplant waiting list, and last month finally obtained a donor heart and underwent the transplant surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Net tax revenues up 9 percent in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:17:21 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The central government collected NT$146.4 billion (US$4.53 billion) in net tax revenues in November, up 9 percent from the same month of the previous year -- the first year-on-year rise since March, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Thursday.
However, for the first 11 months of this year, the government garnered NT$1.43 trillion in tax revenue, a decrease of NT$243.4 billion, or 14.6 percent year- on-year, the statistics show.
Hit by the global economic downturn, Taiwan's net tax revenue in the 11 month- period posted the largest annual decrease in the country's history.

Lin Li-chen, the ministry's statistics chief, said that the 11-month tax revenue accounted for 80 percent of the budgeted NT$1.7844 trillion -- which was also the lowest rate for the same period in recorded history.

Income tax revenue -- including corporate income tax and individual comprehensive income tax revenue -- amounted to NT$613.6 billion in the 11 months, recording a year-on-year decline of NT$191.7 billion, or 23.8 percent.
Income tax revenue, which was affected most by the economic downturn, accounts for almost 50 percent of the country's total tax revenues.
Tax offices collected NT$45.8 billion in business turnover tax last month -- the highest level in a year, up 4.9 percent from the same month of last year.
Land value tax, which the government just began collecting from November, reached NT$36 billion, up 17.9 percent year-on-year.

Commodity tax revenue increased by 84.6 percent to NT$11.4 billion in November, while the share transaction tax revenue of NT$8.2 billion represented a rise of 112 percent, according to MOF statistics.

With the economy starting to recover, some tax categories started to show revenue improvements, said Lin, adding that the monthly commodity tax revenue has been standing above NT$10 billion for the past six months, while the share transaction tax revenue increased by 10.2 percent, to total NT$94.4 billion for the 11 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carbon emission reduction efforts pay off at schools
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:22:31 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Government efforts to cut back on carbon dioxide emissions have paid off at schools and universities, with the campaign helping to save over NT$700 million (US$21.54 million) in electricity costs at educational institutions around the country last year.

According to the Ministry of Education (MOE) , 312 universities and colleges, as well as 248 senior high schools and 59 junior high and elementary schools, have been taking part in a carbon reduction campaign since 2007.

Comparing the schools' combined consumption levels in 2008 with the figure recorded for 2006, they consumed about 7.8 less electricity last year than they did in 2006, representing savings of more than NT$700 million in electricity costs, according to MOE statistics.

Among all the participating schools, vocational senior high schools scored the highest rate of 12.31 percent in slashing carbon emissions, followed by colleges and universities, which recorded an 8.03 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, an environmental protection task force under the MOE said.
Senior high schools posted a reduction rate of 7.23 percent, ahead of junior high schools with 6.54 percent and elementary schools with 6.07 percent, it went on.
The MOE hopes that all the country's schools and colleges will achieve an average electricity use reduction of 7 percent per year by 2015, it added.
Chang Zih-chao, executive secretary of the MOE task force, ascribed inadequate measures and ageing lighting or air conditioning equipment to some schools' failure to cut electricity use.
The MOE will allocate more budget to help these schools phase out their inefficient equipment in the coming years, he added.
Yuan Ze University was among the 13 green universities selected this year by the MOE for their outstanding performance in cutting back electricity consumption on their campuses.
Yuan Ze University has slashed some 4.6 percent off its electricity use this year, saving it some NT$19 million in electricity costs.
Wei Jung-chung, head of the privately run university's general affairs department, said it is very important to build a carbon-reducing concept among students.

Wei said students have to pay for the lights if they want to play basketball or tennis on school facilities. At the same time, devices are installed in classrooms' air conditioning units and lamps so that they switch off automatically at the end of the class and switch on 10 minutes before the next one starts, he explained.

Generally speaking, however, public universities such as National Taiwan University, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology and Taichung University of Education (TUE) were more effective than their private counterparts in cutting back on electricity during the 2007-2008 period, Wei said.
The top 21 public universities succeeded in reducing about a total of 15,000 metric tons of greenhouse gas -- equivalent to a saving of NT$44 million in electricity costs, he noted.

Yi Cheng-ming, general affairs department director at the TUE, pointed out that in addition to installing automated devices to regulate electricity use, it is of maximum importance to raise carbon reduction awareness among students.
To this end, the TUE has personnel periodically patrol the campus to persuade students not to waste electricity, he added.
