DOC.HEADLINE: New DPP secretary-general named
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:54:39 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen announced late Thursday that the party's campaign strategist in the Dec. 5 local elections, Su Chia-chuan, will succeed Wu Nai-jen as party secretary-general.

Tsai said that Su's appointment signifies the succession of what she described as the party's "intermediate generation." She also lauded the administrative experience of Su, who has previously served as Pingtung magistrate (December 1997-April 2002) , minister of the interior (April 2004-January 2006) and minister of the Council of Agriculture (January 2006-May 2008).

Wu tendered his resignation two days earlier, just days after the elections. While the party's performance exceeded expectations, Wu said he was both physically and mentally exhausted after the election battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait taxation agreement benefits taxpayers: finance minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:26:21 (By Ye-fong Lin, Chao-fen Kao and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A proposed taxation agreement with China expected to be signed during the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks later this month will protect Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, lower the burden on taxpayers and increase the government's tax revenues in the long run, Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Thursday.

Lee also gave an assurance that information on neither individuals nor companies will be revealed during tax information exchanges between the two sides, in line with international tax treaty protocols. Such information will only be supplied when there is a specific need for tax inspection in cases of major tax evasion, he added.

He made the remarks at a session at the Legislative Yuan in which legislators voiced concern that the taxation agreement might enable China to obtain more financial information about Taiwanese businessmen operating there, which could affect their future operations.

Lee said the agreement closely follows guidelines set forth by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) and the United Nations in their model tax convention documents. Taiwan has signed similar tax treaties with 16 countries.

Among those 16 countries, Lee said, there have been only eight cases of tax information exchange -- all of them in relation to major tax evasion or avoidance -- in the past five years, with four cases initiated by Taiwan.
He also said it would be impossible for either side to send officials across the strait to conduct tax inspections.

The taxation agreement will cover issues such as the taxation rights of each government, the avoidance of double taxation and mutual assistance on taxation matters. In recent talks, both sides have reached consensus on most of the contents of the agreement, including tax allocation and exchange of tax information.
President Ma Ying-jeou has said that all cross-strait agreements, including the taxation one, must be open and transparent to the public, and must be reviewed and approved by the Legislative Yuan.

Lee said that without the taxation agreement, the two sides can hide their incomes from each other, causing a lot of unfairness, and that the agreement will help improve information transparency and better protect Taiwanese businessmen working in China.
In the long term, the agreement could also help attract more Chinese corporate investment into Taiwan, further increasing the government's tax revenues, Lee said.

The agreement will also ensure that Taiwanese workers who stay for less than 183 days per year in China will only have to pay taxes on their salaries received in China to the Chinese government rather than suffering double taxation.
There are about 1 million Taiwanese people working in China, who mostly allocate a larger portion of their income to be received in Taiwan so they can enjoy the country's lower income tax rate.

In addition, as the amount of Taiwanese investment in China is far bigger than the amount of Chinese investment in Taiwan, the Chinese government will need to give up its taxation right or apply lower tax rates for some of its income after the agreement takes effect.

Taiwan's net tax revenue for the first 11 months of this year totaled NT$1.43 trillion, representing a 14.6 percent drop from the same period of last year, according to the latest statistics released by the ministry Thursday.

The fourth and latest round of cross-strait talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is scheduled to take place in Taichung City Dec. 22-23.

The negotiations will mainly focus on four issues -- fishery cooperation, avoidance of double taxation, examination and certification of standards and the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should boost domestic consumption, investment: economist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:32:35 (By Cheng Yun-shuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As economies around the world are undergoing structural reshuffles, Taiwan should seek to restructure its economy by boosting domestic consumption and investment, Liu Yi-ju, chief economics consultant to the Chinatrust Financial Holding Co. said Thursday.

Liu said at a forum on economic prospects for 2010 that Taiwan has been marginalized for some time in the process of regional economic integration. With the improvements in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, however, the country now has the chance to reverse the situation, according to Liu.
She added, however, that should Taiwan fail to grasp the opportunity for change, it will remain in the back seat in terms of economic growth next year.

Stressing Taiwan's advantages of talent and solid infrastructure for industrial development, Liu said it is possible for Taiwan to return to the international stage in terms of economics and trade, even though many international enterprises which have been focusing on China had abandoned Taiwan over the past few years.
She suggested that Taiwan should try to lure international capital in addition to its efforts to attract Chinese investors.

The economist, a former advisor to the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that instead of relying on exports to boost the economy, Taiwan should shift its focus from foreign trade to domestic consumption and investment.

While Taiwan's economic growth in the past relied heavily on exports and foreign reserves from trade surplus, the trade surplus accounted for only 4 percent to 8 percent of the nation's gross domestic product (GDP).
On the other hand, domestic consumption accounted for 60 percent of the GDP, while domestic investment and government expenditure together accounted for more than 30 percent, according to Liu.
"It is as if a family is relying heavily on the youngest kid working at a fast food stand to earn the household's bread, while the elder brothers are idle," Liu said.
"Since the fast food stand has folded, it is time for all the brothers to do their shares of the work," Liu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:40:01 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Thursday: COMMERCIAL TIMES What if 'unequitable taxation" was an option in poll on public grievances?

Acting on Premier Wu Den-yi's directive, the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) recently conducted an online survey to identify the "top 10 public grievances," and found that exorbitant housing prices in urban areas was at the top of the list.
However, the respondents were given 15 pre-selected options from which to chose, which means that the survey results might not be fully reflective of the whole picture.
We wonder whether the main grievances would have been different if "unequitable taxation" was included on the RDEC-proposed list.
Unequitable taxation has been relatively less frequently discussed because tax issues can be very technical and the public tends be insufficiently informed about the details.

Only through academic research papers have we learned that eight of the 40 richest people in Taiwan, who each had annual incomes of over NT$100 million in 2002, did not have to pay any income tax that year, and that average wage earners contribute more than 70 percent to the government's annual tax revenues.

It was not until early this year when the government lowered the inheritance and gift tax rates to 10 percent that we realized only 5 percent of local taxpayers -- particularly the 200 most wealthy people who were originally subject to a 50 percent tax rate -- had benefited from the new measure.

During a recent inspection tour of the Ministry of Finance, some Control Yuan members took ministry officials to task over the lowering of the inheritance and gift tax rate and what they said was the country's unusually low rate of capital gain tax. In our view, finance officials have failed to give any convincing explanations about the two issues.

We are not opposed to the government's efforts to determine the main sources of public grievances through opinion polls. But we suggest that "unequitable taxation" be included on the list next time such a survey is conducted. ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS: Policy initiatives most needed to rev up economy
President Ma Ying-jeou has vowed to improve the macro environment after the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 local elections.
Ma also recognizes that "revving up the economy" is an effective short-cut to improving the macro economy.

If he wants such endeavors to help boost the KMT's showing in next year's elections of the mayors of the country's five municipalities, then his administration should present the meat of its policy incentives as soon as possible and take action with full vigor and urgency.
However, there is irony in the government's budget plan for the coming year.

At a time when most world powers are adopting expansion strategies to sustain economic growth in the wake of the year-long global recession, Taiwan seems to be joining the ranks of the first group of countries that have ended their stimulus measures.
According to the 2010 budget plan, the government's regular budget and special budget will both fall short of this year's amounts, while public investment will also contract.

If Taiwan does not want to see itself knocked out at a time when the global economy is on the track of slow recovery, the Ma administration should correct such flawed budget planning, come up with well-devised policy initiatives and act resolutely to accelerate economic growth. CHINA TIMES Legislative speaker's temper should have flared earlier

The even-tempered Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng finally lost his cool Monday when opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers again paralyzed the legislature by besieging the speaker's podium to protest the government's decision to relax restrictions on U.S. beef imports.
The DPP, which holds 27 of the legislature's 113 seats, has managed to disrupt legislative floor meetings for more than one month over the U.S. beef import issue.
Wang angrily criticized the DPP legislators' boycott strategy, describing it as "very, very inappropriate" and "senseless."
Wang has reason to blast the DPP, but we must remind him that the ruling Kuomintang should also be blamed for the Legislature's poor efficiency.
People on the street are entitled to ask why the KMT, with more than 90 legislative seats, has been unable to pass legislation that is critical to the implementation of the government's policies.

Some KMT lawmakers like to ridicule President and KMT Chairman Ma Ying-jeou over what they call his incompetence, but they should be aware that one of the reasons behind Ma's fading popularity is his administration's inefficiency, as many of his policy initiatives and reform programs are shelved in the Legislature.

If KMT lawmakers sit idly and let the DPP hold up the legislative proceedings over the beef trade issue, it will be a no-win situation for both parties. APPLE DAILY New appointment epitomizes Ma's reform commitment

Ma's surprise appointment of his most trusted confidant, King Pu-tsung, as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, sends a clear message that he will continue streamlining the KMT monolith in line with the principles of "integrity and capability."

King and Ma share some common features in their characters. Both are characterized by a strong moral ethos, self-motivation and drive, and political cleanliness. King is a bit more smart and shrewd and takes comfort in playing the role of a behind-the-scenes strategist and adviser.

Therefore, the duo have developed a close partnership. During Ma's tenure as Taipei mayor, King served as his door-guard in his capacity as deputy mayor, helping to steer away many filthy politicians and shady political deals and thereby allowing Ma to maintain his clean image.

We are pleased to see that Ma remains committed to reforming the KMT after the party suffered its election setback. Should that continue to be the case, we hope Ma will delegate full power to King so that he can wipe out the party's old guard with their shady criminal backgrounds. UNITED DAILY NEWS Can King Pu-tsung change KMT culture?
Some KMT lawmakers' strong reaction to Ma's appointment of King Pu-tsung as new KMT secretary-general signals how challenging and tough his new role will be.

As the KMT once ruled Taiwan uninterruptedly for more than five decades until 2000, its ranks are rife with the "sitting on a palanquin culture" -- with its politicians used to passively waiting for other people to pave the way for them to harvest their rewards and few willing to blaze a trail to explore new frontiers.
Only if King, with his resourcefulness and activism, can infuse new spirit into the KMT apparatus, will Ma's pledge to overhaul the century-old party be realized. LIBERTY TIMES No-one is an idiot
Premier Wu Den-yi is wrong to describe independence advocates as "idiots."
The majority of Taiwanese people do not want to be unified with China and a series of public opinion surveys have repeatedly confirmed this.

This is why the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has to wrap up its ultimate goal of unifying Taiwan with China in the guise of signing a cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement, which will eventually integrate both sides into a "one China" market.

With such a scenario looming, advocating independence is a wise and responsible strategy. According to the San Francisco Peace Treaty, Taiwan's sovereignty belongs to the people of Taiwan. Local people should stand up to safeguard this independent status quo and work even harder to make it a normal country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth round of cross-strait talks to open Dec. 22 in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 19:41:52 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The fourth round of talks between the chief cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators on each side -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will be held Dec. 22 in Taichung, the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Thursday.

The main purpose of the meeting will be to sign four cross-strait agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
Chen is scheduled to arrive in the central city Dec. 21, according to an itinerary released by the MAC.

A seminar on Chinese investment in Taiwan will be held Dec. 23 on the sidelines of the talks, after which Chen and his delegation will tour Taichung's peripheral areas, including the popular tourist attraction of Sun Moon Lake, before returning to Beijing Dec. 25.
According to MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun, there are no arrangements for Chen to attend banquets hosted by political parties or businessmen during his visit.
However, MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan will meet Chen Dec. 22 in Taichung, Liu said, adding that there will also be a meeting between Chen and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu on an as-yet undetermined date.
Also Thursday, Chao Chien-min, another MAC vice chairman, said there are no plans by the Taichung city government to set up a protest zone during the talks.

The pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party had earlier announced a plan to hold a demonstration in Taichung Dec. 20 to voice their objections to the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
In addition, more than 10 DPP-leaning groups in central Taiwan will also hold protests during Chen's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung commemorates 30th anniversary of `Formosa Incident'
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:50:16 (By Cheng chi-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Thirty years after a demonstration in Kaohsiung turned into a brutal confrontation between the pro-democracy opposition and the authorities Dec. 10, 1979, the Kaohsiung city government is sponsoring a series of commemorative activities to mark the struggle for democracy and human rights.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, one of the opposition activists who attended the rally in front of the Kaohsiung headquarters of Formosa Magazine and who was arrested and jailed for several years for her part in the Formosa Incident, or Kaohsiung Incident as it is known internationally, visited an exhibition of photos and archives at the former headquarters of the magazine Thursday.

Looking back over the past 30 years, Chen said she had mixed feelings about the incident and the years that followed, since it was the first time she had stepped into the building that housed the magazine.

Formosa Magazine was created in the summer of 1979 by a group of people calling for an end to the martial law and demanding democratic elections and the lifting of a ban on unauthorized newspapers and political parties.
The incident was sparked when magazine staff and opposition politicians held a rally to mark World Human Rights Day in Kaohsiung under tight police surveillance.

Lamenting the fleeting 30 years, Chen said she was grateful toward the land that nourished the aspirations for democracy and freedom, toward the people who came to their protection and defense when they were under trial, and toward the families of those jailed, for their understanding and support.

Some of the Formosa comrades, like the late Legislator Huang Hsin- chieh, have died and some have taken different paths, Chen went on, adding that she honors the decisions of those who declined to take part in the commemorative activities.

Former Chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party Shih Ming-teh, for instance, refused to attend, while former President Chen Shui-bian, who as a young lawyer represented some of those put on trial by the KMT following the incident, is in detention, conducting an appeal against his life sentence for graft and corruption.

The Kaohsiung city government and various civic groups started the commemorative program in mid-November, including seminars, a photo and archive exhibition, a concert, a symposium and a mass rally slated for Dec. 12 in downtown Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan takes three tennis gold medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:53:07 (By Oscar Wu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei took three gold and two silver medals in the tennis event and one silver in the cycling event at the East Asian Games in Hong Kong Thursday.

Taiwan swept the board in the mixed doubles final, which saw Chuang Chia-jung and Yi Chu-huan edge out compatriots Hsieh Su-wei and Lee Hsin-han 6-3, 6-7, 7-5 to win gold, leaving silver for Hsieh and Lee.
Earlier that day, Chuang and Hsieh won gold in the women's doubles after defeating South Korea's Kim Song Jung and Lee Jin A in straight sets 6-0, 6-3.
Taiwan's Chang Kai Chen pulled off the women's singles title after coming from behind to beat China's Zhang Shuai 4-6, 7-6, 6-2.
In the men's doubles final, Taiwan's Li Chu-huan and Lee Hsin-han lost to China's Zeng Shao-xuan and Zhang Ze 4-6, 6-7, 4-7 to win silver.
However, the result was not a satisfactory one for Taiwan's tennis players, as they failed to beat their own record of four gold medals won at the last East Asian Games in Macau in 2005.
Chen Nan, chief coach of Taiwan's national tennis team for international competitions, said the games were merely seen as a warm up for the 2010 Asian Games in Guangzhou, China.
Also Thursday, Taiwanese cyclist Huang Ho-hsun finished second in the Individual Road Race for Women, winning Taiwan's second silver medal in the cycling events. China's Liu Xiahui won gold.
At the close of Thursday's competition, Taiwan ranked fifth among the nine states and regions taking part in the games, with six golds, 22 silvers and 20 bronzes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Woman recovering after heart transplant
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 21:55:20 (By Wang Hong-kuo and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Tzu Chi General Hospital announced Thursday that it had carried out its first successful heart transplant surgery on a woman in her 60s who had suffered from left ventricular aneurysm.
The patient, identified only by her surname Liao, was discharged from the hospital that day after making a full recovery.
"This is the first time in 30 years that I have felt my heart is beating powerfully," Liao said.
According to the hospital, the woman's cardiac function had been declining since she gave birth to her second child more than 30 years ago.
She was diagnosed with left ventricular aneurysm -- a bulge in the lower chamber of the heart -- after developing severe symptoms such as chest pain and breathing difficulty in recent years.

When a left ventricular reconstructive surgery and a cardioverter defibrillator implant failed to improve her condition, she was put on a heart transplant waiting list, and last month finally obtained a donor heart and underwent the transplant surgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Net tax revenues up 9 percent in November
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:17:21 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The central government collected NT$146.4 billion (US$4.53 billion) in net tax revenues in November, up 9 percent from the same month of the previous year -- the first year-on-year rise since March, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported Thursday.
However, for the first 11 months of this year, the government garnered NT$1.43 trillion in tax revenue, a decrease of NT$243.4 billion, or 14.6 percent year- on-year, the statistics show.
Hit by the global economic downturn, Taiwan's net tax revenue in the 11 month- period posted the largest annual decrease in the country's history.

Lin Li-chen, the ministry's statistics chief, said that the 11-month tax revenue accounted for 80 percent of the budgeted NT$1.7844 trillion -- which was also the lowest rate for the same period in recorded history.

Income tax revenue -- including corporate income tax and individual comprehensive income tax revenue -- amounted to NT$613.6 billion in the 11 months, recording a year-on-year decline of NT$191.7 billion, or 23.8 percent.
Income tax revenue, which was affected most by the economic downturn, accounts for almost 50 percent of the country's total tax revenues.
Tax offices collected NT$45.8 billion in business turnover tax last month -- the highest level in a year, up 4.9 percent from the same month of last year.
Land value tax, which the government just began collecting from November, reached NT$36 billion, up 17.9 percent year-on-year.

Commodity tax revenue increased by 84.6 percent to NT$11.4 billion in November, while the share transaction tax revenue of NT$8.2 billion represented a rise of 112 percent, according to MOF statistics.

With the economy starting to recover, some tax categories started to show revenue improvements, said Lin, adding that the monthly commodity tax revenue has been standing above NT$10 billion for the past six months, while the share transaction tax revenue increased by 10.2 percent, to total NT$94.4 billion for the 11 months.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carbon emission reduction efforts pay off at schools
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:22:31 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Government efforts to cut back on carbon dioxide emissions have paid off at schools and universities, with the campaign helping to save over NT$700 million (US$21.54 million) in electricity costs at educational institutions around the country last year.

According to the Ministry of Education (MOE) , 312 universities and colleges, as well as 248 senior high schools and 59 junior high and elementary schools, have been taking part in a carbon reduction campaign since 2007.

Comparing the schools' combined consumption levels in 2008 with the figure recorded for 2006, they consumed about 7.8 less electricity last year than they did in 2006, representing savings of more than NT$700 million in electricity costs, according to MOE statistics.

Among all the participating schools, vocational senior high schools scored the highest rate of 12.31 percent in slashing carbon emissions, followed by colleges and universities, which recorded an 8.03 percent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions, an environmental protection task force under the MOE said.
Senior high schools posted a reduction rate of 7.23 percent, ahead of junior high schools with 6.54 percent and elementary schools with 6.07 percent, it went on.
The MOE hopes that all the country's schools and colleges will achieve an average electricity use reduction of 7 percent per year by 2015, it added.
Chang Zih-chao, executive secretary of the MOE task force, ascribed inadequate measures and ageing lighting or air conditioning equipment to some schools' failure to cut electricity use.
The MOE will allocate more budget to help these schools phase out their inefficient equipment in the coming years, he added.
Yuan Ze University was among the 13 green universities selected this year by the MOE for their outstanding performance in cutting back electricity consumption on their campuses.
Yuan Ze University has slashed some 4.6 percent off its electricity use this year, saving it some NT$19 million in electricity costs.
Wei Jung-chung, head of the privately run university's general affairs department, said it is very important to build a carbon-reducing concept among students.

Wei said students have to pay for the lights if they want to play basketball or tennis on school facilities. At the same time, devices are installed in classrooms' air conditioning units and lamps so that they switch off automatically at the end of the class and switch on 10 minutes before the next one starts, he explained.

Generally speaking, however, public universities such as National Taiwan University, National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology and Taichung University of Education (TUE) were more effective than their private counterparts in cutting back on electricity during the 2007-2008 period, Wei said.
The top 21 public universities succeeded in reducing about a total of 15,000 metric tons of greenhouse gas -- equivalent to a saving of NT$44 million in electricity costs, he noted.

Yi Cheng-ming, general affairs department director at the TUE, pointed out that in addition to installing automated devices to regulate electricity use, it is of maximum importance to raise carbon reduction awareness among students.
To this end, the TUE has personnel periodically patrol the campus to persuade students not to waste electricity, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: New DPP secretary-general named
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 10 (CNA) 12/10/09 22:54:39 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen announced late Thursday that the party's campaign strategist in the Dec. 5 local elections, Su Chia-chuan, will succeed Wu Nai-jen as party secretary-general.

Tsai said that Su's appointment signifies the succession of what she described as the party's "intermediate generation." She also lauded the administrative experience of Su, who has previously served as Pingtung magistrate (December 1997-April 2002) , minister of the interior (April 2004-January 2006) and minister of the Council of Agriculture (January 2006-May 2008).

Wu tendered his resignation two days earlier, just days after the elections. While the party's performance exceeded expectations, Wu said he was both physically and mentally exhausted after the election battle.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 11, or the 25th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1816: The British restore Java, Indonesia, to the Dutch.
1853: Britain annexes Nagpur, one of the leading Mahrata states in India.
1927: The Chinese Communist Party stages a riot in Kwangchow (Canton) which results in massive burning and looting.
1935: The Nationalist government sets up the Hopei-Chahar Political Affairs Commission, with Soong Chih-yuan being appointed as chairman.
1936: George VI becomes King of England following the abdication of Edward VIII.
1941: The United States declares war against Germany and Italy during World War Two.
1951: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly is established, with Huang Chao-chin being elected as speaker.
1961: Two companies of U.S. military helicopters arrive in Saigon on an aircraft carrier, representing the first direct U.S. military support for the South Vietnam regime's battle against communist guerrillas.
1970: Taipei Mayor Henry Kao is impeached by the Control Yuan for breaking the law and for misfeasance.
1972: The U.S. Apollo 17 astronauts land on the moon and begin extensive exploration of the lunar surface.
1973: Maj. Gen. Slade Nash, newly appointed chief of the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
1974: The Executive Yuan of the ROC approves the Sino-Ivory Coast Agricultural Development Technical Cooperation Pact.
1974: Ten "outstanding entrepreneurs" of the year are awarded plaques and citations in Taipei.
1976: The opening ceremony of the National Conference on Atmospheric Science is held at the Central Weather Bureau in Taipei with some 100 experts participating.
1976: Eric G. Sandstrong Jr., deputy commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars of the United States, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1976: Lt. Gen. Kung Ling-cheng becomes head of the National Police Administration and concurrently the director of the Taiwan Provincial Police Department, succeeding Lt. Gen. Chou Chu-tsun.
1977: Kaohsiung County's Hsingta Port, the largest fishing port in Taiwan, is inaugurated and formally opened for use.
1989: Liu Pin-yen, a mainland Chinese writer residing in the United States, arrives in Taipei with his wife for a visit.
1990: Albania announces it will allow the formation of independent political parties.
1991: Leaders of 12 European countries agree to establish a loose federation with a common foreign policy and a single currency by 1999.
1994: Russian troops and armored vehicles roll into Chechnya in a bid to restore Moscow's control over the breakaway region.
1996: Tung Chee-hwa, a shipping magnate, sweeps to victory in the election for Hong Kong's leader-in-waiting to take over when the British colony reverts to Chinese rule.
1998: A Thai Airways Airbus crashes into a flooded rubber plantation, killing 101 people in southern Thailand.
1999: Chinese Taipei wins an across-the-board victory at the Czech Table Tennis Open with both the men and women's teams gaining group singles and group doubles victories.
2000: David Hu, director-general of the South and Central American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is confirmed by MOFA to be the new ROC ambassador to Panama.
2001: Newly elected county magistrates and legislators from Kinmen and Matsu meet in Beijing with Li Bingcai, deputy director of the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council, to discuss exchanges between the mainland and the two Taiwan-controlled islands.
2001: The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, impeaches Ting Yuan- chin, former director-general of the National Police Administration, for filing a fraudulent report on payments for a luxury house.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man who is not serious will not inspire respect; what he learns will not remain permanent. Make conscientiousness and sincerity your first principles. Have no friends who are not as yourself. When you have bad habits do no hesitate to change them."

The weighted price index fell 119.51 points, or 1.53 percent, to close at 7,677.91 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: cross-strait tax pact
DOC.DATELINE: 12/11/09 10:36:20 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait are scheduled to sign a tax agreement in central Taiwan's Taichung City Dec. 22 to avoid the double taxation of investors on each other's territory. While senior officials say the accord will help enhance the transparency of tax information, some lawmakers are skeptical of its benefits for Taiwan.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments: China Times:

Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Thursday that there is a "blind spot" in Taiwan's control of tax information concerning Taiwanese businesses operating in China and that once the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign a taxation agreement, the transparency of cross-strait tax data will increase.

In that way, the government will be able to control tax evasion or avoidance by Taiwanese businessmen through a third country, and it will also be able to protect businesses that pay tax in a legal manner, Lee said.

Lee pointed out that there are around 800,000 Taiwanese businessmen who currently have accumulated investments of NT$80.5 billion (US$2.5 billion) in China. The data on tax figures for these people, however, are hazy.

The Ministry of Finance only knows that they have paid their comprehensive income tax totaling around NT$1 billion each year in Taiwan, Lee said, which he described as a blind spot. (Dec. 11, 2009) Liberty Times:

Lawmakers from the "pan-blue camp" have cast doubt on the government's stance that Taiwan will benefit from the signing of a cross-strait tax agreement, which, according to the minister of finance, will protect Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, lower the burden on taxpayers and increase the government's tax revenues in the long run.

At a Legislative Yuan Committee of Finance meeting Tuesday, several legislators of the ruling Kuomintang conveyed the concern of many Taiwanese businessmen over a possible integrated tax inspection by the governments on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The lawmakers claimed that the planned agreement will in fact help Beijing collect tax from businessmen from Taiwan but will lead to a decline in Taiwan's tax revenues (Dec. 11, 2009).

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: Bureaucracy

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih panned official red tape at a weekly Cabinet meeting Thursday, saying the nonsensical working style of the country's bureaucracy lets the people down.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments: China Times:

Premier Wu Den-yih expressed fury Thursday over the inefficiency of some government agencies in performing their duties, which he summarized as a mix of inertia, procrastination and bureaucratic red tape.

At a regular Executive Yuan meeting, Wu ordered all Cabinet agencies to boost their administrative efficiency, saying that the last thing he wants to see as premier is pointless document-shuffling -- "because the people cannot wait." (Dec. 11, 2009) United Daily News:

Premier Wu Den-yih lashed out at some Cabinet-level agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Public Construction Commission, for their snail-paced planning on and implementation of public construction projects that are of vital importance to the day-to-day lives of the people.
"Bureaucratic red tape is a waste of time and life, and we the government owe an apology to the country and its people for being inadequate and inefficient," he said. (Dec. 11, 2009) Liberty Times:

Premier Wu Den-yih said he gave directives immediately after the devastating Morakot Typhoon that wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan in August to have earthwork banks established in disaster-prone areas to help prevent future landslides and mudslides.
He complained that nearly four months later, he still has not seen any plans from the relevant government agencies. (Dec. 11, 2009) Commercial Times:

Saying that he had never and would never let documents lie unattended on his desk even for a night, the premier said he does not understand why a plan that can be mapped out in half an hour has taken several months to produce.
"It strikes me that our officials would feel they did not exist if they were to get rid of their bureaucratic red tape, " Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH assures H1N1 vaccine safe before national immunization starts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 12:35:25 (By Chang Ching-fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) and experts have again given their assurances of the safety of A(H1N1) vaccine as a national vaccination program is set to begin Saturday following initial immunizations targeting specific groups.

DOH Deputy Minister Chang Shan-chwen said that since the immunization program kicked off Nov. 1, 2.6 million people had been given shots as of Dec. 7. Among the 242 cases of possible side effects reported, most complained of dizziness, fever, headache, nausea, vomiting and shortness of breath.
Most of them recovered within 48 hours, but the 44 more serious cases included miscarriage, sudden death and weak legs.
Chang, as well as Lee Bin-yin from National Taiwan University Hospital and Chiu Nan-chang of Mackay Memorial Hospital, urged the public not to be alarmed by the figures.

They explained that even without the immunization program, there is a certain ratio of miscarriage, sudden death and neuritis, while the DOH observed that the ratio is no different to past years during seasonal flu vaccination programs.

City hospitals in Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as DOH hospitals around Taiwan, will hold a competition in which hospitals and doctors who have given the most shots will get commendations from the Central Epidemics Prevention Center, DOH officials said.
There will also be temporary immunization stations set up in big department stores, hypermarkets, railway stations and temples, the officials went on.
To encourage the public to get the shots, the DOH is offering agricultural produce, stationery sets and lucky draws at these stations, they added.

The already-completed vaccination program for specific groups targeted the priority groups of typhoon-affected victims living in shelters, high-risk medical personnel, elementary school students, pre-school children, pregnant women and seriously ill patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gambian students in Taiwan learning how to run gas stations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 13:22:13 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three college students from the Republic of The Gambia have recently begun an internship program at a gas station run by Taiwan's state-operated petroleum company, attracting public attention.
Several customers at the CPC Corp. gas station in southern Taiwan's Chiayi City said it was "new and interesting" to see foreign students working there.

Two of the students are girls -- Tsaton Jallow and Astatou Jallow -- who have been studying at National Taipei University of Technology for four years, and the other is Madun Sanyang, who studied in Britain for a year before coming to Taiwan, according to Lee Tien-chieh, head of the CPC's Chiayi-Tainan branch office.

They were assigned by the Gambia National Petroleum Company to take a three-week training program Dec. 7-25 on gas station operation and management in Taiwan, in anticipation of the establishment of the first state-run gas station in The Gambia, scheduled to open in 2010.
At present, there are four private companies involved in the liquid fuel retail business in the West African country.

Lee said the students will learn to operate the software and hardware at the gas station, explaining they must know how to handle oil tanks and oil-loading operations, how to operate the gas pumps and how to keep the accounts. They also need to learn standard procedures for pumping and handling complaints, he added.
The Gambia is the smallest country on mainland Africa, with an estimated population of 1.54 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tie-boosting efforts have yielded fruit: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 13:57:11 (By Lin Ye-fong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that his administration's efforts over the past year to boost and cement relations with Japan have yielded fruit, evidenced by a string of developments that have enhanced bilateral exchanges.

Addressing the opening of the 37th assembly of the Taiwan-Japan Economic Conference in Taipei, Ma said he is basically satisfied with what has been done by the two countries over the past year in terms of cementing bilateral ties, although he admitted that more could be done in the future.
Ma dismissed a Japanese daily's recent allegation that relations between Taiwan and Japan have been "abruptly frozen" since he took office in May 2008.
"The report was completely off-base," he said.

He told his audience that while one Japanese dietman had expressed worry that he would turn anti-Japan after being sworn in as Taiwan's new president, Ma said the politician's perspective of him has changed completely over the past year.
"I think you're pro-Japan now, " Ma quoted the dietman as saying to him during a recent visit to Taipei.

Ma said he hopes Japan will realize that his administration's efforts to improve relations with China do not run counter to its bid to enhance ties with Japan and that they should not be mistaken for a tilt toward Beijing, because the tempering of the cross-Taiwan Strait situation is consistent with regional and global interests.

He said that while Taiwan has improved its relations with China, it has also spared no efforts to increase exchanges with Japan, the United States and the European Union, and he stressed that it is vitally important that Taiwan should become a "responsible partner and a peace creator" if it wants to make a mark for itself and maintain good relations with the rest of the global community.

DOC.HEADLINE: Weather chief leaves for China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 14:42:41 (By Wang Shu-fen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The chief of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) left for China Friday to attend a seminar next week, as well as to pave the way for substantive meteorological cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

CWB Director-General Shin Tzay-chyn and Lin Hsiu-wen, deputy director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, along with several scholars, will attend the seminar that is being jointly sponsored by the meteorological societies on both sides of the strait.

Dismissing speculation that Shin's trip is related to the government's efforts to join the World Meteorological Organization -- a specialized agency of the United Nations, the Meteorological Society of the Republic of China said that Shin's visit is purely for technological and academic exchanges.
Cheng Ming-tian, director of the CWB's Weather Forecast Center, said that such exchanges will help contribute to substantive cooperation in meteorology across the strait.

He noted that although the two sides have established direct links, Taiwan often still has to rely on Japan and South Korea to obtain China-related meteorological information, which he said delays the timeline and means that the information received is often patchy.
"If both sides can swap meteorological information directly it will help upgrade the services we offer to the public," Cheng noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 16:07:36 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 117.16 points, or 1.52 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,795.07.
The local bourse opened at 7,709.96 and hit a low of 7,700.76 during the session.
A total of 4.65 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$134.75 billion (US$4.18 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues moving up the most at 3.13 percent. Paper and pulp issues advanced 1.79 percent, plastics and chemicals shares gained 1.57 percent, and machinery and electronics shares rose 1.5 percent.
Construction issues increased 1.39 percent, banking and financial shares moved up 1.03 percent, textile stocks rose 0.96 percent and cement stocks increased 0.94 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: French artist unveils vegetal walls in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 16:37:40 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A French artist unveiled two living walls composed of orchids at the National Theater Hall in Taipei Friday, vertical gardens that the environmentalist said are aimed at paying homage to both the flower and orchid growers in Taiwan.

Patrick Blanc, a botanist and artist who invented the concept of a vertical garden, told the Central News Agency in an interview that his creations can appeal to people of all ages and professions and encourage them to think more about nature.
"What I like, actually, is to try to put plants where people are not waiting for plants, " said Blanc, who calls his version of the concept "vegetal walls," from the French "mur vegetal."

"I want to show that life can be installed everywhere, " added the 56-year-old artist, whose passion for plants is self-evident in his hair, which has been dyed green for the past 25 years, and his green pants and shoes.
His two latest vertical gardens, both measuring 8.15-meters long and 5.7-meters wide, were unveiled at a ceremony Friday.

Blanc, who created a vertical garden in the National Concert Hall in 2007, said the two new walls at the National Theater Hall reflect the diversity of native orchid species in Taiwan and Southeast Asia and recognize the achievements of Taiwanese orchid hybridizers in developing unique, high quality orchids.

The first wall, titled "The Wild Dance, " was made of 25 native Taiwanese orchid species and others from Southeast Asia to exhibit the diversity of structure and growth habits of the orchid family, which contains about 22,500 species.
The second wall, "The Butterfly Dance, " composed of 46 colorful varieties of phalaenopsis orchids, pays homage to the work of Taiwanese orchid hybridizers.
Over the past 20 years, most of the new phalaenopsis hybrids were created by Taiwanese horticulturists in the southern part of Taiwan.

The most challenging part of the project, Blanc said, was to find native orchid species, but he admitted to enjoying putting together the living walls because everybody involved was knowledgeable and very easy to work with.
Blanc stressed that living walls are appropriate in both indoor and outdoor settings, but they have different criteria and benefits.
While outdoor walls are more about choosing the right plants for the right place based on prevailing weather conditions, indoor walls are more about design and aesthetic values.
The benefits of living walls include increasing humidity and purifying the air in indoor spaces and moderating temperatures and noise when used outside buildings, Blanc said.

Having installed some 200-250 vegetal walls around the world, Blanc said he tries to visit each of his works every two to three years, no matter how far away they are, or asks their keepers to send photos to help him keep track of how his walls evolve.
Some of the original plants used in the first vegetal wall he created at his home in 1982 are still alive, an indication, Blanc says, of how easy the vertical gardens are to maintain.
Outdoor walls only need to be checked two to three times a year, while indoor walls need to be checked every 45 days to two months.

Since Blanc's first vertical garden was unveiled at the Museum of Science and Industry in Paris in 1988, the designer has created many other vertical landscapes around the world, including green walls at the Musee du Quai Branly in Paris, the Siam Paragon shopping mall in Bangkok, and the 21st Century Museum of Contemporary Art in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma pushes for adoption of global covenants into domestic law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 16:53:55 (By Garfie Lee, Ann Chi-shen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan will continue to adopt international covenants as domestic law to demonstrate its willingness to meet its responsibilities as a member of the global village.

Ma said Taiwan will keep "internalizing" international covenants -- formal international treaties that Taiwan cannot sign or was forced out of because it is not a United Nations member -- to facilitate its integration into the international community.

The president hailed the adoption of two U. N. covenants -- the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights -- into domestic law, as bringing Taiwan's human rights protection on a par with international norms.
The two convenants took effect in Taiwan Thursday.

Addressing a round-table with a group of representatives from the local legal and judiciary sector, Ma said the Ministry of Justice will review relevant laws and statutes of the country and come up with amendment suggestions in two years if it finds certain articles run against the spirit of those two U.N. human rights covenants.
"It will be a giant legal engineering feat in the history of the Republic of China," the president said.
From Thursday on, any individual in the Republic of China can cite these two laws on human rights protection, which is an important step for Taiwan, Ma said.
The Legislative Yuan passed a bill in March this year to make these two treaties domestic law.

Taiwan was one of the original signatories to the two treaties in 1967 when the Republic of China was still a U.N. member. It did not incorporate the treaties into local law before losing its U.N. seat in 1971.

Meanwhile, Ma told the panelists that from Jan. 1, 2010, computer monitors will be installed and used at prosecutors' questioning sessions so that the suspects can watch the recording of his or her interrogation as it happens.
"This will contribute to reducing controversies afterward and better protecting the suspects' human rights," he said.
He added that the practice of illegal wiretapping or telephone monitoring that has been long condemned by society will disappear.
In related news, representatives of disadvantaged people and legal and judiciary groups met with President Ma Friday to lodge appeals and propose suggestions on judicial reforms.

The representatives, headed by Taiwan Law Society Chairman Wellington Koo, suggested that a judicial reform committee be established under the Presidential Office, with half of the committee's members coming from the private sector to serve as supervisors.

They also suggested that President Ma give judicial reform as high a priority as a government campaign against corruption and make a progress report to the public once every three months, according to Koo.
"The president said he will see to it that the Judicial Yuan and the Ministry of Justice come up with concrete plans on the reform program in one month," Koo noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vocational schools expected to draw Chinese students: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 17:12:49 (By Kuo Chih-hsiuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Wu Ching-ji expressed his pride in the country's vocational education system Friday and anticipated that junior college vocational schools around the island will be "stuffed" with Chinese students once they are allowed to enroll in Taiwan's colleges and universities.
"Taiwanese schools are attractive enough to draw Chinese students, " Wu said at the 44th founding anniversary of Meiho Institute of Technology in Pingtung County, southern Taiwan.

Taiwan's vocational education is globally recognized as being of the same quality as in Germany and Australia, Wu said, pointing out that National Pingtung University of Science and Technology's Department of Tropical Agriculture and International Cooperation is the only one of its kind in the world.
Moreover, Taichung City-based National Chung Hsing University enjoys a reputation on a par with Japan's prestigious University of Tokyo in agricultural and biotech research, he added.

Wu said he believes the academic exchanges between Taiwan and China will help further ease political tensions, but he also reiterated that principles are in place to prevent Chinese students from seizing education resources from local students, as some believe could happen.

The principles include imposing restrictions on the number of Chinese students allowed in Taiwan, not offering scholarships to Chinese students, and prohibiting Chinese students from staying in the country to work after they finish their studies here, according to Wu.

The Ministry of Education has begun a series of 17 separate public hearings around the country on its policy to open its doors to Chinese students and recognize academic credentials from Chinese universities.

The first public hearing of the series, which will run until Dec. 23, took place Thursday at National Kaohsiung Normal University in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City and was hosted by Vice Minister of Education Wu Tsai-shun.
