DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait intangible cultural heritage show to open Dec. 12
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 17:44:48 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: An exhibition showcasing the intangible cultural heritage of Taiwan and China will open Dec. 12 in Taichung, the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA) said Friday.

The exhibition to take place at the Taichung Creative Culture Park will cover two main shows: one focusing on China's intangible cultural heritage that will run through Dec. 20 and the other focusing on Taiwan's that will run through Feb. 28, CCA officials said.

A total of more than 800 cultural artifacts will be put on display, and there will also be on-site demonstrations by approximately 20 national intangible cultural legends from China, including papercutting master Liu Jinglan and ingigo print expert Wu Yuanxin, the officials said.
To highlight the theme of this grand event, an installation artwork titled "inheritance" created by an indigenous craftsman has been set up at the venue's entrance, they said.
Saturday's opening ceremony will present string puppet shows from China's Quanzhou and programs featuring characters from Taiwan's popular TV puppet dramas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local associations call for cross-strait fishing labor pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 18:32:58 (By Y. C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Representatives from local fishing associations across the country handed a petition to the Legislative Yuan Friday that urged all lawmakers to support a pact on fishing labor that will be signed during the upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

Speaking at a news conference, Huang Yi-cheng, the head of the Taiwan Provincial Fisherman's Association, said such a pact is critical to help protect the personal safety and property of Taiwanese fishing vessel owners through an institutionalized system.

Without a formal fishing cooperation agreement between Taiwan and China, Taiwan's fishing boat operators have been unable to verify the identities of Chinese crew members or deal with many incidents, including frequent mutinies on the high seas in recent years, he said .
Also, in May 2006, China began demanding that Taiwan's brokers apply to hire fishing boat crewmen and pay a handsome deposit to Chinese authorities, Huang said.

If the existing practice were to continue over the long term, Taiwanese fishing operators would be forced to accept the terms set by the Chinese side, making it difficult for them to protect their own rights, he explained.

More than 2,000 of some 4,600 Chinese nationals currently employed on Taiwanese fishing vessels have been introduced to local fishing operators by private brokers through channels appointed by Chinese authorities, Huang noted.

TPFA chief delegate Lin Chi-chang voiced the hope that the government could clinch a fishing labor pact as soon as possible with China to allow Taiwanese fishing companies to hire Chinese fishermen through an institutionalized channel and screen their identity in advance.

Lu Hsueh-chang, a whip of the ruling Kuomintang's legislative caucus, said such a pact will help address some grave problems facing Taiwan's fishing boat owners and upgrade the quality of Chinese fishermen they hire.

Lu also urged the legislative caucus of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to back the signing of a fishery cooperation pact in the upcoming fourth round of cross-strait talks between Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- slated to open on Dec. 22.

The main purpose of the meeting will be to ink four cross-strait agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor council to amend laws to better protect dispatched workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 18:44:12 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Friday that it will amend the Labor Standards Law in an effort to better protect the welfare of "dispatched" workers -- those who work for employment agencies or specialized contractors and then are dispatched to companies.

"The CLA has decided to first amend the chapter in the Labor Standards Law that governs labor contracts to strengthen the benefits of dispatched workers and the responsibility of companies that employ such workers, " CLA chief secretary Huang Chiu-kuei said at an international seminar on the subject held by the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU).
The amended regulations will also apply to government agencies, which have the largest number of dispatched workers, she added.

CLA and Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics figures showed that in May 687,000 of Taiwan's 9 million employees were dispatched workers, far more than the 130,000 in 2003 and the 60,000 in 1996.

TCTU Secretary-General Hsieh Chuang-chih said the statistics indicated a continuing deterioration in Taiwan's employment environment, and TCTU Chairman Mao Chen-fei said improvements in the system were needed.
"Current regulations and laws do not provide sufficient protection for dispatched workers, many of whom are underprivileged," Mao said.
These people are usually vulnerable and tend to be laid off when the economy goes bad, such as after the global financial crisis erupted in 2008, he added.

Hiring dispatched workers from contractors or employment agencies saves companies the responsibility of hiring workers on their own and paying them health and retirement benefits, bonuses, or severance pay. The practice helps them reduce labor costs and gives them more flexibility in managing their manpower.

Mao said, however, that his confederation opposes dispatching jobs and contends that the government should restrict such employment to certain industries and provide better protection for dispatched workers rights and benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP agrees to discuss amendment on U.S. beef imports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 19:25:33 (By Kelven Huang, Vicky Hsu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus Friday to continue consultations on an amendment related to a controversial protocol signed by Taiwan and the United States that opened Taiwan's market to U.S. bone-in-beef.

Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called in the whips of the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to discuss the issue, and the two sides agreed to continue to talk based on a resolution reached a month earlier.

The Nov. 3 resolution stated that before the Act Governing Food Sanitation is amended, U.S. beef parts considered hazardous, including beef offal, ground beef, spinal cord, brain, skull and eyes, should not be allowed to be imported.

Wang met earlier with the DPP caucus and Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to exchange views on the dispute over the amendment, which led the DPP to boycott the operations of the legislature for more than one month.

Sources said Tsai asked the KMT legislative caucus to conclude the consultations in one week, and stressed that if a consensus could not be reached, the DPP legislative caucus will continue its boycott campaign.

Meanwhile, William A. Stanton, Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan, called on Wang to reiterate Washington's view that Taiwan should abide by the protocol signed with the U.S., which allows the import of previously banned bone-in beef, ground beef and offal.

DPP legislative whip Wang Sing-nan said only U.S. slaughterhouses can test cow's brains for prion protein, which is linked to bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease, and establish the safety of the cow.

The examination fee for each cow would be NT$700 (US$22) , Wang said. If the cows are turned into ground beef and imported to Taiwan without undergoing the test, it will be impossible to detect such a disease.

Wang said that to deter potentially hazardous beef from entering Taiwan, the U.S. will have to take the initiative to inspect its beef, and that if Taiwan thinks that it can conduct rigorous inspections of the beef when it arrives in Taiwan, then it is delusional.
KMT whip Lu Hsueh-chang said that according to quarantine officials of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, only the U.S. can detect the prion protein.
"This is why the amendment will try to deter the beef from coming to Taiwan in the first place," Lu said.

Under a protocol with the U.S., Taiwan agreed to allow the entry of U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef, and beef offal that were not contaminated by "specific risk materials (SRMs) " related to mad cow disease.

SRMs are defined in the protocol as brains, skulls, eyes, trigeminal ganglia, spinal cords, vertebral columns and dorsal root ganglia from cattle 30 months and older, or tonsils and the distal ileum of the small intestine from cattle of all ages.

The pact has resulted in great misgivings among the public. Civic groups recently submitted a petition to the Central Election Commission to try to initiate a national referendum on restarting negotiations with the U.S. on the issue.
The DPP's principle will be to stop high-risk U.S. parts at their source and that the government should restart talks with the U.S., DPP chairwoman Tsai said earlier in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan editorial abstracts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 19:28:23 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The following is a brief roundup of selected local newspaper editorials Friday: APPLE DAILY China gearing up to undermine foundation of Taiwan-U.S. ties

President Ma Ying-jeou said after American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond Burghardt briefed him on U.S. President Barack Obama's visit to China in November that the triangular Taiwan-U.S.-China relations are in their best shape in six decades.

If his remarks were not aimed at comforting himself or the man in the street, they reflect Ma's ignorance of the fact that Taiwan-U.S. relations are changing profoundly as China has geared up to undermine the foundation of Taiwan-U.S. relations through lobby groups.

If Ma was not alarmed by Obama's failure to mention U.S. obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) during his Beijing visit, his national security team should read a recent article by former U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff Vice Chairman William A. Owens.

The retired admiral said unequivocally that the TRA enacted 30 years ago has done more harm than good to the U.S. and that selling defensive weapons to Taiwan is also not in Washington's best interests.
Owens further said that the United States should start to take China as a friend and should not repeat the historical blunder of old powers engaging in wars with rising powers.

He suggested that the U.S. stop arms sales to Taiwan in exchange for China's amity and that the themes of U.S. policy toward China should be cooperation, openness and trust instead of restriction, competition or containment.

It is worth paying attention to whether Owens' article signals that a pro-China force is pushing the U.S. to invalidate the TRA under Beijing's encouragement on the grounds that the present U.S. situation and development should not be restricted by a 30-year-old law.
The latest information from Washington shows that the U.S. is likely to sell Taiwan Black Hawk helicopters and Patriot PAC III missiles but will reject Taiwan's appeal for F-16C/D jet fighters.

By so doing, the Obama administration has fulfilled the U.S. commitment to abide by the TRA to help with Taiwan's national defense needs and to allow Taiwan to remain confident in negotiations with China while avoiding angering its giant neighbor.

While the Ma administration is touting the achievements of its pragmatic diplomatic approach, we must remind Ma's national security team that China does not care whether the U.S. abolishes the TRA, as it is strongly lobbying Washington to gradually retrench arms sales to Taiwan. COMMERCIAL TIMES Enhancing transparency in cross-strait financial talks

After hurriedly signing a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on cross-strait financial supervisory cooperation with China Nov. 16, Taiwan's government did not reveal the content of the pact until after the curtain fell on mayoral and magistrate elections last Saturday.
We are concerned whether all future cross-strait agreements in trade, economic and political fields will all follow this working model.

The government began to advocate signing a cross-strait financial MOU more than a year ago, but it had since been evasive on issues discussed during the negotiations and the progress made in such talks.
Policy and information opaqueness has led to rampant speculation about the pact in local society and market players have used related issues to speculate on local financial stocks over the past year.

Insufficient transparency has also resulted in unrealistic mirages. Among others, many thought Taiwanese banks would enjoy promising business opportunities once they are allowed to set up in China following the signing of the MOU.

The reality, however, is that foreign banks, including Taiwan's, must first set up liaison offices in China before they are allowed to open branches there. Even after they manage to open up branches, they have to wait another three years before their branches can handle Chinese yuan-denominated deposits and loans.

It's no secret that local banks will face challenges in the Chinese market, but the government has not kept information transparent from the very beginning and only reluctantly admitted to the barriers Taiwanese banks would encounter in the Chinese market at the last minute.
With this in mind, we cannot but ask whether other information has also been deliberately concealed by the government.

We must remind the present administration that popular demand for policy transparency has increased significantly since the second change of power between political parties. The government should never try again to keep key provisions of any cross-strait agreements secret. CHINA TIMES Government needs to provide platform for ECFA debate

Some political analysts have partly attributed the ruling Kuomintang's recent election setback to the government's plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, which the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party has denounced as a prelude to Taiwan's integration into a "one China" market.
In an effort to clarify misconceptions, both Premier Wu Den-yih and Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang have offered to debate DPP lawmakers and politicians on relevant topics.
The government and the ruling party are indeed obliged to defend major policies through dialogue. However, we do not see the need for senior officials to debate the ECFA issue in person.
The government just has to provide a platform or arrange a setting for proponents and opponents to discuss the issues directly.
As the free trade agreement-like ECFA will involve scores of industries, those who will benefit from the accord should stand out to defend the proposal.

If representatives of industries believed to benefit from the pact fail to convince opponents in public debates, the government may have to think twice on whether to go ahead with its plan to start ECFA talks early next year.

On the other hand, if DPP politicians and other opponents lose such debates, they should stop their irrational opposition to the proposal. UNITED DAILY NEWS Don't let people live in pall of election battles

Soon after the curtain fell on elections for mayors and magistrates in 17 cities and counties, society's focus moved to the more important elections for mayors of five special municipalities next year and even the 2012 presidential election.

While some KMT politicians are fervently speculating on who should represent the party in next year's mayoral elections, we should remind them that good governance is the best strategy to win back the hearts and minds of the voter in the street.

For the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, our advice is that its gains in the just-concluded elections is no guarantee for its performance in the next elections. As many voters remain skeptical about its radical ideology and governing competence, the party should rather think about how to contribute to people's well-being rather than indulging in empty talk. ECONOMIC DAILY NEWS Don't blame macroeconomic environment any more

President Ma Ying-jeou's appointment of his most trusted ally as the ruling Kuomintang's new secretary-general seems to indicate that Ma is still not fully aware of the reasons behind his party's poor showing in the just-concluded local elections.
Ma attributed the KMT's election setback to economic woes resulting from a global financial meltdown. However, the worldwide financial crisis was just the last straw to sink Taiwan's economy.

The culprit actually lied in China's reckless policy of forcing its coastal export-processing industries to upgrade. Under such a policy, Taiwanese and other foreign investors were forced to relocate offshore or move into China's inland provinces.
China's export-driven economy then fell through and Taiwan's shipments to China also dropped substantially.

By mid-2008, China was facing an even more serious economic crisis than Taiwan's. China's leaders did not blame the global financial tsunami for the country's economic hardships and instead endeavored to find the root cause of the problem and took immediate steps to address the issue.

China stopped its rash industrial upgrading policy by resuming tax rebates and easing wage restrictions to bolster its export sector. In addition, it invested heavily in infrastructure construction and green industry while encouraging private consumption to expand domestic demand. In the end, its economic growth rate for this year will exceed its target of 8 percent.
In comparison, Taiwan's leaders seem to still have their heads buried in the sand and have failed to come up with substantive policy incentives to revive the battered economy.
With a much smaller territory and population, Taiwan needs to operate with wisdom, vigor and ingenuity. Otherwise, how can it compete with China?

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan begins Middle East week to promote trade
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 19:30:43 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Middle East Trade Week, organized by the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , formally opened Friday, attracting the participation of more than 30 buyers from five countries in that region.
Notably, the opening ceremony was also attended by Ali Khorram, the deputy director for international affairs of the Tehran Chamber of Commerce and Industries and Mines.

The foreign buyers were expected to purchase approximately US$30 million worth of Taiwan-made products at a procurement workshop that took place following the opening ceremony, according to the TAITRA.
The trade week is part of the government's efforts to promote trade in the Middle East region that has many "petrodollar" trade opportunities, TAITRA officials said.

The council revealed that Taiwanese businesses have sold nearly US$400 million worth of products to Middle East countries this year, and many listed enterprises, including the Hon Hai Group and the Pou Chen Group, have listed the Middle East as a key market, the official noted.
Meanwhile, the TAITRA inaugurated two economic and trade associations Friday that will be used as key platforms for Taiwanese companies to explore the Middle East market.
The Republic of China Middle East Economic and Trade Association, and the Taiwan-Iran Economic and Trade Association were formed under the guidance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

On Friday, Taiwan Fertilizer Chairman Chung Jung-chi was elected to chair the Middle East association which has been joined by 66 leading companies in the country, including state-run oil refiner CPC Corporation, Taiwan, shipbuilder CSBC Corp., Taiwan, and the TECO Group.
Mobiletron Electronics Chairman Kim Y.C. Tsai was elected to chair the Taiwan- Iran association.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA first step for Taiwan to get fair competition on world market

TEXT.P: As the economic globalization continues relentlessly, Taiwan has no option but to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China as the first step to remain competitive in the world market, a top national growth strategist said Friday.
Chiang Ping-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), told the CNA all Taiwan wants is fair competition in worldwide trade and investment to survive the globalization,

one of whose most distinctive features is regionalization, where Taiwan is unfairly disadvantaged. In Asia, Chiang said, what is commonly known as "Ten- plus-One" is coming into being as a free trade zone on January 1 next year. The ten being member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), and the one the People's Republic of China. Taiwan is excluded.

The exclusion makes Taiwan exports uncompetitive. Somewhere between 7 to 10 percent of tariff will be imposed on products ranging from textiles to petrochemicals. Service industries, including banking and financing, will be seriously affected, too. Most of manufacturing industries will be forced to relocate away from Taiwan. Unemployment will soar, further worsening its economic downturn.

"That's why we have to have the ECFA, a framework of economic cooperation, first with the other side of the Taiwan Strait," said Chiang, who will talk with his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin in Taichung at their fourth meeting scheduled to start on December 22.

Chiang and Chen, chairman of the Association for Relations across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), are expected to sign four agreements to improve relations between Taiwan and China, though the much-heralded ECFA will not be signed.

"No," Chiang said, "we are not going to ink the ECFA this time. We will put it on the agenda for our next meeting." The meeting where the ECFA will be signed will take place in China in the first half of next year.

Chiang allayed apprehension that the ECFA is a step toward Taiwan's closer economic integration with China. "Far from it," he pointed out, "it's the first step we should take and are taking to get the chance of fair competition to remain economically competitive in the world in general and in Asia in particular.

"For one thing, the ECFA isn't a free trade agreement. It's like the list of contents of a book, stating what Taiwan and China will do to remove all obstacles to better cooperation in trade and investment.

"We don't have a timetable for where to proceed and how," Chiang said. Prioritization, also known as early harvests, is being arranged . For that reason, many people in Taiwan do not understand what the ECFA does offer and how it's going to impact some industries, farming and fishing among others. "One thing we have to do," Chiang said, "is to make our people have a better understanding of the ECFA."

Countries in Asia and elsewhere are concerned that the ECFA may give Taiwan more advantages than are fair. Seoul believes Taiwan, with the ECFA in force, will outsell products from South Korea. Japan, whose new ambition is to form an East Asian economic community with South Korea and China, does not like Taiwan to have better edges in trade and investment across the strait. The United States, excluded from the emerging Asian free trade bloc as well as the "ASEAN-plus- Three" by 2012, does not consider favorably Taiwan's increasingly heavy economic reliance on China. The other two of the "three" are Japan and South Korea.

Why with China first?" Because it's our top trade partner," said Chiang, minister of economic affairs and chairman of the Council of Economic Planning and Development under former President Lee Teng-hui .Trade with China, including Hong Kong and Macao, accounts for 40 percent of Taiwan's worldwide sales and purchases. With the ECFA signed with China, ASEAN states, whose trade with Taiwan representing 15 percent of the total, is likely to follow suit, Chiang said.

The signing of such agreements, however, does not involve Chiang's SEF, a quasi- official organization which together with Chen's ARATS conducts substantive relations between the two sides of the strait.
Efforts will then be made to conclude a similar arrangement with Japan, whose trade with Taiwan makes up another seven percent of the latter's worldwide volume.
"Then it will be the United States and the European Union, each accounting for 12 percent of our international trade," Chiang said.

"Our global economic cooperation framework will be completed then," he pointed out. "Only then will Taiwan be truly able to compete fairly in the world market." Taiwan will be free of fear for economic marginalization. "We are not afraid of competition," Chiang declared. "We are afraid only of unfairness in competition," he said.

Of course, an ECFA may be signed not in that order. The United States is planning to resume its TIFA (trade and investment framework agreement) negotiations with Taiwan. It may be signed ahead of that with the EU or vice versa. That depends on how these countries think such arrangements are mutually or commonly beneficial. (By Joe Hung)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan ink air treaty to expand flight services
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 20:57:25 (By Shih Hsin-yao, Wang Shu-fen and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan inked a new air treaty Friday to expand flight services between the two countries that will pave the way for direct flights between the city airports of Taipei and Tokyo beginning next October.

Under the new treaty, the weekly number of flights from Taiwan to Japan's Kansai region and central Japan will be increased from 28 to 45, including four new daily round-trip flights between Taipei Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport.
Flights between Taipei and Okinawa will also be increased.

Peng Run-tsu, chairman of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' Association of East Asian Relations, and Reijiro Hattori, chairman of Japan's Interchange Association in Taipei, signed the pact at a ceremony in Taipei.
"It is foreseeable that the agreement will further increase the economic benefits and convenience of people-to-people exchanges between the two sides," Peng said.
"We will continue to negotiate and seek resolutions to all kinds of aviation issues between Taiwan and Japan and to create a win-win situation for mutual benefit," he added.

According to Peng, China Airlines, Eva Air, Japan Airlines and All Nippon Airways will operate the flights between Songshan and Haneda airports, and service will begin when the carriers have made the necessary prepartions and Haneda Airport's new runway is ready, which is expected next October.
Currently, flights between Taipei and Tokyo go through Taiwan's Taoyuan International Airport and Japan's Narita International Airport.
Flying through airports located near the two countries' capital cities could save around 90 minutes in door-to-door travel times for passengers.

Peng also noted that the treaty will allow carriers to have more flexibility when it comes to scheduling flights from each other's airports on to third countries -- known as the Fifth Freedom -- by increasing cargo and passenger capacities, the number of flights and the choice of beyond points.
The increase in flights resulted from mounting demand because of the growing economic and tourism ties between Taiwan and Japan, Peng said.
Bilateral trade reached US$60.4 billion in 2008, and 2.48 million tourists traveled between Taiwan and Japan last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low energy prices blamed for Taiwan's high greenhouse gas emissions
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 20:59:32 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng, Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Low energy prices in Taiwan are responsible for Taiwan's worsening greenhouse gas emissions, a problem that requires immediate attention from the government, a minister without portfolio said in the southern city of Kaohsiung Friday.

Raising the issue in a lecture on Taiwan's environmental, energy and economic strategies and trends, Liang Chi-yuan noted that while fuel and electricity prices in Taiwan are the lowest among non-oil producing countries, the nation's energy efficiency is barely half that of Japan and the European Union.

Liang reasoned that low energy prices are unfavorable to the promotion of energy-conserving products and technologies, which in turn undermines overall energy efficiency, delays the structural adjustment of local industries and hampers greenhouse gas reductions.

This situation is best demonstrated by the fact that Taiwan has recorded the world's highest growth in greenhouse gas emissions -- 138 percent -- over the past 16 years, with the situation worsening noticeably after 2000, he said.

On a proposal to impose a carbon tax in Taiwan, Liang said such a policy should be promoted in a gradual manner to lower its impact on the economy and that personal and corporate income tax rates should be reduced to ease the burden of the new tax.

He suggested that revenue from the carbon tax could then be used to offset lower personal and corporate income tax revenues and that companies with excellent greenhouse gas reduction performances be granted energy tax exemptions or refunds.
Also, the government should provide energy subsidies to low-income households and encourage local businesses to buy carbon emission rights from abroad, he said.

In an interview with the Central News Agency later Friday, Liang explained that the Cabinet's plan to reform the country's energy tax policy will not lead to an increase in tax burden because the reforms will be implemented alongside other measures, such as lowering income taxes and abolishing the excise tax for most products.
Before levying a carbon tax, the government will weigh whether it is the proper time to do so, based on factors such as whether the economy has truly begun to recover, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier sets sight on more new star industries
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 21:13:15 (By Emmanuelle Tseng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The patterned innovation, green building, information and communications technology (ICT), and smart electric car sectors were added Friday by Premier Wu Den-yih to the government's list of new star industries.

Wu's predecessor Liu Chao-shiuan had already designated specialty agriculture, green energy, health care, tourism, cultural innovation and biotechnology as industries with outstanding potential that could make significant contributions to Taiwan's economy.

The four new sectors will be added to the list, Wu said as he attended the closing ceremony of a training course for local leaders sponsored by the southern branch of the Executive Yuan in Kaohsiung City.
Taking advantage of Taiwan's strong competitiveness in the ICT field, the government decided to list it along with three other sectors as one of the government's latest star industries, Wu said.
According to Wu, 14 ICT-related products manufactured by Taiwan are at the top of their respective markets around the globe, especially the IC design, semiconductor and LED display panel sectors.

Based on the sound foundation of Taiwan's cloud computing ICT industry, the government is confident that the patterned innovation, green building and electric car sectors will also become growth engines in the country in the future, the premier explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign for U.S. beef import referendum passes first hurdle
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 21:51:47 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A grassroots campaign to initiate a national referendum on restarting negotiations on U.S. beef imports has passed its first hurdle, the Central Election Commission (CEC) announced Friday.

The campaign was launched by the Consumers' Foundation and several other civic groups to appeal for a national referendum that will ask voters to veto the government's decision in November to open Taiwan's market to U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef and beef offal and demand that the government renegotiate a beef trade protocol with the United States.

According to Taiwan's Referendum Act, referendum campaigners must first obtain the signatures of at least 0.5 percent of eligible voters in the most recent presidential election to have their proposal accepted by the CEC.
Needing to collect 86,000 signatures to get past the first hurdle, trade protocol renegotiation advocates submitted their initiative with the endorsement of 130,459 signatures to the CEC Tuesday.

After an initial screening, CEC officials said, the referendum proposal has passed the first threshold as 129,065 signatures submitted by the advocacy groups were found to be valid, far exceeding the minimum requirement.
"The referendum initiative will be referred to the Executive Yuan Referendum Screening Committee soon for confirmation, " said CEC Secretary-General Teng Tien-you.

If the committee sanctions the proposal, the referendum campaign will enter the second stage, where the civic groups must collect the signatures of at least 5 percent of the electorate -- in this case 860,000 eligible voters.
Only if this second hurdle is passed will a national referendum on the beef trade issue take place in accordance with the country's Referendum Act.
Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and beef offal.
However, consumer rights activists have contended that the importation of high- risk beef products could put consumers at risk of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
With their appeals for re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef talks having been rejected by the administration, advocacy groups have decided to push for a referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chaishan in Kaohsiung City becomes national park
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 22:09:16

TEXT.P: Chaishan, a popular hiking area in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City, will be designated as a national park by the Executive Yuan, Premier Wu Den-yih announced Friday.

The Executive Yuan will soon announce the decision to set up a park administration under the Ministry of the Interior to take over the park's management, Wu said while attending the closing ceremony of a training course for local leaders sponsored by the southern branch of the Executive Yuan in Kaohsiung City.

Stressing that the government is resolved to pursuing sustainable growth nationwide and fully protect the public's health, Wu gave his assurance that the government will never walk the old path again in its quest for a "green" Taiwan.

"I made the decision to terminate the 70-year-old mining business in two mountain areas -- Chaishan and Panpingshan -- when serving as Kaohsiung mayor, and now it is time we take action to preserve their natural environment," the premier said.
"The government is fully committed to developing southern regions, including a future special municipality composed of Kaohsiung City and County that will be merged next year," he added.

Chaishan is a scenic spot located in Kaohsiung City's Gushan district and forms a natural protective screen for the city -- the largest in southern Taiwan. The famous Sizihwan is located at Chaishan's foothills.

In recent years, many mountain climbers in Chaishan have been harassed by monkeys that roam and beg for food in the area -- the result of a partial military ban imposed on the mountain a decade ago. (By Emmanuelle Tseng and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to step up protests against Chiang-Chen talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 22:17:39 (By Sophia Yeh, Lee Hsi-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will step up its protests against the upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks to be held in Taichung, with various demonstrations planned for Dec. 21-23 in addition to a march and rally on Dec. 20, officials said Friday.

The DPP came to the decision one day after the initerary of the fourth round of talks between the chief negotiators on each side -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- was made public.

According to the initerary released by the Mainland Affairs Council, Chen will arrive in Taichung Dec. 21 and meet with Chiang Dec. 22 to sign four cross- strait agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

In anticipation of Chen's visit, the pro-independence DPP had earlier announced a plan to hold a march Dec. 20 in the central city to protest the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China.

The DPP decided Friday that the protest campaign will be extended to cover the first three days of Chen's stay in Taichung, in order to highlight the "unreasonableness" of the Chiang-Chen talks, party officials said.

Among the many protest ideas raised by party members were flash mobs and having 50 model planes hovering over the venue, they said, adding that further discussions will be held to finalize the details of the planned protests.

Meanwhile, expressing concerns over the DPP's planned action, local politicians from the ruling Kuomintang urged the opposition party to make sure the protests are non-violent so that the talks can proceed smoothly.

Chang Hung-nien, speaker of the Taichung City Council, said that the DPP should take the event in stride because it is intended to address economic issues and will not touch upon any political subjects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to build marinas to develop leisure fishing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/11/09 22:43:30 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government has worked out a plan to invest NT$2 billion US$ (61.54 million) from now until 2012 to build marinas in different regions around the country to help develop the leisure fishing industry, President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.
Ma made the announcement during a meeting with representatives from local fishermen's associations at the Presidential Office.

According to the president, marinas will be constructed in Badouzih in northern Keelung City, Wushih in neighboring Yilan County, Anping in southern Taiwan's Tainan City and Wuci in central Taiwan's Taichung County, by 2012.
A total of 190 berths for yachts will be built in those areas, and the marinas will have water and electricity and telecommunications facilities, he elaborated.

"From now on, Taiwan will develop its yacht industry and leisure fishing sector together, " which form part of the government's efforts to honor its promise to take better care of fishermen despite the fragile economy.

Other measures to be adopted include increasing fuel subsidies for fishing boats, easing restrictions on requirements for leisure fishing and greater financial assistance to phase out aging fishing boats, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan adds three silver medals in East Asia games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Nov. 11 (CNA) 12/12/09 00:09:36 ( By Oscar Wu & Bear)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's athletes earned three more silver medals Friday at the East Asian Games in Hong Kong and are now four medals behind Hong Kong in the medals table with two days of competition remaining.
In the men's basketball final, defending East Asian Games champion Taiwan lost to South Korea 98-97 after blowing a 10-point third-quarter lead.
Center Tseng Wen-ting led Taiwan with 23 points, 10 rebounds and 11 assists, while Chang Chih-feng contributed 20 points and Lin Chih-chieh added 19.
In the women's basketball final, Taiwan lost to China 83-58 to take its second consecutive East Asian Games silver medal in the event.
Taiwan only trailed the powerful Chinese women by 20-19 after the first quarter, but then could not score more than 13 points in any of the final three quarters as China pulled away.
In the men's shot put, Taiwan's Chang Ming-huang took silver with a throw of 18.33 meters, more than 2 meters shorter than the 20.41-meter gold medal winning throw of China's Zhang Jun.

As of the end of competition Friday, Taiwan had captured a total of six golds, 27 silvers and 24 bronzes, placing it fifth in the medals table, four medals behind fourth-place Hong Kong, which had 11 golds, 18 silvers and 32 bronzes.
China leads the medals table with 76 golds and 160 total medals, followed by Japan (38 gold, 133 total) and South Korea (30 gold, 103 total).

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 12, or the 26th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1642: Abel Yasman, a Dutch navigator, discovers New Zealand.
1787: Pennsylvania becomes the second state of the United States.
1804: Spain declares war on Britain.
1894: Japanese troops invade Korea.
1901: Italian physicist Marchese Guglielmo Marconi completes his first trans- Atlantic wireless radio transmission.
1906: The German company Telefunken successfully tests a wireless telephone.
1915: Yuan Shih-kai, the provisional president of the Republic of China who promised to establish a republican government, proclaims himself emperor.
1932: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.
1936: Chang Hsueh-liang's troops mutiny in Xian and hold Chiang Kai-shek and other ranking ROC government officials hostage.
1937: Japanese planes bomb and sink a U.S. warship in the Yangtze River in China, straining relations between Japan and the United States.
1941: The "Taiwan Revolutionary Alliance" is set up in Chungking and issues a statement urging all compatriots to unite against Japanese aggression.
1946: The ROC Ministry of the Interior rebuilds a national boundary monument at its southernmost boundary in the Nansha (Spratly) Islands.
1959: The "Hai Ming" freighter of China Merchants Steam Navigation Co. begins plying a route between Taiwan and the east coast of the United States, becoming the first Chinese ship to sail the route.
1971: Yiu Mi-chien, who was known as "the father of Taiwan's tourism industry," dies in Taipei at the age of 74.
1972: The Taipei City Council adopts a resolution on the establishment of sisterhood relations with Guam.
1972: The Sino-Guatemalan agricultural technical cooperation agreement is put into effect.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo declares that the ROC will become a nation of heavy industry after the completion of the "Ten Basic Construction Projects."
1979: Maj. Gen. Chun Doo-hwan and his colleagues stage an army coup and seize power in South Korea.
1982: The ROC wins a high proportion of medals, including 4 golds and 16 others as well as a special prize, at the 31st World Fair for Inventions held Dec. 4-12 in Brussels.
1984: An extradition treaty between the ROC and the Republic of Costa Rica is signed, the first such treaty signed by the ROC.
1991: Boris Yeltsin wins landslide approval in the Russian Parliament for his new Commonwealth of Independent States.
1992: Major earthquakes kill 2,500 people on Flores Island in eastern Indonesia.
1994: The Lien Chan Cabinet is re-organized, and new Cabinet members are sworn in three days later.
1995: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations passes a resolution to implement a treaty to set up a non-nuclear zone.
1999:A four-member delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng departs for Panama to attend a forum of presidents of legislative assemblies of the ROC and Central American countries.
2000: Legislator Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, takes the helm of an association of lawmakers to promote relations between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: Internet and media firm tom.com Ltd. and Taiwan's Business Weekly Publishing Inc. reach an agreement that tom.com purchases the magazine group's equity interest for NT$1.65 billion.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Bandeira Melo de Menezes, accompanied by his counterpart, ROC President Chen Shui-bian, visits the Sixth Naphtha Cracking Plant of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) at Mailiao in Yunlin County, southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in business and careful in speech. He should seek the company of men of virtue and learning in order to profit by their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Our Lady of Guadalupe mosaic to be inaugurated in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 15:28:07 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A ceramic mosaic of Mexico's most popular religious and cultural icon, Our Lady of Guadalupe, will be inaugurated Sunday in Taipei as part of celebrations to commemorate the reported appearance of the Virgin Mary to a peasant nearly five centuries ago, according to the Taipei-based Mexican Trade Services Documentation and Cultural Office.
"The image of Our Lady of Guadalupe was donated by the Iberoamerican Community in Taiwan to observe the Catholic event, "the office said.

A special Holy Mass is scheduled to be held Sunday at St. Christopher Church located in Taipei's Little Manila on Zhongshan North Road, along with a ceremony to inaugurate a St. Damian crucifix and the mosaic of "Our Lady of Guadalupe, " which have already been set on the sidewalk outside the church.
The mosaic is made of Talavera tiles from the Mexican city of Puebla, while the crucifix is made of limestone from Mexico's Guanajuato State.

Monsignor Paul Russell, the Vatican's charge d'affaires to Taiwan, and clergies from the United States, the Philippines and Spain, as well as the local Latin American and Philippine communities, are expected to attend the ceremony.
According to the traditional account, on Dec. 12, 1531, the Virgin Mary appeared miraculously to a Native American peasant at Tepeyac, a hill northwest of downtown Mexico City.

She identified herself as the Mother of the True God, instructed the seer, Juan Diego, to have the bishop build a temple on the site, and left an image of herself imprinted miraculously on his tilma, a poor quality cactus-cloth that should have deteriorated in 20 years but shows no sign of decay until today. Diego was canonized by Pope John Paul II July 31, 2002.

Pope Pius XII declared the Virgin of Guadalupe "Queen of Mexico and Empress of the Americas" in 1945, and "Patroness of the Americas" in 1946. Pope John XXIII invoked her as "Mother of the Americas" in 1961, referring to her as Mother and Teacher of the Faith of All American Populations.

DOC.HEADLINE: President offers to debate ECFA with opposition leader
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 15:35:02 (By Garfie Li, Sophia Yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has raised the possibility of holding a debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that the pro-independence party strongly opposes.

Speaking on the issue during an interview with the cable network CTiTV Friday, Ma again warned that if such an agreement is not signed, Taiwan will soon face an exodus of local industries, especially those in the petrochemical sector, which will greatly affect the country's economy.
"The DPP is definitely aware of this situation, but it is simply branding me as leaning toward China." said Ma, who serves concurrently as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang.
"Could they (the DPP) please identify one thing I did that could be construed as China-leaning?" he asked.

Ma said he hopes the debate with Tsai will take place after the ECFA negotiations with China have produced some results, which will be a better time to determine whether the agreement would be favorable or unfavorable to Taiwan.

The president gave the assurance that even after the ECFA is signed, the government will only liberalize the importation of certain necessary items, and there will be no expansion of agricultural imports from China.

He promised that the government will promote the signing of the ECFA in a transparent manner because it has the responsibility to make the people understand that the agreement is essential to preventing marginalizion of Taiwan's economy.

Responding to Ma's suggestion of a debate, DPP spokeswoman Hsiao Bi-khim said her party has been waiting for such an opportunity for a long time and expects the president to extend an official invitation to Tsai.
Tsai will respond as soon as she receives the invitation, Hsiao said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government should give comprehensive information on ECFA: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 15:43:46 (By Tyson Lu, Tang Pei-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen responded positively Saturday to President Ma Ying-jeou's suggestion of a debate with her on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, saying it is the government's responsibility to provide the public with comprehensive information on the controversial trade deal.

Commenting on the matter during a trip to the eastern county of Taitung, Tsai said the DPP has long been supportive of the idea of a debate to discuss ECFA issues because it believes that holding policy debates is "a responsibility of political leaders" and "a must in a democratic society."
"What the government has done so far is mere propaganda, which is not something that a responsible government should be doing, " she said.

According to the opposition leader, the Ma administration has an obligation to explain clearly to the people on the possible long-term effects of the pact on Taiwan's politics, economy and society and how the administration plans to deal with them.
This type of information is needed particularly in light of public opinion polls that indicate many people have no idea what the ECFA is, Tsai said.

In an interview Friday with the cable network CTiTV, Ma raised the possibility of debating the ECFA with Tsai, and said he hopes the debate will take place after there have been some results from the negotiations with China.

The president again stressed that such an agreement is important to preventing marginalization of Taiwan's economy and he rejected the pro-independence DPP's claim that his promotion of the ECFA is an example of him leaning towards China.
Also commenting on Ma's suggestion Saturday, Premier Wu Den-yih said a debate between Tsai and Ma, who is also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, will help focus the public's attention on the issue.
It will also help to give the people a better idea of the likely benefits and disadvantages of the agreement and allow them to form a truer picture of the situation, Wu said.
He agreed that a public explanation by the administration is crucial to clearing up misunderstandings about the government's policies.

For example, he said, none of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products that are allowed into Taiwan were liberalized by the Ma administration, but some farmers in central and southern Taiwan are convinced that it was Ma who lifted the restrictions and are concerned that the signing of the ECFA will lead to an expansion of agricultural imports from China.

The truth, Wu noted, is that the restrictions on 936 of the items were lifted during the former DPP administration led by President Chen Shui-bian, and 479 others were allowed in during the previous 50 years.

Pointing to another example, Wu said although the government has repeatedly assured the public that Taiwan will not open up to Chinese laborers, many people are being misled into believing that there will be an influx of Chinese workers after the signing of the ECFA.
According to the premier, the government has not been able to clearly explain the details of the ECFA to the public because there had been no substantial results from the negotiations with China.
Today, however, the lists of products to be covered by an early harvest program under the trade deal are gradually taking shape through negotiations between the two sides, he said.

The results of a recent survey revealed that 48 percent of the people are in favor of the pact while more than 30 percent are against it, which indicates that the government should step up communication with the people and legislators to seek a stronger consensus on the issue, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to worry about Taiwan's opening to Chinese students: NTU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 15:54:47 (By Szu-yu Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top ranked National Taiwan University (NTU) said Saturday that there is no need to worry about the government's policy to allow the admission of Chinese students, and gave the assurance that it will find the best strategy to continue to develop leadership talent in the greater China region.

Amid worry in some quarters over Taiwan's plan to recognize diplomas from top Chinese universities and to allow Chinese students to study at Taiwan universities, NTU president Lee Si-chen said that NTU is the best school in the great China region, and people should trust Taiwan's quality of education.
Lee said at a seminar that NTU has produced many leaders in the past, and he is confident the trend will continue.
In order to attract outstanding Chinese applicants, Lee said, NTU will seek corporate donations to establish scholarships for such students.

He also pointed that over the past 50 years the Taiwan government's education policy regarding overseas Chinese students has been very successful, adding that there is no need to debate or worry about the admission of Chinese students once they are classified either as overseas Chinese or as foreign students.

According to the 2009 Academic Ranking of World Universities (ARWU), which was published by the Center for World-Class Universities and the Institute of Higher Education of Shanghai Jiao Tong University, NTU ranked 150th in 2009, up from 164th the previous year, and maintained its place as the top university in Taiwan, China and Hong Kong.
Lee said that although National University of Singapore ranked higher than NTU at 142nd in 2009, he is confident that NTU will "surpass them within two years".
In October, NTU for the first time made the top 100 list of the Times Higher Education -- QS World University Rankings for 2009, with a ranking of 95.

DOC.HEADLINE: National H1N1 vaccination program launched
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 16:56:38 (By Chen Ching-fang, Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A national inoculation program against influenza A(H1N1) , commonly known as swine flu, was launched Saturday, targeting the entire population in an effort to stem the spread of the virus in the country.

The central Department of Health (DOH) has set up free vaccination stations at all public health centers, DOH-run and DOH-contracted hospitals, and in department stores, hypermarkets, railway stations and temples around Taiwan.

Deputy Minister of Health Chang Shan-chwen, while on a visit to Taoyuan County earlier in the day to inspect the inoculation operations there, called on the public to get vaccinated against the H1N1 virus.
The northern Taiwan county, where the country's main gateway Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport is located, has opened temporary immunization stations at 18 popular hypermarkets.
Meanwhile, in Taipei County, the shots were being offered at 262 hospitals, 29 public health centers and other stations.

Taipei County health officials said that the public is responding well to the initiative, judging from the fact that over 400 people were waiting at the Banciao public health center in the morning to receive vaccinations.
The population of Taipei County in northern Taiwan is more than 3.8 million people, which means that it is the largest administrative region in Taiwan.
According to statistics from the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC) , as of Friday over 3.2 million people, or 14 percent of the country's population, had been inoculated against swine flu.

Among the 12 groups prioritized in the national immunization program that began on Nov. 1, elementary school students had the highest rate of vaccination at 75 percent, followed by medical and health care personnel at 70 percent.
The lowest rate was recorded among pregnant women, at 8 percent, the CECC statistics show.
Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw said the low rate of H1N1 immunization among the 200,000 pregnant women in the country may be linked to two cases of stillbirth.
"Although it has not been confirmed that the stillbirths resulted from the vaccine, the inoculation rate among pregnant women remains low," he said.
Other reported problems and side effects associated with the vaccine include deaths among elderly people and dizziness among students, which have dissuaded some people from getting vaccinated.
DOH officials admitted the reports of dizziness have scared some parents, who withdrew their permission for their children to receive the shots.

One of the concerned parents, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Ying, told the CNA that she will wait until the vaccine is proven safe before allowing her children to be inoculated.

Kuo Han-pin, director of the pulmonary medicine department at Chang Gung Hospital in Linkou, Taipei County, said that about half of his outpatients had been vaccinated. He said he will try to persuade the reluctant ones to have the shots because the side effects are much milder than the symptoms of the disease.
National Taiwan University Hospital physician Yao Chien-an in the family medicine department said he is also doing the same, as one vaccinated person can help prevent the infection of many others.
If someone asks whether or not to take the shot, "I will strongly recommend that they do," Yao said.
The H1N1 virus has claimed the lives of tens of thousands of people around the world this year, including 33 in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges protection of human rights in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 17:26:49 (By Carfie Lee and and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government will do its best to improve Taiwan's handling of human rights issues in the future, President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday at the opening of the Jingmei Human Rights and Cultural Park in Taipei County.
Addressing the ceremony, Ma said the opening of the park is a landmark in Taiwan's transition from an authoritarian regime to a democratic society.
Emile Sheng, minister of the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng, and former Vice President Annette Lu also attended the ceremony.
Ma bowed to apologize on behalf of the government for the persecution of many democracy activists in the past and pledged to take concrete and swift action to further protect human rights in Taiwan.
The president said that Taiwan's recent adoption of two international human rights conventions as domestic law reflected the government's commitment to safeguarding human rights in this country.
In his address at the event, Sheng said the purpose of the park is to recover the historical facts pertaining to human rights in Taiwan.

Sheng said that after reading several letters sent to him by the relatives of some political victims, he is deeply convinced that the CCA has to make a greater effort to obtain more content for exhibitions at the park.

Sheng paid tribute to the many people whom he said fought and made sacrifices to achieve freedom and democracy in Taiwan, and he urged the public not to take Taiwan's progress in this regard for granted.
The CCA minister also solicited the opinion and advice of the public to better equip the park with historical artifacts.

The Jingmei Human Rights and Cultural Park is located in Xindian City, Taipei County on the site of a former military zone that was used as a detention center and trial venue for many political prisoners, including Lu, during the "Formosa Incident" in 1980 and the period of "White Terror."
Ma and Lu toured the court rooms, reception rooms and jail cells, including the one in which the former vice president was held.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges reduction of greenhouse gas emissions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 17:57:42 (By Garfie Lee and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Saturday called on the public to take steps to help reduce carbon dioxide emissions and build Taiwan into an environmentally responsible country.

In his weekly address published on the Presidential Office's Web site, Ma noted that Taiwan is not a signatory to the Kyoto Protocol or the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). He warned that the country could soon become a victim of climate change and be punished by international organizations if it fails to respond to global efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

"For our own benefit and in order for Taiwan to become a creative and constructive member of the international community, we should think of energy conservation and carbon reduction as a virtue and work together to establish Taiwan an environmentally responsible country," the president said.

Ma's remarks coincided with a UNFCCC meeting that is currently taking place in Copenhagen, Denmark, at which some 100 heads of states from around the world are trying to decide on the future extent of reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and work out a new international climate change agreement before the Kyoto Protocol expires in 2012.
Taiwan, which has 3 per mille of the world's total population, produces around 1 percent of the global greenhouse gas emissions, a number that Ma said is way too high and is worrying.

Climate change is no longer a fictional story or a disaster scene created by special effects in movies such as "The Day After Tomorrow" and "2012," said Ma. Humans would put themselves in irreversible danger if they allow continued deterioration of the situation, he warned.

Decades ago, it might have been hard for people to imagine that some island countries in the South Pacific Ocean would soon have to relocate their entire populations for fear of being submerged as the sea levels continue to rise, Ma said.

He noted that although it is already winter, the weather in Taiwan is still as warm as at the beginning of autumn or the end of summer. The Chinese calendar, developed through thousands of years of observations of nature, may have to be rewritten if the situation continues to worsen, he added.

Taiwan's Environmental Protection Administration has laid out an ambitious plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions, and has established targets to cut emissions to the 2008 level by 2020, to the 2000 level by 2025, and to half of the 2000 level by 2050, according to Ma.

Some might wonder why the government has set such stringent targets, he said, but if Taiwan does not reduce its greenhouse gas emissions, it would be punished by other countries around the world, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records more runaways since opening to Chinese tourists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 18:01:39 (By Vicky Hsu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The number of Chinese citizens who run away after arriving legally in Taiwan has been increasing since the country expanded its admission of sightseers from China in July 2008, according to a report released earlier this week by the Legislative Yuan.

The situation calls for immediate action by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and related agencies to address the possible effects on public order, travel security and tourism quality, the report stated.
It noted that in the past 17 months since the liberalization policy was implemented, the number of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan has jumped by 9 percent.
The number of runaways, however, has also been rising, it stated.
While there were four runaways, with one remaining on the loose, in 2007, the number went up to six in 2008, four of which have not yet been found, the report said.
The latest statistics compiled by the National Immigration Agency show that in the first nine months of 2009, there were 15 runaways, 13 of whom have not been located, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: Universities to raise scholarships funds for Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 18:47:23 (By Lin Shu-yu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Several leading universities in Taiwan are seeking to attract outstanding Chinese students by offering them scholarships, but instead of using government subsidies for this purpose, the universities plan to raise funds from the business and industry sector.

At a seminar Saturday on the impact of opening Taiwan's universities to Chinese students, university presidents from the host National Chengchi University (NCCU) , National Taiwan University (NTU), and National Cheng Kung University (NCKU) shared the view that offering scholarships would be a good incentive for Chinese students to pursue advanced studies in Taiwan.
NCCU President Wu Se-hwa said that he would consider offering scholarships comparable to those granted by U.S. universities.

As the Ministry of Education has reiterated that universities are not allowed to use allocations from the government to set up scholarships for Chinese students, NCCU has contacted local enterprises in an effort to raise funds, he added.

Expanding on the NTU proposal, NCKU President Michael M.C. Lai said he plans to set up a foundation that will offer full scholarships (tuition and board and accommodation) , partial scholarships that cover living expenses, and others that pay tuition, for students with various qualifications.

Fan Liming, vice president of Shandong University, one of the government-focused universities on the Chinese mainland, said at the seminar that once Taiwan begins to recognize diplomas issued by Chinese universities, schools in Taiwan will become more attractive to Chinese graduate students because they will be able to pursue studies on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and earn double degrees.

Since 1998, the Chinese government has selected more than 30 research universities to receive special subsidies, ranging from hundreds of millions to billions of yuan annually, in order to raise academic standards. The initiative was taken under the "985 Project", which was named after a phrase used by then Chinese President Jiang Zemin on May 4, 1998 in a speech that pledged support for prestigious universities.
However, according to Fan, Taiwan's current policy of "three restrictions and six prohibitions" would frustrate the interests of many Chinese students.

In November 2008 when then Education Minister Cheng Jui-cheng announced the policy of opening Taiwan universities to Chinese students, he stressed that there will be three restrictions -- recognition of certificates will be limited to only some universities, only limited numbers of students will be admitted to Taiwan's universities, and only limited categories of studies will be recognized.

In addition to the three restrictions, the educational authorities also set six principles -- student admissions can only be acquired through applications, the number of Chinese students admitted will not affect the quota for local students, schools are not allowed to use government allocations to set up scholarships for Chinese students, Chinese students are not permitted to work other than in campus jobs such as research assistantships, Chinese students are not allowed to take examinations for vocational certificates, and Chinese students are not permitted to seek jobs in Taiwan.

Fan said that she could understand the reasons for Taiwan's step-by-step approach to the recognition of certificates issued by China universities. However, in order to attract more Chinese students to Taiwan, the "three restrictions and six prohibitions" policy needs to be reviewed and relaxed to allow more incentives to be offered to Chinese students, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: St. Lucia thanks Taiwan for medical assistance
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 19:37:37 (By Jorge Liu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: St. Lucia Prime Minister Stephenson King has expressed his government's gratitude to Taiwan for the medical assistance provided in the wake of a fire at a local hospital, according to a statement released by the Taiwan embassy in the Caribbean country.
St. Jude Hospital in Vieux Fort faced a severe shortage of medical staff due to the departure of many foreign volunteer physicians following the fire that engulfed the hospital in September.

Upon receiving a request for help from the government of St. Lucia, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs dispatched a volunteer medical team of six health care workers from Changhua Christian Hospital, which maintains sisterhood ties with St. Jude Hospital.
The members of the team were received by King Thursday, prior to their return to Taiwan after three weeks of service in St. Lucia.

King told the volunteers that their performance was highly praised by the patients, and that the staff of St. Jude Hospital had also learned a lot from their advanced medical skills and professional work attitude.

In a report to parliament Wednesday, King announced that his government has obtained a commitment from international organizations and diplomatic allies, including the Republic of China, to help rebuild St. Jude Hospital.

In addition, King said he was thankful to the ROC government for helping his country draft a reconstruction blueprint in a short period of time, the details of which has been reviewed by the World Health Organization and the Pan American Health Organization.
The reconstruction project will begin in January 2010, with the first phase of the work expected to be completed within 18 months, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: First cross-strait medical conference opens in Beijing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 19:51:22 (By Huang Chih-kuan and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The first cross-Taiwan Strait conference on the promotion of exchanges and cooperation between Taiwan and China in the field of medicine opened Saturday in Beijing.

The event was attended by high-ranking Chinese officials, including He Luli, vice chairwoman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China; Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits; and his deputy Wang Fuqing.

However, several Taiwanese health officials that were originally scheduled to attend the event failed to show up at Saturday's opening ceremony. Their absence was seen by some Chinese participants as related to the setback Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang suffered in the local elections last week.

Wang said in his opening remarks that medical exchanges will play an important role in the development of cross-strait relations, as they will cover areas such as basic medical science, clinical medicine, Chinese Medicine, healthcare business management, medical education and medical technology.
"The outlook is bright for the medical sectors of Taiwan and China to strengthen cooperation under the new cross-strait relations "Wang said.

Over the years, China has introduced a number of measures to encourage medical exchanges between the two sides, Wang said. It has encouraged Taiwanese citizens to take medical doctor qualification tests or apply for licenses to practice medicine in China, he added.

Taiwanese medical institutions are also welcome to work with their Chinese counterparts to set up hospitals in mainland China, where several Taiwanese- funded hospitals and health institutions are already in operation, he said.

Organized by the Cross-straits Medicine Exchanges Association, a quasi-official agency under the authority of the PRC's Ministry of Health, the two-day conference is themed "Creating a win-win opportunity -- cross-strait cooperation and development of the medical industry."

Some 500 experts and scholars from Taiwan, China, Hong Kong and Macau are expected to participate in the event to discuss hospital management, technology development in the medical industry and globalization of healthcare services. They will also share experiences in the field of stereotactic radiosurgery and the treatment of cardiovascular disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas credit guarantee fund to help more overseas Chinese: OCAC
DOC.DATELINE: Portland, Dec. 11 (CNA) 12/12/09 19:58:27 (By Yen Ling-ju and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The NT$1.2 billion(US$37.3 million) Overseas Credit Guarantee Fund needs further rectification to assist more overseas Chinese with their financing needs, the head of the Cabinet-level Overseas Compatriot Affairs Commission (OCAC) said Friday.

OCAC Minister Wu Ying-yih said at a meeting with overseas Chinese groups in the city of Portland, Oregon that he plans to put greater effort into rectifying the fund after it transferred from the Financial Supervisory Commission and put under the management of the OCAC.
Wu said he hopes that the fund will be able to guarantee loans to more overseas Chinese who are unable to borrow from local banks.
As of the end of November, the Overseas Credit Guarantee Fund, which was established in 1988, had provided guarantees for a total of 5,500 borrowers for credit amounting to US$1.06 billion.
It has helped overseas Chinese and Taiwanese enterprises, in more than nine industries, to obtain loans totalling US$1.6 billion from financial institutions, its statistics show.
The highest number of applications, 1,595, were from the Los Angeles area, and New York was the second with 830.

The purpose of the fund is to provide credit guaranties for overseas Chinese businesses and Taiwanese enterprises that have growth potential but lack of collateral, so as to assist them in securing loans from financial institutions.

Meanwhile, the OCAC chief also said that overseas Chinese education, which accounts for about 50 percent of the OCAC's annual budget, is still its main focus that it will put much more effort into managing that aspect well.

Currently, OCAC textbooks are printed in both simplified and traditional Chinese, with Zhu-yin and Pinyin phonetic system included, he noted. It is hoped that the OCAC could provide more assistance to overseas Chinese teachers and help more foreign nationals understand Taiwan through these textbooks, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Traffic congestion top public complaint in Taipei City
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 20:39:28 (By C. Y. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Traffic congestion is the main source of complaints among citizens of Taipei City, followed by high housing prices and surging consumer prices, according to the results of a survey released Saturday.

Traffic jams were cited by 49.3 percent of the respondents in the poll, high housing prices by 19.7 percent, and rising consumer prices by 16.9 percent, according to Taipei City councilors Hung Chien-i and Yen Kuan-sheng who publicized the results.

Also on the top-10 list in descending order were growing unemployment (9 percent) , the problematic Wenhu line on the city's mass rapid train system (8.3 percent), shortage of parking spaces (8 percent), bumpy roads (7 percent) , frequent road construction work (6.7 percent) , poor public order (5.9 percent) and low salaries (4 percent).
The survey was held to allow Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin to hear the voices of the people, Yen said.

Hung called on the municipal authorities to pay greater heed to public complaints related to road traffic, noting that it is the source of 80 percent of the public's grievances. He urged the city government to re-examine the necessity for exclusive bus and cycling lanes in some road segments.

In response to the councilors' comments, Taipei City Government spokeswoman Rose Chao promised that more effective measures will be taken to improve traffic congestion and rising unemployment in the capital. Attention will also be given to a road resurfacing project that is currently being carried out in many areas of the city, she added.
However, Chao had reservations about the city's ability to address high housing and consumer prices, noting that these are nationwide issues.
The survey was conduced Dec. 10-11, through 1,073 valid questionnaires. It had a margin of error of 3 percentage points.

According to a poll carried out late last month by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC), the top ten public complaints in the country were about rampant telephone scams, high unemployment, high consumer prices, high housing prices in urban areas, food safety, lack of parking lots, drug abuse, strays dogs, the high cost of elderly care, and too many traffic tickets.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF advocates smoother application for visiting Chinese professionals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 20:53:29 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should remove a requirement for individual Chinese citizens applying to enter Taiwan to list their profession and reason for wanting to visit, Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) deputy chairman suggested Saturday.
"In light of the current exchanges (between the two sides across the Taiwan Strait) , the two requirements should be removed, " Kao Koong-lian said.

Kao, who is also secretary-general of the semi-official SEF, said at a public policy forum on cross-strait exchanges that it is not necessary for Chinese professionals visiting at the invitation of local groups to include such information on their applications.

Taiwan maintains a ban on visits by Chinese public servants, Communists and military personnel, but this cannot be strictly observed as Chinese visitors who are industry leaders, business managers, and technicians also serve in the China government, Kao said.

Currently, Taiwan allows visits by groups of Chinese sightseeers and professionals engaged in exchanges in the fields of culture, education, science, technology, health, sports and the media, and for business purposes.

Regarding the upcoming fourth round of cross-strait talks on Dec. 22 in Taichung City, Kao confirmed that the two sides will not sign the widely discussed cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) during that round of negotiations between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
"There will be dialogue and discussions at the most, " he said, explaining that the ECFA issue has not yet been placed on the agenda for SEF-ARATS negotiations.
Meanwhile, Kao expressed the hope that the issue of intellectual property rights will be included in the fifth round of cross-strait talks.

He also said that he hopes culture and education will be two of the major topics in the cross-strait negotiations, as they can serve as a good "lubricant" in relations between the two political rivals.
