DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan bags 1 silver, 3 bronze medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 21:01:57 (By Oscar Wu and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan athletes bagged another silver medal and three more bronzes at the East Asian Games in Hong Kong Saturday, moving into fifth place on the medals table one day before the games end.

In the men's discus event, Taiwan's Wang Yao-hui finished in second place with a throw of 55.18 meters in his last try, while Chang Ming-huang won a bronze medal with a throw of 54.92 meters in his second attempt.
The gold medal went to Japan's Shiro Kobayashi, who threw 55.98 meters.
Wang expressed regret over the results, saying that they could have been very different had he not been faulted by the judge in the second throw, which he said would have been easily over 57 meters.
"I didn't grab the chance to win the gold medal when I could. I need to adjust my technique because when I throw, the angle of elevation tends to be too big," he said.

In finals of the 100-meter sprint, Taiwan's Yi Wei-chen finished third in a time of 10.49 seconds. China's Su Bingtian won the race in 10.33 seconds, while Japan's Shintaro Kimura clocked 10.39 seconds to take second place.
In the women's 400-meter hurdles, Taiwan's Chang Ai-hua took a bronze medal, finishing in 1 minute 3.57 seconds, while Japan's Miyabi Tago and Kana Tsuru took gold and silver, respectively.

China is leading the medals table with 91 golds and a total medal count of 189, followed by Japan with 51 golds and 163 total, South Korea with 36 golds and 124 total, and Hong Kong with 20 golds and 89 total.

The 5th East Asian Games is being held in Hong Kong Dec. 5-13. Some 2,300 athletes from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, North Korea, China, Hong Kong, Macau, Mongolia, and Guam are competing in 262 events in 22 sports. It is the largest international multi-sport event ever held in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Half million people vaccinated against H1N1 in one day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/12/09 21:17:01 (By Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 500,000 people in Taiwan were vaccinated against influenza A(H1N1), commonly known as swine flu, on Saturday, the first day of a national free inoculation program that targets the entire population, a health official said.

Most county and city health authorities around the country reported that they had met their goal for the day in terms of the number of people inoculated, Centers for Disease Control Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw said.
No serious side effects were reported among the people who were vaccinated Saturday, except for 15 cases of people complaining of dizziness after the shots, he said.
However, after resting at the immunization stations, all 15 recovered, he added.

The national immunization drive will continue Sunday and the rest of the week at all public hospitals around the country, Chou said, urging the public to take advantage of the opportunity to get vaccinated.

The comprehensive national H1N1 vaccination program was launched weeks after the first shots were administered on Nov. 1 to people listed in priority groups, such as typhoon victims in shelters, high-risk medical personnel, elementary school students, pre-school children, pregnant women and seriously ill patients, Chou said.
The daily average over the past month was 150,000 to 190,000 doses, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 13, or the 27th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1784: Samuel Johnson, British writer and lexicographer known as "Dr. Johnson," dies at the age of 75. The leading literary figure in the second half of the 18th century, he wrote the "Dictionary of the English Language" and "Lives of the Poets."
1797: German poet and critic Heinrich Heine is born in Dusseldorf.
1897: Russian forces occupy Port Arthur on the Yellow Sea.
1904: The first electric train comes into service on London's Metropolitan Railway.
1916: Some 9,000 Austro-Hungarian troops are killed in an avalanche in the Alps.
1918: U.S. President Thomas Woodrow Wilson arrives in France, becoming the first American president to visit a European country.
1921: Britain, the United States, France and Japan sign the Washington Treaty, pledging to respect each others' claims over insular possessions in the Pacific.
1937: Japanese troops occupy Nanking. During the following two months, the aggressors rape and kill some 300,000 Chinese and lay waste to the city in what would become known as the "Rape of Nanking."
1944: A Japanese kamikaze pilot crashes his plane into the U.S. cruiser Nashville, killing 133 crew members.
1955: In the U.N Security Council, China vetoes the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.
1961: Anna Mary Robertson Moses, known as "Grandma Moses," an American painter noted for her colorful primitive-style paintings of rural scenes, dies in New York at the age of 101.
1963: The Junior Chamber of the Republic of China announces the list of winners of the ten "outstanding youth awards."
1968: The Hsin Hsin Bus Co. is established, becoming the first private bus company in Taipei City.
1972: On the last U.S. mission to the moon, Apollo 17 astronauts unveil a plaque on the lunar surface dedicated to peace.
1974: Malta, the former British crown colony which became an independent country in 1964, changes its form of government to that of a republic.
1976: A four-member Chinese judo team leaves Taipei for Spain to participate in the second world youth judo championships.
1978: The first council meeting of the Organization of African Freedom opens in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
1982: An earthquake devastates Dhamar Province in Yemen, killing 3,000 people and injuring 2,000 others.
1988: South Africa signs an accord in Brazzaville granting independence to Namibia.
1989: The first Vietnamese refugees are repatriated from Hong Kong, escorted to an airplane at dawn by police in riot gear.
1991: A non-aggression agreement aimed at working toward negotiation of a permanent peace treaty is signed by North and South Korea.
1995: Wei Jingsheng, noted Chinese democracy advocate and a 1995 Nobel Peace Prize nominee, is imprisoned for 14 years for subversive acts.
1996: Ministers and officials from 128 countries, including those from the ROC, adopt a wide-ranging declaration at the end of the five-day World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui reiterates that the "special state-to-state relationship" theory is the Republic of China's basic stance on relations with mainland China.
2000: The Executive Yuan approves a draft of rules governing the implementation of trial transport links scheduled to be established between Taiwan's outlying Kinmen and Matsu islands and mainland China beginning Jan. 1, 2001.
2001: Semiconductor designers from Taiwan meet in Beijing with mainland Chinese high-technology representatives to sound out the possibility of technological cooperation across the Taiwan Strait.
2001: Visiting Sao Tome and Principe President Fradique Banderira Melo de Menezes visits Taichung Port.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If in governing you depend upon laws and maintain order by enforcing those laws by punishments, you can also make the people keep away from wrongdoing, but they will lose the sense of shame for wrongdoing. If, on the other hand, in government you depend upon moral sentiment and maintain order by encouraging education and good manners, the people will have a sense of shame for wrongdoing and, moreover, will emulate what is good."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
More than 2,000 'walk' to mark International Immigrants Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 15:52:05 (By Chen Hung-chin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Zoo was turned into a "mini United Nations" Sunday as many new immigrants in Taiwan donned their own countries' attire during a walk to mark International Immigrants Day, which falls on Dec. 18.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah, dressed in South Korean garb, greeted participants in Korean.
"There are 960,000 new immigrants in Taiwan, and they have injected fresh blood into this land and enriched Taiwan's culture, " Jiang said.
National Immigration Agency (NIA) Director-General Hsieh Li-kung, who wore traditional clothing from Southeast Asia during the event, laid out his agency's future goals.
"Human rights, jobs, language training, and helping people get acclimated to life in Taiwan will be the goals the NIA will strive for," Hsieh said.

The NIA official noted that his agency is already working with the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to deal with the top complaint among new immigrants -- the use of different romanization systems in public facilities and on roads.
Many foreign nationals who took part in Sunday's walk have favorable impressions of Taiwan.

Nathan Kaiser from Switzerland, who has lived in Taiwan for a decade and was with his Taiwanese wife and their two-and-a-half-year-old son, said he loves the living environment here and intends to stay for a long time.
Salieh from Malaysia, who works in Taiwan and has her two children with her, said she doesn't worry about "cultural barriers" because "everybody here is very friendly."
Malaysian Kamalrudin Bin Ali, in Taiwan with his children to visit his wife, who works here, said he feels Taiwan's people are friendly to Islamic culture.

The Ministry of the Interior, which sponsored the activity, estimated that more than 2,000 people showed up for Sunday's walk. Most were Taiwanese, but there were also many foreign housemaids and foreign spouses of Taiwanese citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students join Copenhagen climate parade
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/09 16:36:33 (By Lin Yu-li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Some 30 university students from Taiwan, acting as environmental ambassadors, joined thousands of protesters on the streets of Copenhagen Saturday to demand that world leaders take stronger action to fight climate change.

Some of the Taiwanese students were dressed as the endangered Formosan black bear, while others wore cardboard cutouts depicting Taipei 101 -- one of the world's tallest buildings -- with a ring-shaped life preserver to show that Taiwan is under threat of rising sea levels.

Chen Yi-chin, a National Taiwan University student, said the group wanted to express Taiwan's concern about global warming and climate change and its willingness to help resolve the crisis, at the same time as the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) is being held in Denmark's capital.

Many individuals and environmental groups from around the world braved 2 degree Celsius temperatures to participate in the march, with some dressing as polar bears, which are under serious threat of becoming extinct because of global warming.

Donning a Formosan black bear costume, National Chung Hsing University student Chen Kuan-wei said he was proud to shout the name "Taiwan" at an international airport and bring the symbol of Taiwan's wildlife conservation efforts to Copenhagen.
Taiwan has been excluded, however, from participating in the U.N. climate talks as a "state" because it is neither a member of the U.N. nor a signatory nation of the UNFCCC.

To reflect the country's discontent, Cheng Yuan-ching, an official of Taiwan's Government Information Office posted in Denmark, wrote a letter to the editor published on Saturday in the Jyllands-Posten -- Denmark's largest newspaper with a daily circulation of over 170,000.

Cheng said in the letter that although the conference being held from Dec. 7-18 is the most important climate conference in history, event organizers excluded Taiwan from participating, in defiance of the goal of acknowledging that the global nature of climate change calls for the widest possible cooperation by all countries.
Even Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute, a nongovernmental organization, was listed as being in China, Cheng protested.
Taiwan's inability to join a U.N. carbon emission quota allocation will hurt the competitiveness of Taiwan's green technology industry and affect its development, he argued.
Cheng said the event's organizers should have invited Taiwan to attend the UNFCCC meetings as an observer, adding that it could provide support that they cannot afford to ignore.

Despite Taiwan's exclusion from the conference, the young environmental ambassadors posted the minutes of the meetings and what they saw and heard online at http: //blog.yam.com/tisecop15 to give the public a better understanding of the proceedings.

Meanwhile, NTU graduate student Lin Ting-chie said that when he chatted with people from other countries during the rally, he expressed the concerns of Taiwan's students over global warming and told them that global warming is a public issue that stretches beyond boundaries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA debate should be well planned: DPP chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 18:01:12 (By Bian Chin-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou should come up with a well-devised format if he is sincere in suggesting holding a public debate on his administration's controversial plan to sign a free trade pact with China, an opposition leader said Sunday.

"If President Ma indeed sees the need for a debate on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) deal with Beijing, he should flesh out a detailed plan instead of merely floating the idea to news media, " said Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen.

Stressing that the government is obliged to keep the public informed of the government's policy plans and work agenda, Tsai said prior to her departure for a visit to Japan that she hopes the ECFA debate idea will not turn out to be just another of Ma's political "teases."
On several previous occasions, Tsai contended, Ma also offered to meet or debate her on major policy issues.
"However, those offers just left me feeling like I was being used... This time around, I hope the president is not playing us any more," Tsai said.

Ma has touted the urgency of striking an ECFA deal with China to protect Taiwan from being marginalized after a free trade area agreement between China and the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN) takes effect at the start of next year.

The DPP and its pro-independence allies, however, are wary about signing such an agreement with China, fearing that the pact could make Taiwan more reliant on China economically and eventually lead to its annexation by China.

Some political analysts attributed the ruling Kuomintang's worse-than-expected showing in the Dec. 5 local elections partly to public discontent with the government's ECFA proposal, and Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, decided to become more visible publicly on the issue.

In a television interview over the weekend that focused in part on the potential trade pact, Ma said he would be willing to debate Tsai on ECFA-related issues in response to the interviewer's question.
Tsai said, however, that she would not like to see such a debate end up as simply political maneuvering or verbal sparring.

She contended that through the process of debates, the people could better understand the government's major policies and what impact they could have on them, enabling them to decide if they agree with the policy or not.
"Public debates among social elites are a healthy thing, " Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wang becomes free agent after Yankees fail to tender new contract
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 18:44:19 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng, Sarah Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The New York Yankees decided not to offer Chien-Ming Wang a new contract before Saturday's deadline, a move that officially made the two-time 19-game winner a free agent and left his future with the Yankees in doubt.

"There's no doubt that we had to make a tough decision, " said Yankees general manager Brian Cashman. "We are still hopeful that our relationship can continue, but those decisions are yet to be made."

The Yankees could re-sign Wang to a lesser, incentive-based deal, as many have speculated they will attempt to do, but Wang's agent, Alan Nero, said the right- hander will now engage all 30 clubs as a free agent and take all other options into consideration.
"I think it's difficult to rationalize a non-tender as further building a bridge with a team, but we'll see," Nero said.

Wang could be a relatively inexpensive addition for another club, and some believe that the Los Angeles Dodgers -- managed by Joe Torre, who managed the Yankees when Wang had his best years -- would have some interest.

Wang, who will turn 30 in March, earned US$5 million this season, becoming the highest paid Taiwanese player in any U.S. professional sport, but he could only manage a 1-6 record and 9.64 ERA in 12 appearances.

He has never been the same since injuring his foot while running the bases in a game in Houston on June 15, 2008. The injury forced him to miss the rest of that season, and he was obviously not fully recovered at the start of 2009.

After three disastrous starts, he was sent to the minors to continue his rehabilitation. He then returned to the Yankees in late May and seemed to be making progress until he injured his right shoulder.
Wang, who is eligible for arbitration, would have had to be tendered a contract of at least US$4 million, or no more than a 20 percent pay cut from his 2009 salary.

The Taiwanese hurler is not expected to pitch until sometime between April and June, and the Yankees obviously did not want to risk committing US$4 million to a pitcher who may not be productive in the upcoming season.
Wang's mother-in-law said in Kaohsiung Sunday that all family members support Wang no matter what team he eventually joins.
She also said that Wang has not shown much emotion over the Yankees' latest move and that the family "will respect his decision."
Wang returned with his wife and their new born son to Tainan last month, but he couldn't reached as of Sunday afternoon.
Beset by injuries since signing with the Yankees in 2000, Wang was finally called up to the big league club in 2005, when he compiled a respectable 8-5 record and 4.02 ERA.

He had a breakout season in 2006, winning 19 games to tie for the major league with Johan Santana and posting a 3.63 ERA. He finished second to Santana in the voting for the American League Cy Young award, the most prestigious award for Major League pitchers.
He again recorded 19 wins in 2007 despite starting the season in the disabled list.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan bags two more gold medals at East Asian Games
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 18:54:44 (By Oscar Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan held off challenges from Japan and China to secure the coveted gold medal in the men's 4x100m relay at the 2009 East Asian Games Sunday and then completed its gold medal haul in Hong Kong by winning the men's doubles in badminton.
The two gold medals brought Taiwan's total to eight in the quadrennial sports competition, which ended Sunday.

The team of Tu Chia-lin, Liu Yuan-kai, Tsai Meng-lin and Yi Wei-chen won the 4x100m relay in a time of 39.31 seconds, its season's best but still four-tenths of a second off the East Asian Games record of 38.93 set by Japan in 2001.
Japan was second with a time of 39.40, and China won bronze with atime of 39.86.
The gold medal was only the fifth Taiwan has won in the athletics competition -- traditionally a weak discipline for the country's athletes -- at the East Asian Games.

In 1993, sprinter Wang Hui-chen won gold in the women's 100-meter and 200-meter springs and Nai Hui-fang captured a gold in the men's long jump. Eight years later in 2001, Chen Tien-wen took gold in the men's 400m hurdles.
In badminton, Taiwan's Hu Chung-hsien and Tsai Chia-hsin defeated compatriots Chen Hung-ling and Lin Yu-lang in straight sets 21-17, 22-20 to win gold in the men's doubles tournament.
The winning duo dropped only one set in winning four consecutive matches to emerge victorious.
Taiwan finished the Games with a total of eight golds, 34 silvers and 37 bronzes to finish fifth out of nine teams in the medals table.

Entering the weekend, Taiwan trailed Hong Kong by only four medals in the overall medals standings, but Hong Kong's athletes performed well on Saturday and Sunday to secure its fourth place finish with 26 golds, 31 silvers and 53 bronzes.
China, Japan and South Korea took the top three spots with 113, 62, and 39 gold medals respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's sea levels on the rise due to global warming
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 19:24:23 (By Szu-yu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Like many countries around the world, Taiwan's sea levels have risen steadily as a result of global warming and measures need to be taken urgently to combat an increased threat of flooding, local environmental scientists said Sunday.

Taiwan's sea level has risen by an average of 3 centimeters over the past 10 years, or about 0.3 cm each year, said Fan Kuang-lung, a professor in National Taiwan University's Institute of Oceanography.

Fan, who led an NTU research team in studying tidal changes along the coasts of Keelung, Yilan, Taitung and Kaohsiung between 1991-2001, said global warming and human behavior, particularly on the west coast of the island, are leaving Taiwan increasingly vulnerable to climate change.

"Flooding will become the norm in some western tidal land areas," Fan said. He explained that when typhoons strike, flash floods that inundate rivers will have difficulty flowing out to sea because the sea's level will be higher than the river's level.
Floods could be exacerbated if sea waters inundate the areas as well, Fan said.

Human behavior is only complicating the problem, the scientist suggested. Many households along Taiwan's western coast regularly pump underground water for farming or everyday use, gradually causing the ground to subside to a level lower than sea level.
When sea water floods in, Fan warned, it will not be able to flow back out and consequently will accumulate in low-lying areas and cause severe floods and property damage.

Liu Shao-chen, a distinguished researcher and director of Academia Sinica's Research Center for Environmental Changes, said global warming, caused by increased carbon dioxide emissions, is causing the polar ice caps to melt at a pace faster than formerly estimated.

He cited the latest report by the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), which forecast that if Greenland's entire ice cap melts down, the Earth's sea levels will rise by an average of 4-5 meters, and if the entire Antarctic Pole melts down, the world's sea levels will rise by an apocalyptic 70 meters.
The SCAR report predicted that if global warming continues at its current level, South Pole ice will melt at an accelerated clip and sea levels will rise 1.4 meters by 2100.
The estimate far exceeds the 18-43 cm rise predicted by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Liu said.

"It is already too late to save Tuvalu, even if the world's nations step up reductions in energy consumption and carbon emissions now, " Liu argued. "Tuvalu will be completely submerged in 20 to 30 years."

His prediction is based on the argument that carbon dioxide, the main culprit in global warming, remains in the atmosphere for 80 years and that the CO2 layers that are impacting the Earth's temperatures today have been accumulated over the past eight decades.
Liu said Taiwan does not face an immediate threat of being totally submerged, but he predicted flooding would become an increasingly normal phenomenon.

Noting that precipitation in Taiwan will increase 1.4 times for every 1 degree Celsius rise in global temperatures, he urged Taiwan's government and people not to relent in its flood prevention efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group calls for small donation to help monitor legislature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 19:46:37 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A civic group has appealed for small donations to help it continue monitoring and evaluating the performance of Taiwan's lawmakers.

Citizen Congress Watch Executive Director Ho Tsung-hsun said Sunday that the organization needs around NT$8.9 million (US$247,600) a year to operate, but he lamented that a fundraiser in November had collected less than NT$500,000.
"We hope to get 2,000 citizens to donate NT$10 a day to help the group continue the job of monitoring the legislature," Ho said.

Ku Chung-hwa, the group's chairman, said that since it began to closely follow the lawmaking body, it has issued a weekly report, and many legislators have become aware of being subject to the group's watchful eye.

Those efforts, the group believes, have led to concrete accomplishments over the past two years, such as pushing the attendance rate of lawmakers to 98 percent, getting them to speak more at hearings, and helping increase the number of bills that clear the legislature.
But more needs to be done, Ku said, especially in shutting down a loophole that has been abused by legislators who do not complete their term in office.

Lawmakers Justin Huang and John Chih-yang Wu of the ruling Kuomintang and Chang Hwa-kuan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were elected county chiefs in the Dec. 5 local elections, bringing to 13 the number of lawmakers in the current legislature who will have left office before completing their terms in 2012.
None of them, however, have returned a portion of the subsidies they receive for winning a legislative election, Ku complained.
The group hopes to plug the loophole by amending the law so that lawmakers who quit in the middle of their term will return the subsidies on a prorated basis.
More than 100 evaluators -- including academics, journalists, college students, and representatives from civic groups -- took part in a review meeting in Taipei on Sunday.

Lawmakers in each legislative committee were assigned scores and ranked within their committees based on criteria such as attendance, the number of proposals they had made and whether they had supported bills to increase transparency in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges youth volunteers to promote energy conservation
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 20:36:42 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday called on members of a youth volunteer team organized by the National Youth Commission to spread the concept of carbon emission reductions and energy conservation as they perform volunteer services.

Praising the contribution of the Youth Volunteer Service for Regional Peace during the team's anniversary celebration in Kaohsiung County, Ma urged the volunteers to maximize the impact of their volunteer activities by stressing the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to those they help.

He also asked the team, which has grown to 450,000 members this year from 109,000 last year, to respond to global efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions at a time when the United States Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) is being held in Copenhagen.

Ma said that since he assumed office in May 2008, Taiwan has saved about 6 billion kWh of electricity, equal to the total energy consumed in Tainan City and County over 16 months and representing a reduction of 3.84 million tons of carbon emissions.

People around the country, however, need to work together to conserve energy and cut carbon emissions even further, Ma said, because while Taiwan's 23 million people account for only 0.0034 percent of the world's population, they produce around 1 percent of the world's global greenhouse gas emissions, ranking 18th in per capita emissions.

The president also noted that since he took office, the Presidential Office has been working to conserve electricity, gasoline, water, and paper, and have cut expenditures on these items by 10 to 20 percent, saving over NT$7 million annually in the process.

The president stressed that water conservation is particularly important as water shortages loom in southern Taiwan. At present, Tsengwen Reservoir's water supply is at about 39 percent of capacity, while Nanhua Reservoir and Wushantou Reservoir are at about 50 percent, Ma said.

The volunteer group was modeled after the U.S. Peace Corps, which was created in 1961 by President John F. Kennedy to help the Third World economically but also to spread democracy, the president said, and volunteers sometimes have life- changing experiences.

Ma said the child of one of his friends eventually realized the world is not fair and revised his vision of an ideal life after serving in Latin America, and he touted volunteer service as offering a unique opportunity to learn and help others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interest in Chinese feed corn does not represent policy shift: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 20:39:45 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture has clarified a media report that charged the government has covertly opened Taiwan's doors widers to Chinese agricultural goods by importing feed corn, saying feed corn purchases from China were being made to meet supply shortages.

The Ma Ying-jeou administration has been adamant that it will not open Taiwan any further to Chinese agricultural products in a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, a pledge that has been received with skepticism by the potential deal's critics.

The media report said Taiwan was opening its doors to feed corn and other grains to curry favor with China, but the Council of Agriculture argued Sunday that Chinese feed corn was being imported on a spot basis to meet emergency needs.

According to the COA, Taiwan imports 99 percent of the feed corn consumed domestically, mostly from the United States and Brazil. The imports from China were approved after being requested by local dairy farms to cope with postponed deliveries from other parts of the world or surging prices.

COA figures show that a total of 6,285 tons of the corn used to feed livestock have been imported from China so far this year, compared to 137,821 tons in 2008 and 90,448 tons in 2004, all accounting for less than 3.2 percent of Taiwan's average annual demand of 4.3 million tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: President promotes trade framework agreement with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:37:32 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will be based on the needs of Taiwan and the interests of the people, and the document will be subject to legislative review.
Comparing the pact to a book, Ma said negotiations on the agreement should be completed chapter by chapter and could not possibly be finished at once.

With two-way trade between Taiwan and China over US$130 billion annually, talks on the issue need to be held year by year, Ma said while promoting the ECFA with China during a tour of Chiayi where he visited a food processor and a machinery manufacturer.

The president argued that signing a framework agreement would help regulate economic cooperation with China, and because China is Taiwan's largest trade partner, such a move would be beneficial to Taiwan's development.
In addition, signing such a deal would prevent Taiwan from being marginalized.
The president argued that since he took office last year and relations between Taiwan and China have improved, Taiwan's mutual trust with Japan, the United States and Europe has been restored.

In similar fashion, Ma suggested, once an ECFA is signed with China, other countries will be more willing to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan because obstruction from China would be partially removed.
The president reiterated his pledge not to open Taiwan's market further to Chinese agricultural products or allow the entry of Chinese laborers.

He said that of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products allowed to be imported into Taiwan, 479 items were approved by the previous Kuomintang administration, with the other 936 approved by the Democratic Progressive Party when it was in power.
Ma also insisted again that the signing of the framework agreement would not compromise Taiwan's sovereignty and dignity.
Meanwhile, a senior official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs disclosed that next May would be the target date for the signing of the ECFA.
With a very limited timeframe, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will hold at least five formal negotiations in order to meet the deadline, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chief vows to protect Taiwan's rights in cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:49:34 (By Hao Hsueh-chin, Kuo Mei-lan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's top China policy planner vowed again Sunday to safeguard Taiwan's interests during the next round of talks between Taiwan and China that will take place later this month in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan also said she hoped plans by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to hold large protest rallies would not lead to skirmishes during the talks.

"I hope there will be no confrontation so as not to affect Taiwan's image internationally, " Lai said while in her hometown of Taichung to attend the inauguration of the Lai Family Shrine, during which she exchanged views with DPP Taichung City councilors Chang Liao Wan-chien and Huang Kuo-shu.

Chang Liao said the attitude of the police will be crucial, urging them to "respect the people's expression of views and venting of negative feelings, " and not to adopt coercive measures to "contain" their activities.
Huang suggested that the MAC run more ads to enable people to better understand "cross-strait" issues.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), are scheduled to meet in Taichung for their fourth round of talks and expected to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
Chiang said Sunday that he has told his counterpart that there might be protests during the talks, which will demonstrate that Taiwan is a free and democratic society.
He said that the resumption of institutionalized talks is aimed at achieving peace and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait.
But "the core value of Taiwan lies in its democracy, and democracy incorporates different voices," Chiang said.
The freedom to express different views should be protected and it is natural to have protests, said Chiang, who added that he had said the same thing to his Chinese counterpart.

But he also said that "freedom is restrained by law and should be rational, " and he expressed the hope that it will be "a good opportunity for China's delegates to see Taiwan as a democratic and orderly society."

During the second round of SEF-ARATS talks that took place in Taipei in November last year, Chen and the other Chinese negotiators were besieged by protesters at a Taipei hotel after attending a dinner party hosted by Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.
Chen and other members of his delegation were unable to leave the hotel until after midnight, despite a strong police presence.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said earlier that such disturbances should not be allowed to happen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-profile DPP delegation visits Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:52:54 (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation organized by Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) arrived in Tokyo Sunday to reach out to Japanese politicians from across the political spectrum.

Addressing a welcoming party sponsored by Taiwanese expatriate groups, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the party has managed to emerge from the ashes of its embarrassing defeats in the presidential and legislative elections in 2008 with gains in the recent mayoral and magistrate elections.

Thanks to concerted efforts of party members and many young volunteers, Tsai said, the party not only retained its control in three southern Taiwan counties but also reclaimed the northeastern county of Yilan.
With limited resources, the DPP had to rely on small donations from passionate supporters to finance its campaign activities, she said.
Despite all the hardships, Tsai said she was gratified with the maturity of Taiwanese voters shown in the Dec. 5 local elections -- a trend that will contribute to Taiwan's democratic development.

Touching on next year's mayoral elections for five special municipalities that account for 60 percent of Taiwan's population, Tsai said the DPP will finalize a slate of its best candidates for the races by next March.
She further indicated that the DPP will come up with a forward-looking platform to win the hearts and minds of Taiwanese voters.

The platform will lay out the party's visions for international and regional situations as well as the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. It will also present strategies to tackle problems related to environmental protection, aging population, and technological upgrading, Tsai added.
In addition to meeting with Japanese political figures, Tsai will also give speeches and news conference during her stay.
The delegation, composed of more than 20 DPP heavyweights, including two former Taiwanese representatives to Japan Lo Fu-chuan and Koh Se-kai, is scheduled to wrap up its visit Dec. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Intangible cultural heritage show held ahead of cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 12 (CNA) 12/13/09 22:01:01 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Just 10 days before the next round of formal talks between Taiwan and China, an exhibition showcasing the intangible cultural heritage of the two countries opened in Taichung Saturday, which officials from both sides said could help develop cross-strait relations.
The exhibition, which was organized by the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA), opened at the Taichung Creative Culture Park in central Taiwan with more than 800 cultural artifacts on display.

Emile Sheng, head of the country's top cultural agency, said at the exhibition's opening ceremony that as Taiwan and China have many similar cultural traditions, intangible cultural heritage exchanges can further improve cultural ties and help develop better relations between the two sides.
Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said he always stressed that Taiwan and China should increase cultural exchanges, which could enhance mutual understanding and therefore avoid necessary harm.

China's Qu Shengrui, deputy director-general of the Ministry of Culture's division of intangible cultural heritage, also recognized the significance of cultural exchanges and said he will put greater effort into expanding such exchanges in the future.

According to CCA officials, there will also be on-site demonstrations of cultural traditions by approximately 20 national intangible cultural legends from China, including papercutting master Liu Jinglan and ingigo print expert Wu Yuanxin.

The exhibition covers two main shows: one focusing on China's intangible cultural heritage that will run through Dec. 20 and the other focusing on Taiwan's that will run through Feb. 28, officials said.

The fourth round of talks between the chief cross-Taiwan Strait negotiators on each side -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin- kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will be held Dec. 22-23 in Taichung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business recovering in southern science park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 22:02:31 (By S. J. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Businesses in the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) are showing signs of recovering from a deep economic slump, as job openings are increasing and fewer workers remain on unpaid leave, STSP Administration Director Chen Chun-wei said Saturday.

Chen's assessment came as 12 companies based at the science park in Tainan County, including prominent firms such as TSMC, UMC, Chi Mei and Motech, jointly sponsored an employment fair at which more than 500 job openings were available.
Apart from the private sector, Chen said, the county's labor affairs bureau was also recruiting over 100 workers for companies from outside the science park at the fair.

Although more than 4,000 job seekers flocked to the event to find work, a sign of continuing high unemployment, Chen predicted confidently that the business environment has improved and that the park will employ 60,000 people next year and reach a production value of NT$550 billion (US$16.92 billion).
Meanwhile, the number of park workers still on unpaid leave has dwindled to around 200, compared to an average of over 600 new jobs being created in the park every month since September, Chen said.
The Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan, the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park are the country's main high-tech manufacturing centers.

The southern park is composed of two separate parks -- the Tainan Science Park and the Kaohsiung Science Park -- with integrated circuits, optoelectronics, biotechnology, telecommunications, and precision machinery the main sectors represented there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must not lose place in interpretatng its history: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 22:25:29 (By Yeh Su-ping and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Control Yuan member Huang Huang-hsiung urged the government on Saturday to carefully deal with Chinese efforts to develop systematic research on Taiwan's contempotary history, which he warned will give China the upper hand in interpretating it.

Huang, a Taiwanese contemporary history scholar, said that China's interpretation of modern and contemporary historical events and developments related to Taiwan, such as the Sino-Japanese war and the conflict between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party, could became the mainstream interpretation in the future.
Compared with China's all-out effort, Taiwan has done too little to interpret its own history, according to Huang.

Huang, who has written extensively about important Taiwanese political figures, social movements and cultural developments in the first half of the 20th century, said that based on his understanding, not many government establishments have preserved documents and archives on the Japanese colonial era, with the exception of Academia Sinica, Taiwan Historica under Academia Historica, and the National Central Library.

Although some nongovernmental foundations have dedicated themselves to preserving materials related to Taiwan's contemporary history, Huang suggested that the Ministry of Education set up a research center under the National Central Library to study and preserve such materials, especially those related to social and political movements during the years of Japanese colonization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's sea levels on the rise due to global warming
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 19:24:23 (By Szu-yu Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Like many countries around the world, Taiwan's sea levels have risen steadily as a result of global warming and measures need to be taken urgently to combat an increased threat of flooding, local environmental scientists said Sunday.

Taiwan's sea level has risen by an average of 3 centimeters over the past 10 years, or about 0.3 cm each year, said Fan Kuang-lung, a professor in National Taiwan University's Institute of Oceanography.

Fan, who led an NTU research team in studying tidal changes along the coasts of Keelung, Yilan, Taitung and Kaohsiung between 1991-2001, said global warming and human behavior, particularly on the west coast of the island, are leaving Taiwan increasingly vulnerable to climate change.

"Flooding will become the norm in some western tidal land areas," Fan said. He explained that when typhoons strike, flash floods that inundate rivers will have difficulty flowing out to sea because the sea's level will be higher than the river's level.
Floods could be exacerbated if sea waters inundate the areas as well, Fan said.

Human behavior is only complicating the problem, the scientist suggested. Many households along Taiwan's western coast regularly pump underground water for farming or everyday use, gradually causing the ground to subside to a level lower than sea level.
When sea water floods in, Fan warned, it will not be able to flow back out and consequently will accumulate in low-lying areas and cause severe floods and property damage.

Liu Shao-chen, a distinguished researcher and director of Academia Sinica's Research Center for Environmental Changes, said global warming, caused by increased carbon dioxide emissions, is causing the polar ice caps to melt at a pace faster than formerly estimated.

He cited the latest report by the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR), which forecast that if Greenland's entire ice cap melts down, the Earth's sea levels will rise by an average of 4-5 meters, and if the entire Antarctic Pole melts down, the world's sea levels will rise by an apocalyptic 70 meters.
The SCAR report predicted that if global warming continues at its current level, South Pole ice will melt at an accelerated clip and sea levels will rise 1.4 meters by 2100.
The estimate far exceeds the 18-43 cm rise predicted by the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), Liu said.

"It is already too late to save Tuvalu, even if the world's nations step up reductions in energy consumption and carbon emissions now, " Liu argued. "Tuvalu will be completely submerged in 20 to 30 years."

His prediction is based on the argument that carbon dioxide, the main culprit in global warming, remains in the atmosphere for 80 years and that the CO2 layers that are impacting the Earth's temperatures today have been accumulated over the past eight decades.
Liu said Taiwan does not face an immediate threat of being totally submerged, but he predicted flooding would become an increasingly normal phenomenon.

Noting that precipitation in Taiwan will increase 1.4 times for every 1 degree Celsius rise in global temperatures, he urged Taiwan's government and people not to relent in its flood prevention efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civic group calls for small donation to help monitor legislature
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 19:46:37 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A civic group has appealed for small donations to help it continue monitoring and evaluating the performance of Taiwan's lawmakers.

Citizen Congress Watch Executive Director Ho Tsung-hsun said Sunday that the organization needs around NT$8.9 million (US$247,600) a year to operate, but he lamented that a fundraiser in November had collected less than NT$500,000.
"We hope to get 2,000 citizens to donate NT$10 a day to help the group continue the job of monitoring the legislature," Ho said.

Ku Chung-hwa, the group's chairman, said that since it began to closely follow the lawmaking body, it has issued a weekly report, and many legislators have become aware of being subject to the group's watchful eye.

Those efforts, the group believes, have led to concrete accomplishments over the past two years, such as pushing the attendance rate of lawmakers to 98 percent, getting them to speak more at hearings, and helping increase the number of bills that clear the legislature.
But more needs to be done, Ku said, especially in shutting down a loophole that has been abused by legislators who do not complete their term in office.

Lawmakers Justin Huang and John Chih-yang Wu of the ruling Kuomintang and Chang Hwa-kuan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party were elected county chiefs in the Dec. 5 local elections, bringing to 13 the number of lawmakers in the current legislature who will have left office before completing their terms in 2012.
None of them, however, have returned a portion of the subsidies they receive for winning a legislative election, Ku complained.
The group hopes to plug the loophole by amending the law so that lawmakers who quit in the middle of their term will return the subsidies on a prorated basis.
More than 100 evaluators -- including academics, journalists, college students, and representatives from civic groups -- took part in a review meeting in Taipei on Sunday.

Lawmakers in each legislative committee were assigned scores and ranked within their committees based on criteria such as attendance, the number of proposals they had made and whether they had supported bills to increase transparency in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges youth volunteers to promote energy conservation
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 20:36:42 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Sunday called on members of a youth volunteer team organized by the National Youth Commission to spread the concept of carbon emission reductions and energy conservation as they perform volunteer services.

Praising the contribution of the Youth Volunteer Service for Regional Peace during the team's anniversary celebration in Kaohsiung County, Ma urged the volunteers to maximize the impact of their volunteer activities by stressing the importance of reducing greenhouse gas emissions to those they help.

He also asked the team, which has grown to 450,000 members this year from 109,000 last year, to respond to global efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions at a time when the United States Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) is being held in Copenhagen.

Ma said that since he assumed office in May 2008, Taiwan has saved about 6 billion kWh of electricity, equal to the total energy consumed in Tainan City and County over 16 months and representing a reduction of 3.84 million tons of carbon emissions.

People around the country, however, need to work together to conserve energy and cut carbon emissions even further, Ma said, because while Taiwan's 23 million people account for only 0.0034 percent of the world's population, they produce around 1 percent of the world's global greenhouse gas emissions, ranking 18th in per capita emissions.

The president also noted that since he took office, the Presidential Office has been working to conserve electricity, gasoline, water, and paper, and have cut expenditures on these items by 10 to 20 percent, saving over NT$7 million annually in the process.

The president stressed that water conservation is particularly important as water shortages loom in southern Taiwan. At present, Tsengwen Reservoir's water supply is at about 39 percent of capacity, while Nanhua Reservoir and Wushantou Reservoir are at about 50 percent, Ma said.

The volunteer group was modeled after the U.S. Peace Corps, which was created in 1961 by President John F. Kennedy to help the Third World economically but also to spread democracy, the president said, and volunteers sometimes have life- changing experiences.

Ma said the child of one of his friends eventually realized the world is not fair and revised his vision of an ideal life after serving in Latin America, and he touted volunteer service as offering a unique opportunity to learn and help others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interest in Chinese feed corn does not represent policy shift: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 20:39:45 (By Yang Su-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture has clarified a media report that charged the government has covertly opened Taiwan's doors widers to Chinese agricultural goods by importing feed corn, saying feed corn purchases from China were being made to meet supply shortages.

The Ma Ying-jeou administration has been adamant that it will not open Taiwan any further to Chinese agricultural products in a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, a pledge that has been received with skepticism by the potential deal's critics.

The media report said Taiwan was opening its doors to feed corn and other grains to curry favor with China, but the Council of Agriculture argued Sunday that Chinese feed corn was being imported on a spot basis to meet emergency needs.

According to the COA, Taiwan imports 99 percent of the feed corn consumed domestically, mostly from the United States and Brazil. The imports from China were approved after being requested by local dairy farms to cope with postponed deliveries from other parts of the world or surging prices.

COA figures show that a total of 6,285 tons of the corn used to feed livestock have been imported from China so far this year, compared to 137,821 tons in 2008 and 90,448 tons in 2004, all accounting for less than 3.2 percent of Taiwan's average annual demand of 4.3 million tons.

DOC.HEADLINE: President promotes trade framework agreement with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:37:32 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will be based on the needs of Taiwan and the interests of the people, and the document will be subject to legislative review.
Comparing the pact to a book, Ma said negotiations on the agreement should be completed chapter by chapter and could not possibly be finished at once.

With two-way trade between Taiwan and China over US$130 billion annually, talks on the issue need to be held year by year, Ma said while promoting the ECFA with China during a tour of Chiayi where he visited a food processor and a machinery manufacturer.

The president argued that signing a framework agreement would help regulate economic cooperation with China, and because China is Taiwan's largest trade partner, such a move would be beneficial to Taiwan's development.
In addition, signing such a deal would prevent Taiwan from being marginalized.
The president argued that since he took office last year and relations between Taiwan and China have improved, Taiwan's mutual trust with Japan, the United States and Europe has been restored.

In similar fashion, Ma suggested, once an ECFA is signed with China, other countries will be more willing to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan because obstruction from China would be partially removed.
The president reiterated his pledge not to open Taiwan's market further to Chinese agricultural products or allow the entry of Chinese laborers.

He said that of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products allowed to be imported into Taiwan, 479 items were approved by the previous Kuomintang administration, with the other 936 approved by the Democratic Progressive Party when it was in power.
Ma also insisted again that the signing of the framework agreement would not compromise Taiwan's sovereignty and dignity.
Meanwhile, a senior official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs disclosed that next May would be the target date for the signing of the ECFA.
With a very limited timeframe, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will hold at least five formal negotiations in order to meet the deadline, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chief vows to protect Taiwan's rights in cross-strait talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:49:34 (By Hao Hsueh-chin, Kuo Mei-lan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The nation's top China policy planner vowed again Sunday to safeguard Taiwan's interests during the next round of talks between Taiwan and China that will take place later this month in Taichung, central Taiwan.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan also said she hoped plans by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to hold large protest rallies would not lead to skirmishes during the talks.

"I hope there will be no confrontation so as not to affect Taiwan's image internationally, " Lai said while in her hometown of Taichung to attend the inauguration of the Lai Family Shrine, during which she exchanged views with DPP Taichung City councilors Chang Liao Wan-chien and Huang Kuo-shu.

Chang Liao said the attitude of the police will be crucial, urging them to "respect the people's expression of views and venting of negative feelings, " and not to adopt coercive measures to "contain" their activities.
Huang suggested that the MAC run more ads to enable people to better understand "cross-strait" issues.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), are scheduled to meet in Taichung for their fourth round of talks and expected to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
Chiang said Sunday that he has told his counterpart that there might be protests during the talks, which will demonstrate that Taiwan is a free and democratic society.
He said that the resumption of institutionalized talks is aimed at achieving peace and prosperity across the Taiwan Strait.
But "the core value of Taiwan lies in its democracy, and democracy incorporates different voices," Chiang said.
The freedom to express different views should be protected and it is natural to have protests, said Chiang, who added that he had said the same thing to his Chinese counterpart.

But he also said that "freedom is restrained by law and should be rational, " and he expressed the hope that it will be "a good opportunity for China's delegates to see Taiwan as a democratic and orderly society."

During the second round of SEF-ARATS talks that took place in Taipei in November last year, Chen and the other Chinese negotiators were besieged by protesters at a Taipei hotel after attending a dinner party hosted by Kuomintang Honorary Chairman Lien Chan.
Chen and other members of his delegation were unable to leave the hotel until after midnight, despite a strong police presence.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said earlier that such disturbances should not be allowed to happen again.

DOC.HEADLINE: High-profile DPP delegation visits Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/13/09 21:52:54 (By Mike Chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A high-profile delegation organized by Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) arrived in Tokyo Sunday to reach out to Japanese politicians from across the political spectrum.

Addressing a welcoming party sponsored by Taiwanese expatriate groups, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said the party has managed to emerge from the ashes of its embarrassing defeats in the presidential and legislative elections in 2008 with gains in the recent mayoral and magistrate elections.

Thanks to concerted efforts of party members and many young volunteers, Tsai said, the party not only retained its control in three southern Taiwan counties but also reclaimed the northeastern county of Yilan.
With limited resources, the DPP had to rely on small donations from passionate supporters to finance its campaign activities, she said.
Despite all the hardships, Tsai said she was gratified with the maturity of Taiwanese voters shown in the Dec. 5 local elections -- a trend that will contribute to Taiwan's democratic development.

Touching on next year's mayoral elections for five special municipalities that account for 60 percent of Taiwan's population, Tsai said the DPP will finalize a slate of its best candidates for the races by next March.
She further indicated that the DPP will come up with a forward-looking platform to win the hearts and minds of Taiwanese voters.

The platform will lay out the party's visions for international and regional situations as well as the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. It will also present strategies to tackle problems related to environmental protection, aging population, and technological upgrading, Tsai added.
In addition to meeting with Japanese political figures, Tsai will also give speeches and news conference during her stay.
The delegation, composed of more than 20 DPP heavyweights, including two former Taiwanese representatives to Japan Lo Fu-chuan and Koh Se-kai, is scheduled to wrap up its visit Dec. 16.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 14, or the 28th day of the 10th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1783: William Pitt, known as "Pitt the Younger," is made British prime minister and chancellor of the exchequer at the age of just 24. He accomplished the Act of Union between Ireland and Britain but was unsuccessful in his efforts at achieving Catholic emancipation.
1808: James Madison is elected the fourth president of the United States. His presidency was marked by the War of 1812.
1858: The French and Spanish announce a blockade of the port of Taku near the Chinese city of Tientsin prior to an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing which saw the burning of the Imperial Summer Palace by invading troops.
1887: The first U.S. hospital for cancer patients is inaugurated in New York.
1902: Thomas Nast, an American political cartoonist who was born in Germany in 1840, dies at the age of 62. He was the first to depict the Democratic Party as a donkey and the Republican Party as an elephant.
1917: U.S. President Woodrow Wilson declares war on Austria.
1941: Japanese planes bomb the American naval base at Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, killing 2,400 men and destroying many aircraft and battleships.
1949: The government of the Republic of China moves its seat of power to Taipei.
1951: The Communist Chinese launch the "three antis campaign" -- anti- corruption, anti-extravagance, and anti-bureaucracy.
1971: An unmanned Soviet space capsule sends back radio and television signals from Mars.
1973: The Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center formally opens in Shanhua, Tainan County.
1974: A three-month exhibition of Chinese products is opened in Taipei by Economics Minister Y.S. Sun. The exhibition has 10 pavilions with 859 showrooms and 465 retail booths.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford delivers his "New Pacifism" speech in Hawaii.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo announces the ROC government's plan to build Asia's most modern farm villages under the first Six-Year Economic Development Plan beginning in 1976.
1975: Indonesian troops enter East Timor as civil war breaks out after the Portuguese, rulers of East Timor for three centuries, leave the colony.
1978: Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira forms a new Cabinet.
1982: Robbers make away with more than NT$14 million from an armored truck of the United World Chinese Commercial Bank in Taipei.
1984: The Legislative Yuan passes the Special Education Law after its third reading.
1985: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the severing of diplomatic ties with the Republic of Nicaragua.
1986: The new Taipei City Zoo is inaugurated in the Taipei suburb of Mucha.
1988: A massive earthquake claims over 100,000 lives in Soviet Armenia.
1989: Lithuania abolishes the constitutional guarantee of Communist Party supremacy and legalizes the multiparty system.
1993: Ivory Coast President Felix Houphouet-Boigny, Africa's longest-serving ruler, dies.
1996: The space shuttle Columbia and its crew return safely to earth after ending the longest space shuttle flight ever at nearly 18 days.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew accepts the resignation of Cabinet member Peng Tso- kwei as chairman of the Council of Agriculture and appoints Ling Shiang-nung to fill the vacancy.
2000: Justice Minister Chen Ding-nan appeals to the government of France for judicial cooperation between the two countries to help in the investigation of kickback allegations surrounding the ROC Navy's purchase of six Lafayette-class frigates some 10 years earlier.
2001: A rehearsal for the formal commission of Taiwan's first F-16 fighter wing is held at Chiayi air force base in southern Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is indeed a pleasure to acquire knowledge and, as you go on acquiring, to put into practice what you have acquired. A greater pleasure still is when friends of congenial minds come from afar to seek you out because of your attainments."

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: Hosting int'l games

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two gold medals in mainstream events -- athletics and swimming -- in the East Asian Games have further fed the country's zeal for hosting international sports extravaganzas. While some sports observers believe Taiwan is overqualified to host a regional meet like the East Asian Games, others think Taiwan should focus first on becoming more familiar with general world trends before putting forward any formal bid.
The following is a digest of some local media reporting on the subject:

China Times: Lin Hong-do, vice president of the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee who headed the Taiwanese team at the just-concluded East Asian Games in Hong Kong, said that in terms of efficiency and infrastructure, the former British colony was excellent. Overall, the games were good, although there was little passion in the city, he said.

In comparison, the Taiwanese people participated enthusiastically in the World Games in Kaohsiung and the Deaflympics in Taipei, Lin said, adding that the country definitely has the capability to host the quadrennial East Asian Games. (Dec. 14, 2009)

United Daily News: Taiwan bagged two more golds -- in the men's 4x100m relay and men's badminton doubles -- on the last day of the East Asian Games Sunday, bringing its total haul of gold medals at the games to eight.
After winning a swimming event Dec. 10, Taiwan finished first in an athletics race, taking two golds for the first time in mainstream sports at a major meet.

Huang Yu, a professor at National Hsinchu University of Education, said in an opinion piece in the UDN that following the successful hosting of the World Games and Deaflympics in Taiwan, cities on the island are now keen to bid for other chances to host international sports event such as the East Asian Games.

But Huang is of the opinion that Taiwan's most important task now is to collect information, learn more about the application process and the politics of international sports, and set up a mechanism to screen cities first at the local level, instead of talking so much. (Dec. 14, 2009)

Huang, a Taiwanese contemporary history scholar, said that China's interpretation of modern and contemporary historical events and developments related to Taiwan, such as the Sino-Japanese war and the conflict between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communist Party, could became the mainstream interpretation in the future.
Compared with China's all-out effort, Taiwan has done too little to interpret its own history, according to Huang.

Huang, who has written extensively about important Taiwanese political figures, social movements and cultural developments in the first half of the 20th century, said that based on his understanding, not many government establishments have preserved documents and archives on the Japanese colonial era, with the exception of Academia Sinica, Taiwan Historica under Academia Historica, and the National Central Library.

Although some nongovernmental foundations have dedicated themselves to preserving materials related to Taiwan's contemporary history, Huang suggested that the Ministry of Education set up a research center under the National Central Library to study and preserve such materials, especially those related to social and political movements during the years of Japanese colonization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Business recovering in southern science park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 13 (CNA) 12/14/09 11:39:45 (By S. J. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Businesses in the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) are showing signs of recovering from a deep economic slump, as job openings are increasing and fewer workers remain on unpaid leave, STSP Administration Director Chen Chun-wei said Saturday.

Chen's assessment came as 12 companies based at the science park in Tainan County, including prominent firms such as TSMC, UMC, Chi Mei and Motech, jointly sponsored an employment fair at which more than 500 job openings were available.
Apart from the private sector, Chen said, the county's labor affairs bureau was also recruiting over 100 workers for companies from outside the science park at the fair.

Although more than 4,000 job seekers flocked to the event to find work, a sign of continuing high unemployment, Chen predicted confidently that the business environment has improved and that the park will employ 60,000 people next year and reach a production value of NT$550 billion (US$16.92 billion).
Meanwhile, the number of park workers still on unpaid leave has dwindled to around 200, compared to an average of over 600 new jobs being created in the park every month since September, Chen said.
The Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan, the Central Taiwan Science Park and the Southern Taiwan Science Park are the country's main high-tech manufacturing centers.

The southern park is composed of two separate parks -- the Tainan Science Park and the Kaohsiung Science Park -- with integrated circuits, optoelectronics, biotechnology, telecommunications, and precision machinery the main sectors represented there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/14/09 11:45:19 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Monday, moving down 1.93 points at 7,793.14 on a turnover of NT$5.18 billion (US$160.47 million).
The weighted price index grew 117.16 points, or 1.52 percent, to close at 7,795.07 Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: water shortage
DOC.DATELINE: 12/14/09 11:48:37 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Four months after southern Taiwan was swamped with floodwaters, the region is now facing the threat of a dire water shortage, as its major are reservoirs drying up due to years of environmental degradation. The relevant government agencies are scheduled to hold a meeting Monday to work out response measures.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments:
United Daily News: It is difficult to image that Taiwan's southern region, which was inundated during a typhoon just four months ago, is now facing the possibility of a water shortage next year.

Chen Tzai-chung, the South Region Water Resources Office official responsible for maintenance, said over the weekend that the region's two major irrigation and drinking water supply sources -- Tsengwen and Nanhua reservoirs -- are dying up because of landslides in the mountain upstream.

"This is a national calamity, " Chen said, adding that "if no efficient strategy is devised now, millions of southern Taiwan people would likely encounter the rigors of water shortage on the scale experienced during the post World War II years."

Chen, who is in charge of the government plan to restore the silted Tsengwen Reservoir. He noted that the Tsengwen River bed, which was once 100-200 meters wide, is now less than 10 meters across. (Dec.14, 2009)
In another report appearing in the United Daily News, Water Resources Agency Deputy Director-General Hsieh Sheng-yen also warned "the Tsengwen and Nanhua reservoirs are slowly drying up."
Liu Chung-ming, director of the Global Chang Research Center at National Taiwan University, further pointed out that southern Taiwan's Tainan area has had 300 dry days this year.

Drought and serious silting of the reservoirs have forced the Chiayi-Tainan irrigation association to stop farmers in the region from planting their first rice crop for 2010. A war against drought is at hand, Liu said. (Dec. 14, 2009)
