DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan drops in global ranking on carbon reduction performance
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, Germany, Dec. 14 (CNA) 12/15/09 17:46:29 (By Lin Yu-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked the 47th among 57 countries with the world's largest carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions in the latest climate change performance index, dropping from its previous ranking of 32nd place, according to the index for 2010 released on Monday.

The German non-governmental organization, Germanwatch, presented the "Climate Change Performance Index (CCPI) 2010" together with the Climate Action Network Europe (CAN-Europe) -- a union of over 100 European organizations advocating environmental protection -- in Germany and at the United Nations climate conference taking place in Copenhagen, Denmark.
The CCPI, published annually by Germanwatch and CAN-Europe, compares the climate protection performance of 57 industrialized countries and emerging economies.
The 57 countries and economies together account for more than 90 percent of global energy-related CO2 emissions.

The CCPI contains three partial ratings, including the evaluation of emissions trends, that of a country's current emissions level, and that of a country's national and international climate policies.

Taiwan was not evaluated as part of the system until 2008, when it was ranked 32nd place among 57 countries in the CCPI for 2009 with 51.5 points, a performance better than its Asian neighbors of Singapore, South Korea, Japan and China.
But in the CCPI for 2010, Taiwan only got 47.5 points, which pushed it down to the "poor" category.

According to the 2010 index, Taiwan's performance in carbon reduction was seen to be better than only Malaysia and China in Asia, while lagging behind India, Indonesia, Thailand, Japan, Singapore and South Korea.

In separate ratings, Taiwan fell in ranking to behind the 40th place in all the evaluation of carbon emissions of power departments, the CO2 emission volume of every unit of preliminary energy sources like coal and crude oil, and the per- capita consumption of the preliminary energy sources.

Taiwan only received a good score with its climate policies, and was seen as having improved in the CO2 emissions of road transportation, as well as those of the manufacturing and construction sectors.
Germanwatch's Jan Burck, one of the CCPI report authors, told the CNA that industrial and developing countries around the world should equally share the obligation to cut carbon emissions.
The per-capita carbon emission volume should be the same among the countries by 2050, Burck said.

Speaking of Taiwan's ranking, the expert who has helped develop the CCPI methodology, said Taiwan fell behind in the climate change performance because it has experienced significant growth in carbon emission volume per capita since 1990.
In the latest CCPI index, Brazil, Sweden, Britain and Germany all recorded the best performance, while China and the United States placed in the "very poor" category along with Australia and Canada.

According to Burck, countries are ranked against one another as well as against the criteria of keeping temperature rise below the dangerous level of two degrees. Since no country is thus far from adequately on the path toward halting dangerous climate change, the three top spots in the rankings are empty once again this year.

If Taiwan is compared only to the other countries, then it would rank in the 44th place this year, but since the CCPI compares countries not only to each other but to the criteria, Taiwan therefore ranks 47th place this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has room for improvement in carbon reduction: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 17:47:27 (By Chen Li-Ting, Jou Ying-cheng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The decline in Taiwan's performance in protecting the environment from climate change show that the country still has room for improvement in this aspect, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Tuesday.
However, it noted that Taiwan's carbon dioxide emission volume in 2008 posted negative growth for the first time.

According to the fifth Climate Change Performance Index released Monday by Germanwatch and Climate Action Network Europe, Taiwan ranks 47th among 57 countries, with a rounded score of 47.5 this year, down from 32nd in the previous year when the country's score was 51.5.
Taiwan's performance has been rated as "poor" for both years.
EPA Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said the results indicate that other countries have performed better than Taiwan and that Taiwan needs to work harder to push its ranking upward.
But he pointed out that Taiwan's efforts to reduce its carbon dioxide emissions have produced some initial results.
For example, the volume of Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions in 2008 was 4.4 percent lower than the previous year, and the per capita emissions was 4 percent lower, Shen said.
Despite Taiwan's unsatisfactory overall performance, Shen pointed out that the country is ranked 7th in terms of climate policy this year.

This, he said, demonstrates that the various carbon reduction measures adopted by the government, including the enactment of the Renewable Energy Development Act, have won Taiwan international recognition.

Meanwhile, EPA Deputy Minister Chiu Wen-yen, who was in Copenhagen to attend the United Nations Climate Change Conference, told the Central News Agency that there is a need for Taiwan's industrial and electricity generation sectors to increase their awareness on climate protection.
He noted that more than 60 percent of Taiwan's carbon dioxide emissions are from the electricity generation sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan confers medals on U.S. troops for helping with disaster rescue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 18:09:49 (By Shu-hua Lee, Yung-chieh Chou and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) has presented about 600 medals to members of the United States Armed Forces, in recognition of the help and support given to Taiwan in the aftermath of Typhoon Morakot, an MND official said Tuesday.

The medals -- bearing the words "In commemoration of the Typhoon Morakot rescue operations" -- were presented to the U.S. troops Monday by Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu at a ceremony that was also attended by William A. Stanton, Taipei office director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the MND said.
Legislator Lin Yu-fang, whose idea it was to award the medals, said that about 600 U.S. troops participated in the search and rescue operations after Typhoon Morakot.

They included 500 Navy personnel from the USS Denver, an amphibious transport dock that was stationed off the coast of Taiwan during the humanitarian mission. The medals were also conferred on members of the U.S. Pacific Command and the U.S. Seventh Fleet, military personnel stationed in Japan, representatives of AIT, and staff of the U.S. Defense Department.
According to Lin, who was also at the ceremony, Defense Minister Kao extended thanks, on behalf of the Taiwan people, to the U.S. for its "brotherly" assistance.
The medals, 3.5 centimeters in diameter, feature the national flag of the R.O.C. and an image of a rescuer carrying a disaster victim.

A total of 85,000 medals were produced at a cost of NT$1.67 million, an MND spokesperson said, adding that some will also be conferred on Taiwan military personnel who participated in the search and rescue operations.
It was the first time in the 30 years since diplomatic relations between the U.S. and Taiwan were severed that Taiwan was awarding medals to U.S. troops.
The AIT reportedly asked that the award ceremony be kept low-keyed.

DOC.HEADLINE: From salted duck egg to telor asin

TEXT.P: The bride is the daughter of Ferry Yahia, former Indonesian economic and trade representative in Taipei. Mrs. Yahia is a daughter of the Palembang datuk, an Indonesian counterpart of a great British lord of yore.

Her daughter' s traditional wedding ceremony, which took place at a rebuilt regal Sumatran palace in the Pendopo Agung Sasono Utomo cultural theme park in the heart of Jakarta, started with a parade, led by a martial-art dancing duet. The performance appears like an ancient bride-robbing ritual.

Under a noble canopy, the couple to be married, in full princely and princessly regalia, followed with a long cortege of ladies in waiting. They proceeded to the throne-like seats between those of the parents of the bride and the groom.

Siti should be fascinated to watch the wedding parade in the palace along with hundreds of relatives, friends and dignitaries. She wasn't, for she had to wait in vain until after all of them had extended congratulations to the newly-weds and their parents in law for a chance to get the only thing she wanted, telor asin.

That's one of the salted duck eggs, attached to short plumed bamboo sticks like Easter eggs. They were inserted into a straw- wrapped pole decorated like a Christmas tree. Siti coveted telor asin, which would be given away to guests as a souvenir for their lucky attendance, though she doesn't know how salted duck eggs, a common and not expensive Chinese delicacy, have come to be part of Indonesian culinary culture.

Chinese emigrants to the former Dutch East Indies left their southern Fujian home a little earlier than those who migrated to Taiwan in the 17th century. Salted duck eggs were one of the least expensive sources of protein on their diet.
Indigenous peoples on Taiwan did not take to the salted eggs, but their cousins in the Dutch Indies did. Well, some of Taiwan's tribespeople still keep away the eggs which they regard as taboo.
Over the years the Austronesian people in Indonesia have come to consider telor asin a coveted part of their diet, like bihun, rice vermicelli that is Taiwan's most popular "pasta."

They accept rice vermicelli as their own and use the Hoklo word of bihun to call the tasty food, which is also enjoyed by those Japanese born and brought up on Taiwan while it was under Japan's colonial rule.

Waiting for almost two hours, Siti was close to tears, when she was given the souvenir. All her misery was gone. She beamed when Sun Shine Kwang, chairperson of Radio Taiwan International, gave her her telor asin.

Visiting Jakarta to attend the 72nd founding anniversary of Antara, Kwang was invited to the prince's wedding party. Andrew Hsia, Taipei's economic and trade representative in Indonesia, had also been invited, but he had to excuse himself. As he had to attend a meeting in Bali of Taiwan businessmen in Indonesia, he asked Tommy Lee, his press counselor, to represent him.

While in Jakarta, Kwang's RTI signed a memorandum of understanding on news exchange with the Indonesian national news agency on news exchange. So did Antara and the Central News Agency. Their cooperation is expected to promote a better understanding and friendship between Taiwan and Indonesia, the largest of the ASEAN states.

All ten members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations will join China in forming one of the world's biggest free trade zones, come January 1. Taiwan has to promote trade with and investment in Indonesia.
"You know our Taiwan entrepreneurs have invested heavily in Indonesia," said Lester Leu, deputy director of the economic division of the Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta.

Indonesia is the third top destination of Taiwan's foreign direct investment after China and Vietnam. They invest mostly in textile and other manufacturing industries. "We hope more investment will come to Indonesia from Taiwan," Leu said.
Some investors from Taiwan must introduce products that will become part of Indonesian culture like telor as in and bihun. (By Joe Hung)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei to look into Beijing's alleged plagiarism of flora expo emblem
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 19:25:58 (By Chen Hung-chin and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taipei City's government will look into an accusation made by a city councilor, who accused China of copying the emblem design of its 2010 Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition (Taipei Intl Flora Expo) for a similar domestic event in Beijing, an official said Tuesday.

Kao Chen-yuan, head of the Taipei City Government's Department of Economic Development, said that it remains uncertain whether Beijing did pirate Taipei's design for the 7th China Flower Expo that ran from Sept. 26-Oct. 5 in Beijing.

He said that the emblem of the Taipei Int'l Flora Expo is inspired by orchids, while Beijing's emblem is based on peonies, but that the city government will ask experts to determine the similarity of the two emblems based on their design and concepts.
The Taipei City government will resort to legal actions if Beijing's emblem is a pirated copy of its emblem, he added.

Kao made the remarks at a press conference held by Hung Chien-yi, a city councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party. Hung accused Beijing of copying the emblem design of the Taipei flora expo, saying that the emblem of the 2010 Taipei Int'l Flora Expo was revealed in February 2008, while Beijing presented its design in September that year.
The two look so much alike in the choice of color, their shape and overall patterns, according to Hung.

"Besides the tiny difference on the design of the peripheral part of the flowers, the two emblems have a 90 percent resemblance," Hung said. "I think the Taipei City government should take legal actions against Beijing and seek compensations," Hung said.

Scheduled to be held for the first time in Taiwan from Nov. 6, 2010 to April 25, 2011, the Taipei Int'l Flora Expo is the first category A2B1 world exposition for Taiwan to host under the authorization of the Netherlands-based International Association of Horticultural Producers.
The Int'l Flora Expo is dubbed as the "Olympics in horticultural industry, " while the China Flower Expo, launched in 1987, is a nation-level exhibition held domestically in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER adjusts 2010 economic forecast upward
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15. (CNA) 12/15/09 19:29:53 (By Erin Ho and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A local think tank forecast Tuesday a 4.66 percent economic growth for Taiwan next year, 0.01 percentage points over its previous prediction made in October.

The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) also predicted that the economic contraction will be reduced to 2.96 percent from its previous forecast of 3.72 percent, against a backdrop of rising consumer confidence, boosted revenues for both the retail and restaurant sectors, and positive November growth of both exports and imports -- the first growth of this kind this year.

However, Wang Lee-rong, director of CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, said at a Taipei seminar on global economic prospects that the country's employment market will only show signs of slow recovery, with the jobless rate moving downward to 5.8 percent next year compared to this year's 5.91 percent.

Wang said that although the world economy has began to bottom out, there are still unfavorable factors, including a possible comeback of inflation -- a result of famine, rising oil prices, depreciation of the U.S. currency and speculation -- and a rapid accumulation of national debts among the developed countries.
Turning to China's economic performance, CIER research fellow Tien Chun-mei said the country is sure to achieve its projected 8 percent growth for 2009.

Nevertheless, he warned of the risk of a Chinese economic bubble brought about by the government's heavy financial burden, over-production, the expanding gap between the rich and the poor, the skyrocketing loan volume and rising share and property prices.

Moreover, the Chinese currency has depreciated 6.9 percent since February this year, resulting in frequent U. S. accusations that Beijing has manipulated the value of its currency at the expense of reduced job opportunities in the U.S. and demands for a correction to help safeguard steady global economic growth.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Get mad Mr. Premier

TEXT.P: Based on statistics for the first 11 months of 2009, Taiwan's tax revenues could fall NT$250 billion short of the budgeted target. It will not be difficult for the government to make up for the shortfall, but we are worried about the prospect of finding a real solution to the government's financial woes.
The huge shortfall can be attributed to the excessive optimism of planners when they worked out last year's budget, but we also believe such a result is self- induced.

The Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan has buckled under the slogan of "increasing debt to save the economy" and the strong lobbying of vested interests, leading to a spate of tax cuts rather than tax hikes.

We are worried that tax revenue shortfalls will become a long-term phenomenon as tax reduction measures passed this year begin to take effect in the future. Premier Wu Den-yih's rejection of proposals to expand the tax base and raise the value-added tax rate out of political considerations also does not bode well for future revenues.

The country's financial woes are now extremely serious. The Directorate General of the Budget, Statistics and Accounting estimates that next year's budget deficit will reach 22 percent of overall government spending, and that new debt, including special budgets, will exceed NT$500 billion. Both would be record highs.
No one likes tax increases, but the public cannot accept it if the country is plunged into financial turmoil. Premier Wu should show his rage at such a predicament.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Can Ma deliver?

TEXT.P: As world leaders are meeting in Copenhagen to discuss climate change, President Ma Ying-jeou has urged the public to help build Taiwan as environmentally responsible country.

But we notice that Ma failed to mention his most important pillar of environmental protection -- energy taxes. This omission, coupled with Premier Wu Den-yih's recent remarks that there is no timetable for the implementation of an energy tax, raises doubts over the government's determination to introduce the tax.
Without a solid policy, Taiwan would not be able to attain the goal of becoming an environmentally responsible country.

Rich and poor countries are fighting bitterly at the Copenhagen meeting on who should cut more carbon emissions. Although Taiwan is not a member of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change and has no obligation to abide by any agreements reached at the meeting, it has already experienced the disastrous results of global warming, as seen during Typhoon Morokat in August.
After such an ordeal, can Taiwan still buck world trends and recklessly develop more high-polluting and high energy-consuming industries?

We should be ashamed of our record, as Taiwan has one of the fastest emissions growth rates in the world and the rate has escalated sharply since 1999. Analyses indicate that the government, with its long-term support for low-cost energy and high-energy industries, should be blamed.

If President Ma, now that he is also chairman of the ruling party, cannot deliver on his presidential campaign promise to introduce a basic energy tax, we don't know how he can talk about building an environmentally responsible country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Let's vote on ECFA

TEXT.P: Quite a few observers have described Taiwan politics in recent years as "blue versus green, " but we believe that blue, represented by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), has actually disappeared from the political scene as the blue parties have become proxies of the Communist Party of China (CPC).

Since 2005 when then KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Chinese leader Hu Jintao signed a communique, the KMT has embraced the CPC "ideologically." Three years later, Ma Ying-jeou was elected president and the communique was even put into the party's platform.

With the KMT doing little except toeing the CPC line, the pacts signed between the two parties, including the nine agreements and one consensus reached during the last three rounds of cross-strait talks, have yielded fewer benefits than promised.

Fortunately, more and more Taiwan people are learning the truth. Recent public opinion polls have shown that a high percentage of the public wants the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to be delayed and the government to clearly explain the nature of the agreement.

President Ma has instructed that the ECFA publicity campaign be stepped up and has said he would debate the issue if necessary. We think there has been too much publicity and too little explanation of policy since Ma took office.
Against such a backdrop, the exercise of civil rights through referendum is the last safety net in the formulation of policies toward China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: What is ECFA?

TEXT.P: After the ruling Kuomintang suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 elections, President Ma Ying-jeou offered to have an open debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), which was a target of attacks during the local elections.
But what is strange is that Tsai claims that she does not even know what the ECFA is, a claim that seems to be in line with most experts and the media, not to mention ordinary people.
The ECFA has been one of the most important policies of the Ma administration. We wonder why the trade pact is still a mystery to most others even after one year of intensive publicity campaign.

The ECFA is without doubt a free trade agreement under the World Trade Organization. Taiwan has wanted desperately to sign FTAs with other countries, but has been in the past hampered by China's obstruction.
Now that China, our biggest trade rival, is willing to sign this FTA-like pact with us, why are Taiwanese people afraid?

We would like to take the ASEAN free trade agreement as an example, which actually evolved from an ECFA a decade ago. After the signing of the FTA, most of the commodities will begin a free trade, and reach a free trade status within two or three years.
In contrast, the ECFA will be for both sides to negotiate a framework, and there is no substantive free trade, or at most is about "3,000" kinds of items on the "early harvest list."

In the ensuing negotiations on specific items and service trade, the reciprocity will become more clear, but unless specific items are negotiated and signed, there will be no free trade. Such a process can take as long as several years to 10 years..
Even if both sides of the Taiwan Strait sign the ECFA next year, the situation could still be the same within the next few years.

Even so, we think that there is still room for debate, such as the impacts on Taiwan's industrial structure, public employment, as well as whether the signing of the ECFA will remove the hurdles for Taiwan to sign FTAs with other countries.
If the ruling and opposition parties could clear misgivings through debates, it will help clear the way for the KMT to move toward a new milestone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Design and concept of Taiwan pavilion for Shanghai Expo revealed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 19:47:08 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The design and concept of Taiwan's pavilion at the Shanghai World Expo 2010 was officially revealed Tuesday in Taipei, with high-ranking officials from the expo's organizing committee coming to promote the much-anticipated event.
The Taiwan pavilion, which is designed by renowned Taiwanese architect Lee Chu- yuan, features a theme revolving around nature and soul.

The outside structure of the pavilion resembles a "sky lantern" or "Kong Ming lantern, " which people fly during Chinese New Year and the Lantern Festival to pray for happiness, safety and health. It is a steel structure covered with smart film, a new kind of smart glass technology that adjusts to light under electric pressure to switch between a transparent and a semi-opaque state.
Hanging down from the roof of the Taiwan Pavilion is a gigantic globe made of a panoramic light-emitting diode (LED) screen, which will display projections of Taiwan's natural and cultural images.
Lee said that while the 20th Century world expos empathized on technology civilization, the 21st Century expos should be focused on the spiritual and soulful aspects of human beings.

Wang Chih-kang, chairman of the Taipei World Trade Center (TWTC) -- which is in charge of the Taiwan pavilion project -- said that Taiwan's participation in the 2010 World Expo is of special significance, as it will be the first time in 40 years that it was invited.

Taiwan had not participated in world expos over the past four decades because the country is not a member of the Paris-based Bureau of International Exhibitions. It was blocked from becoming a member of the Bureau due to opposition from China, which considers Taiwan a part of its territory and objects to Taiwan participating in groups whose members are normally countries. With improving relations between Beijing and Taipei, however, Taiwan received invitation from China on May 21 this year to take part in the event it is hosting.

Wang noted that the construction of the Taiwan pavilion is going according to schedule, with the exhibition hall's steel structure completed on Dec. 10. It took less than four months for workers to finish the pavilion's steel structure, since construction started in August, according to Wang, adding that the exhibition will be installed by the end of March and trial operations will start in April.

Zhong Yanqun, a deputy director of the World Expo 2010 Shanghai Executive Committee, was among a delegation of the Shanghai Expo organizing committee who attended the ceremony to officially reveal what the Taiwan pavilion will look like.

With 137 days to go before the Shanghai Expo opens, Zhong expressed great confidence in the event, saying that the construction and preparation work are going smoothly and that the event is expected to attract a record 70 million visitors.

"I sincerely invite people from Taiwan to visit the 2010 Shanghai Expo," Zhong said. "As the events emblem is trying to represent, the expo will not only serve as the platform for cultural exchanges, but also a special occasion for people from around the world to gather joyfully together."

DOC.HEADLINE: Luxury houses to be heavily taxed: finance ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 20:03:24 (By Y. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Finance (MOF) Chang Sheng-ho confirmed Tuesday that the government is considering a heavy tax on luxury homes and said that his ministry will present a detailed plan after an initial assessment is completed in spring 2010.
The MOF has asked the Taipei City Government's revenue service to formulate a definition of luxury mansions within its jurisdiction by March or April 2010, he said.

"Based on that initial definition of a luxury home, the MOF will devise a detailed process to appraise the market value of such residences and to levy higher taxes on them across the country, " Chang added.

Citing the Taipei Revenue Service, Chang said houses valued at more than NT$100 million (US$3.1 million) in Taipei City would be considered luxury residences. The existing tax on such properties is unfairly low, he added.

A deluxe home in Taipei City can cost NT$2 million to NT$3 million per ping (3.305 square meters) , but the tax on a NT$100 million residence is only about NT$38,000 a year, Chang noted. This is extremely low compared to public space management fees for such buildings, which is around NT$50,000 to NT$60,000 per month, he said.

The MOF has reportedly notified all tax offices in other cities and counties to take similar steps based on the Taipei City model, with the intention of raising taxes on luxury homes nationwide by 2011.

On the reports, stock prices of major construction companies, such as Kindom Construction, Kuo Yang Construction, Huang Hsiang Construction, Highwealth Construction and Farglory Land Development, fell on the local bourse by an average of about 2 percent during Tuesday's trading.

Kindom, which is set to launch several construction projects in upscale districts in Taipei and Taichung cities, suffered the biggest stock price plunge of more than 3.5 percent shortly after the market opened, and did not recover during the day's trading.

Highwealth, which is planning to build a luxury tower near the intersection of Nangjing East Road and Hsinsheng East Road in downtown Taipei, with each unit valued at more than NT$100 million, saw its stock price fall by over 1.6 percent Tuesday.

Although the MOF's taxation plan is likely to affect the stock performance of some high-end construction companies in the short term, analysts forecast, the impact would be more psychological than substantial.
The luxury house tax would not significantly affect the wealthy, according to one analyst.
As long as bank interest rates remain low, the tax will not produce any major impact on the local bourse and the real estate property market will continue to prosper, others contended.

The tax is unlikely to drive down top-end housing prices in Taipei City, as deluxe homes are not usually built on average land plots, and wealthy people looking to build luxury homes will continue to buy exclusive properties, market observers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's opposition may besiege Presidential Office to protest talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 20:14:29 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) unveiled Tuesday a plan to besiege the Presidential Office in protest against what the party claimed were under-the-table deals between President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and Beijing.

The protest was being planned to coincide with the fourth round of talks between the chief negotiators of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- which is slated for Dec. 22 in Taichung.

In anticipation of Chen's arrival on Dec. 21, the pro-independence DPP is also planning to muster 100,000 people to take part in a march on Dec. 20 in the central city to voice the party's opposition to the proposed cross-strait trade agreement, known as an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

Chuang Suo-han, an acting spokesman of the pro-independence DPP, said his party believes that the upcoming Chiang-Chen talks are intended to set the stage for the signing of the controversial trade pact.

The DPP insists that in promoting such an agreement, the government must consult with the industrial sector, be subject to monitoring by the Legislative Yuan, hold public debates on the issue, and call a referendum to allow the people to decide whether the pact should be signed, but none of these things have been done so far, Chuang said.
Lee Chun-yee, a senior DPP legislator, said the DPP will oppose any cross-strait negotiations unless they are conducted in a transparent manner.
He accused Ma of being two-faced by offering to debate ECFA with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the one hand and continuing to promote the Chiang-Chen talks on the other.
Ma's move, he alleged, is made in preparation for Taiwan's ultimate unification with China.

Ma, however, has pledged he will not discuss unification with China during his term as president. He has also argued that the free-trade agreement is crucial for Taiwan to maintain its competitiveness when trading with China, as the mainland is about to sign free-trade accords with its other trade partners in Asia, which will offer those countries tariff-free access to the Chinese market.
Chuang claimed that remarks made by Ma in a recent interview with The Wall Street Journal have revealed his intention to promote unification between the two sides, which is against the people's will.

He pointed out that over 85 percent of the people in Taiwan are in favor of maintaining the cross-strait status quo, and the DPP insists that any decision to change the status quo should be made by the people in a referendum.

In a story published Monday that was based on the interview with Ma, the newspaper quoted the president as saying that "whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decade."
The Presidential Office clarified Tuesday that Ma was misquoted because what he said was "in the next decades, " instead of "in the next decade."

Lee, however, said it is not important whether the term used by Ma is "decades" or "decade." The point is how come Ma can decide on behalf of the people that Taiwan will ultimately move toward unification with China, instead of achieving independence or maintaining the status quo, he added.
"If Ma is to promote unification with China against the people's will, the people will be forced to shed blood to resist tyranny, " he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: 560,000 people vaccinated on first national immunization day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 21:07:54 (By Chen Chin-fang and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Some 560,000 people were vaccinated against influenza A (H1N1), commonly known as swine flu, on the first day of a national free inoculation program that began Dec. 12, bringing to 4.12 million the total number of people immunized in the country, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Central Epidemics Command Center (CECC).

Deputy Minister of Health Chang Shan-chwen said at a CECC press conference that Taiwan is among the world's top five countries with the highest inoculation rate, as since the DOH's immunization program started Nov. 1, 17.9 percent of Taiwan's 23 million people have been vaccinated against H1N1.

"Given that no country but Taiwan has held a large-scale inoculation program in schools, it could also be a world record that 80 percent of lower-grade and 75 percent of higher-grade elementary school students have been vaccinated," Chang said.

Targeting the entire population in an effort to stem the spread of H1N1 following an inoculation program for people considered at higher risk of contracting the disease, the national inoculation program kicked off Dec. 12 in 2,584 clinics and hospitals and 354 free vaccination stations set up by the Department of Health (DOH).
According to CECC statistics, 563,712 people received vaccinations on the first day of the program, with 20 counties and cities meeting their target numbers of inoculations.
Among them, Lienchiang County, Chiayi City, Chiayi County, Tainan County and Taitung County vaccinated 1.5-3.5 times more people than expected, the CECC added.
The H1N1 virus has claimed the lives of tens of thousands of people around the world this year, including 35 in Taiwan.

Meanwhile that day, Health Minister Yang Chih-liang said in an interview with a local radio station that compared with other countries in the region, Taiwan has done a good job with its vaccination program and getting the epidemic under control.

He noted that over 4 million of 7 million vaccines doses acquired by the government have been used, while the rate of people developing side effects after receiving the vaccine is similar to the international level.
Also, people in Taiwan should consider themselves lucky because the government's immunization program is free and covers everybody, said the health minister.
According to Yang, Hong Kong, which has only one-third of Taiwan's population, has had twice the number of H1N1 deaths recorded in Taiwan, despite having acquired H1N1 vaccines much earlier.
He also noted that in Japan, only low-income people are eligible for free vaccinations, while in the United States, they are free only for seriously ill patients and children.

Rebutting criticism that the government is giving profits to Adimmune Corp., Taiwan's only human vaccine manufacturer, by purchasing their vaccine, Yang pointed out that the company produces high-quality vaccine at only half the price of imported products.
The company also has stricter standards in testing for residues and toxins than the World Health Organization, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fishing pact with China does not signal labor market opening: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 21:35:50 (By C. C. Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun denied Tuesday that a fishing labor pact to be signed soon between Taiwan and China is meant to pave the way for Taiwan's opening to Chinese workers.

Liu said the media report on the issue was "totally groundless" and stressed that the fishing cooperation pact, to be clinched in the upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks in Taichung City, "has nothing to do with the importation of Chinese workers into Taiwan."

The MAC vice chairman urged the public to stay calm over the matter prior to the fourth round of cross-strait negotiations, because the government is not planning to allow in fishery workers or white-collar employees from China.

The fishing crew cooperation pact, along with three other agreements on agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation, will be signed in the coming round of talks between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) from Dec. 22 in Taichung, central Taiwan.

According to Liu, the main objective of the fishing labor agreement is to ensure proper management of Chinese fishermen on Taiwan fishing vessels so as to guarantee the rights and personal safety of people from both sides.
The pact is meant to help Taiwan's ship owners better manage Chinese crews, and the key stipulation that Chinese fishermen must be hired offshore remains unchanged, he said.

More than 2,000 of the approximately 4,600 Chinese nationals currently employed on Taiwanese offshore fishing vessels and over 10,000 Chinese laborers working on board Taiwan deep-sea vessels were recruited by private brokers, which makes it very difficult for Taiwan fishing boat operators to check the crews' credentials, Liu explained.

Under the terms of the planned fishing labor pact, Taiwanese fishing vessel owners will be able to recruit qualified crew through an institutionalized channel and ask China to assume responsibility in cases of mutiny, he added.
In related news, Council of Agriculture (COA) Minister Chen Wu-hsiung reiterated Tuesday the restrictions on 830 banned Chinese agricultural and industrial items will not be lifted.
"I will step down as COA chairman if any of these Chinese products are allowed to enter Taiwan, " Chen vowed during a citation ceremony for the 10 most outstanding agricultural promotional depots.
The upcoming cross-strait agricultural quarantine inspection agreement aims only to provide quick and safe shipment of agricultural products between the two sides, he stressed.
The newspaper report that claims Taiwan is about to open its market to a wider range of agricultural products from China is far-fetched, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank to solicit views on coins honoring democracy pioneer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 21:49:14 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Among the coins in circulation in Taiwan, only portraits of three historical figures -- Dr. Sun Yat-sen, late President Chiang Kai-shek and aboriginal resistor against Japanese rule Mona Rudao -- are featured, but the Central Bank of the Republic of China is considering whether to issue a new coin bearing an image of Taiwanese democracy pioneer Chiang Wei-shui.
However, it remains unclear whether the coin will be a commemorative coin or a replacement for the existing NT$10 coin featuring Chiang Kai-shek, which was introduced 28 years ago.

Lin Fu-hsin, Deputy Director-General of the bank's Department of Issuing, said the central bank will solicit public opinion on the issue before presenting a proposal to the Executive Yuan for approval.
The bank is required by law to submit to the Executive Yuan in advance a report detailing the face value, composition, form and design of any new version of banknotes or coins.

Rebutting reports that President Ma Ying-jeou has failed to deliver on a campaign promise to issue commemorative coins bearing the likeness of Chiang Wei-shui, the Presidential Office said Monday that the central bank will introduce the new coin at the proper time and according to its own rules.

The Liberty Times reported that same day that following his election in March last year, Ma wrote a letter to ask Chiang's descendants for their consent to replace the current NT$10 coin -- which bears the likeness of the late President Chiang Kai-shek -- with one showing the prominent late Taiwanese dissident.
According to the report, Chiang's grandson, Chiang Chao-ken, said he felt disrespected, as there had been no further news about the coin, despite the family's agreement that it could be minted.
Chang Kuo-pao, director of the Presidential Department of Public Affairs, said there might have been some misunderstanding over the issue.

Chang said Chiang's descendants thought after they received the letter from Ma that the central bank would issue a new version of the NT$10 coin, but he pointed out that the issuance of a commemorative coin has to follow administrative procedures.

He explained that Ma had suggested to Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan that it would be better to issue commemorative coins featuring Taiwanese historical figures rather than the past precedent of having the new president on the post- election coins issued as keepsakes.
However, the central bank still issued coins for commemorating the inauguration of the president and vice president in May 2008 bearing images of Ma and Vice President Vincent Siew.
According to a central bank official at Department of Issuing, some 9,000 sets of gold commemorative coins and 46,000 sets of silver coins have been sold.
At present, the NT$10, NT$5 and NT$1 coins all bear the image of Chiang Kai- shek.
It was not until 2001, when the central bank issued a new NT$20-denomination coin bearing the portrait of Mona Rudao, that the trend of using Chiang Kai- shek's portrait was changed.

The portrait of Sun Yat-sen -- frequently referred to as the Father of the Nation -- has been used twice in the country's coin history. First was on a commemorative NT$10 coin to celebrate the nation's 90th birthday in 2001, and again on the NT$50 coin introduced in 2002.
Known as "Taiwan's Sun Yat-sen," Chiang Wei-shui was a doctor and also founder of the Taiwanese Cultural Association and the Taiwanese People's Party -- the island's first legal political party.

He was imprisoned several times under Japanese rule and is seen as one of the most important figures in the colonial-era resistance movement. He died in 1931 at the age of 40 and the freeway from Taipei to Suao in his native Yilan County is named after him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mine clearing on Kinmen, Matsu making progress: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 21:55:57 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The military's efforts to remove landmines on two of Taiwan's outlying islands are making good progress, with demining work 46.4 percent complete on Kinmen and 33.3 percent complete on Matsu, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday.
According to the Anti-Personnel Landmines Control Act enacted in 2006, all anti- personnel landmines on the two islands must be cleared by 2013.
Hsiao Tung-le, chief engineer of the Army Command Headquarters, said that 47 minefields on Kinmen and 35 on Matsu have so far been cleared.

On the disposal of waste ordnance, Chen Chung-yuan, deputy commander for ammunition affairs at the Combined Logistics Command, said the military decommissioned more than 50,000 tons of ordnance between 2005 and November this year.
While 93 percent of the materiel has been disposed of, the rest is expected to have been treated by June 2010, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA inks cooperative MOU with Indonesian news agency
DOC.DATELINE: Jakarta, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 22:07:26 (By Charales Kang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's CNA signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with the Antara News Agency of Indonesia Tuesday to promote bilateral news exchanges and cooperation.
CNA Chairman Joe Hung and Antara President Ahmad Mukhlis Yusuf inked the pact at a ceremony held earlier in the day at Antara headquarters in Jakarta.
Under the terms of the pact, in addition to increasing exchanges of news and journalists, CNA and Antara will also join hands to hold news photo exhibitions.

Hung said at the signing ceremony that Indonesia, with its vast land area and population and the upcoming formation of the "Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) plus one" arrangement with China next year, has long been very important to Taiwan.
Indonesia plays a very important role in the 10-member ASEAN grouping, which will inaugurate a free trade zone with China from Jan. 1.
Hung said the MOU will be of great help to both news agencies, as each will be able to obtain information from the other about Taiwan and Indonesia.
Meanwhile in the ceremony, Sun Shine Kwang, chairwoman of Taiwan's Radio Taiwan International, signed a similar pact with Antara.
Andrew Hsia, Taiwan's representative to Indonesia, was also present at the ceremony.
Both Hung and Kwang were in Jakarta to attend the 72nd anniversary a day earlier of Antara, the country's national news agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: 100,000 Henan Province Chinese expected to visit Taiwan in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 22:09:20 (By Feng Chao and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The central Chinese province of Henan will step up its efforts to promote Taiwan as a tourist destination in 2010, with the goal of 100,000 residents traveling to Taiwan during the year, a visiting provincial official said Tuesday.
The first group of 10,000 tourists will arrive in January, according to Henan Deputy Governor Kong Yufang.
Kong said that at present, more Taiwan residents make pleasure trips to Henan than the other way around.
Only 8,000 Henan residents have visited Taiwan for sightseeing purposes so far this year, she said.

She made the remarks while participating in a ribbon-cutting ceremony for a Henan painting and folk art exhibition held in Taipei, part of an exhibition and performance series featuring Henan artists.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three winners announced for 2009 Presidential Science Prize
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 15 (CNA) 12/15/09 23:07:16 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office announced Tuesday that three outstanding members of Taiwan's highest research institution, Academia Sinica, are the winners of this year's Presidential Science Prize, the fifth of its kind, held every two years since 2001.

Presidential Secretary-General Liao Liou-i announced Li Jen-kuei, Liao I-chiu and Chien Shu as the winners at a news conference at the Presidential Office that was attended by Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-huey and National Science Council Minister Lee Lou-chuang.
Liao Liou-i hailed their remarkable academic performances on the world stage and described them as "the pride of Taiwan."
President Ma Ying-jeou will personally deliver the awards to the three scientists Dec. 18, with each one receiving prize money of NT$2 million (US$61,920), a certificate and a trophy.
Liao I-chiu, 73, took the award in the category of applied science for his prominent research in and contribution to Taiwan's breeding of shrimps and fish.

Dubbed Taiwan's "father of black tiger shrimp, " Liao is the first scientist in the field to receive the prize. He is also responsible for introducing from Israel the tilapia, a fish now popular among Taiwanese consumers.
Chien, 78, attributed his award in the category of life science, to his wife, to whom he has been married for 52 years.

Chien, a graduate from the National Taiwan University School of Medicine and internationally famous for his long-term research in microcirculation and hemorheology, said Taiwan must cultivate deep roots in scientific studies if it wants to be a strong power.
The 73-year-old Lee, a linguistic expert for over 40 years, won the award for his long-term studies of the Austronesian tribes.

Since 1968, Lee has traveled to islands scattered across the South Pacific, including Vanuatu and the Philippines among many others, to trace the origins of the diverse Austronesian languages and dialects.
"It is hard for many people to imagine what kinds of hardship and solitude a man has to endure while carrying out such a task, " he recounted.

Li commented that Taiwan's aboriginal languages are the biggest gift the country has endowed to the world because "Taiwan's aboriginal languages are essential and indispensable to the reconstruction of Austronesian history and culture."
His work on the dispersal of the Formosan aborigines in Taiwan stands as witness to his devoted research in the field.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 16, or the first day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar canlendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1773: Bostonians creep onto British ships in Boston Harbor and dump cargoes of tea overboard.
1922: Tu Tsung-ming is granted a medical doctorate at the Kyoto University, becoming the first Taiwanese to gain the doctorate during the Japanese colonial period.
1949: Chinese Communist Chairman Mao Zedong visits Soveit Union for the first time.
1962: The United States launches the "Explorer 16" satellite into orbit.
1975: Chinese Communist Central Committee Vice Chairman Kang Sheng dies in Beijing at the age of 77.
1978: The United States and mainland China announce that they will establish diplomatic relations from Jan. 1, 1979.
1988: The United States and the Palestinian Liberation Organization hold a meeting in Tunis, Tunisia, for the first time.
1991: Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lien Chan presides over a ceremony to inaugurate the South-Link Line of Taiwan's railway system.
1991: The Association for Ralations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), mainland Chinese quasi-official organization responsible for talks with Taiwan on cross- strait issues, is formed in Beijing.
1996: Former South Korean Presidents Chuan Doo Huan and Roo Tae Woo are sentenced life imprisonment and 17-year jail term, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campuses warm to tackling energy conservation challenge
DOC.DATELINE: 12/16/09 10:26:43 (Also with contribution by Szuyu Lin)

TEXT.P: CNA staff writer
The air conditioning system in Yuan Ze University classrooms is just like that at any other university. It costs a lot of money to run.

But at Yuan Ze, where saving energy has become an obsession, the air conditioning and the lights are only turned on 10 minutes before class begins and shut off automatically after class ends. Lights in hallways and student lounges go off five minutes after they are turned on.
Rather than simply preach environmental consciousness, Yuan Ze administrators also make students pay for the discretionary use of electricity to instill energy-saving concepts.
Students are required, for example, to use stored value cards to pay to play on the campus's tennis and basketball courts at night.
"The idea is not aimed at saving or making money, " said Rong-jong Wai, the university's chief general affairs officer. "We want the students to be environmentally conscious."

Yuan Ze University's aggressive approach to saving energy seems to be working. The private school, founded by business conglomerate Far Eastern Group, won a Ministry of Education (MOE) Green University competition this year by cutting power consumption 4.6 percent in 2009 and reducing the school's electricity bill by NT$19 million (US$588,780).
"The trick is to link the school's power supply and monitoring systems to the scheduling of classes," Wai disclosed.

Believing that environmental awareness should be cultivated through everyday life and in schools, the MOE started a campaign in early 2008 to get schools to take the issue seriously and offer them assistance in saving energy and water.

The MOE is limited by budgetary constraints and can provide only minimal cash incentives to schools that succeed in saving resources, but the program has nonetheless awakened institutions to the threat of climate change and Taiwan's need to protect the environment.
So far 312 universities and colleges, 248 senior high schools and 59 junior high and elementary schools have responded to the campaign, according to the MOE Environmental Protection Task Force.
Though the rate of participation remains relatively low, it has created a spillover effect among other schools, the task force said, leading to a reduction in power usage.

The combined electricity consumption of the country's schools in 2008 was 7.8 percent lower than in 2006, the task force said, citing data from Taiwan Power Co., Taiwan's sole power generator and distributor.

"That represents savings of about NT$700 million if the value of the savings are calculated based on a unit cost of NT$2.65 per kilowatt-hour," said Chang Tzu- chao, executive secretary of the task force.

A breakdown shows that vocational high schools were the most effective at conserving energy, reducing power consumption by 12.3 percent in 2008 compared to 2006, followed by universities and colleges, senior high, junior high, and elementary schools, which lowered power use by 8.03 percent, 7.23 percent, 6.54 percent and 6.07 percent, respectively, over the same period.
Unlike in 2009 when a private university won the top prize for being a "green" institution, the top 21 universities in 2008 were all public national institutions, Chang said.

That top 21 saved NT$44 million in electricity expenses in 2008 from a year earlier, translating to a reduction of 10,500 tons of greenhouse gas emissions that would have otherwise been emitted, he noted.

Of these schools, National Taiwan University, with NT$7 million in savings, and National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology, with NT$6 million in savings, saved the most in electricity expenses.
National Taichung University, however, had the highest rate of reduction of electricity consumption of the 21 top performers.
University administrator Yi Cheng-ming said the school's mechanical systems and other facilities were overhauled to save power, but getting people to change their behavior was more difficult.
"People are more difficult to manage than machines, " Yi said, explaining that it has taken more than rhetoric to get students to be environmentally responsible.
He said the university employs extra shifts of workers to patrol the campus simply to prevent electricity from being wasted.
If the person on patrol finds that students engaged in after-class studies are scattered too thinly over too many classrooms, he will ask the students to move to one or two smaller rooms to study.
If he finds that the ambient temperature is not high enough to warrant the use of air conditioning, students are persuaded to turn them off, Yi explained.

The MOE Environmental Protection Task Force said conserving electricity is not a daunting task. Schools can easily reduce power consumption by at least 5 percent if people in schools become more environmentally conscious and closely adhere to power-saving measures, Chang said.

He indicated that a significant portion of the power consumed on campuses was wasted because schools tend to use old air conditioners and conventional light bulbs that are not energy-efficient, a problem that can be easily fixed.

"Electricity bills will shrink by 10 percent if old light bulbs are replaced with energy-saving bulbs and by another 10-15 percent if out-of-date air conditioners are replaced with new, energy-efficient models," he asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local news media -- Unification

TEXT.P: After the Wall Street Journal Asia misquoted President Ma Ying-jeou on his vision of the future development of relations with China, the Presidential Office responded quickly, highlighting how contentious talk of cross-strait unification is.

The newspaper quoted Ma as saying: "Whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decade, " but the Presidential Office produced a recording showing that Ma actually said "decades." Opposition groups took the opportunity to again stress that Taiwan's future should be decided by its people in a national referendum, not by any single party or individual.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments related to the sensitive unification issue:

United Daily News: President Ma Ying-jeou reaffirmed Tuesday that he will not negotiate unification with China during his term in office and that his cross- strait policy is no independence, no unification and no use of force while maintaining the status quo.

In a private meeting with professor Winston L. Y. Yang from Seton Hall University of the United States, Ma also clearly said that "there is little support in Taiwan for unification with China." (Dec. 16, 2009)

Liberty Times: The ruling Kuomintang suffered a setback in recent local elections and a recent opinion poll suggests it has to do with the Ma administration's China-oriented political and economic policies.
A poll released by CommonWeath Magazine Tuesday showed that 61 percent of the people worried that Taiwan's economy is too dependent on China.

The survey also found that 62 percent of respondents identified themselves as Taiwanese, 22 percent as both Taiwanese and Chinese, and only eight percent as Chinese. Among those in the 18-29 age bracket, 75 percent said they are Taiwanese. (Dec. 16, 2009)
China Times: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing- wen said in Tokyo Tuesday that the party will insist that Taiwan's people decide their future.
Speaking at the Foreign Correspondents' Club of Japan in Tokyo, Tsai also said that the party will safeguard the democratic system in Taiwan to let Taiwan's people choose and decide their own future.

DOC.HEADLINE: New KMT secretary-general arrives home from U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 10:57:26 (By Bien Chin-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: King Pu-tsung, who was recently named to serve as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), arrived in Taiwan Wednesday after spending time in the United States.
Upon his arrival at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, he said he would attend the KMT's Central Standing Committee meeting later in the day.

Asked to comment on the just-concluded local elections in which the KMT suffered a setback, he said he will address the issue publicly at a later date, stressing that at present, he wants to "speak less and do more."
King, a former deputy mayor of Taipei, was widely seen as President Ma Ying- jeou's right-hand man during Ma's tenure as the city's mayor.
In his capacity as KMT chairman, Ma appointed King on Dec. 9 to replace Chan Chuen-po, who is also a KMT vice chairman, as the manager of the party's day-to- day affairs.
The announcement came as King was serving as a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution in the U.S. and drew mixed reactions from within the KMT.
Before he returned to Taiwan, King told the Central News Agency that he was also surprised by the appointment and that he would make every effort to prove the skeptics wrong.
"I will speak less and do more in the future and give the job my best shot," he said.
He appealed to the KMT hierarchy and Taiwan's society to give him time to do his best to streamline the ruling party.
It is widely believed that Ma's appointment of King to the management post was a response to the KMT's setback in the just-concluded local elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: Carbon reduction

TEXT.P: Taiwan dropped 15 places and was ranked among countries judged as performing poorly in a global rating of national carbon emission reduction performance.

But government officials said the assessment by two Germany-based nongovernmental think tanks was based on 2007 figures and did not reflect Taiwan's current situation. If last year's figures were used in the poll, they said, Taiwan should have been part of the group of top-ranked countries.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments related to the carbon emissions reduction issue:
China Times:

Taiwan was ranked 47th and received 47.5 points in the 2010 Climate Change Performance Index (CCPI) , lagging behind India, Indonesia, Thailand, Japan, Singapore and South Korea in Asia while faring better than only China and Malaysia.
It was just the second year that Taiwan was included in the CCPI, which compared the emissions reduction performance of 57 industrialized countries.

While pointing out that Taiwan's CO2 emission volume posted negative growth for the first time in history in 2008, Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen said Tuesday the decline in Taiwan's CCPI ranking indicates there is still room for improvement and that other countries have progressed faster than Taiwan.
United Daily News:

The EPA unveiled the "Taiwan Carbon Label" Tuesday as part of its efforts to raise consumer awareness of the environmental impact of individual products. The labeling campaign will be launched in March 2010 at the earliest.

"The label, featuring the words 'CO2, ' a footprint composed of a dark green heart carrying a number representing the carbon footprint of a product, and two pale green leaves, epitomizes our love for the Earth and our commitment to move toward a low carbon society, " said Yang Ching-hsi, director of the EPA's Performance Evaluation and Dispute Settlement Bureau, at a news conference held to unveil the label.

DOC.HEADLINE: Temperature to fall to 10 degrees in north this weekend
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 12:07:21 (By Wang Shu-fen, Lin Heng-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A cold air mass from China sent temperatures falling through much of Taiwan Wednesday and could further push the mercury down to below 10 degrees Celsius in northern and central Taiwan this coming weekend, according to the Central Weather Bureau.
The cold air mass will envelop Taiwan completely beginning Thursday, making the weather noticeably colder, and could linger over Taiwan until next week, a CWB forecaster said,.

On Wednesday, temperatures are expected to be around 18 degrees in the north and northeast -- with lows of around 15-16 degrees -- 22-23 degrees in central and eastern Taiwan, and 24-25 degrees in the south and southeast.

The cold air mass brought snow to Taiwan's highest mountain, Yushan, early Wednesday morning. Around 1.5 centimeters of snow had accumulated on the 3,952-meter peak, also known as Jade Mountain, as of 8 a.m.

Hsieh Hsin-tien, a technician at the CWB's Yushan station, said the temperature in mountain areas around Yushan fell below freezing to minus 1.8 degrees in the early hours of the day but had climbed to minus 0.7 degrees at around 7:30 a.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to push for cheaper cross-strait air fares
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 13:23:59 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Wednesday that it will try to push for more flights between Taiwan and popular destinations in China to help bring fares down to a more reasonable level.

Amid complaints that fares are still high one year after the launch of shortened nonstop flights between Taiwan and China, Deputy Transportation Minister Kuang S. Yeh said the relatively high fares are mainly due to the popularity of some flight destinations.
"When destinations are too popular, air fares will naturally go up, " he said. Yeh argued that if the government deliberately intervened to cut fares, it might give rise to scalpers.
"The ministry will also actively communicate with carriers in a bid to make air fares more reasonable and cheaper," he said.
Fielding questions at a legislative hearing on why the government will not step in to deal with the issue, Yeh also noted that fares on some routes have come down.
He said fares between Shanghai and Taipei's Songshan Airport have fallen 17.7 percent for tickets with a validity of 30 days and 15.9 percent for tickets valid for 90 days.
According to an opinion poll conducted by the Consumers' Foundation, 74 percent of those surveyed think that cross-strait air fares should come down.
