DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan must work harder to join in regional integration: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 15:20:04 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Concerned that Taiwan may become further marginalized after Southeast Asian countries and China form a free trade zone in 2010, President Ma Ying-jeou said Taiwan needs to work harder to be part of the trend toward regional economic integration.

"I hope Taiwan will not be further isolated or marginalized, " Ma said in an address at a ceremony held by the partially government-funded think tank Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) to dedicate its newly established Taiwan ASEAN Studies Center (TASC).

Taiwan has long faced Beijing's suppression in the international community, leaving most countries unwilling to sign free trade agreements with Taiwan or accepting it into regional economic alliances.
Ma noted in his speech that North Korea and Taiwan are the only two countries that have not signed a free trade agreement (FTA) with other nations in the Asia-Pacific region.

Since Ma took office in 2008, the hostile standoff between Taiwan and China has eased, but better relations have yet to translate into new opportunities to sign free trade pacts with non-allied countries.

In his address delivered in English, Ma mentioned Taiwan has signed a memorandum of understanding on financial supervision cooperation with China and that Taiwan is preparing to forge an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with Beijing to promote mutual exchanges further.
At the same time Taiwan also wishes to increase its interaction with Southeast Asian countries, Ma said.

His administration believes that signing an economic cooperation framework agreement can open the way for Taiwan to engage in trade talks with other countries, including the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Meanwhile, CIER Chairman Cyrus C. Y. Chu, introducing the new center, said Taiwan needs a professional research institute to assist the government and people in gaining a better understanding of Southeast Asian countries and their economic alliance, the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN) , as it forms bigger economic blocs with China, South Korea and Japan.

Chu warned that with the ASEAN countries moving to further forge an East Asian common market by 2015, Taiwan could end up isolated and marginalized, causing serious harm to its export-oriented economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF-ARATS talks should include international organization issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 16:10:25 (By Sinyao Shih and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Timothy C.T. Yang said Wednesday that the ministry will propose that Taiwan's desire to join international organizations be included in future cross-Taiwan Strait talks.
He said the ministry will propose the matter to the Mainland Affairs Council, the nation's top China policy charter, so that it can in due time list the issue for communication with China.

Yang said that "Taiwan's bid to join international organizations requires support from other countries, as well as the goodwill of China, " adding that "presently, Taiwan has seen China display goodwill on international affairs."

He made the remarks at a legislative hearing in which legislators expressed concern about Taiwan being shut out of international organizations due to Chinese obstruction and suggested that the issue be included in cross-strait talks scheduled for next week.

The legislators are also concerned that Taiwan was represented by a non- governmental organization -- The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) -- at a recent climate conference in the Danish capital of Copenhagen, and that the ITRI was listed under the name of China.

Legislator Liu Shen-liang of the ruling Kuomintang said Taiwan's lodging of protests at the meeting were to no avail and suggested that the MOFA use the warmer cross-strait relations under the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to include the issue in the upcoming meeting between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
"If this is not done, Taiwan will have to protest every time, " Liang said.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party echoed his words, saying that the issue should be included on the meeting agenda to help Taiwan's bids to join United Nations-affiliated agencies.

During the SEF-ARATS talks scheduled to take place next week in the central city of Taichung, four agreements are expected to be signed on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Indian politicians, journalists visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 16:15:39 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A former member of India's Members of Legislative Assembly said Wednesday while visiting CNA that he was impressed by the democratic developments and the plurality he has seen in Taiwan over the past two days.
Vijay Jolly is heading a six-member bipartisan delegation of politicians of India's National Congress Party and the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) on a six- day visit to Taiwan.

As a join convener of the BJP's foreign affairs department, Jolly said that the trip to observe Taiwan's democratic system and pluralistic values represents "the fulfillment of a childhood dream." Members of the delegation hope to learn areas for exchange and cooperation between India and Taiwan, he added.
He cited in particular the possibility of further bilateral economic and cooperation exchanges.
Taiwan's trade with India totaled US$5.3 billion in 2008 and direct investment in India by Taiwanese businesses to date has reached US$1.2 billion, according to Jolly.
He suggested that in comparison with Taiwanese investment in China, "there is obviously much more room for growth."

The other members of the delegation are Ravni Thakur, joint secretary of the foreign affairs department of the All India Congress Committee; Alka Lamba, chairman of the Go India Foundation and national secretary of the All India Congress Committee; Manjinder Singh Sirsa, councilor of the Delhi Municipal Corporation; Kamal Akhtar, a parliamentarian representing the Samajwadi Party; and Dinesh Sharma, a senior editor of the Hindi-language newspaper Punjab Kesari.

Thakur, who is concurrently professor for Chinese studies at the Department of East Asian Studies of Delhi University, said she was impressed to find Taipei's uniqueness as a metropolitan area incorporating tradition and modern development.
During their stay, the visitors will meet leaders of Taiwan's political parties and visit various economic and cultural establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: Better ties with China benefit Taiwan, ASEAN: Malaysian lawmaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 16:33:30 (By Erin Ho and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) cannot change its one-China policy, but the positive developments in China-Taiwan relations can help Taiwan in its efforts to sign free trade pacts with ASEAN countries, a Malaysian lawmaker said Wednesday.

Tan Sri Dato' Seri Syed Hamid bin Syed Jaafar Albar, a former foreign minister, made the remarks in a keynote speech at an international conference on Taiwan- ASEAN economic cooperation and strategy that was organized by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) and its newly established Taiwan ASEAN Studies Center (TASC).

Based on recent remarks and efforts by President Ma Ying-jeou to rebut incorrect media reports about cross-Taiwan Strait policies, the senior Malaysian official said he believes the future development of cross-strait relations will be positive, which he said means a greater opportunity for Taiwan to sign free trade pacts with ASEAN countries.

China-Taiwan relations need to be changed before any change can take place in relations between Taiwan and ASEAN, he went on, adding that ASEAN will closely watch the movement of Taiwan and China toward integration.

He said ASEAN is different from the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, as the latter handles mostly economic issues. Taiwan needs to solve its sovereignty problem before it can join ASEAN plus three (China, Japan and South Korea), he added.
Addressing the opening ceremony of TASC that same day, Ma said Taiwan is eager to be included in regional economic integration.

The two-day international conference has invited several scholars and experts from Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand and Vietnam to discuss topics that include the effects of the global financial crisis on the regional economy and their implications on regional integration, economic cooperation between Taiwan and ASEAN, the progress and implications of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation agreement in the region, and Taiwan- ASEAN cooperation beyond economic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP might deal separately with municipal, presidential nominations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 16:51:49 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might deal separately with its nominations for the 2010 elections in five special municipalities and the 2012 presidential election, party officials said Wednesday.

In recent discussions with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, most party heavyweights said the municipal nominations should be given priority over the presidential nominations, a view shared by Tsai, the officials said.

However, Tsai, who just returned from a visit to Japan, will consult with more party members before coming to a conclusion on the issue, they went on, adding that related details will also be raised for discussion in a provisional party congress slated for Jan. 24.
Tsai said Sunday in Tokyo that the DPP is planning to finalize its nominations for the municipal elections by next March.
Before her departure for Japan last week, Tsai met with former Vice President Annette Lu and former party chairmen Yu Shyi-kun, Frank Hsieh and Su Tseng-chang to hear their opinions on the elections.

According to DPP officials, Lu believes that with the next presidential election still more than two years away, the party should not rush to decide on its nominee now, because doing so too early might be unfavorable to the party's campaign.

Yu said that deciding on the presidential nominee too soon would mean exposing him or her to attacks by the ruling party ahead of time, which could be very disadvantageous to the DPP as the party has no administrative resources.
Hsieh said the DPP's top priority should be to unite its many factions to win next year's municipal elections and that the presidential nomination should be put off until after that.
Su for his part said he had no opinion on nomination matters and added that he will let the party and public opinion decide on which municipal election he should run in.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price of Master Kong TDRs jump on first day of public offering
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 17:25:37 (By Han Ting-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The price of Master Kong Taiwan Depository Receipts (TDRs) jumped by its daily maximum 7 percent at the opening of trading on the first day of public offering Wednesday.
The price was offered at NT$45 (US$1.4) per TDR and jumped to NT$48 immediately after opening, with orders to buy another 150 million shares at the day's maximum price.

The foodstuff giant's TDRs are the seventh to be listed on the Taiwan bourse this year, and its public share release was also the largest in terms of money raised. The "honeymoon effect" of the new shares is being widely watched by investors.

Wei Ing-chou, chairman of the Ting Hsin International Group, the largest Taiwanese-funded company in China and the mother company of Master Kong, said Wednesday that the group will increase its investments in Taiwan's real estate, distribution and cultural industries.
"In view of the improvement of the cross-Taiwan Strait investment environment, the group will increase its investment in Taiwan, " Wei said.
Master Kong instant noodles have a dominant 54 percent share of China's instant noodle market, while its tea beverage line has a 50 percent share and bottled water has a 21 percent share.
Master Kong Holdings made Forbes Asia's Fabulous 50 Companies list in 2009, with a total market value of NT$416.82 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: King Pu-tsung assumes office as KMT secretary-general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 17:33:53 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: King Pu-tsung, one of President Ma Ying-jeou's right-hand men during Ma's tenure as Taipei mayor and in his presidential election campaign, assumed his new post as the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 's secretary-general Wednesday, succeeding Chan Chuen-po.

President Ma, in his capacity as chairman of the KMT, officiated at the handover ceremony. Lauding King's loyalty to the party, President Ma said that King is a "very appropriate person" for the post. Ma named King as the KMT's new chief executive officer last week after the party suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 local elections.

Upon receiving the seal of office, King said that he is aware of the challenges and difficulties he faces and would do his best to cooperate with his colleagues to carry out the task of party reform. He reiterated that he would stick to the principle of "less talk and more action."
He pledged that he would make the party more attractive in order to win greater public support, and that of the young generation in particular.
King's predecessor, Chan Chuen-po, who will remain as one of the party's vice chairmen, remarked in English that "the torch has passed from one generation to another generation."
He described King as "young, experienced, decisive and capable of implementing great tasks." The appointment of King comes "at the right time," he added.
Noting that the KMT will face a series of elections in the coming year, Chan said that King will be of big help to the party in pushing forward its reforms and other goals.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 17:41:47 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.047 to close at NT$32.328.
A total of US$819 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.360 and was traded between NT$32.294 and NT$32.400.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices drop on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 17:50:56 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 56.02 points, or 0.71 percent, to close at 7,751.60.
The local bourse opened at the day's high of 7,801.30 and hit a low of 7,724.58 during the day's trading session.
A total of 3.96 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$113.76 billion (US$3.52 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with foodstuff issues moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 1.5 percent, paper and pulp issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemicals, as well as cement shares, both down 1.0 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, and machinery and electronics issues at 0.4 percent.
Of the major stock categories, only textiles advanced, gaining 0.8 percent. Losers outnumbered gainers 1,791 to 856, with 220 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$3.41 billion-worth of shares.
Institutional investors said a strong rally is unlikely in the near future unless the market turnover expands.

However, UBS Securities financial analyst William Dong said the market is expected to test the 8,800 mark in the first quarter of next year and that the market's momentum next year will hinge on a rebound in the economy.

The impact on the local bourse of a possible influx of Chinese capital into Taiwan will not be felt until the second half of next year, when a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China is expected to be signed, Dong added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Generational injustice

TEXT.P: Taiwan once prioritized economic development at all costs, which led to a squandering of environmental resources and disregard for ecological protection. As a result, future generations will inherit a huge environmental debt.
Because of that lack of foresight, Taiwan has also accumulated enormous financial debts.

Given Taiwan's ever declining birth rate and its aging population, its younger generations are already saddled with heavy burdens. The continued pile- up of national and environmental debts amounts to generational injustice.
A responsible government should not sit idly and let these problems escalate, but instead should act quickly to correct the trend of excessive consumption of resources.

The "double debt" plight is not insoluble. If the government has the guts to introduce energy and environmental taxes, the two problems could be resolved in the long run. Levying green taxes on industries in proportion to their ecological footprint would not only encourage energy conservation and carbon emissions reduction, but can also serve to fund government welfare services for the poor, develop green industries and bolster industry upgrade.

The introduction of an energy tax was one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises. It is regrettable that his administration has decided to indefinitely postpone that plan on the one hand while promoting several energy- consuming investment programs on the other.
That is an issue that should spur Premier Wu Den-yih to "get mad."

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Things the DPP cannot shun
DOC.DATELINE: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 12/16/09 17:52:49 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: has gotten back on its feet following its recent electoral gains. But as some insightful DPP bigwigs have observed, the party only managed to solidify its core support base in the just-concluded local polls.
Whether the party can return to power will hinge on its leadership's capability to lead the party onto a path of normalization.

The DPP must show a stronger commitment to uphold clean politics and ethical integrity. The Dec. 5 polls were seen as the DPP's first post-Chen Shui-bian elections, with none of its candidates trying to draw on the strength of the detained former president to canvass support on the campaign trail.

But the ruling Kuomintang still has higher approval ratings than the DPP, an indication that voters have yet to become fully confident in the DPP's determination to root out corruption once it reclaims power.

Another hurdle will be to win the hearts and minds of independent swing voters. Though it improved its share of the vote in places like Taoyuan County, that may have reflected the absence of KMT-leaning voters at the polls to express their dissatisfaction with the KMT administration (rather than the DPP picking up swing voters).

Also, when the DPP was in power from 2000-2008, it was often restricted by its ideologies. The radical pro-independence rhetoric in Chen's second term was one case of the DPP's failure to shed the specter of its deep-rooted pro- independence ideology.

Even though the DPP has emerged from the pall of Chen's corrpution scandal and its defeat in the 2008 presidential election, it has not yet freed itself from the restraints of its ideology as shown in its stubborn opposition to the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The DPP should propose an alternative package to help Taiwan recover from its economic recession and resolve the looming threat of further marginalization after the "ASEAN plus One (China) " free trade area comes into being in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity group calls for assistance to help children fulfill dreams
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 18:29:32 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A charity group based in Taichung, central Taiwan has called for public donations toward the year-end to help children fulfill their dreams.

Steven Hsiung, executive director of the Lovesharing Association, said Wednesday that this year, the group has set a target of helping 10,000 children from impoverished families to fulfill their dreams.
"So far, however, our association has received fewer than 4,000 donated presents, far short of our target," Hsiung said.
He noted that an entrepreneur friend, Greg Cook from Utah, the United States, donated 30 presents to special education students in Taichung during a business trip to Taiwan last month.
Hsiung cited Cook as saying that to be able to help children in Taiwan is significant and that he "feels warmth at bringing children great joy for little money."
Cook also promised to enlist more American friends to join the charity cause.
Hsiung noted that the association usually works with over 30 underprivileged groups and that this year, the focus has been on helping children affected by Typhoon Morakot in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: 40% of office workers interested in financial jobs: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 18:45:04 (By Chou Pin-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Positions in the financial sector are returning to the hot job list in Taiwan as the sector appears to be recovering well from the global financial crisis, an online employment broker said Wednesday.

Driven by the recovery, many financial firms have abolished pay cuts for employees. The recent signing of memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial supervision and regulation with China has also greatly boosted the sector's prospects, 1111 Job Bank said.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the job bank, approximately 40 percent of office workers are planning to enter the financial sector, mainly because they have an academic background or expertise in this area, are interested in the field, or are attracted to the high pay.
Among the workers who intend to enter the sector or are already in the sector, more than 50 percent chose to work in banks, and 17 percent in the securities and futures industry, the poll showed.

Sixty-four percent of office workers said the signing of the cross-strait MOUs has heightened their interest in pursuing a career in the financial sector, 85 percent of whom indicated an intent to work in China.

The main reasons for choosing to work in China are that career development there is better, China-invested firms have good prospects in Taiwan, and China is more internationalized, according to the respondents.

Ho Chi-sheng, the job bank's director of public relations, noted that Taiwan and China are about to open their financial markets to each other under the terms of the MOUs, which will result in an increased flow of financial talent across the Taiwan Strait.
Under these circumstances, people with professional licenses will have more career opportunities, he predicted.
The survey was conducted Dec. 2-15 among 1,239 office workers and employees in the financial sector. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.41 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung rated most digitized city in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 19:06:49 (By Chia-chen Hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taichung City was rated as the most digitized city in the country this year for the first time, with more than 81 percent of residents having used computers and 77 percent having used the Internet, according to the results of an annual survey on the country's digital divide released Wednesday.
In terms of digitization, Hsinchu City and Taipei City were ranked second and third, respectively. Taipei was ranked as the country's most digitized city in 2008.

The survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) found that 67.6 percent of people above the age of 12 in Taiwan have accessed the Internet, representing little change from 68.5 percent recorded the previous year.

Based on the results of the survey, RDEC Minister Chu Chin-peng said during a press conference that Taiwan's wired population is estimated to be close to 14 million, compared to 13.71 million last year.
The RDEC pointed that although 78 out of every 100 households have access to the Internet, the connection rate for Taiwanese households remained little changed compared to 2008.

Among households with Internet connections, one in every three households considers connection fees to be a heavy financial burden, showing that fees are one of the barriers preventing more families from upgrading their information environment.
The results show that Internet users spend an average of 2.95 hours a day on the Internet -- nine minutes more than the average of 2.8 hours last year.

They also show that 67.1 percent of respondents in the 41-50 age group are Internet users, up from 64.2 percent last year, while the rate of Internet use in the 51-60 age group has edged down from 40.5 percent to 37.8 percent.
Among the Internet users, 52 percent have mobile phones with Internet connection, 38.2 percent have notebooks with Internet connection, and 9.9 percent have PDAs with Internet access.

However, 75 percent of Internet users said they do not use their mobile phones for Internet access, even though they believe that is a future trend, with 31 percent of the respondents citing high costs as the reason preventing them from using this service.

The survey results also show that Internet connection fees would need to be reduced to NT$500 monthly per household in order to reduce the financial burden on citizens and help attain the goal of providing universal Internet access.
The survey was carried out between July 13 and Aug. 21 among 16,133 people via telephone. It had a margin of error of 0.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Three quarters of foreigners satisfied with life in Taiwan: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 19:22:22 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's efforts in establishing a foreigners-friendly environment has received a positive response with 75.1 percent of white-collar foreign residents living in the country expressing satisfaction with life here, according to a survey released Wednesday.

A majority of foreigners who had responded to a poll by the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) said they are happy with Taiwan on the whole, including their life here, work here, Taiwan's cultural tolerance, and its degree of globalization, RDEC Minister Chu Chin-peng said.
Generally speaking, Chu said foreigners felt life in Taiwan was "convenient and delightful."
Chu made the statement while releasing the results of the survey targeting white-collar foreigners who are working and living in Taiwan.

According to the RDEC, respondents were questioned in four categories, including their life in Taiwan, their work in Taiwan, Taiwan's tolerance toward other cultures and the level of internationalization here.

Asked about life in Taiwan, 80.9 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with both the material and cultural lives here; 87.4 percent expressed satisfaction with the convenience of using their mother tongue in speaking with local people; and 82.6 percent said they are content with the shopping convenience.

In terms of their work environment in Taiwan, 70.7 of the respondents said they were satisfied, with 87.1 percent of the respondents saying their local colleagues are friendly and 78.5 saying their employers are friendly, the survey showed.

Half of the respondents also stated that their fondness for Taiwanese culture is the major motive for them to stay on the island for work. Meanwhile, 62.1 percent of the surveyed expressed satisfaction with their salary in Taiwan.

In terms of satisfaction with Taiwan's tolerance toward foreign cultures, the overall satisfaction level reached 65.2 percent, according to the survey, which revealed that 72.1 percent of the polled said they saw the Taiwanese face different cultures with an attitude of acceptance, active tolerance and eagerness to learn.

While 50.4 percent of the respondents were found speaking English most of the time in Taiwan and 30.9 percent using Chinese here, 44.2 percent of the respondents said Taiwanese people employ a "common" English proficiency, according to the survey.

Meanwhile, the foreigners' overall satisfaction with Taiwan's internationalized living environment was at 71.4 percent, with 65.5 percent content with the airport and customs services and 40 percent satisfied with the English-Chinese bilingual signs on public transport tools and tourist spots.
However, only 19.5 percent of the surveyed foreigners expressed satisfaction with the bilingual labels on the packages of merchandise, the survey showed.
The survey also indicated that 88.8 percent of foreign residents think the Taiwanese are friendly, and 76.7 percent expressed they have adjusted to life in Taiwan.
The commission said the survey will serve as a reference for the government to implement policies aimed at attracting more foreign investors and talented professionals to live in the country.

The poll was conducted by Taipei-based Shih Hsin University under the RDEC's commission on randomly-selected white-collar foreign residents from Aug. 1-Sept. 15. A total of 1,076 valid samples were collected. The margin of error was at plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Accomplice in annexation plan

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's recent interview with the Wall Street Journal Asia has once again exposed his hope for the ultimate unification of Taiwan and China.
The newspaper quoted Ma as saying: "Whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decade."
Although the Presidential Office quickly produced a recording showing that Ma actually said "decades, " the issue is not about "decade" or "decades."

Ma's major fault lies in his ignorance of Taiwan's independent sovereign status. There is no such issue as unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The term "unification" is just a term coined by China to camouflage its attempt to annex Taiwan.

Ma's other mistake is his failure to recognize that only the 23 million people of Taiwan have the right to decide Taiwan's future. Since Taiwan and China are two different countries, China's 1.3 billion people should have no say in determining Taiwan's destiny. It is wrong to say that Taiwan's future would be jointly decided by people on both sides of the strait.
Most threatening is that Ma thinks Taiwan has resisted unification because "conditions are not ripe...We don't even know each other that well."

In other words, unification is a given for him. This is why he has promoted many China-leaning policies since assuming office -- he is striving to lay a solid foundation for so-called cross-strait unification.
Ma must remember that as a popularly elected president, he is obligated to defend Taiwan's national security and sovereignty. If he fails in his duty and lets the people down, he would be a traitor.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Did DPP truly win?

TEXT.P: Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang recently urged the party not to be too ecstatic over its recent electoral gains because it has not yet seen any significant expansion of its core support base.

According to Hsu, the rise in the DPP's share of votes in the Dec.5 local elections mainly resulted from some pan-blue supporters' reluctance to vote due to their dissatisfaction with the incumbent Kuomintang administration.
The total number of ballots cast for the DPP actually decreased by tens of thousands compared to previous mayoral and magistrate elections, he noted.

Hsu's view was shared by other cool-headed political observers. Although the DPP narrowed the gap between its share of the vote and the KMT's to 2.5 percentage points, if the ballots cast for KMT mavericks are factored in, the gap between the KMT-led blue camp and the DPP-led green camp would be 8 percent.
The green camp has so far not succeeded in tipping the scales from the current 60/40 percent to gain a core support of 50 percent of the electorate.
We hope the DPP will not misread its recent electoral gains and misdirect its strategy, thus losing its opportunity for revival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's airlines seeking transshipment permission in China flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 20:38:54 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation has sent delegates to Xiamen to negotiate with Chinese authorities for permission to fly cross-Taiwan Strait direct flights that carry transit passengers and operate transshipment business.

If China agrees, flights, currently only allowed to fly between two destinations - one in Taiwan and one in mainland China - could carry passengers or cargo to a third destination, giving a potential boost to airline businesses.
One year after the signing of an agreement on cross-strait direct air and sea travel between Taiwan and mainland China, cross-strait travel has become much more convenient.
However, the transportation sector in Taiwan has said that remaining restrictions on cargo transshipments have limited their business opportunities.

In April this year at the third round of negotiations between the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart the Association for the Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), it was agreed that cross- strait cargo flights would increase from 60 flights per month to 28 flights per week or more than 100 a month, and passenger planes would be allowed to carry cargo.

But as China insists that the cargo be limited to goods transported between only China and Taiwan, Taiwan's transportation sector has been disappointed about not being able to take up the transshipment business.
CAA statistics indicate that 70 percent of the cargos transported between Taiwan and China were goods to be transshipped to other destinations.
Unless China lifts its ban, the transportation sector's profits from direct air and sea transportation would be limited, according to a business source.

Also, Chinese passengers are not allowed to take connecting or follow-up flights from Taiwan to other destinations. Aviation companies believe that there is a need for direct cross-strait travel to be allowed more flexibility.

China allows its people to travel to Taiwan with an existing passenger permit, instead of a passport of the People's Republic of China. Without a passport, a mainland Chinese passenger will not be able to proceed on a trip from Taiwan to another destination.

CAA delegates are currently in Xiamen to negotiate more flexibility in cross- strait transportation since issues related to cross-strait direct transportation are not included in the fourth round of negotiations between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and ARATS Chairman Chen Yunlin scheduled to be held in Taichung, central Taiwan, from Dec. 21-23.

One year after the relaxation of cross-strait travel, Taiwan's transportation sector expects that aviation authorities on both sides can work out measures to allow more flexibility, according to the business source.

DOC.HEADLINE: President makes commitment to carbon emissions reduction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 21:39:18 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that Taiwan, as a constructive member of the global village, is committed to reducing carbon emissions and the government will uphold its responsibility in that regard in the years ahead.
Ma said he envisions that the country will make greater progress in its efforts to cut emissions, as there is a desire worldwide to reduce greenhouse emissions and slow global warming.

Commenting on Taiwan's poor ranking in the Climate Change Performance Index 2010 released Tuesday in Copenhagen, the president said that "over the past 19 months up to the end of November, Taiwan had saved 6 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity -- equivalent to a reduction of 3.84 million tons of carbon emissions."
In the index, Taiwan's ranking dropped from 32nd in 2009 to 47th among 57 economies. The 57 countries and economies together account for more than 90 percent of global energy-related CO2 emissions.

Despite the lower ranking, studies by the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs showed that Taiwan's six major industries, which are engaged in more than 2,000 reduction projects, had succeeded in cutting carbon emissions by 5.34 million tons during the 2005-2008 period.

In related news, a group of green activists have embarked on a "meat-free" campaign to raise public awareness of the importance of cutting carbon emissions, to coincide with the global climate change meeting in Copenhagen.

Su Hsiao-huan, a long-term vegetarian and writer; Hsu Jen-shiu, a famous photographer of Taiwan's ecology; and Homemaker's Union and Foundation CEO Hu Ya-mei were among those who announced the "Meat-free Monday" campaign at a news conference in September in Taipei.
"If each person in Taiwan goes without meat for three days a year, it would help reduce greenhouse gases in the country by 200,000 tons per year," Su said at the time.
According to Su, the campaign aims to make "meat-free Monday" a routine for Taiwan people for the next two years.

Following in the footsteps of the Belgian town of Ghent that designated Thursday as "meat-free day," Taipei City is likely to become the world's second city to adopt this approach, according to Su. "The Taipei City council is assessing the possibility of designating Monday as 'meat-free day' in the capital," he said.

Su said he was surprised to learn that Paul McCartney, a former member of the Beatles and an avid vegetarian, is also advocating that Americans eat no meat on Mondays in an effort to cut carbon emissions.

"When I launched the campaign, I did not know about McCartney's 'meat-free' mission, " Su said. "This coincidence fully reflects an irreversible trend across the globe, and devastating natural catastrophes are a warning for us to take concrete action."

McCartney was quoted on the Web site of the U.K.'s Guardian newspaper as saying that "one designated meat free day a week is actually a meaningful change that everyone can make, that goes to the heart of several important political, environmental and ethical issues all at once."

A 2009 World Bank study showed that the livestock industry was responsible for 60 percent of the world's total release of methane, which is 72 times more effective than carbon dioxide in trapping heat in the atmosphere.

Yen Mei-chuan, CEO of the Earth Charter Taiwan, urged Taiwan consumers to eat locally grown fresh food, in part to help cut greenhouse emissions and in part to help domestic small farmers continue with sustainable growth.

In line with the "food miles" concept, Taiwan will introduce a carbon footprint label in March next year to help consumers make informed food choices, under a plan unveiled by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The aim of the program is to help consumers identify the environmental impact of a product by assessing its carbon footprint, EPA Minister Stephen Shen said.

As the Copenhagen climate change summit kicked off on Dec. 12, hundreds of people also took to the streets in Taipei City and held a candle light vigil to express their grave concerns over increased global warming.

DOC.HEADLINE: Businessmen say impact of direct cross-strait transportation limited
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 21:53:32 (By Tang Pei-chun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: One year after the expansion of direct travel between Taiwan and mainland China, businessmen in Taiwan have said that its impact is limited and that it is of benefit mainly to those making investments in China.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs in July conducted a survey among 3,100 manufacturers in Taiwan, to obtain their views on the impact of direct cross- strait transportation in terms of investments in China, exports, company operations, domestic investments, and domestic market demand.
The poll results, released in late November, show that the transportation links have not produced much change in domestic investments, according to 79.65 percent of the respondents.
In terms of domestic market demand, 72.24 percent of those polled said they saw little change, while 71.37 percent said not much development had taken place in terms of investments in China.
Some 65.42 percent said there was no change in exports, and 63.34 percent said company operations remained very much the same.

Businesses that considered the cross-strait direct link positive far exceeded those with negative assessments, with 26.62 percent saying that it would benefit people investing in China, 27.76 percent considering it good for Taiwan's exports, 28.42 percent seeing advantages in company operations, 13.46 percent suggesting it would be beneficiary to domestic investments, and 14.33 percent expecting the benefits to boost the domestic market.

Among manufacturers, traditional industries may have the greatest cause for concern about the opening, as they are facing the competition from Chinese products. Among the 3,100 manufacturers polled, 13.43 percent said they believed that cross-strait direct transportation would have an adverse impact on Taiwan's domestic market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trusted Ma adviser becomes secretary general of ruling party
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 22:07:53 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday swore in his long-time trusted adviser to a leading post as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party, in a move widely seen as an attempt by Ma to gear up for reelection in 2012.

King Pu-tsung, considered the brains behind Ma's successful presidential campaign which helped him get elected in 2008, flew back to Taiwan Wednesday, cutting short his visiting scholar post in the United States, and was sworn in almost immediately as the KMT's new secretary general.

He gave few clues about what his top priorities are on his first day on the job, but promised to "less talk and more action" and carry out various party reform plans that are underway, saying he will be the one who is responsible for reforming the 115-year-old party.

"My job is the (KMT's) chief executive officer, therefore I am the one to be held accountable if things fail, " the close confidant of Ma said in the first press conference he gave after assuming office.
Ma has been keen to rid the party of corruption and clean up its image, but observers said that would not be the only reason the president sought King's help.

King's appointment comes just days after Ma's ruling party suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 county and city elections, winning a smaller percentage of overall votes than it did in local elections four years ago. The election results were widely seen as a warning to the party, especially with the presidential race just two years away.

King served as the main campaign manager in Ma's two mayoral elections and the 2008 presidential election. He was lured back to Taiwan halfway through his visiting scholar program with the Washington-based Brookings Institution.
His main tasks now are believed to be helping the ruling party win four upcoming elections in the next 12 months, reversing the party's long standing culture of vote-buying and handling its assets.
King said all of these tasks will not be easy, and he will not be able to do it alone without teamwork.
Nicknamed "the Switchblade, " and "loner" King, an avid Triathlon runner, has built a reputation in Taiwanese politics over the years as someone who is good at political maneuvering.

But King presented a different image at the press conference Wednesday. He said that if he could be good at one thing, he wants to change the polarization in Taiwanese politics and make the KMT's battle with the opposition Democratic Progressive party (DPP) "a healthy competition".
He also envisioned the party being "accepted and embraced" by younger generations of Taiwanese people.
"I want to make the KMT a better party," King said.

King told the media his first move will be visiting local counties and cities, especially those the KMT had lost in previous elections and the ones which will hold legislative by-elections next month.
He did not rule out the possibility of carrying out a personnel reshuffle in the KMT, saying that "of course we'll make personnel changes."
Whatever he does, he is expected to enjoy the backing of the president, who also serves as the KMT's chairman and handpicked King as his right hand man.
With King's help, Ma has never lost an election.

Now, many political analysts and ordinary Taiwanese people will be watching to see if King can again deliver an election victory for the president, whose approval ratings have taken a beating from the recession, public criticisms over his administration's handling of Typhoon Morakot, and criticisms over his proposed free-trade agreement with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's tax revenues will rise after pact with China: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 22:14:07 (By Lin Ye-fong & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Wednesday that he expects most of the Taiwan investors in China will choose to be taxed in Taiwan after the proposed cross-strait agreement on avoidance of double taxation is signed.
This is because Taiwan only levies a 20 percent operating income tax, much lower than the 25 percent imposed by China, he said.
As a result, the government's tax revenues will definitely grow, Lee said at a press conference held to explain the proposed tax agreement with China.

But Lee said he cannot assess how much the additional tax income will amount to until after the pact takes effect, as the government currently has no idea about the business situation of Taiwan investors in China.
Taiwan and China negotiators will meet in the central Taiwan city of Taichung Dec. 21-23 to sign four agreements, including the tax pact.
Lee said that the tax agreement is aimed at protecting Taiwanese businessmen's rights and ensuring the government's power to levy taxes on its nationals on the mainland.
Without the pact, Taiwan investors in China are not under any government protection since Taiwan does not have a say in the way China treats them, he said.
Lee refuted news reports that many Taiwan investors in China are worried that the proposed Taiwan-China tax agreement will enable the government to easily trace their business deals and incomes.

He said that Taiwan has signed tax agreements with 16 countries, and over the past five years, there have been only eight cases of tax information exchange between Taiwan and those countries for the purposes of preventing major tax evasions.
Lee gave the assurance that exchanges of tax information would not result in leakage of data on the incomes of any Taiwanese individual or company in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet shopping increases from last year: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 22:47:07 (By Chia-chen Hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of Internet users in Taiwan have made online purchases this year -- an increase of 10 percentage points compared to 2008, according to the results of an annual survey on the country's digital divide.

The survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) found that 59.3 percent of people over the age of 12 in Taiwan who went online this year have made Internet purchases.

However, due to the economic downturn, the average value of individuals' online purchases dropped to NT$9,816 (US$304) from NT$13,565 in 2008, according to the survey results which were released Wednesday.
The poll also found that 88 percent of Internet users went online to search for information on daily life, up slightly from 86 percent the previous year.

In addition, 80.7 percent of Internet users searched for information on travel and gourmet food; 80.7 percent for news; and 68.6 percent researched product and pricing information before making purchases.

Some 75 percent of the respondents engaged in online leisure and entertainment activities, 6.7 percentage points higher than last year; while 28.9 percent used online banking services, up from 26.1 percent last year.
There is an obvious gender divide in terms of online shopping, the poll indicated, as 63 percent of the online shoppers were women, while 55.1 percent were men.
The survey also found that about 10 percent of Internet users have sold products online, with 90 percent of them being part-time online sellers.

In terms of the profit generated from online auctions, 50.3 percent of the sellers said they gained less than NT$1,000 a month, 22.2 percent said their profits were between NT$1,001 and NT$5,000, and 4.2 percent said they made more than NT$5,000 a month.
The survey results also show that 43.8 percent of Internet users have their own blogs, up from 36.7 percent last year.
Nearly half of the younger respondents -- 49.5 percent of the 21-30 age group -- have their own blogs, compared to 44.4 percent last year.
Instant messaging and blogging remain a craze among the younger generation, with micro-blogging becoming a new, growing segment this year.
Some 81.7 percent of those in the 21-30 age group said they have MSN Instant Messenger accounts, 58 percent are members of Facebook, 13 percent are on Plurk and 4.6 percent have Twitter accounts.

According to 38 percent of the respondents, they spend time on Internet social networks primarily because they want to connect with friends quickly and economically; while 7 percent admitted that they suffer anxiety if they are away from the Internet for more than a day.

Among those who are on social networks, 40 percent said they have forwarded information about influenza A(H1N1), disaster prevention and important government information via MSN Instant Messenger, email and other services.

The RDEC said that the Internet is expected to become another excellent public information dissemination tool based on the fact that each Internet user has an average of 60 contacts on their online friends list, with more than 80 percent of those being known acquaintances.
The survey was carried out between July 13 and Aug. 21 among 16, 133 respondents via telephone. It had a margin of error of 0.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't sets goal of reverse mortgage plan by end of 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 23:32:08 (By Kao Chao-fen, Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government is expected to work out by the end of 2010 a plan for the introduction of reverse mortgages in Taiwan, which is considered essential to retirement security among the growing number of senior citizens, Minister of the Interior (MOI) Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

According to Jiang, the government will solicit the opinions of various sectors of society in its formulation of the plan, with attention to details such as whether to enact a special law for the system and whether to link it to a social welfare program.

The minister noted that the policy -- which will allow senior homeowners to convert equity into cash -- has received much public attention since it was proposed a few months ago, mainly because it is likely to meet the needs of Taiwan's fast-graying society.
At present, the number of citizens aged 65 or older accounts for over 10 percent of the country's population, and is likely to surpass 20 percent in less than 20 years, Jiang said.
Meanwhile, the results of surveys conducted by the MOI revealed that the number of seniors who live alone has been increasing, from 25 percent in 1986 to 40 percent in 2008, he said.
The percentage of seniors who live with their children, on the other hand, dropped from 70 percent in 1986 to below 50 percent in 2008, he added.
Also, the surveys found that 33 percent of seniors do not have any regular source of income, while more than 60 percent are living on their own or their spouses' retirement benefits, Jiang noted.
The minister was attending a seminar in Taipei on the issue of reverse mortgages.

Among the other speakers was Edward Szymanoski, a member of a team within the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development that 20 years ago developed a reserse mortgage model which came to be known as the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage.

Sharing his country's experience in promoting the program, Szymanoski said when the model was first launched in the United States, the results were unsatisfactory because there was too little government intervention.
The program, however, has produced prominent results since it was made part of the U.S. social welfare system, he said.

Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, explained that reverse mortgages are intended to allow seniors to "age in place," which means not having to move from their residence in order to secure support services in response to changing personal needs.
In addition to reverse mortgages, a sale-and-leaseback program under which seniors can sell their homes to an insurer in return for annuities can also serve a similar purpose, Chang said.

Another option is for senior homeowners to obtain loans using their property as collateral, and those loans would not have to be repaid until after the death of the borrowers. They could also transfer their property into a trust to pay for the care services provided by social welfare institutions, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP plans mass protest on arrival of key Chinese official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/16/09 23:45:06 (By K.H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued a mobilization order Wednesday for its members to gather for a protest at an airport in Taichung where Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, will land Monday for a meeting in the central city.
The DPP also plans to hold a mass protest march and rally Sunday afternoon prior to Chen's arrival, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang told reporters..

On Tuesday, the DPP will organize a motorcade in the city in protest against Chen's presence in Taiwan, and on Wednesday it will hold a seminar discussing the facts surrounding past secret deals between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China, Tsai said.
More than 100,000 DPP supporters are expected to take part in the series of anti-China activities, he said.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, former Vice President Annette Lu and former Premier Frank Hsieh are expected to join Sunday's protest march, he noted, adding that party members who fail to show up at these events will be disciplined.
"These activities will be conducted peacefully, " the spokesman said, and he urged the police and other authorities not to overreact to the protests.
Bloody squabbles erupted between policemen and DPP supporters last year when Chen was in Taipei City for the second round of cross-strait talks.

Chen, in his capacity as president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will hold the fourth cross-Taiwan Strait talks with his Taiwan counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Dec. 22-23, in Taichung City.

Four agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation are expected to be signed by Chiang and Chen in the coming talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, Dec. 17, or the second day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: The Ching dynasty establishes its Peiyang (northern) navy and appoints Ting Ju-chang as the admiral.
1891: Hu Shih, a noted Chinese scholar who proposed that literature be written in the vernacular language rather than in the classical style, is born in Shanghai.
1902: Classes begin for the first time at National Peking University, China's first university and most prestigious institution of higher education.
1903: American aviation pioneer Orville Wright and his brother Wilbur make the world's first successful sustained flight in a heavier-than-air vehicle, which they invented, flying over sand dunes near Kitty Hawk, North Carolina.
1919: Pierre Auguste Renoir, French impressionist painter whose warm luminous works include "Child with Watering Can" and "Luncheon of the Boating Party," dies at the age of 78.
1925: The Anping Canal in Tainan, southern Taiwan is inaugurated.
1941: Japanese forces invade North Borneo during World War II.
1948: The Dutch attack Indonesia and arrest President Sukarno and other leaders.
1949: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the severing of diplomatic relations with Burma.
1957: The United States successfully test-launches its first intercontinental ballistic missile.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold Holt disappears while swimming at Portsea, Victoria.
1968: The Chinese National Committee of the International Press Institute is established in Taipei.
1971: Pakistan and India end a two-week war over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1971: The International Commercial Bank of China (formerly the Bank of China) is inaugurated, becoming a complete private enterprise.
1973: Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez, Costa Rican speaker of the Chamber of Deputies, arrives in Taipei for a weeklong visit.
1973: Denzo Okubo, president of the Federation of the Japan-ROC Association, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1975: Economics Minister Y. S. Sun and Korean Deputy Premier Nam Duck Woo sign a joint communique calling for further economic cooperation.
1975: A boxing tournament opens at the Tainan City Gymnasium, with boxers from the Philippines, South Korea, Japan and the ROC competing.
1978: More than 5,000 people stage an angry protest outside the U.S. embassy in Taipei.
1979: Tsiang Yien-si succeeds Chang Pao-shu as the secretary-general of the Central Committee of the Kuomintang.
1986: The 1986 Nobel Prize winner in chemistry, Lee Yuan-tseh, a member of the Academia Sinica, returns to the ROC. Lee and his wife are received by President Chiang Ching-kuo on Dec. 18.
1986: New Costa Rican Ambassador to the ROC Ruben Acon Leon calls on President Chiang Ching-kuo to present his credentials.
1989: Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, who succeeded Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell as commander of the U.S. forces in China during World War II, dies in Washington D.C.
1991: Boris Yeltsin and Mikhail Gorbachev agree to dissolve the Soviet Union and proclaim a new commonwealth on New Year's Day.
1993: Lee Yuan-tseh succeeds Wu Ta-you, becoming the 7th president of the Academia Sinica.
1996: The Ching dynasty's last eunuch Sun Yao-ting dies in Beijing at the age of 93.
1997: A treaty eradicating bribery in international business is signed by the representatives of 34 countries.
1999: Mandarin Airlines, a subsidiary of the Republic of China's former flag carrier China Airlines, opens direct flights between Taipei and Thailand's northern city of Chiang Mai.
2000: Ten king penguins from the United States arrive in Taipei. They are introduced into Taiwan by the Taipei Zoo.
2001: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan meets with about 100 party representatives from Japan's Tokyo and Yokohama areas over a dinner in Tokyo.
2001: Five Japanese Lower House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit at the invitation of the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Confucius: "A wise man will not make himself into a mere machine fit only to do one kind of work. A wise and good man is one who acts before he speaks, and afterwards speaks according to his actions. A wise man is impartial, not neutral. A fool is neutral but not impartial."

DOC.HEADLINE: Trusted Ma adviser becomes secretary general of ruling party
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 08:36:18 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday swore in his long-time trusted adviser to a leading post as secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party, in a move widely seen as an attempt by Ma to gear up for reelection in 2012.

King Pu-tsung, considered the brains behind Ma's successful presidential campaign which helped him get elected in 2008, flew back to Taiwan Wednesday, cutting short his visiting scholar post in the United States, and was sworn in almost immediately as the KMT's new secretary general.

He gave few clues about what his top priorities are on his first day on the job, but promised to "less talk and more action" and carry out various party reform plans that are underway, saying he will be the one who is responsible for reforming the 115-year-old party.

"My job is the (KMT's) chief executive officer, therefore I am the one to be held accountable if things fail, " the close confidant of Ma said in the first press conference he gave after assuming office.
Ma has been keen to rid the party of corruption and clean up its image, but observers said that would not be the only reason the president sought King's help.

King's appointment comes just days after Ma's ruling party suffered a setback in the Dec. 5 county and city elections, winning a smaller percentage of overall votes than it did in local elections four years ago. The election results were widely seen as a warning to the party, especially with the presidential race just two years away.

King served as the main campaign manager in Ma's two mayoral elections and the 2008 presidential election. He was lured back to Taiwan halfway through his visiting scholar program with the Washington-based Brookings Institution.
His main tasks now are believed to be helping the ruling party win four upcoming elections in the next 12 months, reversing the party's long standing culture of vote-buying and handling its assets.
King said all of these tasks will not be easy, and he will not be able to do it alone without teamwork.
Nicknamed "the Switchblade, " and "loner" King, an avid Triathlon runner, has built a reputation in Taiwanese politics over the years as someone who is good at political maneuvering.

But King presented a different image at the press conference Wednesday. He said that if he could be good at one thing, he wants to change the polarization in Taiwanese politics and make the KMT's battle with the opposition Democratic Progressive party (DPP) "a healthy competition".
He also envisioned the party being "accepted and embraced" by younger generations of Taiwanese people.
"I want to make the KMT a better party," King said.

King told the media his first move will be visiting local counties and cities, especially those the KMT had lost in previous elections and the ones which will hold legislative by-elections next month.
He did not rule out the possibility of carrying out a personnel reshuffle in the KMT, saying that "of course we'll make personnel changes."
Whatever he does, he is expected to enjoy the backing of the president, who also serves as the KMT's chairman and handpicked King as his right hand man.
With King's help, Ma has never lost an election.

Now, many political analysts and ordinary Taiwanese people will be watching to see if King can again deliver an election victory for the president, whose approval ratings have taken a beating from the recession, public criticisms over his administration's handling of Typhoon Morakot, and criticisms over his proposed free-trade agreement with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's tax revenues will rise after pact with China: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 08:37:06 (By Lin Ye-fong & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said Wednesday that he expects most of the Taiwan investors in China will choose to be taxed in Taiwan after the proposed cross-strait agreement on avoidance of double taxation is signed.
This is because Taiwan only levies a 20 percent operating income tax, much lower than the 25 percent imposed by China, he said.
As a result, the government's tax revenues will definitely grow, Lee said at a press conference held to explain the proposed tax agreement with China.

But Lee said he cannot assess how much the additional tax income will amount to until after the pact takes effect, as the government currently has no idea about the business situation of Taiwan investors in China.
Taiwan and China negotiators will meet in the central Taiwan city of Taichung Dec. 21-23 to sign four agreements, including the tax pact.
Lee said that the tax agreement is aimed at protecting Taiwanese businessmen's rights and ensuring the government's power to levy taxes on its nationals on the mainland.
Without the pact, Taiwan investors in China are not under any government protection since Taiwan does not have a say in the way China treats them, he said.
Lee refuted news reports that many Taiwan investors in China are worried that the proposed Taiwan-China tax agreement will enable the government to easily trace their business deals and incomes.

He said that Taiwan has signed tax agreements with 16 countries, and over the past five years, there have been only eight cases of tax information exchange between Taiwan and those countries for the purposes of preventing major tax evasions.
Lee gave the assurance that exchanges of tax information would not result in leakage of data on the incomes of any Taiwanese individual or company in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Internet shopping increases from last year: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 08:38:08 (By Chia-chen Hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of Internet users in Taiwan have made online purchases this year -- an increase of 10 percentage points compared to 2008, according to the results of an annual survey on the country's digital divide.

The survey conducted by the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission (RDEC) found that 59.3 percent of people over the age of 12 in Taiwan who went online this year have made Internet purchases.

However, due to the economic downturn, the average value of individuals' online purchases dropped to NT$9,816 (US$304) from NT$13,565 in 2008, according to the survey results which were released Wednesday.
The poll also found that 88 percent of Internet users went online to search for information on daily life, up slightly from 86 percent the previous year.

In addition, 80.7 percent of Internet users searched for information on travel and gourmet food; 80.7 percent for news; and 68.6 percent researched product and pricing information before making purchases.

Some 75 percent of the respondents engaged in online leisure and entertainment activities, 6.7 percentage points higher than last year; while 28.9 percent used online banking services, up from 26.1 percent last year.
There is an obvious gender divide in terms of online shopping, the poll indicated, as 63 percent of the online shoppers were women, while 55.1 percent were men.
The survey also found that about 10 percent of Internet users have sold products online, with 90 percent of them being part-time online sellers.

In terms of the profit generated from online auctions, 50.3 percent of the sellers said they gained less than NT$1,000 a month, 22.2 percent said their profits were between NT$1,001 and NT$5,000, and 4.2 percent said they made more than NT$5,000 a month.
The survey results also show that 43.8 percent of Internet users have their own blogs, up from 36.7 percent last year.
Nearly half of the younger respondents -- 49.5 percent of the 21-30 age group -- have their own blogs, compared to 44.4 percent last year.
Instant messaging and blogging remain a craze among the younger generation, with micro-blogging becoming a new, growing segment this year.
Some 81.7 percent of those in the 21-30 age group said they have MSN Instant Messenger accounts, 58 percent are members of Facebook, 13 percent are on Plurk and 4.6 percent have Twitter accounts.

According to 38 percent of the respondents, they spend time on Internet social networks primarily because they want to connect with friends quickly and economically; while 7 percent admitted that they suffer anxiety if they are away from the Internet for more than a day.

Among those who are on social networks, 40 percent said they have forwarded information about influenza A(H1N1), disaster prevention and important government information via MSN Instant Messenger, email and other services.

The RDEC said that the Internet is expected to become another excellent public information dissemination tool based on the fact that each Internet user has an average of 60 contacts on their online friends list, with more than 80 percent of those being known acquaintances.
The survey was carried out between July 13 and Aug. 21 among 16, 133 respondents via telephone. It had a margin of error of 0.8 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't sets goal of reverse mortgage plan by end of 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 08:39:12 (By Kao Chao-fen, Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government is expected to work out by the end of 2010 a plan for the introduction of reverse mortgages in Taiwan, which is considered essential to retirement security among the growing number of senior citizens, Minister of the Interior (MOI) Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday.

According to Jiang, the government will solicit the opinions of various sectors of society in its formulation of the plan, with attention to details such as whether to enact a special law for the system and whether to link it to a social welfare program.

The minister noted that the policy -- which will allow senior homeowners to convert equity into cash -- has received much public attention since it was proposed a few months ago, mainly because it is likely to meet the needs of Taiwan's fast-graying society.
At present, the number of citizens aged 65 or older accounts for over 10 percent of the country's population, and is likely to surpass 20 percent in less than 20 years, Jiang said.
Meanwhile, the results of surveys conducted by the MOI revealed that the number of seniors who live alone has been increasing, from 25 percent in 1986 to 40 percent in 2008, he said.
The percentage of seniors who live with their children, on the other hand, dropped from 70 percent in 1986 to below 50 percent in 2008, he added.
Also, the surveys found that 33 percent of seniors do not have any regular source of income, while more than 60 percent are living on their own or their spouses' retirement benefits, Jiang noted.
The minister was attending a seminar in Taipei on the issue of reverse mortgages.

Among the other speakers was Edward Szymanoski, a member of a team within the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development that 20 years ago developed a reserse mortgage model which came to be known as the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage.

Sharing his country's experience in promoting the program, Szymanoski said when the model was first launched in the United States, the results were unsatisfactory because there was too little government intervention.
The program, however, has produced prominent results since it was made part of the U.S. social welfare system, he said.

Chang Chin-o, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, explained that reverse mortgages are intended to allow seniors to "age in place," which means not having to move from their residence in order to secure support services in response to changing personal needs.
In addition to reverse mortgages, a sale-and-leaseback program under which seniors can sell their homes to an insurer in return for annuities can also serve a similar purpose, Chang said.

Another option is for senior homeowners to obtain loans using their property as collateral, and those loans would not have to be repaid until after the death of the borrowers. They could also transfer their property into a trust to pay for the care services provided by social welfare institutions, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP plans mass protest on arrival of key Chinese official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 08:42:13 (By K.H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) issued a mobilization order Wednesday for its members to gather for a protest at an airport in Taichung where Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, will land Monday for a meeting in the central city.
The DPP also plans to hold a mass protest march and rally Sunday afternoon prior to Chen's arrival, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang told reporters..

On Tuesday, the DPP will organize a motorcade in the city in protest against Chen's presence in Taiwan, and on Wednesday it will hold a seminar discussing the facts surrounding past secret deals between the Kuomintang (KMT) and the Communist Party of China, Tsai said.
More than 100,000 DPP supporters are expected to take part in the series of anti-China activities, he said.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, former Vice President Annette Lu and former Premier Frank Hsieh are expected to join Sunday's protest march, he noted, adding that party members who fail to show up at these events will be disciplined.
"These activities will be conducted peacefully, " the spokesman said, and he urged the police and other authorities not to overreact to the protests.
Bloody squabbles erupted between policemen and DPP supporters last year when Chen was in Taipei City for the second round of cross-strait talks.

Chen, in his capacity as president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), will hold the fourth cross-Taiwan Strait talks with his Taiwan counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Dec. 22-23, in Taichung City.

Four agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation are expected to be signed by Chiang and Chen in the coming talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local news media -- Security during
DOC.DATELINE: 12/17/09 11:08:21 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: With the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) preparing to stage massive protest rallies during the fourth round of high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks, government authorities have stepped up security measures to prevent any incidents during the Chinese delegation's upcoming visit.
The DPP headquarters has also issued action guidelines to demand that its members exercise self-restraint during the protest activities.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments related to security concerns in Taiwan during that time:
China times:

The Taichung City police have begun to prepare for protests during the Dec. 21-25 meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).

The SEF said it has been told that security personnel will be able to cope with up to 150,000 protesters. If the weather in the central city of Taichung is fine, the protests will be marathons, which means that China's top negotiator with Taiwan could be besieged for all five days during his stay.

Information obtained by the SEF indicated that a number of private companies are footing the bill for protesters to travel by bus from southern Taiwan to Taichung to join the demonstrations against Beijing's proxy and his delegation.

Yu Hui-mao, deputy director-general of the Taichung city police department, said the police will set up a restricted zone near the venue of the Chiang-Chen meeting to ensure security, and if necessary, traffic to and from the Taichung Cloverleaf will be closed. (Dec. 17, 2009)
Liberty Times:

In order to protect Chen and his group, the security forces of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration will not only be in battle array against their own compatriots, but the police could also close the main traffic artery in Taichung.
It is far too much to have the right of movement of thousands of motorists compromised simply because of one man's visit. (Dec. 17, 2009)
United Daily News:

ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong is expected to lead a group of Chinese security officers to Taiwan Friday, three days before Chen's arrival Dec. 21, to ensure that the meeting is held smoothly and order is maintained.
Zheng and his group are expected to scout the 10-plus locations that the SEF has arranged for Chen and his delegation to visit, to simulate security conditions there. (Dec. 17, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media: LCD panel industry

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan -- Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan next Monday for a new round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung -- on matters of mutual concern, such as industrial certification standards, agricultural quarantine and avoidance of double taxation.

Chen will reportedly take advantage of his Dec. 21-25 visit to push Taiwan to further ease restrictions on cross-strait investment and lobby Taiwan's top flat panel manufacturer AU Optronics Corp. to invest in China to produce new generation liquid crystal display (LCD) panels.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the latest developments related to the flat panel industry:
Commercial Times:
Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs has promised to evaluate before the end of this year the feasibility of allowing local companies to invest in China in the production of large-sized LCD panels.
With this in mind, ARATS President Chen Yunlin will try to attract Taiwanese manufacturers in the field to venture into the Chinese market, with AU Optronics (AUO) as the prime target.
Chen's delegation will include representatives of 18 blue-chip companies in electronics, fiber optics and other high-tech industries.

On the sidelines of the formal Chiang-Chen talks, Chinese high-tech industry executives will meet with their Taiwanese counterparts on possible trade or joint-venture deals. Chen will also take the opportunity to explore the possibility of AUO setting up production facilities in China.
Economic Daily News:
With flat panel prices going up, foreign institutional investors have raised profit forecasts for major local LCD companies, such as AUO and Chi Mei, for the first quarter of next year.

Merrill Lynch securities analysts said Wednesday that major South Korean flat panel makers have reported increases in market demand for their products. With panel prices about to be raised from January, the analysts predicted that AUO and Chi Mei will see better profits next quarter.
