DOC.HEADLINE: TAITRA opens new office in Singapore to explore ASEAN markets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 14:45:37 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade promotion agency officially opened a new overseas office in Singapore Thursday, as part of efforts to develop a more comprehensive trade network service and to further explore business opportunities in the markets of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

The establishment of the 48th overseas branch of the government-funded Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) is an indication of the value it attaches to helping Taiwanese companies further explore the ASEAN markets, the trade promotion body said.

The core mission of the new Taiwan Trade Center is "to help Taiwanese companies expand their market share in Singapore and to provide Singaporean companies with better services and information on trade and investment opportunities in Taiwan, " Liao Jun Sheng, head of the center, was quoted as saying in a TAITRA press release.

Noting that it had an office in Singapore from 1987-1996, TAITRA said the decision to return there will help to develop the friendship between Taiwan and Singapore on the basis of their current strong economic and trade relations.
The new office will coordinate with other TAITRA branches in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam, India and Bangladesh to build a comprehensive trade promotion network in the region, TAITRA added.

According to TAITRA, bilateral trade between Singapore and Taiwan for the period January to November 2009 was US$12 billion, making Singapore Taiwan's 6th largest trading partner, after China, Japan, the United States, Hong Kong and South Korea.
Taiwanese companies have some 465 investment projects in Singapore valued at a total US$5.47 billion, mainly in the electronics and financial sectors, it noted.

The opening of TAITRA's Singapore center was attended by officials and representatives from the business sectors, including TAITRA Chairman Wang Chih- kang, Taiwan's representative to Singapore Vanessa Y.P Shih, and deputy chief executive officer of International Enterprise Singapore Chua Taik Him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Government Efficiency

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yi's temper flared at a recent weekly Cabinet meeting over the slow progress of major infrastructure construction projects.
Wu was not the first top administrator to become angry over the government's poor efficiency. His predecessor Liu Chao-shiuan also got upset over the slow pace of public construction.
The government's inefficiency is not confined to the public construction sector, but is actually pervasive and a major source of public grievances.
For years, lackluster government efficiency has repeatedly dragged down Taiwan's ranking in global competitiveness surveys.

Following Taiwan's democratization, senior leaders became obsessed more with campaigning than day-to-day governance. Working-level civil servants tend to follow rigid regulations and seldom show any initiative on reform or innovation.

Legislative lethargy is also a major contributing factor to the government's poor efficiency. The opposition party, with its filibustering and boycotts, is partly responsible, but the ruling party must also share the blame since it controls more than two-thirds of the seats. Only 27 of the 50 urgent bills listed by the Cabinet as urgent were passed in the last legislative session. The ruling Kuomintang should exercise more discipline over its lawmakers.
Now that President Ma Ying-jeou has taken over the helm of the KMT, collaboration between the government and the ruling party should improve.

As the country's top administrator, Premier Wu should also lead by example and work out a package of measures to upgrade government efficiency and oversee its full implementation. He will leave a memorable legacy if he can achieve this.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central Taiwan's science park aims high
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 15:09:21 (By Maranda Hsu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Six years since its inception, the Central Taiwan Science Park (CTSP) is fast catching up with the country's two other older major science parks to become another powerful engine driving the country's innovation and high-tech manufacturing industries.
Ground-breaking for the science park's Erlin Site -- its fourth phase of expansion -- located in the central county of Changhua, is slated for Dec. 25.
With the new site, the park, known as the "Silicon Valley" of central Taiwan, is poised to add another high-tech manufacturing arm, said CTSP Administration Director-General Yang Wen-ke.
The Erlin science park, which will mainly house a cluster of optoelectronics makers, is expected to solicit NT$1.2 trillion (US$37 billion) in investment capital once it is completed.
"The new park area is expected to create 30,000 job openings and generate NT$920 billion in business turnover annually when it eventually becomes fully operational," Yang said.

The Erlin Park, situated on an area of 350 hectares -- equivalent to the area of the Hsinchu Science Park in northern Taiwan, which is the biggest science park in Taiwan -- will be home to the 10th-generation of TFT-LCD display manufacturing operations of AU Optronics Corp., one of the leading TFT-LCD display manufacturers in Taiwan, according to Yang.
"Currently, around the world only Sony and Sharp have operated such type of plants in Japan, while South Korea's Samsung is planning on building one," Yang said.

Yang added that the Erlin Park will eventually be a high-tech production chain integrating the upstream- midstream- and downstream-optoelectronic industry, along with other satellite industries, such as semiconductor, precision machinery, biotechnology and green energy manufacturing.
In the face of rising environmental awareness, Yang said, the Erlin Park will spare no efforts to perfect management of waste water and control of hazardous chemicals discharges.

"Communicate, communicate and communicate, " Yang said, pointing out that it is the CTSP's responsibility to communicate with the public, particularly residents living in areas adjacent to the Erlin Park, on the possible impact that the new park area may cause to the environment.
"Our aim is to secure a balance between economic development and environmental protection," he asserted.
Meanwhile, Yang said the Chung Hsing New Village in central Taiwan's Nantou County, once the seat of the Taiwan provincial government, will be transformed into a high-level research park in 10 years.

According to a CTSP plan, the 276-hectare Chung Hsing New Village park project will break ground in 2010, with the first phase of construction to be completed in 2014, and the full project in 2019, at a total cost of NT$26.7 billion.

With some 250 companies, 7,500 research and development personnel, as well as 16,500 residents expecting to be accommodated in the park, it is envisioned to generate an output of cutting-edge products worth NT$29.5 billion annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia-Pacific film festival opens in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 15:38:02 (By Tsai Ho-ying and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More than 500 movie industry players in the Asia-Pacific region gathered in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County Thursday for the opening of the Asia-Pacific Film Festival, as a more than half a century old event is revived for the first time.

The festival, which came to a sudden stop two years ago due to the global financial crisis, opened with the 500 delegates from 17 countries and regions attending festivities at I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County.

As a founding member and eight-time sponsor of the international event and a long-time host of its secretariat, Taiwan felt obliged to revive the film festival, according to Justin Chou, a Taiwanese legislator who is also chairman of the event.

Chou, as a commissioner of the Secretariat, attended the festival's board meeting in Jakarta in November 2008. It was at that time that he agreed to sponsor the 53rd Asia-Pacific Film Festival on behalf of Taiwan's film industry.

Chou said in a press conference earlier this month that Kaohsiung County was chosen as the venue of the international event because the organizer hoped the festivities could help revitalize the region devastated by Typhoon Morakot in August.

Among the 63 entries from Taiwan, Japan, Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, Iran, Indonesia, Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, India, and Australia, dozens have been selected to be shown at theaters at the E-Da World recreational park near I-Shou University.
The festival will run from Dec. 17-19, with the awards presentation ceremony to be held at I-Shou University's stadium on Saturday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unpaid leave at science parks continues to wane
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 15:52:17 (Chiachen Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of furloughed workers at Taiwan's three major science parks has continued to decline, as the country's economy seems to have bottomed out, the National Science Council (NSC) said Thursday.

The total number of workers on unpaid leave at the Hsinchu Science Park, Southern Taiwan Science Park and Central Taiwan Science Park had dropped sharply to 1,032 as of Dec. 1, down 99 percent compared to the record high of 132,414 posted in January, NSC officials said in a report to the Executive Yuan.
Premier Wu Den-yih attributed the encouraging trend mainly to a series of stimulus measures that the administration has taken over the past year to boost business at the three leading science parks.
The measures included halving the management fees the NSC charges firms operating at the science parks and promoting projects aimed at upgrading the parks' R&D capabilities, Wu said.

The premier also exhorted the administrations of the three science parks to accelerate planning for the construction of new, eco-friendly science parks around the country, including a biomedical park in Hsinchu County, a new science park in Yilan County, a science park in Tongluo, Miaoli County, the Erlin science park in Changhua County and the Chung Hsing New Village high-end research park in Nantou County.
"Equal importance should be given to production and environmental protection to achieve sustainable development in the country while striving for industrial competitiveness," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Health insurance fee overhaul
DOC.DATELINE: Department of Health (DOH) 12/17/09 16:36:14 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Minister Yaung Chih-liang has braved the possibility of populist backlash to advocate an increase in national health insurance premiums.

It is no secret that Taiwan's health insurance system is heavily in debt. Without some increase in fees, the government would have to cut welfare spending to support the universal health care system. In essence, freezing health insurance fees will not benefit anyone.
However, there is room for discussion about the DOH's reform plan.
In a bid to expedite the process by avoiding a law revision, the DOH has proposed raising premium rates. Under the plan, highly-paid wage earners will be required to pay more for health insurance.

When the universal health care system was launched in March 1995, computerized databanks were still in the development stage in Taiwan, therefore it would have been difficult for the government to peg health insurance premiums to income other than wages.

As a result, the existing health insurance system is not equitable, as the premiums of wealthy corporate bosses, who earn most of their money from capital gains and dividends, are not calculated based on their full income, but rather only on wages.
Now that computerization has become the order of the day and detailed income data is easily available, it is no longer justifiable to calculate premiums on the basis of wages only.

We hope Minister Yaung will pay attention to this point in his efforts to revise health insurance premium payments. He should be patient and go the distance to push for an amendment to Article 22 of the National Health Insurance Act so other forms of income, such as capital gains and stock dividends, could be factored into the calculation of premiums.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices slide on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 16:40:26 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices slid Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 9.43 points, or 0.12 percent, to close at 7,742.17.
The local bourse opened at 7,804.70 and fluctuated between 7,836.43 and 7,728.88 during the day's trading session.
A total of 4.44 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$130.28 billion (US$4.02 billion).
All eight major stock categories except for machinery and electronics shares, which remained unchanged, lost ground.

Paper and pulp shares lost the most at 2.5 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 1.2 percent, cement issues and foodstuff issues both at 0.7 percent, while banking and financial issues and plastics and chemicals stocks both lost at 0.1 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,898 to 765, with 251 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$4.88 billion worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: 48.5% of Taiwanese want protests during Chiang-Chen talks: DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 17:06:43 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people responding to a recent public opinion survey are in favor of staging protests against the next round of talks between Taiwan and China's top negotiators slated to be held next week in Taichung City, according to the results of the poll released Thursday by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The survey was conducted by the DPP to explore the public's views on issues surrounding the fourth round of talks between Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin.

Survey results show that 65.2 percent of respondents expressed opposition to a government ban on various demonstrations that the DPP and other pro-localization groups are planning to hold during the talks, while 48.5 percent said they are in favor of staging such protests and rallies during this period.

The main purpose of the meeting will be to sign four cross-Taiwan Strait agreements regarding cooperation on certification standards, agricultural quarantine, fishing-related labor affairs, and avoidance of double taxation.
However, the DPP said that 87.06 percent of the respondents said they do not know the contents of the agreements.
According to the survey, 81.5 percent of respondents thought the government had failed to state the agreements' contents and the impacts they would have.

While 67.6 percent of them believed that the signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will benefit business consortiums, 36.7 thought the proposed ECFA will have a negative impact on their employment and their family income, and 49.6 percent expressed their opposition to signing the ECFA with China.

On the controversy surrounding an article published Monday in the Wall Street Journal Asia, in which President Ma Ying-jeou was quoted as saying: "Whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decade, " and a follow-up clarification by the Presidential Office that the president actually said "the next decades, " 70.1 percent of the respondents said they believe Ma will lead Taiwan toward unification with China, while only 5.5 percent thought Taiwan will move toward independence.

The survey was conducted from Dec. 15-16 among people who are 20 years old or older by random sampling via telephone interviews. A total of 956 valid samples were collected. It had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 3.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 17:13:32 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.348.
A total of US$776 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.345 and fluctuated between NT$32.296 and NT$32.350.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign offices in Taiwan opt for e-cards this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 17:27:33 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Several foreign representative offices in Taiwan have decided to send electronic Christmas cards to government agencies and other contacts this year, as part of efforts to protect the environment.

The Taipei-based European Economic and Trade Office (EETO) and the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) said that the use of e-cards is less detrimental to the environment than buying paper cards.

The decision also coincides with a United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) meeting that is currently taking place in Copenhagen, Denmark, at which some 100 heads of states from around the world are trying to decide on the future extent of reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and work out a new international climate change agreement before the Kyoto Protocol expires in 2012.

"The world is currently searching for a solution to combat climate change. It is therefore important that we take action rather than simply talk about taking action, " Guy Ledoux, head of the EETO, told the Central News Agency in an e-mail.

"The electronic card is one small action that we can do to save the environment, and even though it is not an actual card, it still conveys our most sincere appreciation to all the friends of the EU and the EETO," he added.
The decision to send e-cards for the first time was an internal one made by the EETO.

Meanwhile, the BTCO, which sends an average of 600-700 cards each year, is also taking similar action to help save the planet by encouraging its staff to use e-cards or existing printed cards to send seasonal greetings this year.

This is one of the many steps taken by the BTCO to be kinder to the environment, according to the office, adding that other energy-saving measures include using natural light whenever possible and turning off computers, printers and copy machines at lunchtime and after work.
The EU and the United Kingdom are playing leading roles in global efforts to mitigate climate change, as they have set ambitious targets to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

The EU has adopted legally binding measures to reduce carbon dioxide emissions to an average of 30 percent below the 1990 level by the year 2020 and is prepared to further increase this effort if other partners take on comparable commitments in a new international agreement. The U.K. introduced a Climate Change Act in November 2008 to cut emissions by at least a third by 2020 and by at least 80 percent by 2050.

With the increasing public awareness of environmental protection and the convenience of sending holiday greetings via e-cards and text messages, the sale of Christmas cards in Taiwan has been gradually declining, said Huang Hui-ling, public relations specialist
at Eslite Corp., one of Taiwan's largest bookstores that launched its first Christmas card sale in 1989.

She told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview that the company has seen a steady decrease in the number of Christmas cards sold over the past decade, but sales have been stabilized in recent years because of a retro trend of sending printed cards.
"Despite the convenience of sending e-cards, it is a completely different experience for people to receive printed cards, which symbolize the love and care of the senders," said Huang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S. trade talks might reopen in early 2010: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 17:44:29 (By S. S. Yao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States are likely to resume two-way talks early next year based on the foundation of a Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) , a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Since the two countries suspended formal diplomatic ties in 1979, the TIFA talks have provided a significant official channel for Taiwan-U.S. dialogue on trade and economic issues after the agreement was signed in September 1994. The talks are usually hosted by either side on an annual basis.

Harry Ho-jen Tseng, director general of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, told reporters Thursday that ranking officials with the U.S. Trade Representative Office had visited Taiwan last week to pave the way for the next round of the TIFA talks.
"Although a precise date has yet to be set, the talks might take place in early 2010," he added.

According to Tseng, a wide range of matters can be discussed in the two-way TIFA talks, but agreements on bilateral investment and the avoidance of double taxation are the more pressing issues facing the two sides.

American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Raymond F. Burghardt, the top U.S. liaison official with Taiwan who was in Taipei late last month to brief Taiwan's authorities on U.S. President Barack H. Obama's China visit, also mentioned that U. S. officials would visit Taiwan in December to prepare for the reopening of the TIFA talks.

Taiwan and the United States held their last TIFA talks in Washington, D.C. in July 2007, when Taiwan was represented by John C.C. Deng, chief negotiator of the Office of Trade Negotiations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the United States was represented by Deputy Trade Representative Karan Bhatia.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT's new secretary-general vows to push for Ma-Tsai meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:11:42 (By Shu-hua Lee, Kuei-hsiang Wen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) new secretary-general said Thursday that he will do his best to help engineer a meeting between the leaders of the main opposition and ruling parties.

On his second day in office, King Pu-tsung said that President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the KMT, would like to see more positive communication and healthy competition between the KMT and main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
"We will try our best to achieve this and to do it well, " said King, in response to reporters questions about the proposed meeting.
However, King said he is not sure whether Ma will meet with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen in his capacity as president or as KMT chairman.
"This is not something I can decide," he said.

On the question of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, King said that while the Executive Yuan is working to promote the agreement, the KMT will help to explain the details of it to the public.
He said it is not appropriate for him to comment further on ECFA issues, adding that there should be a clear line between the administration and the party.
On Wednesday, King said since the DPP does not have any idea whether the ECFA is "round or flat," the party's strong opposition to the pact lacks legitimacy.

His comments raised hackles in the DPP, with its spokesman Tsai Chi-chang noting Thursday that various public opinion polls have shown that a lot of people have no idea what the ECFA is, and adding that it would be too late wait until the pact is signed to object to it.
Su Tseng-chang, a former party chairman and premier, also urged the government to clearly explain the ECFA, as not only the DPP, but also the general public, is still at sea.
Meanwhile, DPP spokeswoman Hsiao Bi-khim said Thursday that the party has not yet received an invitation to debate the issue with President Ma, as he proposed.

In a television interview last Friday, Ma raised the possibility of debating the ECFA with DPP Chairwoman Tsai, and said he hopes the debate will take place after there have been some results from the negotiations with China.

However, DPP spokesman Tsai expressed doubts over the government's sincerity to debate the ECFA, and said it was regrettable that Premier Wu Den-yih had declined to discuss ECFA issues with university students.

Earlier this week, the student unions of three universities in Taiwan -- National Taiwan University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, and National Taiwan Normal University -- released a joint statement, asking Premier Wu to explain to students in person what the ECFA is all about.
Premier Wu said he has asked Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang, who is most familiar with topic, to represent the government in the discussions with the students.

President Ma has touted the urgency of striking an ECFA deal with China to protect Taiwan from being marginalized after a free trade area agreement between China and the Association of Southeast Asia Nations (ASEAN) takes effect at the start of next year.

The DPP and its pro-independence allies, however, are wary about signing such an agreement with China, fearing that the pact could make Taiwan more reliant on China economically and eventually lead to its annexation by China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't braces itself for planned protests against China-Taiwan talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:20:22 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Hao Hsueh-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih pledged Thursday that the government will try to strike a balance between maintaining public order and upholding individual freedom, in anticipation of protests to be launched by the opposition against the upcoming cross-Taiwan Strait talks in Taichung.
"While the government is obliged to protect its citizens' freedom of speech, as the host, Taiwan must also show its generous hospitality and ensure the security of its guests," Wu said.
He urged the protesters to work with the government to protect Taiwan's international image and win respect from the rest of the world.

According to Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah, 200 police officers will be deployed at the venue during the talks, and the police force will be increased to 1,000 when the guests are taken on tours, when traffic control measures are needed.
In a report to the Legislative Yuan, the ministry said that police will respect citizens' rights to express their differences while enforcing the law.
In doing so, police will protect law-abiding citizens, crack down on those who break the law, and take actions against violence, it said.

The chief negotiators of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will meet Dec. 22 in Taichung to sign four cross-strait agreements regarding fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Accusing the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou of attempting to formulate under-the-table deals with Beijing by promoting the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between the two sides, the pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has planned a series of protests right before Chen's arrival and during his stay in the central city, including a march and rally on Dec. 20.
Various demonstrations will also be held on Dec. 21-23.

DPP politicians in Taichung said Thursday that protesters will be ubiquitous and will follow Chen wherever he goes during the period to let Chen know that half of Taiwan's population are against the controversial trade pact.

Among the protest methods to be adopted will include releasing sky lanterns inscribed with protest messages outside the event's venue and bombarding the venue with paper-made missiles, according to Fan Sung-yu, convener of the DPP caucus in the Taichung City Council.
The party will also have floats stationed around the venue to propagate its appeals, Fan said, stressing that all of these protests will be non-violent.
Hsieh Ming-yuan, a former DPP legislator, said his party is against the ECFA because the pact will downgrade Taiwan's status to that of a region within China.

The DPP insists that the government should hold a referendum to allow the people to decide whether Taiwan should engage in ECFA talks with China and calls on all people in Taiwan to come out to voice their opposition to the Chiang-Chen talks and proposed trade pact, Hsieh said.

Also Thursday, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu again urged the DPP to take the cross- strait talks in stride and make sure the protests are conducted through rational and non-violent means so as not to undermine Taiwan's democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Food safety a major concern among consumer protection groups
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:32:41 (By Yang Shu-min and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: With food safety remaining a major concern among Taiwan' s consumer protection groups, the relaxation of restrictions on American beef imports and the ensuing controversy was chosen by the Consumers' Foundation as the top consumer-related news item of the year.

At the end of every year for the past two decades, the foundation has been selecting 10 consumer-related issues that made news headlines during the year. This year, the government's decision to open the Taiwan market to bone-in beef from the United States was at the top of the list.

Other food safety issues identified by the foundation as of grave concern included the detection of cancer-causing arsenic in products of the international restaurant franchises McDonald's and Domino's Pizza, the slaughter of more than 9,000 ducks contaminated with toxic dioxins in Kaohsiung County, heavy metal contamination of fishing ponds and farmlands, and the discovery of pesticide residues in Chinese herbal ingredients such as white fungus, wolfberries and jujubes.

The repeated breakdown of the Taipei Neihu-Muzha mass rapid transit line was among the top news stories of concern to consumers, while news reports on housing prices and the revision of the standard construction contract with regard to price assessments of main buildings and supplementary buildings also attracted much attention.

Other top news items included the posting of incorrect prices on the Web sites of Dell and Hola, the Nanshan Life Insurance acquisition that caused panic among its policyholders, and Next Media's posting of obscene animated news on its Web site and the furious reactions from the government and private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: President attends inauguration of houses built for typhoon survivors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:42:37 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and over 100 guests gathered together Thursday in a small village of the eastern county of Taitung to celebrate the official handover of 50 newly built houses for families affected by Typhoon Morakot which devastated parts of Taiwan in August.

The 50 permanent houses is the first batch of some 1,200 homes that World Vision Taiwan, the local chapter of the international Christian charity, is planning to build in Taitung, Pingtung, Kaohsiung and Chiayi counties, some of the worst affected areas.

"I have visited Taitung County four times since Typhoon Morakot struck. Every time I passed by this construction site, I saw these houses being built and felt very touched, as these houses look like real homes," Ma said.

The president made the remarks in a celebration of the inauguration of the new houses in Taitung County's Jalan Village, praising World Vision Taiwan for having respectfully incorporated into its reconstruction project the cultures and values of the indigenous people, many of whom were seriously affected in the storm.
World Vision Taiwan and donor HTC Foundation handed a symbolic door key to village chief Lin Jiao-guang, to mark a significant milestone for Typhoon Morakot reconstruction efforts.
Ma also helped villager Wu Jin-shan install a doorplate for his new house number 112-50 and visited other typhoon-affected families to share their joy of moving into the new homes.

Hank Du, executive director of World Vision Taiwan, expressed gratitude to the many donors and partners who have contributed funds, gifts-in-kind, time, and talent to help the typhoon survivors recover from the disaster.
"Thanks to the efforts of all the villagers and partners, we have seen many stories full of blessing and gratefulness happening on this piece of land," Du said.
"Recovery is more than recovering what is lost. More importantly, it's about sharing love, peace and hope," he added.

According to World Vision Taiwan, through its "Collaborative Home Building" approach, these houses were constructed by the beneficiaries with help from professional teams, military personnel, and volunteers from Taiwan and overseas.

The construction work commenced two weeks after the typhoon struck in early August, and took four months of tireless labor to complete. It has transformed what was once a wasteland into a settlement now called "Jalan 88 New Community," it added.
World Vision Taiwan has announced that it will invest over NT$1.4 billion (US$433 million) from public donations in its long-term rehabilitation programs to help storm survivors rebuild their lives.
Typhoon Morakot swept through Taiwan from Aug. 8-9, killing more than 600 people. The damage caused by the typhoon in parts of southern and eastern Taiwan was the worst in 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 60 percent of Taiwan's affluent report wealth increase
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:45:05 (By Kao Chao-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Over 60 percent of affluent Taiwanese investors say they became wealthier during the last six months, mainly due to the global stock market rally, according to a survey conducted by the Nielsen Company.

The percentage of affluent respondents in Taiwan who said their wealth rose climbed to 61 percent from 33 percent six months ago, according to the Hong Kong-based HSBC Holdings Plc, which commissioned the survey.

The poll on wealth management for the Asia Pacific found that some 80 percent of Taiwan's rich people responding to the poll own stocks, nearly 90 percent still hold Taiwanese currency in cash and savings, and 43 percent have taken out a life insurance policy, said Betty Miao, an HSBC official in Taiwan in charge of personal financial services.
Thirty-nine percent of the Taiwanese respondents said they have savings in foreign currencies, marking the highest percentage in all eight Asian countries and areas surveyed, Miao said.
The pollsters defined "affluence" in Taiwan as people earning at least NT$70,000 (US$2,166) per person per month, in addition to possessing liquid or floating assets worth NT$3 million or more.
Meanwhile, the poll found that 70 percent of the Taiwanese respondents say they will invest in the stock or securities markets in the Greater China area over the next six months.
The poll also found that affluent Taiwanese tend to choose the Greater China area and new emerging markets for stock or fund investment.
"The Taiwanese affluent are not only well traveled, they also have relatives and friends from all over the world, " Miao quoted the poll findings as indicating.
The survey, conducted in September and October, was based on interviews with 1,700 wealthy investors aged between 30 and 55, HSBC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade pact conducive to Taiwan-China trade ties: Swedish envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 18:50:23 (By P. C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Sweden's top representative here Henrik Bystrom said Thursday that a planned trade pact between Taiwan and China should be conducive to closer cross-Taiwan Strait trade ties and that it is something looked forward to by many people.
Bystrom was referring to an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), which Taiwan hopes to sign with China by early next year.

He made the comments after receiving an Economic Medal from Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang at the ministry for his outstanding contribution to Taiwan-Sweden exchanges in both the government and private sectors.
In principle, the pact should be a pact that would help Taiwan and China forge closer trade and economic relations -- which Bystrom said will be a welcome development for many people.

He hailed Taiwan as an open society with friendly people and a bright future, but he pointed out that Taiwan is facing a serious challenge of building value- added brands in the world market amid fierce competition in the region as many Taiwan-based companies have relocated their operations to China.
Bystrom, who has been representative of the Swedish Trade Council Taipei since August 2001, will retire from the post by the end of this year.

During his tenure of more than 10 years in Taipei, the Swedish envoy has helped push the two countries to clinch mutually beneficial pacts on two-way cooperation concerning energy and environment conservation, telecommunications, and the avoidance of double taxation.
During the decade Bystrom has served in his post, the number of Swedish firms with a stronghold in Taipei grew from 35 to 70 at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: From Chaos to Hope
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan editorial abstract (file 3 of a daily roundup) 12/17/09 19:36:55 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: "Pan" -- the pronunciation of the Chinese character for "hope" -- has been selected as the word most representative of Taiwan for 2009 in a recent opinion survey.
When the survey asking respondents to choose a word best reflecting the situation in the country for the year was held for the first time in 2008, the word "chaos" was chosen.

The selection of the word "hope" to replace last year's choice represents an encouraging turn of mood in Taiwan. It shows that the majority of local people have endeavored to set aside the confusion and disorder of the previous year to focus on a more promising future.

The annual survey, co-sponsored by the United Daily News and the Far Eastern Group, provides clues to general social sentiment over the past year and is aimed at inspiring those in power to reflect upon their governance.

In this year's survey, more than 60 percent of the 30 final selections were negative, but "hope" winning the largest number of votes indicates that the mainstream attitude of Taiwanese people last year was to move forward in a positive and optimistic manner.

Hope implies happiness and its selection as the word best representative of 2009 symbolizes most people's good wishes and eagerness to usher in a new year. It is hoped that the coming year will be a period of harmony, peace and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Figures Tell

TEXT.P: A recent CommonWealth Magazine poll about local people's stances on Taiwan's future found that 78 percent of the respondents want the present status quo, while 11 percent look forward to de jure independence soon and 2 percent desire for quick unification with China.
Among the status quo supporters, 35 percent hope to see the status quo maintained forever; 33 percent yearn for slow moving toward de jure independence; 10 percent call for ultimate unification.

Sometime ago, a National Taiwan University survey conducted as part of a research on globalization also found that 44.78 percent of the respondents want the status quo to remain; 29.97 percent want to maintain the status quo and gradually move toward de jure independence; 4.32 percent aspire to maintain the status quo and gradually move toward unification; 9.11 percent call for fast independence and a mere 1.82 percent want fast unification. In other words, up to 83.86 percent do not want to see Taiwan annexed into China.

Both surveys convincingly prove that maintaining the status quo and eventually moving toward de jure independence is the common aspiration of the people of Taiwan. In essence, maintaining the status quo and transforming Taiwan into a fully normalized country is the choice of a majority of Taiwanese people.
Against this backdrop, the only road for the leader of a democratic country like Taiwan to take is safeguarding its present independent status quo and then moving toward de jure independence.

As a presidential candidate, Ma Ying-jeou spoke loudly on the campaign trail that Taiwan's future should be determined solely by the 23 million Taiwan people and vowed to fight for local people's common aspiration for representation in the United Nations.
Once elected, Ma, however, immediately backed off his promise and recognized the so-called "92 consensus" - a move tantamount to embracing Beijing's "one China" principle.

Since assuming office more than a year ago, Ma has even moved faster to "lock Taiwan's economy into China's fold." In the face of China's relentless suppression of Taiwan in the international arena, the Ma administration still touts its "diplomatic truce" strategy at the expense of Taiwan's sovereign status.

While Ma is seeking even closer economic ties with China by preaching the urgency of signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement, the CommonWealth Magazine poll shows that 61 percent of the respondents worry about Taiwan's economic over reliance on China.

If Ma remains oblivious to the alarming signals shown in the ruling Kuomintang's setback in the recent local elections, he should heed the mainstream opinion seen in the results of the latest CommonWealth poll; otherwise, his chance to win a second presidential term would be slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Steel Corp. to invest US$94.55 million in Brazil iron mine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 19:59:16 (By Chiu Kuo-chiang and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: An official from Taiwan's largest integrated steel maker, China Steel Corporation (CSC), said Thursday that the company has reached an agreement with two Japanese major shareholders of Brazil's NAMISA iron ore mine to obtain a 1 percent share in the mine.

It is the first time CSC has sought to obtain a stake in a foreign iron company and the decision is seen as an effort to try to take control of the raw material source, as Brazil is one of Taiwan's main suppliers of iron ore.

Chung Lo-min, CSC executive vice president, said the agreement was officially passed in a CSC board meeting that same day, but will only take effect after it is approved by NAMISA stakeholders and the Brazilian government.

CSC has agreed to pay 8.5 billion Japanese yen (US$94.55 million) to obtain the 1 percent stake in NAMISA from the Itochu Corporation, a Japanese trading company, and major Japanese steel producer Sumitomo Metal Industries Ltd., which own 16 percent and 2.64 percent of the Brazilian iron ore mine, respectively.
Founded in 2007, NAMISA is largely owned by Brazilian steel maker CSN, which has a 60 percent share, while the rest is owned by a consortium of Japanese and South Korean steel companies.
NAMISA is estimated to produce 14.5 million tons of iron ore this year, rising to 39 million tons per year by 2014.

"After years of exploitation, iron ore and coal are destined to become rare resources, with prices continuing to increase in the long run. Therefore, this participation project is of great investment value," Chung said.
He noted that CSC's 1 percent stake is too little to suggest that the company is trying to get total control of the iron ore resource.
According to the Brussels-based World Steel Association, CSC, which is largely state-owned, was the 26th-largest steel producer in the world in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA to spend US$1.1 billion to help workers deal with trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 20:10:09 (By Shu-fen Wang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has agreed to allocate NT$36.4 billion (US$1.1 billion) to help workers with job placement in anticipation of the impact of a proposed economic pact it hopes to sign with China, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Thursday.

The labor assistance fund, which will be part of NT$94.3 billion that will be allocated to help upgrade and transform industries that could be seriously affected in the wake of the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), will be managed by the CLA, said CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan at a legislative committee meeting.
The CLA will not use its employment insurance fund or employment security fund to assist workers with the ECFA impact, Wang said.

The NT$36.4 billion budget will be allocated over 10 years, he went on, adding that the subsidies offered to workers will be short- term and designed to enhance their job skills so that they can find stable jobs in the long term.

According to Wang, a widespread idea that signing the ECFA with China will only benefit industry and not workers is "a misunderstanding." Industries and workers are all in the same boat, he said, adding that signing the ECFA will strengthen the competitiveness of industries, which can also increase job opportunities.

Based on the CLA's report, the signing of the ECFA will create 105,000 to 125,000 jobs -- a far cry from a report from the Ministry of Economics Affairs (MOEA) that predicts a net increase of 250,000 jobs.

Wang explained that the lower CLA figure is because it uses a static simulation that only considers jobs created while the country's competitiveness increases, while the MOEA study applies a dynamic simulation that assumes that after the signing of the ECFA, more industries from other countries will invest in Taiwan, which will bring more jobs.
Wang said that overall, the signing of the ECFA will not increase the unemployment rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese students score worse than South Koreans in English test
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 20:28:09 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students at four education levels all fared worse than their South Korean counterparts in the 2008 Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC), with local senior high school students performing the poorest with an average score of 524, 151 points lower than the South Korean average.

The average scores of Taiwanese students at senior high schools, technical and vocational colleges, general universities and graduate schools, respectively, were all lower than those of South Korean students at similar education levels, according to a report on comparisons of 2008 TOEIC scores in Taiwan, Japan and South Korea released Thursday by the Taiwan branch of the U.S. Educational Testing Service (ETS).

Taiwanese university students scored an average of 577 points on the TOEIC last year, again lower than the 621 average scored by their South Korean counterparts but higher than 553 average scored by Japanese students.

Taiwan's technical and vocational college students scored an average of 408, lower than the average of 460 scored by their counterparts in South Korea and also lower than the average of 484 obtained by students at two-year junior colleges in Japan.
Local senior high school students got an average score of 524 points, close to the 522 average recorded by their Japanese counterparts but far lower than South Korea's 675 average.
Graduate students in Taiwan also lagged behind their South Korean counterparts, scoring an average of 585, behind South Korea's 663 average but slightly higher than Japan's average of 583.

The report was issued after ETS Taiwan released the 2008 TOEIC scores for global test takers earlier this year that shows the average TOEIC score in Taiwan ranked in eighth place among 14 Asian countries and areas, ahead of Japan but behind South Korea.

Benjamin Wang, an ETS representative in Taiwan said the comparisons made to gauge students' English language proficiency in the three countries with similar education systems can help show their overall competitiveness in the world market.

TOEIC is a test of English proficiency used as a standard for establishing workplace English writing skills and spoken English proficiency for non-native English-speaking people. The highest possible score is 990.

However, according to another report released that same day by the Taiwan branch of Cambridge ESOL, Taiwanese children in the 7-12 age group ranked second among non-English-speaking countries in Asia in the 2009 Cambridge Young Learners English tests, second only to Indonesia but ahead of China and South Korea.
Cambridge ESOL in the United Kingdom offers the world's leading range of certificates for learners and teachers of English.

DOC.HEADLINE: High court decides to keep ex-president in custody
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 20:57:20 (By Yu-chia Lai and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A three-judge panel of the Taiwan High Court ruled late Thursday that former President Chen Shui-bian should remain in custody for another two months, on the grounds that he might abscond if released from detention.

The court announced that Chen should be detained for another two months from Dec. 24-Feb. 23. The next hearing on whether Chen should be detained for a longer period might be held before the Feb. 13-21 Lunar New Year holiday.

The judges said that Chen, who was president for eight years and took part in many secret diplomatic missions, has had the chance to come into contact with foreign governments and members of the private sector, making him "more familiar than ordinary people with ways to flee overseas."
With Chen's influence and the assets stashed overseas by his family, he could live a comfortable life if he were to run away to evade the severe sentence that he could face, the judges said.

Both Chen and his wife Wu Shu-jen were sentenced Sept. 11 by the Taipei District Court to life in prison, in addition to receiving fines of NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on several counts of corruption, including embezzling from a presidential fund for state affairs, taking bribes from local businessmen and money laundering.
The high court panel took charge of Chen's case Sept. 24 after he appealed the judgment. The panel ruled that same day that Chen should remain in custody for another three months.
The former president was first detained Nov. 12, 2008 and was released Dec. 13 following his indictment.
He was detained again Dec. 30 after the Taipei District Court approved a request by prosecutors to take him back into custody and he has not been released since.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's verified emission reductions valued at NT$1.7 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 21:29:50 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Ten businesses in Taiwan have been independently verified in terms of their greenhouse gas emission reductions, generating carbon offsets worth an estimated NT$1.7 billion (US$52.55 million) , a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Thursday.

In preparation for the establishment of a carbon emissions trading system, the government has since 2005 provided guidance to 120 businesses in the energy sector on how to calculate their emissions, with 95 percent of the emissions having been tallied so far, according to Yeh Huey-ching, director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Energy.
The bureau in 2006 began to help these businesses obtain independent verification of their emissions reductions, and 10 of them have now succeeded, Yeh said.
The total reductions by these businesses have been measured at 2.5 million metric tons of carbon dioxide-equivalent, he went on.
With each metric ton of reductions being traded for 14 euros on the European Climate Exchange, the volume is estimated to carry a total value of NT$1.7 billion, Yeh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Palau and Saint Lucia advocate inclusion of Taiwan in climate talks
DOC.DATELINE: Copenhagen, Dec. 16 (CNA) 12/17/09 21:46:20 (By Chou Ying-cheng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Palau President Johnson Toribiong and Saint Lucia Prime Minister Stephenson King advocated that Taiwan should be included in the global discussions on climate change, while addressing the climate conference in Copenhagen Wednesday.

The leaders of two of the 23 countries that still have diplomatic ties with Taiwan were speaking at the 15th Conference of Parties to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
Dozens of national leaders gave their statements on the urgency to unite the efforts of all inhabitants on the earth in the face of climate change.

Stressing the importance for the world to move beyond distinction, race, class, and national boundaries and to relearn to live in harmony with Nature, President Toribiong said that as all inhabitants on earth are required to work together, "in this context, we advocate the inclusion of Taiwan in these discussions."
Saint Lucia's Prime Minister King also mentioned in his speech that Taiwan has been left out in the process of climate change negotiations.
King pointed out that the climate change negotiations are delicate and challenging and the world has high expectations on the Copenhagen conference.

Taiwan has called on the UNFCCC to consider the needs of the 23 million people on the island to participate in the climate change discussions in view that the island is especially vulnerable to extreme weather conditions, rising temperatures, unpredictable storms and loss of biodiversity.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA talks may take 20 years: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:02:09 (By Erin Ho and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may take 20 years to complete its talks with China on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), an economist said Thursday.
In a bid to forge closer cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade relations to sharpen its competitive edge, Taiwan is poised to sign the ECFA early next year.

"Given the great differences among the public with regard to ties with China, it might take 20 years or so for Taiwan to complete ECFA issues other than the items to be included on an `early harvest list, '" said Chu Yun-peng, a former minister without portfolio and one of the main economic advisers to President Ma Ying-jeou.

Chu, now an economics professor at National Central University, said at a Taipei seminar on the global financial crisis and cooperation between Taiwan and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) that the ECFA is not a panacea but rather a possible solution for Taiwan in the face of the formation of regional trade groupings from which Taiwan is excluded.

He added that the countries in the region and the rest of the world have been aggressively signing free trade agreements (FTAs) , which are having a negative impact on Taiwan, especially in terms of its trade competitiveness.

Although it is now too late for Taiwan to seek an FTA with ASEAN, it still could pursue bilateral economic cooperation and tariff reduction arrangements with ASEAN countries through negotiations, Chu said, adding that "China's influence will be crucial to Taiwan's attempts to forge closer economic ties with ASEAN."
Chu, who has been dubbed the "pusher" of the ECFA idea, said that since public support for the pact is still low, it poses a rigorous challenge for the government.
He said that an ECFA is not tantamount to an FTA with China but is rather a framework agreement with most of its contents needing to be added step-by-step through negotiations.
An ECFA can only serve to help eliminate Taiwan's competitive disadvantages, while the nation has to create "a new blue sea" by creating brands and possessing advanced technologies, Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kiribati, Burkina Faso back Taiwan's UNFCCC bid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:04:39 (By Ho Hung-ju and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Kiribati and Burkina Faso expressed support Thursday during the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Conference held in the Danish capital of Copenhagen for the inclusion of Taiwan in the global response to climate change.

According to Kiribati President Anote Tong, in achieving its carbon reduction commitment, it is very important for the UNFCCC to be inclusive so as to ensure that all nations, including Taiwan, can play a part in the efforts.
Blaise Compaore, president of Burkina Faso, also urged UNFCCC to admit Taiwan.
He said it is time for the world to allow Taiwan to participate more actively in the international community and help with the global effort to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

The remarks by Tong and Compaore followed similar ones by Palau President Johnson Toribiong and St. Lucia Prime Minister Stephenson King a day earlier at the conference, which opened Dec. 7 and will run through Dec. 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: Exchange of spies could be included in cross-strait talks: SEF
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:20:24 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An exchange of intelligence agents from Taiwan and China being held captive by each side could be put on the agenda for the future round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Chairman Kao Koong-lian said Thursday.

Answering reporters' questions at the Legislative Yuan, Kao said that though the subject never emerged, "if the time is right, " many issues could be put on the negotiation table between negotiators of Taiwan and China, including the exchange of intelligence agents.

The reporters were conveying a call made a day earlier by Chen Hu-men, a former Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) chief, for the SEF to work toward the release of Taiwanese spies held in China over the decades by taking advantage of the opportunity presented by the talks between Taiwan's SEF and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) next week in Taichung.

If it is inconvenient for the government to openly raise the issue, it could commission a task force formed by retired MIB officials to initiate contacts with the Chinese authorities to discuss the matter, Chen Hu-men added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators says plainer language needed to promote ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:23:30 (By Shu-fen Wang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator said Thursday at a legislative committee meeting that the government should use metaphors to teach the public about the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

According to Lin Hung-chi, signing the proposed trade pact with China is like wearing spiked racing shoes to enhance Taiwan's competitiveness, while forcing Taiwanese companies to compete with other countries on a non-level playing field is like wearing iron shoes.
Lin said he had been told by some labor leaders that briefings held by the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) about the ECFA were not very helpful and that they still do not understand what it is.
Therefore, Lin went on, the administration should use plainer language to promote the trade pact with China.
CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan agreed with Lin and said the CLA will start using plainer language to promote the ECFA.
KMT Legislator Huang Ho Tsai-feng also said that even though the CLA has spent NT$1.1 million on nine ECFA briefings, many workers who have attended the briefings are still no wiser about the ECFA.
With another 16 such briefings to be held, she demanded that the CLA develop a better approach to the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Master Kong TDRs fall after first-day daily jump
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:24:48 (By Han Ting-ting and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The price of Master Kong Taiwan Depository Receipts (TDRs) fell Thursday on the Taiwan Stock Exchange after surging to its 7 percent daily limit at the opening of trading, a worse-than-expected performance on the second day of the public offering.

The price of the famous instant noodle maker's TDRs opened at NT$51.5 (US$1.59) at the opening of trading, but soon dropped to NT$50.3 and hovered around that level before closing at NT$50.1 amid heavy selling on a large handover volume of 109,032 shares -- breaking widespread speculation among many investors about a "honeymoon effect" that the shares would see a 7 precent jump in price at least for three days in a row.

This is a sign that market confidence in the release of the Master Kong TDRs is not that strong as had been widely speculated, analysts said, adding that their performance -- good or bad -- will have an effect on the local bourse.
The share rallied to its daily limit at NT$48.15 shortly after the opening on its debut the previous day on the local bourse.
Wei Ing-chou, chairman of Tingyi Holding Corporation, which owns the Master Kong brand, had predicted recently that Master Kong shares would reach the daily ceiling at least three times.
Master Kong made Forbes Asia's Fabulous 50 Companies list in 2009, with a total market value of NT$416.82 billion.

The TDR listing was the biggest ever launched in the country by a Taiwan- invested company returning from overseas, and it raised some NT$17 billion by floating about 380 million TDRs through a premium-priced strategy on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Dec. 2-7.

Tingyi is the largest food and beverage maker in terms of market value in China. Ting Hsin International Group is the biggest shareholder in Tingyi and is controlled by Wei and his three younger brothers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government performance in health, financial supervision poor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/17/09 22:38:56 (By Yang Shu-min and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation announced Thursday that the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) and Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC), along with the Civil Aviation Administration (CAA), turned in the most unsatisfactory performances by any government agencies in 2009.

Meanwhile, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Consumer Protection Commission under the Cabinet, and the Control Yuan were lauded for their efficiency in monitoring, inspecting and correcting matters in relation to consumer protection.
The foundation said that a "Gold Good Award" will be presented to each of the three outstanding agencies, while the poor performers will suffer the ignominy of being given a "Gold Bad" token.

The Control Yuan was appraised for correcting a mistake by the Ministry of the Interior in its real estate price assessment, while the foundation had high praise for a Consumer Protection Commission initiative in dealing with food safety issues and e-commerce disputes.
Turning to the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, the foundation praised its efficiency in inspecting the safety of household equipment.
On the other hand, the relaxation of import restrictions on bone-in beef from the United States and numerous food contamination cases have made the DOH a major target of complaint.

The FSC, which has been faulted by the foundation for two consecutive years, was accused of failing to keep the interest rates of debit cards and credit cards within reasonable levels, in addition to being incapable of protecting the public from losses caused by the collapse of some businesses.

The CAA for its part caused discontent mainly because ticket prices for cross- Taiwan Strait flights have not been lowered in line with reductions in operating costs thanks to the average 43 percent cut in distances caused by direct flights, according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 18, or the third day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1787: New Jersey becomes the third state of the United States.
1825: Tsar Nicholas I succeeds to the Russian throne.
1829: Jean Baptiste Pierre Antoine de Monet Lamarck, one of France's best scientists, dies at the age of 75. His most important work was the study of evolution.
1865: The United States abolishes slavery.
1911: Wu Ting-fang, representative of anti-Ching revolutionaries, holds peace talks in Shanghai with Tang Chao-yi, representative of the Ching government.
1913: Willy Brandt, German statesman and chancellor of West Germany from 1969 to 1974, is born.
1913: Lo Fu-hsing, who participated in Dr. Sun Yat-sen's overthrow of the Ching dynasty and was a leader of the "Miaoli Incident," is arrested by the Japanese in Tamsui.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, who was appointed commander of the National Revolutionary Army on June 5, 1926, captures Wuhan (Hankow), which had been proclaimed the capital of the Nationalist government by a left-wing group of the Kuomintang on Jan. 1, 1927.
1941: German forces retreat in North Africa during World War II.
1956: Japan is admitted into the United Nations.
1961: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic ties with Upper Volta.
1965: Nine African states break diplomatic ties with Britain over Rhodesia.
1969: Britain formally abolishes the death penalty.
1969: The ROC's first satellite ground station is established, enabling satellite communications with the United States, Japan and Thailand.
1976: Thanat Khoman, former Thai foreign minister, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: Soviet Premier Aleksei Nikolayevich Kosygin, who succeeded Nikita Khrushchev but was often overshadowed by the Communist Party secretary, Leonid Brezhnev, dies at the age of 76.
1985: Chang Fu-lin, the first Chinese-American astronaut, flies aboard the space shuttle Columbia.
1987: The Taiwan Provincial Government announces that it will cease to issue lottery tickets starting in 1988.
1987: In South Korea, Roh Ta-woo is declared the winner of the first presidential election to be held in 16 years. However, students riot, claiming electoral corruption.
1987: The "Hai Lung," a submarine purchased by the Republic of China from the Netherlands, arrives in Kaohsiung.
1989: The European Economic Community signs a 10-year trade pact with the Soviet Union.
1991: The first international project to save the world's rainforests is launched when the World Bank, the European Commission, and the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations grant Brazil US$250 million for conservation work in the Amazon basin.
1992: Kim Young-sam, a member of South Korea's Democratic Liberal Party, is elected the country's first civilian president after 32 years of military rule.
1998: Andrew Lavern Smith is put to death in the state of South Carolina, becoming the 500th person to be executed in the United States since capital punishment was reinstated in 1977.
1999: Construction on Taiwan's first national children's hospital, to be operated by National Taiwan University Hospital, is begun.
1999: TransAsia Airways formally opens passenger flight services between Taipei and the Thai island of Phuket.
2000: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC), the world's biggest semiconductor manufacturer, sets a record by delivering the world's first batch of 12-inch wafers ordered by a customer.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian presides over a ceremony marking the commissioning of the nation's first F-16 fighter wing into service held at Chiayi Air Base in southern Taiwan.
2001: The Central News Agency (CNA) and the MiTAC-Synnex Group enter into a strategic alliance to offer speedy corporate news and commercial and industrial information services in Chinese to domestic and global enterprises.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Study without thinking is labor lost. Thinking without study is perilous. To give oneself up to the study of metaphysical theories -- that is very injurious indeed. Shall I teach you what is understanding? To know what it is that you know, and to know what it is that you do not know -- that is understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 09:35:53 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened lower Friday.
The weighted price index was down 51.73 points at 7,690.44 on a turnover of NT$3.09 billion (US$95.66 million) at the open. The index fell 9.43 points, or 0.12 percent, to close at 7,742.17 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- Polls on talks
DOC.DATELINE: 12/18/09 10:22:16 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A series of public opinion polls has found that more than half of the respondents do not want to see street protests against high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks slated to take place Dec. 21-25 in the central Taiwan city of Taichung. Even a survey conducted by the opposition DPP, which is planning to stage the protests, found that only 48.5 percent support the plan.
The following is a digest of local media reports on the latest developments related to the polls on cross-strait talks:
China Times:

Fifty-three percent of the Taiwan people oppose the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) intention to stage massive protest rallies against the upcoming meeting between the top negotiators from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait in Taichung City.

The latest poll conducted by the daily found that 71 percent of the respondents are aware of the Dec. 21-25 meeting between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

Thirty-nine percent of the respondents said they are in favor of the meeting, 49 percent said the current pace of cross-strait engagement is "just right, " while 53 percent said they disagree with the DPP's plans to boycott the meeting.

The poll also found that 50 percent of the respondents do not consider it as "selling out" Taiwan if the country chooses to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, while a high of 76 percent hope President Ma Ying-jeou will debate with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen over the ECFA plan. (Dec. 18, 2009)
United Daily News:

The holding of the fourth round of high-level cross-strait talks in central Taiwan has triggered a new standoff between the DPP and the Kuomintang government, with the Ministry of the Interior stepping up security measures to prevent any incidents from occurring and the DPP threatening a massive "siege" against Beijing's proxy and his delegation.

A DPP poll has found that nearly 50 percent of the Taiwan people support the planned protests and demonstrations against the forthcoming Chiang-Chen meeting, while over 60 percent oppose the government's plans to compromise the people's freedom of assembly in the name of assuring Chen's personal security during the visit. (Dec. 18, 2009)
Liberty Times:

Taiwan's top China policy planner, the Mainland Affairs Council, has claimed that over half of the Taiwan people have endorsed all of the four agreements expected to be signed during the imminent Chiang-Chen meeting.

Poll figures, however, are telling the truth that the people's support for systematic cross-strait negotiations has waned, from over 70 percent in the past to lower than 60 percent now. (Dec. 18, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese NGO representatives shut out of Copenhagen conference
DOC.DATELINE: Copenhagen, Dec. 17 (CNA) 12/18/09 11:37:23 (By Jou Ying-cheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A number of Taiwanese delegations attending the Copenhagen conference on climate change in Denmark as non-government organizations (NGOs) were unable to attend the conference Thursday due to the sponsor's strict restrictions on the number of NGOs allowed to attend.

The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change Secretariat said in an email sent to the major attending NGOs that to ensure the safety of leaders from over 110 countries and in consideration of the limited accommodation at the Bella Center, the conference venue, it could allow only 300 NGO members to attend that day's conference.
Chiu Wen-yen, deputy minister of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , described the restriction as "very inappropriate."

"The task of fighting climate change is not only a government matter, the private sector all over the world also plays a major role, " he said, adding that the United Nations' shutting out of NGO members does not conform to its principle of tolerance.

Reports have said that if a global carbon emissions agreement is passed at the conference, Taiwan's exports will face an uncertain future as the United States and other parties will be allowed to impose trade sanctions through tariffs, border and carbon taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- English ability
DOC.DATELINE: 12/18/09 11:38:42 (Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese schoolchildren's English ability is second-best in non-English- speaking Asian nations, but older students lag behind other countries in the region, according to the results of recent international examinations.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on Taiwanese students' English proficiency:
United Daily News:

Benjamin Wang, president of the Taiwan branch of the U.S. Educational Testing Service (ETS), attributed the problem Thursday to the fact that Taiwan's English education at senior high and vocational schools attaches no importance to the field of teaching or guiding students on how to use the language in daily life.

Even though English proficiency among children in the 7-12 age group ranked 2nd among non-English-speaking Asian nations, the poor performance of technical and vocational school students in the Test of English for International Communication (TOEIC) played a leading role in pulling down the overall average TOEIC score of Taiwanese students, according to Wang.

A manager at the Taiwan branch of Cambridge ESOL -- another major English proficiency test -- said the overall performance of Taiwanese children in the 7-12 age group in the ESOL test was almost at the average global level, but she agreed that they lost their edge when they entered more advanced levels. (Dec. 18, 2009)
China Times:
Wang Su-wei, a manager at the Cambridge ESOL Taiwan branch, said she has found that Taiwanese students cannot use English well in daily life and treat the language as only a tool for school tests.

Since the ESOL tests focus on overall English proficiency in listening, speaking, reading and writing, they appear difficult for local students at higher grades, who are simply taught to recite vocabulary and study grammar when learning English, Wang said. (Dec. 18, 2009)
Liberty Times:

Professor Chen Chao-ming of the Department of English at National Chengchi University said Taiwanese college students do not read enough English and warned that if the problem is not addressed, Taiwanese students' English skills will lag further and further behind those of other Asian countries such as South Korea. (Dec. 18, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 percent support systematic cross-strait consultations: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 12:16:46 (By Feng Chao and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) unveiled the results of a public opinion survey Friday showing that nearly 60 percent of the respondents support systematic consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The results show that 59.5 percent of those polled support such talks, while 18.7 percent do not.

The results also show that over half of the respondents support the four agreements expected to be signed Dec. 22 in Taichung, central Taiwan by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Association of Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

According to the survey results, 65.3 percent support an agreement on industrial product standards, inspection and certification, while 61.3 percent believe an agreement on agricultural quarantine inspections will help safeguard public health.
Fifty-six percent support both sides reaching an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation, while 50.2 percent support a fishing crew cooperation agreement.

Asked about their views on cross-strait trade relations, 31.7 percent said they "should be further strengthened." This compared with 25.7 percent who said the pace was "just fine, " and 27.3 percent who said trade relations are "too close."

The Dec. 11-13 survey, conducted by the Election Study Center of National Chengchi University and commissioned by the MAC -- targeted people over the age of 20, collecting 1,092 effective samples with a margin of error of 2.97 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: China cuts in to oppose Taiwan's UNFCCC bid
DOC.DATELINE: Copenhagen, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 14:30:31 (By Jou Ying-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A marathon meeting of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) Conference was held in the Danish capital Thursday, during which many of Taiwan's diplomatic allies spoke in support of Taiwan's inclusion in the group until a Chinese delegate cut in to oppose the bid.

Unlike the heads of states or ministers of Republic of China allies who took the meeting's podium to voice their support for Taiwan's inclusion in the global response to climate change, the Chinese official merely signaled his opposition from his seat in the audience.

Citing Beijing's "one China principle" as the reason for his opposition, he said those nations' initiatives in favor of Taiwan's bid to join the UNFCCC as an observer have "hurt the feelings of the 1.3 billion Chinese people."

Altogether, nine of Taiwan's diplomatic allies had voiced support for Taiwan's UNFCCC bid over the past two days in Copenhagen -- Palau, St. Lucia, Kiribati, Burkina Faso, Swaziland, Sao Tome and Principe, Saint Christopher and Nevis and The Gambia, as well as Nicaragua.

Gambian Vice President Isatou Njie-Saidy spoke to support Taiwan's cause. She cited Taiwan's admission into the World Health Assembly -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- as an observer in May this year as an "acceptable precedence, of course applicable to other international fora, in this case the UNFCCC, with climate change affecting no doubt all members of the international community and humans everywhere."
"Taiwan as a member of the global family therefore should be part of all United Nations-related mechanisms, for the sake of justice and fairness," she added.
Soon after Njie-Saidy's speech, the Chinese official was allowed by the meeting's chair to make a brief statement from his seat.
Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Samuel Santos Lopez followed the Chinese official's statement to express Nicaragua's support for Taiwan's UNFCCC bid.
The meeting had proceeded until nearly 3 a.m. Friday as of press time.

Taiwan has called on the UNFCCC to consider the need for the country to participate in climate change discussions as it is especially vulnerable to extreme weather conditions, rising temperatures, unpredictable storms and loss of biodiversity.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Israel ink agreement on avoidance of double taxation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 15:29:07 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Israel's top representative to Taiwan signed an agreement with Taiwan Friday that will prevent double taxation, deter tax evasion, and ensure that taxpayers in both countries will be treated equally.

Raphael Gamzou, representative of the Israeli Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei (ISECO) , Israel's de facto embassy in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic relations, said he will bring the treaty to have it signed by Terry G.C. Ting, Taiwan's top representative to Israel, next week, before it takes effect Jan. 1.
Taiwan has signed similar agreements with 16 other countries, including Singapore, Australia, New Zealand, the United Kingdom, and the Netherlands.
