Describing the agreement as a milestone in bilateral economic relations between Taiwan and Israel, Gamzou said it will serve as an incentive to entrepreneurs of Taiwan and Israel and will encourage the business communities in both countries to be more willing to enter into partnerships with the other side.
"I think it is a good finale for 2009, which was not the best economic year, but this is definitely a good sign for the future year and years to come," Israel's top envoy to Taiwan said.

Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said at the signing ceremony that both sides worked very hard to push through the treaty since beginning negotiations in 2006 and that the agreement will further strengthen the already close economic relations and cooperation mechanisms between Taipei and Tel Aviv.
"The agreement will help systematize, simplify and bring transparency to bilateral taxation affairs and business exchanges, " Lee said.
Taiwan and Israel inked an agreement on mutual assistance and cooperation in customs affairs in June this year and a bilateral temporary admission carnet in 2003, he noted.
According to Israel's Central Bureau of Statistics, bilateral trade between Taiwan and Israel reached US$1.18 billion in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: First map of Taiwan vegetation published
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 16:17:05 (By Jian-bang Liu and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: After six years of field investigation, the first map of Taiwan's vegetation -- nearly 60 percent of which is forest -- was published Thursday.

According to officials of the Council of Agriculture's Forestry Bureau, it can be used as a "treasure map" to learn the distribution of plant species in the country and expand conservation areas if necessary.

The first national vegetation resources inventory project, which began in 2003, involved hundreds of people who climbed hundreds of mountains on the island, the officials said. A total of 1.62 million hectares was mapped, with more than 670,000 hectares, or about 41 percent, designated as conservation areas, the Forestry Bureau said.
The map, which will be sold at price of NT$1,200 (US$37), can serve as a reference guide for ecological conservation and national land planning, according to the bureau.

"Just like a treasure map, it can tell us what kinds of plant communities we have and exactly where they are so that we can plan conservation," said Lee Tao- sheng, deputy director-general of the Forestry Bureau.

Up to 67 percent of the native vascular plant species in Taiwan was recorded, and 59 percent of the total area of Taiwan was mapped in the project, according to Hsieh Chang-fu, president of the Taiwan Society of Biodiversity Conservation who headed the project.

One of the most noteworthy findings in the field studies was the discovery of a new habitat of the Taiwan Beech, a rare and valuable endemic plant species, in the mountains of Yilan County in northeastern Taiwan, said Hsieh.
The new beech forest, covering about 35 hectares, was found at the lowest altitude ever for the species, in the Daibai Mountain and Lankan Mountain areas, he added.
Beech forests are mostly found in Europe and the temperate areas of North America, so it was surprising to discover a new growth in subtropical Taiwan, Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Let Them Stay

TEXT.P: Fifty-six exiled Tibetans have been staging a hunger strike outside the central government building in Taipei for more than two days as their visas will expire at the end of this year. Several of them have become so weak they have been taken to hospital.

Some legislators are planning to come up with a proposal demanding that the National Immigration Agency extend their visas for one more year. They have also promised to legislate a refugee act to address relevant issues.

Since Taiwan has signed into law the U.N.-sponsored International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, it should be a matter of course that political refugees are legally allowed to remain on Taiwanese territory.

None of the Tibetans have criminal records in Taiwan and they have no other place to go. If Taiwan expels them, they will become stateless "human balls." Fearing China's possible strong opposition, few countries would be willing to shelter them.
Since they are already in Taiwan, we hope lawmakers and the NIA will find or create a legal basis for them to rebuild their lives and careers in Taiwan.

As China has also signed the U.N. human rights covenant, the government need not consider a possible China backlash while grappling with the Tibetan exiles' visa issue. Human rights know no borders. The government should not let the Tibetans become displaced outcasts.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 16:40:05 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.032 to close at NT$32.380.
A total of US$737 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.430 and slid to a low of NT$32.343.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pregnant women's problems have nothing to do with H1N1 vaccine: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 16:50:22 (By Chen Ching-fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said recent cases of pregnant women losing their babies after being immunized against the influenza (H1N1) virus were unrelated to getting the vaccine, and it urged pregnant women not to fear getting a flu shot.

Liu Ting-ping, who is in charge of the immunization program at the DOH's Centers for Disease Control, said hospitals have notified her agency of five complaints from pregnant women after receiving an H1N1 flu shot.
Two cases involved stillborn babies, two involved miscarriages, and one woman was simply unhappy at getting an H1N1 shot before learning she was pregnant.

DOH Deputy Minister Chang Shan-chwen said that in two of the cases reported in the media, an older woman's baby was stillborn because of an abnormal placeta, and one of the miscarriages was caused by the umbilical chord encircling the fetus.

After studying the two cases, a group of physicians who serve as advisers to the DOH found that neither incident was caused by the new vaccine, Chang said, and he insisted that based on results to date, the immunization program is safe for pregnant women.

"More than 13,000 pregnant women have been immunized. The ratio of miscarriages is lower than for pregnant women who have not taken the shots, and the ratio of stillborn babies is the same for the two groups," he said.
The DOH will continue to monitor the effect of H1N1 vaccines on pregnant women and their babies, he added.

The CDC's Liu said her agency has received 22 applications for redress from people who suffered problems after receiving H1N1 shots. Among them, one was filed by one of five pregnant women reported to the CDC, but her case is still being reviewed.
Of the other 21 applications, three have been screened by a team of medical experts, which found that their conditions had "nothing to do with the new vaccines," according to the DOH's Chang.

The three cases involved an 82-year-old man who died because of acute cerebrovascular disease or a heart attack; a 19-month-old infant whose right eyelid droop was caused by a disease in the immune system; and a senior high school student who became numb on the left side of her body after taking the shot but whose neural functions were found to be normal.
Liu noted that the family members who were not satisfied by the panel's judgment could take legal action to have a forensic examination to help determine the exact cause of death.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices edge higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 17:03:25 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 11.46 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,753.63.
The local bourse opened at 7,690.44 and dipped to a low of 7,688 during the session.
A total of 3.47 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$93.61 billion (US$2.89 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile stocks gaining 1 percent, the most of any category. Cement stocks rose 0.6 percent, construction stocks and paper and pulp issues gained 0.5 percent, and banking and financial issues advanced 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff shares were the only category which lost ground, giving up 0.4 percent, while plastics and chemicals shares remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,604 to 952, with 275 remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net sellers of NT$3.68 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Without gov't help, Taiwan film industry will fail: director
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 17:17:17 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: "Without you, without revival efforts, Taiwan's film industry will be reduced to doing OEM work for the movie industry on the Chinese mainland, " Taiwanese director Leon Dai told the government Thursday in Taipei, during a discussion with a Hollywood director on the limited resources in the local film industry.

The two directors, Dai and John Woo, were invited to discuss film industry issues at a forum attended by government officials, film industry specialists and the media, as part of the program of the 53rd Asian-Pacific Film Festival from Dec. 17-19.

Dai is seen an emerging talent in Taiwan's movie industry, while Woo is an acclaimed Hong Kong director known for his highly choreographed action films in the 1980s and his success in Hollywood in the past decade.
At the forum, Woo praised Dai's Golden Horse Award winner "No Pudeo Visir Sin Ti, " saying that with better commercial packaging it could have done even better at the box office.
In response, Dai said, with open frustration, that the production crew did the best it could, with a budget of NT$4 million, to package the film.
"You cannot expect a film with such a small budget to achieve a box office record of NT$100 million," said Dai.

The gap between Hollywood productions and those of most Taiwanese directors is like the difference between a posh restaurant and a roadside food stand, Dai said, adding that like many Taiwanese directors he must start with the food stand.
Dai lamented that because the traditional Chinese concept of theater is merely one of entertainment, he is doubtful that the country's leaders would make the film industry a key incentive sector.

He urged the government to give adequate support to Taiwan's movie industry to help it avoid the fate of becoming an OEM for China, as is already the case with some traditional manufacturing industries.
He suggested that the government put similar efforts into reviving the movie industry, as it has done for the electronics sector, by providing incentives.

In response, Frank Chen, director of the Government Information Office's (GIO's) Department of Motion Pictures, said that the GIO has mapped out a five-year development plan to provide more incentives to film producers and that a market research institute is being planned.
Citing market research and his experience in the international market, Woo suggested that Taiwan producers try films of various genres.
"If you want to explore the international market, you must be able to find the movie language recognized by audiences of different regions and cultures," he said.

The Taiwan film industry was greatly encouraged last year by the success of the local production "Cape No. 7, " which achieved a box office record of NT$350 million in the domestic market that is generally dominated by Hollywood movies.

On the heels of that success, Dai impressed audiences and the jury of the Golden Horse Film Festival in November with a film based on a true story about an impoverished single father's struggle to retain guardianship of his young daughter.
"No Pudeo Visir Sin Ti, " a NT$4 million production, won four Golden Horse Awards -- best feature film, best director, best original screenplay and most outstanding Taiwanese film of the year.

However, while the awards may help propel his movie career, Dai said, they do not guarantee financial support for his future projects and he still needs to find capital from investors at home and abroad.

"Creativity is one of Taiwan's advantages in the development of its film industry," he said, adding that he expects the government to provide more support to the local film industry to create an original Taiwanese cultural brand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica to honor record number of graduates this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 17:45:55 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top academic institute Academia Sinica will this year honor a record number of nine graduates from its prestigious Taiwan International Graduate Program (TIGP), according to a press statement released Friday.

Liu Chao-han, vice president of Academia Sinica and director of the TIGP, was quoted as saying that he was delighted by the success of this year's graduates, many of whom have taken up positions in leading international institutions such as the College of Veterinary Medicine at Cornell University and the Department of Chemistry at the University of Ottawa in Canada. Others will continue their research as post-doctoral fellows at Academia Sinica, he added.

A total of 45 papers were published by this year's graduating TIGP students in prestigious journals that included PNAS, BMC Bioinformatics, Nucleic Acids Research, BioTechniques, Cell, Journal of Applied Physics, and the Journal of the American Chemical Society, Liu noted.

Launched in 2002 through collaboration between Academia Sinica and Taiwan's top research universities, the TIGP program is touted as integrating the first-class facilities and top-notch faculty at Academia Sinica into a learning environment where English is the first language.
According to the institute, currently there are 307 students enrolled in nine PhD programs in the TIPG and approximately half of the students are from abroad.

One of this year's graduates Ho Cheng-hsun, who recently published a research paper on nitrate sensors in plants in the academic journal Cell, said that the key advantage of the TIGP is its diverse student body.
"The multinational background of the students in TIGP encouraged me to become more competitive on the global stage," Ho was quoted as saying in the press statement.

Another TIGP graduate Su Chia-yu, who has accepted a position as an assistant professor at Taipei Medical University, also praised TIGP's international learning environment, saying that to be eligible for graduation, students must have their papers published in top international journals.
This requirement, she stressed, inspired her to search for research topics that "matter most in the world of science." The certificate award ceremony will be held in Taipei Dec. 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan improving relations with Indonesia

TEXT.P: Taiwan is fast improving relations with Indonesia after an eight-year lag that resulted from the loss of trust between Jakarta and Taipei due mainly to former President Chen Shui-bian's ill-advised diplomatic sally.
That trust is being restored, said Taiwan's top representative to Indonesia Andrew Hsia, who assumed his post as head of Taiwan's Economic and Trade Office in Jakarta, Indonesia two weeks ago.

Relations between Taiwan and Indonesia were on course before Taiwan's former President Chen Shui-bian began adopting "checkbook diplomacy," in which he tried to expand Taiwan's diplomatic activities and overseas visits.

Chen's stopover in the Indonesian island of Batam under the pretext of making his journey more "comfortable" on his way back from his Latin American tour in 2006 was actually politically motivated and had shattered any trust Jakarta had ever had in Taipei.
With the change of government in Taiwan in 2008, relations between the two sides began to change, Hsia told the Central News Agency in an interview.
Since taking up his new post, Hsia has met with Indonesian lawmakers and top government officials for talks on how to promote cultural, educational and economic exchanges between the two countries.
"We have so much to talk about after that long delay," said Hsia, who had previously served as deputy foreign minister.
Hsia succeeded Timothy C. T. Yang, who was recalled to Taipei as foreign minister a little more than a month ago due to a Cabinet reshuffle that occurred in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
Indonesia is one of Taiwan most important trade partners.
In the first three quarters of this year, trade between the two nations totaled US$3.95 billion.
Taiwan's aggregate investments in Indonesia as of the end of September had hit US$13.94 billion, its third highest after China and Vietnam.
"Our foreign direct investment is expected to create at least one million jobs for Indonesians," Hsia said Sunday, speaking in Bali at a conference of Taiwan chambers of commerce in Indonesia.
The conference was held to help the Taiwanese business community learn more about investment potential in Indonesia.
Indonesia needs investment in agriculture, aquaculture and IT (information technology) industries to expedite economic growth and employment, according to Hsia.
"We are helping Indonesia to attract our entrepreneurs," Hsia added.
One of them is Taiwan's CPC petroleum company, which is interested in producing biofuel in Indonesia, Hsia said.

Meanwhile, cultural and educational exchanges are also being promoted. For one thing, Hsia has helped Radio Taiwan International and the Central News Agency sign memorandums of understanding on news exchanges with Indonesia's Antara News Agency.

RTI has a Bahasa Indonesian service for more than 130,000 Indonesian migrant workers in Taiwan. Antara and the CNA will organize photo exhibitions in each other's country as a starter for closer partnership.
"I've received three university presidents from Taiwan, and all of them look forward to student and faculty exchanges with Indonesia," Hsia said.

As the largest member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, with a population of over 200 million, Indonesia must enhance its higher education to train its people to be scientists, engineers, doctors and other professionals, Hsia said.
There is no doubt that Taiwan can be of help to Indonesia in this field, particularly in the training of personnel for medical service, Hsia said.

"Taiwan has top-rate hospitals where more Indonesians may go to get treatment that is unavailable here," Hsia said, adding that the hospitals offer better and cheaper treatment than their counterparts in advanced countries in Asia.

Taiwan's medical service could also greatly boost tourist arrivals from Indonesia, according to Hsia. Hsia's office is Taiwan's busiest consular office abroad. It has a dozen consular officers to handle visa applications from migrant workers from Indonesia. Staff at the office have to take care of the workers as well as an influx of tourists from Taiwan, who keep the China Airlines and EVA Airway as well as Garuda airline of Indonesia busy year round.

All of this will strengthen Taiwan's relations with Indonesia, according to Hsia, who added that Indonesia will play a major role in the emerging free trade zone in Asia, known popularly as Ten-plus-One.
The grouping is made up of the 10 ASEAN members and the People's Republic of China. The new Asian trade bloc comes into being on January 1.

One thing that surprised Hsia most was the popularity in Indonesia of Taiwan's Tzu Chi Foundation. The Buddhist organization made great contributions to the relief of victims of last year's tsunami, which killed thousands of people in Indonesia.
"Indonesians know that and are ever thankful," Hsia said, "but I was truly surprised to find the Da Ai Drama, offered by Da Ai TV, winning an increasingly large number of fans in Indonesia."
Da Ai, which means Great Love, is operated by the Tzu Chi Foundation.
One of the fans is the wife of a deputy minister Hsia met last week.

"She told me she loves the TV series for they are true stories of moving love and friendship," he said, noting that they are not cheap soap opera churned out by commercial TV networks to boost their ratings for advertising income.

The belief among Indonesian people that Taiwan is extending its friendship and assistance to their country the way Tzu Chi is giving its help to the tsunami victims, could make Hsia's challenging work in Jakarta a little easier. (By Joe Hung)

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma hopes Beijing will refrain from obstructing Taiwan NGOs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:15:52 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that Taiwan's non-governmental organizations are still encountering obstacles in their efforts to participate in international activities, due to Beijing's interference.

"There are still incidents of Beijing blocking Taiwan NGOs' representation in the international community, " Ma said during a year-end meeting with heads and executives of the five branches of government over tea.
"This is an issue that the government should strive harder to address," he said.
He said his administration hopes China would turn away from that trend of interference "to avoid giving the Taiwan people a bad impression of Chinese authorities."

The president's comment was seen as an oblique reference to a recent incident in Copenhagen, in which a Chinese official cut in to signal opposition during speeches by Taiwan's diplomatic allies in support of Taiwan's inclusion in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) as an observer.
Ma said that his administration has made strenuous efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions and reduce energy consumption in Taiwan.
He said it is still unclear whether the ongoing meeting of UNFCCC signatories in Copenhagen will reach any operational agreements on climate change and carbon emissions as previously expected.
However, "Taiwan's resolve to further reduce its carbon footprint will not change," he added.

Meanwhile, on the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Ma said that there have been great improvements over the past year, with the two sides having signed nine agreements to improve the everyday lives of the people on both sides.
Four more accords are expected to be signed during the fourth round of high- level cross-strait talks that will be held Dec. 21-23 in Taichung, central Taiwan, he said.
"I hope there will be further stabilization of cross-strait ties so that Taiwan can have an environment in which we can gradually realize our ideals," the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI hopes more national pension insurance enrollees pay premiums
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:28:45 (By Shih Sin-yao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to encourage more individuals eligible for the government-run national pension insurance program to pay premiums so that they can have some financial security when they get older, the vice interior minister said Friday.

A total of 4.1 million people are eligible for the program, a social insurance system covering individuals in the 25-65 age group who are not enrolled in national labor insurance systems for public servants, military personnel, teachers, workers and farmers.

Although all of those eligible are forcibly enrolled in the program, they are free to decide whether or not they want to pay the premium that entitles them to receive a monthly pension after they are 65 years old.

At present, 60 percent of those eligible paid their premiums in 2009 -- a ratio similar to that seen in Japan and South Korea -- but the government hopes to push the ratio higher, said Vice Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang at a conference held by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) to review the pension insurance system.

Chien said more than 1 million people had already benefited from the program since it was put into practice on Oct. 1, 2008, with a total of NT$37.9 billion (US$1.17 billion) being disbursed to the insured.
Around 870,000 of the beneficiaries are senior citizens who were receiving senior citizen pensions under a program that was incorporated into the national pension insurance scheme.

Chan Hou-sheng, a professor in National Taiwan University's Department of Social Work, warned that because most of those under 65 enrolled in the program are economically disadvantaged, the scheme could turn into a "social relief" program if the government fails to increase the number of those eligible who actually pay for the insurance.

At present, the monthly premium for pension insurance costs NT$1,123, with 60 percent of the total, or NT$674, to be paid by the insured and the remaining 40 percent to be picked up by the government.
The government's portion of the bill rises by varying degrees if the insured are physically or mentally challenged or live in poverty.

Chan cautioned that the government's financial burden will grow as more people turn 65 and become eligible to receive monthly stipends, and he suggested that measures be taken to adjust the system by reviewing and collecting data on all of the other existing pension systems in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Integrate Research and Industry

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been strong in scientific and technological research as evidenced in its frequent victories in major world invention competitions and its always prominent rankings in terms of the annual number of patents granted by the United States.
However, Taiwan's efforts in technological research and patent applications have not been complemented with a comparable devotion to turning them into commercial gains.

Take the biotechnology industry. Taiwanese scientists have often managed to have their high-quality research papers published in professional journals, but Taiwan has yet to secure a significant share of the multibillion global pharmaceutical and medical equipment markets.
In the face of this "fault line, " the government should figure out how to integrate scientific and technological research and industrial development.

The best approach would be to pick a person well versed in scientific and technological research to head the government's top economic planning agency -- the Council for Economic Planning and Development -- or name somebody skilled at industrial development planning to serve as a state minister in charge of science and technology affairs.
Only by so doing can we make headway in knowledge-based conomic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Amphibious tour vehicle unveiled in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:35:02 (By Wang Shwu-fen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An amphibious vehicle to be used for sightseeing tours of Kaohsiung City was unveiled Friday ahead of the official launch of commercial service on March 2.

The amphibious vehicle that can travel on both land and water, often referred to as a duck boat, will be offering rides on a trial basis to travel agents interested in trying the service between Sunday and Jan. 21, 2010, Ou Hsiu- ching, a Kaohsiung transportation official, said Friday.
The trial tours will operate for 20 minutes on land and 40 minutes on water to give passengers the best views of Lotus Lake and the surrounding area, according to Ou.

Once the duck boat passes a final check Friday, it will be put into service on water starting next week. But the land tours will only be available once the vehicle is registered and obtains a license, Ou said.
A second round of test runs will be held from Jan. 22 to Feb. 28, with free tickets offered to tourists staying in hotels in the southern port city, Ou said.

Once the service formally begins, the vehicle will conduct six tours per day with a maximum of 30 passengers per tour. Ticket prices will be NT$300 for adults and NT$150 for children, according to Ou.
A second duck boat is being built and is expected to ready next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: Road won't be sealed off despite DPP protests: Taichung official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:42:56 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taichung City government said Friday that a main road leading to the hotel where talks between Taiwan and China are to be held next week will not be sealed off, despite planned protests by the opposition.

Taiwan and China's chief negotiators -- Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will meet Dec. 22 at the Windsor Hotel Taichung to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

The pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has planned a series of protests right before Chen's arrival and during his stay in the central city, including a march and rally Dec. 20 on Jhonggang Road, where the Windsor Hotel is located.

The DPP has accused President Ma Ying-jeou's administration of attempting to formulate under-the-table deals with Beijing by promoting the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between the two sides and will protest the proposed ECFA even though it is not formally on the agenda of this round of talks.
Various demonstrations will also be held on Dec. 21-23 near the hotel.
Worried that the protests could disrupt traffic on the busy road, Taichung Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi visited Chen Ta-chun, chairman of the DPP's Taichung branch office, to negotiate a solution.
Hsiao said in light of the fact that Jhonggang Road is one of the city's most important arteries, the city government is not going to seal it off unless necessary.
He urged the DPP to help respect the flow of traffic so as not to affect the rights of other road users.
Chen, meanwhile, promised that the protests will be conducted in a peaceful manner and will not hamper traffic.
He asked, however, that law-enforcement authorities not overreact to the protests, warning that improper security measures by police could provoke negative sentiments among the protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S. trade talks might not reopen in January: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:47:49 (By Shu-yuan Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Friday that although a senior U.S. Trade official visited Taiwan last week to discuss various economic and trade issues, it is difficult to say whether bilateral trade talks will resume in January on the basis of the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA).

Tim Stratford, Assistant U.S. Trade Representative for China Affairs at the Office of the United States Trade Representative, met last week with MOEA Vice Minister Liang Kuo- hsin to discuss issues related to the possibility of signing a bilateral investment agreement and amending the regulations on U.S. beef imports, an MOEA official said.

Because the U.S. is concerned about the position being taken by the Legislative Yuan on U.S. beef imports, it is difficult to say whether U.S.-Taiwan trade talks would reopen in January, the official said.

The representative group, led by Stratford who is responsible for developing and implementing U.S. trade policy toward China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao and Mongolia, also discussed with Taiwan officials matters such as rice imports, pesticide residues, and standards for fire-proof construction materials, according to the official.

The U.S. hopes Taiwan would follow international standards on building material imports, not just Japanese standards, as sometimes U.S. building materials are rejected under the Japanese standard, the
MOEA official said.
The U.S. may seek to resolve that issue with Taiwan within the framework of the World Trade Organization, the official added.

Since the two countries suspended formal diplomatic ties in 1979, the TIFA talks, agreed to in 1994, have provided a significant official channel for Taiwan-U.S. dialogue on trade and economic issues. However, the talks, which are usually hosted by either side on an annual basis, have been suspended since 2007.

Harry Ho-jen Tseng, director general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) North American Affairs Department, told reporters Thursday that the visit by officials of the U.S. trade representative office last week was meant to pave the way for the next round of TIFA talks.

According to Tseng, a wide range of matters could be discussed in the next round of talks, but agreements on bilateral investment and the avoidance of double taxation are the most pressing matters for the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma hopes cross-strait reconciliation extended to NGOs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 18:56:09 (By Wang Hung-kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed the hope Friday that the present atmosphere of cross-Taiwan Strait reconciliation could be extended to Taiwan's nongovernmental organizations (NGOs).
As tensions with China have eased since his inauguration last year, Ma has repeatedly called for mutual respect and cooperation across the Taiwan Strait instead of engaging in vicious competition.

That has not only helped Taiwan cement its relations with its 23 diplomatic allies, the president said, but also enabled it to take part in the Agreement on Government Procurement under the World Trade Organization and in the World Health Assembly, the decision-making body of the World Health Organization.
In comparison, however, Taiwan's NGO activities around the world still encounter Beijing's pressure and suppression, Ma said.

"NGOs form a major area where both sides of the Taiwan Strait should show respect and cooperation, " Ma said, expressing the hope that Beijing would stop suppressing Taiwan's NGOs so that cross-strait relations can further develop peacefully.

Speaking at a seminar on NGOs' international participation sponsored by the Taipei County government, Ma lauded the performance of Taiwan's NGOs and asked government agencies to make more resources available to help in their development.

Ma noted that organizations such as the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation and the Buddha's Light International Association have set up footholds in foreign countries to provide international assistance.

He also cited the Taiwan Democracy Foundation, which received an international human rights award for the fourth consecutive year in Asia, and the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families and World Vision Taiwan, which have sponsored over 280,000 children at home and abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Promote EITC

TEXT.P: Taiwan has grossed an additional NT$51.1 billion in tax revenues since the introduction of an alternative minimum tax (AMT) in 2006, with NT$38.7 billion coming from corporations and the rest from individuals.

Most of the AMT revenues from individual taxpayers derive from income on stock bonuses given to employees and capital gains from unlisted stock transactions, an indication that the AMT system has to some extent helped make our income tax system more equitable by "taxing the rich more."

According to the 2007 tax data, 4,284 individuals paid the alternative minimum tax. Among them, 343 had an annual net income of over NT$10 million and 828 had an annual net income ranging between NT$5 million and NT$10 million.

Starting next year, overseas income will also be subject to the alternative minimum tax, and the tax's impact on income redistribution will be even more evident. At the very least, wealthy individuals will be discouraged from transmitting assets abroad to evade tax payments.

The introduction of the tax has been lauded as the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration's most impressive achievement in tax reform. It is also regarded as Taiwan's only "tax increase" in decades.

President Ma Ying-jeou's approval rating has plunged to a new low following the ruling Kuomintang's setback in the Dec. 5 local elections. We believe it would help Ma regain voters' hearts and minds if he took a cue from the United States' Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC) system to help the working poor.

The EITC is a refundable income tax credit for low to moderate income working individuals and families. In the U.S., the EITC was originally conceived to help people offset social security taxes. When it exceeds the amount of taxes owed, it results in a refund for the applicant.
Over 93 percent of the respondents to a recent CommonWealth Magazine poll described the growing rich-poor divide in Taiwan as a "serious" problem, the most in the annual survey's history.
If Ma heeds such a concern, he should promote an EITC-like system to deliver on his campaign promise of creating an equitable tax system that will "tax the rich to help the poor."

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to conduct 'minor' Cabinet reshuffle around Dec. 20
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:06:29 (By Yi-fong Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: There will be a "minor" Cabinet reshuffle sometime around Dec. 20, and two-term mayors and magistrates who have performed well will be invited to join the Cabinet when their tenures expire after that date, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

However, they will not necessarily be asked to serve as ministers, or ministers without portfolio, but rather may be assigned to head state-owned enterprises, Wu said in response to reporters' questions at the Ministry of Finance.
The reshuffle would be a minor one, as a new Cabinet was assembled just three months ago, Wu said.

Earlier this month, Wu disclosed that Hsinchu's two-term mayor Lin Junq-tzer was one of those being considered for a seat in the Cabinet. Lin has consistently been at the top of the rankings in surveys on the performance of mayors and magistrates in Taiwan.
The possibility of a Cabinet reshuffle has been at the forefront of discussions since the ruling Kuomintang's less-than-ideal performance in the just- concluded local elections.

The KMT managed to hold on to 12 of the 17 mayor and magistrate seats that were up for grabs in the Dec. 5 local elections, but lost a significant seat in Yilan County and saw its solid support base eroded in several localities.
The last Cabinet reshuffle took place on Sep. 10 amid public criticism of the government's response to the Typhoon Morakot disaster in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Cement acquires major cement producer in southern China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:13:45 (By Wei Shu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Cement Company, Taiwan's leading cement maker, is poised to become a cement giant in southern China after formally acquiring the capacities held by the Hong Kong-based Prosperity Minerals Holding Ltd., a corporate source said Friday.

Taiwan Cement signed a memorandum of understanding on the proposed acquisition deal with PMH in late November and the two firms struck a final agreement Friday on the deal, said Edward Huang, senior vice president of Taiwan Cement.

Under the deal -- signed by the PMH management and Taiwan Cement's Hong Kong subsidiary, TCC International Holdings -- Taiwan Cement will buy out all of the existing five kilns in China owned by Upper Value Investments, a PMH spin-off, at a cost of HK$3.8 billion (around NT$16.634 billion), according to Huang.
The acquisition meant that Taiwan Cement's capacities in China will increase by 16 million metric tons annually.
This is set to boost the company's total cement producing capacity in China to some 43 million tons, up from 27 million tons now.
"It significantly helps us near the target laid by Chairman Leslie Koo that Taiwan Cement's annual output should top 50 million," Huang said.

The deal also echoed a recent remark made by Koo that the company will expand its Chinese operation via collaboration with other enterprises, as the Chinese government has banned the construction of new cement kilns.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Dec. 18

TEXT.P: with H1N1 vaccines 14. Road won't be sealed off despite DPP protests: Taichung official 15. Academia Sinica to honor record number of graudates from its
pretigous program 16. Ma hopes cross-strait reconciliation extended to NGOs
17. Taiwan will have more difficulties without ECFA: Bureau of

Foreign Trade 18. Taiwan-China talks a new start for reaching consensus: MAC 19. Chinese historians clarify misreprentation of Sino-Japanese War 20. Premier to conduct 'minor' Cabinet reshuffle around Dec. 20

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS vice president arrives in Taiwan to arrange meeting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:35:39 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 20-member Chinese delegation, led by Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) Vice President Zheng Lizhong, arrived in Taiwan Friday to make the final arrangements for the meeting between the top cross-strait negotiators of the two sides.

The delegation arrived ahead of ARATS Chairman Chen Yunlin, who will arrive in Taiwan Monday and will hold the fourth round of cross-strait talks with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), from Dec. 22-23 in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

Four pacts on avoidance of double taxation, inspection of agricultural and farm produce, cooperation in the fisheries industry, and industry standards certification are expected to be signed during the meeting, but the two sides will not ink a proposed trade pact on economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party is planning to launch mass anti-China protests and rallies in the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing proposes inclusion of IPR issue in fifth round of talks
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:43:59 (By C. K. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, proposed Friday in Beijing that the issue of intellectual property rights (IPR) be included in the fifth round of cross-Taiwan strait negotiations.

Chen, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said it is time to establish a sound system to protect IPR on both sides of the Taiwan Strait amid increased two-way exchanges and that China is very willing to list the issue in the fifth round of bilateral negotiations.

Many brands from Taiwan, such as Want Want, Giant, President Chain Store and BenQ, are already popular in China, but are just a fraction of the 62,925 Taiwan's trademarks officially registered in China as of September 2009 and they need effective protection, he told the press.
Famous brands of Taiwan's fine-quality farm produce, including tea, fruit, and vegetables, are rampantly pirated in China.

Chen noted that while a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will not be signed in the fourth cross-strait talks, he and his Taiwan counterpart might discuss ECFA-related issues on Dec. 22.

Commenting on the misgivings of some Taiwan businesses about the proposed pact, Chen said Chinese authorities will do their best to address the matters of major concern to Taiwan in a way that would benefit both sides.
Chen is due to arrive Monday in Taichung City, central Taiwan, for the fourth cross-strait talks with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

According to Chen, scores of prominent Chinese entrepreneurs from a wide range of sectors will accompany him to Taiwan and they will explore the possibility of forming joint ventures with Taiwan companies and will try to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's laws and regulations.
Chen said he believes more and more Chinese state and private companies will be willing to make investments in Taiwan.

During their meeting next week, Chen and Chiang are expected to sign four agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County magistrate visits Japan to promote tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:47:07 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan visited Japan recently to meet with Masanori Nishio, the mayor of Changhua's sister city Hakodate in Hokkaido, and promote tourism in the central Taiwan county, a county official said Friday.
During the meeting with Nishio, Cho promised to design Changhua tour packages catering to tourists from Hokkaido to attract more Japanese visitors to the county, according to the official.
The magistrate particularly appealed to Hokkaido golfers who cannot play during the northern island's harsh winters to visit the new course built in Changhua County, which is open year round.
Cho's visit drew considerable coverage from Japanese media, including the Hakodate Shimbun, Hokkaido Shimbun, and local TV stations, the official said.

Cho also visited Aeon LakeTown, Japan's largest eco-shopping center, which opened in Saitama outside of Tokyo in October 2008. He was there to learn how the shopping mall has been able to generate 80 billion Japanese yen (NT$28.72 billion) in sales and attract 45 million visitors over the past year.
The magistrate attributed the mall's success to many factors, including accessibility and an effective marketing strategy that targets customers in various age groups and categories.

The trip also gave Cho the idea of collaborating with the private sector to promote the development of the county's logistics and tourism sectors under build-operate-transfer, build-operate-own or other models to stimulate consumption and expand employment, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to enjoy 4.45 percent economic growth in 2010: think tank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:56:31 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will bounce back to enjoy a growth rate of 4.45 percent in 2010 after weathering the anticipated recession of 2.57 percent this year, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) predicted on Friday.

TRI President Wu Tzai-yi attributed the next year's predicted growth to the gradual global economic recovery that is expected to boost Taiwan's exports, as well as the recovery in local consumer confidence as the country's economic fundamentals regain momentum.
The TRI forecast the quarterly economy in 2010 will grow by 8.48 percent in Q1, 5.53 percent in Q2, 3.59 percent in Q3, and 0.99 percent in Q4.
The Q4 economy in 2009 is forecast to grow 6.76 percent, according to the TRI.
Private consumption will increase 1.82 percent next year, ,thanks to the recovery in the stock and labor markets, and private investment is expected to increase by 7.56 percent, he added.

Other economic research institutes have also predicted growth for Taiwan in 2010, with a growth rate of 4.66 percent forecast by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, 4.57 percent by the Polaris Research Institute, and 4.21 percent by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
The Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecast an economic growth of 4.39 percent next year.

Meanwhile, National Taiwan University mathematics professor Lin Chien-fu suggested the government bring an end to its interest rate lowering policy, explaining that low interests have resulted in a drop in people's banking interest incomes, frustrating private consumption.
The decline has become a big challenge to the country's economic recovery, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Without ECFA, Taiwan could face more difficult situation: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:08:25 (By Hsu Rei-ting and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will face a more difficult situation if the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is not signed, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Friday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, argued that the trade pact would prevent Taiwan from being marginalized in the region after a free trade agreement between China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries takes effect Jan. 1 and similar pacts between ASEAN and other countries in the region are put in place by 2018.

While the economic pact might affect certain industries, Huang said the overall benefits of signing an ECFA with China outweigh its negatives, and he promised that the government will continue to communicate with the public and help companies in vulnerable industries upgrade or transform their operations.

"A lot of decisions need to be made through compromise by many parties. The government will go on with ECFA talks and report regularly to the legislature without sacrificing the interests of certain groups, " pledged Huang, who serves as the MOEA's contact with China's Ministry of Commerce.

Huang was speaking at a public hearing on ECFA's impact on Taiwan held Friday by Democratic Progressive Party legislator Pan Men-an and attended by government officials, scholars and business representatives.

Woo Rhung-jieh, a professor in National Taiwan University's Department of Agricultural Economics, said that based on trade theory, Taiwan's workers will suffer the most if the trade pact is signed because trade liberalization usually leads to a narrowing in price and wage differences between the trade partners.
Taiwan wage rates would therefore fall if a deal with China were signed, Woo contended.

Lee Chung-hang, executive director of the Pingtung Agricultural Development Association, contended that farmers already believe that Taiwan's agricultural sector would suffer a blow if the ECFA is signed.
He accused the government of not clearly explaining to farmers what the trade deal's impact would be, at what level "stop-loss" points would be set, and the direction of future agricultural policies.

Defending the potential deal, Chang Su-san, head of the Council of Agriculture's International Affairs Department, reiterated the government's pledge that the 830 agricultural products that cannot be imported from China at present would continue to be barred under the ECFA.

Also, aside from establishing an information channel on animal and plant diseases, Taiwan and China could discuss how to label agricultural products to avoid infringements of the intellectual property rights of Taiwan's agricultural products.

Wang Liang, director-general of the Ministry of Finance's Department of Customs Administration, said that after the ECFA is signed, the government could introduce anti-dumping or other defensive measures to protect products made in Taiwan.
Taiwan has been pushing for the signing of ECFA, which is aimed at expanding economic and trade cooperation and removing barriers.
Critics have said the deal will allow China to flood Taiwan with cheaper products and threaten Taiwanese businesses, putting many people out of work.
Proponents of the agreement, including President Ma Ying-jeou, have insisted it is necessary to help Taiwan maintain its competitiveness in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth round of Chiang-Chen talks to take place next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:17:37 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) will open their fourth round of talks in Taichung Monday, a day after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launches a large-scale protest.

Led by Taiwan's chief negotiator SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, the negotiations are expected to result in agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Both SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

The three-day meeting, from Dec. 21-23, represents the fourth round of the biannual talks over the past two years since the two organizations resumed discussions in June 2008 after a 13-year hiatus, ending years of tension.

In a press briefing on Thursday, SEF Chairman Chiang said that the nine agreements reached during the past three rounds have benefited Taiwanese businesses by helping them reduce their operating expenses and improving efficiency.

He suggested that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which aims to normalize trade between the two countries and eventually lead to the reduction of tariff barriers, will be on the agenda of the next round of talks, which will be held in China.
Meanwhile, the opposition DPP and more than 10 civil groups are expected to hold a major protest against the ECFA, even though it is not on the agenda of this round of talks.

Lo Chih-cheng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Society, one of the civil groups to participate in the Sunday protest, said his group was against the lack of transparency in the ECFA negotiations and advocated holding a referendum on the proposed trade pact before the start of the negotiation process.
Other smaller scale protests are expected to be held throughout Chen's stay in Taiwan.
Chiang as host of this round of talks, called on the protesters to be peaceful, rational and law-abiding.

The DPP hopes to mobilize 100,000 demonstrators for Sunday's rally, while the Ministry of the Interior plans to mobilize 200 police officers to patrol the negotiating venue in Taichung and a total of 1,000 to share the task of providing security for Chen when he travels outside the venue, according to Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China talks a new start for building consensus at home: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:27:12 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's government agency tasked with handling China affairs expressed hope Friday that consensus can be reached in Taiwanese society over controversial issues arising ahead of Taiwan and China's new round of talks next week.

As the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning rallies against China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin, Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Friday that the government highly respects freedom of speech expressed in a legitimate manner.

Previous similar round of talks in Taipei sparked fierce protests from the DPP and pro-independence activists who accused the government headed by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party of leaning toward China.
Lai urged all sectors within Taiwan to rationally and realistically look at the negotiations between Taiwan and China, while calling for people to back the government's efforts.
She said she hopes that the new round of Taiwan-China talks to be held in Central Taiwan's Taichung City from Dec. 21-23 could be a new starting point for reaching consensus at home.

Taiwan and China used to be long-time political rivals, but they resumed talks aimed at strengthening the two sides' economic cooperation after Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May last year.

Representatives from Taiwan and China in the coming Taichung talks will sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Opponents however will target the government's plans to sign a controversial trade agreement with China, saying it will flood Taiwan with cheaper Chinese products, cause job losses and ultimately hurt Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Staying focused

TEXT.P: The recent controversy surrounding President Ma Ying-jeou's interview with the Wall Street Journal Asia is a typical example of "trivial matters shifting the focus on key policy initiatives" that have often hindered his administration's achievements over its 18 months in power.
In the interview, Ma tried to remind Chinese leaders that political freedom and democracy are crucial to achieving reunification as expected by China.

Ma's actual and complete wording was: "Whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decades, " but the Journal wrote "next decade" -- which triggering criticism from pro-independence groups that Ma was setting a 10-year timetable for unification.
It was not the first time that he has been misquoted by foreign news media. Why have similar situations repeated themselves? It can be attributed to two causes.

One factor lies in Ma's preference to give interviews in English, even when such interviews take place at home. The other is the Presidential Office's customary failure to issue official English transcripts of interviews.
As the head of state, Ma should speak the country's official language while meeting with foreign dignitaries or journalists to express his patriotism and loyalty to the country and avoid misquotes.

Moreover, the Presdiential Office is obliged to issue formal press releases on international media interviews because he is speaking on behalf of the country rather than expressing his personal views.

The Presidential Office should remember that it is obligated to keep the public informed on what the president has said to foreign news media and both the Chinese and English versions of such interviews are official documents and historical records.

DOC.HEADLINE: Communists' role in Sino-Japanese war exaggerated: Chinese historians
DOC.DATELINE: Shandong, China, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:02:12 (By Chang Ming-kun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese historians said Friday that misconceptions on the mainland about the 1937-1945 Sino-Japanese War tend to overemphasize the role of the Chinese Communists in the resistance against the Japanese invasion.
The historians said this view is an exaggeration that is misleading, because the Kuomintang (KMT), which was ruling China at the time, was actually the principal player in the war.

The issue was raised at a conference held in Zaozhuang City, Shandong province to review the history of the Battle of Taierzhuang in 1938, during the Sino- Japanese War, in which the Chinese scored a major victory under the leadership of Li Tsung-jen, supreme commander of the KMT's fifth War Zone.
Some participants at the conference, however, argued that the victory could be credited to collaboration between the KMT and the Chinese Communists to fight the Japanese.

This perception of the battle, which gives credit to the Communists, is common in Chinese TV dramas on the Sino-Chinese War. These dramas often play up the prowess of the Communist troops and depict the KMT soldiers as a band of cowards.
Ma Zhonglian, former curator of the Chinese People's Revolution Military Museum, said it would be too much of a generalization to simply attribute the victory to a KMT-Communist alliance.
If that argument is to be convincing, there must be supporting evidence, Ma said.

Han Xinfu, a research fellow in modern history at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said he disagrees with the idea of accentuating the role of a certain party in the war for political purposes.

Calling for a fair assessment of the war based on facts, Han said the KMT troops were undoubtedly responsible for the victory in the Battle of Taierzhuang, as they were the dominant force in the resistance against the Japanese.
According to Han, there is still a long way to go before Chinese academia can shed its political shackles and fairly judge the contributions of the KMT and the Communists in the war.

Wang Juying, a member of a society that studies the history of the Sino-Japanese War, said the KMT and the Communists should stop denying each other's role in the war and should seek to achieve a more consistent perception on this chapter in history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned architect to bring skills to Changhua County golf course
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:39:31 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A local golf course operator and world renowned Portuguese architect Ivaro Siza signed an agreement recently to create landscape architecture works that will become cultural landmarks in Changhua County, the county's magistrate said Friday.

The agreement was signed last month by Tai Hong Golf Club Chairman Lin Por-shih and Siza, who has won a number of architecture awards, including the Pritzker Prize in 1992, and was named as the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) 's 2009 Royal Gold Medalist.

Siza will design and build structures on the golf course that will merge with their natural surroundings and help commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Republic of China in 2011, according to Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan.
Cho said he believes the structure will help raise the county's visibility and become one of its new landmarks that can attract tourists from home and abroad.

Describing Taiwan as a place that possesses both natural and spiritual beauty, Siza pointed to the county's Lugang old street and the Lungshan Temple as representing local artisans' creations and traditional art forms.
The contemporary architect said he will incorporate some of those traditional art elements into the small hall, resort buildings and other works he will create on the course.
The golf club, established in 1981, is one of several courses built relatively early in central Taiwan and the only one that hosts two international tournaments a year.
The golf club project is just one of many deals clinched by the central county in recent months, with the other including a major transportation project and investment projects, according to Cho.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet mulls tax increases after economy recovers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:49:54 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih has instructed the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to prepare measures in advance to increase taxes so that they can be readily promoted after the country's economy recovers, an official said Friday.
The directive was issued by the premier during a visit to the MOF, according to Deputy Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ford.
Wu believes that despite the government's worsening fiscal difficulties, it is not the right time now to raise taxes now because it could lead to public outrage, Chang said.
Therefore, Wu requested the MOF to take the time to communicate the government's policies to the public before they are implemented, he said.
Also, Chang added, the premier asked the MOF not to give in to any requests for tax cuts too quickly because it could further worsen the fiscal situation.
Wu said he expects the ministry to effectively use and manage state-owned property to increase the government's revenue, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to open landscape plant production park
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:56:57 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government will hold a series of activities on Saturday to mark the opening of a special park zone dedicated to the production of flowers and landscape saplings.

To help publicize flowers grown in the central county, the final round of a flower fairies' beauty pageant and a logo design selection event for the local flower industry will be held in the zone in Sijhou Township, a county official said Friday.
Five flower fairies will be chosen based on their knowledge about the floral industry, creativity, poise, and verbal expression, according to the official.

A contest to select logo designs that represent the characteristics of the county's flowers will also be held, with the winning designs to be used in the future on promotional literature that trumpet locally grown flowers, the official added.
Meanwhile, exhibitions of farm products and saplings will also take place at the park Saturday.

The zone was divided into 87 segments for lease, with each segment covering an area of 1,900-7,000 square meters. So far, 51 segments have been leased for NT$58,438-NT$152,199, according to the official.
More information about the events will be available at the county government's Web site at http://www.chcg.gov.tw/.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT clarifies report on company selling nuclear components to Iran
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 22:52:30 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Friday that a Taiwanese firm reported to have illegally sold components to help Iran with its nuclear program did not breach international rules on the proliferation of nuclear arms.

The bureau said that after a thorough investigation, it was found that the company did not violate international regulations when it sold 108 pressure transducers to Iran in March, because the item was not included on a list of strategic high-tech commodities (SHTC) in Taiwan at the time.
The BOFT has reported the result of its probe to the international body in charge of the issue, bureau officials said.

The investigation came after the London-based Daily Telegraph reported in early December that a Taiwan-based company had sold Iran 100 pressure transducers that the Middle East country could use to enrich uranium to weapons grade.

The report added that the equipment, which it said was banned for sale to Iran by the Nuclear Suppliers Group, was believed to have been originally manufactured in Europe, but then sold to Iran through intermediaries based in Taiwan.

According to the BOFT officials, the Taiwan company imported the 108 pressure transducers from Switzerland and then sold them with MOEA approval to Iran in March, before the world body issued an advisory saying that the item had been listed on the SHTC control list.
The deal at that time did not violate either Taiwan's export regulations or international norms, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to enjoy 4.45 percent economic growth in 2010: think tank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 19:56:31 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will bounce back to enjoy a growth rate of 4.45 percent in 2010 after weathering the anticipated recession of 2.57 percent this year, the Taiwan Research Institute (TRI) predicted on Friday.

TRI President Wu Tzai-yi attributed the next year's predicted growth to the gradual global economic recovery that is expected to boost Taiwan's exports, as well as the recovery in local consumer confidence as the country's economic fundamentals regain momentum.
The TRI forecast the quarterly economy in 2010 will grow by 8.48 percent in Q1, 5.53 percent in Q2, 3.59 percent in Q3, and 0.99 percent in Q4.
The Q4 economy in 2009 is forecast to grow 6.76 percent, according to the TRI.
Private consumption will increase 1.82 percent next year, ,thanks to the recovery in the stock and labor markets, and private investment is expected to increase by 7.56 percent, he added.

Other economic research institutes have also predicted growth for Taiwan in 2010, with a growth rate of 4.66 percent forecast by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, 4.57 percent by the Polaris Research Institute, and 4.21 percent by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
The Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecast an economic growth of 4.39 percent next year.

Meanwhile, National Taiwan University mathematics professor Lin Chien-fu suggested the government bring an end to its interest rate lowering policy, explaining that low interests have resulted in a drop in people's banking interest incomes, frustrating private consumption.
The decline has become a big challenge to the country's economic recovery, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Without ECFA, Taiwan could face more difficult situation: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:08:25 (By Hsu Rei-ting and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy will face a more difficult situation if the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is not signed, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Friday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, argued that the trade pact would prevent Taiwan from being marginalized in the region after a free trade agreement between China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member countries takes effect Jan. 1 and similar pacts between ASEAN and other countries in the region are put in place by 2018.

While the economic pact might affect certain industries, Huang said the overall benefits of signing an ECFA with China outweigh its negatives, and he promised that the government will continue to communicate with the public and help companies in vulnerable industries upgrade or transform their operations.

"A lot of decisions need to be made through compromise by many parties. The government will go on with ECFA talks and report regularly to the legislature without sacrificing the interests of certain groups, " pledged Huang, who serves as the MOEA's contact with China's Ministry of Commerce.

Huang was speaking at a public hearing on ECFA's impact on Taiwan held Friday by Democratic Progressive Party legislator Pan Men-an and attended by government officials, scholars and business representatives.

Woo Rhung-jieh, a professor in National Taiwan University's Department of Agricultural Economics, said that based on trade theory, Taiwan's workers will suffer the most if the trade pact is signed because trade liberalization usually leads to a narrowing in price and wage differences between the trade partners.
Taiwan wage rates would therefore fall if a deal with China were signed, Woo contended.

Lee Chung-hang, executive director of the Pingtung Agricultural Development Association, contended that farmers already believe that Taiwan's agricultural sector would suffer a blow if the ECFA is signed.
He accused the government of not clearly explaining to farmers what the trade deal's impact would be, at what level "stop-loss" points would be set, and the direction of future agricultural policies.

Defending the potential deal, Chang Su-san, head of the Council of Agriculture's International Affairs Department, reiterated the government's pledge that the 830 agricultural products that cannot be imported from China at present would continue to be barred under the ECFA.

Also, aside from establishing an information channel on animal and plant diseases, Taiwan and China could discuss how to label agricultural products to avoid infringements of the intellectual property rights of Taiwan's agricultural products.

Wang Liang, director-general of the Ministry of Finance's Department of Customs Administration, said that after the ECFA is signed, the government could introduce anti-dumping or other defensive measures to protect products made in Taiwan.
Taiwan has been pushing for the signing of ECFA, which is aimed at expanding economic and trade cooperation and removing barriers.
Critics have said the deal will allow China to flood Taiwan with cheaper products and threaten Taiwanese businesses, putting many people out of work.
Proponents of the agreement, including President Ma Ying-jeou, have insisted it is necessary to help Taiwan maintain its competitiveness in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth round of Chiang-Chen talks to take place next week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:17:37 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) will open their fourth round of talks in Taichung Monday, a day after the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) launches a large-scale protest.

Led by Taiwan's chief negotiator SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, ARATS President Chen Yunlin, the negotiations are expected to result in agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Both SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

The three-day meeting, from Dec. 21-23, represents the fourth round of the biannual talks over the past two years since the two organizations resumed discussions in June 2008 after a 13-year hiatus, ending years of tension.

In a press briefing on Thursday, SEF Chairman Chiang said that the nine agreements reached during the past three rounds have benefited Taiwanese businesses by helping them reduce their operating expenses and improving efficiency.

He suggested that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which aims to normalize trade between the two countries and eventually lead to the reduction of tariff barriers, will be on the agenda of the next round of talks, which will be held in China.
Meanwhile, the opposition DPP and more than 10 civil groups are expected to hold a major protest against the ECFA, even though it is not on the agenda of this round of talks.

Lo Chih-cheng, secretary-general of the Taiwan Society, one of the civil groups to participate in the Sunday protest, said his group was against the lack of transparency in the ECFA negotiations and advocated holding a referendum on the proposed trade pact before the start of the negotiation process.
Other smaller scale protests are expected to be held throughout Chen's stay in Taiwan.
Chiang as host of this round of talks, called on the protesters to be peaceful, rational and law-abiding.

The DPP hopes to mobilize 100,000 demonstrators for Sunday's rally, while the Ministry of the Interior plans to mobilize 200 police officers to patrol the negotiating venue in Taichung and a total of 1,000 to share the task of providing security for Chen when he travels outside the venue, according to Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China talks a new start for building consensus at home: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 20:27:12 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The head of Taiwan's government agency tasked with handling China affairs expressed hope Friday that consensus can be reached in Taiwanese society over controversial issues arising ahead of Taiwan and China's new round of talks next week.

As the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is planning rallies against China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin, Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said Friday that the government highly respects freedom of speech expressed in a legitimate manner.

Previous similar round of talks in Taipei sparked fierce protests from the DPP and pro-independence activists who accused the government headed by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) party of leaning toward China.
Lai urged all sectors within Taiwan to rationally and realistically look at the negotiations between Taiwan and China, while calling for people to back the government's efforts.
She said she hopes that the new round of Taiwan-China talks to be held in Central Taiwan's Taichung City from Dec. 21-23 could be a new starting point for reaching consensus at home.

Taiwan and China used to be long-time political rivals, but they resumed talks aimed at strengthening the two sides' economic cooperation after Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May last year.

Representatives from Taiwan and China in the coming Taichung talks will sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

Opponents however will target the government's plans to sign a controversial trade agreement with China, saying it will flood Taiwan with cheaper Chinese products, cause job losses and ultimately hurt Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Staying focused

TEXT.P: The recent controversy surrounding President Ma Ying-jeou's interview with the Wall Street Journal Asia is a typical example of "trivial matters shifting the focus on key policy initiatives" that have often hindered his administration's achievements over its 18 months in power.
In the interview, Ma tried to remind Chinese leaders that political freedom and democracy are crucial to achieving reunification as expected by China.

Ma's actual and complete wording was: "Whether there will be reunification as expected by the mainland side depends very much on what is going to unfold in the next decades, " but the Journal wrote "next decade" -- which triggering criticism from pro-independence groups that Ma was setting a 10-year timetable for unification.
It was not the first time that he has been misquoted by foreign news media. Why have similar situations repeated themselves? It can be attributed to two causes.

One factor lies in Ma's preference to give interviews in English, even when such interviews take place at home. The other is the Presidential Office's customary failure to issue official English transcripts of interviews.
As the head of state, Ma should speak the country's official language while meeting with foreign dignitaries or journalists to express his patriotism and loyalty to the country and avoid misquotes.

Moreover, the Presdiential Office is obliged to issue formal press releases on international media interviews because he is speaking on behalf of the country rather than expressing his personal views.

The Presidential Office should remember that it is obligated to keep the public informed on what the president has said to foreign news media and both the Chinese and English versions of such interviews are official documents and historical records.

DOC.HEADLINE: Communists' role in Sino-Japanese war exaggerated: Chinese historians
DOC.DATELINE: Shandong, China, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:02:12 (By Chang Ming-kun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of Chinese historians said Friday that misconceptions on the mainland about the 1937-1945 Sino-Japanese War tend to overemphasize the role of the Chinese Communists in the resistance against the Japanese invasion.
The historians said this view is an exaggeration that is misleading, because the Kuomintang (KMT), which was ruling China at the time, was actually the principal player in the war.

The issue was raised at a conference held in Zaozhuang City, Shandong province to review the history of the Battle of Taierzhuang in 1938, during the Sino- Japanese War, in which the Chinese scored a major victory under the leadership of Li Tsung-jen, supreme commander of the KMT's fifth War Zone.
Some participants at the conference, however, argued that the victory could be credited to collaboration between the KMT and the Chinese Communists to fight the Japanese.

This perception of the battle, which gives credit to the Communists, is common in Chinese TV dramas on the Sino-Chinese War. These dramas often play up the prowess of the Communist troops and depict the KMT soldiers as a band of cowards.
Ma Zhonglian, former curator of the Chinese People's Revolution Military Museum, said it would be too much of a generalization to simply attribute the victory to a KMT-Communist alliance.
If that argument is to be convincing, there must be supporting evidence, Ma said.
