Han Xinfu, a research fellow in modern history at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, said he disagrees with the idea of accentuating the role of a certain party in the war for political purposes.

Calling for a fair assessment of the war based on facts, Han said the KMT troops were undoubtedly responsible for the victory in the Battle of Taierzhuang, as they were the dominant force in the resistance against the Japanese.
According to Han, there is still a long way to go before Chinese academia can shed its political shackles and fairly judge the contributions of the KMT and the Communists in the war.

Wang Juying, a member of a society that studies the history of the Sino-Japanese War, said the KMT and the Communists should stop denying each other's role in the war and should seek to achieve a more consistent perception on this chapter in history.

DOC.HEADLINE: Renowned architect to bring skills to Changhua County golf course
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:39:31 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A local golf course operator and world renowned Portuguese architect Ivaro Siza signed an agreement recently to create landscape architecture works that will become cultural landmarks in Changhua County, the county's magistrate said Friday.

The agreement was signed last month by Tai Hong Golf Club Chairman Lin Por-shih and Siza, who has won a number of architecture awards, including the Pritzker Prize in 1992, and was named as the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) 's 2009 Royal Gold Medalist.

Siza will design and build structures on the golf course that will merge with their natural surroundings and help commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Republic of China in 2011, according to Changhua County Magistrate Cho Po-yuan.
Cho said he believes the structure will help raise the county's visibility and become one of its new landmarks that can attract tourists from home and abroad.

Describing Taiwan as a place that possesses both natural and spiritual beauty, Siza pointed to the county's Lugang old street and the Lungshan Temple as representing local artisans' creations and traditional art forms.
The contemporary architect said he will incorporate some of those traditional art elements into the small hall, resort buildings and other works he will create on the course.
The golf club, established in 1981, is one of several courses built relatively early in central Taiwan and the only one that hosts two international tournaments a year.
The golf club project is just one of many deals clinched by the central county in recent months, with the other including a major transportation project and investment projects, according to Cho.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet mulls tax increases after economy recovers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:49:54 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih has instructed the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to prepare measures in advance to increase taxes so that they can be readily promoted after the country's economy recovers, an official said Friday.
The directive was issued by the premier during a visit to the MOF, according to Deputy Minister of Finance Chang Sheng-ford.
Wu believes that despite the government's worsening fiscal difficulties, it is not the right time now to raise taxes now because it could lead to public outrage, Chang said.
Therefore, Wu requested the MOF to take the time to communicate the government's policies to the public before they are implemented, he said.
Also, Chang added, the premier asked the MOF not to give in to any requests for tax cuts too quickly because it could further worsen the fiscal situation.
Wu said he expects the ministry to effectively use and manage state-owned property to increase the government's revenue, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to open landscape plant production park
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 21:56:57 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Changhua County government will hold a series of activities on Saturday to mark the opening of a special park zone dedicated to the production of flowers and landscape saplings.

To help publicize flowers grown in the central county, the final round of a flower fairies' beauty pageant and a logo design selection event for the local flower industry will be held in the zone in Sijhou Township, a county official said Friday.
Five flower fairies will be chosen based on their knowledge about the floral industry, creativity, poise, and verbal expression, according to the official.

A contest to select logo designs that represent the characteristics of the county's flowers will also be held, with the winning designs to be used in the future on promotional literature that trumpet locally grown flowers, the official added.
Meanwhile, exhibitions of farm products and saplings will also take place at the park Saturday.

The zone was divided into 87 segments for lease, with each segment covering an area of 1,900-7,000 square meters. So far, 51 segments have been leased for NT$58,438-NT$152,199, according to the official.
More information about the events will be available at the county government's Web site at http://www.chcg.gov.tw/.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT clarifies report on company selling nuclear components to Iran
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/18/09 22:52:30 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said Friday that a Taiwanese firm reported to have illegally sold components to help Iran with its nuclear program did not breach international rules on the proliferation of nuclear arms.

The bureau said that after a thorough investigation, it was found that the company did not violate international regulations when it sold 108 pressure transducers to Iran in March, because the item was not included on a list of strategic high-tech commodities (SHTC) in Taiwan at the time.
The BOFT has reported the result of its probe to the international body in charge of the issue, bureau officials said.

The investigation came after the London-based Daily Telegraph reported in early December that a Taiwan-based company had sold Iran 100 pressure transducers that the Middle East country could use to enrich uranium to weapons grade.

The report added that the equipment, which it said was banned for sale to Iran by the Nuclear Suppliers Group, was believed to have been originally manufactured in Europe, but then sold to Iran through intermediaries based in Taiwan.

According to the BOFT officials, the Taiwan company imported the 108 pressure transducers from Switzerland and then sold them with MOEA approval to Iran in March, before the world body issued an advisory saying that the item had been listed on the SHTC control list.
The deal at that time did not violate either Taiwan's export regulations or international norms, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 19, or the fourth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1036: Chinese poet Su Tung-po is born.
1154: Henry II accedes to the throne of England.
1741: Vitus Bering, the Danish navigator and explorer who in 1728 sailed through the Bering Strait while exploring a route around Siberia to China, dies of scurvy at the age of 60.
1793: French troops under Napoleon Bonaparte capture Toulon.
1842: The United States recognizes the independence of Hawaii.
1932: The third plenary session of the fourth Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the convening of an assembly that will meet regularly and which will give the public a voice in governmental affairs.
1941: Adolf Hitler dismisses his chief of staff and takes personal command of the German army after military setbacks.
1946: War breaks out in Indochina as Ho Chi Minh's troops launch widespread attacks against the French.
1950: General Dwight D. Eisenhower is named by the North Atlantic Council as Supreme Commander for the Allied Powers, Europe.
1965: Charles de Gaulle defeats Francois Mitterand in the French presidential election runoff.
1969: President Apollo Milton Obote of Uganda is shot and injured. He would later be overthrown by the Ugandan army in 1971.
1972: The Apollo 17 spacecraft splashes down on target in the Pacific Ocean, bringing to an end the United States' Apollo program of landing men on the moon.
1980: The States-General of the Netherlands approves the selling of two submarines to the Republic of China.
1984: Britain and mainland China sign an agreement determining the fate of Hong Kong after a 99-year lease of the territory to Britain expires in 1997. The joint declaration signed by British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang spells out the terms for Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty on July 1, 1997.
1985: U.S. Sen. Edward Kennedy announces that he will not run in the 1988 presidential campaign.
1988: Indian Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi visits Beijing.
1990: The first stock exchange on the Chinese mainland opens in Shanghai.
1990: Albanian authorities formally recognize the country's first non-Communist party.
1991: Mikhail Gorbachev resigns as president of the United Soviet Socialist Republic, a country that effectively ceased to exist on Dec. 12 of the same year.
1992: The Kuomintang wins 53.02 percent of the popular vote and the Democratic Progressive Party gets 31.03 percent in the elections for the Second Legislative Yuan.
1996: The ceiling on foreign institutional investments on the Taiwan Stock Exchange is raised from US$400 million to US$600 million.
1997: A Singapore SilkAir Boeing 737-300 airliner crashes near Palembang in Indonesia, killing all 104 people on board.
1997: South Korea's newly elected president, Kim Dae-jung, proposes dialogue with North Korea as a step toward reconciliation.
1999: Chen Shui-bian calls on voters to support the DPP's Chen-Lu ticket in the March 18 presidential election and says he will do what he can to finish off the KMT's "black gold" dealings and to distribute the money held by the KMT to the populace.
1999: Macau is formally handed over to mainland China at midnight after 442 years of Portuguese colonial rule.
2000: Peter Banko, managing director Taiwan and country manager of the Bank of America, is elected as the new president of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei.
2001: ROC Vice President Annette Lu departs for Gambia to attend the inauguration of re-elected Gambian President Yahya Jammeh Dec. 21 on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius: "Read and learn everything, but suspend your judgment on anything of which you are in doubt; for the rest, be careful in what you say: in that way you will give few occasions for men to criticize what you say. Mix with the world and see everything, but keep away and do not meddle with anything that may bring you into trouble; for the rest, be careful in what you do: in that way you will have few occasions for self-reproach."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
World's largest container shipper plans to register in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 15:23:08 (By Wang Shu-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Danish-based Maersk Line, the world's largest container shipper, is planning to have at least one of its vessels registered in Taiwan to get in on the booming direct shipping services across the Taiwan Strait, a Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) official said Saturday.
This will make Maersk the first foreign shipping company to register in the country, according to deputy minister Yeh Kuang-shih.

The cross-strait route, which was inaugurated in December 2008, is open only to Taiwanese and Chinese vessels or foreign-registered vessels owned by Taiwanese or Chinese shippers. Other ships must detour through a third area when sailing between Taiwan and China.
In the year since the direct shipping links were launched, 10 vessels that were previously registered overseas have now been registered in Taiwan by Taiwanese shippers, MOTC data show.
The direct route is highly attractive to shippers because it reduces their travel time and costs considerably.

Compared with the past when a detour was required, a voyage between Keelung and Shanghai is now eight to nine hours faster, and one between Keelung and Fuzhou is 11 to 12 hours faster. Transportation costs, meanwhile, are 15-30 percent less.
MOTC statistics show that between Dec. 15, 2008 and Nov. 20, 2009, a total of 161 ships were permitted by Taiwan to operate the cross-strait route.
During that period, there were 10,533 voyages between Taiwan and China carrying more than 1.22 million standard containers and 22.99 million tons of cargo, the statistics showed.
The cross-strait container volume accounted for 10 percent of Taiwan's total container volume during the period.
The MOTC predicted that cross-strait container volume will increase significantly in 2010 as the world economy gradually recovers from a recession triggered by the global financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau, L.A. TV station in joint venture to promote Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/09 15:34:11 (By C.C. Chiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, in collaboration with cable TV station LA 18 -- the largest Asian language TV station in the United States -- will produce shows on the travels of four Asian American groups in Taiwan to help promote local tourism to United States audiences.

The bureau has invited LA 18 anchors who speak Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese and Filipino to lead the groups to interesting spots around Taiwan early next year, and their tours will be filmed and turned into programs to be aired on the cable station.

Lin Shing-jen, tourism section chief at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Los Angeles, said the campaign hopes to capitalize on the participation of the cable station's celebrities to create a buzz and expose more Asian Americans to Taiwan's natural beauty and its potential as a tourism destination.
LA 18 offers news and other programming in 13 different Asian languages. The Tourism Bureau initially chose four languages based on the number of people that speak them in the Los Angeles area.

The TV station reaches 6.2 million TV equipped households and 2.9 million cable subscribing households in Southern California, entertaining diverse Asian groups in the area, including in Los Angeles, Orange, San Bernardino, Riverside, Ventura and San Diego counties.

Speaking of the different travel habits of the ethnic groups, a TECO official said Korean-speaking tourists would love to visit the sites where popular TV dramas are made, while temple tours would be most attractive for ethnic Vietnamese.

Although a bureau study found that Filipinos in the United States seldom travel overseas, she said the Tourism Bureau will do its best to lure those with financial means on leisure or shopping trips to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry of Transportation promotes railway-bicycle tours
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 15:48:49 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Saturday promoted new tours in the eastern counties of Yilan and Hualien that combine rail travel, cycling and the natural beauty of the region.

"To keep with the government's policy to promote low-carbon green transportation, the packages are aimed at marketing new railway services and cycling paths in the eastern counties, " the MOTC said in a statement.

In collaboration with the East Rift Valley National Scenic Area Administration in Hualien and the Yilan County government, the MOTC packages encourage cyclists to take their bicycles on trains to these two counties where they can take advantage of newly constructed bicycle slopes at railway stations and enjoy scenic cycling paths.
The ministry has also launched buses with bicycle racks in Hualien County to improve transit services for cyclists.
According to the MOTC, it has designed or improved five cycling paths in northern and northeastern Taiwan to provide a friendlier environment for cyclists.
They are the Old Caoling Railway Tunnel in Taipei County, the Dongshan River path in Yilan County, the Liyutan path in Hualien County, and the Guanshan and Shihmen-Changbin paths in Taitung County.

The ministry specifically proposed two routes for bikers, with one going from Yilan County's Dongshan railway station to Pearl Community, Dongshan River Water Park, the National Center for Traditional Arts, Luodong Sports Park, Plum Blossom Lake and back to the train station.
The other route is from the Hualien railway station to Lotus Garden, Mukumugi eco path, Liyutan (Carp Lake), Chisingtan, Nanbin Park and back to the start.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water shortage a national security issue: President
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 16:52:37 (By Garfei Li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With reservoirs in southern Taiwan currently holding 50 percent less water than in years past, President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that the severe water shortage loom and need to be dealt with as a national security issue.

Taiwan suffered from a drought in the first half of the year, Ma said, and water saving measures were about to be implemented when Typhoon Morakot drenched the country in August. But since then, there has been 70 percent less rainfall than past averages, leaving the country vulnerable to water shortages once again.

Because the next rainy season will not come until next May, the water shortage will worsen over the next five to six months and "should be elevated to the level of a national security issue, " Ma said at an anti-drought meeting held at the Presidential Office.
Ma pointed that the government needs to take effective water conservation measures and help people endure the crisis.
Reducing consumption and saving water represent the only real solution, Ma said, because it will be difficult to deliver water from the north to the south or dig wells to increase water supply.
The president said the government's first priority is to solve the pressing issue and then plan for long-term comprehensive measures.
Ma recalled that he was mayor of Taipei City when it encountered a water shortage in March 2002 and said that experience had left him with a lingering fear of a lack of water.
Last week, Premier Wu Den-yih asked the Ministry of Economic Affairs to work out a comprehensive plan to deal with the worsening water shortage.
The Water Resources Agency said early this month that water rationing might be imposed by the end of February if no rain falls from now until next spring.

Taiwan has been affected by a continuing drought since the beginning of this year, except for August, when Morakot hit the country, according to a climate change monitoring center at National Taiwan University.
During the first 10 months of 2009, it rained on only 52 days, some 90 days fewer than the average level, the center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Science park focuses on green energy, biomedical tech development
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 17:04:40 (By Chang Chien-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Hsinchu Science Park, known as Taiwan's "silicon valley, " has targeted the green energy and biomedical sectors as key industries that will propel the park's development over the next 10 years and complement its strength in semiconductors and flat panels.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Park Director-General Yen Tzong-ming expressed confidence in Taiwan's ability to maintain its edge in the global semiconductor and flat panel markets, which he said "will continue to be the park's two major industrial pillars."

Yen attributed that success to the park's ability over its 29-year history to build a complete industrial cluster and cultivate specialized technologies in the semiconductor sector, and now it hopes to do the same in the green energy field as concerns over climate change mount.
In the solar energy sector, for example, upstream producers of solar cell wafer materials and midstream manufacturers of solar cells have already moved into the park, Yen said.

As to light emitting diode (LED) technologies, seen as having huge potential in saving energy used in lighting, production lines in the park have been upgraded from simply making LED chips to the production of ultra bright LED epitaxial wafers.
Efforts are now being made to develop technologies related to long wavelength communication and advanced laser diodes, Yen noted.
He revealed that the park administration plans to position its Tongluo park as an environmental science zone for the planned green energy cluster.

Turning to the biomedical industry, Yen said the administration is planning to develop the Hsinchu Biomedical Science Park, located in Jhubei in northern Hsinchu County, into a cradle of knowledge innovation and cultivation featuring an international-standard medical center and biotech businesses.

It will host factories, a medical center, a center for the development and testing of medical equipment and devices, and an industrial innovation center. Yen said the facilities should be completed by 2015.

The Hsinchu Science Park, the first of its kind in Taiwan, was established on Dec. 15, 1980 to introduce high-tech industries and attract talent to Taiwan, promote the upgrading of Taiwanese industries, balance regional development and drive national economic development.
It is currently comprised of zones in Hsinchu, Jhunan, Tongluo, Longtan, and Yilan and also includes the biomedical science park.
As of Aug. 31, the 451 high-tech companies operating the park employed 128,585 people and had paid-in capital of NT$11.457 trillion.
Park companies generated revenues of NT$524.2 billion between January and August this year, down 28.8 percent from the same period a year ago.

But combined revenue in July and August of NT$166.3 billion was 15.6 percent higher than in the previous two months, an indication that Taiwan's economy was recovering from the severe global slump that hit earlier in the year, the park said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang-Chen talks in the interest of people: ARATS vice president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 17:10:41 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Zheng Lizhong, vice president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , said Saturday that there is no reason to protest against next week's cross-Taiwan Strait talks because they are in the interest of people.

Zheng, who arrived in Taiwan Friday afternoon to prepare for the meeting between the top negotiators of the two sides, later encountered protests from several opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Taichung city councilors, who yelled "one country on each side" in the lobby of the Windsor Hotel where the Chinese delegation will stay and negotiations will be held.

"People can express their opinions, but everything we are going to discuss in the talks are in the interests of the people from the two sides, " Zheng said Saturday morning when asked about the protest. "There is no reason to protest against us."
He later added, "I believe that other Taiwanese should not be like (the protesters)."
After holding a preparatory meeting with Taiwan representatives Saturday morning, Zheng visited nearby Miaoli County -- which may also welcome the ARATS head, who will arrive in Taiwan Monday.

The 20-member delegation, led by Zheng, arrived ahead of ARATS President Chen Yunlin, who will meet for the fourth time with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), from Dec. 22-23 in Taichung City, central Taiwan.

Four pacts, covering the avoidance of double taxation, inspection and quarantine of agricultural produce, fishing crew cooperation, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification, are expected to be signed during the meeting, but the two sides will not ink a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

The DPP has planned a series of protests right before Chen's arrival and during his stay in the central city, including a march and rally Dec. 20 on Jhonggang Road, where the Windsor Hotel is located.

DOC.HEADLINE: Smoking ban helps reduce number of smokers by 300,000: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 17:33:10 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: There are 300,000 fewer people in Taiwan who smoke since the implementation of a smoking ban early this year, which helped create an anti-smoking mood in society, according to a report released Friday by the Department of Health (DOH).

Based on the results of an annual survey on adult smoking behavior, the DOH's Bureau of Health Promotion (BHP) estimated that there were 3.61 million smokers aged 18 or older in Taiwan in 2009, down from 3.93 million in 2008.

The bureau said the findings were consistent with the results of another BHP- commissioned survey conducted by Shih Hsin University between July 2008 and December 2009, which showed that a collective anti-smoking spirit is gradually taking shape.

The BHP survey also found that more than 90 percent of respondents interviewed in December 2009 were aware that under the terms of the ban that took effect Jan. 11, smoking is not allowed in offices manned by three or more people, on public transport, or in indoor areas of most public premises.
That marks a significant increase from July 2008, when fewer than 60 percent of respondents were aware of the ban.
Compared with 2008, the frequency of secondhand smoke exposure, both indoors and outdoors, has also been on the decline, the results revealed.
Secondhand smoke exposure at home, however, has worsened.
While the DOH welcomed the decline in the number of smokers, it acknowledged that the trend was cutting into its revenues.

The DOH had predicted that after the health surcharge on cigarettes was increased from NT$10 per pack of cigarettes to NT$20 in June, revenue from the tax would reach NT$20 billion this year, but only NT$15 billion has been collected so far.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China pact to hit Taiwan investors in Southeast Asia: expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 18:05:11 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese scholar warned Saturday that the signing of a proposed trade pact between Taiwan and China will negatively impact Taiwanese invested businesses in Southeast Asia, notably those in Vietnam.
Taiwan is intent on negotiating an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, which will lay down the principles for more liberalized trade between the two countries in the future.

Chen Ming-chang, dean of the Management Institute in Taipei, told the Central News Agency in a telephone interview that after the pact is inked, some of the Chinese products that had been barred from entering Taiwan would gradually be allowed in, "offering traders in Taiwan another option."
In addition, the signing of the ECFA would make Chinese products that are already allowed into Taiwan more competitive, he pointed out.

"As the tariffs (on Chinese goods) will drop, Chinese goods will be quite attractive to Taiwanese traders, " he said, referring to products in conventional industries, such as shoes, umbrellas, towels and clothes.

That would deliver a blow to Taiwanese-invested companies in Southeast Asia, and "particularly those in Vietnam, " where there are a great many Taiwanese investors and major Taiwanese companies, Chen contended.

The warning came as many Taiwanese manufacturers that had been active in China have relocated to Vietnam and elsewhere in Southeast Asia following China's implementation of a labor law from the start of last year, which raised labor costs.

The influx of Taiwanese investment in Vietnam, however, has led to the demand for labor outstripping supply, prompting workers there to ask for higher wages, according to Chen, who served as an economic official with the Mainland Affairs Council in the 1990s.
The growing number of strikes and the lack of adequate infrastructure in the Southeast Asian country are now actually discouraging some companies from moving there, Chen observed.
Taiwan was the largest foreign investor in Vietnam between 1988 and 2009, with investment exceeding US$21 billion, according to Vietnam's economic and cultural office in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Rallying for Survival
DOC.DATELINE: Civil groups and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 12/19/09 18:38:26

TEXT.P: will stage a series of protests as Taiwan and China hold talks in Taichung next week, with a large scale protest march on the streets Sunday set to launch the mobilization.

We want to stress the righteousness of the rallies, as the people are applying their constitutional rights of freedom of speech and assembly to protest the nation's deteriorating economy and endangered sovereignty.

The administration of Ma Ying-jeou claimed that its leaning toward China could help revive the economy and bring peace. However, while none of these have been achieved, the nation's sovereignty has been weakened.

Taking the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China as an example, while the Ma administration suggests that with the signing of such an agreement, it is expected that China will not voice its objection when other countries negotiate free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan. But China has openly declared that it will not give way on this matter since FTAs are agreements between sovereign countries.

From the experiences of other countries, the signing of FTAs remains an economic as well as political issue. The resistance reflected in Taiwanese society can be used by Taiwan as leverage in the negotiations. While the government fails to take the advice from the people, there is no other way but to take to the streets to make a show of protest.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Fickle Opinion Polls
DOC.DATELINE: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 12/19/09 18:40:53

TEXT.P: will mobilize large rallies to protest upcoming talks between Taiwan and China to be held in Taichung. In addition to a large scale protest on the streets Sunday, the party plans to stage large rallies of up to 10,000 people every day during the negotiations.

Taichung Mayor Jason Hu has time and again asked the protesters to be rational and not cause harm to the city, recalling the protest at Yuanshan in Taipei City last year, which turned into a violent confrontation when similar talks were held last year.

According to an opinion poll conducted by the China Times, 53 percent of respondents did not agree with the DPP's plan to stage protests at this time. DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said, however, that she would only accept the result of a DPP opinion poll, which found that 49 percent of respondents backed the DPP plan to take to the streets to voice their appeals.
We do not know how the DPP conducted its poll.
But we would like to remind Tsai that after the incident at Yuanshan, the Kuomintang's support rating did not go up, and support for the DPP and its chairwoman Tsai also remained low.
Taiwan is not a country which will tolerate violence. No one in this country will ask for confrontation. This is the simplest truth.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily: Two tigers: Ma Ying-jeou and Chen Shui-bian

TEXT.P: The detained Chen Shui-bian said from prison that he and Ma Ying-jeou were both born in the Year of the Tiger and that the conflict between the two "tigers" would destabilize the whole nation.

As a matter of fact, Ma and Chen in many aspects represent two extremes -- while Chen is among the few who do not follow regulations or respect discipline, Ma is a rare case who is confined by regulations and discipline.

Judging the two from their perceptions of family values and management of money, Chen has shown an aggressive, plundering and forward nature, while Ma can be characterized as conservative, reserved, and even timid.
Chen's impudent personality has eventually led to disaster, but Ma's overcautiousness has also been faulted for self-confinement.

DOC.HEADLINE: Despite slump, Taiwan sees record number in foreign visitors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 18:50:59 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has seen significant growth in the number of foreign visitors this year despite a decline in international tourism caused by the global economic slump and the spread of the H1N1 flu virus, the Tourism Bureau said Saturday.

Boosted by the Tourism Bureau's global management strategy and diversified marketing approaches, the number of foreign visitors to Taiwan broke the 4 million barrier for the first time in its history on Dec. 5.
Total arrivals are expected to grow to 4.2 million by the end of the year, about 10 percent more than the 3.85 million foreign visitors who came to Taiwan in 2008, the bureau said in a statement.

Taiwan is one of the few countries in Asia that will post growth in foreign arrivals this year, the bureau said, citing the United Nations' World Tourism Organization, which estimated that global tourist numbers would fall 4-6 percent in 2009.

As of August 2009, only Taiwan (11.63 percent) , South Korea (14.88 percent) and Malaysia (4.41 percent) had recorded gains among Asian countries in foreign arrivals for the year, the U.N. tourism body reported.
In contrast, visitor numbers to Japan, Thailand, and Singapore had fallen by 25.34 percent, 12.39 percent and 9.22 percent respectively, according to the U.N. tourism body's figures.
"The most important goal in promoting Taiwan's tourism is to put the country on the international tourism map, " Taiwan's Tourism Bureau said in its statement.
"Once we adopted customized marketing strategies for tourists from different markets, we started to see good results, " the statement added.
According to the Tourism Bureau, Taiwan drew 3,945,198 foreign visitors between January and November, a 12.94 percent increase compared to the same period last year.
Among them, a record 2.03 million, or 51 percent, were tourists, a 28.46 percent rise from the first 11 months of 2008, the bureau said.
Breaking down the tourist figures, European tourist arrivals grew 18.27 percent year-on-year, the fifth consecutive year of positive growth.

Also, arrivals from Hong Kong have risen by 26.70 percent, from the United States by 4.99 percent, from New Zealand and Australia by 5.46 percent, and from Malaysia by 6.88 percent in 2009, the statement said.

Taiwan previously placed little emphasis on developing its tourism industry but has recognized in recent years that its natural beauty and cultural assets could be attractive to tourists and has more aggressively promoted the sector.
It has invested NT$1 billion (US$30.9 million) to boost foreign tourist arrivals as part of its "Tour Taiwan Years 2008-2009" program that kicked off Feb. 15, 2008.

Much of the growth in overseas tourist numbers has been due to visitors from China, who were allowed to come to Taiwan in large numbers for the first time last year. Expanded direct flights between Taiwan and China this year have also boosted arrival numbers.

Noting that a total of 880,000 Chinese have visited Taiwan between July 2008, when the opening to Chinese tourists began, and November 2009, the Tourism Bureau said it is optimistic about the future of cross-Taiwan Strait tourism, because Taiwan has done a much better job in attracting Chinese tourists than other Asian countries.

It took Japan five years to draw 650,000 Chinese tourists, seven years for South Korea to draw 700,000, 18 years for Malaysia to attract 680,000, and 10 and 12 years, respectively, for Thailand and Singapore to draw 600,000, the bureau said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's animation industry eyes Chinese market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 19:25:27 (By Anita Pan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Representatives of Taiwan's animation and comics industry called for more government assistance Saturday to help them break into the vast Chinese market.

Of the approximately 100 animation and comics companies in Taiwan, only 22 percent have paid-in capital of NT$30 million or above, Dan Yu-li, president of the Animation and Comic Creative Association, said at an industry seminar held in Taipei.

That means that most of the companies in the sector are operating with very limited resources and require more guidance from the government in training talent, devising marketing strategies, and raising capital, Dan said.

According to the Institute for Information Industry (III), one of the organizers of the seminar, China's animation and comics market, worth 100 billion Chinese yuan a year, offers a great opportunity for Taiwan, especially in light of the gaping shortage of animated products on the mainland.
In 2008, domestic animation makers in China produced 249 animated films with total running time of 131,000 minutes, which accounted for only 4.49 percent of total demand for the year, the III said.

Wu Chu, CEO of Taiwan-based Yaox Edutainment Co., which has been operating in China for 10 years, said in addition to reputation, branding and local connections, the most important requirement for animated filmmakers to survive in China is to control the channels of distribution.
Yaox, for example, has succeeded in gaining access to China's domestic market by building and operating its own theaters, Wu said.
With Yaox becoming an increasingly prominent brand in China, the company has won the contracts to design and operate the China Pavilion and Taiwan Pavilion at the World Expo 2010 Shanghai, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, U.S. stepping up fishery cooperation: official
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 18 (CNA) 12/19/09 19:31:28 (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and the United States have markedly improved their fishery cooperation in recent years, and thanks to U.S. assistance, Taiwan succeeded in joining a new fisheries management body last month, Fisheries Agency Director-General James Sha said Friday.

Sha, who is visiting the U.S. capital, said that through U.S.-Taiwan cooperation over the years, Taiwan has been able to join many international fishing management organizations as a "fishing entity."

Its latest success, achieved with the help of the United States and other friends such as the European Union, New Zealand and Australia, was to join the South Pacific Regional Fisheries Management Organization (SPRFMO) as a "fishing entity" under the name "Chinese Taipei."

The organization was created in Auckland, New Zealand, on Nov. 14, 2009, following the 8th round of international consultations on the group's establishment, during which the Convention on the Conservation and Management of High Seas Fishery Resources in the South Pacific Ocean was adopted.

Once the convention takes effect, there will no longer be gaps in the international conservation and management of non-highly migratory fisheries and the protection of biodiversity from the eastern part of the southern Indian Ocean across the Pacific to the exclusive economic zones (EEZs) of South America.
Concrete cooperation between Taiwan and the United States has also been seen in substantive fishing operations, evidenced by several bilateral joint ventures that have been formed, Sha explained.
For instance, Taiwan-U.S joint venture fishing vessels now form the bulk of the U.S. fleet operating in the western and central Pacific Ocean, he noted.
Taiwan, as a major global fishing power, has actively sought to enter international fishery resources conservation and management organizations for many years, he added
The country has been a member of the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission since 2005, and it plans to join the Inter-American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA could help revive local film industry: report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 19:59:59 (By Yung-chieh Chou and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The signing of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will benefit Taiwan's film industry by facilitating cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation and providing a broader market for local filmmakers, a Legislative Yuan report has concluded.

A report released Saturday by the Legislative Research Bureau (LRB) argued that China is the biggest market in the Greater China region and therefore Taiwan and China should cooperate more on producing major motion pictures.
Signing the economic pact with China could bring more opportunities for Taiwan's filmmakers to obtain co-production rights and broadcasting rights in China, the report said.
It argued that cross-border reciprocal investment is a trend among international film industries because it can lower risk and expand markets and said the big China market should not be ignored.

The LRB mentioned that the closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) between Hong Kong and China, signed in 2003, has helped open up the Chinese market to Hong Kong's movie industry and give Hong Kong's directors more space to create movies.
Taiwanese director Leon Dai, a Golden Horse Award winner, said Thursday at a forum that the government needs to put effort into reviving Taiwan's film industry.
Dai said it would be too late to do so three to five years from now, when China's film industry becomes more stable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yeh Ming-shun memorial ceremony draws leading politicians
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 20:07:38 (By Lin Si-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A solemn memorial ceremony for legendary journalist Yeh Ming-hsun, was held Saturday and attended by many leading politicians and journalists, including President Ma Ying-jeou.
Ma presented a state citation during the ceremony in recognition of Yeh's contribution to the development of journalism in Taiwan.

Also participating in the ceremony were Vice President Vincent Siew, Kuomintang (KMT) honorary Chairman Lien Chan, former Premier Hau Pei-tsun and Central News Agency (CNA) Chairman Joe Hung, as well as Yeh's widow, son and three daughters.
Yeh passed away on Nov. 21 at the age of 96.

Born in 1913 in China's Fujian Province, Yeh was the first correspondent dispatched by CNA in China to Taiwan in 1945. In that same year, he was tasked in Taipei to take over the office of Domei Tsushinsha, the official news agency of the Empire of Japan.

Yeh served as president of CNA's Taipei branch until 1950, when the agency moved its headquarters to Taipei. In the following year, he began his career in newspapers as president of the KMT-owned Chunghwa Daily.

From 1959 to 1965 he served as the president of the Independence Evening Post, and after working in television and setting up one of Taiwan's most important advertising agencies in the following decades. He returned to the newspaper business as acting chairman of the Taiwan Shin Sheng Daily News between 1998 and 1999.

In the late 1950s, Yeh and Cheng She-wo jointly established the Shih Hsin School of Journalism -- the predecessor of Shin Hsin University (SHU) -- and he served as vice president of the school in 1966 and then as chairman of the university between 1991 and 2006.

He was also named by the government in 1990 as one of the members of a special task force in charge of investigating the 228 Incident, also known as the 228 Massacre -- an anti-government uprising in Taiwan that began on Feb. 27, 1947 and was violently suppressed by the KMT government.
Regarded as a legendary figure in Taiwan's journalistic circles, Yeh was awarded an honorary doctorate by SHU in 2008.
SHU President Lai Ting-ming said in a documentary film on Yeh's life, broadcast at the memorial ceremony, that "Yeh never really rested until falling down."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-China legal assistance cases outnumber Taiwan-U.S. cases
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 21:05:59 (By Ann Chi-shen, Lin Shen-hsu and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: There have been 47 times more requests for legal assistance between Taiwan and China in the five months after a mutual assistance pact took effect in June than between Taiwan and the United States in seven years, according to government figures.

Taiwan and China asked each other for help 3,452 times between June 25 and Nov. 30, compared to only 73 cases between Taiwan and the United States over the past seven years, according to the latest figures obtained by the Central News Agency from the Ministry of Justice.
Mutual legal assistance cases cover repatriating criminals, collecting evidence, exchanging intelligence, and sending alerts on major events.

Of the above cases, 93 were requests to repatriate wanted persons, 243 were to exchange intelligence, 61 were for investigations and collecting evidence, 64 were for picking up criminals returned by either side, 264 were for sending important alerts, 22 were for exchanging ideas on specialized fields, and 2,705 were related to the delivery of legal documents.
The exchange of requests was made possible after the two countries signed an agreement on crime fighting and mutual legal assistance during talks in April 2009.

Despite the agreement, however, China has failed to hand over most of the wanted Taiwanese fugitives who are living on its soil, many of whom have committed major economic crimes, a ministry official said on condition of anonymity.

The official said Chinese authorities are willing to hunt down criminal offenders and repatriate them, because they may hook up with local gangsters in China and commit more crimes there, but many economic criminals avoid arrest by keeping a low profile or exerting political or financial influence.
The same goes for the U.S., where no major Taiwanese economic criminal has been repatriated so far, the official said.

The source said Chinese officials told their Taiwanese counterparts after the pact took effect that nabbing economic criminals would have a major adverse impact on the economies of Taiwan and China as such arrests might create a panic among Taiwanese-invested businesses.

The official said he is hoping for further development in Taiwan-China cooperation in this area, saying it would create a new milestone if judicial authorities on either side was allowed to conduct investigations on each other's territories in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day V News digest of local media V Cross-strait

TEXT.P: An agreement on cross-strait taxation is expected to be signed during the fourth round of negotiations between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the coming week. Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said the agreement will help protect Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, lowering the burden of taxpayers and increasing the government's tax revenues.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue: China Times:

While four agreements are expected to be signed during the Chiang-Chen negotiations next week, some Taiwanese businessmen believe that the signing of a cross-strait investment protection agreement should have been the priority, and it is regretful that the negotiation of such an agreement was not included.

Vice Economics Minister Lin Sheng-chung said that although an investment protection agreement will not be included in the fourth round of the Chen-Chiang negotiations, it doesn't mean that it will be excluded in future negotiations. As long as the policy of opening Chinese investment in Taiwan is effectively implemented, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will make the discussion of an investment protection agreement one of the priorities on the agenda of the next round of talks.

Lin pointed out that no discussion on an investment protection agreement has been held, because up to date cross-strait investment has remained unbalanced, with far more Taiwanese investment in China than vice versa. Economic Daily News:

Finance Minister Lee Sush-der emphasized that the cross-strait taxation agreement will be signed next week based on the principles of equality, reciprocity, and mutual benefit and the safeguarding of Taiwanese businessmen's rights and welfare.

Lee maintained that the more a country relies on trade, the more it needs to conclude taxation agreements with other countries. By signing a cross-strait taxation agreement, it is expected Taiwan will be able to conclude such agreements with more countries, thus improving its competitiveness in international trade, he added.

Meanwhile, Israel became the 17th country to have signed a taxation agreement with Taiwan by signing a bilateral double taxation avoidance agreement on Dec. 18, Lee said, adding that there are three similar agreements still under negotiation. Liberty Times:

As a cross-strait taxation agreement is expected to be signed during the fourth round Chiang-Chen negotiations next week, some Taiwanese businessmen are worried that they will be prodded for their tax records.

Finance Minister Lee Sush-der has suggested that signing taxation agreements with other countries would help improve Taiwan's competitiveness in international trade, and he didn't think local businessmen should worry about being harassed over taxation.

However, Professor Norman Yin of National Chengchi University said that the concerns of the Taiwanese businessmen should be noted. He suggested that before signing the agreement, the negotiators must clarify its content and make known that the agreement is specifically for the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gap between Taiwan, South Korea doubled in 'the lost decade': scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 21:17:10 (By Chen Yun-hsiuan and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The gap in exports and average wages between Taiwan and South Korea doubled over the past 10 years, reflecting the country's loss of competitiveness during the "lost decade, " a former government official said Saturday at a forum on Taiwan and South Korea.

Chu Yun-peng, a former minister without portfolio and now a professor in National Central University's (NCU's) Department of Economics, said Taiwan has fallen behind South Korea in a number of economic indicators because of a "lost decade" that resulted from the government's politically oriented decision making starting in the mid-1990s.
In 1993, Taiwan exported more than South Korea, but in June 2009, Taiwan exported US$16.95 billion in goods compared to South Korea's 33 billion, Chu said.
Moreover, in 2007, South Korea's average wage in the manufacturing sector was US$18.4 per hour, more than double the US$8.2 per hour in Taiwan.

Chu argued that the gap was still too big even after taking inflation into account, not to mention that over the past 10 years, the average starting monthly salary for first-time workers in Taiwan has stagnated at the same level.

Another difference between the two countries lies in the fact that while South Korea had two brands -- Samsung and Hyundai -- ranked among the world's top 100 brands by Business Week in 2008, no Taiwanese companies made it onto the list, Chu said.

After a free trade agreement (FTA) between China and member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) takes effect Jan. 1, 2010, Taiwanese companies will be at an even greater competitive disadvantage because 95 percent of the products manufactured by ASEAN countries will be allowed into China duty free, Chu said.
South Korea and Japan have also started FTAs negotiations with many other countries, which would also seriously impact Taiwan's trade competitiveness, he added.

"However, this urgent situation has not created a sense of unity in Taiwan, " said Chu, referring to the controversy over the signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Taiwan has been pushing for the signing of ECFA, which is aimed at expanding economic and trade cooperation and removing barriers.

Critics have said the deal will allow China to flood Taiwan with cheaper products and threaten Taiwanese businesses, putting many people out of work, while proponents of the agreement, including President Ma Ying-jeou, have insisted it is necessary to help Taiwan maintain its competitiveness in the region.

Chu argued that instead of taking ECFA as a "cure-all, " Taiwanese companies have to develop their brand names and key technologies to ensure profitability and continue to develop the service sector to improve the employment situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Desilting plan for southern reservoirs proposed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 21:24:54 (By M.C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: To address the growing specter of water shortages, particularly in southern Taiwan, the government has decided to earmark NT$34 billion (US$1.05 billion) to dredge two reservoirs in Tainan and Chiayi counties, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said Saturday.

The decision was made after President Ma Ying-jeou called an anti-drought meeting earlier the same day at the Presidential Office with Vice President Vincent Siew, Premier Wu Den-yih and others in attendance.

While Ma described the mounting water crisis as a national security issue and demanded a national campaign to counter the worsening situation, Siew called for setting up a sound system to deal with such problems over the long term in view of the growing impact of global warming, according to Su.
Su said the government will allocate NT$26 billion to desilt the Tsengwen Reservoir over the next six years and NT$8 billion to clean the Nanhua Reservoir.
Tsengwen reservoir, Taiwan's largest, is in Chiayi County, while Nanhua Reservoir is in Tainan County. Both supply water to residents in Tainan and Kaohsiung counties.
After Typhoon Morakot hit southern Taiwan in August, the two reservoirs suffered major buildups of sand, mud and driftwood.
Since then, no rain has fallen in southern Tainan and the two reservoirs have not collected any more water, exacerbating the threat of water shortages.

At current levels of reserves, tap water for households in southern Taiwan will only last until next March or April. In northern Taiwan, there is enough water to last into May if water for agricultural use is suspended for the first harvest next spring, Su quoted Wu as saying.

In line with a central government water rationing plan, the Chianan irrigation association announced earlier this month that some 18,000 hectares of rice paddies in the Chianan area of Chiayi and Tainan counties will be left fallow for the first harvest next year due to the emerging drought.
According to experts, not much help can be expected early next year, with the rainfall forecast noticeably lower than previous averages for the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Pan-green' alliance highlights "peace" for planned protest march
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 21:35:40 (By Sophia Yeh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The "pan-green" alliance headed by Taiwan's largest opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reiterated Saturday that its planned protest march and rally Sunday in central Taiwan's Taichung City will be held in a peaceful manner.
The DPP will "uphold the principles of rationality, peace and non-violence" in carrying out the "Break the Black Box, Protect our Rice Bowl" protest, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said.
He also expressed confidence that 100,000 people would participate in the march "if the weather is not too wet and cold."
Temperatures are expected to drop to 9-12 degrees Celsius in Taichung late Saturday and climb to 10-16 degrees Sunday, the Central Weather Bureau forecast.
DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen and most party heavyweights, including former Vice President Annette Lu, former Premier Su Tseng-chang and former Premier Frank Hsieh, will join Sunday's march.

The DPP has accused President Ma Ying-jeou's administration of negotiating an economic cooperation framework agreement with China without any transparency and believes the deal would hurt Taiwan's economy.
It has therefore organized a series of protests even though the issue has not been formally placed on the agenda of talks between Taiwan and China to be held this coming week.

Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin will meet on Dec. 22 to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
In 2008 when Chen was in Taipei City for the second round of cross-strait talks, bloody squabbles erupted between policemen and DPP supporters.
Other planned demonstrations will be held Dec. 21-23 during Chen's stay in Taiwan. Chen will arrive in Taichung Dec. 21 and spend five days here before flying back to Beijing Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strong quake rocks Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 22:02:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Richter scale 6.8 earthquake shook Taiwan at around 9: 02 p.m. Saturday night, jolting buildings around the island, the Central Weather Bureau reported.
The epicenter of the quake occurred off the coast of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, approximately 25 kilometers southeast of Hualien City. It struck at a depth of 46 kilometers, the bureau said.
The earthquake lasted for about 20 seconds, according to the weather station in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
Initial reports said some residents of Hualien County were injured by falling rocks during the temblor.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP secretary-general advises Chen Yunlin not to travel around
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 22:04:10 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan suggested Saturday that Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), must not travel around while in Taiwan to avoid giving the impression of "conducting an inspection," which could be provocative.
Chen had previously expressed his desire to visit some victims of Typhoon Morakot while in Taiwan, but it remains unclear if any such trip has been arranged or if Su's advice will be taken.

Accompanied by party officials from the DPP's branches in Taichung City and Taichung County, Su called on Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to discuss issues related to security and public order during the ARATS president's negotiations with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation, from Dec. 21-23 in Taichung.

The DPP and some civil groups have mobilized their followers to launch a large- scale rally in Taichung Sunday and other protest activities on the following days to express their appeal for transparency in cross-strait negotiations.
Su told the Taichung mayor that the DPP will not be involved in any "sabotaging" behavior.

Over the past few days, Hu has repeatedly called on the DPP to prevent a repeat of the violent confrontation between protesters and the police that occurred last year during the second round of Chiang-Chen negotiations in Taipei.
He has also cautioned policemen not to overreact when facing the protesting crowds.

Expressing confidence in the mayor's wisdom to manage the situation, Su said the DPP, for its part, has set up a command center in Taichung City and party officials on duty will maintain communications with the city government to reduce the possibility of confrontation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defendant may refuse night interrogation starting Jan. 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 22:34:39 (By Lai Yo-chia, Ann Chih-hsian and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A recently promulgated amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, to take effect Jan. 1, will better protect the human rights of defendants or arrested suspects because it empowers them to refuse to attend detention hearings after 11 p.m.

The amendment to Article 93 of the Criminal Procedure Law stipulates that when the court begins deliberations late at night on a request to detain a suspect or defendant that is filed after 11 p.m., a party, lawyer or representative may ask the court to postpone the hearing until the next morning.
The court cannot deny the defendant's request without proper reasons and should provide the defendant a proper place to rest, it adds.
According to existing regulations, defendants must be interrogated immediately whenever the court decides to proceed with a detention request.

This often results in a situation where the defendant, who might already be worn out after being interrogated by the police, investigation bureaus and prosecutors, still has to appear in court overnight.
Earlier in the year, the Judicial Yuan requested all courts to set up waiting rooms with bedding, a pillow, and disposable bathroom kits for defendants and to provide them with breakfast.

"Although most defendants will choose to get the interrogation over with as soon as possible, and the trial waiting rooms might not be used as often, we still have to ask all the courts to have such rooms based the need to protect human rights, " said Hsieh Wen-ting, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan.

According to Hsieh, the newly renovated trial waiting chambers at the Taiwan Taipei District Court, for instance, are properly furnished similar to budget hotels. He said the court will display the rooms before the end of the year

Meanwhile, also as part of the efforts to better protect the defendant's rights, the Taipei district court has specific regulations that require alarms and monitoring equipment to be installed in the trial waiting rooms and that the recordings be preserved for six months.

Should the defendant feel ill and need medical attention, he will be admitted into Taipei City Hospital's Heping Branch, and the judicial police will have to record the entire process and report to the courts on a regular basis by radio, according to the regulations.

Noting that the Taipei district court held a drill last week regarding related procedures, Huang Chun-ming, a presiding judge at the Taipei district court, said footage of the defendant when he or she is in the bathroom will be blurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Our voice will be loud, our action will be peaceful': DPP chairwoman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 22:37:19 (By Tsai Su-ping and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen reiterated Saturday that Sunday's planned protest in Taichung against the government's China policy will be peaceful.
"Our voice will be loud, our action will be peaceful, " she said on the eve of the protest to be held ahead of negotiations between Taiwan and China in the central city this coming week.

Tsai was attending a fund-raiser held by the Taiwanese Professors' Association in Taipei when she was asked by reporters about the DPP's mobilization of the protest against the fourth round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , to be held in Taichung from Dec. 21-23.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins big in Asia Pacific Film Festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 23:31:22 (By Angela Tsai, Emmanuelle Tseng and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Film Festival took to the stage in southern Taiwan Saturday after a two-year hiatus, with Taiwan taking home five awards, including those for best director and best actress.
Taiwanese filmmaker Leon Dai won the best director award for his film No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti, which was a five-time winner at this year's Golden Horse Awards, Taiwan's version of the Oscars.
Chang Hsiang-yu, who had never before helped produce a film, won the best cinematography award for his work on Dai's film. It was also the first award that Taiwan won on the night.

The best documentary award went to Baseball Boy, a Taiwanese film that has been sold to France and South Korea, according to a representative from the Public Television Service station, which partially funded the film.

Taiwanese-French actress Sandrine Pinna won the best actress award for her work in the film Yang Yang, while Hopscotch, a 28-minute drama, earned another honor for Taiwan by winning the best short film award.
World-renowned filmmaker John Woo of Hong Kong received the lifetime achievement award. "When I use these eyeglasses (reading glasses) , " he said, "it is about time to get a life achievement award."

Halfway through the ceremony, an earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richer scale rocked Taiwan for around 20 seconds and created a panic among the audience, including those from abroad who had never experienced an earthquake before. It did not disrupt the ceremony, however.
This year's awards presentation also featured Azharuddin Ismail and Rubina Ali, child stars in the Oscar-winning Indian film Slumdog Millionaire, as well as South Korean pop group Super Junior-M.
The festival saw 16 member countries taking part, along with 58 films competing for a total of 15 awards. The festival has a total of 18 members.

The film festival was suspended for two years due to the global economic crisis. It is the annual event of the Federation of Motion Picture Producers in Asia Pacific, and its secretariat is based in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Best director Leon Dai regretful about society wanting sympathy
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/19/09 23:36:54 (By Chen Yun-yu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Leon Dai showed no sign of happiness Saturday evening after accepting the best director award for his film No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti at the 53rd Asian Pacific Film Festival, as he criticized ruthless newspapers that failed to respect the positions of others.

"I am afraid that I have opened a 'Pandora's Box, '" said Dai, referring to his movie which was based on the true story of a single father's frustration over his efforts to maintain legal custody of his daughter.
The film won five awards, including best director, at Taiwan's Golden Horse Film Festival last month.

After accepting his award, the director mentioned that he was sorry to find that two newspapers played on his movie's name to call attention to stories published Saturday about single fathers who had abused their daughters, a far cry from the film's narrative of a father's devotion to his daughter.
The director said that he was in no mood to be happy about receiving another award because he found some media had manipulated the theme of his film and that society had little sympathy for others.
"I spent three years to produce a film with an intention to provide some positive energy to society, and I am afraid that I have opened a 'Pandora's box' and incurred negativity instead, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day V News digest of local media V taxation agreement

TEXT.P: An agreement on cross-strait taxation is expected to be signed during the fourth round of negotiations between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the coming week. Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said the agreement will help protect Taiwanese businessmen operating in China, lowering the burden of taxpayers and increasing the government's tax revenues.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue: China Times:

While four agreements are expected to be signed during the Chiang-Chen negotiations next week, some Taiwanese businessmen believe that the signing of a cross-strait investment protection agreement should have been the priority, and it is regretful that the negotiation of such an agreement was not included.

Vice Economics Minister Lin Sheng-chung said that although an investment protection agreement will not be included in the fourth round of the Chen-Chiang negotiations, it doesn't mean that it will be excluded in future negotiations. As long as the policy of opening Chinese investment in Taiwan is effectively implemented, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will make the discussion of an investment protection agreement one of the priorities on the agenda of the next round of talks.

Lin pointed out that no discussion on an investment protection agreement has been held, because up to date cross-strait investment has remained unbalanced, with far more Taiwanese investment in China than vice versa. Economic Daily News:

Finance Minister Lee Sush-der emphasized that the cross-strait taxation agreement will be signed next week based on the principles of equality, reciprocity, and mutual benefit and the safeguarding of Taiwanese businessmen's rights and welfare.

Lee maintained that the more a country relies on trade, the more it needs to conclude taxation agreements with other countries. By signing a cross-strait taxation agreement, it is expected Taiwan will be able to conclude such agreements with more countries, thus improving its competitiveness in international trade, he added.

Meanwhile, Israel became the 17th country to have signed a taxation agreement with Taiwan by signing a bilateral double taxation avoidance agreement on Dec. 18, Lee said, adding that there are three similar agreements still under negotiation. Liberty Times:

As a cross-strait taxation agreement is expected to be signed during the fourth round Chiang-Chen negotiations next week, some Taiwanese businessmen are worried that they will be prodded for their tax records.

Finance Minister Lee Sush-der has suggested that signing taxation agreements with other countries would help improve Taiwan's competitiveness in international trade, and he didn't think local businessmen should worry about being harassed over taxation.

However, Professor Norman Yin of National Chengchi University said that the concerns of the Taiwanese businessmen should be noted. He suggested that before signing the agreement, the negotiators must clarify its content and make known that the agreement is specifically for the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 20, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven- member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

Accompanied by party officials from the DPP's branches in Taichung City and Taichung County, Su called on Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to discuss issues related to security and public order during the ARATS president's negotiations with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation, from Dec. 21-23 in Taichung.
