Su told the Taichung mayor that the DPP will not be involved in any "sabotaging" behavior.

Over the past few days, Hu has repeatedly called on the DPP to prevent a repeat of the violent confrontation between protesters and the police that occurred last year during the second round of Chiang-Chen negotiations in Taipei.
He has also cautioned policemen not to overreact when facing the protesting crowds.

Expressing confidence in the mayor's wisdom to manage the situation, Su said the DPP, for its part, has set up a command center in Taichung City and party officials on duty will maintain communications with the city government to reduce the possibility of confrontation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Street protest

TEXT.P: On the eve of the arrival of China's top negotiator with Taiwan for a new round of high-level talks, pro-independence activists, led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , are taking to the streets in the central city of Taichung Sunday to protest what they call the President Ma Ying-jeou administration's pandering to China at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty.

While organizers have guaranteed that street protests will be peaceful and rational, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu has also vowed not to treat the protesters as rioters. Hu also said he would take full responsibility if the police abused their power and hurt civilians during demonstrations.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
Liberty Times:

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits is scheduled to arrive in Taichung Monday for a second visit. During his Dec. 21-25 stay, he will sign with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, four agreements covering cooperation on fishing crew issues, double taxation, industrial product standards and agricultural quarantine.

Like the nine agreements that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has signed with China in the past 18 months without popular consent, the soon-to-be- signed four agreements have also not been approved or screened by the Legislature.

With that in mind, the DPP and other civic groups are organizing street marches in Taichung to voice their opposition to the Ma administration's China-leaning policy. DPP officials said all those who are concerned about Taiwan's political future, economic well-being and their own job prospects and welfare rights are welcome to join the protests.
China Times:
As in the past, the DPP is welcoming the latest round of Chiang-Chen talks with a mass movement.
During Chen's first visit to Taiwan in 2008, bloody clashes erupted between DPP supporters and law enforcement officers, tarnishing the country's image.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is clearly aware that if the street protests get out of hand, the party will have to pay the price in the upcoming legislative by- elections and even in elections for mayors of five municipalities to be held late next year.

Sunday's street rally will just be a prelude. The real test to Tsai's leadership will come in the next five days with the presence of China's top envoy in Taiwan. Her political career will see a breakthrough only if the DPP can cut a balance between making its political stance heard and applying heat on Taiwanese and Chinese authorities with a mass movement.
United Daily News:

DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan paid a visit to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Saturday to convey his party's hope that during Sunday's "100,000-persons protest march, " there would be no recurrence of incidents seen in Chen Yunlin's first visit to Taipei last year, in which police officers forcibly took away national flags held by demonstrators and tried to stop a music CD shop from playing Taiwanese folk songs.
Su also assured Hu that the party has set up an emergency response center and will do its utmost to keep the protest march orderly and peaceful.
In response, Hu said he is confident of the DPP's sincerity to avoid violence in street rallies.
Describing the planned protests as "typhoons, " Hu said it would be best if typhoons never hit. "Our democracy will take a stride forward if 'typhoons' become 'breezes,'" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funds of diplomatic fraud convict to be returned to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 16:21:40 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Singapore's high court ruled Saturday that S$2.1 million (US$1.49 million) in a Singapore bank account held by Wu Shih-tsai, a key figure in a diplomatic fraud scandal that rocked the previous Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, be returned to Taiwan.

The sum that had been in Wu's OCBC Bank account since 2006 was only a small part of the US$29.8 million that Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) wired into a joint account held by Wu and Ching Chi Ju at the same bank on Sept. 15, 2006.

The money was meant to help the two middlemen broker the establishment of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Papua New Guinea, but most of it later disappeared without any progress in relations between the two countries.
According to the Singapore court's ruling, Taiwan's government can continue to retrieve the balance of the payment from Wu over the next 12 years.
Wu is presently doing time in a Taiwan jail after he was convicted in October 2008 of forgery and making false accusations and sentenced to 28 months in jail. He began serving time in May 2009.
Wu was indicted on the charges by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office after it discovered that Wu gave the MOFA a false bank statement to account for the money.
The prosecutors also asserted that Wu falsely claimed, after the scandal became public in May 2008, that he had been threatened at gunpoint.

Meanwhile, Ching, who was commissioned by the MOFA in 2006 to help broker the diplomatic initiative, allegedly embezzled most of the US$29.8 million that was intended as aid to the Pacific nation to help smooth the way in establishing formal ties.

Ching, whose whereabouts are unknown, had his lawyer tell the Singapore High Court that he had not embezzled the money and that it could not be returned because most of it had been spent as "grease money" to help advance the diplomatic initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 100 aftershocks reported after Saturday's strong quake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 17:19:37 (By Chen Hsun-hsieh, Andrew Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 129 aftershocks have been recorded as of noon Sunday after a magnitude 6.8 earthquake hit Taiwan Saturday at 9:02 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

Kuo Kai-wen, director of CWB's Seismology Center, said the strong quake and later aftershocks are normal seismic energy release, and he urged the public "to be on guard" but said there was no need to panic.

Kuo said Saturday's quake, whose epicenter was 25.5 kilometers southeast of Hualien City off the coast of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, resulted from friction between the Eurasian Plate and Philippine plate, which converge off Taiwan's east coast.
Because it struck at a depth of 45.9 kilometers, its impact was less than if it had been shallower, Kuo said, but he expected seismic energy to continue to be released.
"It is estimated that there will be aftershocks with magnitudes of less than 6.8 in the next few days," Kuo said.

Kuo also said that compared with the more than 1,000 aftershocks that occurred within 24 hours after a magnitude 7.3 temblor hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, the aftershocks after Saturday's quake were relatively mild.
Eleven people suffered minor injuries in Hualien, and other minor damage was reported elsewhere after Saturday's quake.
Yuching Bridge in northern Taiwan's Miaoli City was sealed off for inspection Sunday after its expansion joint opened wider because of the earthquake.
The Miaoli County government said the bridge poses no immediate danger, but it decided to close out of safety considerations.
Among the 11 injured in Hualien Saturday, 10 were tourists at a Hualien City hotel whose discomfort may have been caused by chlorine leaking from a pipe that ruptured during the earthquake.
The other injured person, a 16-year-old boy, was hit by a falling rock in Siulin Township, Hualien County.
Provincial Highway 11 was disrupted by landslides at its 40 kilometer marker, but the road was later cleared and traffic returned to normal.
Also, some 9,000 households were left without electricity after the Rueisuei transformer station in Hualien County's Kuangfu Township broke down, but power has since been restored in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Zhejiang tourism teams to visit southern Taiwan in spring
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 17:52:00 (By Wang Su-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Delegations of travel agency managers from Hangzhou and Ningbo in China's Zhejiang province will visit tourist destinations in Kaohsiung and Pingtung in southern Taiwan next spring, a Kaohsiung City government official said Sunday.

The planned tours, resulting from a recent tourism promotion trip to the two Chinese cities by a tourism industry alliance from Kaohsiung City and County and Pingtung County, are expected to give a boost to southern Taiwan's tourism sector, said Lai Jui-long, chief secretary of the Kaohsiung City Tourism Bureau.

A number of Chinese tour groups reportedly canceled trips to Kaohsiung City following a controversial visit by exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in late August and the screening of a documentary about the exiled leader of China's Uighur minority, Rebiya Kadeer, in the city in September.
The city government has since come under pressure to work out measures to respond to speculation that Chinese tourists are boycotting Kaohsiung over the issues.

As part of their efforts to save local tourism, Lai and Pingtung County and Kaohsiung County officials joined the industry alliance in traveling to Hangzhou and Ningbo, where they held two tourism promotion events to spark interest in southern Taiwan as a travel destination among Chinese tour operators, Lai said.
During their visit, the delegation interacted positively with Zhejiang tourism officials and exchanged views on boosting city tourism on both sides, Lai added.

Zhejiang tourism officials said that visitors from their province account for one-fifth of total Chinese arrivals in Taiwan and told Lai they hoped the promotional campaigns would help attract more Zhejiang natives to southern Taiwan and give the tourism sector there a lift.

Lai said travel agencies in Hangzhou and Ningbo were well positioned to arrange convenient five-day packages to southern Taiwan because there are seven weekly nonstop flights between Kaohsiung International Airport and the two Chinese cities.

Tour operators have begun devising customized tours for the two Chinese travel agent delegations, and Lai said the Kaohsiung City government in particular will offer them special deals, including giving them free admission to sightseeing cruises around Kaohsiung's port.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to continue tracking down money duped by diplomatic brokers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 18:01:53 (By Chung-sen Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to track down nearly US$30 million that was allegedly stolen by two diplomatic brokers three years ago, the Taipei District Prosecutors Office vowed Sunday.

Local prosecutors have maintained contact with their counterparts in Singapore and the United States in a bid to recover the US$29.8 million (NT$965 million) that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) wired to a Singapore bank on Sept. 15, 2006, ostensibly to facilitate the establishment of diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea.

The money was remitted to an account at Singapore's OCBC Bank jointly held by the two brokers, Wu Shih-Tsai, a Singaporean national, and his partner Ching Chi Ju, a Taiwanese with a U.S. passport who was commissioned by the MOFA in 2006 to help facilitate a deal to establish diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea.

The MOFA asked Wu and Ching for a statement of account early last year after finding that by Dec. 1, 2006, the money in the joint account had disappeared without any progress being made on the initiative with Papua New Guinea.
Wu, without knowing that the MOFA had been aware of the fraud, produced a false bank statement from his own notebook computer and gave it to the ministry.

He was taken into custody by prosecutors in May 2008 and indicted for forging the bank statement and making false accusations in September 2008. He was found guilty of the charges a month later and sentenced to 28 months in prison.

The scandal came to light May 1, 2008, when a Singaporean daily reported that the Singapore High Court had approved Taiwan's application for an injunction to freeze the joint bank account held by Wu and Ching.

According to the prosecutors, Taiwan has had NT$300 million worth of bank accounts held by Wu and Ching and property Wu bought in Taipei City frozen. Some NT$70 million of the assets are in Wu's name.
The Singapore High Court ruled Saturday that the S$2.1 million (US$1.49 million) that had been in another of Wu's accounts at Singapore OCBC Bank be returned to Taiwan's authorities.
Meanwhile, Taipei prosecutors listed Ching, who is said to be living at his home in California, as one of Taiwan's most wanted fugitives last May as they continued their investigation into the case.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office said it had asked for judicial assistance from the U.S. government in the investigation and suggested having U.S. prosecutors interrogate Ching on Taiwan's behalf or sending their own people to California to question Ching themselves.
They have yet to receive a response from the U.S. government.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to officiate meeting on security in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 18:32:10 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a briefing on security and police preparedness in Taichung on Monday, the day when China's top negotiator with Taiwan is scheduled to arrive for the latest round of high-level cross-strait talks, the Presidential Office said Sunday.

The president will listen to officials' reports and issue directives regarding public order in the central Taiwan city, where the fourth meeting between Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, and his Taiwan counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, will take place, said Paul K. Chang, director- general of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.

Highly concerned about public order in Taichung because of plans by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to stage protests during Chen's stay there from Dec. 21-25, President Ma will preside in person over the meeting on public order, Chang said.
Presidential Office meetings on public order are usually overseen by the deputy secretary of the office, he added.
Ranking officials from the National Security Council, the National Police Agency and the Government Information Office are also expected to attend.
Chang said the Presidential Office believes Chen and his group are guests and are entitled to safety, comfort and dignity during their visit.
"We should behave ourselves with grace as hosts," Chang said.

According to a ruling Kuomintang heavyweight who spoke on condition of anonymity, Ma presided over a similar security meeting in early November 2008 before Chen Yunlin set foot on Taiwan's soil for the first time.

The DPP, however, held massive protests outside the Grand Hotel in Taipei City where Chen and his group stayed. One of the protests, staged outside the Grand Formosa Regent where Chen was having dinner, forced the Chinese diplomat to stay in the hotel until the early hours of the morning.

Ma will remind those attending Monday's meeting that if undesirable scenarios occur during Chen's visit in Taichung, law enforcement authorities should handle the situations and respond in real time, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-China protest march kicks off on eve of envoy's arrival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/20/09 19:40:03 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Large crowds took to the streets in Taichung to protest the government's China policy a day before China's top negotiator on Taiwan affairs was to arrive for another round of talks on bilateral cooperation.

The massive protest march in central Taiwan was organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and pro-independence civic groups to drive home their belief that the government's strengthening of economic ties with China is undermining Taiwan's sovereign status and threatening its people's economic well-being.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said DPP supporters have turned out in droves to oppose the President Ma Ying-jeou administration's lack of transparency in negotiating deals with China, which prevents any form of supervision by the people and puts the country's interests at risk.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is expected to sign four agreements with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, during his stay from Dec. 21-25.
The accords will cover cooperation on fishing crew issues, double taxation, industrial product standards and agricultural quarantine.

Dubbing Sunday's protest as a march to "break the black box and protect the rice bowl, " DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan said an estimated 100,000 people were expected to join an evening rally near the city's open-air circular theater.
DPP supporters began to converge at Taichung's Anhe Road and Mincyuan Road, respectively, and long lines had formed at the two gathering points by 2:30 p.m. Sunday.

Demonstrators from central Taiwan gathered at the intersection of Jhonggang Road and Mincyuan Road and started to walk toward the rally site at 3: 30 p.m. under the leadership of Su and Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei.
Almost at the same time, protesters from northern and southern Taiwan, headed by Tsai and other DPP bigwigs, also began the march from the intersection of Anhe Road and Chaoma Road.
Both marches proceeded in an orderly fashion, with police officers and DPP members helping keep traffic flowing along the thoroughfares where the processions passed.
Braving chilly weather, demonstraters waved brightly colored anti-China and anti-government banners and placards, and in some spots the parades resembled street carnivals.

Chen Ta-chun, head of the DPP's Taichung chapter, led the demonstrators in chanting pro-independnece slogans such as "Taiwan and China, one side one country" and "Cross-Strait Affairs, Listen to the People's Voices" to boost morale.
He said he was confident that the number of protesters would reach the party's target of 100,000 when the evening rally began later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT will sort out principles on handling its assets by year end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 20:00:46 (By Tyson Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The newly appointed secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , King Pu- tsung, said Sunday that the direction and principles the party will follow in handling its assets will be determined by the end of this year.
King made the pledge during a visit to the eastern city of Taitung, where a grassroots KMT worker urged him to boldly and resolutely deal with the controversial party asset issue.

The opposition contends that the KMT's assets were illegally obtained during its decades of authoritarian rule in the second half of the 20th century when the lines between state and party were blurred.
King was also told that the KMT has suffered from a shortage of workers in the Taitung area and that the roles of those working for the party were ill-defined.
He replied that the roles of grassroots party workers have changed with the political environment.
"In the past, their jobs focused on providing services and seeking help for constituents, but now they should help reflect the people's plight and search for problems," he said.

Fielding complaints about President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, King said that nobody is perfect and that if Ma has some shortcomings, the people around him, including King himself, will fill in the gaps.
"Chairman Ma is a man who is willing to reflect on his behavior," King told his audience.
King had been a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank, since September before being tapped to take over the party's day-to-day affairs.

While King is expected to dedicate much of his time to legislative by-elections scheduled for Jan. 9 and Feb. 27 and mayoral elections in five special municipalities in December, the party asset issue, which is often used by the opposition to attack the KMT, will also be a priority, according to King's predecessor, Chan Chuen-po.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to strive for FTAs after inking ECFA with China
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Taiwan, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 20:14:51 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday the government will continue its efforts to seal free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries after signing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Ma also said during a meeting with representatives of stockings manufacturers in the central county of Changhua that the government will negotiate the ECFA with China based on the principle that Taiwan is the focus and that the interests of the public come first, and he also said the document will be subject to legislative review.
The president reiterated that only Taiwan and North Korea among Asia Pacific countries have not signed FTAs with other countries in the region, which threatens to marginalize Taiwan.

He said that after the ECFA is signed, the administration will try to seal FTAs with other countries and will not ask China for its approval to sign them "because Taiwan is a sovereign independent country."

Free trade deals can only be signed if both sides are willing to do so, Ma said, but he argued that once an ECFA is signed with China, other countries will be more willing to sign FTAs with Taiwan because China's suppression of such deals would be reduced.

Earlier that day, Ma told farmers during a tour of an eustoma flower export production zone in Changhua that he has honored his pledge not to further open Taiwan's market to Chinese agricultural products since assuming office in May 2008.

He noted that of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products allowed to be imported into Taiwan, 479 items were approved by the previous Kuomintang administration and the other 936 were approved by the Democratic Progressive Party when it was in power.

countries 7. Funds of diplomatic fraud convict to be returned to Taiwan 8. Taiwan to continue tracking down money duped by diplomatic brokers 9. Ma to officiate at meeting on public order 10. KMT to sort out directions in handling party property 11. Tens of thousands march to protest trade pact with China

DOC.HEADLINE: 17 local chiefs assume posts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 21:36:50 (By Andrew J. T. Liu, Lin Heng-li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The individuals elected on Dec. 5 to head 17 cities and counties in Taiwan assumed their posts Sunday with varying levels of creativity and articulated their visions for their four-year terms.

Of the 17 local chiefs, 12 are from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), four are from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and one is an independent, who quickly installed his ex-wife as his deputy.

In perhaps the most stunning debut of any of the newly elected magistrates, independent Fu Kun-chi appointed his ex-wife Hsu Chen-wei, who he apparently recently divorced, as his deputy in his inauguration ceremony.
Fu said the appointment was in line with regulations and stressed that his family "has made preparations to sacrifice for the sake of Hualien's development."

Fu said Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang inquired about his decision in the evening, and he clearly explained to him that he had completed divorce proceedings and that the appointment was legal.
Under Taiwan's laws, a married couple cannot serve as the magistrate and deputy magistrate of a county.

Fu represented the KMT as a legislator, but the party did not nominate him as its candidate in the Hualien County magistrate election because he is currently being tried in separate cases for violating securities transaction laws.
He has already been convicted of one crime, and if his appeal is rejected, he will have to relinquish his post.
Despite his legal problems, Fu ran as an independent and handily defeated the KMT's official nominee and one other rival.

He complained Sunday that the central government had tried to smear his reputation before and after the election but insisted on his innocence and vowed to do everything he could for Hualien residents.

Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching began his second term in office by offering a cash award of NT$1 million (US$30,960) to anyone who could provide a good idea on how the county's most scenic spot -- Sun Moon Lake -- could tie the knot with the West Lake in Hangzhou, in China's Zhejiang province.
Lee said that when he first assumed office four years ago, he promoted the plan without success.

"I hope all residents of the county can help me in coming with a good way or idea to stage the marriage so as to draw international attention and participation and promote the status and development of Sun Moon Lake," he said.

In Taoyuan County, former Legislator John Chih-yang Wu greeted wellwishers, including Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, his father and KMT honorary Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, past magistrates and hundreds of political and business figures, in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal dialects.

Wu said that he hopes to become the most tolerant and loving magistrate in Taoyuan County's history, and vowed to complete major infrastructure projects, including turning the area around its international airport into an aviation city and building a mass rapid transit system, while also pushing to upgrade the county into a municipality.
Chu, who served as Taoyuan County magistrate before leaving to become vice premier in September, lauded Wu for his dynamism, expertise and ideals.
In Hsinchu County, former Legislator Chiu Ching-chun, who emerged victorious from a fierce election battle, vowed to solicit more private sector investment in the county to help improve its finances.
In Taitung County, newly elected magistrate Justin Huang reaffirmed his focus on tourism, the economy, culture, education, agriculture and care for underprivileged groups.

The former KMT legislator vowed to make the eastern Taiwan county more progressive and prosperous, before heading to a settlement center in Dawu Township to visit people who were displaced from their homes by Typhoon Morakot in August.

In Chiayi City, Huang Ming-hui began her second term in office, saying that she will focus on improving the southern Taiwan city's infrastructure and seek out opportunities to host major events to help market Chiayi and stimulate the local economy.
In Keelung City, incumbent mayor Chang Tung-jung noted that a marine science museum will open in 2012, which is expected to bring 2 million tourists to the northern Taiwan city every year.
Chang said the city will now engage in peripheral traffic network planning.

In outlying Kinmen County, which lies just kilometers from China's coast, newly elected magistrate Lee Wo-shih hopes to bring world-class infrastructure to the county so that its residents will have higher incomes, excellent environmental quality and health protection.
In Matsu, the county's new magistrate Yang Sui-sheng vowed to overcome its difficulties as an outlying island by making it a duty-free area to attract tourists from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa said Sunday that although the county's financial situation is dire, he will continue to push for a strong social welfare policy in his second term.

Among the four counties headed by DPP politicians, Yilan County Magistrate Lin Tsung-hsien vowed to push the county's anti-flooding efforts and sponsor the Yilan Green Expo and children's festival in the next half year.
Chiayi County has its first female magistrate, with former DPP Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan taking the helm from her predecesor Chen Ming-wen.
Chang hoped that county's administrative team will improve services and upgrade its efficiency. She also hoped that the central government will help narrow the urban-rural gap seen in the county.
In Yunlin County, Su Chih-fen said that in her second term, she will continue to push to make the county into an agriculture stronghold.

Considering the close relationship between water and people's lives, she said she will craft ecological, environmental, agricultural, water control, and education policies from the perspective of their impact on the county's water resources.
In Pingtung County, incumbent Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung launched a "Pingtung taking off" remote-control airplane to symbolize the taking off of the southern Taiwan county.

Tsao said he would work to develop the solar power industry and turn Siaoliouchiou into a low-carbon islet. With the bicycle network in the county nearing completion, he said Pingtung will be the county that puts the most effort into energy conservation and carbon emissions reduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tens of thousands march to protest trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Taiwan, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 22:04:22 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Tens of thousands of Taiwanese marched in the central Taiwan city of Taichung to protest the government's plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The rally took place one day before Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , arrives here to sign four economic agreements with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), but the ECFA is not on the meeting's formal agenda.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and local civic groups said the purpose of the protest was to call attention to the poor overall performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and the lack of transparency in its negotiations on the ECFA with China.

Braving strong winds in temperatures of around 10 degrees Celsius, pro- independence protesters from across the country assembled in downtown Taichung for the rally after marching in two separate legs in the city.
"Taiwan is facing three problems. The first problem is Ma, the second problem is Ma. The third problem is still Ma, " DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen told the crowd.
Polls show that the president is leading Taiwan to unification (with China), she said, adding that "the biggest problem is that we have a president who is only focused on unifying with China."
Tsai said people gathered because no one knows what the president is doing, especially on the ECFA, which Ma argues Taiwan must sign or it will be marginalized.
The ECFA is expected to be included in the next round of talks between both sides, which is scheduled to take place in the first half of 2010 in China.
Tsai accused Ma of never explaining the ECFA clearly and of refusing to communicate with the people, the Legislative Yuan or the opposition on its contents.

The only beneficiaries from the ECFA are big corporations, while many ordinary people will lose their jobs because of it, Tsai contended, adding that the president has never disclosed its potential adverse impact on Taiwan's people.

An economic model run by the Ministry of Economic Affairs found that Taiwan would gain a net 260,000 jobs if an ECFA was signed, while the Council of Labor Affairs estimated it would create a net 105,000 to 125,000 jobs.
Both models acknowledged, however, that some workers in vulnerable industries could lose their jobs.
Almost all the DPP heavyweights showed up and spoke to the gathered crowd.

"If Taiwan signs the ECFA with China, President Ma should also ask China to help Taiwan sign FTAs with other countries, such as Japan and South Korea, so Taiwan will be able to trade with others as well, " said former Vice President Annette Lu.

In the days leading up to Sunday's protest rally, the DPP said it hoped to mobilize 100,000 people, and the party estimated after the event that the turnout had surpassed its goal. The Taichung City government, on the other hand, put the turnout at 31,000.

Fears that clashes would break out never materialized. Taichung City government spokesperson Tsou Mei-liang earlier said that no confrontations took place Sunday, and it was not a surprise since "the protest was legally applied for and all arrangements had been implemented beforehand."

Prior to the main rally, the protesters marched for more than two hours in Taichung's streets, and made the most noise when they walked past the Windsor Hotel, where Chen will stay during his five-day stay, to express their displeasure over the Chinese negotiator's visit.
The crowds chanted slogans such as "Taiwan and China; one country on each side" as they marched, while others expressed their views in more colorful ways.
A senior citizen from Chiayi City showed everyone a picture of Ma wearing only a swimming suit and said "this is all he does -- swim."
A protester surnamed Hsu, who came from the southern city of Tainan complained not only about the government's China policy but also security precautions taken for Chen's visit.

"We don't want a trade agreement with China. And all these barricades, security deployments and traffic controls for a Chinese representative are outrageous. The Taichung City police should remove them all."

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on hiring foreign caregivers should remain: foundation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/20/09 22:09:34 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government should reconsider its plan to ease restrictions on hiring foreign caregivers or maids because such a move could deprive local middle-aged and older women of job opportunities, an advocacy group said Sunday.

The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is considering allowing families that have two members in their 80s or one member older than 90 plus a toddler under one year of age to apply to hire foreign caregivers.

"On the surface, the proposed liberalization is not large, but in effect, its impact on local women, particularly those in middle or senior age groups, would be great, " said Lin Shih-chia, chairman of the Peng Wan-ju Foundation.

According to Lin, foreign caregivers who have come to Taiwan on caregiving contracts usually have to do all sorts of household chores, such as cleaning the house, washing clothes, and cooking, the jobs that in many cases are currently done by middle-aged local women.
"As a result, middle-aged and senior women's job opportunities could be affected, " Lin explained.
An initial estimate shows that at least 10,000 local women could fall victim to the proposed measure, he added.

Over the years, the foundation has offered training courses for local women who want to work as maids. In 2009 alone, Lin said, the foundation successfully helped mediate 13,442 maid contracts worth more than NT$900 million.
At the same time, Lin said, the in-home service market has grown steadily.

"The Cabinet-level CLA should not ignore potential market demand and should instead adopt measures to boost the development of this line of service which is especially suitable for middle- or senior-aged women to undertake," Lin said.
With an average service charge ranging between NT$180 and NT$250 per hour, a well-trained or trusted live-in maid can earn more than NT$30,000 a month, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA daybook for Dec. 21, 2009

TEXT.P: Disclaimer The CNA provides this listing of some of tomorrow's events in Taipei and some other cities as part of our daily English-language service. Reporters interested in covering the events listed in the Daybook are advised to contact the organizers for additional information. DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, Dec. 20, or the fifth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1852: British troops annex Pegu, lower Burma, during a war with Burma.
1913: Taiwan's North-South Railway Trunk Line is completed.
1921: Mahathir Mohamad, Malaysian prime minister, is born.
1927: Kim Young-sam, former president of South Korea, is born.
1922: Fourteen republics of Russia form the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
1924: Adolf Hitler is paroled after serving eight months of a prison sentence after being convicted of high treason.
1928: Britain recognizes the government of the Republic of China.
1941: The Flying Tigers, flown by U.S. Air Force volunteers, shoot down four Japanese planes in their first encounter near Kunming in southwest China.
1944: Young Chinese students begin to enter training camps in response to a call to join the armed forces and fight against Japan.
1945: Soviet troops move an estimated US$2 billion-worth of machinery from Manchuria to the Soviet Union.
1950: Fu Shih-nien, president of National Taiwan University, dies of a stroke at the age of 55. He collapses while answering interpellations at the Taiwan Provincial Assembly.
1968: John Steinbeck, the American novelist who won the Nobel Prize for literature for books such as "The Grapes of Wrath" and "East of Eden," dies at the age of 66.
1960: The Viet Cong, the armed wing of the National Liberation Front, is founded in South Vietnam.
1968: The ROC chooses 26 new members of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan from among 52 candidates.
1971: President Agha Mohammed Yahya Khan resigns after Pakistan losses control over East Pakistan, now Bangladesh.
1973: Spanish Premier Luis Carrero Blanco is killed when assassins bomb his car in Madrid, Spain.
1981: The Kuangfu River Tunnel in Taitung is formally open to traffic, becoming the first railway tunnel under a river in Taiwan.
1982: Arthur Rubinstein, Russian-born American pianist, dies at the age of 95 in Geneva.
1986: Some 30,000 students march for democracy through the streets of Shanghai in mainland China's largest demonstration since the Cultural Revolution.
1988: The first batch of five mainland Chinese students, who are studying in the United States, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1989: Some 12,000 U.S. troops join 12,000 already in Panama to unseat Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as head of that country.
1991: President Boris Yeltsin announces that Russia wants to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO).
1994: Mexico lowers the peso's trading floor, triggering a drastic devaluation.
1997: South Korean President Kim Dae-jung pardons Chun Doo-hwan and Roh Tae-woo, two former military dictators who had tried to kill him when he was a dissident.
1998: Nkem Chukwu of Houston, Texas, becomes the first woman to give birth to eight live babies.
1999: The Wang Kuang-ying Library, dedicated to a public-spirited ROC man who collected garbage for 35 years and used the money he earned to buy books and donate them to the local and overseas institutions, is inaugurated in Taipei.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui tells visiting U.S. Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) that the ROC's ultimate goal of seeking peaceful reunification with mainland China remains unchanged.
2000: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says when receiving a seven- member Japanese parliamentary delegation that maintaining peace across the Taiwan Strait is in the common interest of the ROC, Japan and the United States.
2001: Twenty-one city and county chiefs from around Taiwan are sworn in at official ceremonies, vowing to better serve the local people and to deliver on their campaign promises.
2001: A consortium of leading telecommunication companies launches services on the Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 (APCN 2), the world's first Asian submarine ring system that comprises 19,000 km of cable connecting mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore.
Confucius: "Now, if in your conversation you give few occasions for men to criticize you, and in your conduct you have few occasions for self-reproach, you cannot help getting preferment."

DOC.HEADLINE: Best director Leon Dai regretful about society wanting sympathy
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/09 12:32:19 (By Chen Yun-yu and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Leon Dai showed no sign of happiness Saturday evening after accepting the best director award for his film No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti at the 53rd Asian Pacific Film Festival, as he criticized ruthless newspapers that failed to respect the positions of others.

"I am afraid that I have opened a 'Pandora's Box, '" said Dai, referring to his movie which was based on the true story of a single father's frustration over his efforts to maintain legal custody of his daughter.
The film won five awards, including best director, at Taiwan's Golden Horse Film Festival last month.

After accepting his award, the director mentioned that he was sorry to find that two newspapers played on his movie's name to call attention to stories published Saturday about single fathers who had abused their daughters, a far cry from the film's narrative of a father's devotion to his daughter.
The director said that he was in no mood to be happy about receiving another award because he found some media had manipulated the theme of his film and that society had little sympathy for others.
"I spent three years to produce a film with an intention to provide some positive energy to society, and I am afraid that I have opened a 'Pandora's box' and incurred negativity instead, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins big in Asia Pacific Film Festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/09 12:33:03 (By Angela Tsai, Emmanuelle Tseng and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The Asia Pacific Film Festival took to the stage in southern Taiwan Saturday after a two-year hiatus, with Taiwan taking home five awards, including those for best director and best actress.
Taiwanese filmmaker Leon Dai won the best director award for his film No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti, which was a five-time winner at this year's Golden Horse Awards, Taiwan's version of the Oscars.
Chang Hsiang-yu, who had never before helped produce a film, won the best cinematography award for his work on Dai's film. It was also the first award that Taiwan won on the night.

The best documentary award went to Baseball Boy, a Taiwanese film that has been sold to France and South Korea, according to a representative from the Public Television Service station, which partially funded the film.

Taiwanese-French actress Sandrine Pinna won the best actress award for her work in the film Yang Yang, while Hopscotch, a 28-minute drama, earned another honor for Taiwan by winning the best short film award.
World-renowned filmmaker John Woo of Hong Kong received the lifetime achievement award. "When I use these eyeglasses (reading glasses) , " he said, "it is about time to get a life achievement award."

Halfway through the ceremony, an earthquake measuring 6.8 on the Richer scale rocked Taiwan for around 20 seconds and created a panic among the audience, including those from abroad who had never experienced an earthquake before. It did not disrupt the ceremony, however.
This year's awards presentation also featured Azharuddin Ismail and Rubina Ali, child stars in the Oscar-winning Indian film Slumdog Millionaire, as well as South Korean pop group Super Junior-M.
The festival saw 16 member countries taking part, along with 58 films competing for a total of 15 awards. The festival has a total of 18 members.

The film festival was suspended for two years due to the global economic crisis. It is the annual event of the Federation of Motion Picture Producers in Asia Pacific, and its secretariat is based in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Our voice will be loud, our action will be peaceful': DPP chairwoman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/09 12:33:52 (By Tsai Su-ping and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen reiterated Saturday that Sunday's planned protest in Taichung against the government's China policy will be peaceful.
"Our voice will be loud, our action will be peaceful, " she said on the eve of the protest to be held ahead of negotiations between Taiwan and China in the central city this coming week.

Tsai was attending a fund-raiser held by the Taiwanese Professors' Association in Taipei when she was asked by reporters about the DPP's mobilization of the protest against the fourth round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , to be held in Taichung from Dec. 21-23.
Tsai said she was not worried about the turnout and suggested that party members had found a good consensus and supporters had high expectations.
From the experience of mass rallies, followers of the DPP have learned that protests should be peaceful and rational, according to Tsai.

DOC.HEADLINE: Defendant may refuse night interrogation starting Jan. 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/09 12:34:45 (By Lai Yo-chia, Ann Chih-hsian and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: A recently promulgated amendment to the Criminal Procedure Law, to take effect Jan. 1, will better protect the human rights of defendants or arrested suspects because it empowers them to refuse to attend detention hearings after 11 p.m.

The amendment to Article 93 of the Criminal Procedure Law stipulates that when the court begins deliberations late at night on a request to detain a suspect or defendant that is filed after 11 p.m., a party, lawyer or representative may ask the court to postpone the hearing until the next morning.
The court cannot deny the defendant's request without proper reasons and should provide the defendant a proper place to rest, it adds.
According to existing regulations, defendants must be interrogated immediately whenever the court decides to proceed with a detention request.

This often results in a situation where the defendant, who might already be worn out after being interrogated by the police, investigation bureaus and prosecutors, still has to appear in court overnight.
Earlier in the year, the Judicial Yuan requested all courts to set up waiting rooms with bedding, a pillow, and disposable bathroom kits for defendants and to provide them with breakfast.

"Although most defendants will choose to get the interrogation over with as soon as possible, and the trial waiting rooms might not be used as often, we still have to ask all the courts to have such rooms based the need to protect human rights, " said Hsieh Wen-ting, secretary-general of the Judicial Yuan.

According to Hsieh, the newly renovated trial waiting chambers at the Taiwan Taipei District Court, for instance, are properly furnished similar to budget hotels. He said the court will display the rooms before the end of the year

Meanwhile, also as part of the efforts to better protect the defendant's rights, the Taipei district court has specific regulations that require alarms and monitoring equipment to be installed in the trial waiting rooms and that the recordings be preserved for six months.

Should the defendant feel ill and need medical attention, he will be admitted into Taipei City Hospital's Heping Branch, and the judicial police will have to record the entire process and report to the courts on a regular basis by radio, according to the regulations.

Noting that the Taipei district court held a drill last week regarding related procedures, Huang Chun-ming, a presiding judge at the Taipei district court, said footage of the defendant when he or she is in the bathroom will be blurred.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP secretary-general advises Chen Yunlin not to travel around
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 19 (CNA) 12/20/09 12:35:29 (By Hau Hsueh-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan suggested Saturday that Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), must not travel around while in Taiwan to avoid giving the impression of "conducting an inspection," which could be provocative.
Chen had previously expressed his desire to visit some victims of Typhoon Morakot while in Taiwan, but it remains unclear if any such trip has been arranged or if Su's advice will be taken.

Accompanied by party officials from the DPP's branches in Taichung City and Taichung County, Su called on Taichung Mayor Jason Hu to discuss issues related to security and public order during the ARATS president's negotiations with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation, from Dec. 21-23 in Taichung.

The DPP and some civil groups have mobilized their followers to launch a large- scale rally in Taichung Sunday and other protest activities on the following days to express their appeal for transparency in cross-strait negotiations.
Su told the Taichung mayor that the DPP will not be involved in any "sabotaging" behavior.

Over the past few days, Hu has repeatedly called on the DPP to prevent a repeat of the violent confrontation between protesters and the police that occurred last year during the second round of Chiang-Chen negotiations in Taipei.
He has also cautioned policemen not to overreact when facing the protesting crowds.

Expressing confidence in the mayor's wisdom to manage the situation, Su said the DPP, for its part, has set up a command center in Taichung City and party officials on duty will maintain communications with the city government to reduce the possibility of confrontation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Street protest

TEXT.P: On the eve of the arrival of China's top negotiator with Taiwan for a new round of high-level talks, pro-independence activists, led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , are taking to the streets in the central city of Taichung Sunday to protest what they call the President Ma Ying-jeou administration's pandering to China at the expense of Taiwan's sovereignty.

While organizers have guaranteed that street protests will be peaceful and rational, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu has also vowed not to treat the protesters as rioters. Hu also said he would take full responsibility if the police abused their power and hurt civilians during demonstrations.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
Liberty Times:

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits is scheduled to arrive in Taichung Monday for a second visit. During his Dec. 21-25 stay, he will sign with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, four agreements covering cooperation on fishing crew issues, double taxation, industrial product standards and agricultural quarantine.

Like the nine agreements that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration has signed with China in the past 18 months without popular consent, the soon-to-be- signed four agreements have also not been approved or screened by the Legislature.

With that in mind, the DPP and other civic groups are organizing street marches in Taichung to voice their opposition to the Ma administration's China-leaning policy. DPP officials said all those who are concerned about Taiwan's political future, economic well-being and their own job prospects and welfare rights are welcome to join the protests.
China Times:
As in the past, the DPP is welcoming the latest round of Chiang-Chen talks with a mass movement.
During Chen's first visit to Taiwan in 2008, bloody clashes erupted between DPP supporters and law enforcement officers, tarnishing the country's image.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen is clearly aware that if the street protests get out of hand, the party will have to pay the price in the upcoming legislative by- elections and even in elections for mayors of five municipalities to be held late next year.

Sunday's street rally will just be a prelude. The real test to Tsai's leadership will come in the next five days with the presence of China's top envoy in Taiwan. Her political career will see a breakthrough only if the DPP can cut a balance between making its political stance heard and applying heat on Taiwanese and Chinese authorities with a mass movement.
United Daily News:

DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan paid a visit to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu Saturday to convey his party's hope that during Sunday's "100,000-persons protest march, " there would be no recurrence of incidents seen in Chen Yunlin's first visit to Taipei last year, in which police officers forcibly took away national flags held by demonstrators and tried to stop a music CD shop from playing Taiwanese folk songs.
Su also assured Hu that the party has set up an emergency response center and will do its utmost to keep the protest march orderly and peaceful.
In response, Hu said he is confident of the DPP's sincerity to avoid violence in street rallies.
Describing the planned protests as "typhoons, " Hu said it would be best if typhoons never hit. "Our democracy will take a stride forward if 'typhoons' become 'breezes,'" he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Funds of diplomatic fraud convict to be returned to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 16:21:40 (By Charles Kang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Singapore's high court ruled Saturday that S$2.1 million (US$1.49 million) in a Singapore bank account held by Wu Shih-tsai, a key figure in a diplomatic fraud scandal that rocked the previous Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government, be returned to Taiwan.

The sum that had been in Wu's OCBC Bank account since 2006 was only a small part of the US$29.8 million that Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) wired into a joint account held by Wu and Ching Chi Ju at the same bank on Sept. 15, 2006.

The money was meant to help the two middlemen broker the establishment of diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Papua New Guinea, but most of it later disappeared without any progress in relations between the two countries.
According to the Singapore court's ruling, Taiwan's government can continue to retrieve the balance of the payment from Wu over the next 12 years.
Wu is presently doing time in a Taiwan jail after he was convicted in October 2008 of forgery and making false accusations and sentenced to 28 months in jail. He began serving time in May 2009.
Wu was indicted on the charges by the Taipei District Prosecutors Office after it discovered that Wu gave the MOFA a false bank statement to account for the money.
The prosecutors also asserted that Wu falsely claimed, after the scandal became public in May 2008, that he had been threatened at gunpoint.

Meanwhile, Ching, who was commissioned by the MOFA in 2006 to help broker the diplomatic initiative, allegedly embezzled most of the US$29.8 million that was intended as aid to the Pacific nation to help smooth the way in establishing formal ties.

Ching, whose whereabouts are unknown, had his lawyer tell the Singapore High Court that he had not embezzled the money and that it could not be returned because most of it had been spent as "grease money" to help advance the diplomatic initiative.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 100 aftershocks reported after Saturday's strong quake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 17:19:37 (By Chen Hsun-hsieh, Andrew Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A total of 129 aftershocks have been recorded as of noon Sunday after a magnitude 6.8 earthquake hit Taiwan Saturday at 9:02 p.m., the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said.

Kuo Kai-wen, director of CWB's Seismology Center, said the strong quake and later aftershocks are normal seismic energy release, and he urged the public "to be on guard" but said there was no need to panic.

Kuo said Saturday's quake, whose epicenter was 25.5 kilometers southeast of Hualien City off the coast of Hualien County in eastern Taiwan, resulted from friction between the Eurasian Plate and Philippine plate, which converge off Taiwan's east coast.
Because it struck at a depth of 45.9 kilometers, its impact was less than if it had been shallower, Kuo said, but he expected seismic energy to continue to be released.
"It is estimated that there will be aftershocks with magnitudes of less than 6.8 in the next few days," Kuo said.

Kuo also said that compared with the more than 1,000 aftershocks that occurred within 24 hours after a magnitude 7.3 temblor hit Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, the aftershocks after Saturday's quake were relatively mild.
Eleven people suffered minor injuries in Hualien, and other minor damage was reported elsewhere after Saturday's quake.
Yuching Bridge in northern Taiwan's Miaoli City was sealed off for inspection Sunday after its expansion joint opened wider because of the earthquake.
The Miaoli County government said the bridge poses no immediate danger, but it decided to close out of safety considerations.
Among the 11 injured in Hualien Saturday, 10 were tourists at a Hualien City hotel whose discomfort may have been caused by chlorine leaking from a pipe that ruptured during the earthquake.
The other injured person, a 16-year-old boy, was hit by a falling rock in Siulin Township, Hualien County.
Provincial Highway 11 was disrupted by landslides at its 40 kilometer marker, but the road was later cleared and traffic returned to normal.
Also, some 9,000 households were left without electricity after the Rueisuei transformer station in Hualien County's Kuangfu Township broke down, but power has since been restored in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Zhejiang tourism teams to visit southern Taiwan in spring
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 17:52:00 (By Wang Su-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Delegations of travel agency managers from Hangzhou and Ningbo in China's Zhejiang province will visit tourist destinations in Kaohsiung and Pingtung in southern Taiwan next spring, a Kaohsiung City government official said Sunday.

The planned tours, resulting from a recent tourism promotion trip to the two Chinese cities by a tourism industry alliance from Kaohsiung City and County and Pingtung County, are expected to give a boost to southern Taiwan's tourism sector, said Lai Jui-long, chief secretary of the Kaohsiung City Tourism Bureau.

A number of Chinese tour groups reportedly canceled trips to Kaohsiung City following a controversial visit by exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in late August and the screening of a documentary about the exiled leader of China's Uighur minority, Rebiya Kadeer, in the city in September.
The city government has since come under pressure to work out measures to respond to speculation that Chinese tourists are boycotting Kaohsiung over the issues.

As part of their efforts to save local tourism, Lai and Pingtung County and Kaohsiung County officials joined the industry alliance in traveling to Hangzhou and Ningbo, where they held two tourism promotion events to spark interest in southern Taiwan as a travel destination among Chinese tour operators, Lai said.
During their visit, the delegation interacted positively with Zhejiang tourism officials and exchanged views on boosting city tourism on both sides, Lai added.

Zhejiang tourism officials said that visitors from their province account for one-fifth of total Chinese arrivals in Taiwan and told Lai they hoped the promotional campaigns would help attract more Zhejiang natives to southern Taiwan and give the tourism sector there a lift.

Lai said travel agencies in Hangzhou and Ningbo were well positioned to arrange convenient five-day packages to southern Taiwan because there are seven weekly nonstop flights between Kaohsiung International Airport and the two Chinese cities.

Tour operators have begun devising customized tours for the two Chinese travel agent delegations, and Lai said the Kaohsiung City government in particular will offer them special deals, including giving them free admission to sightseeing cruises around Kaohsiung's port.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to continue tracking down money duped by diplomatic brokers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 18:01:53 (By Chung-sen Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will continue to track down nearly US$30 million that was allegedly stolen by two diplomatic brokers three years ago, the Taipei District Prosecutors Office vowed Sunday.

Local prosecutors have maintained contact with their counterparts in Singapore and the United States in a bid to recover the US$29.8 million (NT$965 million) that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) wired to a Singapore bank on Sept. 15, 2006, ostensibly to facilitate the establishment of diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea.

The money was remitted to an account at Singapore's OCBC Bank jointly held by the two brokers, Wu Shih-Tsai, a Singaporean national, and his partner Ching Chi Ju, a Taiwanese with a U.S. passport who was commissioned by the MOFA in 2006 to help facilitate a deal to establish diplomatic ties with Papua New Guinea.

The MOFA asked Wu and Ching for a statement of account early last year after finding that by Dec. 1, 2006, the money in the joint account had disappeared without any progress being made on the initiative with Papua New Guinea.
Wu, without knowing that the MOFA had been aware of the fraud, produced a false bank statement from his own notebook computer and gave it to the ministry.

He was taken into custody by prosecutors in May 2008 and indicted for forging the bank statement and making false accusations in September 2008. He was found guilty of the charges a month later and sentenced to 28 months in prison.

The scandal came to light May 1, 2008, when a Singaporean daily reported that the Singapore High Court had approved Taiwan's application for an injunction to freeze the joint bank account held by Wu and Ching.

According to the prosecutors, Taiwan has had NT$300 million worth of bank accounts held by Wu and Ching and property Wu bought in Taipei City frozen. Some NT$70 million of the assets are in Wu's name.
The Singapore High Court ruled Saturday that the S$2.1 million (US$1.49 million) that had been in another of Wu's accounts at Singapore OCBC Bank be returned to Taiwan's authorities.
Meanwhile, Taipei prosecutors listed Ching, who is said to be living at his home in California, as one of Taiwan's most wanted fugitives last May as they continued their investigation into the case.

The Taipei District Prosecutors Office said it had asked for judicial assistance from the U.S. government in the investigation and suggested having U.S. prosecutors interrogate Ching on Taiwan's behalf or sending their own people to California to question Ching themselves.
They have yet to receive a response from the U.S. government.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to officiate meeting on security in Taichung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 18:32:10 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will preside over a briefing on security and police preparedness in Taichung on Monday, the day when China's top negotiator with Taiwan is scheduled to arrive for the latest round of high-level cross-strait talks, the Presidential Office said Sunday.

The president will listen to officials' reports and issue directives regarding public order in the central Taiwan city, where the fourth meeting between Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, and his Taiwan counterpart, Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, will take place, said Paul K. Chang, director- general of the Presidential Office's Department of Public Affairs.

Highly concerned about public order in Taichung because of plans by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to stage protests during Chen's stay there from Dec. 21-25, President Ma will preside in person over the meeting on public order, Chang said.
Presidential Office meetings on public order are usually overseen by the deputy secretary of the office, he added.
Ranking officials from the National Security Council, the National Police Agency and the Government Information Office are also expected to attend.
Chang said the Presidential Office believes Chen and his group are guests and are entitled to safety, comfort and dignity during their visit.
"We should behave ourselves with grace as hosts," Chang said.

According to a ruling Kuomintang heavyweight who spoke on condition of anonymity, Ma presided over a similar security meeting in early November 2008 before Chen Yunlin set foot on Taiwan's soil for the first time.

The DPP, however, held massive protests outside the Grand Hotel in Taipei City where Chen and his group stayed. One of the protests, staged outside the Grand Formosa Regent where Chen was having dinner, forced the Chinese diplomat to stay in the hotel until the early hours of the morning.

Ma will remind those attending Monday's meeting that if undesirable scenarios occur during Chen's visit in Taichung, law enforcement authorities should handle the situations and respond in real time, according to Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-China protest march kicks off on eve of envoy's arrival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/20/09 19:40:03 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Large crowds took to the streets in Taichung to protest the government's China policy a day before China's top negotiator on Taiwan affairs was to arrive for another round of talks on bilateral cooperation.

The massive protest march in central Taiwan was organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and pro-independence civic groups to drive home their belief that the government's strengthening of economic ties with China is undermining Taiwan's sovereign status and threatening its people's economic well-being.

DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said DPP supporters have turned out in droves to oppose the President Ma Ying-jeou administration's lack of transparency in negotiating deals with China, which prevents any form of supervision by the people and puts the country's interests at risk.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is expected to sign four agreements with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, during his stay from Dec. 21-25.
The accords will cover cooperation on fishing crew issues, double taxation, industrial product standards and agricultural quarantine.

Dubbing Sunday's protest as a march to "break the black box and protect the rice bowl, " DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan said an estimated 100,000 people were expected to join an evening rally near the city's open-air circular theater.
DPP supporters began to converge at Taichung's Anhe Road and Mincyuan Road, respectively, and long lines had formed at the two gathering points by 2:30 p.m. Sunday.

Demonstrators from central Taiwan gathered at the intersection of Jhonggang Road and Mincyuan Road and started to walk toward the rally site at 3: 30 p.m. under the leadership of Su and Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kun-huei.
Almost at the same time, protesters from northern and southern Taiwan, headed by Tsai and other DPP bigwigs, also began the march from the intersection of Anhe Road and Chaoma Road.
Both marches proceeded in an orderly fashion, with police officers and DPP members helping keep traffic flowing along the thoroughfares where the processions passed.
Braving chilly weather, demonstraters waved brightly colored anti-China and anti-government banners and placards, and in some spots the parades resembled street carnivals.

Chen Ta-chun, head of the DPP's Taichung chapter, led the demonstrators in chanting pro-independnece slogans such as "Taiwan and China, one side one country" and "Cross-Strait Affairs, Listen to the People's Voices" to boost morale.
He said he was confident that the number of protesters would reach the party's target of 100,000 when the evening rally began later in the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT will sort out principles on handling its assets by year end
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 20:00:46 (By Tyson Lu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The newly appointed secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , King Pu- tsung, said Sunday that the direction and principles the party will follow in handling its assets will be determined by the end of this year.
King made the pledge during a visit to the eastern city of Taitung, where a grassroots KMT worker urged him to boldly and resolutely deal with the controversial party asset issue.

The opposition contends that the KMT's assets were illegally obtained during its decades of authoritarian rule in the second half of the 20th century when the lines between state and party were blurred.
King was also told that the KMT has suffered from a shortage of workers in the Taitung area and that the roles of those working for the party were ill-defined.
He replied that the roles of grassroots party workers have changed with the political environment.
"In the past, their jobs focused on providing services and seeking help for constituents, but now they should help reflect the people's plight and search for problems," he said.

Fielding complaints about President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, King said that nobody is perfect and that if Ma has some shortcomings, the people around him, including King himself, will fill in the gaps.
"Chairman Ma is a man who is willing to reflect on his behavior," King told his audience.
King had been a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank, since September before being tapped to take over the party's day-to-day affairs.

While King is expected to dedicate much of his time to legislative by-elections scheduled for Jan. 9 and Feb. 27 and mayoral elections in five special municipalities in December, the party asset issue, which is often used by the opposition to attack the KMT, will also be a priority, according to King's predecessor, Chan Chuen-po.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to strive for FTAs after inking ECFA with China
DOC.DATELINE: Changhua, Taiwan, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 20:14:51 (By Wu Jhe-hao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday the government will continue its efforts to seal free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries after signing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Ma also said during a meeting with representatives of stockings manufacturers in the central county of Changhua that the government will negotiate the ECFA with China based on the principle that Taiwan is the focus and that the interests of the public come first, and he also said the document will be subject to legislative review.
The president reiterated that only Taiwan and North Korea among Asia Pacific countries have not signed FTAs with other countries in the region, which threatens to marginalize Taiwan.

He said that after the ECFA is signed, the administration will try to seal FTAs with other countries and will not ask China for its approval to sign them "because Taiwan is a sovereign independent country."

Free trade deals can only be signed if both sides are willing to do so, Ma said, but he argued that once an ECFA is signed with China, other countries will be more willing to sign FTAs with Taiwan because China's suppression of such deals would be reduced.

Earlier that day, Ma told farmers during a tour of an eustoma flower export production zone in Changhua that he has honored his pledge not to further open Taiwan's market to Chinese agricultural products since assuming office in May 2008.

He noted that of the 1,415 Chinese agricultural products allowed to be imported into Taiwan, 479 items were approved by the previous Kuomintang administration and the other 936 were approved by the Democratic Progressive Party when it was in power.
