DOC.HEADLINE: 17 local chiefs assume posts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 21:36:50 (By Andrew J. T. Liu, Lin Heng-li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The individuals elected on Dec. 5 to head 17 cities and counties in Taiwan assumed their posts Sunday with varying levels of creativity and articulated their visions for their four-year terms.

Of the 17 local chiefs, 12 are from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), four are from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and one is an independent, who quickly installed his ex-wife as his deputy.

In perhaps the most stunning debut of any of the newly elected magistrates, independent Fu Kun-chi appointed his ex-wife Hsu Chen-wei, who he apparently recently divorced, as his deputy in his inauguration ceremony.
Fu said the appointment was in line with regulations and stressed that his family "has made preparations to sacrifice for the sake of Hualien's development."

Fu said Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang inquired about his decision in the evening, and he clearly explained to him that he had completed divorce proceedings and that the appointment was legal.
Under Taiwan's laws, a married couple cannot serve as the magistrate and deputy magistrate of a county.

Fu represented the KMT as a legislator, but the party did not nominate him as its candidate in the Hualien County magistrate election because he is currently being tried in separate cases for violating securities transaction laws.
He has already been convicted of one crime, and if his appeal is rejected, he will have to relinquish his post.
Despite his legal problems, Fu ran as an independent and handily defeated the KMT's official nominee and one other rival.

He complained Sunday that the central government had tried to smear his reputation before and after the election but insisted on his innocence and vowed to do everything he could for Hualien residents.

Nantou County Magistrate Lee Chao-ching began his second term in office by offering a cash award of NT$1 million (US$30,960) to anyone who could provide a good idea on how the county's most scenic spot -- Sun Moon Lake -- could tie the knot with the West Lake in Hangzhou, in China's Zhejiang province.
Lee said that when he first assumed office four years ago, he promoted the plan without success.

"I hope all residents of the county can help me in coming with a good way or idea to stage the marriage so as to draw international attention and participation and promote the status and development of Sun Moon Lake," he said.

In Taoyuan County, former Legislator John Chih-yang Wu greeted wellwishers, including Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, his father and KMT honorary Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, past magistrates and hundreds of political and business figures, in Mandarin, Taiwanese, Hakka and aboriginal dialects.

Wu said that he hopes to become the most tolerant and loving magistrate in Taoyuan County's history, and vowed to complete major infrastructure projects, including turning the area around its international airport into an aviation city and building a mass rapid transit system, while also pushing to upgrade the county into a municipality.
Chu, who served as Taoyuan County magistrate before leaving to become vice premier in September, lauded Wu for his dynamism, expertise and ideals.
In Hsinchu County, former Legislator Chiu Ching-chun, who emerged victorious from a fierce election battle, vowed to solicit more private sector investment in the county to help improve its finances.
In Taitung County, newly elected magistrate Justin Huang reaffirmed his focus on tourism, the economy, culture, education, agriculture and care for underprivileged groups.

The former KMT legislator vowed to make the eastern Taiwan county more progressive and prosperous, before heading to a settlement center in Dawu Township to visit people who were displaced from their homes by Typhoon Morakot in August.

In Chiayi City, Huang Ming-hui began her second term in office, saying that she will focus on improving the southern Taiwan city's infrastructure and seek out opportunities to host major events to help market Chiayi and stimulate the local economy.
In Keelung City, incumbent mayor Chang Tung-jung noted that a marine science museum will open in 2012, which is expected to bring 2 million tourists to the northern Taiwan city every year.
Chang said the city will now engage in peripheral traffic network planning.

In outlying Kinmen County, which lies just kilometers from China's coast, newly elected magistrate Lee Wo-shih hopes to bring world-class infrastructure to the county so that its residents will have higher incomes, excellent environmental quality and health protection.
In Matsu, the county's new magistrate Yang Sui-sheng vowed to overcome its difficulties as an outlying island by making it a duty-free area to attract tourists from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Penghu County Magistrate Wang Chien-fa said Sunday that although the county's financial situation is dire, he will continue to push for a strong social welfare policy in his second term.

Among the four counties headed by DPP politicians, Yilan County Magistrate Lin Tsung-hsien vowed to push the county's anti-flooding efforts and sponsor the Yilan Green Expo and children's festival in the next half year.
Chiayi County has its first female magistrate, with former DPP Legislator Chang Hwa-kuan taking the helm from her predecesor Chen Ming-wen.
Chang hoped that county's administrative team will improve services and upgrade its efficiency. She also hoped that the central government will help narrow the urban-rural gap seen in the county.
In Yunlin County, Su Chih-fen said that in her second term, she will continue to push to make the county into an agriculture stronghold.

Considering the close relationship between water and people's lives, she said she will craft ecological, environmental, agricultural, water control, and education policies from the perspective of their impact on the county's water resources.
In Pingtung County, incumbent Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung launched a "Pingtung taking off" remote-control airplane to symbolize the taking off of the southern Taiwan county.

Tsao said he would work to develop the solar power industry and turn Siaoliouchiou into a low-carbon islet. With the bicycle network in the county nearing completion, he said Pingtung will be the county that puts the most effort into energy conservation and carbon emissions reduction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tens of thousands march to protest trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Taiwan, Dec. 20 (CNA) 12/20/09 22:04:22 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Tens of thousands of Taiwanese marched in the central Taiwan city of Taichung to protest the government's plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

The rally took place one day before Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , arrives here to sign four economic agreements with his Taiwan counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), but the ECFA is not on the meeting's formal agenda.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and local civic groups said the purpose of the protest was to call attention to the poor overall performance of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration and the lack of transparency in its negotiations on the ECFA with China.

Braving strong winds in temperatures of around 10 degrees Celsius, pro- independence protesters from across the country assembled in downtown Taichung for the rally after marching in two separate legs in the city.
"Taiwan is facing three problems. The first problem is Ma, the second problem is Ma. The third problem is still Ma, " DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen told the crowd.
Polls show that the president is leading Taiwan to unification (with China), she said, adding that "the biggest problem is that we have a president who is only focused on unifying with China."
Tsai said people gathered because no one knows what the president is doing, especially on the ECFA, which Ma argues Taiwan must sign or it will be marginalized.
The ECFA is expected to be included in the next round of talks between both sides, which is scheduled to take place in the first half of 2010 in China.
Tsai accused Ma of never explaining the ECFA clearly and of refusing to communicate with the people, the Legislative Yuan or the opposition on its contents.

The only beneficiaries from the ECFA are big corporations, while many ordinary people will lose their jobs because of it, Tsai contended, adding that the president has never disclosed its potential adverse impact on Taiwan's people.

An economic model run by the Ministry of Economic Affairs found that Taiwan would gain a net 260,000 jobs if an ECFA was signed, while the Council of Labor Affairs estimated it would create a net 105,000 to 125,000 jobs.
Both models acknowledged, however, that some workers in vulnerable industries could lose their jobs.
Almost all the DPP heavyweights showed up and spoke to the gathered crowd.

"If Taiwan signs the ECFA with China, President Ma should also ask China to help Taiwan sign FTAs with other countries, such as Japan and South Korea, so Taiwan will be able to trade with others as well, " said former Vice President Annette Lu.

In the days leading up to Sunday's protest rally, the DPP said it hoped to mobilize 100,000 people, and the party estimated after the event that the turnout had surpassed its goal. The Taichung City government, on the other hand, put the turnout at 31,000.

Fears that clashes would break out never materialized. Taichung City government spokesperson Tsou Mei-liang earlier said that no confrontations took place Sunday, and it was not a surprise since "the protest was legally applied for and all arrangements had been implemented beforehand."

Prior to the main rally, the protesters marched for more than two hours in Taichung's streets, and made the most noise when they walked past the Windsor Hotel, where Chen will stay during his five-day stay, to express their displeasure over the Chinese negotiator's visit.
The crowds chanted slogans such as "Taiwan and China; one country on each side" as they marched, while others expressed their views in more colorful ways.
A senior citizen from Chiayi City showed everyone a picture of Ma wearing only a swimming suit and said "this is all he does -- swim."
A protester surnamed Hsu, who came from the southern city of Tainan complained not only about the government's China policy but also security precautions taken for Chen's visit.

"We don't want a trade agreement with China. And all these barricades, security deployments and traffic controls for a Chinese representative are outrageous. The Taichung City police should remove them all."

DOC.HEADLINE: Restrictions on hiring foreign caregivers should remain: foundation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.20 (CNA) 12/20/09 22:09:34 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government should reconsider its plan to ease restrictions on hiring foreign caregivers or maids because such a move could deprive local middle-aged and older women of job opportunities, an advocacy group said Sunday.

The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) is considering allowing families that have two members in their 80s or one member older than 90 plus a toddler under one year of age to apply to hire foreign caregivers.

"On the surface, the proposed liberalization is not large, but in effect, its impact on local women, particularly those in middle or senior age groups, would be great, " said Lin Shih-chia, chairman of the Peng Wan-ju Foundation.

According to Lin, foreign caregivers who have come to Taiwan on caregiving contracts usually have to do all sorts of household chores, such as cleaning the house, washing clothes, and cooking, the jobs that in many cases are currently done by middle-aged local women.
"As a result, middle-aged and senior women's job opportunities could be affected, " Lin explained.
An initial estimate shows that at least 10,000 local women could fall victim to the proposed measure, he added.

Over the years, the foundation has offered training courses for local women who want to work as maids. In 2009 alone, Lin said, the foundation successfully helped mediate 13,442 maid contracts worth more than NT$900 million.
At the same time, Lin said, the in-home service market has grown steadily.

"The Cabinet-level CLA should not ignore potential market demand and should instead adopt measures to boost the development of this line of service which is especially suitable for middle- or senior-aged women to undertake," Lin said.
With an average service charge ranging between NT$180 and NT$250 per hour, a well-trained or trusted live-in maid can earn more than NT$30,000 a month, Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 21, or the sixth day of the 11th month of Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1620: Pilgrims on the ship Mayflower come ashore at Plymouth, Massachusetts.
1804: Mohammed Ali Jinnah, founder and first governor-general of Pakistan, is born.
1817: Governor Lachlan Macquarie formally adopts the name "Australia" for the British colony located on the continent with the same present-day name.
1876: Joseph Stalin, Soviet leader, is born.
1898: Scientists Pierre Curie and Marie Curie discover radium.
1901: The "Ching Yi Pao," a newspaper founded by Liang Chi-chao, who together with Kang Yu-wei initiated a reform movement in 1898, ceases publishing after the 100th issue.
1930: Hwang Thu-sui, Taiwan's first sculptor, dies at the age of 35.
1935: Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs" premieres in the United States.
1940: F. Scott Fitzgerald, the American author who chronicled the Jazz Age in books such as "Tender is the Night" and "The Great Gatsby," dies at the age of 44.
1945: George Smith Patton Jr., the U.S. general who led the Third Army's sweep across France and into Germany during World War II, dies in a car crash at the age of 60.
1958: Charles de Gaulle is elected president of France after a new constitution is adopted, marking the beginning of the Fifth Republic.
1968: The Apollo 8 spacecraft, as a part of the United States' Apollo program to land men on the moon, is launched.
1971: Hsieh Kuan-sheng, president of the Judicial Yuan, dies in Taipei.
1971: Kurt Waldheim, an Austrian diplomat who later become president, is chosen to be the secretary-general of the United Nations on his birthday.
1972: East and West Germany sign a treaty ending more than two decades of enmity.
1975: The convention of the World Chinese Language Education Association opens in Taipei.
1975: Oil ministers from 12 countries are taken hostage after terrorists raid an OPEC meeting in Vienna, Austria.
1975: The Executive Yuan announces that Taiwan's economy grew by 2.8 percent in 1975, with a GNP of US$14.4 billion and per capita income of US$700.
1988: Soviet cosmonauts Musa Manarov and Vladimir Titov return to earth after a record 365 days in space.
1988: A Pan American jumbo jet crashes in the Scottish border town of Lockerbie, killing all 258 people on board.
1990: The building of the ROC Navy's first missile frigate begins at the Kaohsiung shipyard of the China Shipbuilding Corp.
1991: The ruling Kuomintang wins 71 percent of the vote and 254 of the 325 seats in elections for the Second National Assembly.
1995: Under an agreement signed between Israel and the PLO in September 1995, Israeli troops withdraw from Bethlehem, ending their 28 years of occupation.
1998: Beijing sentences mainland Chinese dissidents Xu Wenli and Wang Youcai to prison terms of more than 10 years each for trying to register the China Democracy Party.
1999: Taiwan is listed as the 12th-most important maritime country in the world for the year.
2000: Taiwan's non-profit Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announces the development of a commercial software package, dubbed Fast Local Alignment for Gigabases (FLAG), allowing rapid genomic DNA searches and comparisons.
2001: The Legislative Yuan approves an amendment to the Employment Services Act allowing foreign workers to work in Taiwan up to six years instead of three years.
Confucius: "Uphold the cause of the just and put down every cause that is unjust, and the people will submit. But uphold the cause of the unjust and put down every cause that is just, then the people will not submit."

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Surprise appointment
DOC.DATELINE: 12/21/09 11:33:09 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi, who was elected on Dec. 5, assumed his post Sunday with a bomb said to be stronger than the magnitude 6.8 earthquake that struck Taiwan the day before by appointing his "ex-wife" as his deputy.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the incident:
United Daily News:

In perhaps the most stunning debut of any of the 17 newly elected local chiefs who assumed their posts en masse Sunday, Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi appointed his wife Hsu Chen-wei as his deputy at his inauguration ceremony.

Fu was a Kuomintang legislator who ran for the Hualien County magistrate seat on an independent ticket after the party failed to nominate him because he was being tried in court on several counts of violating securities transaction laws.

Fu's surpise nomination of his wife is believed to be a well-planned precautionary scheme, as he has already been convicted in one case and if he loses the appeal, he will have to relinquish his post.
The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) issued a news release at 6: 47 p.m. Sunday saying that Fu's nomination of his wife as his deputy is "invalid."
However, shortly after, at 9 p.m. the MOI issued another news release discounting what it had said earlier, apparently after being informed by Fu that he had divorced his wife three days ago.
Under Taiwan law, a married couple cannot serve as magistrate and deputy magistrate of a county. (Dec. 21, 2009)
China Times:
Fu has planned his scheme well and it seems that it cannot be dealt with under the country's laws, but will the voters be fooled by him in the long run?
His nomination of his "ex-wife" as his deputy was blatant political maneuvering aimed solely at consolidating power in the eastern county.
"How can Hualien constituents bear to be fooled by Fu like monkeys?" (Dec. 21, 2009)
Liberty Times:
MOI officials have said that they would look into whether Fu has indeed divorced his wife and whether they are still living under one roof.
"There is indeed a legal 'grey area' in the nomination (of Fu's deputy)," said Deputy Interior Minister Chien Tai-lang Sunday.
Fu said the appointment was in line with the law and stressed that his family "is prepared to make some sacrifices for the sake of Hualien's development."
Fu said he clearly explained to Chien that he had completed divorce proceedings and that the appointment was legitimate. (Dec. 21, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: China says no lack of transparency in new talks with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 11:45:40 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: China's Taiwan affairs chief dismissed allegations of a lack of transparency in the upcoming new round of trade negotiations with Taiwan, as China's top negotiator left Beijing for the island Monday.

Wang Yi, director of China's Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, said at the Beijing Capital International Airport prior to the Chinese delegation's departure that the agenda for the fourth round of China-Taiwan trade talks was determined by both sides and that there were no secret meetings.
"We hope that the people of Taiwan would understand the real situation and get the correct information," he said.
Wang's remarks came one day after Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) staged a large-scale rally to protest the Chinese delegation's visit.

Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was scheduled to arrive in Taiwan later in the day for talks with his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, Chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait dealings in the absence of official contact between the two sides.

During the meeting this week, Taiwan and China are expected to sign four economic agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Bracing for talks

TEXT.P: Taiwan is braced for a new round of high-level talks with China, as Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, is scheduled to arrive later Monday.

To avoid a recurrence of the chaos and clashes that occurred during Chen's first-ever visit to Taipei for a similar meeting last year, security authorities are on heightened alert and have made meticulous preparations.

On the eve of Chen's arrival, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party staged a massive protest march in Taichung where the talks will take place this time around. Because of comprehensive prior arrangements, the march was more like a carnival, in contrast to the heavy police deployment.
But observers have said the real test may be just beginning as some pro- independence activists have vowed to trail Chen throughout his Dec.21-25 stay in Taiwan.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:

China Times: President Ma Ying-jeou called a meeting Monday morning, with National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi, Premier Wu Den-yih, National Police Agency and Government Information Office officials among those attending for a briefing on security arrangements and police preparedness in Taichung.

Ma is concerned about the security in this latest round of cross-strait talks Dec. 21-25, in view of the serious clashes that occurred between police and DPP protesters during last year's meeting in Taipei. (Dec. 21, 2009)

United Daily News: The Taichung City government has kept secret Chen Yunlin's itinerary during his stay in Taiwan. The Government Information Office will arrange for vehicles to transport reporters to the venues and the media will not know the locations until arrival there. (Dec. 21, 2009)

United Daily News: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said even if the DPP's march ended peacefully Sunday, he wouldn't say that "the typhoon has passed," and that he will celebrate only after Chen Yunlin's safe departure from Taiwan on Dec. 25.

Hu reaffirmed that he would not interfere with the talks taking place in his city, and that he also would not prevent protesters from expressing their views. He provided shuttle buses at major transportation depots to take demonstrators to the protest areas, winning kudos for that arrangement.
He made great effort to coordinate among the various forces and tried not to lose face as the host of the meeting or to tarnish the image of Taichung. (Dec. 21, 2009)
Liberty Times: An action alliance of local civic groups announced Sunday that it will stage a series of protests after Chen's arrival.

The alliance will raise a Taiwan national flag in front of Chen's hotel Monday afternoon and will march from a church to the hotel for a rally that evening to demonstrate to Chen the will of the Taiwanese people.
The alliance said it will trail Chen like a shadow during his stay in Taiwan. (Dec. 21, 2009) enditem/pc e

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Climate crisis
DOC.DATELINE: 12/21/09 12:36:15 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A documentary featuring the climate crisis in Taiwan as a result of global warming will premiere Feb. 22.

Inspired by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore's documentary "An Inconvenient Truth, " local media celebrity Sisy Chen initiated the proposal to produce the film that documents for the first time the impact of global warming on Taiwan.
The film, produced from a Taiwan perspective, also documents climatic and environmental challenges faced by the country.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the announcement of the plan to make the documentary:
China Times:
Global warming is a fact that Taiwanese cannot avoid. "An Inconvenient truth, " produced by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore in 2006, forced the world to face the problem of global warming.

TV commentator Sisy Chen said she hopes to present a similar documentary featuring the impact of climate change "on Taiwan's future prospects." The film, titled "Plus or Minus 2 Degrees Celsius, " begins with the devastating flooding in southern Taiwan caused by Typhoon Morakot in August.

Days after the global climate change meeting ended in Copenhagen, Denmark, many of Taiwan's business tycoons -- including Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Goo, Quanta Computer Chairman Barry Lam and Yulon Group Chairman Kenneth Yen -- appeared at a press conference in Taipei on Dec. 20 to pledge their full financial and other support for Chen's documentary.

The documentary production team is trying to obtain images from a state satellite to show how severely the recent floods damaged the mountain areas. Singer and composer Kimbo Hu, known as Taiwan's father of folksong, will be shot performing the song "Beautiful Island" in scenes of a land devastated by floods.

Chen noted that if the sea level rises one meter, 11 percent of the land in Taiwan would become unusable, which she said is a reminder that climate change is not just a movie scene, but a visible "truth." (Dec. 21, 2009)
United Daily News:

Preliminarily clips of the documentary show data provided by Director of the Global Change Research Center at National Taiwan University Liu Chung-ming, which puts Taiwan on a United Nations draft list of the world's first group of climate change victims, among Vietnam, Bangladesh and the South Pacific island countries.
However, Taiwan is not a U.N. member and will therefore not be invited to join U.N. meetings on global warming, Sisy Chen said.

Chen said the documentary will be distributed to media outlets for broadcast free of charge, and also to schools, in the hope that children would be able to understand the crisis that Taiwan is facing. (Dec. 21, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Mixed voices greet China's top cross-strait negotiator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 12:57:04 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Protestors and well-wishers gathered in front of a Taichung hotel where the latest round of cross-strait talks will begin Monday, awaiting the arrival of China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , arrived in the central Taiwan city Monday.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) mobilized its supporters to vent their anger at the talks, while scores of Falun Gong practitioners held banners to press their demand for China to stop its political persecution.
Another group of more than 1,000 people from Changhua County, central Taiwan, held the banners and placards that read "Welcome Chen Yunlin."

Wang Kun-sheng, who headed the welcome group, said that there needs to be peaceful development of ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and that his group was in Taichung to "show Chen that there is not only one voice in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Police officer punished for using spay against protestors
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 13:36:22 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A police officer has been punished for using a gas spray device against protestors in Taichung City ahead of an upcoming round of trade talks between Taiwan and China, the city's Mayor Jason Hu said Monday.
The punishment came after the police officer sought to stop two citizens from entering a prohibited area outside the hotel where negotiators from Taiwan and China are set to meet later in the day.
The protestors were sent to the hospital after the use of the spray but suffered no serious injuries.

Hu said that the Taichung City police officer received an administrative disciplinary penalty for not using standard issue equipment and that further investigations are underway to clarify the incident.
More demonstrations by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are planned to protest the Chinese delegation's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interior Ministry probing legality of Hualien deputy appointment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 13:46:23 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As the new Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi is apparently trying to manipulate the law by first divorcing his wife and then appointing her as his deputy, the Ministry of the Interior is investigating whether the couple is still living under the same roof, which would disqualify her for the post.

Fu, an expelled Kuomintang member who garnered 56.37 percent of the vote, or over 85,000, to win the Dec. 5 magistrate election as an independent, shocked government officials as well as the media by announcing at his swearing in ceremony Sunday that he was appointing his "ex-wife" Hsu Chen-wei as his deputy.

The couple completed divorce proceedings three days before the appointment, according to Fu. In Taiwan, the divorce process can be completed at the household registration office once the couple presents an agreement signed by two witnesses.

Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang, said that he had called Fu Sunday evening and the divorce was confirmed. Admitting that Fu might be playing with a "grey area" of the law, Chien said that the authorities would look into whether Fu and his "ex-wife" are still living under the same roof.

Chien pointed out that it is against the law for the holder of a public office to appoint a spouse or a member of the family living under the same roof as his or her deputy. The regulation is meant to avoid conflict of interest, he added.

Article 1123 of the Civil Law rules that a person living permanently under the same roof as the head of the family will be legally recognized as a member of the family, even if the person is not a relative.
Chien said that as long as Hsu is still living with the Fu family, she would not qualify for the post.
According to Chien, the relevant authorities will decide on the case based on facts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't to increase budget for greeenhouse gas reduction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 14:34:01 (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The budget to fund energy research and development in Taiwan will be doubled in four years time and the country will strive to cut greenhouse gas emissions to the 2000 level by 2025, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.

In a report to the Legislative Yuan on the formulation and implementation of new national energy policies, MOEA officials said the energy R&D budget will be increased to NT$10 billion (US$308.64 million) in four years time.
Under the new plan, the country's carbon dioxide emissions will be gradually reduced to the 2008 level by 2020 and hopefully even earlier, by 2016, the MOEA said.
The plan calls for the aggressive development of clean energy that will account for about 15 percent of the country's total electricity capacity by 2025.
It also calls for a reduction in gasoline consumption by public offices and schools, hopefully by 7 percent by 2015.

The MOEA said it will continue to push for the upgrade of energy resources and production facilities to achieve greater efficiency. This will involve replacing old power generators with new models that use Best Available Technology (BAT) and complying with regulations on limiting emissions, in line with the overall strategy, MOEA officials said.
The ministry said it will also seek to enter international energy cooperation agreements on the import of clean coal and the development of carbon capture and storage technology and facilities.

Meanwhile, the MOEA said its incentive measures to encourage less electricity consumption have born fruit -- as evidenced by the fact that some 3.44 billion kilowatt-hours of electricity was saved nationwide in the first 11 months of this year.
"That figure is roughly equivalent to half of the total electricity consumed by Kaohsiung City residents in a year, " an MOEA official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Top China envoy says he respects different voices

TEXT.P: China's top cross-strait negotiator made a goodwill gesture to a crowd that was protesting against his visit to Taiwan, after he arrived on the island Monday for a new round of negotiations.
Chen Yunlin, chairman of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , waved amicably to a group of protesters before entering his hotel.
Chen also said at a welcoming ceremony that he "completely respects those who are voicing different opinions."
The Chinese negotiator arrived in central Taiwan 40 minutes later than scheduled as confrontations broke out among supporters of his visit and protesters at the airport.
Chen exited from one of the three main gates at the airport, avoiding pro-Taiwan independence activists who had assembled at another gate.

Chen was trapped in a Taipei hotel that was surrounded by large numbers of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and other pro-independence supporters last year when he first visited Taiwan for similar negotiations.

During this visit, the envoy will sign four economic agreements with his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, industrial product standards, inspection and certification, and the avoidance of double taxation.
Pro-independence and civic groups have vowed to stage more protests against what they described the "China-leaning" policies of President Ma Ying-jeou's administration.
Practitioners of Falun Gong, a spiritual group that has suffered heavy suppression in China, also staged a relatively quiet protest in an area across from Chen's hotel.
The Chinese delegation is scheduled to leave Taiwan Dec. 25 after completing its negotiations with the SEF and touring local tourist attractions.
(By Lee Hsi-chang, Sophia Chen, Feng Chao, Kuo Mei-lan and Alex Jiang)
