DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't Repeat Mistakes

TEXT.P: A year ago, China-bashers laid seige to a Taipei hotel to protest a visit by China's top negotiator with Taiwan, and once again, pro-independence activists staged massive street protests Sunday on the eve of a new round of high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks.
It seems that the institutionalized cross-strait talks, known as the Chiang-Chen meetings, have become a rite of expression of social sentiments and emotions.
On the surface, the massive street march in Taichung the day before seemed to heighten partisan standoff, but in essence, the event mainly reflected Taiwan's common anxiety.

The core issues to be addressed at the Dec. 22-23 meeting between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, have nothing to do with partisan, ethnic and regional differences, but rather are related to the predicament of Taiwan being gradually marginalized as a result of globalization.

No matter which party is in power, the challenges Taiwan must tackle are the same -- how to grapple with East Asia economic integration and how to protect agricultural, fishery and traditional industrial sectors that have been hardest- hit by the waves of globalization.
It is time to end the relentless accusations tossed back and forth between the ruling and opposition parties. Too much partisan confrontation only blinds us to seeing opportunities for Taiwan.
The chaos and clashes that marred last year's Chiang-Chen talks should not recur.
Smart and conscientious political parties and politicians should not only win the hearts and minds of their supporters but should also earn the respect of their opponents.

Both the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party should take this round of Chiang-Chen talks as an opportunity to give more local people an understanding of the plight Taiwan faces and rationally hammer out strategies for the country's survival under the premise of globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Wasted Talent

TEXT.P: Taiwan used to be known as Asia's anime-comic talent bank. Many riveting, stunning and highly acclaimed Hollywood computer animated special effects have been partly produced in Taiwan.
Although we have a lot of animation and comic talent, the government has paid little attention to this promising sector.
As a result, many of our outstanding cartoon and comic artists can only work as OEM contractors.

While government disregard has led to a decline of our animation and comic industry, China and South Korea have been very actively cultivating talent in this field. Despite its late start, South Korea is catching up with Japan, a world power in the field. China has built 17 hubs to bolster its anime-comic industry development.

Lured by the sector's lucrative market potential, Hollywood has been busy churning out blockbusters featuring computer animated special effects. Films such as 2012, District 9 and Avatar have proved to be worldwide box-office hits.

With this in mind, the government should take a cue from the Chinese and South Korean governments. As the first step, the government should help set up an anime-comic industry park that will facilitate the integration of education, production, capital and marketing in one shot and open up new frontiers for this knowledge-based software industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese business leaders travel with ARATS head to Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 16:03:43 (By Huang Chi-kuang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: More than a dozen business leaders traveled across the Taiwan Strait Monday with China's top negotiator to Taiwan for the latest round of cross-strait talks.

Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, arrived in the central city of Taichung that day at the head of a 79-member delegation to take part in his fourth round of talks with Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, scheduled for Dec. 21-23.

The two cross-strait intermediary bodies will meet Wednesday to discuss Chinese investment in Taiwan, prompting the Chinese business leaders to travel with Chen to learn more about the country's investment environment.

Some of the more notable delegation members include Shang Biyi, vice president of China Shipbuilding Industry Corp., Xu Lirong, executive vice president of China Ocean Shipping (Group) Company, Shi Hongxiang, vice president of the State Development & Investment Corp., Chen Lang, president of China Resources Enterprise and Liang Xiang, counselor of China Investment Corporation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 288 foundation urges eligible families to file compensation claims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 16:12:01 (By Sophia Yeh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: There are still over 4,000 cases in which claims have not been filed by families who may be entitled to compensation in relation to the February 28 Incident in 1947, according to the 228 Incident Memorial Foundation Monday.
Foundation Chairman Tsay Ching-yen called for those families to move fast to apply for the cash compensation being offered, as the application period will expire at the end of 2010.
"The foundation itself will be dissolved by March 2012, " Tsay noted.

Tsay made the call at a hearing at the Legislative Yuan, during which ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Liu Sheng-liang and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Wei-cheh urged the foundation to step up efforts to contact the affected families to allow them to file compensation claims as soon as possible.
The Feb. 28 Incident refers to a series of events in 1947 that led to a brutal crackdown by the then KMT government against the local population, particularly the intelligentsia.

In 1990, the Executive Yuan set up a task force of scholars and other experts to study the 228 Incident. The "Report of the 228 Incident" was published in 1992, and a memorial was set up in 1995 in the 228 Peace Park in Taipei City.
In October 1995, the non-profit 228 Incident Memorial Foundation was established to deal with matters relating to compensation and rehabilitation of 228 Incident victims.
Since its inception, the foundation has acknowledged a total of 7,067 compensation cases involving deaths, missing people, incarceration and defamation, Tsay said.
The foundation has so far disbursed more than NT$18.7 billion (US$577 million) in compensation to the families of the victims in over 3,000 cases, he added.

Tsay said he believes that some 4,000 families did not file claims because in most cases the notices were sent to wrong or inaccessible addresses, or the victims and their families could not be located.

Meanwhile, KMT Legislator Chiang Yi-hsiung said that some Taiwanese residents were indicted on charges of rebellion, but in the end were convicted for engaging in illegal arms deals, which would have disqualified them from applying for compensation.
"I therefore propose an amendment to the law to allow an expansion of the compensation criteria to allow more victims to receive compensation," Chiang said at the hearing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 16:39:28 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 33.64 points, or 0.43 percent, to close at 7,787.27.
The local bourse opened at 7,797.65 and fluctuated between 7,827.14 and 7,787.27 during the session.
A total of 3.74 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$106.53 billion (US$3.28 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement shares gaining the most at 0.9 percent. Machinery and electronics stocks advanced 0.7 percent, textile shares rose 0.3 percent, plastics and chemicals increased 0.2 percent, and construction issues ended the day 0.1 percent higher.

The three other major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp stocks losing the most at 0.7 percent, foodstuff stocks sliding 0.5 percent and banking and financial shares dropping 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,450 to 1,116, with 286 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$5.39 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 16:39:57 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.040 to close at NT$32.384.
A total of US$455 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.410 and dipped to a low of NT$32.355 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators warn against import of shoddy Chinese products
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 16:59:09 (By Hsu Rei-ting, Yang Shu-min and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) expressed concern Monday that shoddy goods from China will flood the Taiwan market after the two sides ink an agreement this week on product inspection.

DPP Legislator Chen Ting-fei said at a press conference that China's product inspection mechanism lacks credibility and that a bilateral agreement on industrial product standards, inspection and certification will allow flawed Chinese products to flow into Taiwan.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , are holding the fourth round of cross-strait negotiations in Taichung City Dec. 21-23.

During the meeting, four main agreements are expected to be signed on fishery cooperation, avoidance of double taxation, inspection, certification of the standards of industrial products, and the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products.

According to the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the agreement on cross-strait industrial product standards inspection and certification will cut time and costs and will benefit Taiwanese companies that export their products to China.

However, Chen argued that the agreement will also allow in Chinese products, which she said are of poor quality, citing a recent report by the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission that said from June to December, a total of 66 Chinese products, including baby strollers, baby cribs, and toys, were listed as flawed goods.
Moreover, from November to December alone, 24 Chinese products, including erasers, children clothes and sports shoes, were also identified by the European Union as shoddy products, she noted.

DPP legislator Su Chen-ching said that while Taiwan and China have signed agreements on attacking crime, expanding cooperation on food safety issues, communicable disease reporting and other issues, several crime and food safety- related issues have yet to be resolved.

Su was referring to the fact that some economic criminals including Chen Yu-hao, former head of the Tuntex Group, are still hiding in China and that no provisions have yet been made to compensate Taiwanese victims of the melamine- tainted milk powder scare that erupted in China last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP plans protests during cross-strait negotiations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 17:32:43 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) held a meeting Monday to prepare for a rapid response to any emergency situation that might crop up during talks between negotiators from Taiwan and China between Monday and Wednesday in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan said after the meeting that as a democratic and free country, Taiwan should ensure that room is given for freedom of expression and that it is inappropriate and unnecessary for the police to expand the areas in which security will be tightened during the talks.

Su gave his assurance that the protests the DPP is planning to stage in Taichung against the government's China policy in the next few days will be peaceful and rational. "They will be based on the principle that our voices will be loud but our actions will be peaceful," Su said.

He also warned those who want to protest against the visit by Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , that they should protect their personal safety and avoid being provoked by others during demonstrations.
Chen arrived in Taiwan that same day for the fourth round of talks with Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung.

Su also accused a police officer of using pepper spray on two pro-independence protesters earlier that day outside a hotel in Taichung City where Chiang and Chen were set to meet. The protesters also included several Taichung city councilors.
The two protesters were reportedly taken to a hospital but suffered no serious injuries, while the police officer was punished for using non-standard-issue equipment.
Over the coming days, the city councilors will hold several demonstrations to express their opposition to the closed-door Chiang-Chen talks.

During a Dec. 19 visit to Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Su told him that the DPP's protests will not involve any "sabotaging" behavior, to which Hu responded that while the city government respects the people's right to protest, the demonstrations should remain peaceful.
He also said he had warned the police not to overreact when facing the protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Deal on double taxation dropped from Taiwan-China talks agenda
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 17:57:48 (By Feng Chao and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: In a surprise move, Taiwan and China decided at a preliminary meeting Monday to remove the issue of double taxation from the agenda of this week's formal talks, confounding expectations that an agreement would be signed on the issue.
The move was made because of technical issues, officials from both sides said without elaborating.

The top negotiators representing Taiwan and China -- Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and Association For Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin -- will open their fourth round of talks Tuesday.
They are still expected to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: China envoy's itinerary made public at President's request
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:01:19 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Most of the itinerary of a visiting Chinese negotiator was made public Monday after President Ma Ying-jeou told the relevant government authorities to do so in a bid to allay concern over the lack of transparency in the latest round of talks between Taiwan and China.
"We seek to make every step transparent to let everyone see that there are no secret operations, " Ma told local university representatives at the Presidential Office earlier in the day.

He made the remarks as Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin and his delegation arrived in central Taiwan's Taichung City while pro-independence supporters staged a protest against the visit.

The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , which was established to handle China affairs in the absence of official ties, had previously informed the media that a section of the delegation made up of Chinese business leaders would be visiting an industrial zone and glass plants in central Taiwan.

According to an itinerary further unveiled by the authorities, the delegates will attend a banquet hosted by Miaoli Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung Dec. 23, which will be followed by a tour of a science park in Taichung, while Chen and his wife will visit the Sanyi Woodcarving Museum.
Chen will later visit the Zhenlan Temple in Dajia and meet some of the disadvantaged children being taken care of by the temple.
The next day, Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart, SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, will visit the Chung Tai Zen Center of Sunnyvale, another well-known temple.
The Chinese envoy also plans to visit an area in the central county of Nantou's Shueili township that was ravaged by Typhoon Morakot in August this year, as well as some of the typhoon victims.
In addition, he will tour Sun Moon Lake, one of Taiwan's most popular tourists attractions, before attending a dinner with Nantou Magistrate Lee Chao-ching.
The delegation is scheduled to leave Taiwan Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Warmer ties with China to boost foreign investment in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:07:34 (By Kao Chao-fen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Improving relations between Taiwan and China in 2010 will be one of a number of factors that will help attract more foreign investment in Taiwan, researchers of a leading global investment bank wrote recently.

In the report published in Barclays Capital's Emerging Markets Quarterly Outlook, researchers of the investment bank forecast that warming cross-Taiwan Strait ties would trigger more foreign institutional investor interest in Taiwan markets, particularly its equity and real estate markets.
Three specific factors -- including two unrelated to Taiwan-China relations -- would lead to the influx of foreign capital, the report said.
One is the interest rate disparity between Taiwan and the United States, which is expected to widen because the U.S. is likely to maintain its low interest rate policy for a longer period of time.
Also, a possible revision by Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) to increase the weighting of Taiwanese shares in its equity indexes could give a boost to local shares.

The key factor related to relations with China, the signing of the financial MOUs allowing banking, insurance, and securities firms in Taiwan and China to invest in each other's markets, will likely attract more Chinese funds into Taiwan, the report suggested.

Barclays Capital said net capital inflows into Taiwan's bourse reached US$7.2 billion in the third quarter of this year and contended that the trend will likely continue into the first quarter of next year.
The report, titled Sharpen Your Pencil, analyzed the future economic development of emerging markets in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, and Latin America.

In its assessment of global markets, the report concluded that the pace of economic recovery in emerging markets will slow in the near future as their respective economic stimulus packages wind down and the manufacturing sector continues its sluggish rebound.

Asia's emerging economies, however, will steadily recover buoyed by the moderate global economic upturn and strong domestic demand, leading to the slight appreciation of Asian currencies next year, the report predicted.

The South Korean won and the Indian rupee are likely to be the Asian currencies that will strengthen the most in the first quarter of 2010, and the Chinese yuan will also start a new round of appreciation, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance minister eyes luxury tax
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:30:24 (By Lin Ye-fong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der expressed support Monday for the notion of imposing a tax on luxury commodities.
Speaking at a bill-screening session at the Legislative Yuan, Lee said the imposition of such a tax would be the "right direction," but added that doing so might involve a law amendment.
Lee said he did not think the luxury tax can be imposed from 2010 because it would be a new law and would therefore take longer for the country to prepare for its enactment and implementation.
However, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lai Shyh-bao rebutted him, saying that the levying of a luxury tax would not require an amendment by the legislature.
"The luxury tax can be levied with just an administrative decree from the Executive Yuan," Lai argued.

In California, luxury tax is imposed on goods such as perfume, tobacco, deluxe cars, alcohol, jewelry and many other items. As it is levied only when the luxury product is purchased, it is also known as an excise tax.
Meanwhile, in response to a question raised by KMT Legislator Lin Teh-fu, Lee also expressed support for the levying of higher taxes on luxurious and expensive houses.

He said, however, that since real estate tax is under the jurisdiction of local governments, the tax authorities should reevaluate the value of so-called luxury mansions based on the land value and the market value of the buildings, as well as construction costs, and adjust tax rates in accordance with the reevaluation.
The finance minister declined to confirm whether higher taxes will be imposed on luxurious homes from next year.
"It depends on how fast the local governments work in this regard," Lee told Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flat panel shares rise on arrival of Chinese negotiator
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:36:56 (By Shu Wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The arrival of China's top negotiator with Taiwan lifted a number of shares Monday that stand to benefit from liberalized economic ties with China, including Taiwan's top flat panel maker AU Optronics (AUO), which rose to a five-month high.

The arrival of Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in Taiwan Monday renewed speculation that Taiwan's flat panel makers would be allowed to invest in flat panel production facilities in China early next year.

With AUO likely to be the main beneficiary of the new policy, investors sent its shares higher in early trading by the maximum 7 percent limit to a five-month intraday of NT$38.4. The stock retreated slightly later in the session to close at NT$37.95, up NT$2.05, or 5.7 percent.
It was the most traded stock on the Taiwan stock exchange Monday, with 141 million shares trading hands.
Chi Mei Optoelectronics, Taiwan's No. 2 LCD maker, rose by NT$0.3, or 1.4 percent, to close at NT$21.25.

The rise of flat panel makers shares pushed the optoelectronics sub-index higher by 1.8 percent, beating the broader market. The Taiex, the market's key barometer, edged up 33.64 points, or 0.4 percent, to close at 7,787.27.

The speculation was set off after the Commercial Times reported Monday that AUO may be allowed to set up a 7.5 generation plant in eastern China's Jiangsu Province, representing an investment of over NT$80 billion.
The report said Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs has noted that allowing Taiwan's flat panel industry to invest in China is a higher priority than allowing the semiconductor industry to do so.

The arrival of Chen, who visited AUO's headquarters in the Hsinchu Science Park when he was in Taiwan last year, also increased the possibility of AUO setting up a flat panel facility in China, the paper said.

AUO and Chi Mei both have assembly plants in China but have been barred from producing flat panels there to date. They are concerned about losing market share to foreign competitors that plan to set up advanced panel plants in China.
Meanwhile, Taiwan Glass was also a star performer on the day, as the market speculated that Chinese industry executives who came with Chen would visit the glass producer Monday.
Taiwan Glass shares rose by the maximum 7 percent, or NT$1.70, to close at NT$26.45, on volume of around 10 million shares -- its highest in the past three months.
Glass shares rose the most of any product index, gaining 5.25 percent. Machinery and electronics shares advanced 1.5 percent.

According to SinoPac Securities, Taiwan shares are expected to move higher in the first half of 2010 as economic growth reaches a peak in Q1 and a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed around mid-2010.
This week's talk's between Chen and Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung are expected to boost China-concept and ECFA-related shares in the near term, SinoPac said.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA rebuts report on signing MOU on cross-strait fishery products
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:50:02 (By Liu Chen-ching and Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said Monday that the signing of a so-called memorandum of understanding (MOU) on the exchange of information on the safety of fishery products between Taiwan and China's Fujian Province is merely an agreement between private individuals that is not legally binding.

The Liberty Times, a local daily, cited an online report carried by the China News that the Fujian Entry-Exit Inspection and Quarantine Bureau and a Taiwanese business body named the "Cross-Strait Council on Fishery Product Safety" inked in September what it described as the "Fujian-Taiwan MOU on Information Exchanges of the Quality and Safety of Fishery Products."

According to the report, the council was set up by a member of the Taiwan Society for Promotion of the Guangcai Program -- a civic group that aims to eliminate poverty and promote economic development through non-government channels and enterprises.

Luoh Hung-bin, chairman of the society, was quoted by the report as saying that his organization never agreed to the establishment of the council and that the signing of the agreement was purely the act of an individual member who has since been expelled from the society.

The COA issued a statement Monday saying that the agreement, which covers only Fujian Province, has no legal effect and is purely acivil pact because the signatory representing Taiwan is not an official agency or government-authorized organization.

The incident, however, highlights the need for the private sector to have a better dialogue mechanism between Taiwan and China on the inspection and quarantine of agricultural and fishery products, according to the COA.

It said an agreement on cooperation in the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products that is scheduled to be signed during the fourth round cross-strait talks this week, will be the first legally binding official cooperation mechanism covering the issue to be established by the authorities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"The agreement, which will govern every province of China, will strengthen the authorities on both sides of the strait in terms of the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products and bring transparency to the behavior of the private sector on either side, " it added.

The fourth round of talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kun and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits President Chen Yunlin, is scheduled to take place in Taichung City Dec. 22-23.

During the meeting, three main agreements are expected to be signed on fishery cooperation, certification of standards for industrial products, and the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT poses 5 questions to DPP chair about 'Chiang-Chen' talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec.21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:51:15 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang posed five questions to opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen Monday about her party's accusations against the economic accords to be signed by Taiwan and China later this week.

KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung brought up the questions as China's top negotiator with Taiwan -- Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- arrived in Taichung earlier in the day for talks on the agreements.
Chen was scheduled to sign the accords with his Taiwanese counterpart -- Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung -- Wednesday.

The agreements were to cover cooperation on fishing crew issues, double taxation, industrial product standards and agricultural inspection and quarantine, but as of Monday afternoon, the agreement on double taxation was withdrawn from the agenda because of "technical issues."

On the eve of Chen's arrival, the DPP and pro-independence civic groups organized a massive protest march in the central city of Taichung to voice their opposition to the KMT administration's lack of transparency in negotiating deals with China, which prevents any form of supervision by the people and puts the country's interests at risk.
In response, Lee asked Tsai to identify which of the accords or topics to be addressed at the Taichung round of talks will undermine Taiwan's sovereign status.
Second, Lee asked Tsai whether the DPP had pushed for signing of a cross-strait pact on avoidance of double taxation and cooperation on fishing crews when it was in power from May 2000 to May 2008.
"Why would the DPP oppose those policy initiatives that it itself had worked for?" Lee asked.

Third, Lee asked Tsai whether she had ever shown her trump card or bottom line before any international negotiations during her years in public service or her tenure as chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council.

Fourth, Lee asked Tsai whether the DPP has any alternative to the KMT-proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , which the KMT hopes to sign with China to protect Taiwan from being marginalized amid a growing trend toward regional economic integration.

While President Ma Ying-jeou has noted the urgency for Taiwan to reach an ECFA with China to facilitate its talks with other countries on free trade agreements, the DPP has voiced strong opposition to the proposal on concerns that it will lead to Taiwan's further reliance on China economically and eventually erode Taiwan's sovereignty.
Fifth, Lee asked Tsai to clarify her accusations that Ma has refused to communicate or have a dialogue with the opposition camp. Lee said he hoped Tsai would offer evidence to back her allegations.

Lee posed the questions after Tsai on Saturday asked Ma, who doubles as KMT chairman, whether he dared to guarantee that signing an ECFA with China would definitely enable his administration to reach FTAs with other major countries.
She also asked whether Ma dared to push China to allow Taiwan to begin FTA talks with ASEAN member states at the same time as ECFA negotiations are being held.
Third, Tsai asked whether Ma would promise to have members of his cross-strait policy planning and negotiating team publicly reveal their interests in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT urges DPP to take responsibility to avoid possible disturbances
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 18:52:37 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Monday urged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) not to shy away from its responsibility for possible disturbances during a Chinese delegation's stay in Taiwan for the latest round of cross-strait talks this week.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said the DPP is trying to give an impression that after its large anti-China march, which drew tens of thousands of demonstrators, ended peacefully Sunday, all ensuing activities will "have nothing to do with the DPP."
King said, however, that protests continued after China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin's arrival Monday and that some protesters who took part in the march Sunday had not really dispersed.
"The DPP should not shy away from its responsibility and should not act inconsistently before and after the talks begin," he added.
King was referring to the DPP's repeated call for "peace and rationality" before Sunday's march, which proceeded in a peaceful manner under the watchful eyes of a heavy deployment of police.

The fourth round of talks between Chen, the president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, and Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, open Tuesday, but Chen is expected to draw protests throughout his visit in Taiwan, which ends Dec. 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT to invite U.S. experts to talk about beef safety issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 19:05:53 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) is scheduled to hold a video conference Tuesday featuring U.S. experts who will talk about beef safety issues that have been of grave concern in Taiwan since the government lifted a ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef.

According to the AIT, the conference, titled "A Forum on U.S. Beef Safety, " will feature presentations by American food safety experts including Keith Belk, a professor at Colorado State University's Department of Animal Sciences, and Melvin Kramer, a representative of the EHA Consulting Group, Inc.

Daniel Engeljohn, deputy assistant administrator of the Office of Policy and Program Development and Inspection Service under the U.S. Department of Agriculture Food Safety, will also attend the conference, it added.
Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other related products, including ground beef and beef offal.

The decision sparked controversy in Taiwan, with opposition parties and civic groups led by the Consumers' Foundation and politicians contending that allowing imports of high-risk beef products could put consumers at risk of contracting the human form of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
With their appeals for re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef talks having been rejected by the administration, the groups have decided to push for a referendum on the issue.

Meanwhile, in order to better safeguard the public's health, the legislature proposed amending the act governing food sanitation to introduce more stringent checks on U.S. beef imports, but the amendment failed to clear the legislature floor as scheduled because of continued boycotts by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which wants its own draft of the amendment used rather than the one put forward by the ruling Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Silent protest in Taichung hopes to be the loudest
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 19:23:45 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: When the motorcade carrying Chen Yunlin, China's top negotiator with Taiwan, arrived at a Taichung hotel Monday, he was welcomed by loud air horns and chants of "Taiwan, China -- one nation on each side."
What he did not hear but could definitely see were numerous banners held high by Falun Gong practitioners, who comprised the bulk of the protesters kept at a distance by barricades.

Falun Gong is a system of spiritual beliefs and practices founded in China by Li Hongzhi in 1992. Before it was banned in China, there were 70 million to 100 million practitioners in China, according to the group's Web site.

"This is not really a protest. We're here to voice our opinion and express our views that Falun Gong practitioners are still being suppressed in China. And it's a wrong thing to do, " said a protest leader surnamed Chen.
Mr. Chen was among around 1,000 Falun Gong members who were scattered around different intersections and open areas surrounding the Windsor Hotel where Chen Yunlin is staying.
Coming from different parts of Taiwan, the Falun Gong demonstrators were easily differentiated from the so-called "political protesters", who can be identified by their loud chants.
"We probably don't say much publicly, but our determination is strong, " the Falun Gong's Chen said.

The group remained silent for much of the day, standing roadside and holding banners up to 10 meters long reading "Stop suppressing Falun Gong, " "The world needs truthfulness, compassion and forbearance" and "High-ranking Chinese Communist Party (CCP) officials were prosecuted by a Spanish judge."
A huge balloon also flew outside the hotel with an attached banner saying "stop suppressing Falun Gong."
On Nov. 18, a Spanish judge indicted five high-ranking CCP officials for their role in crimes of torture and genocide committed against Falun Gong practitioners.
Among the defendants is former Communist Party boss Jiang Zemin, widely acknowledged as the chief instigator of the campaign.

On Dec. 17, an Argentine judge indicted and ordered the local Interpol branch to seek the arrest of two high-ranking CCP officials -- Jiang and Luo Gan -- for crimes against humanity committed against Falun Gong practitioners.

"We were always peaceful in expressing our views. With our fellow practitioners still being suppressed in China, the cases in Spain and Argentina and the arrival of Chen Yunlin, we feel that this is a good time to get our messages out, " the Falun Gong's Chen said.
Hundreds of Falun Gong members practiced their rituals in a lot located across the Windsor Hotel on Monday. Chen said they will remain there for 72 consecutive hours.

Falun Gong members will also gather at Sun Moon Lake, a well-known scenic spot in the central Nantou County especially popular with Chinese tourists, when the Chinese negotiator visits there Thursday, Chen said.
The Falun Gong spokesman also noted that the police have been friendly to its group of demonstrators, Chen noted.

"They still asked a lot of questions, but that's their job. I understand that, " he said, observing that the Falun Gong has seemingly become a sensitive issue for the government because China is not happy with the group.
Taiwan's government should do more to support the group and condemn China's persecution, said a practitioner surnamed Liao, who preferred not to reveal her full name.

Liao said she has been hoping for more support from the government, particularly from President Ma Ying-jeou, who according to Liao never hesitated to show his support for the group in the past but had failed to do so since assuming office as president.

"I thought this is a human rights issue and President Ma always advocated human rights as a universal value, didn't he? On top of that, he signed two United Nations human rights conventions this past year. Honestly, I'm disappointed with him, " Liao lamented.
The Falun Gong Web site says that more than 3,300 practitioners are confirmed to have died in China as a result of abuse in police custody or other forms of persecution since 1999.
According to the U.S. State Department, there are 600,000 Falun Gong practitioners in Taiwan, making it the largest contingent of practitioners outside of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Enterprises encouraged by law to support cultural activities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 19:27:24 (By Teresa Ueng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The legislature passed Monday its first reading of a draft bill on the promotion of the cultural and creative industries, which stipulates that enterprises will be entitled to tax deductions if they donate tickets to cultural and art shows to elementary and junior high school students and members of less-privileged groups.
The draft law for the development of the cultural and creative industries stipulates that the amount of tax deductible should not surpass 10 percent of the annual turnover of the business donor.

The draft is a move to encourage enterprises to engage in cultural activities to the benefit of the public, said Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu of the ruling Kuomintang, who chaired a screening meeting for the draft bill.

Aside from the tax deductions, the bill would also provide a legal basis for the government to distribute "arts and cultural consumption vouchers" for students at elementary and junior high schools that would allow them to take part in art and cultural activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to speed up legalization of electric cars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 19:59:55 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Although electric automobiles wholly designed in Taiwan drew the limelight at the Dubai International Motor Show last week, the producer, Yulon Motor Co., complained Sunday that the government is moving at snail's pace in making it legal for the cars to be used on the roads.

Kenneth Yen, CEO of the Yulon Group, which makes the world's first electric 7-passenger MPV under the Luxgen marque, made the complaint while expressing his discontent with the government's policy on promoting the development of electric automobiles.
"On the issue of global warming, all I can do as a manufacturer is developing electric cars as soon as possible," Yen said.

"However, having now almost completed the development, I find that the cars cannot be licensed because there are still sections of the tax system that are imprecise when it comes to vehicles powered by electricity," he said.

According to Executive Yuan officials, it is the license plate tax that has blocked electric cars from being put on the road because the existing tax system only specifies taxes for traditional gasoline-powered automobiles, based on engine size.

Even though the Luxgen has acquired a license plate from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) as it has passed all acquired safety tests, it still cannot run on the road until the problem of the license tax is resolved, an MOTC official said Monday.
In response, an official of the Tax Agency under the Ministry of Finance told CNA that the agency "is handling the issue in an active manner."

Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu agreed last week to make electric cars the top priority in the government's plan to promote the development of emerging industrial sectors, instructing Minister without Portfolio Yiin Chii-ming to coordinate relevant ministries and agencies in forming measures to carry out the policy.
Under a Ministry of Economic Affairs' preliminary plan, the government from 2010 on will subsidize state-run enterprises and public transport operators that opt to purchase electric cars.
It is hoped that 65,000 electric cars will be sold within six years, creating a production value of around NT$200 billion (US$6.18 billion for the electric automobile sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai group introduces green factory
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 20:02:06 (By Carol Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou agreed Sunday to put the group's green factory under the public spotlight for the first time.
Gou said the factory, located in Tucheng, Taipei County, "does not use lights" and "operates in automated production mode to cut energy consumption."
Gou introduced his green factory at a news conference that day to promote a documentary produced by Sisy Chen, a local political commentator and TV celebrity, which will incorporate the factory.
"To cut carbon emissions, enterprises have to start with research and development, and each individual has to start with himself or herself," Gou said.
The Hon Hai group has long encouraged its staff not to buy bottled water, Gou went on, adding that in addition, he himself carries a handkerchief to reduce his use of water and tissue paper.
He called on the government to spend more on land conservation and disaster prevention for the sake of the sustainable development of the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators raise concerns before taxation agreement shelved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 20:06:59 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China decided at a preliminary meeting on Monday to remove the issue of double taxation from the agenda of their formal talks this week, confounding expectations that an agreement would be signed on the issue.

Earlier in the day, however, before the decision was announced, legislators urged the Ministry of Finance to set conditions for tax information exchanges and ensure that the agreement could not be retroactively applied.

It was not immediately clear if the issues they raised had anything to do with the surprise withdrawal of the issue from the talks, but Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said that around "70 to 80 percent" of the taxation agreement had been discussed with some unidentified technical issues still to be solved.
The two sides, therefore, decided not to sign the agreement this week but will continue to negotiate on the issue, Lee said at a press conference.

On Monday morning, the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee passed a provision insisting on limiting tax information exchanges between the two sides, and making sure the taxation agreement would not be applied retroactively.
Lee told the committee that procedures would follow the rules stipulated in the agreement and that all past cases would be deleted.
"In practice, that's how it would be anyway because there is no way we would pursue those cases," he added.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan earlier this month, Lee gave his assurance that information on individuals and companies would not be revealed during tax information exchanges between the two sides, in line with international tax treaty protocols.
Such information would only be supplied when there is a specific need to conduct audits in major cases of tax evasion, he added.
However, concerns lingered that the taxation agreement might enable China to obtain more financial information about Taiwanese businessmen operating there, which could affect their future operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Public Scrutiny

TEXT.P: As they sit down in the central Taiwan city of Taichung for a fourth round of high-level talks, we would like to remind negotiators for both sides of the Taiwan Strait that now is time to beef up dialogue and engagement mechanisms in their institutionalized negotiations.

Enhancing the transparency and credibility of negotiations between the two sides' quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- has also become more urgent and important.

The vociferous opposition expressed by core supporters of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party stems partly from their lack of access to details about the Chiang-Chen talks, and the government must work to mitigate their misgivings.
To strengthen the cross-strait negotiating framework, civic supervision and evaluation should be included.

With the ruling party controlling both the executive and legislative branches, legislative supervision is not sufficient to avert public criticism of the government's lack of transparency in handling cross-strait deals and win public trust.
Crafting an assessment system to review the results and effects of cross-strait agreements is equally important in winning social support for the government's China policy.

While pacts on tourism, air and shipping links and financial cooperation have generated some positive effects, they may not fully live up to original expectations. Such shortfalls require more mutual efforts in the future.

As to the judicial aid agreement, only if China is willing to repatriate notorious financial criminals, such as former Tuntex Chairman Chen Yu-hao, the public will come to believe that Beijing is true to its words.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan inclined to allow panel makers to invest in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 20:52:43 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is inclined to remove restrictions to allow local flat-panel manufacturers and chip foundries to set up more advanced plants in China, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Monday.

No timetable has been set, however, for when large-size panel makers would be allowed to set up panel factories across the Taiwan Strait, Shih said, though he suggested a decision might come early next year.

The government will hold inter-agency meetings to review regulations related to the issue at the end of the month, Shih said Monday at a legislative hearing. Any decisions made will be based on the premise that Taiwan's flat panel sector should keep advanced core technologies at home, he stressed.

Taiwanese panel makers are currently barred from setting up such facilities in China, although they do operate assembly plants there, and chipmakers can only invest in less advanced fabs, for fear that Taiwan could lose its cutting-edge technologies to its political rival.

Shih was responding to speculation that the government has decided to lift the ban after a local newspaper report said AU Optronics Corp. (AUO) , the world's third-largest flat- panel maker, will set up a 7.5-generation liquid-crystal- display (LCD) plant in Jiangsu, China, to produce television screens bigger than 40 inches.
The plant, requiring an investment of NT$80 billion, would reportedly produce flat panels for televisions to meet growing demand in China.

Last week, Shih said flat panel makers could begin setting up manufacturing facilities in China in the first quarter of 2010, while chip foundries will be allowed to do so in the second quarter of the year.

The arrival of Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in Taiwan Monday for formal talks with his Taiwan counterpart also renewed speculation that Taiwan's flat panel makers would be allowed to invest in China.

The government's plans to ease the restrictions came after the world's two largest flat panel makers, South Korea's Samsung Electronics Co. and LG Display Co., said they plan to set up manufacturing facilities in China to take advantage of strong demand there.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China to press ahead with trade pact discussions
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 21:06:51 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China will step up discussions on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), a local official involved in the negotiations said Monday as the two countries prepared for formal talks on other economic issues set to begin Tuesday.

An ECFA will not necessarily be signed during the next round of talks, but both sides are willing to intensively discuss the proposed trade pact in the near future, Kao Koong-lian, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, told the Central News Agency following a meeting earlier in the day with his Chinese counterpart Zheng Lizhong.

The SEF and Zheng's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait communications in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.

The trade pact and intellectual property rights will be the main issues on the agenda for the fifth round of negotiations, he confirmed, but while the two sides will hold intensive discussions, the signing of the ECFA will happen when the time is ripe.
From both theoretical and practical perspectives, the trade pact is likely to provide greater benefit to a smaller economy, Kao said in defending the controversial proposal.
"It is quite clear which side of the Taiwan Strait is smaller, " he said.

Nevertheless, critics, including Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), believe that the pact would allow in a flood of cheap Chinese products, cause job losses and jeopardize the island's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessmen in China unwilling to reveal their assets
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 21:09:03 (By Chang Ming-kun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese businessmen in China are generally not enthusiastic about a proposed cross-strait taxation agreement because they are not willing to reveal their assets, a Taiwanese businessman in China said after the deal was temporarily shelved.

The businessman, who declined to be identified, told the Central News Agency that as far as he knew, many Taiwanese investing in China operate in gray areas of China's tax system to avoid paying taxes or reducing their tax burden.

The agreement on double taxation avoidance was to have been signed at the fourth round of negotiations between Chiang Pin- kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for the Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), from Dec. 22-23.

Reluctance of Taiwanese businessmen to reveal their financial status was cited as one of the main reasons that representatives of the two sides decided at a preparatory meeting Monday afternoon that signing the taxation agreement should be put off until some "technical issues" are resolved.

The businessman pointed out that the tax systems in Taiwan and China are quite different. Tax collection arms of local governments in China might prey on Taiwanese businesses to help meet their tax revenue targets, because the underdeveloped system would give tax officials unlimited authority.
"If you asked 100 Taiwanese businessmen, 100 of them would suggest that the assets should not be revealed," he said.
If personal assets are required to be disclosed in the future, the businessman said he could not think of any benefits the pact would have for Taiwanese businessmen in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: China envoy gets bird's-eye view of Taichung City
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 21:10:52 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A visiting Chinese negotiator headed to the top of two tall buildings in Taichung to get a bird's-eye view of the central city Monday, one day before formal talks between Taiwan and China were to get underway.

Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), and his wife were given a tour of a luxury penthouse apartment and a hotel overlooking the city, Taichung's Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi said.
The arrangement, which allowed Chen to quickly get a feel for the layout of the city, was made in consideration of his tight schedule in Taiwan.

Chen, accompanied by Taiwan's chief negotiator in the talks, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, enjoyed local snacks and fruit during his visits to the buildings, Hsiao said.

The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait communications in the absence of official contacts between the two sides.
Chen's visit has been greeted by both proponents and opponents of his visit, who gathered around the hotel in downtown Taichung where he is staying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scholars elected fellows of the U.S. top scientific society
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 21:13:33 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top academic institute Academia Sinica announced Monday that four of its member scholars have been elected fellows of the American Association for the Advanced of Science (AAAS), a prestigious U.S.-based scientific association.

Academicians Shen Yuen-ron and Jen Sheen and distinguished research fellows Chen Chung-hsuan and Yu Su-may will be conferred the honor at the AAAS Fellows Forum on Feb. 20 during the 2010 AAAS Annual Meeting in San Diego, according to an Academia Sinica press statement.

This year, a total of 531 members of AAAS were elected by their peers as fellows in 24 different sections, the statement said. Shen and Chen were elected in the physics and chemistry sections, respectively, while Sheen and Yu were both elected to the biological sciences section.

According to the statement, Shen, who is a professor emeritus of the Department of Physics at the University of California, Berkeley, was elected for his pioneering use of lasers to investigate nonlinear interactions of light and matter.

Sheen, who is a professor of the Department of Genetics at Harvard Medical School, was elected for her seminal studies of signaling pathways in plants, which has unraveled molecular mechanisms that are conserved from plants to humans, it added.

"The studies of these master regulators have illuminated research in mammalian and human systems, and provided new insights into genetic manipulation of plants for agricultural improvement and environmental protection," the Academia Sinica said.

Chen was elected for his distinguished contributions to ultra-sensitive detection and biological mass spectrometry technology development, while Yu was elected for her functional genomics and molecular biology research in rice and for her highly successful developments in plant biotechnologies.

Founded in 1848, the AAAS is the world's largest general scientific society and includes about 262 affiliated societies and academies of science. The mission of the non-profit association is to advance science and serve society through initiatives in areas including science policy, international programs and science education.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ECFA talks' brightest spot of 4th Chiang-Chen meeting: Beijing
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, Dec.21 (CNA) 12/21/09 21:19:41 (By Huang Chi-kuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Preliminary discussions on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) across the Taiwan Strait will be the "brightest spot" of the current round of high-level cross-strait talks in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

Reaching such a deal -- a comprehensive accord that would cover market access, economic cooperation in areas such as intellectual property enforcement, and an early harvest program that would lower tariffs on some key commodities -- is one of President Ma Ying-jeou's main goals in office.

Wang Yi, China's point man on cross-strait engagements in his capacity as director of the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, told the Central News Agency Monday that although the trade pact is not on the agenda of this week's cross-strait talks, negotiators from both sides are expected to exchange views on relevant topics.

"Since experts from both sides have developed sound studies on the problems involved and have also reached positive conclusions through joint research and discussions, we hope the preliminary talks can create a good opportunity to activate ECFA negotiations, " Wang said after seeing off China's delegation to the talks Monday morning.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , will hold formal talks with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, Tuesday on the signing of three agreements that will cover cooperation on fishing crew issues, industrial product standards and agricultural quarantine.

Prior to his departure for Taiwan, Chen said in Beijing last Friday that although the two sides will not sign any documents on the proposed ECFA deal, he is likely to exchange views with Chiang on the opening of expert-level ECFA talks next year during their meeting in Taichung on Dec. 22.
The statements by Chen and Wang clearly hinted that the Taichung round of the Chiang-Chen talks will be critical to progress in the ECFA deal.

Authoritative Chinese sources said expert-level talks refer to consultations between officials from both sides to discuss issues under the SEF-ARATS framework in their private capacity as specialists, as China is still reluctant to accept direct official contacts, which it fears would imply its recognition of Taiwan as a sovereign state.
According to Wang, the ECFA deal will be confined to economic issues and will not touch on any sensitive or contentious political issues.

As ECFA involves many complicated issues, inclduing market access, tariff concessions and service trade, and Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps have not yet reached a consensus on the deal, it remains to be seen when formal talks on the topic can take off.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan pressing to recover funds embezzled in diplomatic scandal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 22:34:36 (By Lin Chung-sen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese prosecutors are taking civil action to retrieve the more than NT$200 million (US$8.58 million) frozen in several Singapore bank accounts held by Ching Chi Ju, one of the two middlemen involved in Taiwan's abortive bid to buy diplomatic relations with Papua New Guinea.

The move is the prosecutors latest effort to recover all of the US$29.8 million that Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) wired into a joint account held by Wu Shih-tsai and Ching in Singapore's OCBC Bank on Sept. 15, 2006 to facilitate the diplomatic initiative.

Taiwanese authorities found that the money had disappeared by December 2006 without any progress being made in developing ties with the Pacific country and concluded that Wu and Ching embezzled most of the funds.
Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs filed a civil suit via its representative office with Singapore's High Court against Wu and Ching last year to demand repayment of the sum in full.

The agency received good news on Saturday when Singapore's high court ordered OCBC Bank to remit back to Taiwan the sum of S$2.1 million (US$1.49 million) that had been frozen in an account held by Wu, a Singaporean national.
Local prosecutors have also sought the help of their Singaporean counterparts to investigate the flow of funds held by the two middlemen.

At the same time, they have seized two houses Wu bought using the funds he embezzled and frozen US$1.5 million in a Taiwan bank account he held and NT$70 million worth of structured notes and other financial instruments in his name, according to the source.
Prosecutors to date have frozen nearly NT$400 million worth of assets held by the two suspects, the source added.
Singapre's high court is scheduled to hold a hearing on Ching's case in February 2010.

Wu is presently serving time in a Taiwan jail after he was convicted in October 2008 of forgery and making false accusations and sentenced to 28 months in jail. He began serving the sentence in May 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: DPP Pragmatism

TEXT.P: We keenly hope that the peaceful and rational protest against the government's China policy held by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday will mark the start of shift in the DPP's vision of cross-strait relations and a new pragmatic attitude on the issue.

The DPP's opposition to the present mode of cross-strait interaction bucks mainstream aspirations as most local people yearn to see cross-strait peace and cooperation in creating prosperity and mutual benefits.
The party could put its future at risk if it continues its opposition to cross- strait engagements for opposition's sake.
Here are some suggestions for the DPP leadership:

-- The party should consider "critical acceptance" of institutionalized cross-strait talks known as the Chiang-Chen while continuing to monitor and criticize deficiencies and flaws in those engagements.

-- The party should study the feasibility of DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen meeting with China's Chen Yunlin. As Taiwan's largest opposition party, the DPP can convey its perspective or vision on cross-strait relations to Chinese leaders through such a meeting.

-- The party should study the extent of the impact of cross-strait issues to its voter appeal. The DPP's strong protest against the current round of Taiwan- China talks is believed to be related to its stronger-than-expected showing in the Dec. 5 local elections, but it should cool-headedly examine whether its anti-China policy is truly helpful to its electoral fate. Misperception could misinform policy and ultimately stymie the party's development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei book fair to open in January, will showcase France
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 22:59:57 (By Yulia Chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei International Book Exhibition (TIBE) , set to open Jan. 27, 2010, will host record-setting numbers of French guests and events as it showcases France as the theme country.

According to the Taipei Book Fair Foundation, the organizer of Asia's biggest book fair, France was chosen as the theme country because books in French and translated from French into Chinese have enjoyed steady growth in Taiwan in recent years.
Paulina Lin, director of the foundation said the sales of books translated from French in 2008 rose 28 percent from 2007.

Foundation Chairman Linden Lin said France will send a record 40 people to participate in the exhibition, including renowned writers Muriel Barbery and Philippe Claudel, and the number of special activities held to celebrate the theme country will also be the highest in the show's history.
Some 2,500 of the latest French publications, will go on display, and the National Library of France is preparing to exhibit some of its volumes from between the 18th and 20th centuries.

Among other events, a publishing forum will be held at the book fair for French and Taiwanese publishers to exchange their experiences and an exhibit featuring the picture book "Taiwan-Treasure Island" by French illustrator Nicole Lambert will also be launched.

The fair will take place from Jan. 27 to Feb. 1 at the three exhibition halls of the Taipei World Trade Center, with Hall 1 reserved for international publishers, Hall 2 for animation and comic books, and Hall 3 for children's books.

DOC.HEADLINE: Draft bill offers tax incentives to firms headquartered in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 23:04:44 (By Tang Pei-chun and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A draft bill offering special tax incentives to businesses headquartered in Taiwan is expected to pass the Legislative Yuan Tuesday and take effect starting on Jan. 1, 2010.

A Ministry of Economic Affairs spokesman said that with the implementation of the new bill, Taiwanese businesses with their operating headquarters in Taiwan will be eligible for tax breaks, including receiving tax exemptions for certain categories of income.

Business income from research and development projects and patent rights and profits from investments in related overseas enterprises will not be taxed, while income from other operations will be taxed at 20 percent, the standard corporate income tax rate in Taiwan beginning in 2010.

Multinational companies that establish their headquarters in Taiwan will receive an even deeper tax break. Their corporate income will be taxed at a fixed 15 percent rate while enjoying the same tax exemptions for specific categories of income.

The spokesman said the draft bill is aimed at attracting more multinational companies to set up operational headquarters in Taiwan. He estimated that the global or regional headquarters of an international business could create at least 1,000 job opportunities and contribute tax revenues of NT$3 billion annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiang waxes poetic in lauding cross-strait achievements
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 21 (CNA) 12/21/09 23:13:50 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , recited a poem he composed during a meeting with his Chinese counterpart Monday evening to highlight their achievements in three previous rounds of talks, saying that decades of hostility were "unrelated to winning or losing" and that "through negotiations, world peace can be achieved."

The SEF chairman hosted a dinner to welcome Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for the Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , who is heading China's delegation at this week's round of cross-strait negotiations to be held Dec. 22-23.
Chen also showed his sentimental side at the party, saying that he found it amazing that many issues that had built up over the past six decades had been resolved in the past 18 months.
He said he felt pride whenever thinking about the nine bridges that they had built, referring to the nine cross-strait agreements signed in the previous rounds of negotiations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 22, or the seventh day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1666: Shah Jahan, the mighty Mogul emperor of India who built the Taj Mahal as a mausoleum for his beloved wife Mumtaz-i-Mahal, dies at the age of 74.
1771: Spain agrees to cede the Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic to Britain.
1775: Andre Ampere, the French physicist and discoverer of electromagnets who gave his name to the "amp" as a unit of electricity, is born.
1901: After a 64-year reign, Queen Victoria, whose sense of duty and strict moral code had great influence on 19th-century British society, dies at Osborne House on the Isle of Wight at the age of 81.
1905: Tsarist troops fire salvo after close-range salvo into a crowd in St. Petersburg, Russia, leaving the snow red with the blood of at least 500 strikers.
1922: Pope Benedict XV, originally Giacomo della Chiesa, who sponsored World War I relief efforts and sought to mediate peace, dies in Rome. He was succeeded by Pope Pius XI.
1924: Ramsay MacDonald becomes Britain's first Labor prime minister, replacing Stanley Baldwin.
1935: After long negotiations, Japan pays 140 million yen for Soviet interests in the Chinese Eastern Railway, the last legal trace of Russian influence in Manchuria.
1944: Allied landings begin at Arizo, Italy, involving an estimated 50,000 U.S. and British troops.
1945: More than 500 U.S. warplanes launch air-raids on Okinawa and Taiwan.
1945: The land route to China -- the Ledo Road across Burma from India to China -- reopens.
1946: U.S. President Harry Truman orders the establishment of the Central Intelligence Agency.
1949: The guerrilla army of China's Mao Tse-tung marches toward Beijing after crossing the Yangtze River to defeat the Nationalist army at Huai Hai north of Beijing.
1955: Adm. Felix B. Stump, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, says that the United States will help defend Taiwan if attacked following the signing of the Sino-American Mutual Defense Treaty in Washington on Dec. 3, 1954.
1965: Peng Ming-min, a professor at National Taiwan University, and two students, are charged with subversion against the government by military prosecutors.
1973: Prince Tuipelehake, C.B.E., prime minister of the Kingdom of Tonga, arrives in Taipei for a one-week visit.
1973: Lyndon B. Johnson, the 36th U.S. president, who succeeded John F. Kennedy, dies of a heart attack in Texas at the age of 64.
1975: Nobutaka Shikanai, president of the Sankei Shimbun newspaper and the Fuji Television Corporation of Japan, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1979: Demonstrations are held at Kaohsiung railway station and Chiaotou township in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung County against the arrest of Yu Teng-fa for sedition.
1980: Dr. Andrei Dimitrievich Sakharov, the Soviet physicist who helped develop the first Soviet hydrogen bomb, is arrested, stripped of his honor and banished to Gorky from Moscow. An outspoken advocate of human rights and nuclear disarmament, he won the 1975 Nobel Peace Prize.
1986: Typhoon Wayne blasts across central and southern Taiwan and the offshore island county of Penghu, killing 256 people and causing property losses estimated at NT$11.5 billion. The typhoon damage is the heaviest in 20 years, and the Executive Yuan allocates NT$1 billion to help the victims.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives the chiefs of administrative branches under the Executive Yuan, and urges them and other government officials to persevere in discharging their duties and to endeavor to promote political reform.
1990: The Yugoslav Communist Party renounces its monopoly on power after 45 years of rule.
1996: The Pentagon announces for the first time the size of the U.S. chemical weapons arsenal, and says all 3.6 million weapons will be destroyed by 2004.
2000: Taiwan's Wei Yun-chieh shoots a five-under-par 67 to win the Chunghua Cup Women's Golf Tournament, the first leg of the 2000 Women's Asian Circuit, with a three-day total of 213.
2001: ROC Government Information Office Director-General Su Tzeng-ping conveys his congratulations to Ang Lee, a Taiwan-born director whose "Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon" won the 58th Golden Globe best director and best foreign film awards.
2002: U.S. Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Market Access and Compliance William H. Lash, III arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
2002: Republic of Chad Ambassador to the Republic of China Hissein Brahim Taha presents his credentials to President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Those who know it are not as those who love it; those who love it are not as those who find their joy in it."
