DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China open new round of talks on economic issues
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 11:20:12 (By Chou Hui-ying, Lin Shu-yuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China's top negotiators formally opened their latest round of talks Tuesday following a surprise announcement a day earlier that a planned agreement on double taxation avoidance had been removed from the meeting's agenda.

"Both sides had reached a consensus on the main content of the agreement on avoiding double taxation, " said Chiang Pin-kung, the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , in his opening remarks.
"On the technical front, however, both sides believe that more time is needed," Chiang explained.
Never in the previous three rounds of the carefully scripted Chiang-Chen talks had the two sides put a planned agreement on hold just before the two negotiators met formally to seal the deals.

A number of factors were cited by local media as contributing to the last minute snag. Some reports suggested the two sides succumbed to mounting pressure from Taiwanese-invested companies in China that were worried they would have to pay higher taxes under the new agreement.
Others zeroed in on a possible sovereignty-related dispute.

The proposed tax agreement is based on the OECD (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) standard, which uses a "state to state" framework, and the two sides were reportedly unable to come up with language that papered over wording in some clauses that touched on the sovereignty issue, according to reports of the Economic Daily News.
The negotiators are still expected to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification.

For his part, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, representing China, said that both sides will "exchange ideas on the principle" of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) during this round.
The talks, which started at 9 a.m., are expected to conclude at 2:30 p.m., with both sides holding separate press conferences on the outcome.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Tax talks break down
DOC.DATELINE: 12/22/09 11:46:26 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Last-minute negotiations on a double taxation avoidance agreement between Taiwan and China broke down Monday because of "technical" issues, but both sides agreed to restart talks as soon as possible and sign the agreement when "the time is ripe."

Negotiators representing Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) decided to remove the double taxation issue from the agenda of their formal talks Dec. 22-23, confounding expectations that an accord would be signed on the issue.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the matter:
China Times:

SEF officials attributed the breakdown of the double taxation talks to the fact that officials from certain Beijing offices had different voices at the last minute and wanted some adjustments made to the previously reached consensus.
Taiwanese officials, however, were skeptical that the changes would be acceptable to Taiwan, prompting the Executive Yuan to decide to shelve the talks.
It was alleged that the crux of the breakdown was that Beijing officials wanted Taiwanese businessmen operating in China to be excluded from the list for preferential tax rates.
But Finance Minister Lee Sush-der declined to confirm the rumors, saying only that "some room should be left" for future talks. (Dec. 22, 2009)
Liberty Times:
The content of the cross-strait talks on the avoidance of double taxation was not only blurred and ambiguous, a proposed agreement on the issue was removed from the agenda at the last minute.

Some ruling Kuomintang legislators said Monday that they did not understand the content of a Ministry of Finance (MOF) advertisement run in local newspapers to explain the tax deal and lashed out at the MOF for wasting taxpayer money by spending NT$4 million on the ad campaign prior to the opening of the talks. (Dec. 22, 2009)
United Daily News:
The breakdown of the cross-strait taxation talks certainly was not good news for law-abiding companies, while allowing firms with a knack for "tax manipulation" to let out a sigh of relief.

Rock Hsu, chairman of the Kinpo Group, which runs several high-tech manufacturing operations in China, said the agreement on avoiding double taxation needed to be signed in the long run to secure sustainable development.

Nevertheless, a Shanghai-based Taiwanese businessman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, welcomed the breakdown, saying that with local tax laws in China incomplete, leaving too much discretion to Chinese administrators, the agreement would not help Taiwanese companies there.
"The Taiwanese would be in big trouble once their assets and incomes were exposed," he asserted. (Dec. 22, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Protests
DOC.DATELINE: 12/22/09 12:13:46 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relation Across the Taiwan Straits, arrived in Taichung, central Taiwan, Monday as scheduled for the latest round of cross-strait talks.
Different voices greeted the arrival of China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the event:
United Daily News:
"The Communists have run away, " blasted pro-independence "pan-green" supporters who had waited for Chen outside the main entrance to Taichung's Ching Chuang Kang Airport for hours in chilly winds.

In contrast, supporters of the "pan-blue" camp inclined to favor Taiwan's improving ties with China applauded the police's strategy of deception to deploy massive personnel outside the airport terminal while ferrying Chen away on another route. Both members of the two groups missed the motorcade that took Chen and his entourage to Taichung's Windsor Hotel.
Upon his arrival, Chen said he " completely respects those who voice different opinions." (Dec. 22, 2009)
China Times:

President Ma Ying-jeou requested that Chen's itinerary in Taiwan be made public and transparent in order to prevent misunderstandings or people to be misled. He also highlighted protecting the people's right of assembly as the goal of law- enforcement, reminding the police to avoid abusing power while maintaining order. (Dec. 22, 2009)
Liberty Times:

Following President Ma's request to keep Chen's itinerary in Taiwan transparent, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart ARATS finally made public on Monday a rough itinerary that included some changes from the reported original plan for Chen's visit.

Chen will not visit the temporary shelter for Typhoon Morakot victims in Shueli Township in central Taiwan's Nantou County as was planned but will instead visit a bridge in the township destroyed in the typhoon.
In addition, the plan to sail on popular Sun Moon Lake has also been canceled out of safety concerns. (Dec. 22, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China post offices cooperate to promote online shopping
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 12:51:52 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's postal service and its Chinese counterpart have reached agreement on a framework of cooperation that opens the way for them to launch joint online shopping services, an official at state-run Chunghwa Post Co. said Tuesday.

Tseng Chin-hsiung, director of Chunghwa Post's Department of Mail Business, said it is hoped that the company will be able to open its virtual shop on the Beijing-based China Post Web site next year, and vice versa.
The plan is for Chunghwa Post to feature a "China pavilion" on its Web site and for the China Post Group to include a "Taiwan pavilion" on its site, Tseng said.
Products in the shops will all be carefully inspected to ensure that online shoppers will not receive substandard goods, he noted.

Chunghwa Post President Hu Sheue-yun said talks on e-business cooperation between the two post offices have been conducted for years. The two sides finally reached a consensus on setting up reciprocal shopping platforms, he said, but some details still have to be finalized.
Tseng explained that some technical issues, such as computer connections, also remain unresolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: Strict measures keep beef parts at bay, DOH asserts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 13:23:47 (by Li-ting Chen, Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top health official assured the public Tuesday that strict measures, known as the "three controls" and "five certifications, " have indeed been effective in keeping potentially hazardous beef parts from the United States out of Taiwan.

Leading off the government's planned three-day public briefing on the issue of U.S. beef imports, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said the DOH also supports the inclusion of the "three controls" and "five certifications" in a proposed amendment to the Act Governing Food Sanitation.
The so-called three controls refer to setting controls on beef imports at the source, at borders and in markets.

The five certifications refer to verifying certification documents, checking that shipments are marked with detailed product information, opening a high percentage of cartons of imported beef to check the product, conducting food safety tests, and being able to get information on suspected problem products immediately, according to DOH officials.
Meanwhile, Yaung said he respects efforts made by civic groups to push for a nationwide referendum on whether Taiwan should restart beef talks with the United States.

Yaung's briefing came as the first of three briefings the government will hold in the coming days to explain what it is doing to keep U.S. beef parts that critics contend pose a health risk, such as ground beef and beef offal, at bay.

The briefing comes in response to a public outcry in Taiwan over the lifting of a ban against U.S. bone-in beef, offal and ground beef Nov. 2 based on a protocol signed by Taipei and Washington in October.
Other agencies, including the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, are scheduled to brief the media Wednesday and Thursday, respectively.

The campaign is the latest effort by an administration heavily maligned for its poor public relations skills to explain its stance on a key issue. It has also recently launched a public relations campaign to present its position on a controversial proposed trade pact with China.

Meanwhile, legislators will continue to debate the U.S. beef issue Tuesday. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has boycotted an amendment that would officially allow imports of bone-in beef and other U.S. beef products since the ruling Kuomintang caucus put the bill up for consideration for the first time on Nov. 17.

The DPP caucus insists that the law must prohibit the import of products such as offal, ground beef, spinal cords, brains, and skulls, which critics of the U.S. beef deal suggest are potentially hazardous to human health but Washington argues are safe.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Hoping for More Rational Discussion

TEXT.P: UMC honorary chairman Robert Tsao ran large ads in major newspapers Monday urging President Ma Ying-jeou to put aside his "three no's" policies -- no unification, no de jure independence and no use of force -- and boldly and courageously decide to actively promote the formulation of a law for cross- strait peace.

For too long, discussions on cross-strait issues have been polarized. But we think it is futile to discuss unification or independence for Taiwan for it will never come to any conclusion or consensus.
Unification vs. independence should no longer be the focus. Rather, we should consider, under the premises of peace and democracy, which options or formulas will build mutual trust and assistance.

We know that in Taiwan's current political atmosphere, those initiating this kind of discussion will be "branded" as "tilting toward China " "pro- unification, " or "selling out Taiwan." But can the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and main opposition Democratic Progressive Party avoid the debate on China policy just because of the fear of being tagged?
The KMT now controls over two-thirds of the seats in the legislature, and Ma was elected into presidency by a big margin. The people did not expect an administration rooted in procrastination.

We believe that Ma has displayed a ruling style of "avoiding disputes or controversy" since taking office in May 2008, but the result of such an attitude will be to "give up management, " and to "forgo shouldering responsibility."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan negotiator brings up lack of Chinese action on past deals
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 14:21:42 (By Chou Hui-ying, Lin Shu-yuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator complained about the lagging implementation of previous agreements signed by Taiwan and China on tourist arrivals and nonstop flights at the opening of the latest round of talks between Taiwan and China Tuesday.

The average daily number of Chinese tourist arrivals has failed to meet the goal set by both sides, said Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), in his opening remarks at the meeting being held in Taichung.

He also expressed disappointment that the number of nonstop passenger flights had failed to meet demand and voiced concerns over China's handling of compensation requests for melamine-tainted products shipped from China and its failure to repatriate wanted Taiwanese economic criminals.
Chinese milk products were found to be contaminated by the industrial chemical last year, leading to heavy losses for Taiwanese importers who put in claims for compensation.

Offering a positive response, Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), said he believed that the problems can be solved based on the goodwill communications established over the past year.

"Some problems occurred after we signed the agreements. Some agreements have yet to be realized or realized in full, " Chen said. "Everybody feels we need to increase flights. We have already begun consultations on these issues."

Despite lingering problems over past deals, the negotiators are expected to sign agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification.
The opening remarks from both sides were followed by a round of closed-door talks, which are expected to conclude Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators support putting off signing of cross-strait tax deal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 14:24:24 (By Huang Ming-si and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that he was glad to see that the government has insisted on safeguarding Taiwan's sovereignty and the people's welfare by not signing a cross-strait tax agreement before a dispute over tax jurisdictions was resolved.

The double taxation avoidance agreement was one of four pacts expected to be signed between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) during negotiations being held this week in Taichung, central Taiwan.

But representatives of the two parties decided at a preparatory meeting Monday afternoon that the proposed tax agreement needed to be shelved until lingering "technical issues" were dealt with at a later date.

Wang disclosed that he was told by Premier Wu Den-yih last week that the proposed agreement might not be concluded at this week's meeting. According to Wang, Wu said that no consensus on tax rates and how tax jurisidictions would be defined had been reached.
Acknowledging that both sides have their respective positions, Wang said that it is important to comply with international practice.
Since Taiwan's position is more in line with international practice, "of course, we should stand our ground," said Wang.

Meanwhile, legislators of both the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) voiced their support for putting off the signing of such an agreement, voicing concerns about problems related to the different taxation systems and protection of personal information.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Schizophrenic 'Pan-blue' Voters

TEXT.P: Pan-blue supporters think the pan-green camp's support for disgraced former President Chen Shui-bian is incredible, but it is also incredible to see them support Fu Kun-chi, originally a member of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who ran as an independent to win the race for magistrate by a huge margin in Hualien county.

Chen was engulfed in corruption, but Fu has been implicated in two economic crimes. Fu's involvement in insider trading has seriously undermined the order of financial markets and the interests of the public.
We wonder why pan-blue voters in Hualien, a pan-blue stronghold, would condemn Chen and condone Fu?
If we look at pan-blue voters who support Fu and deep-green voters who support Chen, we will see how similar they are. This is not an error of democracy, but a tragedy of populist politics.
Now Fu has unveiled his ace up his sleeve by appointing his ex-wife Hsu Chen- wei, whom he divorced only days before his inauguration, as his deputy.

The move has demonstrated that he is preparing to serve his term in jail after a local court makes a final ruling on his appeal of an insider trading conviction and that he will pull the strings from behind bars.
Such a self-staged drama should not be allowed to pass, and the Interior Ministry has no reason to accept such an outrageous appointment.

The KMT should also engage in soul-searching. Both Taitung and Hualien have the same drama being played out -- using divorce to manipulate the political situation -- but the KMT has watched it happen and let it continue. How can it face the simple people in the two counties and the support of pan-blue supporters?

DOC.HEADLINE: Academia Sinica predicts economic growth of 4.73% next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 15:44:43 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will emerge from the pall cast by the global economic downturn to return to positive growth in 2010, Academia Sinica, the country's top academic research institute, said on Tuesday.

Academia Sinica's Institute of Economics predicted that Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) will grow 4.73 percent next year, the most optimistic forecast of any made to date by a domestic economic research institution.

The Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research has offered the next most optimistic assessment, forecasting growth of 4.66 percent, followed by estimates of 4.57 percent by the Polaris Research Institute, 4.45 percent by the Taiwan Research Institute and 4.21 percent by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research.
The Executive Yuan's Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has forecast economic growth of 4.39 percent in 2010.
Taiwan's economy is expected to contract by 2.46 percent this year, Academia Sinica said, but it cited a number of indicators pointing to a better 2010.

Export growth turned positive in November, manufacturing growth rose by 8.04 percent in October, the strongest growth since May 2008, and GDP in the fourth quarter of the year will rise 7.17 percent, the research institute noted.

"The outlook for 2010 is expected to extend the current recovery that started in the latter half of 2009, " Academia Sinica said in a statement summarizing the report. "Stimulated by the expectation of global recovery, investment in Taiwan is expected to increase by 7.81 percent."

The anticipated economic growth, however, could be derailed by some uncertainties, including the tenor of negotiations between Taiwan and China on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), said Institute of Economics researcher Ray Yeutien Chou.
He explained that if talks on the controversial trade pact proceed in a peaceful environment without vigorous opposition and protests, it could have a beneficial impact on the economy.
Chou also cited Taiwan's high unemployment rate, which stands at nearly 6 percent, and sluggish domestic consumption as major challenges to the country's economic development.
The researcher also noted that although the Dubai financial crisis has been defused, there are still some potential hidden bombs that could possibly trigger a second wave of recession.
Some Asian countries, particularly China, have major asset bubbles that could burst, he warned.
Despite these uncertainties, Chou said he believes investment in inventories will help fuel growth as traders build up inventories in anticipation of higher demand.

If the current recovery maintains its pace and the government continues efforts to help local businesses emerge from the economic slump, Chou said it was conceivable that unemployment could drop to the government's target of 4.9 percent in 2010 and GDP growth could hit 4.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget Dec. 22

TEXT.P: Commission 13. The Cloud Computing Research Center for Mobile Application opens 14.Most firms will hire new workers in 2010: poll 15.Academia Sinica predicts economic growth of 4.73% next year

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, China seal three agreements on cross-strait cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:05:17 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China formally signed three agreements Tuesday on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification, at a meeting of their top negotiators in Taichung City.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), exchanged the agreement documents and raised a toast after the signing.

The agreements marked the completion of the fourth round of cross-strait talks that resumed after President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May 2008 and immediately began working to improve relations with China.

Tuesday's signing ceremony was witnessed by SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary- General Kao Koon-liang, and other Taiwanese representatives including Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman and SEF Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun, Council of Agriculture Deputy Minister Hu Sing-hwa, MAC Chief Secretary and SEF Deputy Secretary-General Chang Shu-ti, and SEF Deputy Secretary-General Maa Shaw-chang.

The ARATS representatives included its Vice Executive President Zheng Lizhong, Vice President Li Bingcai, Secretary-General Li Yafei, Vice Secretary-General Ma Xiaoguang, and Vice Secretary-General Zhang Shenglin.

The SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations designated by the governments of Taiwan and China, respectively, to handle cross-strait communications in the absence of official contact between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:24:46 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 68.73 points, or 0.88 percent, to close at 7,856.
The local bourse opened at 7,850.05 and traded between 7,871.59 and 7,823.34 during the session.
A total of 3.84 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$111.29 billion (US$3.43 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks gaining the most at 1.6 percent, followed by banking and financial issues at 1.4 percent, machinery and electronics stocks and paper and pulp shares both at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks at 0.7 percent, and textile issues at 0.5 percent.
Cement stocks were the only category that lost ground, shedding 0.4 percent, while construction shares remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,604 to 1,039, with 304 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$8.92 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Time: People Shut Out

TEXT.P: Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relation Across the Taiwan Strait, was given a tour of a luxurious NT$280 million (US$8.66 million) apartment shortly after he arrived in Taichung City, central Taiwan Monday for cross- strait talks.

At about the same time, a Taiwanese man called a news conference in Taichung to protest the illegal detention in China of his relative -- a businessman operating in China -- and to ask the government to protect the personal safety of such entrepreneurs.
This was an ironic contrast, but also an appropriate symbol of the cross-strait talks, we think.

The Ma administration has said that the talks are "Taiwan-oriented and of benefit to the people," but we think this slogan should be changed to "rich and powerful-oriented and of benefit to the conglomerates."

On Wednesday, there will be a meeting of entrepreneurs from both sides of the Taiwan Strait. The Straits Exchange Foundation has unveiled a list of 19 Taiwan representatives, but we would like to ask where these people are from and who chose them. Why are there no representatives from small-and medium-sized enterprises and the labor sector?

We think the nine agreements signed between Taiwan and China over the past two years are not related to the public's interests. The purpose of these agreements has always been to target a few people and create immense business opportunities for them.
It is a pity that the Taiwan-China negotiations are dominated by the rich and powerful on both sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. experts give assurance of beef safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:50:25 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Three U.S. experts gave the assurance Tuesday that beef products from their country are safe, saying that the production process is subject to stringent scientific inspection procedures.

Their remarks came amid debate in Taiwan over the safety of U.S. beef since Taipei and Washington signed a protocol Oct. 22 under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and beef offal.

The decision sparked controversy in Taiwan, with opposition parties and civic groups, led by the Consumers' Foundation and politicians, contending that imports of high-risk beef products could put consumers at risk of contracting Creutzfeldt-Jacob disease (CJD) -- the human form of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

Daniel Engeljohn, deputy assistant administrator of the Office of Policy and Program Development, and Inspection Service under the United States Department of Agriculture Food Safety, said in a video conference that all U.S. beef products are subject to rigorous inspection and test procedures to ensure that no potentially risky beef parts reach the consumer market.
He noted that roughly 8 million inspection procedures each year are conducted at some 6,000 facilities and by 8,000 government inspectors to verify compliance with food safety regulations.

Keith Belk, a professor at Colorado State University's Department of Animal Sciences, said that while there is no such a thing as "zero risk" regarding food products, U.S. beef products are safe, as there have no cases of CJD illness in the U.S linked to the consumption of beef products.
Citing a risk assessment report conducted by Taiwan's Department of Health, Belk said that U.S. beef and beef products pose a "negligible risk" to Taiwan consumers.
Melvin Kramer, an epidemiologist of EHA Consulting Group, Inc., argued that U.S. beef is consumed not only by America's residents but by many others around the world and is arguably risk free.
"If I thought that there was a risk, with everything that I know, would I put my family at risk? The answer is no. I'm not a real risk taker. This is not a real risk," Kramer said.
"Our risk today in the human population is zero. Can I guarantee you that it will remain zero? No. Do I really believe scientifically that it will remain zero? Yes," he added.
Tuesday's video conference was organized by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) as part of its efforts to allay public concerns in Taiwan over U.S. beef products.

In a letter published Dec. 18 in the Apple Daily, AIT Director William A. Stanton also assured the Taiwanese public of the safety of U.S. beef, and expressed hopes that Taiwan will understand why the U.S. is asking it to honor the beef protocol.
"We want our trade to grow on the basis of sound science and established international standards," Stanton said in the letter.

However, the controversy over the Taiwan government's relaxation of restrictions on U.S. beef imports remains, as civil groups decided to push for a referendum on the issue after their appeals for the re-opening Taiwan-U.S. beef negotiations were rejected by Taiwanese authorities.

In addition, the legislature has proposed an amendment to the act governing food sanitation to introduce more stringent checks on U.S. beef imports, but the amendment failed to clear the legislature floor as scheduled because of continued boycotts by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which wants to pass its own version of the bill rather than the one put forward by the ruling Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:51:52 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, falling NT$0.029 to close at NT$32.355.
A total of US$620 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.430 and dipped to a low of NT$32.322.

DOC.HEADLINE: Jefferson Fellowships accepting applications from journalists
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:55:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A U.S. fellowship program has begun accepting applications, offering working journalists with at least five years of experiences an opportunity to explore new opportunities following the global economic crisis.

Ten people who are admitted into the program will travel to Honolulu, Hong Kong, Shanghai and Jakarta next year to meet with business and government decision- makers, scholars, social activists, cultural and political analysts and journalists, according to the organizer's statement.

The fellowship program's focus for next year will be on governance and sustainable growth following the global economic crisis. The program will run from April 17 through May 9 next year. Applicants must submit their applications before Jan. 27, 2010, according to the fellowship program's statement.

Launched in 1967, the program seeks to build a professional network through one week of dialogue with professional colleagues and experts at the East-West Center, followed by a two-week study tour to cities in Asia or the United States.

The program is organized by the East-West Center, a Honolulu-headquartered education and research organization that was established by the U.S. Congress in 1960 to strengthen relations and understanding among the people and nations of Asia, the Pacific and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: Innolux-Chi Mei-TPO merger plan clears Fair Trade Commission
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 16:59:32 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Fair Trade Commission (FTC) approved Tuesday a proposed merger between three domestic liquid crystal display (LCD) manufacturers -- Innolux Display Corp., Chi Mei Optoelectronics Corp. and TPO Displays Corp.
The FTC ruled to allow the merger because it will not restrict competition in the LCD market and will be beneficial to Taiwan's overall economy.

The new company is unlikely to raise the prices of its products or the cost of its services because it will still face competition from six other domestic manufacturers and from foreign manufacturers in South Korea, Japan and China, according to a statement released by the FTC.

Innolux, an affiliate of the world's largest contract electronics maker Hon Hai Group, reached a consolidation deal in November with Chi Mei, Taiwan's second- largest and the world's fourth-largest LCD manufacturer, after sealing a similar deal with TPO in October.
Innolux will be the surviving company and will be renamed Chimei Innolux Corp. after the merger, which is expected to take effect April 30, 2010.
It is predicted that the new company could replace AU Optronics to become Taiwan's largest LCD manufacturer.

DOC.HEADLINE: More young women in Taiwan starting own businesses: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 17:38:20 (By Liu Kuang-ying and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: More young women in Taiwan are trying to start their own businesses, and some online shops run by young female entrepreneurs have proved successful, according to a survey conducted by the National Youth Commission.

Although Taiwan women entrepreneurs have traditionally been at a disadvantage because of comparatively less professional training and fewer channels to acquire funding and market information, they have learned to apply new technology and to maximize their creativity in recent years, according to Hung Ya-ling, secretary-general of the Taiwan Franchises Association.
Not only are more young women breaking into the business world, some have also successfully set up shop in cyber world, Hung said.

The National Youth Commission in late May commissioned a survey team lead by Lu Jui-yang, an associate professor at the Soochow University, to study the career expectations of young women aged 20 to 45.
The survey report released Tuesday indicated that the 4,032 of the respondents were participants in a vocational assistance program run by the youth commission between 2002 and 2008.
Lu said that among the 4,032 respondents, about 20 percent said that they would like to start their own businesses.

Those young women who have already tried to start their own small businesses have mostly opened cosmetics and beauty parlors, fashion and ornaments stores, and food and restaurant enterprises, according to the survey.
One fourth of these young women said that they had experience in starting their own businesses, the poll showed.
In the survey, conducted between May 21 and June 20, 5,052 questionnaires distributed were completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's rival legislative caucuses to face showdown over beef issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 18:00:51 (by Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: After a month-long deadlock over the controversial issue of U.S. beef imports, legislative caucuses of Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus Tuesday that they will meet for a "final showdown" over the issue on Dec. 29.

At a Legislative Yuan meeting Tuesday, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative caucus demanded that legislation of amendments to the Act Governing Food Sanitation over the U.S. beef import issue should not be delayed any longer.
Wang Hsing-nan, a whip of the DPP caucus, challenged the KMT for a showdown, on Dec. 29, for a final decision on the amendment issue.

He told the Central News Agency that the DPP has proposed a DPP-version amendment, which categorically prohibits the import of products such as offal, ground beef, spinal cords, brains, and skulls, in order to "bar the beef imports at the source and borders."
The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus, meanwhile, said it will seek an emergency consensus with the administration before Dec. 25 on how a KMT-version amendment should be presented.

The KMT caucus has put up a bill for consideration for the first time on Nov. 17 that would officially allow imports of bone-in beef and other U.S. beef procusts. The bill, however, has been boycotted by the DPP.

Meanwhile, KMT legislative whip Lu Hsueh-chang said the caucus will invite National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi to a caucus meeting on Dec. 25 to present the administration's discourse about its stance on a possible, workable amendment.
Lu said KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung will also be invited to attend the meeting to offer the ruling party's opinions on the matter.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang assured the Taiwan public Tuesday that strict measures, known as the "three controls" and "five certifications, " have indeed been effective in keeping potentially hazardous beef parts from the United States out of Taiwan.
Yaung said the DOH also supports the inclusion of the "three controls" and "five certifications" in a proposed amendment to the Act Governing Food Sanitation.
The so-called three controls refer to setting controls on beef imports at the source, at borders and in markets.

The five certifications refer to verifying certification documents, checking that shipments are marked with detailed product information, opening a high percentage of cartons of imported beef to check the product, conducting food safety tests, and being able to get information on suspected problem product immediately, according to DOH officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Doctor to sue DOH over son's post-immunization death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 18:17:20 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A medical doctor said Tuesday that he plans to sue the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) over the death of his six-year-old son who had received an H1N1 flu vaccine 32 days before.
Steve Kuo, director-general of the DOH Centers for Disease Control (CDC), said the CDC respects the decision of the doctor, who is based in Taichung County.
Kuo said the DOH has no plans to change the current nationwide influenza H1NI immunization program, even amid doubts as to whether the six-year-old's death was related to the vaccine.

According to Kuo, the boy's father called the 1922 H1N1 vaccination consultation hotline on Dec. 2 after his son developed a high fever and a skin rash. The boy had been given an H1N1 immunization shot on Nov. 19.
Kuo said DOH Vice Minister Chang Shang-chun and CDC experts immediately called an emergency telephone conference with the child's father in an attempt to offer help, but the boy died Dec. 21.

After preliminary discussions, the experts concluded that the boy's death was unrelated to the H1N1 vaccine, Kuo said, adding that an immunity system problem could have been one of the causes of death.
"The boy's parents are welcome to file for a probe into the case to allow other experts to make a more comprehensive, independent judgment," Kuo added.

Since the nationwide immunization program was launched Nov. 1, a total of 22 people have filed for such probes and have sought redress for problems experienced after receiving H1N1 shots, according to the CDC.
Meanwhile, Kuo said the total number of hospitalized H1NI patients in Taiwan since the outbreak began this year has reached 817 as of Tuesday, with 35 of them being fatal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung residents cold-shoulder protests against China-Taiwan talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:00:02 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Some residents in central Taiwan's Taichung City, where the latest round of China-Taiwan talks are being held, were indifferent toward the ongoing protests against a visit by a top Chinese envoy and a proposed free-trade pact between the two sides.

Tens of thousands of people marched on the streets and rallied on Sunday ahead of the Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin's visit in a protest organized by the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Since Chen's arrival on Monday, hundreds of people have demonstrated each day outside the hotel where he is staying.

The protesters are against the government's plans to sign the trade agreement -- known as the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA). They said they fear it could flood the island with cheaper Chinese products, shut down small and medium-size enterprises , cost jobs, and jeopardize Taiwan's sovereignty in the long run by making it too economically reliant on China.
But some local residents in Taichung said they disagreed with the protesters.
"No matter what they (the protesters) do, the government is still going to sign (the ECFA) anyway, " said a cab driver surnamed Yang.

"I say let President (Ma Ying-jeou) do his things. If you're not happy with his performance, don't vote for him in the next election. It's that simple, " Yang said, adding that business in Taichung was not good in the past few days because of the protest and traffic controls.
Another resident said Taiwan will be better off signing the agreement with China.

"Not signing the agreement means certain death, but signing the agreement does not necessary mean death," said the resident, also surnamed Yang. "Taiwan is a small island and China is so economically powerful. The protesters are stupid. Our economy will improve as long as we have good economic cooperation with China."
He said he does not believe Taiwan's sovereignty would be jeopardized.
"I don't think China is going to come in here and tell us what to do," he said.

In Sunday's two-hour parade during which organizers shouted out the damage they believe the economic agreement will cause through a large loudspeaker, onlookers by the roads barely took notice of the protesters as most people chose to keep doing what they were doing.
Despite the lukewarm response, a DPP local representative Chen Da-chun said Taichung City citizens have been very active in the protest.

After Sunday's massive rally, smaller scale protests have been staged on Monday and Tuesday. Pro-Taiwan independence supporters held a sit-in in a vacant lot across the hotel Chen Yunlin is staying. Falungong practitioners lined the streets outside the hotel, holding signs and banners to oppose China's persecution against the spiritual group.
While the Falungong protesters have made little noise, other groups have used bullhorns, gas horns and loud speakers to make their views heard.
A motorcade parade organized by a local branch office of the DPP roamed through Taichung City Tuesday blaring anti-China and anti- trade pact messages on loud speakers.

Some local councilmen tried to enter the restricted area around the hotel at night. This was widely seen as a self-promotional tactic for the upcoming elections in five metropolitans in Taiwan, inclding Taichung.

However, the protests during Chen's visit this year appeared to be different from those during his visit last year. Local pro-independence groups and the DPP, traditional partners which formed a united front, appeared to have different mindset this time.

Local groups said they feel that the DPP has intentionally kept a distance from them because of what happened last year when some protesters clashed with the police in violent protests that happened during that round of talks held in Taipei.
DPP officials have said they do not condone violence and wanted to avoid a repeat of last year's clashes, for which it was criticized.
In the march on Sunday, the DPP and its supporters marched down one route, while the pro-independence groups went down the other, before joining for a final rally.

"It's obvious that the DPP is intentionally alienating local groups this time over fears of things getting out of hand, " said Tsai Ting-kuei, Convener of Alliance of Referendum for Taiwan, one of the groups.
Taiwan's government said signing the economic agreement with China will boost the island's economic growth by 1.65 percent to 1. 72 percent and create more job opportunities.

The government has also said Taiwan will enjoy tariff-free trade with China and greater access to the Chinese market. If it does not sign the agreement, it could lose out to China's other trade partners which will ink free-trade agreements with China, according to government officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negotiators see cross-strait talks on ECFA as urgent
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:17:33 (By Chou Hui-ying, Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China's negotiators stressed in their meeting Tuesday the urgency of the two sides beginning talks on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

The fourth round of cross-strait negotiations opened in Taichung City earlier in the day, led by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS).
"It is of great urgency for the two sides to establish an economic cooperation framework agreement," Chiang said in his opening address.
However, in the formulation of the agreement, "the difference between the economic systems and the size of the two sides should be taken into consideration," he added.
Echoing Chiang's call, Chen said he hopes the two sides will start negotiations on the proposed ECFA as soon as possible.
The ECFA is "purely an economic issue," Chen said, adding that China has been very aggressive regarding this the matter.
"Once it is good for cross-strait relations and economic development on both sides, (China) will try its best to achieve it," Chen said.
He added that he and Chiang will "in principle exchange opinions" on the issue during their talks.
The SEF and ARATS are two intermediary bodies founded to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: A third of Taiwan's firms to raise pay for workers in 2010: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:35:15 (By Y. S. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: In the latest sign that Taiwan's economy is recovering, 37 percent of local firms have indicated they plan to raise salaries for their workers next year, with the average pay raise at 5.84 percent, according to the results of a survey released Tuesday by 1111 job bank.

Many workers have already received pay hikes this year, as the island begins to emerge from its worst recession in decades. The economy contracted 1.29 percent in the third quarter -- the slowest rate in a year.

Workers in the transportation logistics, real-estate and manufacturing sectors received the largest pay hike this year, while those in the real-estate, transportation logistics and financial and business service sectors will see the largest growth in their salaries next year, the survey by 1111 job bank found.

Meanwhile 58.08 percent of the companies said they do not have any plans to raise salaries for their employees, while 2.62 percent said they would continue cutting workers' salaries or simply adjust their workers' salary levels back up to the level before the global economic crisis.
The 1111 job bank carried out the survey of companies from Dec. 8-21, getting 687 valid responses.

Another survey conducted by the executive research 104 job bank showed that some 85 percent of Taiwan's enterprises have plans to hire new workers in 2010, up by 36 percent from the same period last year.

The survey found that financial services and insurance companies, culture- related and IT software businesses as well as those in the construction and manufacturing sectors plan to recruit new blood next year, citing reasons such as the need to fill key vacancies and to expand operations.

Talent are mostly wanted for posts such as sales representatives, R&D engineers and skilled workers, according to the survey results. Job seekers who have one-to-three years of experience in these fields are in strong demand as such job positions account for over 60 percent of the total job openings to be offered. Those with more than three years of experience and new college graduates are also popular in the job market.
104 job bank public relations manager Fang Kuang-wei said companies from almost all sectors are set to employ new personnel at all levels amid a noticeable economic recovery.

While seeking to recruit new workers, enterprises are trying to offer better incentives, including more handsome cash rewards, year- end bonuses and benefits or more comprehensive training courses, to retain current staffers, the survey found.
The head hunting job bank conducted the survey from Nov. 23-30, collecting 800 valid samples. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.46 percentage points.

In another survey the 104 job bank conducted, it discovered that around 81.2 percent of Taiwan's white-collar office workers have thought about switching jobs in the coming year -- the highest rate in three years.

About 50 percent of them are thinking of making the move before getting their year-end bonuses, while 30 percent said they plan to start looking for new jobs after receiving year-end bonuses, according to the poll.

Most of the white-collar office workers pondering how to find new jobs cited major reasons such as "no promotion opportunities, " "unsatisfactory salaries" or "feeling no identity with the entrepreneurial culture."

According to those who have recently found new employment, 32 percent said their new salaries are 14.5 percent higher on average than their previous pay, while 47 percent said their salaries shrank by an average of 18.4 percent, the survey pointed out.
The 104 job bank made the survey on the willingness of Taiwan's office workers from Nov. 23 - Nov. 30 and interviewed 3,514 employees. It had a margin of error of 1.65 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan decides not to tax gains on securities investment for now
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:39:35 (By Lin Ye-fong and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet's tax reform committee reached a consensus Tuesday to maintain for the time being the existing taxation system under which gains obtained by individuals and corporates from securities investment are tax-free.

In the mid- to long term, however, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) should study the possibility of taxing corporates for gains from securities, instead of for securities transactions, the committee decided in a meeting held to discuss issues concerning capital gains.

Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu told reporters after the meeting that the existing securities transaction tax actually takes into consideration gains on securities, and that he has required the MOF to release related data to allow the public to better understand the situation.
In the future, the securities transaction tax for corporates will probably be changed to a securities gains tax, in which losses can be offset against gains, Chu said.
The committee has recommended that in the initial stages of the new system's implementation, corporates should be able to choose whether to shift to securities gains taxation.
According to Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der, the option will be offered to corporates out of fairness.

Citing analyses of the investment performance of more than 10 large companies in Taiwan over the past three years, Lee said that although these companies made gains in the first two years, their losses in the third year far exceeded their previous gains.
These companies nevertheless were still required to pay tax, which raises questions about the fairness of the present system, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT challenges DPP to disclose data on its members' China investments
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:49:01 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) dared the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Tuesday to publish information concerning investments in China by DPP officials and public office holders.

KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said that given the close cross-strait exchanges over the past decade, he wonders if DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen would dare to publicize such data amid its current opposition to the economic accords signed between Taiwan and China earlier that day.
The agreements covered cooperation on fishing crew issues, industrial product standards and agricultural inspection and quarantine.

They were signed by China's top negotiator with Taiwan -- Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) and his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, in the latest round of just-concluded negotiations between the two sides that concluded Tuesday.

Lee said it is regrettable that the DPP ignored the meeting agenda, sent "one- sided" and "misleading" information to its supporters and mobilized protests, instead of engaging in rational policy debates.

He said rhetorically that Tsai -- an expert in international trade who previously served on the National Security Council, the Mainland Affairs Council and in the Executive Yuan -- should realize that the the development of normal cross-strait trade relations is crucial to avoiding Taiwan becoming marginalized.

How else would Taiwan products be able to compete with those of other countries, Lee asked. China products will enjoy zero tariff treatment in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) after China joins the regional grouping in forming a free trade zone from Jan.1., he added. In contrast, Taiwan's products will be subject to tariffs of between 9percent and 10 percent, he said.

Referring to Tsai and the DPP's objections to the government's cross-strait policy, Lee challenged the DPP to identify which of the agreements signed between Taiwan and China since May 2008 have been "self-denigrating," or "a sellout of Taiwan."

Lee said that President Ma Ying-jeou has repeatedly affirmed that the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will not allow for more agricultural products or laborers from China to enter Taiwan.
He questioned the DPP's reasons for what he described as its dissemination of false information and creation of public panic.
He noted that since 2003, China has been Taiwan's number one trading partner, absorbing 40 percent of Taiwan's exports.
"Is Tsai aware of these figures?" Lee asked.
He further challenged the DPP come up with ideas to protect the investments of Taiwan businessmen in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pop singer named goodwill ambassador for Shanghai Expo Taipei Pavilion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 19:54:34 (By Rachel Chan)

TEXT.P: Taipei City named pop singer Wang Leehom as its goodwill ambassador for the Taipei Pavilion at 2010 Shanghai Expo, Tuesday.
"With his great image, high popularity and international profile, Wang is a one in a million pick for goodwill ambassador," said Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin at a press conference.
"I hope that his vitality and talent will attract more people to the Taipei Pavilion to learn about the beauty and advanced development of the city," he added.
Wang, a U.S.-born Taiwanese song-writer and actor, pledged to promote Taipei City's friendliness, energy and diverse culture, which he said are the main inspiration for his music.
The two-time winner of the Golden Melody best producer award also performed the expo theme song, "Smile at first sight, " which he wrote.

Adapted from a song with the same title by the late Taiwanese singer Teresa Teng, Wang brought new element into his version, using a rap segment to introduce Taipei city's ubiquitous wireless Internet access and its successful garbage collection and recycling policies.

Two projects, Wireless Taipei and Taipei Infinity, will be among the 50 "urban best practices area" expo projects at the Taiwan pavilion, which are being designed to display solutions to urban issues, under the expo theme of "Better City, Better Life."

Funded by the Hon Hai Group, the Taipei pavilion is being constructed in line with the "3R" principle of reduce, recycle and reuse to achieve the goals of environmental protection and energy conservation, according the Taipei City Government's Department of Information and Tourism.
There will also be a Taiwan Pavilion in the compound's Zone A at Shanghai World Expo 2010.

According to the Shanghai World Expo Bureau, some 240 countries will take part in the event that will run from May 1 - Oct. 31, 2010. It is expected to attract a record 70 million visitors from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: KMT throwback should retire
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 12/22/09 19:58:41 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: has said it will come up with options to handle the party's ill-gotten assets by the end of this month, including donating such assets to charity.
However, Wang Wen-hsieh, director of the KMT's Huang Fuhsing veterans branch, voiced opposition.

According to Wang, a retired general, the KMT brought a lot of equipment with it when it retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing the civil war to the communists, and that the KMT set up a lot of companies in Taiwan that helped its economic development.
As for donating the assets to charity, Wang said that a lot of the party's assets come from KMT membership fees and that "it is not sensible for outsiders to share our money."

Wang should know that even if the KMT has helped Taiwan's economic development, after the nation's democratization and economic liberalization, all party-owned and state-owned enterprises should be privatized.

Moreover, political parties should not have businesses, because otherwise, if the KMT is so rich while the other political parties have to tighten their belts, how can there be fair competition among them?
Wang should retire. And soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC lauds results of cross-strait talks as fruitful
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:05:38 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top China affairs official on Tuesday lauded the results of the fourth round of negotiation between Taiwan and China as fruitful and said she envisions better bilateral relations.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan addressed the Chinese delegation after Chiang Pin-kung and Chen Yunlin, heads of designated organizations that deal with cross-Taiwan Strait matter s in the absence of formal ties, signed three of four agreements on the meeting's agenda.

"In order for both sides of the strait to avoid war, pursue peace and establish a stable environment for exchanges, we have to resolutely take a path of institutionalized negotiations, which is the right one for cross-strait relations," Lai said.
The three agreements were on cooperation on the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products, standards testing and certification cooperation, and fishery labor cooperation.
An agreement on the avoidance of double taxation and strengthening of tax cooperation was not signed as both sides failed to reach consensus, citing "technical issues."

The MAC chairwoman said that the agreements reached in the four rounds of talks so far have ensured an orderly and systematic progression of bilateral exchanges and that the unsigned agreement signified an institutionalized and mature negotiation process.
Views on cross-strait relations in Taiwan have been polarized and the Chinese might be confused at Taiwan's hesitance and unease despite China's goodwill and its arrangements, Lai acknowledged.
"But this is the norm in a diverse society and a fact that both sides need to deal with carefully," she advised.

The most important factor in cross-strait talks, she stressed, is gaining the support of the people because Taiwan, with a democratic government, has to listen to the people, respect them and respond swiftly.
The development of "peaceful and stable cross-strait relations can only go as far as people's support takes us," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Research center forms R&D consortium for container computer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:12:25 (By Jackson Chang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A newly established center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) plans to form an R&D consortium and to launch the first version of an advanced container computer system by the end of 2010, the center's head said Tuesday.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the Cloud Computing Research Center for Mobile Application (CCMA) , Chiueh Tzi-cker also said the center will develop software talent and assist the government to implement a country-wide program for maintaining electronic medical records.

According to Chiueh, the CCMA plans to form the R&D consortium with four or five local partners to develop the "container computer 1.0" -- a 40-foot preconfigured shipping container that can hold up to 1,000 servers -- and to launch the product by the end of next year.

This would make Taiwan the first country in Asia to develop the container computer, said Chiueh, adding that the product, at an average cost of about US$5 million, will become a building block for any container-based data center.
He said developing the container computer will provide great business opportunities for Taiwanese hardware manufacturers.
Cloud computing is a Web-enabled software solution that uses the Internet as a platform for performing tasks on the computer and delivers a range of inter- operable applications.

ITRI President Johnsee Lee described it as a concept of resource-sharing, and said that cloud computing will not only affect the software and hardware manufacturers in the information and communication industries, but will also help local small- and medium-sized companies and the service industry to transform and upgrade, which could change the economic structure of the country.

Chiueh said the CCMA has 40 employees employed in hardware equipment, software services and applications and that the number of employees is expected to increase to 80 in the first quarter of 2010 and to 150 in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax deal with China involves no sovereignty issue: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:33:58 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Chou Hui-ying, Lin Shu-yuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih on Tuesday dismissed speculations that the reason for the delay in signing a deal with China on avoidance of double taxation was due to issues involving the island's sovereignty.

Negotiators of Taiwan and China concluded the latest round of talks the central Taiwan city of Taichung earlier in the day, without signing the tax agreement, which was among four items on the agenda for discussion.
Taiwan and China had earlier reached consensus on a taxation system based on where the taxpayer resides, Wu said.
However, Chinese negotiators later brought up the idea of basing the system on the origin of the income and cited a similar pact between Hong Kong and China as an example, he added.
"We are not in the same status as Hong Kong," Wu said.

Commenting on reports that China-based Taiwanese investors worried that they would have to pay higher taxes under the proposed agreement, Wu said that there will be no problems if everyone obeys the law.
Following the talks, Taiwan's top negotiator Chiang Pin-kung told a press conference that putting on hold the tax agreement will not have a negative impact on Chinese investment in the island.
Asked if the agreement would be signed at the next round of talks, a Taiwanese official who took part in the talks did not give a specific answer.
"We, of course, hope that it would happen as early as possible, " said Liu Te- shun, the vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Top negotiators from both sides said that the taxation issue remains on the agenda of future negotiations.
"Both sides had reached a consensus on the main content of the agreement on avoiding double taxation, " said Chiang.
"On the technical front, however, both sides believe that more time is needed," he explained.
The agreement had been previously slated to take effect on Jan. 1, 2010. Now, it could enter into force by 2011 at the earliest, according to Liu.

Chiang, the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), ended up with inking three agreements with his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification at the end of the talks held in central Taiwan.

The SEF is a quasi-official body set up to handle cross-strait exchanges with its counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in the absence of formal ties between the two sides.
The next round of Taiwan-China talks, the fifth round since talks resumed last year, is slated to take place in China during the first half of 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA, IPR will be covered in fifth cross-strait talks: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:51:30 (By C.C. Liu, S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and the issue of intellectual property rights (IPR) will be covered in the next round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks slated for the first half of 2010 in China, the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Tuesday.

The MAC made the announcement in a press release after the top negotiators from the two sides -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin -- president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- inked three cooperation pacts in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

Chiang and Chen signed agreements on fishery worker cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection and industrial product standards certification during Tuesday's talks, but an agreement on avoidance of double taxation was not sealed due to non-political technical details, the MAC said, adding that the accord will be signed in the near term after further discussions.

In response to questions from reporters at a news conference later in the day on whether the ECFA will be signed in May, as Taiwan hopes, or in the fifth round of cross-strait talks, ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong voiced reservations, although he pledged that both sides are seeking to start ECFA-related talks as soon as possible.

"Despite the fact that inking a cross-strait ECFA is unavoidable amid the increased economic interaction between the two sides, many discussions remain to be conducted and many arrangements remain to be made," he explained.

Stressing that the ECFA is purely an economic matter, Zheng said, China will take "the scale of Taiwan's market" and "the impact of the trade pact on Taiwan's economy" into consideration in a bid to "maximize the benefit (to Taiwan) at the least cost."

Due to the sharp difference between the size of the two markets, he emphasized, "China will definitely consider the absorbing capacity of Taiwan's market and how much its people can take when signing the ECFA with Taiwan."

According to political analysts, Zheng's emphasis on the economic fronts of the ECFA and his promise to weigh Taiwan's market scale are a clear sign of China's efforts to seek the Taiwan people's backing for the pact -- paving the way for negotiations on the issue that are scheduled to begin next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: November jobless rate drops, monthly wage increases in October
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 21:22:07 (By Erin Ho and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: As the economy recovers, Taiwan's jobless rate dropped for a third consecutive month in November, while the average monthly wage rose in October for the first time in nine months, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

The jobless rate in November dropped to 5.86 percent, 0.1 percentage points down from October. After seasonal adjustment, the unemployment rate stood at 5.98 percent, or 0.06 percentage points less than the previous month and the first time in more than five months it had dropped below 6 percent.

The monthly jobless rate -- either seasonally adjusted or unadjusted -- was lower in November, which is a sign that the unemployment situation has stabilized, said Liu Tien-si, a DGBAS deputy department chief.
Meanwhile, the number of unemployed people totalled 645,000, down 8,000 from the previous month, while the number of employed totalled 10.37 million, up 59,000.
Liu also noted that the labor force participation rate in November rose to 58.15 percent -- the highest level in 11 months -- up 0.21 percentage points over the previous month.
Meanwhile, the average monthly income in October rose by 1.4 percent to NT$40,156, which marked the first positive growth in the past nine months.
However, the average monthly wage between January and October fell by a record 5.57 percent year-on-year to NT$42,766, Liu added.
The average regular monthly wage fell by 1.13 percent in October, to NT$36,143, which marked the smallest decline in almost one year.

The average wage includes regular wages, including salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses, plus overtime and other non- regular wages such as performance bonuses, year-end bonuses and employee bonuses.
Real monthly income, which takes into account the impact of the consumer price index on wages, also fell by a record 4.76 percent to NT$40,964 between January and October, the statistics show.
Real regular wages dropped by 1.45 percent year-on-year to NT$34,253 during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese consumers shows high confidence in stock market: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 21:52:03 (By Kao Chao-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese consumers have been showing high confidence in the stock market, with less pessimism compared with six months ago, according to the results of a semi- annual survey released recently by MasterCard Worldwide.
The latest MasterCard Worldwide Index of Consumer Confidence was conducted between Oct. 1 and Nov. 9 among 10,623 consumers from 24 markets across the Asia-Pacific, the Middle East and Africa.

It measures consumer confidence and sentiments on prevailing expectations in the market for the next six months, with an index score of zero as the most pessimistic, 100 as most optimistic and 50 as neutral.
Taiwan's overallindex score was 56.5, up from 39.4 six months ago and 32.1 a year ago, according to the report.
Consumer sentiment turned optimistic on three indicators compared to six months ago, with the most significant recovery seen in stock market confidence, on which the score jumped from 54.5 to 74.7.
The score is the fifth-highest in the Asia-Pacific region and the highest in the Greater China region.
The score of confidence in the economy, meanwhile, moved up from 47.8 to 60.5, while the score of employment confidence rose from 38.5 to 57.0.
Local pessimism remained, however, about regular income and quality of life, although the scores for these two indicators rose from 22.2 to 47.2 and from 34.0 to 43.1, respectively.
The report revealed that compared to six months ago, the Asia-Pacific region has seen an increase in its consumer confidence index score, from 38.7 to 66.3.
Vietnam (90.0) , China (85.3) and Singapore (79.4) showed significantly higher consumer confidence compared to other markets in the region.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, MasterCard's Asia-Pacific economic advisor, noted that when the global economy started to stabilize in the second half of 2009, conditions improved especially fast in the Asia-Pacific region.
"The latest findings of the overall robust rebound in consumer confidence in the region mirrors progress seen in the real economy, " he said.

He predicted that renewed consumer confidence will contribute to the momentum of recovery, because it will lead to lower precautionary savings and higher spending, which will in turn improve business outlook and encourage more investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien magistrate's appointment of deputy invalid: MOI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 22:59:55 (By C.C. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Tuesday that Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi's naming of his "ex-wife" as deputy magistrate is invalid, on the grounds that their divorce was fake and that the appointment of his wife therefore is in breach of the relevant laws.

Jiang made the announcement following a meeting in which officials from the Interior Ministry, the Justice Ministry, the Central Personnel Administration, the Executive Yuan and the Control Yuan made the decision.
Jiang said his ministry will ask the Executive Yuan to rescind Fu's appointment of Hsu Chen-wei, his wife, as deputy magistrate of Hualien County because the two are still married to each other.
According to the Public Official Employment Law, it is against the law for a holder of public office to designate a spouse or a family member living under the same roof as his or her deputy.

Fu, who was elected by a landslide in the Dec. 5 local elections running as an independent after being expelled by the ruling Kuomintang, supposedly divorced Hsu Dec. 18 and then picked her as his deputy just three days later.
In a bid to make the divorce appear bona fide, Fu re-registered Hsu's family registration in the house of his mother-in-law, who lives next door to Fu, the MOI said in a news release.

According to Jiang, the MOI will also ask the Control Yuan to fine Fu between NT$1 million (US$30,000) and NT$5 million for breaking the Employment Rules of the Act on Recusal of Public Servants Due to Conflicts of Interest because their actual relations are husband and wife.
Fu's appointment of Hsu is widely seen as an attempt to hold on to the post, as he is also appealing a six-and-a-half-year sentence for violating securities trading regulations.
The MOI said Fu and Hsu are recognized as "members of the same family" given that they are rearing their children together and because they have told supporters that they are still a family.
According to the MOI, the divorce apparently violates Article 87 of the Civil Law and thus was ruled invalid.
Also, in line with the fourth provision of Article 75 of the Local Government Law, Fu's designation of Hsu as his deputy is unlawful, the MOI said.
The case also violates Article 6 and Article 7 of the Enployment Rules of the Act on Recusal of Public Servants Due to Conflicts of Interest for naming a "related person" to a public office post.
So-called "related persons" refer to a spouse or family member living under the same roof, according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP blames MAC, SEF for failing to ink tax deal with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 23:10:04 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that both the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head and the chief negotiator with China should be held responsible for failing to ink a tax deal in the latest cross- strait talks that concluded that day in central Taiwan.

MAC Chairwoman Lai shin-yuan and Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Taiwan's chief negotiator in the talks, are to blame for the failure, said DPP acting spokesman Chung Shuo-han at a press conference.

Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, signed three agreements on fishery crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification in the talks, the fourth of their kind since last year, but fell short of a fourth on taxation, citing "technical reasons."

"The government should make public the reasons behind the failure for the tax deal, which could result in a loss of NT$30 billion (US$940 million) in tax revenue," said Chien Yao-tang, a research fellow with the Taiwan Thinktank, at the press conference.

Well ahead of the talks, the government had blared about forging the tax pact, and the last-minute failure shows its inability to control the tenor of the negotiations, said Liu Chieh-hsin, deputy chief of the DPP's Strategy Committee.
Concern on the part of China-based Taiwanese investors about a possible tax probe by the government is the main reason for the delay in the cross-strait tax pact, he claimed.

Meanwhile, in response to a challenge by the ruling Kuomintang for the opposition party to publish information concerning investments in China by DPP officials and public office-holders, Liu said the KMT has been trying to "shift the focus of concerns" and has failed to play its role as the ruling party.

KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said earlier in the day that given the close cross- strait exchanges over the past decade, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen should publicize such data in light of its opposition to the economic accords signed between Taiwan and China in the just-concluded talks.

Lee said it is regrettable that the DPP ignored the meeting agenda, sent "one- sided" and "misleading" information to its supporters and mobilized protests instead of engaging in rational policy debates.

However, Liu said that as the main opposition party, the DPP is obliged to exercise checks and balances on the government, and that in terms of investments in China, its greatest concern is "whether any of the ruling party members have ever pursued personal interests in the process of talks with China."
"Members of Taiwan's negotiating teams should therefore make public the business operations in China of either their own or family members," he said.
