ITRI President Johnsee Lee described it as a concept of resource-sharing, and said that cloud computing will not only affect the software and hardware manufacturers in the information and communication industries, but will also help local small- and medium-sized companies and the service industry to transform and upgrade, which could change the economic structure of the country.

Chiueh said the CCMA has 40 employees employed in hardware equipment, software services and applications and that the number of employees is expected to increase to 80 in the first quarter of 2010 and to 150 in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tax deal with China involves no sovereignty issue: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:33:58 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Chou Hui-ying, Lin Shu-yuan and Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih on Tuesday dismissed speculations that the reason for the delay in signing a deal with China on avoidance of double taxation was due to issues involving the island's sovereignty.

Negotiators of Taiwan and China concluded the latest round of talks the central Taiwan city of Taichung earlier in the day, without signing the tax agreement, which was among four items on the agenda for discussion.
Taiwan and China had earlier reached consensus on a taxation system based on where the taxpayer resides, Wu said.
However, Chinese negotiators later brought up the idea of basing the system on the origin of the income and cited a similar pact between Hong Kong and China as an example, he added.
"We are not in the same status as Hong Kong," Wu said.

Commenting on reports that China-based Taiwanese investors worried that they would have to pay higher taxes under the proposed agreement, Wu said that there will be no problems if everyone obeys the law.
Following the talks, Taiwan's top negotiator Chiang Pin-kung told a press conference that putting on hold the tax agreement will not have a negative impact on Chinese investment in the island.
Asked if the agreement would be signed at the next round of talks, a Taiwanese official who took part in the talks did not give a specific answer.
"We, of course, hope that it would happen as early as possible, " said Liu Te- shun, the vice chairman of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).
Top negotiators from both sides said that the taxation issue remains on the agenda of future negotiations.
"Both sides had reached a consensus on the main content of the agreement on avoiding double taxation, " said Chiang.
"On the technical front, however, both sides believe that more time is needed," he explained.
The agreement had been previously slated to take effect on Jan. 1, 2010. Now, it could enter into force by 2011 at the earliest, according to Liu.

Chiang, the chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), ended up with inking three agreements with his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification at the end of the talks held in central Taiwan.

The SEF is a quasi-official body set up to handle cross-strait exchanges with its counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in the absence of formal ties between the two sides.
The next round of Taiwan-China talks, the fifth round since talks resumed last year, is slated to take place in China during the first half of 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA, IPR will be covered in fifth cross-strait talks: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 20:51:30 (By C.C. Liu, S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and the issue of intellectual property rights (IPR) will be covered in the next round of cross- Taiwan Strait talks slated for the first half of 2010 in China, the Cabinet- level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) announced Tuesday.

The MAC made the announcement in a press release after the top negotiators from the two sides -- Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin -- president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- inked three cooperation pacts in central Taiwan's Taichung City.

Chiang and Chen signed agreements on fishery worker cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection and industrial product standards certification during Tuesday's talks, but an agreement on avoidance of double taxation was not sealed due to non-political technical details, the MAC said, adding that the accord will be signed in the near term after further discussions.

In response to questions from reporters at a news conference later in the day on whether the ECFA will be signed in May, as Taiwan hopes, or in the fifth round of cross-strait talks, ARATS Vice President Zheng Lizhong voiced reservations, although he pledged that both sides are seeking to start ECFA-related talks as soon as possible.

"Despite the fact that inking a cross-strait ECFA is unavoidable amid the increased economic interaction between the two sides, many discussions remain to be conducted and many arrangements remain to be made," he explained.

Stressing that the ECFA is purely an economic matter, Zheng said, China will take "the scale of Taiwan's market" and "the impact of the trade pact on Taiwan's economy" into consideration in a bid to "maximize the benefit (to Taiwan) at the least cost."

Due to the sharp difference between the size of the two markets, he emphasized, "China will definitely consider the absorbing capacity of Taiwan's market and how much its people can take when signing the ECFA with Taiwan."

According to political analysts, Zheng's emphasis on the economic fronts of the ECFA and his promise to weigh Taiwan's market scale are a clear sign of China's efforts to seek the Taiwan people's backing for the pact -- paving the way for negotiations on the issue that are scheduled to begin next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: November jobless rate drops, monthly wage increases in October
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 21:22:07 (By Erin Ho and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: As the economy recovers, Taiwan's jobless rate dropped for a third consecutive month in November, while the average monthly wage rose in October for the first time in nine months, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Tuesday.

The jobless rate in November dropped to 5.86 percent, 0.1 percentage points down from October. After seasonal adjustment, the unemployment rate stood at 5.98 percent, or 0.06 percentage points less than the previous month and the first time in more than five months it had dropped below 6 percent.

The monthly jobless rate -- either seasonally adjusted or unadjusted -- was lower in November, which is a sign that the unemployment situation has stabilized, said Liu Tien-si, a DGBAS deputy department chief.
Meanwhile, the number of unemployed people totalled 645,000, down 8,000 from the previous month, while the number of employed totalled 10.37 million, up 59,000.
Liu also noted that the labor force participation rate in November rose to 58.15 percent -- the highest level in 11 months -- up 0.21 percentage points over the previous month.
Meanwhile, the average monthly income in October rose by 1.4 percent to NT$40,156, which marked the first positive growth in the past nine months.
However, the average monthly wage between January and October fell by a record 5.57 percent year-on-year to NT$42,766, Liu added.
The average regular monthly wage fell by 1.13 percent in October, to NT$36,143, which marked the smallest decline in almost one year.

The average wage includes regular wages, including salary and fixed monthly subsidies and bonuses, plus overtime and other non- regular wages such as performance bonuses, year-end bonuses and employee bonuses.
Real monthly income, which takes into account the impact of the consumer price index on wages, also fell by a record 4.76 percent to NT$40,964 between January and October, the statistics show.
Real regular wages dropped by 1.45 percent year-on-year to NT$34,253 during the period.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese consumers shows high confidence in stock market: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 21:52:03 (By Kao Chao-fen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese consumers have been showing high confidence in the stock market, with less pessimism compared with six months ago, according to the results of a semi- annual survey released recently by MasterCard Worldwide.
The latest MasterCard Worldwide Index of Consumer Confidence was conducted between Oct. 1 and Nov. 9 among 10,623 consumers from 24 markets across the Asia-Pacific, the Middle East and Africa.

It measures consumer confidence and sentiments on prevailing expectations in the market for the next six months, with an index score of zero as the most pessimistic, 100 as most optimistic and 50 as neutral.
Taiwan's overallindex score was 56.5, up from 39.4 six months ago and 32.1 a year ago, according to the report.
Consumer sentiment turned optimistic on three indicators compared to six months ago, with the most significant recovery seen in stock market confidence, on which the score jumped from 54.5 to 74.7.
The score is the fifth-highest in the Asia-Pacific region and the highest in the Greater China region.
The score of confidence in the economy, meanwhile, moved up from 47.8 to 60.5, while the score of employment confidence rose from 38.5 to 57.0.
Local pessimism remained, however, about regular income and quality of life, although the scores for these two indicators rose from 22.2 to 47.2 and from 34.0 to 43.1, respectively.
The report revealed that compared to six months ago, the Asia-Pacific region has seen an increase in its consumer confidence index score, from 38.7 to 66.3.
Vietnam (90.0) , China (85.3) and Singapore (79.4) showed significantly higher consumer confidence compared to other markets in the region.

Yuwa Hedrick-Wong, MasterCard's Asia-Pacific economic advisor, noted that when the global economy started to stabilize in the second half of 2009, conditions improved especially fast in the Asia-Pacific region.
"The latest findings of the overall robust rebound in consumer confidence in the region mirrors progress seen in the real economy, " he said.

He predicted that renewed consumer confidence will contribute to the momentum of recovery, because it will lead to lower precautionary savings and higher spending, which will in turn improve business outlook and encourage more investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien magistrate's appointment of deputy invalid: MOI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 22:59:55 (By C.C. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Tuesday that Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi's naming of his "ex-wife" as deputy magistrate is invalid, on the grounds that their divorce was fake and that the appointment of his wife therefore is in breach of the relevant laws.

Jiang made the announcement following a meeting in which officials from the Interior Ministry, the Justice Ministry, the Central Personnel Administration, the Executive Yuan and the Control Yuan made the decision.
Jiang said his ministry will ask the Executive Yuan to rescind Fu's appointment of Hsu Chen-wei, his wife, as deputy magistrate of Hualien County because the two are still married to each other.
According to the Public Official Employment Law, it is against the law for a holder of public office to designate a spouse or a family member living under the same roof as his or her deputy.

Fu, who was elected by a landslide in the Dec. 5 local elections running as an independent after being expelled by the ruling Kuomintang, supposedly divorced Hsu Dec. 18 and then picked her as his deputy just three days later.
In a bid to make the divorce appear bona fide, Fu re-registered Hsu's family registration in the house of his mother-in-law, who lives next door to Fu, the MOI said in a news release.

According to Jiang, the MOI will also ask the Control Yuan to fine Fu between NT$1 million (US$30,000) and NT$5 million for breaking the Employment Rules of the Act on Recusal of Public Servants Due to Conflicts of Interest because their actual relations are husband and wife.
Fu's appointment of Hsu is widely seen as an attempt to hold on to the post, as he is also appealing a six-and-a-half-year sentence for violating securities trading regulations.
The MOI said Fu and Hsu are recognized as "members of the same family" given that they are rearing their children together and because they have told supporters that they are still a family.
According to the MOI, the divorce apparently violates Article 87 of the Civil Law and thus was ruled invalid.
Also, in line with the fourth provision of Article 75 of the Local Government Law, Fu's designation of Hsu as his deputy is unlawful, the MOI said.
The case also violates Article 6 and Article 7 of the Enployment Rules of the Act on Recusal of Public Servants Due to Conflicts of Interest for naming a "related person" to a public office post.
So-called "related persons" refer to a spouse or family member living under the same roof, according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP blames MAC, SEF for failing to ink tax deal with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 22 (CNA) 12/22/09 23:10:04 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Tuesday that both the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) head and the chief negotiator with China should be held responsible for failing to ink a tax deal in the latest cross- strait talks that concluded that day in central Taiwan.

MAC Chairwoman Lai shin-yuan and Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , Taiwan's chief negotiator in the talks, are to blame for the failure, said DPP acting spokesman Chung Shuo-han at a press conference.

Chiang and his Chinese counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, signed three agreements on fishery crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification in the talks, the fourth of their kind since last year, but fell short of a fourth on taxation, citing "technical reasons."

"The government should make public the reasons behind the failure for the tax deal, which could result in a loss of NT$30 billion (US$940 million) in tax revenue," said Chien Yao-tang, a research fellow with the Taiwan Thinktank, at the press conference.

Well ahead of the talks, the government had blared about forging the tax pact, and the last-minute failure shows its inability to control the tenor of the negotiations, said Liu Chieh-hsin, deputy chief of the DPP's Strategy Committee.
Concern on the part of China-based Taiwanese investors about a possible tax probe by the government is the main reason for the delay in the cross-strait tax pact, he claimed.

Meanwhile, in response to a challenge by the ruling Kuomintang for the opposition party to publish information concerning investments in China by DPP officials and public office-holders, Liu said the KMT has been trying to "shift the focus of concerns" and has failed to play its role as the ruling party.

KMT spokesman Lee Chien-jung said earlier in the day that given the close cross- strait exchanges over the past decade, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen should publicize such data in light of its opposition to the economic accords signed between Taiwan and China in the just-concluded talks.

Lee said it is regrettable that the DPP ignored the meeting agenda, sent "one- sided" and "misleading" information to its supporters and mobilized protests instead of engaging in rational policy debates.

However, Liu said that as the main opposition party, the DPP is obliged to exercise checks and balances on the government, and that in terms of investments in China, its greatest concern is "whether any of the ruling party members have ever pursued personal interests in the process of talks with China."
"Members of Taiwan's negotiating teams should therefore make public the business operations in China of either their own or family members," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, Dec. 23, or the eighth day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar.
Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1888: Dutch painter Vincent van Gogh cut off one of his ears in an epileptic attack.
1948: Japanese war criminal Eiki Tojo is executed.
1957: Republic of China Premier Yu Hung-chun is impeached by the Control Yuan, the highest watchdog body.
1958: The construction of the 333-meter Tokyo Tower is complete.
1974: The test-flight of B-1 bombers by U.S. pilots proves successful for the first time.
1986: Soviet human rights activist Andrei D. Sakharov is released from exile and he returns to Moscow.
1989: Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are arrested.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 09:32:48 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 10:48:05 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar was higher against the New Taiwan dollar in early trading in Taipei Wednesday.
The greenback was trading at NT$32.364 at 9:45 a.m. on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange, up NT$0.009 from Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Fu's controversy

TEXT.P: The drama surrounding new Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi's politically calculated appointment of his wife of 10-plus years to be his deputy has come to an end after Fu withdrew the appointment late Tuesday in wake of the Interior Ministry's announcement that their divorce was fake.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the controversy:
China Times:
The Ministry of the Interior ruled Tuesday that Fu's divorce with Hsu Chen-wei constituted "collusion" between the couple and that Fu's appointment of Hsu is invalid because of the false divorce.
Fu will be fined up to NT$5 million for violating conflict of interest regulations for civil servants, the ministry said.
Fu later said he would act in accordance with the ministry's order, and he withdrew the appointment. (Dec. 23, 2009)
United Daily News:
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said in a tough tone that Fu's divorce with his wife was obviously false and an attempt to "make use of a loophole in the law."

Civil servants have to act according to the law, and if they "try to take advantage of any loopholes, it is very possible that they will ending up being guilty of even bigger violations, " Jiang added.
Liberty Times:
Fu panned the authorities for being "too ruthless" in ruling that his divorce with Hsu Chen-wei is invalid.
Fu called on the Ma administration not to try to divert public attention from the failed cross-strait talks to his county. (Dec. 23, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - H1N1 flu shots
DOC.DATELINE: 12/23/09 11:56:40 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The death of a 7-year-old boy has again drawn concerns about the possible side effects of the H1N1 vaccine. Despite an increase in the number of reports of side effects, the Department of Health remains confident that the immunization program is an effective way to avert the spread of the virus.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the event:
China Times:

Centers for Disease Control statistics show that the number of people who developed side effects from the vaccine for influenza A (H1N1) has increased by nearly 100 over the past week to 424 people since Taiwan started its national immunization program on Nov. 1. Ninety-three have developed serious symptoms that killed one boy living in central Taiwan.
The government, however, has not stopped underlining that the risk of the vaccine is one in a million, as 4.81 million people have been vaccinated in the country.

Nevertheless, the Cabinet-level Department of Health's "quick" move on Tuesday to declare that the boy's death was not related to the vaccine not only made it difficult for the boy's parents to accept the statement but also sparked public doubt over the safety of the vaccine. (Dec. 23, 2009)
United Daily News:
The Taichung District Prosecutors Office has launched an investigation into the death of the 7-year-old boy in Taichung City who died several weeks after receiving a H1N1 flu shots.
Although the Cabinet-level Department of Health has excluded the vaccines as the cause of death, prosecutors think it is necessary to find the real culprit. (Dec. 23, 2009)
Liberty Times:

Following the report of the 7-year-old boy's death, many worried readers have reported to the newspaper that their family members have developed symptoms such as fevers and headaches after receiving the flu vaccine.

Taichung City Councilor Chang Yiao-chung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party took six phone calls on Tuesday from people describing themselves as family members of victims of the H1N1 vaccine. One complained of her daughter suffering from numbness and blurred vision.
The petitioners expressed their hope to make contact with the boy's father and organize with him a self-help association. (Dec. 23, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Formosan sika deer to find new home in Shandong
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 12:05:51 (By Feng Chao and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A pair of Formosan serow and a pair of Formosan sika deer presented to China will be housed in northeast China, according to China's top negotiator with Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), said Tuesday that after an evaluation, it was decided that the animals will be sent to a forest park in Weihai, Shandong province.
Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), welcomed the arrangement.

The SEF and the ARATS signed agreements later that day on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification in the fourth and latest round of the Chiang-Chen talks.
The two intermediary bodies reached a consensus during their second round of talks in Nov. 2008 to present each other with rare indigenous fauna and flora species as tokens of friendship and amity.
A pair of giant pandas and 17 Davidia involucrata, or dove trees, were sent by China to Taiwan last December.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges civil servants to upgrade communication skills
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 13:19:15 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the country's civil servants Wednesday to improve their communications skills and develop the ability to both "work" and "communicate."
The president lauded the standards and efficiency of civil servants, but described their communications skills as being relatively weak.

"Some say civil servants should do their jobs quietly. There's nothing wrong with that but it is not good for civil servants to only 'do' but not 'communicate' or conversely to only 'talk' without doing anything," Ma said.
In some cases, the president said, it is even better if government officials can communicate their ideas before carrying them out.

When, for instance, the Taipei City government launched a policy to collect garbage fees beginning July 1, 2000 by forcing people to pay for the garbage bags they used, the city government began a publicity drive three months earlier on April 1, recalled Ma, who was major of the city at the time.
Because the people do not always believe government publicity drives, the government sometimes has to repeat its message "over and over again."

In other cases, government officials need to "communicate after carrying out a task, " said Ma, citing the recent controversial lifting of a partial ban on imports of U.S. beef, including products such as ground beef and beef offal that some feared could be potentially tainted with bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
Ma said that after the Department of Health (DOH) lifted the ban, it then announced a series of measures to ensure the safety of the imported beef.
DOH minister Yaung Chih-liang also explained Tuesday the results of safety checks over the past two months to assuage public fears on the safety of U.S. beef, he added.
He urged the Examination Yuan and the Central Personnel Administration to make "public relations and communications" among the major points of emphasis of civil servant training.

Ma, speaking at a meeting of national personnel and administrative officials, also asked the Examination Yuan to arrange that the award-winning movie "No Puedo Vivir Sin Ti" be screened for civil servants.
Ma said Leon Dai, the film's director, invited him to watch it when it came out, but he was preoccupied at the time with flood-relief efforts in the wake of Typhoon Morakot.
"I'll go see the movie soon," Ma said.

Dai received the best director award at the 53rd Asian Pacific Film Festival last Saturday for the film, which is based on the true story of a single father's frustration in dealing with unhelpful and uncaring bureaucrats in trying to maintain legal custody of his daughter.
The film won five awards, including best director, at Taiwan's Golden Horse Film Festival, Taiwan's equivalent of the Oscars, last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Wasted taxpayer money

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait decided Monday to temporarily shelve a double taxation avoidance agreement that was scheduled to be signed Tuesday.
It is too early to make any judgment on what happened as the government has yet to reveal how and why the long talked-about agreement was dropped at the last minute.
But scenes of officials giving conflicting explanations or arguments were not what an efficient government should have done.

Public outrage hit a climax after Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said he was informed last Thursday of the possibility that the tax accord might be taken off the list of agreements to be signed at this week's high-level cross- strait talks.

Since government authorities were already aware of the tax pact's fate, why did the Ministry of Finance still run prominently displayed advertisements in various media on the eve of the meeting touting the merits of the accord at a cost of NT$4 million?

If the decision to run the ad was not caused by poor interministerial coordination, then it reflected the Finance Ministry's foolhardiness and idiocy. Worse still, few understood what the ad said. It was truly a waste of taxpayer money.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's negotiator draws protests as he visits Miaoli
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 13:55:43 (By Chen Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, was dogged by protesters Wednesday as he visited tourist attractions in northern Taiwan's Miaoli County.

The president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) had lunch with Miaoli County Magistrate Liu Cheng-hung at a local resort village before visiting the Sanyi Wood Sculpture Museum to get a taste of local art.
Before Chen arrived at the resort village, however, Falun Gong practitioners had already gathered there to wait for him.

According to the activists, over 200 Falun Gong practitioners were to be deployed at each of the places that Chen was to visit Wednesday to protest against Beijing's suppression of the Falun Gong movement in China.

The Falun Group protesters were confronted by a pro-unification group outside the resort village, the West Lake Resortopia, before Chen arrived, but they ended up doing nothing more than trading verbal barbs.
The heavy police presence outside the resort added to the tense atmosphere, but no violence erupted thanks to good communications between the protesters and the police.

Chen arrived in Taiwan Monday for his fourth round of talks with his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), that was held Tuesday in central Taiwan's Taichung City.
During the talks, the two sides signed agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural and food quarantine and inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Failed tax agreement not bad for Taiwan: experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 15:54:59 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's failure to sign a tax agreement with China in just-concluded cross- Taiwan Strait negotiations is not necessarily a bad thing for Taiwan and proves that the deal will have to gain more support before being signed, according to experts.

Representatives from Taiwan and China inked three agreements Tuesday on agricultural inspection and quarantine cooperation, industrial standards testing and certification cooperation, and fishery labor cooperation.

A fourth item on the agenda -- an agreement on the avoidance of double taxation and strengthening of tax cooperation -- was not signed, as the two sides failed to reach consensus, citing "technical issues."
The development marked the first time since cross-strait talks resumed last year after a nine-year hiatus that an agreement on the agenda was not signed.
"China never presumes it has to reach concrete results before entering any negotiations, " said Kenneth Lin, an economics professor at National Taiwan University.

Lin said the failure to sign the tax agreement is not necessarily bad for Taiwan because the country in the past has always asked for something solid in negotiations, even though it could end up to be a disadvantage.
"Not being able to sign the agreement... is not necessarily a bad thing for us. We don't have to set a deadline and tie our own hands, " he said.
The technical issues that were said to hamper the bilateral talks, Lin said, could still be political issues rather than tax revenue problems.

Most Taiwanese businessmen investing in China do so through companies in a third country to avoid being taxed, Lin went on, adding that Taiwanese businessmen are mostly concerned that "China has been using tax inspections as tool to pester Taiwanese businesses in China."
Tax agreements are usually signed between allies, friendly countries or countries at similar levels of economic development, but that is not the case between Taiwan and China, Lin said.
"I would say that the key here is not tax issues but political issues, such as the wording of the document, " he said.
"At the end of the day, a government has to protect its own taxpayers, " Lin noted.
However, other experts looked at the negotiations, which took place in the central Taiwan city of Taichung from Dec. 21-23, in a different light.
Yin Nai-ping, a finance professor at National Chengchi University, said the "technical issues" that doomed the tax talks were related to the avoidance of double taxation.

"I believe that Taiwan made the request to include Taiwanese businesses investing indirectly in China through a third country on the double taxation list in the negotiations, but China refused to accept this, " Yin said.
Yin said the sovereignty issue is not as serious as it might seem and that "the real problem is the sophisticated tax regulations."

Taiwan's opposition parties have questioned whether taxpayers' information could end up in the hands of the Chinese authorities once an agreement on tax cooperation takes effect, which raised concern among local businessmen, Yin said.
"I think the widespread uneasiness over the issue made Taiwanese officials particularly cautious in the talks, " he added.
It is only natural to differ in the process of negotiations and "the most important thing is to identify the argument and ultimately work out a solution that both sides can accept, " Yin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait pacts beneficial to people: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 16:05:37 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that the three latest agreements signed with China are all in the interests of Taiwan and its people.

The agreement on fishing crew cooperation, for example, is aimed at providing a system to regulate the hiring of Chinese fishing crews by Taiwanese boat owners to reduce disputes and conflicts, Wu said during a meeting with a group of Control Yuan members who were visiting the Executive Yuan for an inspection tour.
The agreement on agricultural quarantine inspection, meanwhile, will accelerate and standardize exports of Taiwanese agricultural products to China, Wu went on.

He promised that in pushing toward the goal of signing a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , the government will also make sure that it meets the needs of Taiwan, wins the support of the people, and is subject to the supervision of the Legislative Yuan.
On the country's economic situation, Wu said the economy has shown signs of growth in the fourth quarter of this year, after declines recorded in the three previous quarters.
Although the economy is projected to contract by 2.54 percent for 2009, it is likely to recover and post growth of 4.39 percent in 2010, according to Wu.
Private investment in 2010 is expected to amount to NT$1.03 trillion, he said.

The premier also said boosting employment is one of the most important objectives of the government's economic stimulus measures and that the administration will continue to work to achieve the goal by promoting investment, simplifying procedures and enhancing efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan subsidiaries of Chinese firms to enjoy tax incentives: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 16:24:31 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese subsidiaries of Chinese enterprises in high-tech fields will be eligible to take advantage of tax incentives offered to high-tech businesses, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Wednesday.

C. Y. Ling, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Investment Services, said in Taichung at a seminar on Chinese investment in Taiwan on the last day of cross-strait talks that the enterprises can apply for the tax breaks offered under the Statute for Upgrading Industries and Statute for Innovating Industries.

Woody T. J. Duh, director general of the MOEA's Industrial Development Bureau, explained that any foreign-invested or Chinese-invested enterprise is considered a legal entity in Taiwan and therefore eligible for the tax breaks as long as they have been established in compliance with Taiwan's Corporation Law.
"They must be subsidiaries, however. Branches and representative offices are not eligible," Duh said.

That's because the finances of subsidiaries, unlike branches, are independent of the finances of their parent companies, Duh explained, citing the example of U.S.-based insurer AIG and its Taiwanese subsidiary Nan Shan Life Insurance.
Because their finances were separate, AIG's sale of Nan Shan Life is being reviewed independently from AIG.
Among the foreign investors that now enjoy tax incentives under the statutes are IBM and Philips Electronics, he added.
The Statute for Upgrading Industries will expire at the end of this year and will be replaced by the Statute for Innovating Industries starting next year.

Under the new program, the MOEA will offer incentives for investments in R&D and talent cultivation but will not give companies five-year corporate income tax holidays as had been the case previously.

Wang Jing, chairwoman of Fujian Newland Group, the first Chinese enterprise to invest in Taiwan, expressed the hope on the same occasion that Taiwan will give greater access, such as landing visas, to company employees traveling between the two sides and provide tax incentives for high-tech industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices rise above 7,900 on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 17:14:05 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices extended gains to surge above 7,900 Wednesday, led by a strong showing of automobile and electronics shares and following overnight gains on Wall Street.
By the end of the trading day, the weighted index, the market's key barometer, had risen 45.50 points, or 0.57 percent, to close at 7,901.50.
The local bourse opened at 7,892.75 and fluctuated between 7,910.88 and 7,873.22 during the session.
A total of 4.16 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$118.42 billion (US$3.66 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics shares gaining the most at 0.9 percent. Banking and financial stocks advanced 0.5 percent, textile shares and construction issues both rose 0.2 percent, and plastics and chemicals stocks increased 0.1 percent.
Foodstuff shares remained unchanged.
The two other major stock categories lost ground, with cement shares and paper and pulp stocks both sliding 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,413 to 1,247, with 294 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$10.81 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 17:15:21 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.050 to close at NT$32.360.
A total of US$592 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.400 and dipped to a low of NT$32.300 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Roses and thorns

TEXT.P: The last-minute halt to the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait double taxation avoidance agreement can be seen as "beautiful setback" to the institutionalized high-level cross-strait engagements known as "Chiang-Chen" meetings.

While pessimistic observers may just see thorns on roses and conclude that the incident does not bode well for future cross-strait dealings, we believe the temporary shelving of the proposed accord is a prudent decision of positive significance.

As double tax avoidance accords tend to be applied only to direct investment, signing such an accord with China is expected to help enhance transparency in cross-strait investment supervision and even encourage multinational companies that plan to tap into the Chinese market to use Taiwan as their regional operation hub.

The government has yet to reveal what was the straw that broke the taxation deal at the last minute, but we believe the breakdown indicated that there were difficulties applying internationally accepted regulations to cross-strait engagements due to sensitive sovereignty issues.
As every rose has its thorns, those difficulties were the thorns in the "Chiang- Chen" meetings.

Although the decision came as a surprise, it served as a reminder to local society that the regular meetings between Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart, Chen Yunlin, are not high-profile social functions or rituals, but rather bona fide negotiations that may hit snags.
The unexpected setback should also alert the government to the pitfalls and uncertainties in cross-strait talks.

With negotiations now evolving from the primary stage of dealing with issues that are purely advantageous to both sides, into an intermediate stage of trading benefits or even competing for benefits, the government should work even harder to make its policy more transparent. The government should have confidence in the maturity of public discourse in Taiwan. Candid policy discussion is the best way to win public trust and support.
The opposition party should also fulfill its duty by strengthening supervision and coming up with solid policy initiatives instead of empty talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should develop yachting services: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 17:34:24 (By Yun-hsuan Cheng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: As an island nation renowned for its yacht- building, Taiwan should take an open attitude toward the development of a yachting services industry, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Wednesday.

San Gee, deputy minister of the CEPD, said in a seminar on developing the service industry that it seems ironic that the government restricts the development of local yachting services for security reasons, while even South Korea has decided to develop its maritime tourism this year.

Taiwan is well-known in the rest of the world for its yacht-building industry. However, people in Taiwan have no experience of yachting, San said, adding that the government should consider a different attitude toward developing the country's tourism industry.

San noted that South Korea -- despite the threat from North Korea -- still decided to develop its coastal leisure recreation business to stimulate domestic demand and is considering loosening restrictions on the issuance of yachting licenses.
As South Korea has taken an open attitude, Taiwan can surely follow suit, San said.

Singling out Kueishan Island as an example, Sun noted that the volcanic islet about 10 km off the coast of Toucheng in northeast Taiwan is actually very close to Taiwan. However, as the government has set numerous restrictions on visiting the island, people feel it is a distant place.
He suggested that the government adopt supporting measures such as using a Global Positioning System to manage the island.

According to the island's administration, people who want to visit must file applications via its Web site three to 20 days before their scheduled visit. As the number of total visitors cannot exceed 400 people during weekdays and 500 during weekends, the computer makes random selections each day. Selected applicants have to travel there with qualified and approved boatmen.

One of Taiwan's major yacht-builders has described Taiwan as the only country in the world in which yachts are built on land and the only yacht-building country in the world in which yachting has until recently not been permitted.

According to Horizon Yachts, the largest builder in Asia and sixth-largest in the world, Taiwan's yacht industry is a 30-year veteran in the yachting world, even though the sport is non-existent in the country as a result of restrictive regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hualien magistrate backs down over appointment of `ex-wife' as deputy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 18:38:24 (By Sophia Yeh, J.T. Liu and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said Wednesday that he will revoke his earlier appointment of his "ex- wife" as his deputy in line with a decision by the Ministry of the Interior.

Fu, who was elected by a landslide in the Dec. 5 local elections running as an independent after being expelled by the ruling Kuomintang, supposedly divorced his wife Hsu Chen-wei Dec. 18 and then picked her as his deputy just three days later.

Fu's move was interpreted as a "well-calculated attempt" for his wife to hold on to the post on his behalf in case he has to serve a jail term mid-way through his tenure -- he is appealing a six-and-a-half-year sentence for violating securities trading regulations.

Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah decided after a meeting with officials of relevant government agencies a day earlier that Fu's appointment of Hsu was invalid and in breach of the relevant laws, including the Public Official Employment Law and the Employment Rules of the Act on Recusal of Public Servants Due to Conflicts of Interest, as their supposed divorce was fake.

Fu said in a press conference that he was "surprised" to find the high administrative efficiency of the central government by deciding in just one day in an inter-ministerial meeting that his divorce and appointment of Hsu were invalid, and he questioned whether the marital status of other Taiwanese people are subject to approval by inter-ministerial meeting.

Despite Fu's revocation of Hsu's appointment, Ma Yi-kung, a member of the Control Yuan -- the country's top watchdog agency -- said he will still conduct an investigation into the case and that a fine of between NT$1 million and NT$5 million will be imposed on Fu if he is found to have broken any laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH seeks obligatory autopsies after alleged vaccine death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 18:39:10 (By Chen Li-tien and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) announced Wednesday it will seek to amend the law to allow obligatory autopsies to be performed on controversial deaths involving vaccinations, following the report of a boy who died after getting vaccinated against influenza A(H1N1).

CDC Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw explained that mandatory autopsies will allow health authorities to find out the exact cause of any controversial death related to vaccinations in a short period of time, so that the authorities can mitigate public doubts on the safety of vaccines and prevent panic.
The 7-year-old child, who lived in central Taiwan, passed away on Monday, several weeks after receiving the H1N1 inoculation on Nov.19.
The boy's father, who works as a physician, called the 1922 H1N1 vaccination consultation hotline on Dec. 2 after his son developed a high fever and a skin rash the day after getting the vaccination.
Health authorities, however, could not determine what was making the child ill and treatment they prescribed failed to save the boy.
Following the boy's death, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) was blasted for failing to swiftly and seriously respond to the case.

But DOH Vice Minister Chang Shang-chun and CDC experts had immediately called an emergency telephone conference with the boy's father in an attempt to offer help, according to CDC Director-General Steve Kuo.
After preliminary discussions, the experts concluded the death was unrelated to the H1N1 vaccine and that an immunity system problem could have been one of the causes of the death, Kuo said.
The conclusion, however, has failed to convince the heart-broken father that the H1N1 vaccine was not the killer of his son.
On Wednesday, Chou expressed regret that despite all the efforts the DOH has taken to address the case, it still has not been able to stem public panic amid the national H1N1 immunization.

He pointed out that under the standard procedure regulated in the vaccine injury compensation program (VICP) , a probe into controversial vaccine injuries or deaths can only be launched at the request of the victim's family members.
"If they are not willing to ask for an investigation nor allow an autopsy, it is not possible to swiftly find out the cause, " Chou said.
Chou declined to say whether the family has refused to have an autopsy conducted. The boy's family could not be reached for comment.
Under the existing law, autopsies can only be performed on people who died of unidentified contagious diseases. PLURAL OK?
Meanwhile, the Taichung District Prosecutors' Office has launched an investigation into the latest death case allegedly caused by the H1N1 inoculation.

It is reported that since Taiwan's national H1N1 immunization program began on Nov. 1, a total of 424 out of 4.81 million people who had received the inoculation have complained of suffering from serious symptoms, including high fever after taking the shot.

DOC.HEADLINE: People urged to receive H1N1 immunization
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 18:57:38 (By Chen Li-tien and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The influenza A(H1N1) , commonly known as swine flu, is expected to stage a resurgence that might be more virulent than the present outbreak, a Taiwanese professional medical group warned Wednesday, urging people to get vaccinated.

Lee Ping-ing, secretary-general of the Taiwan Immunization Vision and Strategy Alliance, made the call amid reports of public concerns over the safety of the H1N1 vaccine triggered by a recent case in which a 7-year-old boy from central Taiwan died several weeks after being immunized.
The father of the boy, a physician, has claimed that the vaccine was the culprit, but health authorities and other medical experts excluded the possibility after studying the case.

Lee, who is also a pediatrician at National Taiwan University Hospital, said there are at least 50 percent - 75 percent of people in the country who have still not been immunized, while "1 or 2 million" people have obtained immunity after recovering from the flu and nearly 5 million have had the shot.

These non-vaccinated people will be at highest risk of the next wave of swine flu, which could be more deadly because the virus might have mutated, Lee predicted, noting that judging from the seasonal flu epidemic outbreaks in the past, there are usually two or three big outbreaks in one epidemic.

Citing U.S. research that found the swine flu virus invades deep into the lungs, Lee warned the public not to take the virus lightly, adding that they also should not harbor that idea that they will not need to be vaccinated if others are instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan has difficulty playing a role in TPP process: scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/23/09 18:58:51 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: American scholars said in a video conference with Taiwan government officials and economic specialists Wednesday that while the United States needs trade policy to engage Asia and the expansion of the Trans-Pacific Strategic Economic Partnership (TPP) is seen as an opportunity, Taiwan still has difficulty playing a role.

Ernie Bower, a senior adviser and director of the Southeast Asia Program of the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), pointed out that the multilateral free trade agreement, which was signed 15 years ago by Brunei, Chile, New Zealand and Singapore, was mentioned by U.S. President Barack Obama during a Nov. 14 speech in Tokyo.

His announcement that the U.S. intends to engage its trade partners in shaping a broad-based regional agreement has inspired expectations that the TPP could become a process toward a framework for a free trade agreement for the Asia- Pacific region.
Brower said, however, that the TPP as part of an FTA process is more of a goal or a new approach of the U.S. Democratic Party and that there is no time frame.

Referring to a question from an official of Taiwan's Board of Foreign Trade as to whether the long term goal for U.S. engagement in TPP is to connect TPP to the 21 members of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, Bower suggested that the U.S. will first consider the pending free trade agreements with Korea and the inclusion of Japan.
Charles Freeman, chairman of the CSIS Freeman Chair, said that while the U.S. needs a trade policy to engage Asia, "the closest at hand is TPP to reshape the trade agenda."
He added, however, that the process "doesn't mean much to Taiwan at present."
Both Freeman and Bower suggested that it is too early for Taiwan to expect linkage between TPP negotiation and APEC, of which Taiwan is a member.

As to the question of whether the proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will restrain Taiwan's FTA aspirations, Freeman suggested that Taiwan should maintain a balanced approach between ECFA and its traditional partners.

Referring to the barriers to Taiwan inking free trade agreements with its trading partners, Freeman pointed out that China might mobilize its business lobby in Washington and meanwhile try to put pressure on its trading partners that are over-dependent on China's market to block Taiwan.
Terry Cooke, senior fellow of the Foreign Policy Research Institute, said that "any effort by China to undercut Taiwan's efforts will only undercut China's efforts to separate politics from economy."

The video conference was organized by the Office of Trade Negotiations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, with Sherman Katz, fellow of the Center for the Study of the Presidency and Congress, a Washington-based think tank, as moderator.
