DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media - Clashes

TEXT.P: A local police officer was rushed to hospital and six men were detained late Wednesday after the policeman fell from a truck while trying to stop protesters from shooting fireworks at a Taichung City hotel where top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin was staying.
The incident involved the most serious injury and the first arrests since Chen's arrival Monday for a new round of high-level cross-strait talks.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the controversy:
United Daily News:

A bloody clash broke out Wednesday night when Chen Chu-hsiang, a Taichung police squad leader, was allegedly pushed from a van while trying to stop pro- independence activists from launching fireworks in the direction of the Windsor Hotel in the central city where China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin was staying.

The 49-year-old police officer sustained a head injury that caused bleeding inside the skull, and has been placed in intensive care for further observation, doctors said. "The next three days are the most critical," said a hospital spokesman.
After the incident, the six protesters were detained for questioning. They claimed that the police officer was not pushed, but rather fell from the van accidentally.

In the wake of the bloody incident, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen issued two statements in succession, calling for society to remain calm and urging protesters to express their opinions in a rational, peaceful manner. (Dec.24, 2009)
China Times:

While Chang Chih-mei, chief executive of the "908 Taiwan Republic Campaign" who led the protest, insisted that no one pushed the injured policeman, Yu Hui-mao, deputy director-general of Taichung City's Police Bureau, said police video footage shows that the officer was indeed pushed from the vehicle.
Yu urged the protesters to express their views in a peaceful manner to avoid recurrence of similar incidents. (Dec.24, 2009)
Liberty Times:

More than 300 young adults dressed red jackets or pink T-shirts appeared near the popular CehnLan Temple in central Taiwan's Dajia township Wednesday ahead of a visit there by China's top negotiator Chen Yunlin.

While anti-Beijing protesters claimed that the young men were mobilized by an underworld criminal syndicate to protect Chen, the temple's chairman, Legislator Yen Ching-piao, said the private security detail was from two volunteer groups closely associated with the temple. Their presence was only aimed at ensuring that Chen's visit proceeded smoothly, Yen insisted. (Dec.24, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Preventing sellout
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan editorial abstract (File 2 of a daily roundup) 12/24/09 12:25:35 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The administration of Ma Ying-jeou has blocked the people out of the secret negotiations between the Kuomintang and the Chinese Communists in order to show China its earnestness.

Earlier, the Ma administration refused to allow a referendum for the people to decide on the proposed signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. The administration's aim was the same -- to marginalize its own people.

This approach makes it clear that President Ma is fully aware of the unpopularity of the KMT-CCP secret negotiations, the private agreements, the Legislature's rejection of supervision, and the ever closer cross-strait economic and trade relations reflected in the proposed Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on monetary cooperation and the ECFA.

In a democratic country, the administration should heed public opinion. President Ma, however, has blocked out the people's opinions. As he puts up barriers against the people, isn't President Ma afraid of being rejected by them?
It is generally known that although Taiwan and Hong Kong have totally different status, China has been trying to apply the Hong Kong model to Taiwan.
Since most of the people in Taiwan are not willing to be swallowed by China or become part of China, it will be extremely difficult for China to "unify" with Taiwan with the consent of the people.

Taiwan and China are two countries on each side of the Taiwan Strait, which is different from Hong Kong's status as a colony before its return to China. People in Hong Kong did not have the right to voice their expectations about the future, and it was too late for them to promote democracy after the handover.

Based on Hong Kong's experience, we can see the reasons for the consistent protests by sensible people against the Chiang-Chen negotiations and why the demonstrations must not be demeaned as nonsensical trouble-making.

DOC.HEADLINE: No need to alter H1N1 immunization program: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 13:45:19 (By Justin Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top health official said Thursday there's no likelihood of the government revising the ongoing immunization program against H1N1 flu, as the campaign is doing much more good than harm.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said that so far there has been only one fatality that could possibly be linked to the vaccine, although the cause of the death is yet to be determined, and that relatively few people have developed side effects.

"The number of deaths from influenza H1N1 would have been comparatively much higher had Taiwan not launched the H1N1 immunization campaign, " Yaung told the press after a hearing at the Legislative Yuan on regulations governing Taiwan's medical sector.
"So far Taiwan has had 33 H1N1 fatalities, a much better figure than most other countries in the world," he said.
In addition, he said, the number of new H1N1 cases has dropped significantly since the vaccination campaign was launched nationwide Nov. 1.
According to DOH statistics, since the start of the immunization program, a total of 424 of the 4.81 million people who have been vaccinated have complained of serious symptoms, including high fever.

Meanwhile, Yaung said the DOH will organize a special task force, comprised of experts from Taiwan's medical and legal fields, to address controversies related to side effects of the H1N1 inoculation.

In response to reports that the family of a seven-year-old boy who died allegedly from the H1N1 vaccine has refused to have an autopsy performed on the body, Yaung said the Taichung District Prosecutors' Office has launched an investigation into the case and the DOH will respect the prosecutors' findings and their decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: The Gordian Knot
DOC.DATELINE: 12/24/09 14:24:36 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The 15 member states of the United National Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) concluded the Copenhagen conference with a declaration that the parties would "take note" of the document, called the Copenhagen Accord, but no consensus was achieved regarding the sharing of responsibilities or the right to impose restrictions.

Although the road to continued negotiations is not totally closed, the United States and China's battle for leverage at almost every turn portends difficulty in achieving and implementing a protocol to contain the problem of global warming.

The confrontations between the U.S. and China at the Copenhagen summit reflected the conflict over finding a balance between economic development and the rights and obligations to protect the environment.

For most countries, making a choice between economic development and environmental protection is comparable to untying the legendary "Gordian Knot." In the Greek legend, the person who untied the knot would rule all of Asia, and the highly intricate knot resisted all attempts until the year 333 B.C., when Alexander the Great cut through it with a sword.

The government's difficulty in making a choice is best reflected in Premier Wu Den-yih's recent comments on three job-creating investment projects, although the three projects might run into carbon emissions problems in the environmental screening and evaluation stage, they need to be implemented soon.

On the other hand, Morris Chang, founding chairman and chief executive officer of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company Ltd. (TSMC), who is an advocate of turning the challenge of environmental protection into opportunity for the development of clean the energy industry, has recently voiced concerns about the environment. "Those who do not plan for the future will find trouble on their doorstep, " Chang said, quoting a Chinese proverb.

Taiwan is a small island country constantly threatened by natural disasters such as floods, earthquakes and droughts. Over-development has led to more environmental damage. Although no consensus was reached in Copenhagen, the summit could serve as an reminder of the need for government policy on land conservation.
We expect the government to break through conventional thinking and display its resoluteness to cut its "Gordian Knot."

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA news budget for Dec. 24

TEXT.P: Pregnant women should first consult doctors before

being immunized: CDC 3.Talk of the day -- first clashes 4. Chinese negotiator visits Buddhist Temple 5. Su Chi talks on US beef 6. DOH will facilitate post- H1N1 inoculation tracking 7. Adimmune reassures safety of eggs for vaccine production

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH plans system to track H1N1 inoculation problems
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 16:13:53 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health will consider making survey forms available to people who have received the H1N1 flu vaccine, as a means of tracking side effects or any other problems, Taiwan's top health official said Thursday.

Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said at the Legislative Yuan that the idea is for the DOH to ask people who have received the H1N1 vaccine to enter information on the survey forms that will give health authorities a better grasp of the problems and complaints related to the immunization program.

Yaung made the suggestion in response to opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Huang Sue-ying's criticism of DOH officials' "bad attitude" of immediately denying that reactive symptoms, side effects, and even deaths "had nothing to do with the H1N1 vaccination."

The health minister told the legislator that the DOH will set up a special task force, comprised of experts from Taiwan's medical and legal fields, to jointly address controversies related to H1N1 inoculation complaints.
However, Yaung said, he does not yet have any concrete ideas on how such a task force should function.
Meanwhile, he advised that people who are not medical professionals refrain from making statements or accusations on matters related to H1N1 vaccination complaints.
"It is better to let the specialists talk. Otherwise the DOH will be defeated by the media before the facts could be determined, " he urged.
In related news, Steve Kuo, director-general of the DOH Centers for Disease Control, suggested Thursday that pregnant women consult their obstetricians before getting the H1N1 vaccine.

Although the World Health Organization as well as the health authorities of Taiwan and the United States have advised that vaccination is safe at any stage of pregnancy, Kuo said it would be better for the pregnant women to consult a doctor before getting immunized.

He made the statement after five problem cases involving pregnant women were reported. Two of the women had stillbirths, two had miscarriages, and the fifth was distressed to learn, after she had received the H1N1 vaccine, that she was pregnant.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reneging on beef opening would hurt U.S. support for Taiwan: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 16:42:45 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A top national security official on Thursday urged lawmakers and the public not to demand a reopening of talks with the United States on controversial beef imports, warning that reneging on an agreement to lift a ban on the imports would hurt relations.

National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi said Taiwanese people should take into account Taiwan's limited role in the international community when considering how to approach this issue.

Taiwan needs the support of the United States, its biggest ally, in its participation in international organizations and if Taiwan violates a recently- reached protocol on the import of U.S. beef, it is likely to see the U.S. and its lawmakers hold back their support for the island, said Su.

Su noted that the U.S. Congress attaches great importance to the issue as 70 percent of the U.S. congressional leaders are from agricultural states. U.S. Congress is also a long-time major force backing Taiwan, Su added.

In addition, "there has been no progress in the economic relationship between Taiwan and the U.S. in the past 10 years despite improvements in the political relations" since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May last year, Su said.

Going back on Taiwan's agreement to lift the ban on U.S. beef products previously restricted could continue to put on hold long-stalled talks between the two sides on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) , double taxation, intellectual property rights and energy and environmental cooperation, Su warned.
Nonetheless, Su said that he will "respect the final decision by the legislature" and "the people's right to initiate a referendum on the issue."
He, nevertheless, urged the legislature not to amend any law to deal with the matter, saying that the current control measures are enough to safeguard the public's health.
If the referendum on renegotiating the issue passes, Su said he will "abide by" the decision.
Su made the remarks at his first press conference since he took the post in May last year.

Taiwan's government agreed to lift a ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products in late October, leading to widespread criticisms and concerns about public health due to fears of mad cow disease.

The government has organized a series of press conferences, -- by the Department of Heath, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, respectively -- since Dec. 22 to clarify its policy on U.S. beef.

Ruling and opposition lawmakers have both proposed their versions of the draft amendments to the Act Governing Food Sanitation in face of growing pressure from the public. They may reach a consensus on Dec. 29.

Su on Thursday also clarified that Taiwan and the U.S. could hold a meeting to review the beef import agreement "within, " not "in, "180 days after Taiwan's government decided to allow the U. S. beef products into the island, as stipulated in the pact. But Su did not elaborate on that.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Taxation agreement
DOC.DATELINE: 12/24/09 16:44:42 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The fourth round of negotiations between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , and Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for the Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , concluded with only three agreements on technical issues.

The reason for the failure to sign a double taxation avoidance agreement has not been disclosed either by the negotiators or the Ministry of Finance, but Premier Wu Den-yih has given an explanation that is far removed from the media speculations.

According to the media, the reasons are that the two sides have differing views on the tax jurisdiction; there are fears that China with its non-democratic system may use political means to scrutinize businesses, and financial and taxation data may be used to threaten Taiwanese businesses; and there is worry among many people over the retroactive clause in the proposed agreement.

Some media have also suggested that under strong lobby from some Taiwanese businessmen who are worried that greater transparency would mean paying more taxes, the Ministry of Finance was cowed into shelving the agreement.
We think this is the most unacceptable reason and hope it is nothing but a rumor.
We regret that the government agencies concerned have not issued any statements of clarification and that there have been only whispers and speculations by people other than the relevant authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Dilly-dallying policy making
DOC.DATELINE: 12/24/09 16:47:10 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Last week, Premier Wu Den-yih was "furious" about the low efficiency in the government administration, and the Economic Daily News pointed out in an editorial that the key to the problem remains the irresponsible mentality of government officials.

Taking the proposal of allowing people using their home equity to live a life of retirement as an example, while the practice can be realized as an arrangement between banking institutions and individuals approved by the Financial Supervisory Commission, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said that the government will complete the feasibility study within a year and a prototype of such an arrangement can be expected at the end of next year.

Minister Jiang doesn't seem to understand that "policy evaluation, " which has its urgency is different from "academic research." With the convenience in obtaining information nowadays, the feasibility study should be completed within a month. If the proposal is found workable, a draft plan for the implementation should be submitted within a month.
The issue regarding whether to allow the semiconductor, flat panel display and petrochemical industries to invest in China has been studied by the government for over 10 years.

While China remains the major market for the three sectors with big investments, if Taiwanese manufacturers fail to participate in the growth of these industries on the Chinese mainland, they will suffer a serious setback when the Chinese industries achieve full-fledged development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Teaching old dogs new tricks
DOC.DATELINE: 12/24/09 16:49:13 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The system of evaluating the performance of public servants has been criticized as being useless. President Ma Ying-jeou has suggested that while public servants can be faulted for giving "lip service without action, or action without elaboration, " they should be able "to talk and act, to talk and act at the same time, to elaborate first and then implement, and to elaborate after implementation."
Although there is some truth to Ma's comments, the people can see with their own eyes.

Many public servants, especially some intractable and conservative senior ones, are only concerned about having an easy time before their retirement. Haven't you heard the saying, "You can't teach an old dog new tricks"? This is the result of a system of false equity that purports we are "all taking food from the same pot."

Taiwan's drastic lagging behind other emerging countries is closely related to the quality of its public servants. This is not a matter of communications or government publicity, but rather attitude and mentality.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator visits famous Buddhist temple
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Taiwan, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 17:05:12 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan visited the famous Buddhist Chung Tai Chan Monastery in central Taiwan's Nantou County Thursday amid mild protests from pro-independence activists.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), was greeted by more than 500 Buddhist followers who lined up at the main entrance to the sprawling temple complex to welcome him.

Chen was accompanied by his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, and staff members of the two quasi-official intermediary organizations in charge of cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
Dharma Master Wei Chueh, the monastery's founder and abbot, met Chen in the magnificent monastery's main prayer hall.
In a speech delivered at a welcoming party, Chen said it has been one of his great wishes in his 20 years of dealing with Taiwan affairs to meet Master Wei Chueh.
"My wish is fulfilled today and I feel flattered by warm friendship and hospitality shown by friends at the temple," Chen said emotionally.
Chen praised Wei Chueh for his outstanding contributions to the promotion of cross-strait religious exchanges over the past decades.

Noting that many Chinese people believe in Buddhism in hopes of peace and goodness prevailing in the world and everybody leading a happy life, Chen said he gets a taste of such sentiments while touring around the Chung Tai complex.

While Chen and his mission arrived at the monastery, more than 10 members of a radical pro-independence advocacy group "908 Taiwan Republic Campaign" held up anti-China placards and chanted slogans to protest against the ARATS delegation's visit to Taiwan.
In contrast to clashes the day before in neighboring Taichung City, the protest at the temple proceeded relatively peacefully.

Dozens of practitioners of the Falun Gong spiritual group, which is outlawed and persecuted in China, also staged a sit-in along the main road to the Chung Tai Monastery to appeal for and end to China's suppression of Falun Gong followers in the mainland.

Chen is in Taiwan for the fourth-round of talks between China and Taiwan since relations improved after Taiwan's President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008 focusing on reducing tensions and strengthening economic ties.

Prior to Chen's arrival on Monday, tens of thousands of protesters demonstrated against his visit on Sunday and the Taiwanese government's plan to sign an agreement with China next year aimed at removing trade barriers.
Chen is scheduled to leave Taiwan on Friday after signing three agreements with Chiang Tuesday on cooperation in fishing crew issues, agricultural quarantine and industrial products certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Adimmune affirms quality of eggs used for H1N1 vaccine production
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 17:25:21 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's vaccine manufacturer Adimmune Corp. gave the assurance Thursday that there was no problem with the quality of eggs used to produce the influenza A(H1N1) vaccine, amid suspicion that contaminated eggs could have been responsible for the severe side effects suffered by some individuals who have received the vaccine.

Wei Yi-chih, the company's president, said that the eggs were supplied by two chicken farms that met special specifications. The farms were inspected twice by the Department of Health's (DOH's) Bureau of Food and Drug Analysis and passed inspection on both occasions, he said.
In addition, the eggs produced by the farms passed all nine required tests, including salmonella levels, avian flu infection, and antibiotic residues, according to Wei.

He said that before the immunization program was launched in the country, approximately 30 people had died from the new flu strain, but the fatalities have since dropped significantly thanks to the efficacy of the vaccine.

Pointing out that the company has so far produced more than 40 batches of vaccine, each using 130,000 eggs, Wei said the number of cases of side effects would have been higher if there had been problems with the eggs or the packaging of the vaccine.

DOH statistics show that since the start of the immunization program, a total of 424 of the 4.81 million people who have been vaccinated have developed serious side effects. They include a seven- year-old boy who died early this week, allegedly from the H1N1 vaccine.

With doubts about the safety of the vaccine mounting in the country, opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chen Ting-fei again asked the DOH Thursday to make public the origins of the eggs used to produce the vaccine and the results of the tests on the eggs.

However, Kang Chao-chou, head of the DOH's Bureau of Pharmaceutical Affairs, said that before doing so, the DOH will need to determine whether it is lawful for it to publicize such information, because the egg farms are under the supervision of the the Council of Agriculture, not the DOH.

Meanwhile, Huang Li-min, a professor of pediatrics at National Taiwan University (NTU) who led the vaccine's clinical trials on children, said the trials were conducted in accordance with international standards and that legislators are welcome to scrutinize the results.
He said NTU has confidence in the trial results and has contributed an article on the topic to a U.S. medical journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 18:08:46 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, falling NT$0.06 to close at NT$32.3.
A total of US$783 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.360 and dipped to a low of NT$32.238.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 18:31:31 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 62.04 points, or 0.78 percent, to close at the day's high of 7,963.54.
The local bourse opened at 7,935.34 and traded between 7,988.15 and 7,928.09 during the session.
A total of 4.8 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$142.45 billion (US$4.41 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues moving up the most at 3.8 percent. Textile stocks gained 1.6 percent, plastics and chemicals increased 1.1 percent, machinery and electronics issues advanced 0.9 percent, cement stocks advanced 0.5 percent, construction stocks and banking and financial stocks both gained 0.4 percent.
Foodstuff stocks lost 0.3 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,512 to 1,285, with 311 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$14.22 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's premier says protest organizers responsible for safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 18:40:27 (C. M. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Political parties or individuals who launch mass protests must be responsible for ensuring the safety of those who participate in the demonstrations, Premier Wu Den-yih was quoted as saying Thursday.

"Any political party or individual devoted to the cause must assume the responsibility of maintaining order on the streets and protect the safety of the public whom they have mobilized to gather at a rally," Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin quoted Wu as saying following a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Wu urged all parties concerned to be rational and not to ignite confrontation in public protests, arguing that both freedom of speech and personal safety of the public should be fully safeguarded at the same time.

The premier's comments followed bloody clashes that broke out when some pro- Taiwan independence backers and policemen dispatched to maintain order near the Windsor Hotel, where China's visiting envoy Chen Yunlin was staying.

Chen is in Taiwan for the fourth round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks, held in central Taiwan's Taichung City. Prior to his arrival on Monday, tens of thousands of protesters marched on Taichung's streets on Sunday to protest his visit and the government's plans to sign an economic agreement with China next year aimed at lifting trade barriers. Subsequent, but smaller protests, have been held, including outside his hotel.

One police officer, Chen Chu-hsiang, was pushed to the ground Wednesday while trying to stop a group of activists from setting off firecrackers outside the hotel. Chen sustained serious injuries to his forehead and was rushed to a hospital, while six members of the group that organized the protest -- 908 Taiwan Republic -- were detained.
Although Taiwan's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) organized the march on Sunday, it has sought to distance itself from protesters from other pro- independence groups.

DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan on Thursday expressed shock over the incident involving the injured police officer and stressed that the party is willing to take accountability for the matter even though the detained persons are not DPP members.
Su made the comments after visiting the hospitalized officer, whose condition has taken a turn for the better.

Su ascribed the injury to a "situation that got out of control" and contended that protesters found to have broken the law must be dealt with by law and that police also has to review its handling of the incident.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the party did not endorse the emotional actions of the 908 Taiwan Republic supporters, but asked police to make public its investigation report and video footage filmed on the site.
Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah, meanwhile, called for strong public backing for the police to keep order in mass protests.

In response to the argument by the six arrested men that officer Chen had fallen from the truck on his own, Jiang said police have collected extensive and solid evidence to prove the wrongdoing of these people.
Lee Chien-jung, director of the KMT's Culture and Communications Committee, demanded the DPP take full responsibility for the incident as it has promised, rather than simply paying lip service.
The DPP has failed to keep its pledge of a "peaceful demonstration," he said.
The DPP, however, has called for non-violent protests.
Chen is slated to return to China on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: All members of ex-first family indicted again
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 18:54:12 (By Lin Chung-sen, Ann Chi-shen, Lai Yu-chia and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former President Chen Shui-bian and his three immediate family members were indicted again Thursday, along with 19 other people, on charges of corruption and money laundering --crimes that prosecutors said were carried out by manipulating financial reforms introduced by the Chen administration.

In a third round of indictments, the Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office charged Chen, his wife Wu Shu-jen, their daughter Chen Hsing-yu and son Chen Chih-chung again with bribery, money laundering and forgery.

According to the indictment, the first couple took bribes amounting to NT$610 million (US$18.89 million) from the Cathay and Yuanta financial groups to facilitate the groups' acquisition of other Taiwanese banks to form new financial holdings companies.

Other relatives and friends of Chen on the latest indictment list were Chen Chih-chung's wife Huang Jui-ching; Wu Shu-jen's elder brother Wu Ching-mao; Wu Ching-mao's wife Chen Chun-ying; Chen Shui-bian's former adviser Wu Li-pei; Ma Yung-cheng, a top presidential aide during the Chen administration; and Yuanta Group founder Rudy Ma.
They were indicted on money laundering charges for helping Chen Shui-bian and his wife to "hide and move money" within Taiwan and to transfer NT$740 million to Swiss banks, prosecutors said.

Hou Hsi-feng, former chairman of Kuo Yang Construction, and Lu Yung-tai, chairman of Kao Hsing Chang Iron and Steel, were indicted on similar charges for helping the ex-first couple to purchase a luxury apartment in Taipei City, according to the prosecutors.

The indictment stated that Jeffrey Koo Jr., former vice chairman of Chinatrust Financial Holding Co., was charged with crimes related to manipulating the financial reforms that were conducted during the Chen administration.

In the first round of trials last year, the Taipei District Court sentenced Chen and his wife to life imprisonment, while 10 other people were given prison terms ranging from three months to 20 years.

In the second round of indictments in September this year, prosecutors charged former Vice Premier Chiou I-jen and former Foreign Minister Michael Ying-mao Kao for colluding with Chen to embezzle funds under the guise of "secret diplomacy spending."
Chen has been detained at the Taipei Detention Center since Dec. 30, 2008 on charges of embezzlement, bribery, money laundering and forgery.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mergers of Taiwan's local governments cannot be canceled: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 19:23:42 (By Ling Shen-hsu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government cannot withdraw its approval for the mergers of several local administrative districts into special municipalities, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Thursday, citing the Local Government Act,
In June, the ministry approved the upgrading of Taipei County and the mergers of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County, Tainan City and County, and Taichung City and County into special municipalities.

The redrawing of administrative districts was in line with the spirit of President Ma Ying-jeou's plan to remap the country, Jiang said earlier in the year after his ministry gave its approval for the merger and upgrade plans.

The merging of administrative zones was aimed at streamlining local administration and finance, facilitating a balance in urban and rural development, enhancing local administrative efficiency and promoting the country's overall development and international competitiveness.

However, controversy over whether the merger plans can be canceled grew recently after representatives from township and city administrative offices in areas of southern Taiwan approved for mergers complained that they were not informed that the elections for township and city representatives in the areas will be canceled once the merger plans were approved.

Jiang said Thursday at a legislative session that the plans for mergers of local administrative districts were approved by local city and county governments as well as city and county councils before they were filed with the ministry, so local governments that want to give up their mergers should bring forward their withdrawal proposals and get consent from city and county councils before submitting their proposal to the ministry.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-shen also asked Jiang to make public whether cities and counties that are to be merged into municipalities are offered the option to retract their merged plans.
Jiang said there is a slim possibility for the new special municipalities to retract their plans but should it happen, the ministry will work to address related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. firm wins contracts to produce Patriot system for Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/24/09 19:40:21 (By Zep Hu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: U.S. defense manufacturer Raytheon Company said Wednesday that it has been awarded contracts worth a total of US$1.1 billion to produce new Patriot Air and Missile Defense System for Taiwan.
The awards cover ground-system hardware through an initial contract valued at US$965.6 million and an initial spares contract valued at US$134.4 million, the company said in a statement.
It said the new Patriot fire units will feature improved man-machine interface and reduced life-cycle costs and will be produced in Massachusetts, Texas and Alabama.
The items are part of an arms sale package approved by the administration of former U.S. President George W. Bush in late 2008.

In addition to 330 advanced capability Patriot (PAC-3) missiles, the deal also includes 30 Apache attack helicopters, 32 Harpoon submarine-launched missiles, 182 guided Javelin missile rounds and four E-2T anti-submarine plane system upgrades.
There have also been reports in Taiwan that the administration of President Barack Obama might soon announce more arms sales to Taiwan.
Asked about the issue in a regular press briefing, Taiwan's deputy representative to the United States, Tung Kuo-yu, said he could not confirm the reports.
However, Tung said he understands that inter-agency discussions are still going on within the Obama administration on whether to sell more weapons to Taiwan.

Tan Chih-lung, director-general of the Defense Mission of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States, said Washington has always kept its arms sales to Taiwan highly confidential and usually does not disclose related information until a couple of days before they are formally announced, mainly to prevent possible protests or interference from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to donate executive jet to Panama
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/24/09 19:44:56 (By Hwang Kwang-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will donate an Embraer Legacy 600 jet to Panama as part of a cooperative program between the two countries, Republic of China Ambassador to Panama Simon Y.S. Ko said Wednesday.

The government's decision to donate the Brazilian-made executive jet to the Latin American country was based on consideration of the Panamanian government's need for planes that are safe and can be used for emergency patient transport services, according to Ko.

Most of the Panamanian government's existing fleet of planes are outdated and last May, a 40-year-old Panamanian National Air Service helicopter crashed into a building in Panama City, killing 11 people, including the head of Chile's national police Jose Alejandro Bernales, and injuring five others, Ko went on.

The Taiwanese government's decision to donate the executive plane instead of funds also took into account that in the past, former Panamanian government officials have been accused of misuse of funds donated by Taiwan.
The Embraer Legacy 600, which carries a price tag of US$27.45 million, is capable of carrying 16 passengers in outstanding comfort and has a range of 5,650 km.
The donation will be made at a public ceremony in early 2010, Ko added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator visits Typhoon Morakot-affected area
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 19:46:04 (By Lin Heng-li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan paid a visit Thursday to a mountain village in central Taiwan's Nantou County that was one of the hardest-hit by Typhoon Morakot-induced flooding and landslides in early August.

Chen Yunlin, president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , was briefed on the progress of post-disaster reconstruction after arriving in Sinshan village, where a major bridge collapsed as a result of strong winds and torrential rain brought by the typhoon.
According to Chen, the Chinese people were very concerned about the devastation caused by Morakot, which left more than 700 people dead or missing and thousands homeless.

"Many Chinese people, including some with meager incomes, have donated money to help with post-disaster rehabilitation projects, " Chen said, adding that their move epitomizes the idiom "blood is thicker than water."
After listening to briefings by Taiwanese officials, Chen said he was impressed by the government's efficiency and achievements in post-disaster relief operations.

As part of its cross-Taiwan Strait unification promotion strategy, China has made visits to Morakot-affected zones part of Chen's itinerary during his latest visit. As most of the areas are located in southern Taiwan -- a traditional stronghold of pro-independence forces -- Chen instead visited Nantou, where he conveyed China's goodwill and concern for the typhoon victims.
Following the Sinshan disaster-zone visit, Chen and his ARATS delegation traveled to Sun Moon Lake, one of Taiwan's most famous tourist attractions and a must-see for Chinese tourists.

As pro-independence activists had vowed to shadow Chen's sightseeing tour of central Taiwan, the area surrounding the Lalu hotel, where Chen was to stay overnight before wrapping up his visit Friday, was cordoned off by a heavy security deployment from early Thursday.

Before Chen's arrival, a clash almost broke out between pro-independence activists and a group of pro-unification advocates at a parking lot on way to the hotel, but police helped pacify the brawlers before the situation could escalate.
Chen was originally scheduled to have a boat tour around the lake, but canceled the cruise, instead meeting with opposition People First Party Chairman James Soong for wide-ranging talks instead.
Earlier in the day, he visited Chung Tai Chan Monastery, one of Taiwan's largest Buddhist temples in the county's Puli township, where he met with Dharma Master Wei Chueh.

Chen is in Taiwan for the fourth round of talks between China and Taiwan since relations improved after President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008 and began focusing on reducing cross-strait tension and strengthening economic ties.

A day before Chen's arrival Dec. 21, tens of thousands of protesters in central Taiwan's Taichung City demonstrated against his visit and the government's plan to sign an agreement with China next year aimed at removing trade barriers.

Chen is scheduled to leave Taiwan Friday after completing his main mission of signing three agreements Dec. 22 with his Taiwanese counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, on cooperation on fishing crew issues, agricultural quarantine and industrial products certification.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should not break U.S. beef deal: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 20:03:43 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan should not break its promise after signing an international agreement, as doing so will undermine its international credibility, the country's foreign minister said Thursday, in response to recent calls to renege on an agreement to lift a ban on U.S. beef imports.
"As a responsible member of the international community, ... Taiwan should not categorically take back its promise after signing a deal," Foreign Minister Timothy Chin-tien Yang said.
In addition, Yang pointed out at a news conference that Taiwan signed the protocol to lift the ban on U.S. beef "based on scientific figures that confirmed the safety of U.S. beef."
The press conference was one of three held by the administration in the past three days to defend its policy amid public criticism.

Taiwan inked a protocol with the United States to lift a ban on the import of U.S. beef and related products on Oct. 22, sparking a strong domestic debate over food safety, due to concerns over mad cow disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese envoy concludes Taiwan visit with a no-show
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, central Taiwan Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 20:37:49 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A last-minute no-show of a scheduled boat tour around one of Taiwan's most famous lakes and a visit to a Buddhist temple highlighted Chinese envoy Chen Yunlin's last full day of his five-day visit in Taiwan.

Chen Yunlin, President of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) which is in charge of dealing with matters related to Taiwan, did not show up on a scheduled boat tour around the Sun Moon Lake. Instead, Chen met with People First Party Chairman James Soong for about one and a half hours.
Located in the central county of Nantou, the Sun Moon Lake is one of Chinese tourists' favorite spots in Taiwan with its breath-taking scenery and rich indigenous tribal culture.

Chen's no show left around 100 domestic, Chinese and foreign journalists, who were already on boats to cover the event, in awe and confused. They did not have any choice but to follow the boat tour along with Chen's Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Chiang's wife and Chen's wife.

Chen and his three deputies met with Soong when a large contingent of journalists were stuck on the boat tour. The meeting was not on the itinerary arranged by the SEF. A SEF spokesman said they were not aware of the meeting until moments before the boat tour.
ARATS and the PFP did not disclose what was discussed in the meeting.

The lake tour was highly anticipated as rumors said some legislators from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and pro-independence supporters have rented boats and were ready to launch a protest on the waters. Falun Gong practitioners also said they would protest.

Hundreds of local police were deployed around the lake to maintain order. A number of divers from Nantou County Fire Department told the CNA that they had carried out underwater patrol in the morning due to security concerns.
At least eight police-rented boats escorted the two-hour boat tour, despite Chen's absence.

Bombarded by protests during the last three days in Taichung City, Thursday was the first day Chen was free of loud noises. Hundreds of Falun Gong members held banners near the hotel where Chen is staying that could be seen from the boats.
The rumored "DPP boat fleet" never showed up.
On Thursday morning, Chen visited Chung Tai Chan Monastery, one of the largest Buddhism temples in central Taiwan, and an area stricken by Typhoon Morakot in August.

Chen, after inking three deals Tuesday in the fourth round of cross-Strait negotiations with Taiwan, is scheduled to fly back to Beijing Friday morning. A tax deal didn't go through due to lack of consensus from both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reneging on beef opening would hurt U.S. support for Taiwan: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 20:55:40 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A top national security official on Thursday urged lawmakers and the public not to demand a reopening of talks with the United States on controversial beef imports, warning that reneging on an agreement to lift a ban on the imports would hurt relations.

National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi said Taiwanese people should take into account Taiwan's limited role in the international community when considering how to approach this issue.

Taiwan needs the support of the United States, its biggest ally, in its participation in international organizations and if Taiwan violates a recently- reached protocol on the import of U.S. beef, it is likely to see the U.S. and its lawmakers hold back their support for the island, said Su.

Su noted that the U.S. Congress attaches great importance to the issue as 70 percent of the U.S. congressional leaders are from agricultural states. The U.S. Congress is also a long-time major force backing Taiwan, Su added.

In addition, Su said: "There has been no progress in the economic relationship between Taiwan and the U.S. in the past 10 years despite improvements in the political relations" since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in May last year.

Going back on Taiwan's agreement to lift the ban on U.S. beef products previously restricted could continue to put on hold long-stalled talks between the two sides on the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) , double taxation, intellectual property rights and energy and environmental cooperation, Su warned.
Nonetheless, Su said that he will "respect the final decision by the legislature" and "the people's right to initiate a referendum on the issue."
He, nevertheless, urged the legislature not to amend any law to deal with the matter, saying that the current control measures are enough to safeguard the public's health.
If the referendum on renegotiating the issue passes, Su said he will "abide by" the decision.
Su made the remarks at his first press conference since he took the post in May last year.

Taiwan's government agreed to lift a ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products in late October, leading to widespread criticisms and concerns about public health due to fears of mad cow disease.

The government has organized a series of press conferences, -- by the Department of Heath, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, respectively -- since Dec. 22 to clarify its policy on U.S. beef.

Ruling and opposition lawmakers have both proposed their versions of the draft amendments to the Act Governing Food Sanitation in face of growing pressure from the public. They may reach a consensus on Dec. 29.

Su on Thursday also clarified that Taiwan and the U.S. could hold a meeting to review the beef import agreement "within, " not "in, "180 days after Taiwan's government decided to allow the U. S. beef products into the island, as stipulated in the pact. But Su did not elaborate on that.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Foreign Minister Timothy Chin-tien Yang said Thursday that Taiwan should not break its promise after signing an international agreement, as doing so will undermine its international credibility.
"As a responsible member of the international community, ... Taiwan should not categorically take back its promise after signing a deal," Yang told the same news conference.
The Consumers' Foundation and civic groups have launched bids to initiate a referendum to ask the government to renegotiate the U.S. beef protocol.
Critics of the protocol cited South Korea as an example and said that South Korea had renegotiated a similar deal with the U.S. after facing strong pressure from the public.
But Yang noted that at present, 50 countries allow U.S. beef imports, including Canada, European Union countries, South Korea and the Philippines, which impose no limits on such imports.
In contrast, Taiwan only gave a green light to beef from cattle under 30 months old and those with removed risk materials, which assures a higher level of safety, Yang stressed.

The U.S. is Taiwan's largest source of beef supply in terms of market value, according to Yang. U.S. boneless beef accounted for 38 percent, or US$128 million, of Taiwan's entire beef market valued at US$360 million in 2008.
Taiwan is the sixth largest export market for U.S. beef and beef products, behind Mexico, Canada, Japan, South Korea and Vietnam, according to Yang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan should view Taiwan from new perspective: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 21:15:43 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Japan should look at Taiwan from a new perspective and develop a new relationship, as both countries have changed, a top national security official said Thursday.

National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi said that Japan is now a "new Japan, " as the ruling party has changed and "Japanese society and the younger generation looks at international affairs and Japan's role in Asia differently."
Taiwan has changed, too, he went on, adding that "Taiwan has become democratic with an open environment for the media and many different voices, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has also changed."
Therefore, "new Taiwan and new Japan should engage in a new relationship, " he told Japanese reporters at a press conference held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
He also said that "if Japanese friends consider Taiwan to be the same as it was in the 1990s or earlier, they will be making a very big mistake."
The KMT, which formerly governed the country between 1945 and 2000, returned to power in May last year.
His remarks came in the wake of Masaki Saito's resignation early this month as Japan's representative to Taipei following controversial remarks he made on the "undetermined status" of Taiwan.
Saito was replaced by Tadashi Imai, a move Su said is very welcomed by the Taiwanese government.
He also dismissed reports that the council's senior advisor, Philip Yang, had been replaced by Lee Chia-chin, saying that Lee is in fact working with Yang on Japan affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Marinas to be built for tourism promotion: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 21:21:29 (By Yang Shu-min, Liu Chien-pang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the government will build four marinas as part of its efforts to promote tourism.

"Fishing ports can not only be a hub for commercial fishing but can also serve as bases for recreational yachting, " Ma said at an award presentation ceremony for a tourism promotion event in which Taiwan's top 10 most interesting fishing ports were honored.

Emphasizing Taiwan's rich marine resources, Ma said the government will lift obsolete restrictions on the country's coastal regions to allow tourism promotion under the premise of "no harm to the natural environment and ecology."

Over the past 60 years, particularly during the martial law era, Taiwan imposed strict restrictions on coastal development, which Ma said has made many local people view the sea with a mixture of awe and fear.
Times have changed, however, Ma went on, adding that besides being used for commercial fishing, fishing ports and their surroundings can be developed for recreational and sightseeing purposes.

"The newly selected top 10 most interesting fishing ports are expected to attract both local and foreign visitors," Ma said, adding that the government will build up-market docks at four of the ports -- Badoutzu, which will be given a flagship class dock, and Wushih, Anping and Wuci, which will be given model class docks -- for tourism.

"The marinas will be able to accommodate 190 recreational yachts, " Ma said. "By then, Taiwan will not just be Asia's No. 1 and the world's No. 5 yacht maker but it will also be a country open to yachting."

Despite the global economic downturn, Ma said Taiwan had posted a nearly 13 percent annual increase in the number of inbound visitors as of the end of November, with the total number exceeding 3.94 million for the 11-month period.

Among them, the number coming for sightseeing increased 28.46 percent, while the number of tourists from Europe posted the greatest gain of 18 percent year-on- year. The numbers of tourists from the United States and New Zealand also increased 5 percent and 5.4 percent, respectively.
"The total number of inbound visitors is expected to reach an all-time high of 4.2 million this year," Ma added.

The top 10 most interesting fishing ports selection was sponsored by the Council of Agriculture. In addition to an online vote, a panel of judges composed of scholars and experts were also invited to evaluate participating ports' facilities, resources, cultural heritage and market potential.
The fishery associations that run the winning fishing ports were each given a trophy and a cash prize of NT$200,000 (US$6,191.95).

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS head meets PFP chief
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 22:11:19 (By Feng Chao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin, met with People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong Thursday in central Taiwan's Nantou County after calling off a tour of scenic Sun Moon Lake.
Soong said after the one-hour meeting with Chen and three ARATS vice presidents that it did not take place behind closed doors and was not for personal gain.
He added that the meeting was scheduled during a visit he made to China in November and was originally planned to take place in Miaoli, in northern Taiwan.

Soong also expressed discontent over the refusal of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , the government authorized semi-official body in charge of handling contact with China, to arrange a banquet hosted by Taiwan's political parties in honor of Chen, saying that without his "ice-breaking" trips to China in 2005, Chen's current visit would have been impossible.

In response, SEF spokesman Maa Maa Shaw-chang pointed out that Chen's visit was mainly for the fourth round of talks with SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and that the SEF therefore did not arrange banquets or meetings with political party leaders.
The SEF respects the difference of opinion among various political parties but it is not in a position to provide a communication platform for political parties, Ma added.
Chen's itinerary, which included trips to several scenic spots around Taiwan, was devised to give him and his delegation a better understanding of Taiwan, according to Ma.

Meanwhile, a pro-independence group tried to enter the hotel where the Soong- Chen meeting was taking place to deliver a national flag of Taiwan to Chen, but were blocked by the heavy police presence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial promoting Taiwan tourism to be shown in New York
DOC.DATELINE: New York, Dec. 23 (CNA) 12/24/09 22:17:30 (By Hwang Jaw-pyng and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A commercial featuring Taiwan's beauty will be shown in Times Square, a New York City landmark, for one month starting Dec. 24 as part of efforts to promote tourism, Taiwanese officials posted in the United States said Wednesday.
The campaign, which will cover the prime period between Christmas and New Year, will mark the first time a Taiwanese commercial has been presented in the iconic square.

From 6 a.m. until 2 a.m. every day, the 2.5-minute commercial will be shown every hour on each of two wall screens located on either side of the Times Square Ball -- the focus of the New Year countdown that attracts more than 1.6 million revelers every year.
Kao Jen-chuan, director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, said the presentation will provide a rare opportunity for Taiwan's beautiful scenery to be brought to the world stage.

Chang Cheng-yuan, director of the Tourism Bureau's New York office, said with a total running time of 100 minutes per day during the coming month, the commercial is expected to greatly increase Taiwan's media exposure and help attract more international visitors to the country.
Due to the economic slump caused by the global financial crisis, visitor arrivals from the United States to Taiwan dropped by 5 percent year-on-year in the first 11 months of this year.
Chang said the Tourism Bureau will evaluate the performance of the commercial to decide whether to launch a similar campaign next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU accuses Spanish ranking institute of libel
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 22:23:12 (By Iu Jang-yig and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The National Taiwan University (NTU) lodged a protest Thursday with Webometrics Ranking against an allegation by the Spanish ranking institute that NTU has resorted to " bad practices" to win an inflated status in the world university rankings.

In its latest world university ranking published in July, Webometrics put NTU in 26th place, advancing from 55th place the previous year. NTU was the only Taiwanese university to make the top 100 in the rankings.
The institute, however, named NTU as of one of several universities that have resorted to "bad practices" in a bid to get better rankings.
According to the institute, NTU and several other universities "are hosting large numbers of academic papers authored by scientists that do not belong to those institutions."

"This is not only unfair, but it clearly violates the copyright of the papers involved. We urge these universities to take action to decrease the number of suspicious files," Webometrics said on its Web site.
However, NTU said in a statement that the allegation was not "clear" enough, could be classed as libel, and has undermined the reputation of the university, widely regarded as the best in Taiwan.
The statement said that NTU has always taken matters regarding its world ranking in stride, and has never tried to manipulate its ranking in any way.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing, rental prices in Taipei City forecast to rise
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 22:41:26 (By Y. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Compared to other major cities in Asia such as Tokyo, Shanghai or Hong Kong, house prices and rentals in Taipei City still have potential to continue surging, real-estate brokers said Thursday.
According to the newest list of Asia's most expensive places to live published by Forbes magazine, Taipei ranks 16th with an average monthly rent of US$1,065 for a high-end two-bedroom apartment.
Toyko topped the list at US$4,737, followed by Hong Kong at US$3,871 and Beijing in third place at US$3,659.
Urban enclaves where prices rose the most include the region's financial hubs such as Mumbai, Singapore and Taipei, according to a Mercer Consulting's annual cost-of-living survey.
Despite the global downturn, rents are relatively high and property prices are on the rise in these cities, according to Forbes.

"In the past, we've seen Europe as the most expensive. Over time, the Asian cities have caught up quite a bit in terms of cost-of-living increases, " said Cathy Loose, a principal consultant at Mercer. "Mainly because of the limited space, real estate in terms of demand versus supply is driving the rental price high."

Huang Cheng-fu, an assistant manager with Evertrust Rehouse -- one of the leading real estate brokers in Taiwan, said the US$1,065 monthly rental estimated by Mercer for a fine two-bed room apartment in Taipei's upscale Daan or Hsinyi district is a reasonably accurate figure.

Compared to the US$3,871 average monthly rent for a similar product in Hong Kong, rents and house prices in Taipei are expected to continue rising amid ever closer exchanges in the greater China area, Huang contended.

Su Chi-jung, a manager at Sinyi Realty Estate, said Taipei's 16th-spot ranking reflects the fact that there is ample room for it to become more international, on the grounds that the rate of a city's globalization is closely related to its rental levels.
Once there are more foreign business executives in a city, its rent levels usually go up because such foreign nationals want to rent high-quality houses, he said.
With cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges continuing to expand and more foreign and Chinese executives coming to Taiwan, Su predicted that Taipei will move further up the list in the future.
Locations in other parts of the country, however, will not see a similar rise in real estate property or rental prices, another analyst added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan should view Taiwan from new perspective: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 21:15:43 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Japan should look at Taiwan from a new perspective and develop a new relationship, as both countries have changed, a top national security official said Thursday.

National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Su Chi said that Japan is now a "new Japan, " as the ruling party has changed and "Japanese society and the younger generation looks at international affairs and Japan's role in Asia differently."
Taiwan has changed, too, he went on, adding that "Taiwan has become democratic with an open environment for the media and many different voices, while the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has also changed."
Therefore, "new Taiwan and new Japan should engage in a new relationship, " he told Japanese reporters at a press conference held at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
He also said that "if Japanese friends consider Taiwan to be the same as it was in the 1990s or earlier, they will be making a very big mistake."
The KMT, which formerly governed the country between 1945 and 2000, returned to power in May last year.
His remarks came in the wake of Masaki Saito's resignation early this month as Japan's representative to Taipei following controversial remarks he made on the "undetermined status" of Taiwan.
Saito was replaced by Tadashi Imai, a move Su said is very welcomed by the Taiwanese government.
He also dismissed reports that the council's senior advisor, Philip Yang, had been replaced by Lee Chia-chin, saying that Lee is in fact working with Yang on Japan affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Marinas to be built for tourism promotion: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/24/09 21:21:29 (By Yang Shu-min, Liu Chien-pang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the government will build four marinas as part of its efforts to promote tourism.

"Fishing ports can not only be a hub for commercial fishing but can also serve as bases for recreational yachting, " Ma said at an award presentation ceremony for a tourism promotion event in which Taiwan's top 10 most interesting fishing ports were honored.

Emphasizing Taiwan's rich marine resources, Ma said the government will lift obsolete restrictions on the country's coastal regions to allow tourism promotion under the premise of "no harm to the natural environment and ecology."

Over the past 60 years, particularly during the martial law era, Taiwan imposed strict restrictions on coastal development, which Ma said has made many local people view the sea with a mixture of awe and fear.
Times have changed, however, Ma went on, adding that besides being used for commercial fishing, fishing ports and their surroundings can be developed for recreational and sightseeing purposes.

"The newly selected top 10 most interesting fishing ports are expected to attract both local and foreign visitors," Ma said, adding that the government will build up-market docks at four of the ports -- Badoutzu, which will be given a flagship class dock, and Wushih, Anping and Wuci, which will be given model class docks -- for tourism.

"The marinas will be able to accommodate 190 recreational yachts, " Ma said. "By then, Taiwan will not just be Asia's No. 1 and the world's No. 5 yacht maker but it will also be a country open to yachting."

Despite the global economic downturn, Ma said Taiwan had posted a nearly 13 percent annual increase in the number of inbound visitors as of the end of November, with the total number exceeding 3.94 million for the 11-month period.

Among them, the number coming for sightseeing increased 28.46 percent, while the number of tourists from Europe posted the greatest gain of 18 percent year-on- year. The numbers of tourists from the United States and New Zealand also increased 5 percent and 5.4 percent, respectively.
"The total number of inbound visitors is expected to reach an all-time high of 4.2 million this year," Ma added.

The top 10 most interesting fishing ports selection was sponsored by the Council of Agriculture. In addition to an online vote, a panel of judges composed of scholars and experts were also invited to evaluate participating ports' facilities, resources, cultural heritage and market potential.
The fishery associations that run the winning fishing ports were each given a trophy and a cash prize of NT$200,000 (US$6,191.95).

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, Dec. 25, or the 10th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1915: Tang Chi-yao, Tsai O and others declare independence of Yunnan Province and the establishment of the National Protection Army against self-proclaimed Emperor Yuan Shi-kai.
1926: Japanese Emperor Taisho dies, ushering in a new era of Showa under Emperor Hirohito.
1936: National Government Military Commission Chairman Generalissimo Chiang Kai- shek is freed and flies safely from Xian to Luoyang.
1945: National Taiwan University unveils a list of 36 hopefuls who have passed the school's first ever entrance examination.
1946: The National Constituent Assembly passes the Constitution of the Republic of China.
1947: The Republic of China Constitution goes into effect.
1948: The Mandarin Daily News -- the only paper to use mandarin phonetic symbols along with Chinese characters -- is launched in Taipei City.
1962: The Republic of China government proclaims Dec. 25 as Constitution Day and designates it as a national holiday.
1969: The first Taipei City Council since the city's upgrading to a special municipality is inaugurated, with Lin Ting-sheng elected as speaker; Lo Chia- lun, a national policy adviser to the President, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1975: The first national literary award is introduced in Taiwan, but only Kuo Yi wins a prize, in the photography category; there are no winners in other categories.
1977: Charlie Chaplin, U.S. actor and director, dies in Switzerland at the age of 88.
1986: Sixty-two people killed when a hijacked Iraqi passenger plane explodes during a forced landing at a Saudi Arabia airport.
1989: Romania dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife are executed after being sentenced to death by a military court.
1997: The Taipei metro's Danshuei Line opens in full.
2003: A passenger plane bound for Beirut crashes into the sea shortly after taking off from Benin, West Africa, killing 111.
2005: Taiwan Television Enterprise Chairman Lai Kuo-chou, General Manager Cheng Yu-ho, Chinese Television System Chairman Chou Jung-sheng and General Manager Chiang Hsia, as well as the directors and supervisors that represent the government at the two TV stations, resign en masse in line with a government policy on the withdrawal of political, governmental and military influence from the media.
2007: According to the World Economic Forum's "2007-2008 Global Competitiveness Report,"Taiwan has again taken first place in the world in the "state of Cluster Development" index.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, in the matter of food, should never seek to indulge his appetite; in lodging, he should not be too solicitous of comfort. He should be diligent in virtue and learning in order to profit from their lessons and example. In this way, he may become a man of real culture."
