DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists promote `carbon reduction diplomacy'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 11:43:39 (By Liu Kwang-yin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: With climate change receiving increasing attention around the world, a group of Taiwanese environmentalists have called on the government to adopt a new diplomatic approach that focuses on helping its allies reduce carbon emissions instead of merely providing them with financial assistance.

According to Wang Chun-hsiu, president of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union, such an approach can better enhance the country's international profile, because climate issues are taking center stage following the conclusion of the 12-day United Nations Climate Change Conference in the Danish capital of Copenhagen a week earlier.
Wang and several other members of the union also took part in the meeting as representatives of a non-government organization (NGO).

Hsu Kuang-jung, a former president of the union, suggested that in participating in similar events in the future, the government should develop closer connections with domestic NGOs in order to gain contact with more international groups.

Pointing to the example of Japan, Hsu said that every day during the U.N. conference, representatives of the Japanese government met with NGO representatives at the end of the day to discuss details of the day's meeting and what responses Japan should adopt.
This demonstrates that the Japanese government attaches high importance to its relations with NGOs, Hsu said.

Also, she said that Taiwan, which is promoting a bid to participate in the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) , should take the initiative to comply with the Copenhagen Accord that was sealed upon the conclusion of the conference.
The agreement recognizes the scientific view that an increase in global temperature of less than 2 degrees Celsius is required to stave off the worst effects of climate change.
According to the document, industrialized countries will commit to implement quantified economy-wide emissions targets from 2020, to be listed in the accord before Jan. 31 next year.
A number of developing countries agreed to communicate their efforts to limit greenhouse gas emissions every two years, also listing their voluntary pledges before that date.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- surrogate birth

TEXT.P: Thursday's busting of an online surrogate birth brokering ring has again drawn concern about the country's procrastination on surrogate motherhood legislation. While medical experts affirm the existence of such a need, they caution local couples about the perils of such service.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
Liberty Times:
An online surrogate birth service ring was cracked by Taiwan police Thursday, unearthing an illegal social phenomenon that has taken place in Taiwan for years as a result of demand.

The ringleader, surnamed Lo, headquartered his online surrogate birth brokerage in the United States and the potential "clients" shopped from a diverse catalog of surrogate mothers provided by his Web site.
Lo's ring collected an average of NT$1.6 million (US$49,536) for each successful surrogate birth service, and so far nearly 20 of such babies have been born in Taiwan.

Surrogate birth broker Lo Hsien-lung was nabbed in Changhua City along with five of his ring members for brokering "young," "sweet," and "healthy" women from Vietnam, Thailand and Cambodia as surrogate mothers for Taiwanese couples who could not have their own children.
Lo charged the childless couples based on their selections, with younger, more attractive, better-educated surrogates commanding the highest prices.
When the babies were born, the couples would travel to the country of origin to take delivery, using the adoption procedure.
China Times:
Lo and his accomplices were arrested on charges of violating the statute governing artificial reproduction. The six could also face charges of human trafficking and forgery.
It was found that Lo's ring had earned around NT$20 million from some 20 Taiwanese couples who obtained their babies from abroad using the ring's services.

According to unofficial statistics, about 400,000 married couples in Taiwan have trouble having their own babies. If calculated by Lo's charges, the underground surrogate birth service is a market worth NT$500 billion.
Lo would have found his "cash cow" if he had managed to grasp just 0.1 percent of that huge market. (Dec. 25, 2009)
United Daily News:
A local obstetrician said that since surrogate motherhood is illegal in Taiwan, married couples unable to have their own babies will tread the thin line of the law in order to obtain one.

Lee Mao-sheng, a board member of the Taiwanese Society for Reproductive Medicine, said child-seeking Taiwanese couples are not only risking violating the law but could also suffer even greater regret should their child obtained through surrogacy be unhealthy or have any genetic problems.
On Thursday, the Changhua police also rounded up six married couples raising children they obtained from surrogate mothers overseas.
One father aged between 40 and 50 said he and his wife had tried to seek a local surrogate mother, but the matter proved to be unworkable since surrogate motherhood is illegal in Taiwan.
He argued that he did not violate any law in Taiwan by adopting a child from abroad.

A woman surnamed Liu, who has been a surrogate mother several times in Taiwan secretly, said she would choose not to do it if given the choice, given the mental and physical trauma that she has suffered as a result.
"Adopting a child from an orphanage would satisfy their desire to be parents if the couple have love," she said. (Dec. 25, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day - News digest of local media -- Polls on talks

TEXT.P: With the latest round of high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks drawing to an end, two local newspapers on Friday published the results of opinion surveys on public reaction to the high-profile event.

The following is a digest of media reports on the findings of the latest surveys on the fourth round of talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his Chinese counterpart Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), in central Taiwan's Taichung City.
United Daily News (UDN):

The results of a UDN poll found that in the aftermath of the fourth round of cross-strait talks since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May 2008, 31 percent of the respondents expressed satisfaction with the Ma administration's performance during the talks, which led the two sides to sign three agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural and food quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification, while 32 percent expressed dissatisfaction.
Fifty-six percent of those polled said they were not satisfied with protests organized by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against Chen's visit.

Meanwhile, the public satisfaction rate for DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen dropped to 38 percent from 43 percent after the Dec. 5 local mayor and magistrate elections, while the public satisfaction rate for Ma remained at the low level of 33 percent.

In terms of the three cross-strait cooperation agreements, 32 percent of the respondents said they recognize that Taiwan will benefit from the accords, while 23 percent said the disadvantages will outweigh the advantages.
Another 7 percent held mixed opinions on the three agreements while 38 percent had no comment.
The survey was conducted nationwide via telephone interview Dec. 24 among randomly selected adults. A total of 771 valid samples were collected, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3.5 percent.
Liberty Times:

On Thursday, the DPP unveiled the results of a poll conducted by the party earlier in the week showing that most respondents still feel the government lacks transparency in dealing with the Chiang-Chen talks.
According to the poll, 60.1 percent of the respondents said they did not think the process of the latest talks was public and transparent on the scale instructed by Ma.
Only 21 percent of the respondents had the opposite opinion.

The results also show that 71.6 percent of those surveyed said they do not agree with the idea of trading part of Taiwan's sovereignty in exchange for the formation of an economic cooperation framework agreement with China, while 16.2 percent were in favor.

Asked about the recent cross-strait agreement on industrial product standards, inspection and certification, 52.5 percent of the respondents said it is of greater disadvantage than advantage toward Taiwan, while 33.9 percent said they hold the opposite opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- More charges

TEXT.P: Detained former President Chen Shui-bian faces more criminal charges as prosecutors indicted him Thursday for abusing his power by overriding free market competition in the conduct of badly needed financial reform and taking bribes from financial groups in exchange for aiding their acquisition and merger deals.
Chen's wife Wu Shu-jen, their daughter, son and daughter-in-law, as well as 17 business executives, were also indicted for their roles in those cases.
The following is a digest of media reports on the latest spate of indictments involving the former first family:
China Times:
Prosecutors said the former president took advantage of his position to interfere in matters that should be the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance.

Chen hampered free competition in the market, seriously undermined financial supervision and damaged his credibility as president. He later tried to conceal his stolen fortune through money laundering, for which the prosecutors said he should be severely punished. (Dec. 25, 2009)
United Daily News:

Chen established close ties with local conglomerates during his tenure as president. Prosecutors found that Chen received NT$100 million from Cathay Financial Holdings when he was first elected in 2000 and then asked Cathay to sponsor him to the tune of NT$100 million each year from 2001 to 2004.
Because of these close ties, Chen instructed the then-finance minister to support Cathay's merger of another major bank.
The 17 executives from three major financial holdings who were also indicted include Ruday Ma, founder of the Yuanta Financial Holdings, his wife and two sons. (Dec. 25, 2009)
Liberty Times:

Chen Shui-bian's office said Chen was not directly embroiled in any of the specific cases mentioned by the prosecutors, and that "it is out of the question that he accepted bribes or was involved in corruption."
The prosecution should not rule that Chen accepted bribes just because of his wife's acceptance of political donations.
Lawyer Chuang Po-lin said the indictment of the former first family again during top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin's visit to Taiwan is a manifestation of President Ma Ying-jeou's will.

Chuang said it was a political gesture to Chinese President Hu Jintao and to Chen Yunlin and was designed to show that Chen Shui-bian is being punished for his pro-independence stance. (Dec. 25, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Incredible ruling on business executives

TEXT.P: None of the bosses of five major local financial groups have been indicted for paying bribes to former President Chen Shui-bian in exchange for his aid in their merger and acquisition bids during a financial service market restructuring campaign that took place under his oversight.
Will their immunity to criminal charges encourage the man in the street to bribe officials for private gain?
In many advanced Western countries, individuals can face bribery charges by offering even US$1 in bribes to a police officer if they are stopped for violating traffic rules.

How come local business chiefs can be immune to indictment after giving bribes worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the former first couple? The judicial authorities owe the public an explanation.
Taiwan has a reputation as a haven for official corruption, as giving bribes is not liable to incrimination so long as the bribe-taking officials do not violate their official duties.

On Sept. 24, the Executive Yuan came up with a draft amendment to that provision with the aim of holding bribe-givers accountable, regardless of whether the bribe-taking officials have violated their legal duties.
However, the bill's fate remains uncertain, as the Legislative Yuan has yet to screen it.

The immunity of corporate tycoons to criminal charges after giving huge cash bribes to the former first couple in exchange for business favors is the shame of the local judicial community because few can believe the former president did not lapse in his official duties after taking the bribes.

DOC.HEADLINE: France, Taiwan to inspect each other's fishing ships on open sea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 14:38:12 (By Tang Pei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: France has notified the Western and Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC) that it will start a mutual fishing vessel inspection agreement with Taiwan, the Fisheries Administration said Friday.

From Feb. 2, France and Taiwan will start mutual on-board inspections on the open sea covered by the international organization set up to conserve and manage stocks of highly migratory fish in the Western and Central Pacific Ocean.
France will join New Zealand, the Cook Islands, the United States and Japan in conducting the mutual on-board inspections with Taiwan, the officials said.

They went on that in line with inspection regulations under the WCPFC, Taiwan's tuna boats, whether purse seiners, longliners of over 100 tons or small longliners of under 100 tons, will have to follow the inspection regulations.

When fishing vessels from the other countries board Taiwanese fishing vessels, the skipper will have to have his licence, fishing haul reports and operation log ready and should also report the inspection to the Coast Guard Administration and fishery radio so that the Fisheries Administration can be notified.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government makes last-ditch effort on beef issue: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 14:44:04 (By Garfie Lee, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The government is trying its utmost to coordinate with the legislature over a possible legal amendment aimed at obstructing U.S. beef imports considered to be risky, Presidential Office spokesman Wang Yu-chi said Friday.

Wang said the existing strict measures, known as the "three controls" and "five certifications, " have been effective in keeping potentially hazardous beef parts from the United States out of the country.

However, the government would be willing to bear some of the consequences should the Legislative Yuan remain determined to pass an amendment to the Act Governing Food Sanitation to demand a re-opening of talks with the United States on controversial beef imports, Wang said.
"President Ma Ying-jeou will meet Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng later in the day for a discussion of the issue," he said.
The so-called three controls refer to setting controls on beef imports at the source, at borders and in markets.

The five certifications refer to verifying certification documents, checking that shipments are marked with detailed product information, opening a high percentage of cartons of imported beef to check the product, conducting food safety tests, and being able to get information on suspected problem products immediately, according to DOH officials.

Ma's decision to meet with the legislative speaker came after National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi urged lawmakers and the public a day earlier not to demand a re-opening of the beef talks with the United States, warning that reneging on an agreement to lift a ban on the imports would hurt relations.

The government agreed to lift a ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef, offal and ground beef Nov. 2, based on a protocol that it signed with the U.S. in October, leading to widespread criticism and concern about public health safety due to fears of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease.
Su said the public should take into account Taiwan's limited role in the international community when considering how to approach the issue.

Taiwan needs the support of the United States, its biggest ally, in its bids to participate in international organizations. If it violates the import protocol, it is likely that the U.S. will hold back its support for the country, Su said.
Foreign Minister Timothy Chin-tien Yang said that same day that Taiwan should not break its promise after signing an international agreement, as doing so will undermine its international credibility.
"As a responsible member of the international community... Taiwan should categorically not renege on its promise after signing a deal," Yang said.

Also Friday, ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus whip Lu Hsueh-chang said that over half of the KMT lawmakers would support an amendment version authored by KMT Legislator Daniel Y.J. Huang, which stipulates that ground beef, beef offal and four other categories of beef products should be barred from import if the supplying country "has been a mad cow disease affected area."

Ruling and opposition lawmakers have proposed their own versions of the draft amendments to the Act Governing Food Sanitation in the face of growing pressure from the public and could reach a consensus Dec. 29.
"Taiwan might face U.S. retaliation whatever version of the amendment the legislature decides to propose," Su warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ireland reaches out to Taiwanese tourists through Web page
DOC.DATELINE: London, Dec. 24 (CNA) 12/25/09 15:31:57 (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Tourism Ireland, the Irish government's main tourism promoter, opened a Taiwan page on its Web site recently to cater to Taiwanese tourists and offer them information on traveling and studying there.

The new Web page, found on Tourism Ireland's official Web site at www.discoverireland.com, offers personalized itinerary planning and a rundown of Ireland's main travel destinations and study programs.

The new page, presented in traditional Chinese characters, reflects the importance Tourism Ireland attaches to Taiwan's tourism and overseas study market, said Taiwan's Representative to Ireland Lee Nan-yang, who touted the Web page's varied and detailed contents.

Ireland's push to cater to Taiwanese tourists follows its decision earlier in the year to give Republic of China (Taiwan) passport holders visa-free treatment for visits related to tourism, business and studying.
The visa-free treatment took effect July 1 and allows Taiwan citizens to stay in Ireland for up to 90 days without a visa.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tainan railway station to draw on solar power
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 16:16:11 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A new railway station near completion in the Southern Taiwan Science Park (STSP) is the first to be designed based on the concept of generating solar energy and will produce enough solar power to offset the electricity it uses for lighting, the Tainan County government said Friday.

When the railway station becomes operational in April next year, it will be able to generate up to 16.1 kilowatts of electricity each day and save an equivalent of 84 tons of carbon dioxide emissions a year, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan- jhih said.
The station will generate solar power through solar panels and thin-film solar cells that have already been installed on the station's roof and on top of the covered waiting platform.
The electricity generated will be sent to Taiwan Power Company's grid rather than used directly to power the train station.

The solar power-generating railway station, expected to be completed next month and to obtain its operating license in April, will be a big help to commuters in getting to and leaving the southern science park, Su said.
Meanwhile, he added, the STSP administration will make shuttle buses available to futher faciliate transport between Tainan City and the park.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese negotiator leaves Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 16:32:19 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Lin Heng-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: China's chief negotiator with Taiwan left Taiwan Friday after wrapping up a five-day visit during which three cross-Taiwan Strait cooperation agreements on technical issues were signed but differences between the two sides also emerged.

Shortly before his departure, Chen Yunlin, president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , met briefly with the press at The Lalu hotel in Nantou County where he had stayed overnight to express his gratitude for the "understanding and concern" shown by Taiwan's people toward his delegation.

He said he was also very thankful for the efforts made by police in maintaining order during his stay in Taiwan, which allowed his talks with his Taipei counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, to proceed smoothly.

Chen also expressed concern over the condition of Chen Chu-hsiang, a Taichung police officer who was injured Wednesday when trying to stop protesters from launching firecrackers in the direction of the Windsor Hotel where the ARATS delegation was staying.
Lastly, the negotiator voiced his appreciation for the active involvement of the media to make information about the Chiang-Chen talks known to the public.
He also invited Taiwan journalists to visit China more often to help promote cross-strait journalistic exchanges.

For his part, Chiang said that although he felt some regret that the signing of an agreement aimed at avoiding double taxation was postponed because of technical problems, his latest talks with Chen nevertheless marked the completion of yet another "historic mission" by the two sides.
The semi-annual meeting, which took place Tuesday in Taichung, was the fourth of its kind between Chiang and Chen since June 2008.

Besides signing agreements on fishing crew cooperation, agricultural quarantine inspection, and industrial product standards, inspection and certification, the two top negotiators also agreed to put intellectual property rights protection and the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) on the agenda of their next meeting.
After the talks, Chen was shown around central Taiwan, including a tour to the popular tourist attraction of Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County.

Chen's visit, however, drew a series of protests by pro-independence organizations, led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, and other civic groups that oppose China's violations of human rights, including the Falun Gong spiritual group that is outlawed in China.

Chants of "stop the persecution of Falun Gong" and "Taiwan, China, one country on each side" were still heard when Chen left The Lalu in a limousine to head to Taichung Airport to catch a flight back to Beijing.
On the journey to the airport, however, hundreds of pro-unification activists lined up along the road to bid farewell to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 17:07:00 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar dropped against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, falling NT$0.055 to close at NT$32.245.
A total of US$230 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at the day's high of NT$32.3 and dipped to a low of NT$32.227 during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices continue to flirt with 8,000 barrier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 17:08:00 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly higher Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 9.05 points, or 0.11 percent, to close at 7,972.59.
The local bourse opened at 8,007.50 and traded within a narrow range between 8,009 and 7,965.37 throughout the session.
A total of 4.43 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$115.6 billion (US$3.58 billion).
Two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with machinery and electronics stocks advancing 0.3 percent and banking and financial rising 0.1 percent.

Five others lost ground with construction issues falling the most at 1.1 percent. Paper and pulp stocks lost 0.9 percent, textile issues fell 0.7 percent, foodstuff shares were down 0.3 percent, and plastics and chemicals shares shed 0.2 percent.
Cement stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,398 to 1,293 with 336 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$3.89 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: DPP should lead change

TEXT.P: Four days after a peaceful massive protest against the top Beijing negotiator's visit to Taiwan, a bloody incident took place, in which pro-independence activists pushed a police officer off a vehicle as he tried to stop them from launching fireworks in the direction of the hotel where Chinese envoy Chen Yunlin was staying.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was quick to clarify that none of the protesters aboard the vehicle were its members while expressing willingness to shoulder responsibility for the incident.

The DPP also did not forget to remind the public that the clash was an isolated case and the themes and appeals championed by the activists should not be overlooked simply because of the unexpected incident.
We think it's time for the DPP to face up squarely to the fact that it cannot delink itself with radical pro-independence advocates, or so-called deep-green voters.

The DPP has grown from a rabble-rousing political force into a mature party with eight years of governing experience, and it should lead deep-green or pro- independence extremists to transform and grow. Otherwise, its chances of staging a comeback will be slim.
We also would like to ask deep-green groups if it is necessary for them to repeatedly try to draw attention by instigating conflict.

The protester who allegedly pushed the injured police officer off the vehicle said after being released on bail that he will suffer the consequences if found guilty, but he stressed he did nothing wrong.

Taiwan is a country where freedom of speech is well protected. Pro-independence activists are free to express their views and goals, but they are not allowed to advocate their cause at the expense of others.

If deep-green advocates cannot learn to express their political views in a rational, peaceful manner and learn to respect those who hold different political beliefs and visions, their image will never improve.

DOC.HEADLINE: Costco to set up logistics and distribution center in Taoyuan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 17:20:59 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Costco Wholesale Corp. will set up a Taiwan logistics and distribution center in Taoyuan County at the end of next year, a move expected to significantly cut its cost of distribution, which is currently being outsourced, a county official said Friday.

After factoring in the bright prospects for the Taoyuan Aerotropolis development project and the northern county's favorable geographic location, Costco decided to set up the center there to facilitate the distribution of products to its various branches around Taiwan, according to the official from the county's Economic Development Department.

Costco, the largest membership warehouse club chain in the United States, expects to invest NT$800 million (US$24.81 million) in the center and two new big box outlets in northern and southern Taoyuan.

This was the first large-scale investment project in the county to be announced since Magistrate John Chih-yang Wu assumed his post earlier this month, and the economic development official said it should help stimulate the development of related industries.

Ahmen Lee, Costco Taiwan's regional marketing manager, confirmed the project earlier Friday and said Costco decided to locate the center in Taoyuan because it is a very important market in Taiwan and home of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
The planned logistics center, to cover an estimated 49,600 square meters, will be located in Dayuan Township.

The two Costco branches to be set up in the county at yet-to-be finalized locations will allow local Costco members to shop only a short distance from their homes, rather than needing to travel to Costco outlets in Taipei or Hsinchu as they do now, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: More Taiwanese petitioning for constitutional interpretations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 18:06:23 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More Taiwanese citizens have petitioned for constitutional interpretations over the past 10 years, indicating that Taiwanese people have grown increasingly aware of their constitutional rights, Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw said Friday.

In a report on constitutional rights delivered at the Presidential Office on Taiwan's Constitutional Day, Lai said the number of petitions filed seeking constitutional interpretations from the grand justices stood at 171, from 1999 to 2009.
Of those petitions, 76 percent or 130 petitions were filed by Taiwanese people.
That marks a big increase from the 1967-1976 period when a total of 24 petitions were filed, all of which were filed by governmental organizations, according to Lai.

With their civic and constitutional rights awareness gradually rising after Martial Law was lifted in Taiwan in 1987, Lai said, the people of Taiwan had filed more petitions for constitutional explanations by the grand justices.
Many of those petitions were filed over controversies concerning the rights, duties or jurisdiction of differing public offices, Lai said.
"Seeking constitutional interpretations is most effective way of settling disputes, " he told his audience, who included President Ma Ying-jeou.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Timing and Measures

TEXT.P: As expected, Taiwan's central bank did not announce hikes in its key interest rates after a board meeting Thursday, but it pledged to take action against abnormal housing price increases.

Over the past year, major governments around the world and their central banks have taken measures to bolster their economies to combat a global financial meltdown. Those stimulus measures included loosening monetary policy, expanding government spending and injecting capital into the banking system.

The measures, however, should ultimately come to an end because maintaining a loose monetary policy could lead to inflation and a property bubble and excessive fiscal expansion will make it hard for countries around the world to finance health care for retired baby boomers.

Australia has raised its interest rates three times since October, and the U.S. Federal Reserve also announced last week it will end most of its emergency support measures by Feb. 1, 2010, because the economic recovery has gathered momentum.
Those moves indicate that the time may have come for countries around the world, including Taiwan, to review various recession-fighting measures adopted over the past year.
We suggest that our central bank refer to trends in private sector borrowing in choosing an opportune time to adjust its monetary policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance expert calls for regulatory harmonization in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 18:18:34 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A local finance expert called on the government Friday to work to harmonize the country's financial regulations to prevent arbitrage between markets.
Arbitrage occurs when investors make a simultaneous purchase or sale in two separate financial markets in order to profit from a price difference between them.

According to Lee Tung-hao, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Money and Banking, the recent sale of Nan Shan Life Insurance and the financial woes of Kuo Hua Life Insurance are two examples which show that Taiwan needs to improve its regulations of the insurance sector, although the country is very experienced in regulating banks and financial holdings companies.

Filling the regulatory gaps existing between the insurance and banking sectors is essential to ensuring fair competition and preventing speculators from taking advantage of the differences in pursuit of risk-free profits, he said.
Lee was speaking in a seminar on the status and outlook of the financial industry in the post-financial crisis period. The seminar was held by the Taiwan Financial Services Roundtable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Closer ties with China have not helped people's lives: ex-SEF head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 18:31:27 (By Justin Su and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Closer economic and trade ties with China have not helped improve Taiwan's economy or people's lives but instead resulted in an unequitable distribution of the economic benefits, a former chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Friday.

Hung Chi-chang, who chaired the SEF while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was in power, said the lack of apparent benefits from closer ties has led many people to feel that cross-strait development has progressed too quickly, and he urged the ruling Kuomintang to address the public's misgivings.
Hung said many people thought ties with China proceeded too slowly before President Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration in May 2008 and too fast afterwards.

"The reason for such a perception is because the public does not think that society has felt economic growth or a substantive improvement in their lives through closer cross-strait ties, " Hung observed at a seminar on national competitiveness at the Legislative Yuan.
People also feel relations between Taiwan and China have grown too close because their expectations have not been met, he said.
He also said that Taiwan's international trade is already greater than the country's gross domestic product, and that Taiwan's OEM-oriented industries should transform or upgrade their structures.
Hung also said Taiwan's financial structure is not sound, with its tax revenues accounting for only 13 percent of GDP, compared with 18 percent in the past.
In contrast, the figure is about 35 percent in Scandinavian countries, which often place high in international competitiveness rankings.
Taiwan's outstanding government debt ratio also is approaching its legal ceiling, which he said will be a potential threat to Taiwan's national competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei, Kaohsiung mayors reveal their goals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 18:54:01 (By Jian Chen, Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei's city government will send a publicity team to boroughs and communities to explain to the citizens what the central government's proposed economic agreement with China is all about, Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday.

In celebration of his third anniversary as mayor, Hau highlighted the importance of the trade pact to Taiwan's capital, describing the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) as the key to Taipei City's future development.

Hau explained that 81 percent of the city's employed population works in the services sector. Of the service workers, 62 percent work in retail and wholesale businesses, as well as the banking and insurance sector.
Hau said he expects his city will be the top choice of Chinese enterprises that decide to set up operations or offices in Taiwan.
Taipei City is the best place for the establishment of a business talents breeding center, the mayor touted.

From this viewpoint, Hau said he believes Taiwan's signing of the trade pact with China will benefit Taipei City, noting that his administration in the coming year will focus on ECFA-related matters, including working to upgrade the Neihu high-tech industrial services center into an Asia-Pacific economic and trade services center.

Other major policies include assisting the traditional industries in the city to transform and upgrade themselves, and outlining a management mechanism to ensure the safety of Chinese imports, Hau added.

With the city's survey showing most citizens do not know what the content of the cross-strait trade pact is, despite expressing opposition to its signing, the mayor said he will strengthen efforts to address the concerns that the industrial sectors and individual citizens have over the proposed agreement, including organizing a round-the-city publicity tour.

Meanwhile, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu recognized her administration's achievements in promoting the southern Taiwanese city's development in the past three years, grading the team with a score of 85 points in a 1-100-point scoring system.
Like Hau, Chen also celebrated her third year in office on Friday.

In her address to the celebration ceremony, Chen said that if she wins a second term as mayor next year, she will ensure balanced distribution of resources between Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County after the two merge next December.
Taipei City and Kaohsiung City are Taiwan's largest and second largest city, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: Low interest rate spread threatens banking industry: banking expert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 19:21:55 (By Yun-hsuan Cheng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's interest rate spread, the world's lowest at around 1 percent, is jeopardizing the profitability and operations of the banking industry, and any sudden increase in bad loans could result in bank collapses, a banking industry expert said at a seminar on the industry's outlook Friday.

SinoPac Holdings Independent Director Sophia Cheng, a former managing director and head of research of Merrill Lynch Taiwan, said the low interest rate spread has not only undermined domestic banks' tolerance of risk but also affected their return on equity (ROE) and share price performance.
If there is another recession, even a mild one, the possible rise in non- performing loans could bring down some domestic banks, she warned.

Taiwan's interest rate spread of roughly 1 percent can only cover a bank's expenses but is not enough to account for the average cost of non-performing loans over the long term, explained Cheng, who is known as the "queen analyst of the financial sector" by foreign securities houses.

The interest rate spread is the difference between the average yield banks make on loans and investments and the average rate institutions have to pay on deposits and borrowing. It accounts for the major share of banks' income.
According to statistics from Taiwan's central bank, the interest rate spread among local banks was 1.18 percent in 2009 Q3, compared with 2 percent in the same period in 2006.

Although the global financial crisis did not create large-scale systematic risks in Taiwan, it delivered a warning on banking industry operations, Cheng argued. If no quick action is taken to improve the situation, the local banking industry will be less able to deal with any economic crisis in the future.

She also noted that low interest rates have put huge pressure on insurance companies' investment spread -- the gap between their portfolio yield on invested assets and the interest rate credited on insurance liabilities.

Given that many countries ran up heavy debt to rescue financial markets during the crisis, there is also only limited room for governments to issue more debt in the future. So figuring out how to prevent future crises is particularly important, she added.
Despite fears over the country's low interest rate spreads, Taiwan's central bank on Thursday left its key interest rates unchanged as expected, noting that inflation is not a concern at the moment.
The central bank has left its key rates unchanged since Feb. 19, after having cut them by 237.5 basis points from September 2008 to try and stave off the country's worst-ever recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment in Taiwan's EPZs in 2009 beats target: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 19:34:15 (By Emmanuelle Tzeng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: New investment in Taiwan's export processing zones in 2009 has surpassed the annual target set despite the global economic downturn, the Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration said Friday.

Administrator Jerry J. R. Ou said in his year-end report that investment in Taiwan's EPZs had reached NT$40.885 billion (US$1.265 billion) for the year as of Dec. 21, surpassing the original target of NT$38 billion set by the EPZ authority at the beginning of the year.
Aside from the positive investment figures, Taiwan's EPZs are also taking steps to improve their commercial environments, Ou said.

The Kaohsiung EPZ, for example, hopes to transform itself into an LCD cluster and is encouraging manufacturers in the zone to sign an agreement on technology exchange and cooperation with the nonprofit Metal Industries Research & Development Centre to upgrade their technology.
Meanwhile, to solve water supply problems and counter possible water shortages in southern Taiwan, the Nantze EPZ has planned Taiwan's first experimental industrial waste water recycling plant.
"It's estimated that the plant will produce 1,800 tons of recycled water daily by 2013," Ou said.
The EPZs have also seen continuing signs of economic recovery. Ou said the number of workers on unpaid leave in the EPZs dropped to 451 as of Dec. 21 from the peak of 26,624 in February.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Water crisis

TEXT.P: Responding to a series of reports on the rundown state of major reservoirs in central and southern Taiwan, the government called a "small-scale national security meeting" last Saturday to plot action plans.
The brainstorming session came to two conclusions: dredging silt and mud from the reservoirs and advising individuals and corporations to save water.

If the government believes such measures alone are sufficient to resolve Taiwan's water issue, it has overlooked the gravity of the country's water woes. In the long run, tens of billions of dollars spent on those measures will turn out to be a waste of public funds.

For years, the government has paid little attention to water conservation and supply issues. Every time the country faces the threat of drought, the government tends to map out temporary relief measures but has never tried to plot forward-looking and long-term strategies that can resolve the increasingly serious warter shortage problems once and for all.
At best, the measures initiated at the recent "national security meeting" are only aimed at combatting the threat of an imminent water shortage this spring.
We are worried, however, that the government's passive and shortsighted working style will miss any possible opportunity to truly resolve the issue and may even worsen the situation.
To address water supply problems, the government should preserve water resources while reducing consumption and encouraging recycling.

The government should study how to raise the utilization rate of each water source, including preserving rainwater, and review current water distribution ratios among agricultural, household and industrial users and related management systems. Equally important is water recycling to increase supplies.
As most of Taiwan's reservoirs are located in mountain regions at medium elevation, management of their catchment areas is extremely important to sustain their life spans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's military to help dredge Tsengwen Reservoir: water agency
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 20:06:39 (By P. C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's military will help dredge the sand, mud and driftwood which Typhoon Morakot brought down to southern Taiwan's Tsengwen Reservoir, Water Resources Agency (WRA) Director-General Yang Wei-fu said Friday.

According to Yang, some 1.2 billion cubic meters of sand and mud brought about by the storm, which hit Taiwan in August, has built up in the upstream mountainous area. Over 400 million cubic meters of the substance have washed down to the downstream rivers, including Gaoping River, Laonung River and Chisan River.

The Laonung River has carried some 91 million cubic meters of the substance and driftwood to the Tsengwen Reservoir, causing a water supply problem and leading to a suspension of irrigation for the first harvest next year on farmland in neighboring Chiayi and Tainan counties, Yang told a news conference.
He was speaking to reporters following a meeting of a cross-agency task force which is in charge of the dredging plan.
As part of the dredging project, about 65 million cubic meters of sand and mud will be removed from the reservoir upon the project's completion, slated for late November next year, Yang said.
Sand and rocks dug out from the reservoir will be used for construction and for filling in land reclaimed from the sea, WRA Deputy Director-General Wu Yueh-si said.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang presided over the meeting, which was attended by officials from the Ministry of National Defense, the Council of Agriculture, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Ministry of the Interior and the National Science Council, among others.

In the long-term, the Executive Yuan has decided to earmark NT$34 billion (US$1.05 billion) to dredge the Tsengwen Reservoir in Chiayi County and the Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan County, Executive Yuan spokesman Su Jun-pin said last week.
About NT$26 billion will be allocated to desilt the Tsengwen Reservoir over the next six years and NT$8 billion to clean the Nanhua Reservoir.
Tsengwen Reservoir is Taiwan's largest facility of the kind and has an effective storage capacity of 596 million cubic meters.
Since Typhoon Morakot, no rain has fallen in southern Taiwan and the two reservoirs have not collected any more water, exacerbating the threat of water shortages.

Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih warned that the water supply problem would develop into a food crisis if the two reservoirs could not be effectively and swiftly dredged, now that the rice cultivation for the coming spring harvest has been halted for a lack of water for irrigation.
More frequent of fallows will definitely push up rice prices in Taiwan, which have surged this year, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT Wenhu Line to get new control network in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 21:12:57 (By Jian Chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A new network system will replace the existing one on Taipei's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) Wenhu Line next year to significantly improve the glitch-plagued system's stability, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin said Friday.

The Wenhu Line suffered frequent breakdowns soon after opening in July, but Hau said the system has become more stable since network optimization was implemented in August, and a gigabit Ethernet network will be installed to further upgrade the metro line early next year.
The existing system's performance achieved 99 percent reliability by November, as promised by the MRT line's main contractor Canada-based Bombardier Inc.

But the city government hopes the mean kilometers between failures (MKBF) on the Wenhu Line will reach only one failure per 500,000 kilometers, a reliability level that the Taipei Metro's Muzha Line took six years to reach, according to Hau.

Despite the initial breakdowns, the Wenhu Line now serves an average of 170,000 passengers a day, Hau said, a 70 percent rise over the 100,000 passengers per day that rode the Muzha Line, of which the Wenhu Line is an extension.

The mayor praised the new line as mitigating traffic jams, boosting housing prices along its route and reducing carbon emissions, as many passengers now take the line instead of driving their own vehicles.

The new subway line, which combines the Muzha section that was built by French contractor Matra Co. in the 1990s and the new Neihu section built by Bombardier, has experienced nearly 10 shutdowns since its inauguration.

Taipei Rapid Transit Corp. Chairman Richard Chen promised at a city council meeting Friday to conduct checks on 51 pairs of train cars used on the original Muzha Line, which are being refitted to make them compatible with the Wenhu Line, before putting them into service in the next one to two years.
The refit work is scheduled to be completed by Feb. 14, 2010, after which testing of the refurbished cars will begin.

Hau also addressed the troubled Maokong Gondola, which had to halt service because the foundation for one of its support pillars began eroding. The pillar is now being moved but local residents still complain that the system may have a negative impact on the local environment.

Hau said the city government has commissioned the Chinese Union of Professional Civil Engineer Associations to conduct an overall inspection of the gondola line, with the results expected to be made public next month.
The mayor reiterated there is no timetable for the resumption of the gondola's operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: All talk, no action

TEXT.P: The idiom "all talk, no action" can best describe the latest round of high-level talks between Taiwan and China.

Only three agreements, all of which cover less contentious technical issues, were signed during the visit of China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Chen Yunlin, to Taichung Dec. 21-25. The far more important double taxation avoidance agreement was not signed as scheduled for reasons not clearly identified.

During the Chinese delegation's stay, Taiwanese officials carefully watched whether Chen brought with him any good news on the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and whether China was likely to accept Taiwan's terms.
Chen brushed Taiwan's expectations, however, reminding Taiwan not to engage in too much wishful thinking and not to harbor a "wait-rely-demand" mentality in cross-strait engagements.

Chen's statement might have been a preventive salvo aimed at telling Taiwan's ruling and opposition camps not to expect too much of the ECFA talks, but it also revealed China's growing arrogance and contempt toward Taiwan.
We need not be frustrated by his words, but we should wake up and act confidently to revive our competitive edge.
Over the past two decades, Taiwan has contributed much to China's economic development by supplying capital and technical and managerial talent.
But because of our government's incompetence, we lost our superiority vis-a-vis China economically.
However, we still have plenty of capital. So long as we act in concert and with resolve, our country still stands a good chance to restore its glory. We should never lose our self-confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Whose gain?

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang and the Communist Party of China like to tout the benefits to Taiwan gained from commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan's two top negotiators with China -- Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Chiang Pin-kung and his deputy Kao Koong-lian -- have finally exposed that lie.

Chiang said at a cross-strait forum Thursday in Taichung that Taiwan has invested more than NT$4.8 trillion in China over the past two decades while Kao said on the same occasion that China's investment in Taiwan amounted to NT$1.19 billion.

China has unilaterally benefited from Taiwan's huge capital infusion, while providing little protection for Taiwanese investors. Quite a few Taiwanese businessmen have fallen victim to fraud and disputes in China and lost everything there. Only the proverb "what's gone can never come back" can reflect their plight.

Those who hold illusions about the possible gains from China's investment should learn from those lessons. And that's why Taiwanese people have become ever more wary about the prospects of signing a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA). A recent opinion poll conducted by Weath Magazine found that only 29 percent of respondents supported such a pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: Central bank denies reports of credit controls in property market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 21:35:31 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's central bank denied a newspaper report on Friday that it has imposed controls on credit for investors who want to buy second houses in Taiwan's three major cities.

The Commercial Times reported Friday that the bank had decided to impose credit controls on buyers of second houses in Taipei City and County, Taichung City's seventh land consolidation area, and the area around Kaohsiung City's Museum of Fine Arts.

The newspaper cited Central Bank Governor Perng Fai-nan as saying that the price rises focused mainly on those three areas, and that banks could impose selective credit controls to limit loans to any person who wants to buy a house not occupied by its owner in the overheated districts.

In a statement released Friday, the central bank acknowledged that Perng had noted the rising property prices in the three areas while also pointing to stable or even declining prices in other areas, but it denied that he said anything related to credit controls.
Despite the central bank's denial, construction shares on the Taiwan stock exchange were unable to reverse the slide triggered by the newspaper report.
Construction shares sank 1.13 percent, losing ground to the broader market. The Taiex, the market's key barometer, edged up 9.05 points, or 0.11 percent, to close at 7,972.59.
Kingdom Construction, the most traded construction stock, slipped 2.6 percent to close at NT$26.6.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first WTO reference book unveiled
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 21:46:20 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Seven years after Taiwan joined the World Trade Organization (WTO), it has finally unveiled the first reference book related to terms often associated with the world trade regulatory body.
The book, Decoding WTO -- WTO Glossary, was compiled and published by Chung Hwa Institution for Economic Research (CIER) at the behest of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT).

BOFT Deputy Director-General Hsu Chun-fang said while attending the launch of the new book Friday that she hopes it can include the term ECFA -- referring to a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China -- in its glossary next year.
Hsu said the 372-page book includes more than 6.7 million terms and should become a handy and useful reference for civil servants, scholars and professionals.
The book's editor Hsu Tseng-chi said the reference work took a full year to compile.
Hsu said that after China became a WTO member in late 2001, it published a WTO dictionary in 2004 that is three times the size of Taiwan's glossary.
Hsu said that the book first focused on trade-related entries so that the public can grasp WTO jargon before the glossary is updated in two or three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talks with China do not hamper sovereignty: MAC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 21:53:24 (By Feng Chao, Sophia Yeh & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has held several rounds of talks with China without undermining the country's sovereignty, Lai Shin-yuan, chairwoman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Friday to counter criticism from opposition parties.

"The past rounds of cross-strait talks have been held based on the principles of reciprocity, equality and dignity, and the growing participation of officials from both sides in the talks accentuates the fact that both Taiwan and China cannot deny each other's existence, " Lai said while meeting Taiwan's negotiating team with China.

The team, led by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), concluded the fourth round of cross-strait talks with its Chinese counterpart, the delegation headed by President Chen Yunlin of the Beijing- based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the central Taiwan city of Taichung Tuesday.

A total of 12 agreements, including three from the latest Taichung talks, have been forged between Taiwan and China since the first round of talks in June 2008 to increase economic cooperation, Lai added.

"All the talks have been conducted with the aim of safeguarding national sovereignty, promoting industrial development and taking care of people's lives, " Lai said to counter opposition arguments that the talks have hampered Taiwan's sovereignty and actually endangered some local industrial sectors.

Spokeswoman Hsiao Bi-khim of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said her party has not been against dialogue between Taiwan and China to establish a framework for peace and stability, but rather it has insisted that the talks have to be held transparently and openly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to consider alternative plans for DRAM restructuring
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 22:07:59 (By Pei-chun Tang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will seriously consider alternative plans to help Taiwan's ailing DRAM sector if the Legislative Yuan decides to reject the government's plan to restructure the industry, an MOEA official said Friday.
Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said that with DRAM prices on the rebound, there will be more time for the ministry to consider more sophisticated ways to restructure the industry.
"We will not do it in hurry," he added.

The Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee adopted a resolution in November asking the MOEA to suspend its DRAM industry restructuring plan and withdraw its proposed investment in the state-backed Taiwan Innovation Memory Co. (TIMC), which was supposed to be the centerpiece of the plan.

Although the ministry has been lobbying lawmakers not to scuttle the plan, Shih said it will propose alternative plans if another resolution opposing the restructuring plan is passed by the full Legislative Yuan by the end of the current session on Dec. 31.

The Executive Yuan has conditionally approved TIMC's request for NT$8.1 billion in funding from the National Development Fund (NDF) , but legislators across the political spectrum believe that the Fund should not invest in TIMC because DRAM prices have recovered, making it pointless to proceed with the original plan.

The government had hoped that TIMC would secure badly needed core technologies and bring together some of the sectors' big players, including Powerchip Semiconductor, ProMOS Technologies, and Rexchip Electronics, to spur the consolidation of the fragmented industry.

Taiwan's DRAM industry has been bleeding money over the past two years because of overcapacity and a slump in demand. It boasts six of the world's top 10 DRAM manufacturers but holds a global market share of only 15 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC heads respond to Chinese dissident's sentence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 22:33:32 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: China's 11-year sentence of leading dissident Liu Xiaobo on Friday for subversion serves as a test of the Chinese government's approach to dealing with human rights, according to Taiwan's top government agency for China affairs.

Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun said human rights are universal values and that all governments around the world should endeavor to ensure that their citizens enjoy their human rights.

Earlier, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) spokeswoman Hsiao Bi-khim accused President Ma Ying-jeou, who during his term as Taipei mayor championed the rights of Tiananmen Incident protesters, of staying silent about China's gross violations of human rights since taking office.
Liu did not address the criticism head on, but he said it is inevitable that the Chinese government will move toward the path of freedom, democracy and human rights in the future.
MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan also said that her council has been consistent on its position and attitude toward human rights both at home and abroad.

After a Chinese court handed down the harsh sentence to Liu Xiaobo on charges of "inciting subversion of state power" Friday, the United States and European Union urged Beijing to free Liu immediately, and many countries have expressed concern about the sentence.

The pro-democracy activist has been in jail since 2008 after being arrested one day before releasing a document known as Charter 08, a petition calling for the end of one-party rule in China and the establishment of a multi-party democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Law amendment planned to facilitate imports of U.S. bone-in beef
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/25/09 23:05:39 (By L. C. Su and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers from ruling and opposition camps have decided to discuss an amendment next week that would allow U.S. bone-in beef products to enter Taiwan without disputes, the legislative caucus whip of the governing Kuomintang (KMT) said Friday.

Lu Hsueh-chang said KMT legislators and their opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) peers are slated to deal with the amendment to the Act Governing Food Sanitation that has been stalled for nearly two months on Dec. 29.
They hope to provide a sound legal basis for the executive branch's disputed decision in late October to allow bone-in beef to be imported from the United States.

Lu said versions submitted by the two parties have many similarities, but further discussions may be needed to bridge the differences. He pointed out that the KMT will never give way to the DPP's request that "U.S. bone-in beef products will be permitted to enter Taiwan only after their bones are removed in advance."

According to Lu, the KMT version would note the principle of "offshore inspection guidelines" and would require the government to send officials to check every batch of bone-in beef products in the United States before being shipped to Taiwan.

If the DPP's version is selected, the KMT will add a note explaining that the legislation's logic falls in line with the requirements set by the World Organization for Animal Health, which gives the administration a basis for discussing the issue with the U.S., he said.
Once an amendment is passed, Lu wondered "whether someone in the government should be held politically accountable" for all the furor that has arisen over the issue in the past two months.

"It is important to review the entire process of the government's poor handling of the matter, even if an amendment to the Act Governing Food Sanitation, whether the KMT version or the DPP version, clears the Legislative Yuan," he argued.

The lack of advanced notice to the legislature of its decision to allow U.S. bone-in beef into Taiwan has affected related legislation and also delayed the screening of the central government's budget, he said.

The Cabinet-level Department of Health's announcement Oct. 23 that bone-in beef and other previously banned beef products would be allowed into Taiwan starting Nov. 10 provoked an outcry led by the DPP, and it demanded that the Executive Yuan reopen negotiations with the United States on the protocol covering U.S. beef imports.
Su Chi, secretary-general of the National Security Council, has ruled out the possibility of a new round of beef talks on the grounds that doing so will jeopardize two-way relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, Dec. 26, or the 11th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1792: Charles Babbage, British mathematician and inventor of the first computer, is born.
1797: John Wilkes, British political reformer noted for his published attacks on George III and for his support of the rights of American colonists, dies at the age of 70.
1890: Heinrich Schliemann, the German archaeologist who discovered the ruins of ancient Troy and excavated Mycenae, dies in Naples, Italy, at the age of 58.
1893: Mao Zedong, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party who proclaimed the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, is born in Hunan Province.
1908: American boxer Jack Johnson defeats world heavyweight champion Tommy Burns at Rushcutter's Bay in Sydney, Australia, with a dazzling display of fighting skills, becoming the first black boxer to win the title.
1912: Mackay Memorial Hospital is inaugurated in Taipei.
1914: The United States pays back the remainder of a large sum of indemnities, totaling $11 million, that China was forced to pay in the signing of the Treaty of Peking in 1901.
1916: Tsai Yuan-pei becomes president of National Peking University.
1938: Chiang Kai-shek reiterates China's determination to carry on the war of resistance against Japan and charges that a recent statement by Japanese Prime Minister Prince Fumimaro Konoye clearly reveals Japan's intention to conquer China.
1941: The Unites States declares Manila an open city as Japanese forces approach.
1943: The British Royal Navy sinks the mighty German battle cruiser Scharnhosrt, making the sea lanes of the North Sea safer for Allied convoys.
1971: Sixteen U.S. veterans of the Vietnam War seize the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor to dramatize their anti-war stance.
1972: The Association of East Asian Relations of the Republic of China and the Interchange Association of Japan sign an agreement in Taipei to establish offices in each other's country.
1972: Harry S. Truman, U.S. president between 1945-53, dies in Kansas City at the age of 88.
1974: Hironori Ito, former director of the Taipei Office of the Japanese Interchange Association, returns to Japan for a new assignment.
1975: The Legislative Yuan passes the Radio and Television Act.
1976: The 11th Convention of the Committee on Constitutional Research of the National Assembly opens at the Taipei City Auditorium.
1976: A two-day discussion on the electronic calculator opens at National Taiwan University.
1985: The Futehkeng landfill formally opens in Mucha, Taipei.
1989: Nobel Prize-winning Irish dramatist Samuel Beckett dies in Paris at the age of 83.
1999: Vice President Lien Chan chooses the Taiwan black bear as the one animal most representative of wildlife indigenous to Taiwan.
1999: The China Democracy Party, banned by Beijing a year earlier, issues a bold call to end one-party rule, challenging both the Communist Party's constitutional hold on supreme power and the Beijing regime's threat to use force to reunify Taiwan.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweight John Chang says in Xiamen that the purpose of his ongoing visit in mainland China is to promote the development of Taiwan-funded companies and to establish a bridge of communication with related mainland officials.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung presides over the inaugural ceremony of an administrative coordination center on the frontline island of Kinmen for managing affairs related to the "mini three links."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman never competes in anything he does, except perhaps in archery. But even then, when he wins he courteously makes his bow before he advances to take his place among the winners; and, when he has lost, he walks down and drinks his cup of forfeit. Thus, even in this case of competition, he shows himself to be a gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to consider alternative plans for DRAM restructuring
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 25 (CNA) 12/26/09 10:16:43 (By Pei-chun Tang and Fanny Liu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
No further opening to Chinese farm products after ECFA: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/09 13:20:15 (By Garfie Li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has reaffirmed his commitment to protecting the well- being of local farmers, saying that Taiwan will not open its doors wider to Chinese agricultural products after a trade pact between the two sides is signed.

Instead, the government will seek to expand market access for Taiwanese agricultural products in China, Ma told Huang Hsien-yao, chief of Jhengbei village in Minsyong township, Chiayi County, during a recent visit to the agricultural village.
The dialogue between Ma and Huang was presented in the latest issue of the president's weekly online video journal, released Saturday.
In the conversation, Huang asked Ma why underground radio stations often report that the proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is intended to "sell out Taiwan."

Ma responded by pointing out that during the run-up to the 2008 presidential election, these underground radio stations also claimed that "if Ma Ying-jeou gets elected, the monthly NT$6,000 allowance for old farmers will be gone," a claim later proved to be utterly false.

He noted that of the total of 1,415 Chinese agricultural products that have been allowed access to Taiwan, none were liberalized during his term. The upcoming ECFA talks with China will not touch upon issues concerning further liberalization of Taiwan's market toward agricultural products from China, he added.
"So all farmers please rest assured that as president, Ma Ying-jeou will definitely uphold your interests and will never sell out Taiwan," Ma said.
The president also noted that the launch of direct shipping links across the Taiwan Strait after his inauguration has helped expedite the export of Taiwanese fruit and vegetables to China.
While it used to take eight days for such exports to reach Shanghai from Keelung, it now takes only four days, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Manipulating the law
DOC.DATELINE: 12/26/09 13:25:20 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi divorced his wife after being elected and announced three days after the divorce that he was naming his "ex-wife" deputy magistrate. The Ministry of the Interior ruled Dec. 22 that the divorce is fake and that since the marital relationship still exists, the designation is against the Public Servants Employment Rules on Avoidance of Conflicts of Interest and is subject to penalty by the Control Yuan.
Fu canceled the appointment immediately after the ruling, ending the political farce but marking a negative lesson in Taiwan's democratic development.

Anyone with good observation can see that the incident was motivated by political calculation on the part of Fu, who was sentenced to four years in prison for illegal trading by the Taiwan High Court June 11, 2009. He intended to maintain his magistrate seat by having his wife as acting magistrate when he was inside.
The case of Fu, a political figure who could have used the scheme for the purpose of keeping his public post, reflects how tempting is political power.

Fu had claimed that by naming his spouse as deputy he was only following the example of former Taitung Magistrate Wu chun-li. The grave practice of nepotism in politics has been an unforgivable mistake.
Society should no longer tolerate the manipulation of the law by political figures. The central government, including the Control Yuan, should see to it that the law is strictly enforced.

DOC.HEADLINE: Finance Ministry to enhance management of state-owned shares, land
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/09 14:13:03 (By Yi-fong Lin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will put more effort into managing state-owned shares and land to increase government revenue, a ministry official said Saturday.

National Treasury Agency Director-General Hwang Ding-fang said the MOF has formed a team to supervise the management of government-owned shares, with the aim of more effectively managing them, strengthening corporate performance and competitiveness and increasing the income thereof for the government.
According to Hwang, the government holds a total of 88.1 billion state shares worth NT$2.9 trillion, of which 20.8 billion, worth about NT$600 billion, are held by the MOF.

Premier Wu Den-yih has asked the MOF to focus more on activating national assets, saying that the government, with the large amount of land and shares in its hands, is "complaining about being poor while sitting on a golden chair," an MOF official quoted Wu as saying.

Hwang said the ministry has also formed a team to better manage national land. Citing Taipei 101 as an example, he said the government provided the land for private investors to construct the building, which not only brought more income and tax revenue, but also created 3,000 jobs.

In addition, with outstanding savings deposits of NT$27 trillion and lending of NT$20 trillion, there is about NT$7 trillion held by banks, said Hwang, adding that this money should be invested in public construction projects, which would create a win-win situation for the government and the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Year party organized for Siaolin village: KMT lawmaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 26 (CNA) 12/26/09 15:26:13 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator announced Saturday a plan to organize a New Year party for the survivors of Siaolin village in Kaohsiung County, which was leveled by Typhoon Morakot in August.
"The typhoon has devastated the village, but Siaolin's villagers are not alone because we will stand by them," said Huang Chao-shun.
"It is important to continue providing care to the Siaolin villagers, who are still suffering immense pain at the turn of the year -- the first New Year since the tragedy," she explained.

According to Huang, she and some 30 volunteer workers from colleges and universities in southern Taiwan, in collaboration with a self-assistance group of villagers, will organize the party at the village on New Year's Eve.

"We hope to help the survivors and their families wave goodbye to the past sorrow and embrace a better new year in a warm atmosphere, " she said, adding that "there will be no celebrities or fireworks, but we will stage a concert, a barbecue and a night campfire for them."

Huang said she will also donate a batch of children's books she has collected from the public to the children of the village. "We hope Siaolin's children can find consolation and a new lease on live from these books and can welcome the new year with confidence and strength, " she added.
More than 600 people in Siaolin were buried alive in a landslide triggered by precipitation brought by Typhoon Morakot, making the village the hardest-hit area of the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News
DOC.DATELINE: 12/26/09 15:42:51 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A special prosecution panel under the Ministry of Justice has filed charges against several renowned bankers for assisting former President Chen Shui-bian in money laundering.

Chen and his wife, by enabling Cathay United Bank and Yuanta Financial Holdings to acquire other financial holding companies, accepted a total of NT$610 million from Cathay United Vice Chairman T.Y. Tsai and Yuanta controlling shareholder Ma Chih-ling, in addition to a NT$300 million bribe from Jeffrey Koo, Jr., former Chinatrust Financial vice chairman.

During the eight-year Chen administration, "deals between money and politics" were conducted in the name of "monetary reform." The mentality of achieving goals through black money has distorted the fairness of market competition, disgraced the concept of prudence and honesty, and deepened injustice in society. If judicial personnel fail to enforce the law in this regard, won't they be conniving with the criminals?

Chen and his wife showed no respect for the law in their interference in bank mergers and acquisitions, but it would not have been possible for them to make their unlawful gains if the bankers did not have their own unlawful expectations.

From the years of President Lee Teng-hui to the time of Chen's administration, the problem of black money dealing got worse because big business was polluted by politics and politics were polluted by big business. Both corrupt politicians and greedy businessmen are accountable for unlawful dealing.
The prosecution of the executives of three financial holding companies should serve as a lesson to all entrepreneurs: Don't be polluted by politics, and don't pollute politics, either.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Totalitarian China
DOC.DATELINE: 12/26/09 16:59:43 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: While Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, was visiting Taiwan with his nose in the air, China sentenced well-known dissident Liu Xiaobo to 11 years in prison for "instigating subversion." This relentless brutality against a dissident has drawn severe criticism from around the globe.

The international communities finds it unacceptable that Liu was taken away by public security officers for expressing his political beliefs in a peaceful manner, and that during his detention over the past year, the Chinese government has refused to disclose his whereabouts and directed the media to block news regarding Liu and "Charter 08, " an appeal to the Beijing authorities for increased freedom in China and an end to the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) dominance. Liu's basic human rights and freedom have been seriously infringed upon.

Liu is the just the latest case showing that China is treating dissidents increasingly harshly. As a matter of fact, in recent years, China has made many unwarranted accusations against political prisoners, in addition to persecuting people with different political positions through false accusations of tax evasion, leaking national secrets or violating commercial regulations.

After 30 years of economic opening, China has "emerged" economically in the eyes of the world. However, a one-party ruled China that fails to honor democracy and human rights will not be able to develop into a harmonious civilized society or become a respectable country.

The ruling Kuomintang and the CPC both follow the Leninist model. Now that the two parties have united to control Taiwan, apparently Taiwan's system of democracy, freedom and human rights has failed to influence China. While not being able to treat its own people right, China has never tried to hide its ambition to annex Taiwan. As President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is on its knees in the face of such a neighbor, Taiwanese people who are concerned about democracy, freedom and human rights must not sit and wait. Urgent action is needed to reverse the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Manipulating the law
DOC.DATELINE: 12/26/09 17:49:41 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Hualien Magistrate Fu Kun-chi divorced his wife after being elected and announced three days after the divorce that he was naming his "ex-wife" deputy magistrate. The Ministry of the Interior ruled Dec. 22 that the divorce is fake and that since the marital relationship still exists, the designation is against the Public Servants Employment Rules on Avoidance of Conflicts of Interest and is subject to penalty by the Control Yuan.
Fu canceled the appointment immediately after the ruling, ending the political farce but marking a negative lesson in Taiwan's democratic development.
