DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- vaccine doubts
DOC.DATELINE: The number of hospitalized influenza A(H1N1) 12/27/09 15:59:00 (Dec. 27, 2009) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: patients has increased over the weekend as fewer people have accepted shots amid mounting reports of side effects of the immunization.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue of public doubts about the safety of H1N1 vaccine:
United Daily News:
Amid doubts and concerns over the safety of H1N1 vaccine after a 7-year-old died several weeks after being immunized, there has been resistance among the Taiwan public against the inoculation drive.

As a result of the resistance, the number of new influenza A(H1N1) infection cases in Taiwan rose over the weekend, overturning a positive situation posted last week in which the number dropped significantly since the vaccination campaign was launched nationwide Nov. 1.
The number of people vaccinated against H1N1 reached a single-day record of 560,000 in mid-December, a number that had plummeted to a mere 42,000 as of Dec. 25, according to the Department of Health.
The immunization drive proved its success in Taiwan between Nov. 21 and Nov. 23, when no H1N1 hospitalized cases were recorded.
This performance, however, was smashed Dec. 25 when five new cases were reported, underlining that the resistance against the vaccination drive has dragged down the entire H1N1-fighting effort.

Centers for Disease Control (CDC) Deputy Director-General Chou Jih-haw warned that with fewer than 20 percent of the people in the country immunized so far, it will be a challenge for Taiwan to face a likelihood of a second wave of influenza A(H1N1) , commonly known as swine flu, as colder weather approaches. (Dec. 27, 2009)
China Times:

Lee Ping-ing, a pediatrician with National Taiwan University Hospital, quoted experiences in the United States and Mexico as suggesting that there are usually two or three big outbreaks in any given epidemic.

A second wave outbreak of H1N1 flu will be a sure thing in Taiwan as the winter break approaches and air travel increases if the people continue to resist the vaccination drive because of doubts and concerns, Lee said.
Lee called for the public to "listen more closely to medical professionals" and not to take the virus lightly. (Dec. 27, 2009)
Liberty Times:
Local health authorities are worried that people's doubts over the safety of the H1N1 vaccine is having a negative effect on the nationwide vaccination campaign.
Five new hospitalized cases were reported over the weekend, with two admitted to intensive care units. None of the five new cases had been immunized.

Even though more people have become resistant to accepting the HIN1 vaccine due to an alleged fatality and some 400 people who have been vaccinated have complained of serious symptoms, including high fever, health officials said Sunday that all eight complaints probed under a vaccine injury compensation program (VICP) were confirmed a day earlier to be unrelated to the HIN1 inoculation.
Dozens of other complaints cases are being probed under the VICP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- ECFA controversy

TEXT.P: Concluding a round-the-island walk to promote their cause, referendum activists claimed Saturday that mainstream opinion wants a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) be put to a national referendum. Meanwhile, the government is stepping up publicity efforts to help the public better understand the gist of the deal and the challenges the country could face without such an all-encompassing trade accord with China.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
Liberty Times: A 49-day, round-the-island walk to call for "the people to decide on cross-strait agreements" ended Saturday at its starting point -- Lungshan Temple in Taipei City.

Chen Li-kuei, convener of the journey initiated by former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, read a statement saying that putting a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to a national referendum has become mainstream opinion.

The statement blasted the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou for being arrogant, saying that "mounting public opposition to the signing of the ECFA and continued slipping of the approval rating of the Ma administration has not persuaded it to be on guard and to reflect humbly." (Dec. 27, 2009)
United Daily News: Ma recently visited a village chief in southern Taiwan to speak on issues farmers are most concerned about, including the ECFA.
Huang Hsien-yao, chief of Jhengbei village in Minsyong township, Chiayi County, said he told Ma that farmers will not oppose the ECFA as long as their livelihoods are protected.

Ma, who spoke mostly in Taiwanese throughout the nearly two-hour visit, pointed out that he has not opened one single Chinese agricultural product to Taiwan since his inauguration and that he "sells Taiwan fruit instead of selling out Taiwan, " contrary to claims by some underground radio stations in the south.
The upcoming ECFA talks with China will not touch upon issues concerning further liberalization of Taiwan's market to agricultural products from China, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 28 more sites selected as wetlands of national importance
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 16:10:44 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) has selected 21 wetlands areas that are expected to be listed as wetlands of national importance in February, bringing the total number of nationally important wetlands to more than 100, an MOI official said Sunday.

The newly selected wetlands cover a total area of 20,000 hectares in 14 cities and counties around Taiwan, according to the official, citing an initial assessment report of national wetlands for 2009 released by the MOI's Construction and Planning Agency.

The new sites include one listed as world-class wetlands on the Changhua Coast, 10 listed as national-level wetlands in the Danshui River basin, Taoyuan County's Hsutsuo Harbor, Nankunshen in Tainan County and various other areas, and 17 of local importance in Hisnchu, Nantou, Pingtung and other cities or counties, according to the report.
In the agency's first assessment conducted in 2007, 75 sites were identified as qualifying as wetlands of national importance, according to the official.

This year, the MOI's wetlands evaluation panel selected the 28 sites as nationally important wetlands from a number of wetland areas recommended by 36 civic groups, schools and public and private institutions, the official went on.

The agency also made adjustments on the grades of the original 75 wetland sites. For example, the Jhubei Lianhua Temple wetlands -- the habitat of several rare aquatic carnivorous plants -- was proposed to be upgraded to a national-level wetland site with the aim of strengthening habitat protection there, the official said.
The final assessment report will be made public Feb. 2, next year's World Wetland Day, when a ceremony to present accreditation certificates will be held, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Keep up with times

TEXT.P: The time has come for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to be more practical in arranging their institutionalized high-level talks, known locally as the "Chiang-Chen meetings, " in order to enhance their effects and avoid any snags.

The failure of the two sides to sign a double taxation avoidance agreement at the just-concluded fourth such meeting in Taichung signals that cross-strait negotiations have entered a new stage that will require more dealmaking efforts than previous rounds.

In the past, the two-quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) -- spent much time on formality details, including meeting settings and venues, as they endeavored to create a good atmosphere for cross-strait interaction after years of tension created by the previous Democratic Progressive Party administration's pro-independence stance.

Such efforts can no longer be justified, as cross-strait talks have become more issue- and substance-oriented, with more and more thorny issues involving distribution of interests and benefits topping the agenda.
Those issues can only be discussed in a sincere and frank manner with the support of well-planned preparations. What matters is the delicate dealmaking process rather than hollow pomp and trappings.

According to a preliminary agreement, the next meeting between SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kun and ARATS President Chen Yunlin will mainly deal with two issues -- a much-anticipated cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and cooperation in intellectual property rights (IPR) protection.

Given the scope and complexity of the issues to be covered in the ECFA, the two sides should consider whether they should still arrange the fifth Chiang-Chen meeting in the first half of 2010 in line with the existing formality of holding a high-level meeting once every six months.

The next Chiang-Chen meeting should take place only when the two sides are ready to cut the ECFA deal, which will cover wide-ranging cross-strait distribution of interests and lay the groundwork for normalization of cross-strait trade and economic relations.
The image and framework of the Chiang-Chen talks could be at stake if the ECFA deal is not signed at the fifth meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Carbon action matters

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has only paid lip service to carbon emissions reduction. At the moment, boosting economic figures is the top priority, even though such a move will have a negative impact on the environment.

Taiwan is now pushing forward large petrochemical and industrial investment projects. But is it possible for Taiwan to scrap these projects when facing international pressure to cut emissions? How much emissions does Taiwan need to cut in other areas to meet international standards?
Let us also remind the government that reducing carbon emissions is a long-term task that needs the cooperation of businesses and citizens.

Electricity, for example, is one of the largest emission sources in every economy. Has the government offered enough incentives to encourage the public to buy energy-saving home appliances or fuel-efficient vehicles?
The government also needs to raise environmental standards for emissions, otherwise local companies will not be willing to invest in better and lower emissions production equipment.

This will encourage businesses to focus on clean energy and increase the competitiveness of their products. It will also be beneficial to industrial restructuring and economic development in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to spend NT$13.26 billion on sports promotion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 17:03:38 (By Erin Ho and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has approved a proposal to spend NT$13.26 billion (US$410 million) between 2010 and 2013 on building sports facilities around the country and sponsoring sports activities aimed at promoting sport for all.

The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has recently given the nod to a plan by the Sports Affairs Council (SAC) to improving the country's sports environment and developing Taiwan into a place that is more enthusiastic about sport.

Under the plan, the government will provide funds during the period to establish 20 sports parks and 50 public sports centers around the country, as well as subsidizing local governments to install sports facilities and equipment, an SAC spokesman said Sunday.
From 2010, local governments can begin submitting applications for the installation of sports facilities in their administrative areas, according to the spokesman.
The SAC will evaluate the applications based on population size and population density of an area within 200 hectares of the proposed sports centers, the spokesman said.
Local governments that agree to take charge of the management and operation of the proposed sports facilities will be given priority for subsidization, the spokesman went on.

Meanwhile, the plan also includes the building and refurbishment of sports fields such as basketball courts, swimming pools, skating rinks, tennis courts, slow pitch softball fields and gateball courses, as well as the maintenance and repair of sports facilities.
To encourage more people to exercise, the SAC will set up 125 physical fitness test stations nationwide and plans to hand out 200,000 sports and fitness medals during the period.

The SAC hopes that through the program, the number of people who exercise regularly will increase by 0.5 percent-1 percent per year so that by 2013, the number of people exercising regularly will have reached 26 percent of the population, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature suggests local disaster prevention alliances
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 17:36:03 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has taken stock of the experience of Japan in disaster prevention and has suggested the formation of local disaster relief alliances to provide quick rescue at the first strike of a disaster.

The legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Bureau noted that Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan in August with the most serious precipitation in nearly half a century, exposed the deficiencies of Taiwan's disaster relief mechanism.
As a result, bureau officials went on a tour of Japan to learn about that country's experience in disaster prevention and response.

The officials said they found Japan has shifted its focus to software and management from its past concentration on hardware development, and that disaster prevention orchestrated by the central government has also switched to joint cooperation between local residents and the administration to mitigate the impact of disasters.
The Japanese government attaches great importance to disaster simulation drills, and cities and prefectures form alliances to conduct such drills regularly.
Residents are taught that when disaster strikes, they should first seek self- relief or take shelter to mitigate casualties and then wait for government rescue and relief.

The bureau also suggested that ministries, commissions and bureaus should send their officials to work regularly at the Central Disaster Prevention and Response Council to enhance inter-agency coordination.

A special commission should also be set up to conduct investigations after each major disaster and announce the results. This would establish a mechanism to pass on management and experience in disaster response.

In an evaluation report on the draft amendment on Disaster Prevention and Response Act, the bureau pointed out that the deficiencies in Taiwan's disaster prevention and response system include the lack of a joint disaster response plan, incomplete disaster information, the lack of on-site command system and insufficient use and management of available resources.

The bureau noted that Typhoon Morakot also highlighted the "inappropriate concept and approach" in flood prevention, lack of a land safety and conservation plan, a faulty command system in the central and local disaster response centers and rigid procedure and slow response in providing military support to rescue operations, as well as a lack of regular drills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Opaque and hasty policy-making
DOC.DATELINE: Su Chi, secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC) 12/27/09 18:23:17 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: , has warned of the risks of retaliatory measures by the United States if the legislature amends a law to bar possibly unsafe U.S. beef products from being imported into Taiwan, as such a move will violate the Taiwan-U.S. protocol.
This lose-lose situation could have been prevented if Taiwan had not signed any deal with the U.S. Without the protocol, the U.S. would have little reason for any retaliatory action.

This is the result of the government's secret and hasty decision-making process. Similar incidents have repeatedly occurred in the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou over the past year in the areas of oil price hikes, infrastructure projects, shopping vouchers, tax reductions, the avoidance of double taxation with China and the merger of local counties and cities into special municipalities.

An open process gives people an opportunity to voice their concerns, which makes the outcome of a decision more acceptable to the public. A transparent process also allows experts to review the facts and theories adopted in proposed policies, which could avoid possible shortcomings.

The government should replace those decision makers with people who respect public opinion and who are more willing to face criticism. The government should also assure the public that sufficient time and open discussions will be allowed before decisions are made.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Second thoughts on new institute

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs should have second thoughts on a proposal to set up a new national research institute on the cultural and creative industries.

The council is reported to have come up with the proposal at the suggestion of an opposition legislator who took her cue from the phenomenal success of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in helping spur the development of Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) industry.

As industrial intellectual property tends to originate in laboratories, they have to undergo a period of incubation to evolve into commercial products, a need that necessitates the establishment of ITRI.

The ITRI has long played the role of an incubator in the development of Taiwan's high-tech industry. It has helped test the maturity of new technology, explored its market acceptance and raised money for start-up companies to venture into potential markets. Only when the time is mature does the ITRI-formed start-up companies spin off to become independent corporations.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) -- the world's largest contract computer chip foundry -- is a typical example of the ITRI's incubating mission. TSMC Chairman Morris Chang helped incubate semiconductor technologies during his tenure as ITRI president and his company is an ITRI spin-off.

As the cultural and creative industries mostly do not involve any abstractive technologies developed in laboratories, the need to set up an ITRI-like institute to help with the sector's development is questionable.

Culture refers not to experiments in laboratories but rather to concrete developments in daily life and social activity. If there are indeed some ICT- related cultural or creative products, the government just needs to commission the ITRI's information technology institute to form a task force to help with digitization of relevant products.

Taiwan really has to accelerate its cultural and creative industry development, but the focus should be on marketing rather than setting up a huge institute just for incubation purposes. The government should employ competent officials with marketing expertise to carry out relevant projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer children immunized over vaccine doubts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 18:34:43 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A fatality allegedly due to an inoculation against influenza A(H1N1) involving a 7-year-old in Taichung has caused panic among parents in Taiwan leading to a sharp decline in the number of school children receiving H1N1 immunization over the past week.

Pediatricians at major medical institutions confirmed Sunday that the number of school children receiving H1N1 vaccine shots has declined sharply over the past week, primarily due to concerns over the safety of the vaccine after the 7-year- old boy died several weeks after being immunized.
The doctors, however, still recommended that parents should get their children immunized because the benefits far outweigh the risks.

Huang Li-min, head of the Pediatrics Department of National Taiwan University Hospital, also noted that the immunization effect will be limited if the child receives only one shot rather than the recommended two.
"The young vaccine recipient will become fully protected against the H1N1 virus only after receiving two shots," Huang said.

Meanwhile, Lin Hsiu-chen, a pediatrician with Taipei Medical University Hospital, estimated that the number of school children receiving H1N1 inoculations was down by some 30 percent compared to the number when the nationwide vaccination campaign was launched Nov. 1.
Lin said she will persuade parents to have their young children vaccinated, although she admitted she could not force them to do so.
"The decision is for the parents to make," Lin noted.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education said Sunday it will respect the decisions of parents on whether their children will receive H1N1 vaccine shots or not.

Lee Ping-ing, another pediatrician with National Taiwan University Hospital, attributed the decline in the number of people being immunized to the fact that the number of new H1N1 cases has dropped significantly since the vaccination campaign was launched, while several hundred cases complaining about side effects after being immunized have given rise to doubts about the safety of the vaccine.

Lee, who doubles as secretary-general of the Taiwan Immunization Vision and Strategy Alliance, said that some people have become disenchanted with the vaccination drive and prefer to take medicine such as Tamiflu upon falling victim to the H1N1 virus.

These non-vaccinated people will be at highest risk of the next wave of swine flu, which could be more deadly because the virus might have mutated, Lee predicted, noting that judging from the seasonal flu epidemic outbreaks of the past, there are usually two or three big outbreaks in one epidemic.

Citing U.S. research that found the swine flu virus invades deep into the lungs, Lee warned the public not to take the virus lightly, adding that they also should not harbor the idea that they need not to be vaccinated if others are instead.
"Only those children who are allergic to eggs or those who have developed allergy symptoms after receiving seasonal flu vaccine should forego vaccination," he said.
H1N1 inoculation is safe for almost all children, even if they have nasitis, asthma or dermatitis, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Slang against Chinese envoy stirs up local political discussion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 18:59:33 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A local media story quoting an unnamed Taiwanese official who used a pejorative to brand Chinese envoy Chen Yunlin as a "C-list" politician was incorrect, a top Taiwanese negotiator with China said in a hastily called press conference Sunday.

In a story published a day earlier by the China Times daily, an official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) -- Taiwan's quasi-official organization set up to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait negotiations -- was quoted as saying that the situation of three Taiwanese political heavyweights trying to meet with Chen during his five-day visit that concluded Friday was like "the A-listers versus the C-listers," with Chen as the "C-list" politician.
SEF Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, who signed three agreements with Chen the previous week, questioned the authenticity of the story at a press conference, saying the report was not true.

Major newspapers and news Web sites in Taiwan had all dedicated extensive coverage to the topic over the past two days. The story, which described former ruling Kuomintang (KMT) chairmen Wu Po-hsiung and Lien Chan, and opposition People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong as "A-list politicians who were desperately seeking to meet with Chen, a C-list official in China, " stirred up a political discussion, with President Ma Ying-jeou saying that the usage was "inappropriate and disrespectful."

Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih told reporters that "the use of the expression probably needs more contemplation, " while Soong said the statement would "have a negative impact on cross-strait relations."

Responding to reporters' questions, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Hsin-yuan said that "there is no such thing as A-list or C-list in cross- strait exchanges because the people are the most important factor."

DOC.HEADLINE: Events for welcoming first sunrise of 2010 planned
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 19:03:47 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Several cities and counties around Taiwan are taking advantage of their favorable geographical locations for sunrise appreciation and will host activities on New Year's Eve to attract visitors to usher in 2010 during the year's first ray of sunlight in their administrative regions.
The Central Weather Bureau predicted the first sunrise of the coming year is expected to appear around 6:30 a.m.
Hotel operators in Kenting in the southernmost county of Pingtung, which is known for its scenic tropical coast, have designed tour packages featuring the sunrise in the county's Jialuoshui.
Kenting's Sheding Nature Park, which provides a good view of the ocean, is being touted as a good place to watch the first sunrise of the year.

At least three sunrise activities will take place in Taitung County in southeastern Taiwan, including an event held each year since 2000 at Taimali, another at Sanhsientai to be held by the Tourism Bureau's East Coast National Scenic Area Administration, and the another at the Daguanshan Tunnel on the western section of the Southern Cross-Island Highway.

The stunningly gorgeous Seven Star Lake in Hualien City in eastern Taiwan is also being touted as one of the best places to greet the first sunrise of 2010 and several hotels in the area have devised bicycle tours to allow cyclists to watch the sunrise while enjoying the fun of cycling along the scenic routes in the area.
Meanwhile, a New Year's Eve countdown concert will take place at Fulong Beach at Taipei County as a prelude to a gathering for watching the sunrise there.

At Alishan in southern Chiayi County, the "Alishan Sunrise Impression Concert, " which has been held annually since 2002, will begin at 6 a.m., ahead of the first sunrise of the new year forecast to rise over the popular mountain resort at around 7 a.m.
Following that, a blessing concert and a series of performances by the aboriginal Tsou people will be staged in the area, lasting for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Prominent Chinese dissident envious of Taiwan's democracy

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Writer
It is a dream of Liu Xiaobo, the prominent Chinese dissident who was sentenced to 11 years in jail Dec. 25, for a democratic system like the one in Taiwan to someday take shape in China.

Liu, who had been detained since December last year, was given the jail term -- one of the harshest ever for any Chinese dissenter, on charges of "inciting subversion of state power, " a vague and unique term that China uses to prosecute its dissidents.

In interviews with CNA before the 2008 Beijing Olympics, Liu said he has been very interested in Taiwan's recent democratic development and that it could serve as "an enlightenment or a model" for China.
"I'm very curious about what the younger generation of Taiwan has been thinking and doing, as this would be a key indicator of the direction in which Taiwan will move," he said.
Liu, who has been jailed several times as a political prisoner since 1989, has never shown any sign of cynicism or resentment, unlike many other persecuted Chinese dissidents.
"I know what I have been doing and what kind of cost I have to pay for that," he told CNA in his small home in Beijing.
On the contrary, he expressed a great deal of tolerance toward the policemen who arrested him under the instructions of the authorities.
"The men who nabbed me would probably be good fathers when they have their uniforms off at home," Liu said.
Liu turned 54 three days after his latest sentence was handed down by a Beijing court, and he and his wife have decided not to have a child -- the only one allowed under China's one-child policy.
"We are not against having a child, but rather we dare not have one, as human rights have never been respected in China nowadays, so we have "a hundred reasons" not to have a child."

Liu was arrested in December last year on the eve of the release of "Charter 08, " a blueprint Liu co-authored with about 300 elite from across all spectrums of Chinese society that calls for an end to the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) dominance of the government, military and courts, protection of freedom of speech and religious beliefs and implementation of constitutional democracy in China.
"Charter 08" is reported to have been seconded by more than 10,000 people so far, many of whom are leading intellectuals in China.

In 1989, Liu cut short a visiting scholar program at Columbia University in the United States and rushed back to Beijing to join the hunger strike staged at Tiananmen Square by students calling for political reform in China, a protest that led to the bloody military crackdown by the authorities, known as the Tiananmen Massacre.
He was then detained at Qincheng Prison near Beijing on charges of "anti- revolution" for his role in the incident.

After his release in January 1991, Liu refused to go into exile and instead chose to stay at home to promote China's democratization. He was jailed again in May 1994 for over six months for his appeals for justice for the 1989 massacre.

In October 1996, Liu was dumped in a labor camp in Talian City in the northeastern Chinese province of Liaoning for three years after he advised a CPC congress session to launch a national anti- corruption drive and to usher in the rule of law.
His insistence on the universal value of human rights and democracy has earned him numerous awards from Human Rights Watch, Reporters without Borders and other international organizations.
His latest sentence triggered outcry from international human rights organizations and Western countries, with the United States pressing Beijing for his immediate release.
Taiwan joined the ranks of the international community Dec. 26, with President Ma Ying-jeou calling on China to demonstrate "the greatest possible tolerance" toward its dissidents.

Human Rights Watch said that since 2003, China has sentenced more than 35 people on charges of inciting subversion of state power to prison terms ranging from 1.5 to 11 years, with Liu being the most severely punished.
This shows that the Chinese government will not tolerate Chinese citizens participating in discussions about their own form of government, the group said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to study improving investment climate for Chinese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 19:40:26 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will convene an inter-ministerial meeting before the end of this year to tap the possibility of further improving Taiwan's investment climate for capital from China, an MOEA official said Sunday.

Vice Economics Minister Huang Chung-chiu said the MOEA will invite officials from the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Education for discussions on whether and how Taiwan's investment climate should be improved or relaxed to facilitate investment made by citizens of China.

The discussions are expected to focus on simplification of entry-exit procedures for Chinese investors and their employees traveling between the two sides, greater education access to Taiwan's schools for the children of such people, and various other matters, Huang said.
The MOEA will also discuss in the first quarter of next year the next wave of opening of Taiwan's business and industrial sectors to capital from China, he added.

Wang Jing, chairwoman of Fujian Newland Group, the first Chinese enterprise to invest in Taiwan, expressed hope at a seminar on Chinese investment in Taiwan that took place in Taichung Dec. 25 that Taiwan will give greater access, such as landing visas, to company employees traveling between the two sides and provide tax incentives for the high-tech industry.

On Wang's suggestions, Huang said it is not viable at present for Taiwan to grant landing visas to businessmen from China and that one-year multiple entry visa will remain the only option for company owners or executives from China, given the existing political and economic reality across the strait.

He noted, however, that restrictions on Taiwanese companies inviting Chinese people to Taiwan for business trips will be relaxed further -- with the requirement that the host companies must have annual business transactions of NT$1 billion or over relaxed to NT$100 million annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait negotiation still an uphill battle

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

The fourth round of Taiwan-China talks concluded last week with three agreements signed amid a series of protests by the opposition and mixed views toward a proposed trade pact that seeks closer bilateral economic relations.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung signed three agreements with Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the fourth round of such talks in the central city of Taichung, where protesters harassed the negotiations all week.

The SEF, the quasi-official organization set up to deal with cross-strait talks, and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's top China policy-making agency, both lauded the talks as "fruitful," saying that the 12 agreements signed and a consensus reached over the past two years will benefit the people of both sides.
The U.S. maintained its long-term policy and cheered from the sidelines, encouraging Taiwan and China to engage in peaceful talks to resolve their differences and reduce tension across the strait.

But that did not stop the opposition and non-believers from staging protests throughout Chen's visit, with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasting the government for non-transparency and failure to respect mainstream public opinion in dealing with bilateral matters.

Twenty meters away from where Chen Yunlin made his farewell speech Dec. 25, a famous quote engraved on a stone wall reads: "The meaning of life is in the birth of new lives that will succeed us in this universe; the goal of living is in the betterment of living conditions of the entire humankind."

The man who said this was Chiang Kai-shek, the generalissimo who lost to the Chinese Communist Party in the Chinese civil war and retreated to Taiwan in 1949, starting 60 years of hostility across the Taiwan Strait.

On Dec. 21, the Chinese negotiator's charter flight touched down at Taichung's Chingchuankang Airport. Coincidentally, the airport, which is now known as Taichung International Airport, got its initial name in dedication to late ROC Army Gen. Chiu Ching-chuan, who killed himself after losing a battle in the civil war.

The contradiction shows how much times have changed since 1949. Once bitter rivals, the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China are now collaborating to boost each other's economic development.
Also on the day of Chen's departure, a Beijing court sentenced dissident Liu Xiaobo to 11 years in prison for campaigning for political freedom by organizing the "Charter 08" petition.

Up until now, Taiwan has only been allowed to participate in a handful of international organizations because of China's interference and there are more than 1,000 missiles deployed in China aimed at Taiwan, still considered a renegade province by China.
But Chen Yunlin said all the right things during his visit.

"Hopefully, the right path for peaceful cross-strait development will be broader in the future, " Chen said in his farewell speech, adding that he appreciated the Taiwan people's "understanding, support and caring."
He also offered to endorse Taichung City, where the talks took place, and Sun Moon Lake, a favorite among Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.

The protesters said they do not oppose better relations with China but fear that closer economic relations will cost them jobs in case of a large influx of Chinese labor and products and a bigger exodus of Taiwanese companies to China.

The government has acknowledged it needs to step up its efforts to explain to the public the positives and negatives of a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , which is on the agenda of the fifth round of talks scheduled for next spring.
It has also reiterated that the whole process of negotiation is transparent and beneficial to Taiwan and that the government will safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty every step of the way.
It is also maintaining its policy of "economy first, politics second" in dealing with China.
However, Kenneth Lin, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, argued that "whatever the issue is (between Taiwan and China), it's always a political one in the end."
It all boils down to one simple question, Lin said -- "Can China be trusted by the people of Taiwan? "
The failed tax agreement also suggests that when it comes to conflict of interest, such as tax revenue, more discussion and negotiation will be needed for both sides to find a solution.
Chiang described the cross-strait exchanges in the past two years as having only "scratched the surface of what we can accomplish in the end" and as being "a long and winding road."

DOC.HEADLINE: Water conservation is major government policy: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:06:33 (By Shou Gow Chen, Kuo Chu Chen, Sz-Ruei Yand and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that water conservation is as important a major government policy as energy conservation and carbon emission reduction.

The premier expressed concern during a tour of southern Taiwan to learn more about the water supply situation that supplies in some areas of southern Taiwan might not be able to keep up with demand after next June.
He said the government will use fee incentives to encourage the public to conserve water, as it has done as part of its electricity conservation efforts.

The premier said the Water Resources Agency has estimated that it can dredge 450,000 cubic meters of accumulated silt from Nanhua and Tsengwen reservoirs next year, but this is just a fraction of the volume that needs to be removed.
"We hope to step up promotion of various measures to ensure the functioning of the reservoirs, " the premier said while inspecting Taiwan Water Corp.'s Nanhua water treatment plant in Tainan County.
Earlier, he said in Pingtung County that the government has mapped out short-, medium- and long-term measures to fight the possible water shortage problem.
He said the immediate measure will be for "every household to conserve water" and the government has also prohibited irrigation on 1,900 hectares of farmland since Dec. 15.

In the long-term, the Executive Yuan has decided to earmark NT$34 billion (US$1.05 billion) to dredge Tsengwen Reservoir, which straddles the border of Chiayi and Tainan counties, and Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan County.
About NT$26 billion will be allocated to remove silt from Tsengwen Reservoir over the next six years, with NT$8 billion to be spent on cleaning Nanhua Reservoir.
Tsengwen Reservoir is Taiwan's largest and has an effective storage capacity of 596 million cubic meters.
Since Typhoon Morakot in August, no rain has fallen in southern Taiwan and the two reservoirs have not collected any more water, exacerbating the threat of water shortages.

Inspecting dredging work being carried out with assistance from the military on one section of Gaoping River, Wu also instructed that monitoring the progress of dredging work should be made a priority.
He also noted that the sediment at the Paolai section of the river in Kaohsiung County is now nearly at bridge height and that this section should be given first priority in dredging.
In Kaohsiung County, Wu toured construction sites for permanent housing units beside Shanlin Junior High School for the settlement of flood-affected victims.
He expressed the hope that the first batch of 600 units can be completed by Jan. 31 so that the flood victims can move in before the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poor air quality in southern Taiwan: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:07:57 (By Liu kwang-yin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The impact of a sandstorm sweeping in from China on Taiwan's air quality has subsided and air quality has gradually returned to normal, although the quality in southern Taiwan is still not ideal, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday.
The EPA said in a press release that this is due to wind speed weakening in southern Taiwan, making conditions less than ideal for the dispersal of airborne suspended particles.

The latest data on air quality showed that the concentration of suspended particles in northern Taiwan had dropped to below 100 micrograms per cubic meter, with around 150 micrograms per cubic meter in southern Taiwan.
The EPA said that the sandstorm in northern China Dec. 24 mainly affected South Korea and Japan and that Taiwan was affected to a far lesser extent.
The air quality in northern Taiwan and in the southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung was poor Saturday, while the effect on eastern Taiwan was milder.
Suspended particles on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, however, came close to 300 micrograms per cubic meter, showing a more marked effect.
The EPA noted Chinese sandstorms often affect Taiwan in the winter and spring and that they are most frequent in March and April.
The EPA tracks and forecasts Chinese sandstorms between November and the following May every year and publishes the data on its Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake gondola system to open
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:17:17 (By Lin Heng-li)

TEXT.P: A cable car system that will provide an aerial link between two popular tourist destinations in central Taiwan -- Sun Moon Lake and the nearby Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village amusement park -- will open to the public Dec. 28, the amusement park administration said Sunday.
The 1.87 km system takes 7-10 minutes to travel between the two scenic sites, located 10 km from each other by road, according to the administration.

The system linking the lake's Ita Shao Dock and the private amusement park is expected to promote local tourism because it will give tourists a bird's eye view of the scenic lake area and the Puli basin.
It was constructed by the park under a build-own-operate model, with the work taking 18 months and passed Nantou county government inspections Dec. 24.
Between Monday to Jan. 3, the amusement park will treat residents of the central county's Yuchih township free cable car rides and free admission to the park.
Before its official opening March 31, regular ticket prices will be NT$250, with prices for groups of over 20 or more set at NT$225.
After its official launch, regular ticket prices will be NT$300, concessionary prices will be NT$250, and prices for groups of 20 or more will be NT$270.
The system will operate between 10: 30 a.m. and 4 p.m. weekdays and between 10:30 a.m. and 5 p.m. on holidays.
The 86-car system, which passes through a valley that is 786 meters wide at its widest point and 200 meters deep, will be able to transport up to 3,000 passengers per hour, the administration said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature suggests local disaster prevention alliances
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 17:36:03 (By Kelven Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has taken stock of the experience of Japan in disaster prevention and has suggested the formation of local disaster relief alliances to provide quick rescue at the first strike of a disaster.

The legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Bureau noted that Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in southern Taiwan in August with the most serious precipitation in nearly half a century, exposed the deficiencies of Taiwan's disaster relief mechanism.
As a result, bureau officials went on a tour of Japan to learn about that country's experience in disaster prevention and response.

The officials said they found Japan has shifted its focus to software and management from its past concentration on hardware development, and that disaster prevention orchestrated by the central government has also switched to joint cooperation between local residents and the administration to mitigate the impact of disasters.
The Japanese government attaches great importance to disaster simulation drills, and cities and prefectures form alliances to conduct such drills regularly.
Residents are taught that when disaster strikes, they should first seek self- relief or take shelter to mitigate casualties and then wait for government rescue and relief.

The bureau also suggested that ministries, commissions and bureaus should send their officials to work regularly at the Central Disaster Prevention and Response Council to enhance inter-agency coordination.

A special commission should also be set up to conduct investigations after each major disaster and announce the results. This would establish a mechanism to pass on management and experience in disaster response.

In an evaluation report on the draft amendment on Disaster Prevention and Response Act, the bureau pointed out that the deficiencies in Taiwan's disaster prevention and response system include the lack of a joint disaster response plan, incomplete disaster information, the lack of on-site command system and insufficient use and management of available resources.

The bureau noted that Typhoon Morakot also highlighted the "inappropriate concept and approach" in flood prevention, lack of a land safety and conservation plan, a faulty command system in the central and local disaster response centers and rigid procedure and slow response in providing military support to rescue operations, as well as a lack of regular drills.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Opaque and hasty policy-making
DOC.DATELINE: Su Chi, secretary-general of the National Security Council (NSC) 12/27/09 18:23:17 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: , has warned of the risks of retaliatory measures by the United States if the legislature amends a law to bar possibly unsafe U.S. beef products from being imported into Taiwan, as such a move will violate the Taiwan-U.S. protocol.
This lose-lose situation could have been prevented if Taiwan had not signed any deal with the U.S. Without the protocol, the U.S. would have little reason for any retaliatory action.

This is the result of the government's secret and hasty decision-making process. Similar incidents have repeatedly occurred in the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou over the past year in the areas of oil price hikes, infrastructure projects, shopping vouchers, tax reductions, the avoidance of double taxation with China and the merger of local counties and cities into special municipalities.

An open process gives people an opportunity to voice their concerns, which makes the outcome of a decision more acceptable to the public. A transparent process also allows experts to review the facts and theories adopted in proposed policies, which could avoid possible shortcomings.

The government should replace those decision makers with people who respect public opinion and who are more willing to face criticism. The government should also assure the public that sufficient time and open discussions will be allowed before decisions are made.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Second thoughts on new institute

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs should have second thoughts on a proposal to set up a new national research institute on the cultural and creative industries.

The council is reported to have come up with the proposal at the suggestion of an opposition legislator who took her cue from the phenomenal success of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in helping spur the development of Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) industry.

As industrial intellectual property tends to originate in laboratories, they have to undergo a period of incubation to evolve into commercial products, a need that necessitates the establishment of ITRI.

The ITRI has long played the role of an incubator in the development of Taiwan's high-tech industry. It has helped test the maturity of new technology, explored its market acceptance and raised money for start-up companies to venture into potential markets. Only when the time is mature does the ITRI-formed start-up companies spin off to become independent corporations.

Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) -- the world's largest contract computer chip foundry -- is a typical example of the ITRI's incubating mission. TSMC Chairman Morris Chang helped incubate semiconductor technologies during his tenure as ITRI president and his company is an ITRI spin-off.

As the cultural and creative industries mostly do not involve any abstractive technologies developed in laboratories, the need to set up an ITRI-like institute to help with the sector's development is questionable.

Culture refers not to experiments in laboratories but rather to concrete developments in daily life and social activity. If there are indeed some ICT- related cultural or creative products, the government just needs to commission the ITRI's information technology institute to form a task force to help with digitization of relevant products.

Taiwan really has to accelerate its cultural and creative industry development, but the focus should be on marketing rather than setting up a huge institute just for incubation purposes. The government should employ competent officials with marketing expertise to carry out relevant projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fewer children immunized over vaccine doubts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 18:34:43 (By Chen Li-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A fatality allegedly due to an inoculation against influenza A(H1N1) involving a 7-year-old in Taichung has caused panic among parents in Taiwan leading to a sharp decline in the number of school children receiving H1N1 immunization over the past week.

Pediatricians at major medical institutions confirmed Sunday that the number of school children receiving H1N1 vaccine shots has declined sharply over the past week, primarily due to concerns over the safety of the vaccine after the 7-year- old boy died several weeks after being immunized.
The doctors, however, still recommended that parents should get their children immunized because the benefits far outweigh the risks.

Huang Li-min, head of the Pediatrics Department of National Taiwan University Hospital, also noted that the immunization effect will be limited if the child receives only one shot rather than the recommended two.
"The young vaccine recipient will become fully protected against the H1N1 virus only after receiving two shots," Huang said.

Meanwhile, Lin Hsiu-chen, a pediatrician with Taipei Medical University Hospital, estimated that the number of school children receiving H1N1 inoculations was down by some 30 percent compared to the number when the nationwide vaccination campaign was launched Nov. 1.
Lin said she will persuade parents to have their young children vaccinated, although she admitted she could not force them to do so.
"The decision is for the parents to make," Lin noted.
Meanwhile, the Ministry of Education said Sunday it will respect the decisions of parents on whether their children will receive H1N1 vaccine shots or not.

Lee Ping-ing, another pediatrician with National Taiwan University Hospital, attributed the decline in the number of people being immunized to the fact that the number of new H1N1 cases has dropped significantly since the vaccination campaign was launched, while several hundred cases complaining about side effects after being immunized have given rise to doubts about the safety of the vaccine.

Lee, who doubles as secretary-general of the Taiwan Immunization Vision and Strategy Alliance, said that some people have become disenchanted with the vaccination drive and prefer to take medicine such as Tamiflu upon falling victim to the H1N1 virus.

These non-vaccinated people will be at highest risk of the next wave of swine flu, which could be more deadly because the virus might have mutated, Lee predicted, noting that judging from the seasonal flu epidemic outbreaks of the past, there are usually two or three big outbreaks in one epidemic.

Citing U.S. research that found the swine flu virus invades deep into the lungs, Lee warned the public not to take the virus lightly, adding that they also should not harbor the idea that they need not to be vaccinated if others are instead.
"Only those children who are allergic to eggs or those who have developed allergy symptoms after receiving seasonal flu vaccine should forego vaccination," he said.
H1N1 inoculation is safe for almost all children, even if they have nasitis, asthma or dermatitis, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Slang against Chinese envoy stirs up local political discussion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 18:59:33 (By Chris Wang)

Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih told reporters that "the use of the expression probably needs more contemplation, " while Soong said the statement would "have a negative impact on cross-strait relations."

Responding to reporters' questions, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Hsin-yuan said that "there is no such thing as A-list or C-list in cross- strait exchanges because the people are the most important factor."

"We are not against having a child, but rather we dare not have one, as human rights have never been respected in China nowadays, so we have "a hundred reasons" not to have a child."

Liu was arrested in December last year on the eve of the release of "Charter 08, " a blueprint Liu co-authored with about 300 elite from across all spectrums of Chinese society that calls for an end to the Communist Party of China's (CPC's) dominance of the government, military and courts, protection of freedom of speech and religious beliefs and implementation of constitutional democracy in China.
"Charter 08" is reported to have been seconded by more than 10,000 people so far, many of whom are leading intellectuals in China.

In 1989, Liu cut short a visiting scholar program at Columbia University in the United States and rushed back to Beijing to join the hunger strike staged at Tiananmen Square by students calling for political reform in China, a protest that led to the bloody military crackdown by the authorities, known as the Tiananmen Massacre.
He was then detained at Qincheng Prison near Beijing on charges of "anti- revolution" for his role in the incident.

After his release in January 1991, Liu refused to go into exile and instead chose to stay at home to promote China's democratization. He was jailed again in May 1994 for over six months for his appeals for justice for the 1989 massacre.

In October 1996, Liu was dumped in a labor camp in Talian City in the northeastern Chinese province of Liaoning for three years after he advised a CPC congress session to launch a national anti- corruption drive and to usher in the rule of law.
His insistence on the universal value of human rights and democracy has earned him numerous awards from Human Rights Watch, Reporters without Borders and other international organizations.
His latest sentence triggered outcry from international human rights organizations and Western countries, with the United States pressing Beijing for his immediate release.
Taiwan joined the ranks of the international community Dec. 26, with President Ma Ying-jeou calling on China to demonstrate "the greatest possible tolerance" toward its dissidents.

Human Rights Watch said that since 2003, China has sentenced more than 35 people on charges of inciting subversion of state power to prison terms ranging from 1.5 to 11 years, with Liu being the most severely punished.
This shows that the Chinese government will not tolerate Chinese citizens participating in discussions about their own form of government, the group said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to study improving investment climate for Chinese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 19:40:26 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will convene an inter-ministerial meeting before the end of this year to tap the possibility of further improving Taiwan's investment climate for capital from China, an MOEA official said Sunday.

Vice Economics Minister Huang Chung-chiu said the MOEA will invite officials from the Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of Education for discussions on whether and how Taiwan's investment climate should be improved or relaxed to facilitate investment made by citizens of China.

The discussions are expected to focus on simplification of entry-exit procedures for Chinese investors and their employees traveling between the two sides, greater education access to Taiwan's schools for the children of such people, and various other matters, Huang said.
The MOEA will also discuss in the first quarter of next year the next wave of opening of Taiwan's business and industrial sectors to capital from China, he added.

Wang Jing, chairwoman of Fujian Newland Group, the first Chinese enterprise to invest in Taiwan, expressed hope at a seminar on Chinese investment in Taiwan that took place in Taichung Dec. 25 that Taiwan will give greater access, such as landing visas, to company employees traveling between the two sides and provide tax incentives for the high-tech industry.

On Wang's suggestions, Huang said it is not viable at present for Taiwan to grant landing visas to businessmen from China and that one-year multiple entry visa will remain the only option for company owners or executives from China, given the existing political and economic reality across the strait.

He noted, however, that restrictions on Taiwanese companies inviting Chinese people to Taiwan for business trips will be relaxed further -- with the requirement that the host companies must have annual business transactions of NT$1 billion or over relaxed to NT$100 million annually.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait negotiation still an uphill battle

TEXT.P: CNA Staff Reporter

The fourth round of Taiwan-China talks concluded last week with three agreements signed amid a series of protests by the opposition and mixed views toward a proposed trade pact that seeks closer bilateral economic relations.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung signed three agreements with Chen Yunlin, president of China's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) , in the fourth round of such talks in the central city of Taichung, where protesters harassed the negotiations all week.

The SEF, the quasi-official organization set up to deal with cross-strait talks, and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taiwan's top China policy-making agency, both lauded the talks as "fruitful," saying that the 12 agreements signed and a consensus reached over the past two years will benefit the people of both sides.
The U.S. maintained its long-term policy and cheered from the sidelines, encouraging Taiwan and China to engage in peaceful talks to resolve their differences and reduce tension across the strait.

But that did not stop the opposition and non-believers from staging protests throughout Chen's visit, with the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) blasting the government for non-transparency and failure to respect mainstream public opinion in dealing with bilateral matters.

Twenty meters away from where Chen Yunlin made his farewell speech Dec. 25, a famous quote engraved on a stone wall reads: "The meaning of life is in the birth of new lives that will succeed us in this universe; the goal of living is in the betterment of living conditions of the entire humankind."

The man who said this was Chiang Kai-shek, the generalissimo who lost to the Chinese Communist Party in the Chinese civil war and retreated to Taiwan in 1949, starting 60 years of hostility across the Taiwan Strait.

On Dec. 21, the Chinese negotiator's charter flight touched down at Taichung's Chingchuankang Airport. Coincidentally, the airport, which is now known as Taichung International Airport, got its initial name in dedication to late ROC Army Gen. Chiu Ching-chuan, who killed himself after losing a battle in the civil war.

The contradiction shows how much times have changed since 1949. Once bitter rivals, the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China are now collaborating to boost each other's economic development.
Also on the day of Chen's departure, a Beijing court sentenced dissident Liu Xiaobo to 11 years in prison for campaigning for political freedom by organizing the "Charter 08" petition.

Up until now, Taiwan has only been allowed to participate in a handful of international organizations because of China's interference and there are more than 1,000 missiles deployed in China aimed at Taiwan, still considered a renegade province by China.
But Chen Yunlin said all the right things during his visit.

"Hopefully, the right path for peaceful cross-strait development will be broader in the future, " Chen said in his farewell speech, adding that he appreciated the Taiwan people's "understanding, support and caring."
He also offered to endorse Taichung City, where the talks took place, and Sun Moon Lake, a favorite among Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.

The protesters said they do not oppose better relations with China but fear that closer economic relations will cost them jobs in case of a large influx of Chinese labor and products and a bigger exodus of Taiwanese companies to China.

The government has acknowledged it needs to step up its efforts to explain to the public the positives and negatives of a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , which is on the agenda of the fifth round of talks scheduled for next spring.
It has also reiterated that the whole process of negotiation is transparent and beneficial to Taiwan and that the government will safeguard Taiwan's sovereignty every step of the way.
It is also maintaining its policy of "economy first, politics second" in dealing with China.
However, Kenneth Lin, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, argued that "whatever the issue is (between Taiwan and China), it's always a political one in the end."
It all boils down to one simple question, Lin said -- "Can China be trusted by the people of Taiwan? "
The failed tax agreement also suggests that when it comes to conflict of interest, such as tax revenue, more discussion and negotiation will be needed for both sides to find a solution.
Chiang described the cross-strait exchanges in the past two years as having only "scratched the surface of what we can accomplish in the end" and as being "a long and winding road."

DOC.HEADLINE: Water conservation is major government policy: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:06:33 (By Shou Gow Chen, Kuo Chu Chen, Sz-Ruei Yand and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that water conservation is as important a major government policy as energy conservation and carbon emission reduction.

The premier expressed concern during a tour of southern Taiwan to learn more about the water supply situation that supplies in some areas of southern Taiwan might not be able to keep up with demand after next June.
He said the government will use fee incentives to encourage the public to conserve water, as it has done as part of its electricity conservation efforts.

The premier said the Water Resources Agency has estimated that it can dredge 450,000 cubic meters of accumulated silt from Nanhua and Tsengwen reservoirs next year, but this is just a fraction of the volume that needs to be removed.
"We hope to step up promotion of various measures to ensure the functioning of the reservoirs, " the premier said while inspecting Taiwan Water Corp.'s Nanhua water treatment plant in Tainan County.
Earlier, he said in Pingtung County that the government has mapped out short-, medium- and long-term measures to fight the possible water shortage problem.
He said the immediate measure will be for "every household to conserve water" and the government has also prohibited irrigation on 1,900 hectares of farmland since Dec. 15.

In the long-term, the Executive Yuan has decided to earmark NT$34 billion (US$1.05 billion) to dredge Tsengwen Reservoir, which straddles the border of Chiayi and Tainan counties, and Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan County.
About NT$26 billion will be allocated to remove silt from Tsengwen Reservoir over the next six years, with NT$8 billion to be spent on cleaning Nanhua Reservoir.
Tsengwen Reservoir is Taiwan's largest and has an effective storage capacity of 596 million cubic meters.
Since Typhoon Morakot in August, no rain has fallen in southern Taiwan and the two reservoirs have not collected any more water, exacerbating the threat of water shortages.

Inspecting dredging work being carried out with assistance from the military on one section of Gaoping River, Wu also instructed that monitoring the progress of dredging work should be made a priority.
He also noted that the sediment at the Paolai section of the river in Kaohsiung County is now nearly at bridge height and that this section should be given first priority in dredging.
In Kaohsiung County, Wu toured construction sites for permanent housing units beside Shanlin Junior High School for the settlement of flood-affected victims.
He expressed the hope that the first batch of 600 units can be completed by Jan. 31 so that the flood victims can move in before the Chinese New Year, which falls on Feb. 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poor air quality in southern Taiwan: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:07:57 (By Liu kwang-yin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The impact of a sandstorm sweeping in from China on Taiwan's air quality has subsided and air quality has gradually returned to normal, although the quality in southern Taiwan is still not ideal, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Sunday.
The EPA said in a press release that this is due to wind speed weakening in southern Taiwan, making conditions less than ideal for the dispersal of airborne suspended particles.

The latest data on air quality showed that the concentration of suspended particles in northern Taiwan had dropped to below 100 micrograms per cubic meter, with around 150 micrograms per cubic meter in southern Taiwan.
The EPA said that the sandstorm in northern China Dec. 24 mainly affected South Korea and Japan and that Taiwan was affected to a far lesser extent.
The air quality in northern Taiwan and in the southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung was poor Saturday, while the effect on eastern Taiwan was milder.
Suspended particles on the outlying islands of Kinmen and Matsu, however, came close to 300 micrograms per cubic meter, showing a more marked effect.
The EPA noted Chinese sandstorms often affect Taiwan in the winter and spring and that they are most frequent in March and April.
The EPA tracks and forecasts Chinese sandstorms between November and the following May every year and publishes the data on its Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sun Moon Lake gondola system to open
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 27 (CNA) 12/27/09 20:17:17 (By Lin Heng-li)

TEXT.P: A cable car system that will provide an aerial link between two popular tourist destinations in central Taiwan -- Sun Moon Lake and the nearby Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village amusement park -- will open to the public Dec. 28, the amusement park administration said Sunday.
The 1.87 km system takes 7-10 minutes to travel between the two scenic sites, located 10 km from each other by road, according to the administration.

The system linking the lake's Ita Shao Dock and the private amusement park is expected to promote local tourism because it will give tourists a bird's eye view of the scenic lake area and the Puli basin.
It was constructed by the park under a build-own-operate model, with the work taking 18 months and passed Nantou county government inspections Dec. 24.
Between Monday to Jan. 3, the amusement park will treat residents of the central county's Yuchih township free cable car rides and free admission to the park.
Before its official opening March 31, regular ticket prices will be NT$250, with prices for groups of over 20 or more set at NT$225.
After its official launch, regular ticket prices will be NT$300, concessionary prices will be NT$250, and prices for groups of 20 or more will be NT$270.
The system will operate between 10: 30 a.m. and 4 p.m. weekdays and between 10:30 a.m. and 5 p.m. on holidays.
The 86-car system, which passes through a valley that is 786 meters wide at its widest point and 200 meters deep, will be able to transport up to 3,000 passengers per hour, the administration said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, Dec. 28, or the 13th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1836: Spain recognizes Mexico's independence.
1856: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, American statesman and Democratic president (1913-21), is born.
1881: China's first telegraph line linking Tientsin and Shanghai is made available for public use.
1908: The most violent earthquake ever recorded in Europe destroys the city of Messina in Sicily, killing more than half of its 150,000 inhabitants and causing a giant tidal wave.
1912: City-run streetcars in San Francisco, California, begin operating.
1919: Feng Kuo-chang, a warlord who led the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang army during the first decade of the Republic of China, dies in Peking (Beijing) at the age of 62.
1923: Alexandre Gustave Eiffel, the French engineer who designed the 300-meter- high Eiffel Tower for the Paris Exhibition of 1889, dies at the age of 91.
1931: The ROC government is reformed, with Lin Sen made chairman.
1945: The Big Three Foreign Ministers' Conference in Moscow announces agreements on the establishment of a Commission and Allied Council for Japan, the ultimate establishment of a free Korea, and the withdrawal of Soviet and U.S. troops from China.
1950: Mainland Chinese troops cross the 38th parallel in Korea.
1962: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs declares that the border agreements signed between the Beijing regime and Outer Mongolia and Pakistan are illegal and non- binding for the Republic of China.
1966: Mainland China detonates its fifth atomic bomb.
1968: The ROC opens a telecommunications satellite earth station on Yangmingshan.
1971: Grand Justice Tien Chun-chin is appointed as president of the ROC's Judicial Yuan.
1972: The Republic of China's Embassy in Tokyo and the consulates-general in Osaka, Yokohama and Fukuoka are formally closed.
1974: The Republic of China-Bahamas Cultural and Economic Association is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Gambia following the latter's recognition of the Peiping (Beijing) regime.
1976: The millionth visitor of the year to the Republic of China, Wilhelm Mulmann, professor of sociology and anthropology at the University of Heidleberg, Germany, and his wife are welcomed by officials of the Tourism Bureau.
1976: Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang presents a gold medal and citation to Yen Tjing-ling, board chairman of the Yue Loong Motors Co. Ltd., for his contribution to an industrial research center at National Taiwan University.
1987: The Development Bank of Shenzhen, the first private share-holding bank on the Chinese mainland, is inaugurated.
1988: The first instance of a baby born with Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS) in Taiwan is recorded.
1993: A plane belonging to mainland China's Fujian Airlines is hijacked to Taiwan by Luo Chang-hua and his wife Wang Yu-ying in the 10th hijacking of the year.
1995: In Beijing, judges reject an appeal by dissident Wei Jingsheng, upholding his 14-year sentence on charges of trying to overthrow the Beijing government.
1995: Beijing names the committee responsible for steering Hong Kong through its transition from British colony to Chinese Special Administration Region in 1997.
1999: Taiwan changes the name of its representative office in Macau from Taipei Economic and Cultural Office to Taipei Economic and Cultural Center, Macau.
2000: The Formosa Plastics Group presents its first sedan -- the Formosa Magnus 2.0 -- which was manufactured via technical cooperation with South Korea's Daewoo Group.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Possession of power without generosity; courtesy without seriousness; mourning without grief -- I have no desire to look at such a state of things."
