DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- Trade relaxation

TEXT.P: The question of whether Taiwan should further open up to cross-Taiwan Strait investment flows has been of major concern in local society. With the Ministry of Economic Affairs expected to conditionally allow flat panel and semiconductor industries to invest in China, some analysts have warned that further liberalization could freeze Taiwan's GDP growth.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the proposed opening:
United Daily News:
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will convene an inter-ministerial meeting this week to explore the possibility of further lifting restrictions on China-bound Taiwanese high-tech investment.
The discussions are expected to focus on lifting restrictions on manufacturers of large TFT-LCD display panels, semiconductor testing and packing technology, as well as IC design.
If everything goes according to plan, the opening will be announced before the end of the year, MOEA officials said.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said it is urgent for Taiwan's flat panel makers to secure a foothold in China before massive expansion of the TFT- LCD display market there over the next three to five years.
"It would be too late for Taiwan manufacturers to edge into the huge market if the opening is not approved soon," Shih said.
Commercial Times:
The opening policy is not expected to be announced by the MOEA until January at the earliest.

The MOEA is likely to give a green light mainly to flat panel manufacturing and semiconductor testing and packing technology, on the principle that high-end technologies should remain in Taiwan and only earlier generation technologies should be allowed to head to China.

Based on the Wassenaar Arrangement, the restrictions on the establishment of eight-inch silicon wafer foundries in China using Taiwan's 0.18-micron process technology will be lifted across the board, while investment plans involving technology more advanced than 0.18-micron would be screened on a case-by-case basis, MOEA officials said. (Dec. 28, 2009)
Liberty Times:
Ma Ying-jeou administration's swift deregulation of Taiwan's hi-tech industry to allow investors to head west to China will imperil the country's nascent economic recovery.

In the face of high unemployment rate, dwindling wages and shrinking tax revenues at home, the government's imminent lifting of restrictions on investments in China by Taiwanese hi-tech manufacturers is triggering a new wave of capital exodus and will cause a "sudden freeze" in the domestic economy. (Dec. 28, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the Day -- News digest of local media -- National debt
DOC.DATELINE: 12/28/09 11:40:08 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As Taiwan's public debt approaches an alarming NT$2 trillion (US$62 billion) , some economic scholars have suggested that the government install an early warning system, similar to the odometer-style "debt clock" put up near Times Square in 1989, to prevent the national debt from escalating too fast.
The following is a digest of some local media reports on the issue:
United Daily News:
The total debt incurred by the central and local governments has increased to around NT$450 billion this year, which has pushed the accumulated national debt close to the NT$2 trillion mark.

Lee Yun-jie, a professor at National Open University's Department of Public Affairs, suggested that the debt ceiling must be lowered when the economy is booming but the nation's financial state is deteriorating.

Lee also suggested the central government establish a three-color national debt rating system based on six national financial indices that include the national debt growth rate, the ratio of governmental budget deficits to the gross domestic product (GDP) , the ratio of special budgets to GDP, and the ratio of government debt spending to its total spending in a year.

Under such a system, a "red" light would suggest deterioration of the debt situation, a "yellow" light would reflect a balanced financial state and a "blue" light would signal a sound and stable financial situation, Lee suggested. (Dec. 28, 2009)
Economic Daily News:

Commenting on the increase of the government debt this year to about NT$450 billion -- the highest in nearly five years -- ranking Ministry of Finance officials explained that it was the result of the government's efforts to help stimulate the economy during the global downturn.

Now that the economy is recovering, efforts will be made to reduce the national debt, the officials said. The government will consider raising taxes at an appropriate time to help improve the country's finances, they added.

The proposed tax measures will include raising property taxes and introducing a luxury tax, the officials said, but stressed that the increases will not be carried out without public consensus. (Dec. 28, 2009)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Taiwan is sovereign state owned by the people

TEXT.P: Amid protests, the fourth-round of cross-strait talks ended without a double taxation agreement or any substantial discussion on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
It is obvious that these issues have been deferred to the next round of talks in China when a closed-door deal will be sealed and the Taiwanese people will not be able to stage protests.
What is even more worrying is the Ma administration's servile attitude toward China, and the attempt to achieve the goal of ultimate unification under the guise of cross-strait negotiations.
Ma's advocacy of unification runs counter to historical facts and his presidential mandate and has turned him into a national traitor.
Qing Dynasty Emperor Yongzheng once said that Taiwan had not belonged to China since in ancient times, which is evidence of Taiwan's independence from China.

Former President Lee Teng-hui's rule was a milestone in Taiwan's historical development. Before him, Taiwan was dominated by the alien forces of the Netherlands, Spain, Ming Dynasty loyalist Koxinga, the Qing Dynasty, Japan and Chiang Kai-shek.
But after Lee's push for localization and democratization, Taiwan became a sovereign, independent country.

Taiwan's only connection with China was after the Qing Dynasty's annexation of the island, but it ceded Taiwan to Japan in 1895 after China's defeat. Japan, after its own defeat in World War II, surrendered its sovereignty over Taiwan and Penghu, but did not specify in the San Francisco Peace Treaty to whom they should belong. Chiang established a government in exile in Taiwan after his forces were annihilated by the Communists in a civil war in China in 1949.

Since the presidential election by popular vote in Taiwan in 1996, Taiwan has become a completely democratized and localized country in accordance with the international norm of residents deciding their own fate.
Ma as an elected president should uphold the independent sovereignty of the nation. If he insists on pushing for ultimate unification, he will surely be attacked and rejected by the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's economic activities heat up: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 12:26:52 (By Erin Ho and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The overall monitoring indicator for Taiwan's economic climate in November was expected to flash a "yellow-red" light, marking the first time in 25 months that the country's economic activities are seen heating up, according to a preliminary report by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planing and Development (CEPD).

In addition, thanks to the global recovery, the total score of monitoring indicators for November was likely to rise to the highest level in more than five years and come close to the bottom line for a "red" light that would signal overheating, CEPD officials said on Monday.
The overall economic monitoring indicator flashed a "green" light in October, a sign of stable economic growth.
The CEPD is scheduled to publicize detailed statistics on Taiwan's economic performance in November later Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister remains tight-lipped on investment deregulation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 13:13:22 (By P.C. Tang, Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang remained tight-lipped Monday on whether the government would lift restrictions on China-bound Taiwanese hi-tech investment.

On media reports the day before that the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will conditionally allow TFT-LCD display panel makers and semiconductor industries to widen investment in China, Shih said it is inappropriate for him to make any disclosure before the plan is finalized and approved by the Executive Yuan.
The minister, however, gave the assurance that the MOEA has proposed only liberalization measures that will be beneficial to Taiwan's long-term economic development.
"All factors, including Taiwan's priorities, globalization strategy, domestic employment and wage structures, were studied meticulously before the liberalization plan was proposed," he noted.

MOEA officials was quoted as reporting Sunday that restrictions on manufacturing operations of large TFT-LCD display panels are expected to be lifted, but the measure will exclude top technologies owned by specific companies, such as the 10th-generation TFT-LCD display manufacturing technology of AU Optronics Corp., one of the leading flat panel manufacturers in Taiwan.

The restrictions on the establishment of eight-inch silicon wafer foundries in China using Taiwan's 0.18-micron process technology will be lifted across the board, but investments in more advanced technology at the 0.13-micron level and above will still be banned, MOEA officials said.

Other major aspects of the deregulation package include semiconductor testing and packing technology, naphtha cracking plants, semiconductor IC design and infrastructure development projects, according to the MOEA.

According to the Liberty Times Monday, the Ma Ying-jeou administration's swift deregulation of Taiwan's hi-tech industry to allow Taiwanese companies to head west to China will imperil the country's nascent economic recovery.

In the face of a high unemployment rate, dwindling wages and shrinking tax revenues at home, the government's imminent lifting of restrictions on investments in China by Taiwanese hi-tech manufacturers is triggering a new wave of capital exodus and will cause a "sudden freeze" in the domestic economy, the daily said.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Move to south

TEXT.P: The sixth round of high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks, known locally as "Chiang-Chen meetings, " should be held either in Tainan, Kaohsiung or Pingtung. Whichever one is chosen, the meeting should take place in southern Taiwan.

Based on precedent and the rotating host principle, the sixth Chiang-Chen meeting should be convened in Taiwan late next year, sometime after the elections for mayors of the five special municipalities.

Judging from the current trend, we believe Taiwan's political map will remain practically unchanged after the municipality mayoral elections, with all southern cities and counties still under the control of the opposition pro- independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

By that time, the controversial cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) should have been signed at the fifth Chiang-Chen meeting which is scheduled be held in China in the first half of next year.
Without such a contentious issue on the agenda, it should pose no special problem for any of the DPP-controlled local governments in the south to host the Chiang-Chen meeting.
Most important, it would inspire the DPP to temper its hostility toward China and ultimately lead to a change of attitude by the DPP-led pan-green camp.

When the Chiang-Chen meeting took place in Taipei in late 2008 for the first time, more than 200 police officers and ordinary citizens were injured in violent street protests against top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin's visit, but only one policeman was injured during Chen's just-concluded second visit. This is an indication that violence is no longer acceptable to local mainstream society.

The image of DPP mayors or magistrates taking turns to fete Chen Yunlin could be yet another amazing development in cross-strait relations. The DPP would then be able to deal with such thorny issues such its aim of "building a Taiwan republic" as stated in its party charter, a goal that for years has kept centrist and swing voters away from the party and will hinder its return to power.
As Taiwan's main opposition force, the DPP should stop its anti-China and anti- globalization closed-door policies because they offer no way out for Taiwan and the DPP itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Mistaking A for B

TEXT.P: The Tax Reform Committee under the Executive Yuan recently indicated that it would not introduce any reforms involving stock income tax in the short term. It is clear that even if the government decides to reintroduce stock income tax for enterprises, it will maintain the exemption for individuals.
Even though we did not have any great expectations of the committee, we still deeply regret such a decision.
We know of course the sensitivity of the issue, but if the society is to progress, faulty systems have to be fixed.

Deciding against stock income tax will not only result in annual tax revenue losses of nearly NT$40 billion, but will also lead to unequitable taxation, encourage tax evasions and eventually widen the gap in the distribution of social resources and cripple the tax system.
Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said recently that the public does not full understand the issue, noting that the stock transaction tax actually includes stock income tax.

This is not correct. Stock income tax and stock transaction tax are two different types of taxes, with the former targeting transactions and the latter relating to profits made from the sale of stocks.

The stock transaction tax will add costs to transactions, which means that if the tax rate is too high, it will hamper transactions, while stock income tax will cut into gains. Looking back on the nation's taxation history, we find that both taxes were imposed on and off, but there is no record of one substituting for the other.
We are totally disappointed in the Tax Reform Committee, and we think it should not attempt to use a foul pretext to cover its inability to institute reforms.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: MOJ should review its interpretation

TEXT.P: Prosecutors recently concluded their probe into the controversial financial reforms introduced by former president Chen Shui-bian and indicted him, his wife, five family members, and 15 other people.

But the prosecutors have faced harsh criticism because the indictments have been limited to only a few people, and especially because most of the investigations have been closed on the grounds that "bribery is not in violation of their duties."

Considering the fact that the prosecutors lightly dismissed such a serious matter as selling national property below cost in the name of financial reforms, we would like to point out what is a financial merger and what is a violation of one's duty.

State-controlled banks are the nation's cash cows, bringing in steady revenues to the national coffers. If the state decides to sell a bank, it is usually mainly for the purpose of making as much money as possible for the state coffers.
Therefore, if the Ministry of Finance (MOF) decides to sell a bank, it will sell to the highest bidder or the most appropriate bidder.

For example, if A bids NT$100 billion, while B bids only NT$30 billion, and the MOF decides to sell to B, it would mean a loss of NT$70 billion in revenue. Does that not constitute violating one's duty as a civil servant?

We believe that those civil servants involved should be pursued by the law and those who paid the bribes should also be penalized because they tried to get the civil servants to award them operation rights, in violation of national interests.

We want to ask Justice Minister Wang Ching-feng and prosecutors to address the seriously flawed interpretation of the law, which we believe will not be accepted by the majority of Taiwanese and is a rationalization of bribery at the government's discretion.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Reactivate financial reform

TEXT.P: Prosecution authorities have finally completed probes into suspected irregularities involving the second round of financial reforms, with former President Chen Shui-bian indicted over bribe-taking and money laundering.
Senior executives and major shareholders of several financial holding companies were also indicted for helping with Chen's money laundering.
The indictments have again highlighted the need to address the aftermath of the botched second round of financial reforms and have rekindled concern as to when financial reforms will re-start.

The focus of financial reforms tends to shift with the times and changing market developments. Taiwan's first round of financial reforms focused on cleaning up bad debts in the banking system and mapping out exit rules for poorly managed banks, while the second round concentrated on the privatization of state-owned banks and augmentation of financial institutions.

Although the direction of the second round of financial reforms was correct, it was mismanaged. The government should not stop banking reforms using the excuse of illegal dealings involved in the reforms and should instead reaffirm its determination to reactivate reform by grappling with the issues left by the earlier failed reforms.

In dealing with the aftermath, the Financial Supervisory Commission should factor in both legal provisions and practical reality in drafting solution packages on a case-by-case basis in order to maintain financial stability while upholding rule of law and the principles of fairness and justice.

For instance, the commission should refer to existing regulations and insist that banking institutions review the qualifications of their heads and major shareholders in terms of "fit and proper" principles.

In line with existing bank spin-off and investment laws, the commission can also ask banking institutions that have failed to acquire controlling shares of other banks within the legal deadlines to sell off their stakes in those banks.

Meanwhile, the government should accelerate reform steps, including capital increment, improving merger and acquisition regulations, consistency in releasing government stakes in local banks and management supervision.

The government should also review whether its control of over 40 percent of the stakes in many local banks hampers operational efficiency, innovation and competition. Otherwise, a new financial crisis could be in the offing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Majority in Taiwan favors replacing nuke power with renewables
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 16:10:05 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of the population favors the notion of replacing nuclear power with renewable energy, while 50 percent think nuclear power should be maintained as an option, according to the results of a poll released Monday.
However, Taiwan Power Company, the sole supplier of electricity in Taiwan, said that renewable energy may not be a realistic path as the average consumer would complain about its much higher price.

In a telephone poll conducted by Shih Hsin University on randomly chosen citizens over the age of 20, it was found that 49.1 percent support nuclear power as one of the energy production options, while 69.9 percent favor replacing nuclear power with renewable and clean energy.

Some 73.8 percent of the respondents support industrial restructuring so as to help cut carbon dioxide emissions, according to the poll, which was commissioned by the Atomic Energy Council to determine people's awareness of and opinions on energy production and consumption.

Liang Shih-wu, director of the Shih Hsin public opinion poll center, said the survey results indicate that the Taiwan public generally agrees there is a need for alternative, cleaner energy, but opinions on the safety of nuclear power is evenly divided.
About one-third of the respondents consider nuclear power as "safe, " one-third think it is "unsafe, " and one-third have no opinion on the matter, he said.

Support for clean energy is a matter of theory and practicality. Although Taiwanese people in general support the development of renewable energy, they may find their electricity bills unaffordable once the much more expensive renewable energy is applied to replace traditional sources of electrical power, according to Hsiao Chin-yi, director of the Taipower Department of Public Services.
Besides, Hsiao said, Taipower encountered opposition or resistance by local residents when it tried to establish facilities for solar power or wind power.

Meanwhile, Yang Chao-yueh, an associate professor at National Taiwan University's Institute of Oceanography, said the global share of nuclear power has been dwindling steadily. A German research team has found that global deposits of uranium -- the raw material used for nuclear power -- are enough to last no more than 40 years for use by nuclear power plants around the world, he said.
"With such prospects, it is not worth pursuing nuclear power generation in Taiwan at any cost," Yang added.
The survey conducted in November collected 517 valid samples, and had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of 4.3 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Investment protection, security on cross-strait agenda after ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 16:22:53 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Negotiations between Taiwan and China will move on to the issues of investment protection and security after the signing of a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Monday.

Taiwan's policy and negotiation priority has always been "economics first, politics second, " which is why it intends to sign the ECFA with China before anything else, said James Chang, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of Information and Cultural Affairs.

"After the ECFA is signed, both sides will begin an even more difficult and sophisticated part of talks. The new phase of negotiation is expected to touch upon various issues such as investment protection and security, which includes the missiles deployed on China's southeastern coast, as well as anti-terrorism measures," he said.
Chang made the remarks while briefing the media after the ministry briefed around 70 foreign representatives in Taiwan on the results of the fourth round of cross-strait talks.

Taiwan and China both intend to focus on economic issues at present as Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) President Chen Yunlin made it very clear in the talks that "political discussions are not an urgent issue right now, " Chang said.
Once the ECFA is signed, the new phase of negotiations will not be limited to politics.
Taiwan has always called for China to remove its missiles aimed at the country in order to reduce cross-strait tension and convince the people of Taiwan of China's goodwill.
Meanwhile, investment protection is a serious concern of Taiwanese businessmen in China, some of whom have faced legal problems or have suffered operating losses or various forms of fraud in China.
Taiwan has been doing its best since President Ma Ying-jeou took office in 2008 to improve cross-strait relations, Deputy Foreign Minister Shen Lyu-shun told the foreign representatives.

"One side-effect of improved cross-strait relations is the enlargement of Taiwan's international space, " Shen said, citing Taiwan's participation in the World Health Assembly, the Government Procurement Agreement, and high-level representation in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum as examples.

DOC.HEADLINE: Draft bill of Hakka Basic Law reviewed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 16:59:49 (By Teresa Ueng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A draft bill of the Hakka Basic Law was reviewed by a Legislative Yuan committee Monday, paving the way for the zoning of special Hakka areas in which the unique Hakka language and culture can be conserved and promoted systematically.

Welcoming the review of the draft bill, Council for Hakka Affairs (CHA) Minister Huang Yu-cheng noted that Article 6 -- the centerpiece of the bill -- stipulates that the CHA will zone cities and townships as Hakka areas so long as at least 33 percent of the population there are of Hakka descent.
"The Hakka dialect will also be designated as the official language in those areas," Huang said.
A total of 61 townships around the country are expected to be zoned as Hakka areas as a result of that stipulation, he continued.

The Hakka, which translates as "guest families" in Cantonese, comprise a unique ethnic group of Han Chinese who fled famine and war in central China in past centuries and eventually settled in southern and eastern China, predominantly in the provinces of Guangdong, Jiangxi, Fujian and Taiwan.
A 2008 CHA survey found that Taiwan's Hakka population -- using a broad definition of the term -- accounts for 25.6 percent of the total population.
Huang also said the CHA will begin a nationwide census from 2010 to enable the government to better grasp the situation of the Hakka people in Taiwan. The census is scheduled to be completed in 2011.

He quoted the latest tallies compiled by the CHA as indicating that the total number of Hakka people in Taiwan ranges from 3.10 million to 5.87 million, depending on whether a narrow or broad definition of the term is employed.
Most of the country's Hakka people are concentrated in the northern counties of Hsinchu, Miaoli and Taoyuan, and in the southern county of Pingtung.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Good call by Ma

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou was right to reject offers by three "pan-blue" bigwigs to separately host dinners for top Chinese negotiator Chen Yunlin during his just- concluded visit to Taiwan.

No matter how high their political statures, Lien Chan, James Soong and Wu Poh- hsiung should not have tried to meddle with the biannual high-level cross-Taiwan Strait talks, because they no longer hold any government positions.
Gone are their days of power. Now is Ma's turn. They needed to respect Ma's decision made out of consideration of public sentiment.

Had they entertained Chen, it would have undermined the Ma administration's efforts to emphasize the government-to-government nature of the talks between Chen and his Taiwanese counterpart Chiang Pin-kung.

Given the aversion of Taiwan's people to China's attempts to belittle Taiwan's sovereign status and downgrade cross-strait engagements as party-to-party dealings, their high-profile appearance during Chen's visit would have only served Beijing's goal and even affected the legitimacy of the three agreements signed during Chen's Dec. 21-25 visit.

Many people, particularly pro-independence activists, may have suspected that secret deals were being struck behind closed doors, while others would have had the impression that the trio were pulling the strings from behind the scenes, an image that could have weakened Ma's leadership.
For the country's overall interests, Ma was right to reject the trio's attempts to play a role in Chen's visit, and he need not feel apologetic about it at all.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's 8th national park opens
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 17:56:46 (By Hsien Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The establishment of Taiwan's eighth national park, Taijiang National Park in Tainan, was described by Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu at its opening Monday as an important landmark in Taiwan's environmental conservation efforts.
Speaking in fluent Taiwanese, Chu said the park incorporates environmental conservation efforts into a local salt-production industry.

In addition, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih noted that a plan to build an industrial zone in Binnan in Tainan County where flocks of endangered black- faced spoonbills usually overwinter, was vetoed because the bird protection zone is now part of the park.

The 39,310-hectare park contains many valuable ecological areas, such as wetlands and lagoons, and is the home to some 100 precious species, including black-faced spoonbills and mangroves, according to Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah, who was among the many political figures from across party lines at the opening ceremony.
The national park project, initiated by the local government and supported by the central government, was made possible with the concerted efforts of various government agencies, Jiang said.

According to Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, the park is part of his plans to develop Tainan into an international city characterized by abundant cultural assets, pioneering technology and special ecology.

Located along a coastal area that straddles Tainan City and Tainan County in southern Taiwan, the park has a total area of 39,310 hectares, 4,905 hectares of which is on land and 34,405 hectares at sea, according to the MOI.

The opening ceremony was attended by the four above-mentioned central local government chiefs and other political figures, all of whom are considered as potential candidates for upcoming elections in five municipalities. They included Presidential Office Secretary-General Liao Liou-yi and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lai Ching-teh.

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close higher on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 18:11:21 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 84.90 points, or 1.06 percent, to close at 8,057.49.
The local bourse opened at 8,007.54 and traded between 8,079.62, and 8,007.54 during the session.
A total of 5.3 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$139.57 billion (US$4.32 billion).

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares rising the most at 3 percent, banking and financial issues gaining 2.3 percent, cement shares increasing 1.4 percent and foodstuff issues advancing 1 percent.
Plastics and chemicals gained 0.9 percent, electronics and machinery issues, as well as textile stocks, both increased 0.8 percent, and paper and pulp shares advanced 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,843 to 988, with 256 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign institutional investors were net buyers of NT$10.3 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei FOREX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 18:15:05 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.020 to close at NT$32.294.
A total of US$511 million changed hands during the day's trading.
The U.S. currency opened at NT$32.324 and fluctuated between NT$32.225 and NT$32.324.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to revise law to increase compensation for vaccine victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 18:30:14 (By Chen Li-ting, Vicky Hsu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Monday that it is considering a revision to the law to raise the compensation for victims who suffer adverse reactions to the H1N1 vaccine.

DOH officials made the remarks during a legislative committee meeting after several recent cases, including deaths and miscarriages, that some have attributed to the H1N1 vaccine, began to impact public interest in getting the shots.
Legislator Chen chiech-ju of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that in South Korea, the compensation for death attributed to vaccine is the equivalent of NT$20 million (US$619,540).
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lo Shu-lei said the authorities should pay out at least NT$10 million for each death attributed to the vaccine.

"At present, death related to vaccine gets just NT$2 million, "said Steve H.S. Kuo, director of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the DOH. He added that the DOH is considering raising the amount.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang also pointed out that the regulation has been in place for 20 years and needs to be reviewed, although he noted that "the DOH will not have a final say on the matter, which will require a law revision."
Kuo said that the DOH convened a three-day meeting starting that day to review the vaccine relief system in a bid to regain public confidence.
He noted that the CDC is concerned about the declining interest in getting immunized, down from an average of 150,000 who were getting the shots before the panic took hold.

On reports that military personnel have been given expired seasonal flu shots, Yaung said the DOH is concerned about the matter and that the Medical Affairs Bureau under the Ministry of National Defense will address the matter.
According to Kuo, getting expired vaccine "will not pose a health hazard, " but is "an administrative error" that should be explained by the Medical Affairs Bureau.
Meanwhile that same day, an H1N1 self-assistance association formed by the private sector was launched, with DPP Legislator Chen Ying named as convener.
Chen announced the telephone number 04-24724421 for members of the public to report any symptoms after being given H1N1 shots.
Chen noted that the CDC has set up a 1922 consultation hotline for the same purpose, but said that if the public do not want to call that number, it can call the association instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Draft bill allowing referendum on planned expressway turned back
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 18:39:59 (By Andrew Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Hualien County Council on Monday decided against putting on its agenda a draft bill that would allow the local government to hold a referendum on the construction of an expressway connecting the underdeveloped eastern county with Taiwan's more prosperous areas.

The council made its decision after newly elected Hualien County Magistrate Fu Kun-chi said his administration will seek to hold a referendum if the Cabinet continues to ignore the support among most Hualien residents for the expressway.

Unfazed by the setback, the Hualien County government vowed to continue its efforts to create a legal basis for the planned referendum and said it would submit the bill to the council again in January.

Fu has long supported building an expressway to replace the existing Suhua highway, the main single-lane artery connecting Yilan County and Hualien City that cuts through coastal cliffs and is vulnerable to landslides.
The government has yet to approve the expressway, however, in part because of environmental opposition.

The county council explained that its decision Monday was not based on the substance of the controversy but on technical grounds. County Councilor Wang Yen-mei said Fu's administration failed to make the request by the required deadline.
It was the third time the council had turned back the draft bill, which was approved by the county government in 2005 but shelved by the county council later that year.
The bill was again submitted to be put on the agenda of a provisional session of the county council in May 2007, but the request was again rejected.

Fu, who was elected county magistrate earlier this month, criticized the central government's plans to upgrade the existing Suhua highway instead of building a new expressway linking northeastern Taiwan and the county.
It is the government's job to repair dilapidated highways, Fu said Monday, adding that the expressway was part of a long-planned central government project to construct an islandwide freeway network.
"Such a project should not be withdrawn for any such reason, or because of someone's opposition, " he said, urging the Executive Yuan to pay heed to the wishes of Hualien's residents.
If the Cabinet continues to ignore the residents' views on this matter, the county government would consider holding a referendum on the construction of the expressway, Hu added.

The controversial Suao-Hualien expressway was proposed more than a decade ago, but has faced strong opposition by environmental experts and activists who believe that it will destroy the scenic beauty, flora, fauna and ecological balance in the area.
Proponents of the expressway have argued that it will boost the economy in eastern Taiwan, a region that is relatively underdeveloped and consists mostly of farming townships.

Fu won the Dec. 5 local election as an independent candidate with 56 percent of the vote. One of his campaign slogans was "giving the Hualien people a safe road home." Fu's big victory was seen as a reflection of the people's desire for an efficient and safe transport artery that would open up the mountain-ringed county.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has decided to shelve its plans for the expressway, and will instead try to fix the Suhua highway, replacing dangerous sections along coastal cliffs with tunnels.
However, the MOTC has not ruled out the possibility of "upgrading" the Suhua highway into an expressway in the future, once there is public consensus in support of this plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: No timetable set for panel makers investing in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 18:51:50 (By Tang Pei-chun and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Monday that no timetable has been set for allowing local large-size flat-panel makers to set up panel factories in China and promised that any decision by the government on the issue will be in Taiwan's best interests.

Rebutting news reports the previous day that the government had concluded an inter-ministerial meeting and will conditionally allow the flat panel and semiconductor industries to invest more in China, Shih said that plan is still under discussion and has yet to be finalized and approved by the Executive Yuan.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Pan Meng-an accused the ministry Dec. 26 of making the issue public before a final decision had been made, a move that he said sent several companies' shares skyrocketing. He also lambasted the ministry for indirectly fuelling speculation in the local stock market.

For example, he said, Wintek Corp, the nation's biggest mobile phone panel maker, and LED maker Para Light Electronics Co. advanced by their 7 percent daily maximum limits to NT$25.55 and NT$253.5, respectively.
Reacting to Pan's criticism, Shih argued that as stock prices are highly sensitive to the issue, the ministry has been meticulously assessing the liberalization plan.
Asked when a final decision will be made, Shih said the situation will become more clear over the next two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: US$30 billion in Chinese funds may enter Taiwan after MOU: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 19:24:07 (By Chao-fen Kao and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: China's qualified domestic institutional investors (QDIIs) will be allowed to invest up to an estimated US$30 billion (NT$968 billion) in Taiwan's stock market, Taiwan's top financial regulator said Monday, 30 times more than was originally anticipated.

Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean Chen said the FSC will allow QDII funds approved by the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) , which have a combined investment quota of about US$30 billion, to invest in Taiwan once a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial regulatory cooperation between the two countries takes effect Jan. 16.
Just over one month ago, Chen said China's QDIIs would be allowed to invest up to 10 percent of their estimated US$10 billion in assets, or about NT$30 billion, in Taiwan's market.

China's securities regulator later told the FSC, however, that it would not impose the 10 percent maximum investment limit on investments in Taiwan's stock market, enabling the entire US$30 billion quota to theoretically be injected into Taiwan, according to FSC officials.
Chen said the FSC will discuss with other agencies and Taiwan's central bank whether to impose any upper limit on total QDII investment in the local bourse.

"We will set an upper limit for total investment (for the QDIIs) in the local stock market and for individual companies, " Chen said, while responding to questions from reporters following a legislative committee meeting.

Chen did not mention, however, whether the FSC will eventually allow Chinese QDIIs under a different regulatory regime -- those approved by the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC) -- with a total investment quota of about US$7.9 billion, to invest in the local stock market.

Under the MOU, which was signed Nov. 17 and was to take effect within 60 days, Taiwan and China will also work together to exchange and protect the confidentiality of information, establish a mechanism to deal with possible financial crises, and conduct financial examinations, according to the FSC.
Under existing regulations in China, Chinese QDIIs are only allowed to invest up to 3 percent of their assets in public and corporate bonds in regions that have not signed an MOU with China.
Twelve fund management and securities companies in China have been granted QDII licenses, though they are only operating nine funds so far.

As of the end of August, China's State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE) had granted these QDIIs combined investment quotas of US$33.57 billion, and a total investment of US$14.5 billion has already been made in overseas markets, according to SAFE statistics.
In the first three quarters of this year, the nine QDII funds rose an average of 43.4 percent, statistics show.

Analysts said increased investment from QDIIs is definitely a bullish factor for the local stock market in the medium to long term, and they expect leading electronics issues to benefit the most from Chinese QDII investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: Motor show models wear many hats

TEXT.P: Many of the photographers at Taiwan's largest auto show are aiming their cameras not just at models of concept cars but also at the show girls who survived a stringent selection process that began months ago to allow them to shake their stuff at the show.

Ann Chen, who is working for Suzuki during the Dec. 26-Jan. 3 biennial Taipei International Auto Show, said that unlike other types of show, clients exhibiting at the auto show started looking for models and showgirls much earlier.
This year, the process started as early as April.
Chen, who is also a model agent, said that the size of the new cars on show is one of the key factors in selecting models.
"Firms that plan to display large cars prefer tall girls, while those with small ones choose shorter ones, " she told the CNA Monday.

The preparation process for the auto show is also longer than other shows, Chen added. The screening process requested by clients started in July or August this year, compared with two weeks to two months of preparation for computer and other shows, she said.
Every screening interview is a "ruthless" process for the candidates, she said. "After the screening, you have to learn how to cheer yourself up and go for the next one if you fail to make the list."
At the auto show, the 18th of its kind, the models do not just stand there and smile.
They have to handle a variety of tasks. "Some need to know how to dance, some serve as emcees for activities, while others give away small gifts at the reception desks, " Chen said.
Chen, who wears a red wig and dresses up as a car-race girl along with seven colleagues, has to put on a 20-minute performance five times a day during weekdays and six times on the weekend.

Models at the auto show often outshine their peers at other shows, Chen continued, explaining that "the event takes place twice a year, so the car companies focus very much on the looks and temperament of the models."
Another key element in the presentation of models and showgirls is their costumes, which are tailor-made to go with the cars on display.

"Attention has to be paid to every little detail of the costumes. For example, the car logo must always be seen and visible in photos, no matter how the girls pose, " said Coraline Lin, the publicist for the event.
It costs NT$6,000 (about US$186) to NT$15,000 on average to hire a model for a day in Taiwan, according to Lin.
Nevertheless, not every car company uses models or showgirls as the principal means to help promote their products.
Firms such as Audi and Porsche prefer to appeal to visitors by focusing less on dancing showgirls and more on setting up VIP rooms where visitors can have a seat and enjoy a complimentary dessert.

This tactic might work on Jean-Francois Fort, a French car fan who was surprised to see so many people pointing their cameras at the girls rather than at the cars, and the long line of people waiting to have their photo taken with the girls.
"They should at least take some photos of the cars," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Driven by speculation, property rebound may not last: scholar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 20:47:22 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The domestic property market showed signs of recovery in the third quarter after a year-long recession, but a scholar cautioned Friday that the rebound has been driven by speculation and may be a short-lived phenomenon.

"Excess capital and high expectations are creating conditions that could cast a cloud over the market in the future, " said Chin-oh Chang, a professor in National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics.

"Excess capital could push interest rates higher while high expectations have led to an oversupply of new developments and inventory, " he said, referring to a potential move by the central bank to soak up liquidity in the property and equity markets by raising basic rates.

According to a report released by the Architecture and Building Research Institute under the Ministry of the Interior, the composite monitoring indicator for the domestic real estate market reached 10 points to qualify for a yellow- blue light, signaling that the market may finally be leaving the recession behind.
It marked the first time in a year that the property market has emerged from its slump after showing a gloomy blue light for four straight quarters.
Analyzing the report, Chang said the market rebound was mainly spurred by a substantial rise in investment, but he cautioned that the market reversal could be merely an ephemeral phenomenon.
"Further observation is needed to determine whether the upward trend can be sustained," Chang said.

The third-quarter property market performance rose three points from the previous quarter, with the transaction volume index gaining one point and that of the total acreage of construction licenses issued during the three-month period up two points.
The utilization rate of residential housing and the standard unit price of new development projects remaining unchanged.

Citing the report, Chang said the increase in the number of approved construction licenses during the quarter was most noteworthy because it will create pressure in the future to move inventory and lead to a new wave of buyers saddled with mortgage payments.
"The upward trend indicates that housing buyers will face payment pressure when construction is completed, " Chang said, predicting that the pressure will be most conspicuous in northern Taiwan.

In retrospect, Chang said, the local housing market was stagnant in the first quarter, turned a bit better in the second quarter and then gathered more momentum in the third quarter, during which transaction volume increased and prices stabilized, except for some places where prices posted mild declines.

As to future market prospects, Chang said, several factors may contribute to market stability, including a general economic recovery, a rebound in consumer confidence, "one house in lifetime" land increment tax incentives, and the anticipated signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement.
Negative factors cited included lower than expected Chinese investment in the local property market, high unemployment and a high ratio of unoccupied office space.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma spokesman denies report of checkbook diplomacy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 21:01:00 (By Lee Shu-hua, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Responding to a report accusing Taiwan of continuing to engage in "checkbook diplomacy, " President Ma Ying-jeou's spokesman said the president has always been opposed to the practice and financial aid lacking transparency.
President Ma has reiterated since assuming office in 2008 his objection to conducting checkbook diplomacy, which relies on funds whose purposes and recipients are unclear, spokesman Wang Yu-chi said.
Ma, however, will not reject plans to aid allies if "the purpose is proper and clearly-detailed, and helps promote friendship, " Wang added.

The spokesman's remarks came after a local newspaper on Monday cited criticism in a mainstream Panamanian media of Taiwan's "traditional checkbook diplomacy, " which claimed that Taiwan donated aircraft to Panama this year worth US$40 million.
In a report Dec. 27, the Panamanian newspaper "La Prensa" described the aircraft as a gift to please Panama's new President Ricardo Martinelli, who did not assume office until July.
That raised the concerns of lawmakers of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who voiced suspicions that the donation may have involved corruption.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang told the suspicious lawmakers, however, that it was the new Panamanian government that asked Taiwan for help in replacing rescue helicopters that needed to be replaced.

After evaluating Panama's need for such aircraft to transport sick people living on remote areas to urban hospitals, the government decided to make the donation, Yang said, noting that a public ceremony was even held to mark the aid handover.
The aid program was "totally open to the public and transparent" and met the president's principles on foreign aid, he stressed.
Yang said he "believes there was no corruption involved" in the case but added that he would still look into the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cultural agency plans regular performances to boost local tourism
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 21:05:37 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs will work with local governments and groups to stage performances on a regular basis around Taiwan over the next six months to appeal to tourists visiting Taiwan, CCA Minister Emile Sheng said Monday.

The CCA devised the plan in part to stimulate local cultural and creative industries, which have been designated as one of six emerging sectors for priority development, and also to help boost local tourism, Sheng said.

The CCA is also considering incorporating the performance schedules into travel itineraries prepared by local travel agencies for inbound tourists to enable them to visit Taiwan's popular tourist destinations and enjoy performances staged by local groups at the same time, Sheng added.

He said he plans to make programs with local characteristics -- to be provided by various city and county governments -- part of the activities for the 100th anniversary celebrations of the Republic of China in 2011 and show visitors from home and abroad Taiwan's cultural power.

Meanwhile, to grab more international attention, the agency is also planning to transform the government-funded Formosa festival activities, which have been staged separately by various cities and counties around the country, into a bigger, national festival that combines tourism, arts and travel, Sheng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Big enterprises can invite up to 800 Chinese to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 21:48:11 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Monday that major enterprises with annual turnover of NT$1 billion can double the number of Chinese businessmen they invite to Taiwan to 800.
The new measure is aimed at giving impetus to the nation's convention and exhibition industry, the ministry said.

Under existing regulations, domestic enterprises with turnover between NT$10 million and NT$30 million can invite 45 Chinese nationals to visit Taiwan per year, while those with turnover exceeding NT$30 million can invite 400 Chinese nationals.

But to give fresh impetus to cross-strait trade and get more Chinese businessmen to visit Taiwan, the National Immigration Agency and the MOEA plan to let major businesses with annual turnover exceeding NT$1 billion to double the number of Chinese they can invite to 800.
The measure is expected to be put into practice next year.

The Board of Foreign Trade under the MOEA began this year to promote a four-year exhibition and convention industry development plan because of its high potential for added value in terms of benefits for the peripheral tourism, hospitality and insurance sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial services to gain if included in early harvest list: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 21:51:39 (By Chao-fen Kao and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top financial regulator said Monday that Taiwan will benefit if the financial services sector is included in the early harvest program of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said that signing the ECFA with China is one way to prevent Taiwan's financial services sector from being treated unfavorably.
"If the signing of the ECFA is delayed, I will be worried and sorry about it," he said.

The ECFA is on the agenda of the next formal round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks scheduled for next spring. In negotiations leading up to that meeting, representatives of the two sides will exchange lists of products they hope will be covered by an early harvest program under the trade deal.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Monday that there will be about 500 items included in the early harvest list, mostly involving the petrochemical, textile, machinery and auto parts industries.
Shih also noted that formal ECFA negotiations will be held in January at the earliest.
Some experts have said that including the financial services sector in the early harvest program will bring about reciprocal market openings while not violating WTO guidelines and regulations.
Meanwhile, Chen also said the two sides have not yet discussed the number of Chinese banks that will be allowed to enter Taiwan's market.
It is not appropriate to set the number in the regulations, said Chen, when questioned by ruling Kuomingtang (KMT) Legislator Sun Ta-chien at a legislative committee hearing.

Chen said signing the ECFA is like building a highway, with the question of how many banks will be allowed to enter Taiwan to be controlled similar to the way traffic volume is controlled by regulating access on entry ramps.

Under the memorandum of understanding (MOU) on financial regulatory cooperation sealed by both sides in November, which will take effect Jan. 16, each side will be allowed to set up bank branches in the other's territory and once further agreements are signed, could allow each side to invest in the other's banks.

Chen mentioned last month that during the first stage after the MOU takes effect, Chinese banks will only be allowed to set up branches in Taiwan. The FSC will need to see how negotiations on the ECFA's early harvest list progress before revising related regulations to further open the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's wage levels expected to rebound in 2nd half of 2010: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 22:10:02 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan's economic recovery has continued gathering pace, wage levels are not expected to rise until the second half of next year, an official said Monday.
"Our wage levels are indeed unusually low as they have been declining for several years, " said Hu Chung-ying, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

He attributed the steady fall to a combination of factors, including ever slimmer profits from electronic OEM orders, mounting competition from cheap Chinese goods and changes in Taiwan's industrial structure.

Thanks to a global economic recovery, the CEPD's overall monitoring indicator for Taiwan's economic climate flashed a "yellow-red" light in November, marking the first time in 25 months that the country's economic activity has been seen as heating up.
With Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) announcing last week a 15 percent pay raise for its employees from next year, many wage earners are expecting similar good news.
Hu said if local companies post stable gains as the global economic recovery gains momentum, they will more likely raise their employees' salaries or wages.
"Judging from the current trend, domestic wage levels will rebound in the second half of 2010," he predicted.
Hu said the electronics sector is expected to lead the way in raising pay levels, followed by the financial sector.
Conventional industries and the public sector may lag behind in adjusting pay rates, he predicted.
The CEPD official said rising pay levels are critical to economic growth because only with gains in income will private consumption see substantial growth.

That may take some time, however, according to Hu, who observed that wage levels are generally adjusted only after the economy bottoms out of a recession and grows steadily for two consecutive quarters.

Noting that Taiwan's economy began to show signs of recovery in October, when the monitoring indicator flashed a green light to signal stable growth, Chang said November's "yellow-red" light indicated that the economy's recovery is on a steady track.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma to tour Taiwan to thank voters for their support: KMT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 22:41:15 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou, in his capacity as Kuomintang chairman, will tour Taiwan early next year to thank voters for their support in the Dec. 5 local elections and stump for party candidates in the upcoming legislative by-elections, a KMT official said Monday.

Ma will first visit Taoyuan, Taitung and Taichung counties, where legislative by-elections are to be held Jan. 9, to drum up support for KMT candidates, said Lee Chien-jung, the head of the party's Culture and Communications Committee, after a KMT meeting hosted by KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung.
During his tour, which will last until Feb. 21, 2010, Ma will meet with KMT supporters at New Year's gatherings organized by the KMT in various cities and counties around Taiwan, Lee added.
KMT legislative whip Lu Hsueh-chang said during the meeting that the caucus will convene a delegation to campaign for KMT hopefuls in the by-elections, according to Lee.

Under the KMT plan, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-Pyng and Deputy Speaker Tseng Yung- chuan and Premier Wu Den-yih will organize election activities for Kuang Li-chen, who will represent the KMT in the Taitung County legislative by- election, Lee said.
She hopes to fill the seat vacated by Justin Huang, who was elected Taitung County magistrate on Dec. 5.
KMT Honorary Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu and Taoyuan County Magistrate John Chih-yang Wu will lend their support to Chen Li-ling, the KMT's candidate in Taoyuan County.
The seat was previously held by the party's Liao Cheng-ching, whose election was invalidated after he was convicted of vote-buying.

Meanwhile, local KMT grassroots leaders will throw their support behind Yu Wen- chin, the mayor of Taiping in Taichung County, who will run there for the seat previously held by the KMT's Chiang Lien-fu, Lee said.
King himself will organize and coordinate all campaign activities leading up to election day, Lee added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four detained Taiwanese fishermen return from Myanmar
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Dec. 28 (CNA) 12/28/09 22:49:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Four Taiwanese fishermen detained by Myanmar's military for more than a month were released with the assistance of Taiwanese businessmen after paying a fine and returned to Taiwan on a China Airlines flight Monday evening, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Hsu Kuo-yi and Huang Shih-cheng, skippers of the Donggang-based fishing boats Ho Yi Fa and Ming Cheng Yi respectively, and Chen Wan-yi and Pan Chih-nan, crew members the Taiwanese fishing boats Hung Fa 128 and Ching Ming Tsai 130, were detained by Myanmar authorities for entering the country's waters without permission.

The four were sentenced by a Myanmar court to an unspecified jail term and fined on Dec. 12. They were released after paying the fine, set at US$200 for each skipper and US$20 per crew member, but the fishing boats were confiscated by Myanmar.

The families said they were thrilled by the news of the four men's release, but Hsu's wife could not help lamenting over losing the Ho Yi Fa, which cost them over NT$10 million to build 10 years ago and an additional NT$3 million that was invested in the vessel before its most recent fishing mission.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs was notified in late November that four Taiwanese fishing trawlers were captured by the Myanmar military.
After confirming that there were four Taiwanese among the crew members, the ministry went through various channels to communicate with the Myanmar authorities and ensure the fishermen's safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, Dec. 29, or the 14th day of the 11th month of the Year of the Ox according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1808: Andrew Johnson, the 17th president of the United States, is born. He took over as president after Abraham Lincoln was assassinated.
1857: British and French troops take Canton, southern China.
1911: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected the first president of Asia's first democratic republic -- the Republic of China.
1921: The United States, Britain, France, Italy and Japan sign the Washington Treaty to limit naval armaments.
1924: John Davidson Rockefeller, an American oil magnate who amassed a great fortune through the Standard Oil Company, donates US$1 million to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.
1928: Chang Hsueh-liang pledges allegiance to the national government, thereby leading to the unification of China.
1931: The national government is reorganized, with Lin Sen as the new chairman.
1934: Japan renounces the Washington Treaty limiting naval armaments.
1938: Wang Ching-wei, who deserted the ROC government and left Chungking for Kunming on Dec. 18, issues a statement in Hanoi, Vietnam, advocating the termination of the War of Resistance against Japan and seeking peace with Japan.
1940: German bombers inflict the greatest damage on London since the Great Fire of 1666.
1948: The Executive Yuan appoints Chen Cheng as governor of the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1953: The Legislative Yuan revises the quorum for the National Assembly from the original one-half (1,523) to one-third (1,015) of the total number of members.
1968: The Yangtze River Bridge near Nanking, built by the Communist Chinese, is inaugurated.
1975: Some 100 scholars from Taiwan and abroad attend the Conference on Population and Economic Development. President Yen Chia-kan addresses the opening ceremony.
1980: Hsieh Kuo-cheng, Taiwan's so-called "father of baseball," dies at the age of 69.
1981: U.S. President Ronald Reagan announces a program of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of its alleged role in the imposition of martial law in Poland.
1981: Lee Tien-hui, who earned a mainland scholarship to study in the United States, defects and holds a press conference in Taipei.
1984: India's Congress-I Party, headed by Ragiv Gandhi, wins a landslide victory in India's general elections.
1986: Harold Macmillan, British politician, dies at the age of 92. As prime minister, he presided over the break-up of the British Empire.
1989: Vaclav Havel, a dissident Czechoslovakian philosopher, becomes the first elected non-Communist president without opposition.
1989: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees battle with riot police in Hong Kong.
1994: The first squadron of Ching-kuo indigenous defense fighters is officially commissioned, upgrading the combat ability of the ROC Air Force and demonstrating the initial results of local research and development.
1995: The Executive Yuan approves revised regulations governing the establishment of the Central News Agency.
1996: A peace accord is signed between the Guatemalan government and guerrilla leaders, ending 38 years of civil conflict and bringing Central America's last remaining and longest civil war to a close.
1999: Former ROC Minister of Education Lin Ching-chiang dies of respiratory failure at the age of 60.
2000: Premier Chang Chun-hsiung says that the government plans to spend NT$65.5 billion to create a total of 290,000 job opportunities within a year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is the moral life of a neighborhood which constitutes its excellence. He is not an intelligent man, who, in choosing his residence, does not select a place with a moral surrounding."
